question:
44252852      <row Id="44252852" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44253556" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44252852" CreationDate="2017-05-30T04:40:58.283" Score="4" Body="<p>Use a <a href="http://godoc.org/sync#Mutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer">mutex</a> to protect the map. A mutex is often simpler than using channels &amp; goroutines to protect a resource.</p>

<pre><code>var (
  mu sync.Mutex
  cache = make(map[string]*SessionData)
)

func GetSessionFromCache(sessTkn string) *SessionData {
  mu.Lock()
  defer mu.Unlock()
  sd := cache[sessTkn]
  if sd != nil {
      return sd
  }
  sd := &amp;SessionData{
     // initialize new value here
  }
  cache[sessTkn] = sd
  return sd
}
</code></pre>

<p>Use it like this:</p>

<pre><code>sd := session.GetSessionFromCache(sessTkn) 
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-05-30T15:19:15.350" LastActivityDate="2017-05-30T15:19:15.350" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44255814      <row Id="44255814" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44256314" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44255814" CreationDate="2017-05-30T07:40:19.777" Score="6" Body="<p>You may do concurrent processing by modifying your <code>visit()</code> function to not go into subfolders, but launch a new goroutine for each subfolder.</p>

<p>In order to do that, return the special <code>filepath.SkipDir</code> error from your <code>visit()</code> function if the entry is a directory. Don't forget to check if the <code>path</code> inside <code>visit()</code> is the subfolder the goroutine is ought to process, because that is also passed to <code>visit()</code>, and without this check you would launch goroutines endlessly for the initial folder.</p>

<p>Also you will need some kind of "counter" of how many goroutines are still working in the background, for that you may use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sync.WaitGroup</code></a>.</p>

<p>Here's a simple implementation of this:</p>

<pre><code>var wg sync.WaitGroup

func walkDir(dir string) {
    defer wg.Done()

    visit := func(path string, f os.FileInfo, err error) error {
        if f.IsDir() &amp;&amp; path != dir {
            wg.Add(1)
            go walkDir(path)
            return filepath.SkipDir
        }
        if f.Mode().IsRegular() {
            fmt.Printf("Visited: %s File name: %s Size: %d bytes\n",
                path, f.Name(), f.Size())
        }
        return nil
    }

    filepath.Walk(dir, visit)
}

func main() {
    flag.Parse()
    root := "folder/to/walk" //flag.Arg(0)

    wg.Add(1)
    walkDir(root)
    wg.Wait()
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Some notes:</strong></p>

<p>Depending on the "distribution" of files among subfolders, this may not fully utilize your CPU / storage, as if for example 99% of all the files are in one subfolder, that goroutine will still take the majority of time.</p>

<p>Also note that <code>fmt.Printf()</code> calls are serialized, so that will also slow down the process. I assume this was just an example, and in reality you will do some kind of processing / statistics in-memory. Don't forget to also protect concurrent access to variables accessed from your <code>visit()</code> function.</p>

<p>Don't worry about the high number of subfolders. It is normal and the Go runtime is capable of handling even hundreds of thousands of goroutines.</p>

<p>Also note that most likely the performance bottleneck will be your storage / hard disk speed, so you may not gain the performance you wish. After a certain point (your hard disk limit), you won't be able to improve performance.</p>

<p>Also launching a new goroutine for each subfolder may not be optimal, it may be that you get better performance by limiting the number of goroutines walking your folders. For that, check out and use a worker pool:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38170852/is-this-an-idiomatic-worker-thread-pool-in-go/38172204#38172204">Is this an idiomatic worker thread pool in Go?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-05-30T07:52:21.813" LastActivityDate="2017-05-30T07:52:21.813" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44257729      <row Id="44257729" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44257987" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44257729" CreationDate="2017-05-30T09:08:19.570" Score="3" Body="<p><code>consensus.Block</code> and <code>chain.Block</code> are two separate types but since you are embeddding <code>chain.Block</code> in <code>consensus.Block</code>, you can access one from another.</p>

<p>Just pass <code>consensus.Block</code> in <code>AddBlockToChain()</code>:</p>

<pre><code>`func AddBlockToChain(block consensus.Block)`
</code></pre>

<p>and then access it by: <code>block.Block</code></p>

<p>Example:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type ChainBlock struct {
    id int
}

type ConsensusBlock struct {
    ChainBlock
    idCons int
}

func printChainBlockId(consBlock ConsensusBlock) {
    fmt.Println(consBlock.ChainBlock.id)
}

func main() {
    test := ConsensusBlock{
        ChainBlock: ChainBlock{
            id: 42,
        },
        idCons: 44,
    }

    printChainBlockId(admin)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="963881" LastActivityDate="2017-05-30T09:08:19.570" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44257522      <row Id="44257522" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44258164" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44257522" CreationDate="2017-05-30T09:15:48.733" Score="2" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/unsafe/#Sizeof" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>unsafe.SizeOf()</code></a> and <code>reflect.Type.Size()</code> only return the size of the passed value without recursively traversing the data structure and adding sizes of pointed values.</p>

<p>The slice is relatively a simple struct: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#SliceHeader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect.SliceHeader</code></a>, and since we know it references a backing array, we can easily compute its size "manually", e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>s := make([]int32, 1000)

fmt.Println("Size of []int32:", unsafe.Sizeof(s))
fmt.Println("Size of [1000]int32:", unsafe.Sizeof([1000]int32{}))
fmt.Println("Real size of s:", unsafe.Sizeof(s)+unsafe.Sizeof([1000]int32{}))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/r2ejk8JPx2" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Size of []int32: 12
Size of [1000]int32: 4000
Real size of s: 4012
</code></pre>

<p>Maps are a lot more complex data structures, I won't go into details, but check out this question+answer: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31847549/golang-computing-the-memory-footprint-or-byte-length-of-a-map">Golang: computing the memory footprint (or byte length) of a map</a></p>

<p>If you want "real" numbers, you may take advantage of the testing tool of Go, which can also perform memory benchmarking. Pass the <code>-benchmem</code> argument, and inside the benchmark function allocate only whose memory you want to measure:</p>

<pre><code>func BenchmarkSlice100(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i &lt; b.N; i++ { getSlice(100) }
}
func BenchmarkSlice1000(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i &lt; b.N; i++ { getSlice(1000) }
}
func BenchmarkSlice10000(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i &lt; b.N; i++ { getSlice(10000) }
}
func BenchmarkMap100(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i &lt; b.N; i++ { getMap(100) }
}
func BenchmarkMap1000(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i &lt; b.N; i++ { getMap(1000) }
}
func BenchmarkMap10000(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i &lt; b.N; i++ { getMap(10000) }
}
</code></pre>

<p>(Remove the timing and printing calls from <code>getSlice()</code> and <code>getMap()</code> of course.)</p>

<p>Running with</p>

<pre><code>go test -bench . -benchmem
</code></pre>

<p>Output is:</p>

<pre><code>BenchmarkSlice100-4    3000000        471 ns/op        1792 B/op      1 allocs/op
BenchmarkSlice1000-4    300000       3944 ns/op       16384 B/op      1 allocs/op
BenchmarkSlice10000-4    50000      39293 ns/op      163840 B/op      1 allocs/op
BenchmarkMap100-4       200000      11651 ns/op        2843 B/op      9 allocs/op
BenchmarkMap1000-4       10000     111040 ns/op       41823 B/op     12 allocs/op
BenchmarkMap10000-4       1000    1152011 ns/op      315450 B/op    135 allocs/op
</code></pre>

<p><code>B/op</code> values tell you how many bytes were allocated per op. <code>allocs/op</code> tells how many (distinct) memory allocations occurred per op.</p>

<p>On my 64-bit architecture (where the size of <code>int</code> is 8 bytes) it tells that the size of a slice having 2000 elements is roughly 16 KB (in line with 2000 * 8 bytes). A map with 1000 <code>int-int</code> pairs required approximately to allocate 42 KB.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-05-30T09:34:26.243" LastActivityDate="2017-05-30T09:34:26.243" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44263381      <row Id="44263381" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44263573" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44263381" CreationDate="2017-05-30T13:24:58.237" Score="3" Body="<p>Because the literal <code>0</code> is not the same type. If you do:</p>

<pre><code>if v != int32(0) {
</code></pre>

<p>When the value is an <code>int32</code>, it works as expected. Unfortunately, you're combining all the int types in a single case, which will make this difficult/unwieldy to handle correctly. You could probably work something out using reflection to compare the value against the zero value for its type at runtime, using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#Zero" rel="nofollow noreferrer">reflect.Zero</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-05-30T13:24:58.237" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44263835      <row Id="44263835" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44265022" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44263835" CreationDate="2017-05-30T14:28:06.080" Score="0" Body="<p>It is not the problem of <code>encoding/base64</code>. When using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Reader</code></a>, it's not guaranteed that number of bytes read exactly equal to the buffer size (i.e. <code>blocksize</code> in your example code). The documentation states:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Read reads up to len(p) bytes into p. It returns the number of bytes read (0 &lt;= n &lt;= len(p)) and any error encountered. Even if Read returns n &lt; len(p), it may use all of p as scratch space during the call. If some data is available but not len(p) bytes, Read conventionally returns what is available instead of waiting for more. </p>
</blockquote>

<p>In your example, change <code>PrintBytes</code> to </p>

<pre><code>func PrintBytes(reader io.Reader, blocksize int) {
    block := make([]byte, blocksize)
    for {
        n, err := reader.Read(block)
        //Process the data if n &gt; 0, even when err != nil
        if n &gt; 0 {
            log.Printf("%x\tblocksize=%d", block[:n], blocksize)
        }

        //Check for error
        if err != nil {
            if err != io.EOF {
                log.Fatal(err)
            } else if err == io.EOF {
                break
            }
        } else if n == 0 {
            //Considered as nothing happened
            log.Printf("WARNING: read return 0,nil")
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Update:</strong></p>

<p>Correct usage of <code>io.Reader</code>, modify code to always process the data if <code>n &gt; 0</code> even when error occurs. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-05-30T15:06:34.753" LastActivityDate="2017-05-30T15:06:34.753" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44148184      <row Id="44148184" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44274727" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44148184" CreationDate="2017-05-31T02:35:03.317" Score="2" Body="<p>From the VTune traces I can conclude that TBB queue does not sleep, spending a lot time spinning, while Go version has light green areas indicating threads sleeping on OS synchronization. Why is it better? Usually, it indicates that you have oversubscription on your machine, thus communication through OS pays off.
So, do you oversubscribe it? If yes, I'd say this is rather expected behavior which fits into philosophy of corresponding libraries. TBB is designed for compute parallelism, it does not handle IO tasks well while playing against oversubscription. Go is designed exactly for IO tasks, thus built-in concurrency with FIFO policy of the scheduler that is unfriendly to parallel number crunching. Oversubscription is rather recommend for IO tasks while it affects or even kills computational parallelism.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2527797" LastEditorUserId="2527797" LastEditDate="2017-05-31T02:46:33.673" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T02:46:33.673" CommentCount="0" />

answer:
<row Id="44276686" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44275403" CreationDate="2017-05-31T05:51:43.643" Score="4" Body="<p>If you can get a reference to something in the package, you can use reflect to get the import path.</p>

<p>Here's an example on <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Ug3RkqLtBT" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Play</a>:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
    "reflect"
)

func main() {
    var b bytes.Buffer
    fmt.Println(reflect.TypeOf(b).PkgPath())
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="121631" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T05:51:43.643" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44274221      <row Id="44274221" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44276988" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44274221" CreationDate="2017-05-31T06:12:54.817" Score="3" Body="<p>The problem is in the endianness of variable <code>data</code> and <code>encrypted</code>. In the C code, <code>data</code> (8-bytes) is converted from byte array to <code>unsigned int</code>(32-bit little-endian), then being encrypted in place. It affects the endianness of both input and encrypted result. To get same result in Golang, you must perform endian conversion, e.g.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"

    "encoding/binary"

    "golang.org/x/crypto/blowfish"
)

func convertEndian(in []byte) ([]byte, error) {
    //Read byte array as uint32 (little-endian)
    var v1, v2 uint32
    buf := bytes.NewReader(in)
    if err := binary.Read(buf, binary.LittleEndian, &amp;v1); err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    if err := binary.Read(buf, binary.LittleEndian, &amp;v2); err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    //convert uint32 to byte array
    out := make([]byte, 8)
    binary.BigEndian.PutUint32(out, v1)
    binary.BigEndian.PutUint32(out[4:], v2)

    return out, nil
}

func main() {
    key := []byte{0xc9, 0x04, 0xa7, 0xa8, 0x5b, 0xbd, 0x97, 0x53, 0x24, 0xc5, 0x08, 0x3e, 0xd9, 0x6f, 0xf0, 0x22, 0xf2, 0x5e, 0x06, 0x2d, 0xa1, 0xd5, 0x75, 0xb2, 0x46, 0x2c, 0x2c, 0x98, 0xd8, 0xd6, 0x4d, 0x9d}
    data := []byte{0x53, 0x8b, 0x77, 0x59, 0x83, 0x4d, 0x34, 0x18}

    //Add: This is equal to: (unsigned int *)data in C
    cdata, _ := convertEndian(data)

    cipher, err := blowfish.NewCipher(key)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    fmt.Printf("key: %x
", key)
    fmt.Printf("data: %x
", cdata)

    encrypted := make([]byte, 8)
    cipher.Encrypt(encrypted, cdata)
    fmt.Printf("encrypted-1: %x
", encrypted)

    //Add: This is equal to {uint32, uint32} --&gt; byte array
    ce, _ := convertEndian(encrypted)
    fmt.Printf("encrypted-2: %02x
", ce)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T06:12:54.817" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44000686      <row Id="44000686" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44278364" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44000686" CreationDate="2017-05-31T07:28:38.140" Score="1" Body="<p>I asked the go team and the answer was:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_go/blob/master/proto/go_proto_library.bzl" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_go/blob/master/proto/go_proto_library.bzl</a> does not have a good solution for this case where the .proto is in a  completely different location from the .pb.go files other than using a genrule to copy the .proto file from its source and then a go_proto_library to operate on it.</p>
  
  <p><a href="https://github.com/pubref/rules_protobuf/blob/master/go/rules.bzl" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/pubref/rules_protobuf/blob/master/go/rules.bzl</a> has a go_proto_library that allows the .proto from one place and the .pb.go from another, but disclaimer: this code is not owned or maintained by Google.</p>
  
  <p>As to the questions:</p>
  
  <p>1) No</p>
  
  <p>2) No idea</p>
  
  <p>3) See 2</p>
  
  <p>4) bazel always recommends generating from the source (in this case the .proto files)</p>
  
  <p>5) Not yet</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="1009896" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T07:28:38.140" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44277222      <row Id="44277222" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44282136" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44277222" CreationDate="2017-05-31T10:21:43.970" Score="2" Body="<p>This is not using regex but is just an example of how to achieve the same by using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/strings/#FieldsFunc" rel="nofollow noreferrer">strings.FieldsFunc</a>.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/rr6U8xTJZT" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/rr6U8xTJZT</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "strings"
    "unicode"
)

const foo = `time="2017-05-30T19:02:08-05:00" level=info msg="some log message" app=sample size=10`

func main() {
    lastQuote := rune(0)
    f := func(c rune) bool {
        switch {
        case c == lastQuote:
            lastQuote = rune(0)
            return false
        case lastQuote != rune(0):
            return false
        case unicode.In(c, unicode.Quotation_Mark):
            lastQuote = c
            return false
        default:
            return unicode.IsSpace(c)

        }
    }

    // splitting string by space but considering quoted section
    items := strings.FieldsFunc(foo, f)

    // create and fill the map
    m := make(map[string]string)
    for _, item := range items {
        x := strings.Split(item, "=")
        m[x[0]] = x[1]
    }

    // print the map
    for k, v := range m {
        fmt.Printf("%s: %s\n", k, v)
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1135424" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T10:21:43.970" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44208305      <row Id="44208305" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44285400" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44208305" CreationDate="2017-05-31T12:53:51.823" Score="2" Body="<p>I only used an older version of appengine sdk, but I believe below is still true.</p>

<p>The main issue is that you have google-cloud-sdk inside your GOPATH. This should not be necessary. I have it installed in my path. But even if not installed it should be resolving it's location relative to the executable or script you are running and should find all required sdk files properly. At the same time SDK is roughly 7500 files and you only need to have more than 10000 (approx) in your GOPATH to get that "to many files" warning. So, if you have another (e.g. older) copy of SDK or other big project inside same GOPATH, you are pretty much guaranteed to exceed the threshold. Just locate /Users/Bryan/go in Finder and use "Get Info" to count files.</p>

<p>So, either move appengine SDK outside of your GOPATH. Or make a new folder, export it as your new GOPATH and move your project files (but not SDK) to that new folder. This should fix the "too many files issue".</p>

<p>The other issue is that your app actually fails to build. And as you have already figured out yourself the (immediate) issue is missing appengine package.</p>

<p>But the correct way of getting google.golang.org/appengine is as follows:
<code>
go get google.golang.org/appengine
</code></p>

<p>Though keep in mind that GOPATH must be set correctly <em>before</em> running the above command. It will fetch google.golang.org/appengine and all it's dependencies.</p>

<p>Once you have retrieved all required packages (and fixed errors, if any) it should compile and run without issues.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6375498" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T12:53:51.823" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44283880      <row Id="44283880" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44286169" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44283880" CreationDate="2017-05-31T13:29:18.927" Score="0" Body="<p>If you want to go beyond porting a bash script to Go (which is often more trouble than it's worth), you can use the <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2" rel="nofollow noreferrer">mgo library</a> to actually connect to a MongoDB instance and check if it is healthy:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "gopkg.in/mgo.v2"
    "fmt"
    "os"
)

func main() {
    sess, err := mgo.Dial("localhost")
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
    defer sess.Close()
    err = sess.Ping()
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
    fmt.Println("MongoDB server is healthy.")
    os.Exit(0)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-05-31T13:38:15.553" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T13:38:15.553" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44289704      <row Id="44289704" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44289780" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44289704" CreationDate="2017-05-31T16:12:32.700" Score="2" Body="<p>You can use a cancellation channel:</p>

<pre><code>cancel := make(chan struct{})
for {
    timer = time.NewTimer(30 * time.Second)
    select {
    case &lt;- timer.C:
        doSomething()
    case &lt;- cancel:
        doSomething()
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>When you want to ignore the timer and execute immediately, just send a message on the <code>cancel</code> channel:</p>

<pre><code>cancel &lt;- struct{}{}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T16:12:32.700" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44295820      <row Id="44295820" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44296206" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44295820" CreationDate="2017-05-31T23:29:32.733" Score="1" Body="<p>You would pass a <code>tls.Config</code> struct with your own <code>VerifyPeerCertificate</code> function, and then you would check the certificate yourself.</p>

<p><code>VerifyPeerCertificate func(rawCerts [][]byte, verifiedChains [][]*x509.Certificate) error</code></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If normal verification fails then the handshake will abort before
  considering this callback. If normal verification is disabled by
  setting InsecureSkipVerify then this callback will be considered but
  the verifiedChains argument will always be nil.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>You can look <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/crypto/x509/#example_Certificate_Verify" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a> for an example of how to verify a certificate.  Iif you look <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/crypto/x509/#VerifyOptions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>, you'll see that part of even this verification process includes checking the hostname, but luckily you'll see that it <a href="https://golang.org/src/crypto/x509/verify.go?s=8414:8499#L298" rel="nofollow noreferrer">skips it</a> if it's set to the empty string.</p>

<p>So, basically you write your own <code>VerifyPeerCertificate</code> function, convert the <code>rawCerts [][]byte</code>, which I think would look something like:</p>

<pre><code>customVerify := func(rawCerts [][]byte, verifiedChains [][]*x509.Certificate) error {
    roots := x509.NewCertPool()
    for _, rawCert := range rawCerts {
        cert, _ := x509.ParseCertificate(rawCert)
        roots.AddCert(cert)
    }
    opts := x509.VerifyOptions{
        Roots:   roots,
    }
    _, err := cert.Verify(opts)
    return err
}

conf := tls.Config{
    //...
    VerifyPeerCertificate: customVerify,
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2082673" LastActivityDate="2017-05-31T23:29:32.733" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44299808      <row Id="44299808" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44300473" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44299808" CreationDate="2017-06-01T06:53:05.280" Score="5" Body="<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/y-I6Fb_61R" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/y-I6Fb_61R</a></p>

<p>I hope you can live with the additional outer <code>{}</code> pair.</p>

<p>And without the outer <code>{}</code> pair: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/SSTgln0qJc" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/SSTgln0qJc</a></p>

<p>To not just have a bunch of links and to enable easy criticism of my solution by others, I include the code here, slightly redacted:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "encoding/json"
    "log"
    "strings"
)

var dataAsString = `` //put data between the ``

type Item struct {
    Id          int    `json:"id"`
    Category    string `json:"category"`
    Name        string `json:"name"`
    Description string `json:"description"`
}

type CategoryToItemSliceMap map[string][]Item
type CategoryToIndexItemMap map[string]map[int]Item

func main() {
    // first read the data, we use a decoder as the input was given
    // as a stream of seperate json objects and not a big single one.

    decoder := json.NewDecoder(strings.NewReader(dataAsString))
    var ourData []Item
    for decoder.More() {
        var it Item
        err := decoder.Decode(&amp;it)
        if err != nil {
            log.Fatalln(err)
        }
        ourData = append(ourData, it)
    }

    // collect items according to categories
    catToItemSlice := CategoryToItemSliceMap{}
    for _,v := range ourData {
        catToItemSlice[v.Category] = append(catToItemSlice[v.Category],v)
    }

    // turn those slices into int -&gt; Item maps so we get the index numbers
    // in the encoded json
    catToIndexItemMap := CategoryToIndexItemMap{}
    for k,v := range catToItemSlice {
        if catToIndexItemMap[k] == nil {
            catToIndexItemMap[k] = map[int]Item{}
        }
        for index, item := range v {
           catToIndexItemMap[k][index] = item
        }
    }

    // easiest way to get the "elements: " without an additional outer {} 
    // brace pair
    fmt.Printf("elements: ")

    // We only have one json object in the output and that is a map, so we
    // can use Unmarshal and don't need a streaming encoder. And get nice
    // indentation with MarshalIndent.
    out, err := json.MarshalIndent(catToIndexItemMap, "", "    ")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatalln(err)
    }
    fmt.Println(string(out))

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7824574" LastEditorUserId="7824574" LastEditDate="2017-06-01T07:25:23.573" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T07:25:23.573" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44297057      <row Id="44297057" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44300781" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44297057" CreationDate="2017-06-01T07:08:51.377" Score="3" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>What am I missing here?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>In Java, size of the <code>int</code> type is fixed 4 bytes. In Go <code>int</code> is an architecture dependent type, on 32-bit architectures it's 32 bits (4 bytes), and on 64-bit architectures it's 64 bits (8 bytes).</p>

<p>Most likely you're running it on a 64-bit arch. Which means the size of the Go slice / array you allocate is 8 * 1 GB = 8 GB, while in Java it's only 4 * 1 GB = 4 GB.</p>

<p>Moreover, since you're using <code>int</code> in your loop, Java only has to increment and set 4-byte values, while in Go you're incrementing and setting 8-byte values (type of <code>i</code> and <code>j</code> will be <code>int</code>).</p>

<p>Change your Go code to use <code>int32</code>, and give it a go again.</p>

<p>Also note that your memory usage measurement is flawed, as just the array size in Java is 4 GB and 8 GB in Go, so that 3 GB for Java and 5-8 GB in Go is not the total memory usage!</p>

<p>Also note that <code>[]int</code> in Go is a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">slice</a> and not an <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Array_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">array</a>, they are not the same. Slices in Go are struct-like headers containing a pointer to a backing array (see <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#SliceHeader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect.SliceHeader</code></a> for details), so there is an implicit indirection step involved using them. For details see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38645175/why-have-arrays-in-go/38645895#38645895">Why have arrays in Go?</a> Also related: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30525184/array-vs-slice-accessing-speed">Array vs Slice: accessing speed</a></p>

<p>One last note: your code does not measure memory allocation, as that is just the tiny part of the app's execution time. The majority (like 99.99999%) of the execution time is to increment the loop variable a billion times and to fill the arrays with a billion elements.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-01T09:24:22.203" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T09:24:22.203" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44302790      <row Id="44302790" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44303024" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44302790" CreationDate="2017-06-01T09:02:40.193" Score="5" Body="<p><a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2#Query.All" rel="noreferrer"><code>Query.All()</code></a> never returns <code>mgo.ErrNotFound</code>, so it's useless to check for that. If there are no results, the length of <code>results</code> will be 0, so that's how you can detect that <em>if</em> there were no errors:</p>

<pre><code>err := c.Find(selectQuery).All(&amp;results)
if err != nil { {
    // error handling
    return
}
// If you must detect "not found" case:
if len(results) == 0 {
    // No results
}
</code></pre>

<p><code>mgo.ErrNotFound</code> is used / returned by other methods, usually by those which ought to operate on a single document, such as <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2#Query.One" rel="noreferrer"><code>Query.One()</code></a> or <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2#Query.Apply" rel="noreferrer"><code>Query.Apply()</code></a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T09:02:40.193" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44305617      <row Id="44305617" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44305711" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44305617" CreationDate="2017-06-01T10:57:40.357" Score="1" Body="<p>The <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#The_zero_value" rel="nofollow noreferrer">zero value</a> for map types is <code>nil</code>. It is not yet initialized. You cannot index <code>nil</code> maps, that's a runtime panic.</p>

<p>In your last example you initialize the (outer) <code>data</code> map, but it has no entries. When you index it like <code>data["a"]</code>, since there is no entry with <code>"a"</code> key in it yet, indexing it returns the zero value of the value type which is <code>nil</code> for maps. So attempting to index it like <code>data["a"]["w"]</code> is a runtime panic.</p>

<p>You have to initialize a map first before indexing it, for example:</p>

<pre><code>var data = map[string]map[string]string{}

data["a"] = map[string]string{}
data["b"] = make(map[string]string)
data["c"] = make(map[string]string)

data["a"]["w"] = "x"
data["b"]["w"] = "x"
data["c"]["w"] = "x"
fmt.Println(data)
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/-w-tf4G7dF" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>map[a:map[w:x] b:map[w:x] c:map[w:x]]
</code></pre>

<p>Note that when you declare a variable of map type and initialize it with a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Composite_literals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">composite literal</a> (as in <code>var data = map[string]string{}</code>), that also counts as initializing.</p>

<p>Note that you may also initialize your nested maps with a composite literal:</p>

<pre><code>var data = map[string]map[string]string{
    "a": map[string]string{},
    "b": map[string]string{},
    "c": map[string]string{},
}

data["a"]["w"] = "x"
data["b"]["w"] = "x"
data["c"]["w"] = "x"
fmt.Println(data)
</code></pre>

<p>Output is the same. Try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/FpXvrYpwDW" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-01T11:03:26.757" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T11:03:26.757" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44305170      <row Id="44305170" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44305910" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44305170" CreationDate="2017-06-01T11:09:14.433" Score="0" Body="<h2>Observable behavior</h2>

<p><code>nil</code> and empty slices (with 0 capacity) are not the same, but their observable behavior is the same. By this I mean:</p>

<ul>
<li>You can pass them to the builtin <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#len" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>len()</code></a> and <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#cap" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>cap()</code></a> functions</li>
<li>You can <code>for range</code> over them (will be 0 iterations)</li>
<li>You can slice them (by not violating the restrictions outlined at <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_expressions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Slice expressions</a>; so the result will also be an empty slice)</li>
<li>Since their length is 0, you can't change their content (appending a value creates a new slice value)</li>
</ul>

<p>See this simple example (a <code>nil</code> slice and 2 non-<code>nil</code> empty slices):</p>

<pre><code>var s1 []int         // nil slice
s2 := []int{}        // non-nil, empty slice
s3 := make([]int, 0) // non-nil, empty slice

fmt.Println("s1", len(s1), cap(s1), s1 == nil, s1[:], s1[:] == nil)
fmt.Println("s2", len(s2), cap(s2), s2 == nil, s2[:], s2[:] == nil)
fmt.Println("s3", len(s3), cap(s3), s3 == nil, s3[:], s3[:] == nil)

for _ = range s1 {}
for _ = range s2 {}
for _ = range s3 {}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/_EjBzoz0Ed" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>s1 0 0 true [] true
s2 0 0 false [] false
s3 0 0 false [] false
</code></pre>

<p>(Note that slicing a <code>nil</code> slice results in a <code>nil</code> slice, slicing a non-<code>nil</code> slice results in a non-<code>nil</code> slice.)</p>

<p>You can only tell the difference by comparing the slice value to the predeclared identifier <code>nil</code>, they behave the same in every other aspect.</p>

<p>To tell if a slice is empty, simply compare its length to <code>0</code>: <code>len(s) == 0</code>. It doesn't matter if it's the <code>nil</code> slice or a non-<code>nil</code> slice, it also doesn't matter if it has a positive capacity; if it has no elements, it's empty.</p>

<pre><code>s := make([]int, 0, 100)
fmt.Println("Empty:", len(s) == 0, ", but capacity:", cap(s))
</code></pre>

<p>Prints (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/T29nh9hVpd" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Empty: true , but capacity: 100
</code></pre>

<h2>Under the hood</h2>

<p>A slice value is represented by a struct defined in <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#SliceHeader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect.SliceHeader</code></a>:</p>

<pre><code>type SliceHeader struct {
    Data uintptr
    Len  int
    Cap  int
}
</code></pre>

<p>In case of a <code>nil</code> slice, this struct will have its zero value which is all its fields will be their zero value, that is: <code>0</code>.</p>

<p>Having a non-<code>nil</code> slice with both capacity and length equal to <code>0</code>, <code>Len</code> and <code>Cap</code> fields will most certainly be <code>0</code>, but the <code>Data</code> pointer may not be. It <em>will</em> not be, that is what differentiates it from the <code>nil</code> slice. It will point to a zero-sized underlying array.</p>

<p>Note that the Go spec allows for values of different types having 0 size to have the same memory address. <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Size_and_alignment_guarantees" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: System considerations: Size and alignment guarantees:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A struct or array type has size zero if it contains no fields (or elements, respectively) that have a size greater than zero. <strong>Two distinct zero-size variables may have the same address in memory.</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Let's check this. For this we call the help of the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/unsafe/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>unsafe</code></a> package, and "obtain" the <code>reflect.SliceHeader</code> struct "view" of our slice values:</p>

<pre><code>var s1 []int
s2 := []int{}
s3 := make([]int, 0)

fmt.Printf("s1 (addr: %p): %+8v
",
    &amp;s1, *(*reflect.SliceHeader)(unsafe.Pointer(&amp;s1)))
fmt.Printf("s2 (addr: %p): %+8v
",
    &amp;s2, *(*reflect.SliceHeader)(unsafe.Pointer(&amp;s2)))
fmt.Printf("s3 (addr: %p): %+8v
",
    &amp;s3, *(*reflect.SliceHeader)(unsafe.Pointer(&amp;s3)))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/49I_2os91G" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>s1 (addr: 0x1040a130): {Data:       0 Len:       0 Cap:       0}
s2 (addr: 0x1040a140): {Data: 1535812 Len:       0 Cap:       0}
s3 (addr: 0x1040a150): {Data: 1535812 Len:       0 Cap:       0}
</code></pre>

<p>What do we see?</p>

<ul>
<li>All slices (slice headers) have different memory addresses</li>
<li>The <code>nil</code> slice has <code>0</code> data pointer</li>
<li><code>s2</code> and <code>s3</code> slices do have the same data pointer, sharing / pointing to the same 0-sized memory value </li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T05:55:48.687" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T05:55:48.687" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44302374      <row Id="44302374" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
