answer:
<row Id="44306160" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44302374" CreationDate="2017-06-01T11:22:26.170" Score="0" Body="<p>Now, I am very happy with the mood to share my solution</p>

<pre><code>func NewPostFile(url string, paramTexts map[string]interface{}, paramFile FileItem) ([]byte, error) {
// if paramFiles ==nil {
//  return NewPost(url,paramTexts,header,transport)
// }

bodyBuf := &amp;bytes.Buffer{}
bodyWriter := multipart.NewWriter(bodyBuf)

for k, v := range paramTexts {
    bodyWriter.WriteField(k, v.(string))
}
fileWriter, err := bodyWriter.CreateFormFile(paramFile.Key, paramFile.FileName)
if err != nil {
    fmt.Println(err)
    //fmt.Println("Create form file error: ", error)
    return nil, err
}
fileWriter.Write(paramFile.Content)
contentType := bodyWriter.FormDataContentType()
bodyWriter.Close()
fmt.Println(bodyBuf.String())

resp, err := http.Post(url, contentType, bodyBuf)
if err != nil {
    return nil, err
}
defer resp.Body.Close()
fmt.Println(resp)

if resp.StatusCode &lt; 200 || resp.StatusCode &gt;= 300 {
    b, _ := ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    return nil, fmt.Errorf("[%d %s]%s", resp.StatusCode, resp.Status, string(b))
}
respData, err := ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
if err != nil {
    return nil, err
}
fmt.Println(string(respData))
return respData, nil
</code></pre>

<p>}</p>

<pre><code>type FileItem struct {
Key      string //image_content
FileName string //test.jpg
Content  []byte //[]byte
</code></pre>

<p>}</p>
" OwnerUserId="8095085" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T11:22:26.170" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44307219      <row Id="44307219" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44308109" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44307219" CreationDate="2017-06-01T12:53:48.040" Score="4" Body="<p>Decoding a JSON stream is possible with the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Decoder" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.Decoder</code></a>.</p>

<p>With <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Decoder.Decode" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Decoder.Decode()</code></a>, we may read (unmarshal) a single value without consuming and unmarshaling the complete stream. This is cool, but your input is a "single" JSON object, not a series of JSON objects, which means a call to <code>Decoder.Decode()</code> would attempt to unmarshal the complete JSON object with all items (large objects).</p>

<p>What we want is partially, on-the-fly processing of a single JSON object. For this, we may use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Decoder.Token" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Decoder.Token()</code></a> which parses (advances) only the next subsequent token in the JSON input stream and returns it. This is called <em>event-driven</em> parsing.</p>

<p>Of course we have to "process" (interpret and act upon) the tokens and build a "state machine" that keeps track of where we're in the JSON structure we're processing.</p>

<p>Here's an implementation that solves your problem.</p>

<p>We will use the following JSON input:</p>

<pre><code>{
    "somefield": "value",
    "otherfield": "othervalue",
    "items": [
        { "id": "1", "data": "data1" },
        { "id": "2", "data": "data2" },
        { "id": "3", "data": "data3" },
        { "id": "4", "data": "data4" }
    ]
}
</code></pre>

<p>And read the <code>items</code>, the "large objects" modeled by this type:</p>

<pre><code>type LargeObject struct {
    Id   string `json:"id"`
    Data string `json:"data"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>We will also parse and interpret other fields in the JSON object, but we will only log / print them.</p>

<p>For brevity and easy error handling, We'll use this helper error handler function:</p>

<pre><code>he := func(err error) {
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>And now let's see some action. In the example below for brevity and to have a working demonstration on the Go Playground, we'll read from a <code>string</code> value. To read from an actual HTTP response body, we only have to change a single line, which is how we create the <code>json.Decoder</code>:</p>

<pre><code>dec := json.NewDecoder(res.Body)
</code></pre>

<p>So the demonstration:</p>

<pre><code>dec := json.NewDecoder(strings.NewReader(jsonStream))
// We expect an object
t, err := dec.Token()
he(err)
if delim, ok := t.(json.Delim); !ok || delim != '{' {
    log.Fatal("Expected object")
}

// Read props
for dec.More() {
    t, err = dec.Token()
    he(err)
    prop := t.(string)
    if t != "items" {
        var v interface{}
        he(dec.Decode(&amp;v))
        log.Printf("Property '%s' = %v", prop, v)
        continue
    }

    // It's the "items". We expect it to be an array
    t, err := dec.Token()
    he(err)
    if delim, ok := t.(json.Delim); !ok || delim != '[' {
        log.Fatal("Expected array")
    }
    // Read items (large objects)
    for dec.More() {
        // Read next item (large object)
        lo := LargeObject{}
        he(dec.Decode(&amp;lo))
        fmt.Printf("Item: %+v\n", lo)
    }
    // Array closing delim
    t, err = dec.Token()
    he(err)
    if delim, ok := t.(json.Delim); !ok || delim != ']' {
        log.Fatal("Expected array closing")
    }
}

// Object closing delim
t, err = dec.Token()
he(err)
if delim, ok := t.(json.Delim); !ok || delim != '}' {
    log.Fatal("Expected object closing")
}
</code></pre>

<p>This will produce the following output:</p>

<pre><code>2009/11/10 23:00:00 Property 'somefield' = value
2009/11/10 23:00:00 Property 'otherfield' = othervalue
Item: {Id:1 Data:data1}
Item: {Id:2 Data:data2}
Item: {Id:3 Data:data3}
Item: {Id:4 Data:data4}
</code></pre>

<p>Try the full, working example on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/zHXe-4a4Za" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-01T15:42:13.550" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T15:42:13.550" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44308536      <row Id="44308536" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44308833" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44308536" CreationDate="2017-06-01T13:26:13.720" Score="1" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#Request" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>http.Request</code></a> is a struct, whose <code>URL</code> field is a <strong>pointer</strong>:</p>

<pre><code>URL *url.URL
</code></pre>

<p>In your code you have a single <code>uri</code> variable holding a pointer of type <code>*url.URL</code>.</p>

<p>Then you create 2 requests, storing the pointers in <code>request1</code> and <code>request2</code> variables, but you assign the same value, the same pointer to their <code>URL</code> field.</p>

<p>So there is a single <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/url/#URL" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>url.URL</code></a> value, and you assign its address to both <code>request1.URL</code> and <code>request2.URL</code>. Then you print the addresses of <code>request1.URL.Host</code> and <code>request2.URL.Host</code>, but since both <code>request1.URL</code> and <code>request2.URL</code> point to the same and only <code>url.URL</code> (struct) value, the address of the <code>Host</code> field of that struct will be the same. There are no distinct <code>url.URL</code> values for the 2 request structs.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T13:26:13.720" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44294959      <row Id="44294959" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44309922" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44294959" CreationDate="2017-06-01T14:12:33.967" Score="1" Body="<p>You don't "model shared state using messages", you use messages <em>instead of</em> shared state, which requires designing the application based on different fundamentals. It is generally not a matter of rewriting a mutex as a channel, but a completely different implementation approach, and that approach won't be applicable to all scenarios where you need to synchronize operations. If a shared map is the best approach for your situation, then a mutex is the correct way to synchronize access to it.</p>

<p>As an example from my own experience, I've developed applications that allow for changing their configuration at runtime. Rather than having a shared Config object and synchronizing access to it, I give each main goroutine a channel on which it can receive configuration updates. When the config changes, the update is sent to all the listeners. When a listener gets a config change, it can complete its current operation, then deal with the config change in whatever way is appropriate to that routine - it may just update its local copy of the config, it may close connections to external resources and open new ones, etc. Instead of sharing data, I'm sending and receiving events, which is a fundamentally different design.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T14:12:33.967" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44306554      <row Id="44306554" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44310259" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44306554" CreationDate="2017-06-01T14:28:17.487" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to import <code>_ "k8s.io/client-go/pkg/apis/extensions/install"</code> otherwise the schema is empty, see also <a href="https://godoc.org/k8s.io/client-go/pkg/apis/extensions/install" rel="nofollow noreferrer">docs</a>.</p>

<p>The complete working example is:</p>

<pre><code>$ go get -u github.com/golang/dep/cmd/dep
$ dep init
$ go run main.go
</code></pre>

<p>With the following <code>main.go</code>:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"

    "k8s.io/client-go/pkg/api"
    _ "k8s.io/client-go/pkg/api/install"
    _ "k8s.io/client-go/pkg/apis/extensions/install"
)

var deployment = `
apiVersion: extensions/v1beta1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
name: my-nginx
spec:
replicas: 2
template:
  metadata:
    labels:
      run: my-nginx
  spec:
    containers:
    - name: my-nginx
      image: nginx
      ports:
      - containerPort: 80
`

func main() {
    // decode := api.Codecs.UniversalDecoder().Decode
    decode := api.Codecs.UniversalDeserializer().Decode

    obj, _, err := decode([]byte(deployment), nil, nil)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Printf("%#v", err)
    }

    fmt.Printf("%#v\n", obj)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that I also imported <code>_ "k8s.io/client-go/pkg/api/install"</code> for you so that you can use objects in <code>v1</code> such as pods or services.</p>

<p>EDIT: Kudos to my colleague <a href="https://twitter.com/the1stein" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Stefan Schimanski</a> who proposed the initial solution.</p>
" OwnerUserId="396567" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T14:28:17.487" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44313364      <row Id="44313364" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44313480" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44313364" CreationDate="2017-06-01T17:12:58.617" Score="1" Body="<p>If the function takes a <code>[]Base</code> parameter, you must pass a <code>[]Base</code> parameter. Not a <code>[]interface{}</code>, not a <code>[]thingThatImplementsBase</code>, but specifically a <code>[]Base</code>. A slice of interfaces isn't an interface - it isn't "implemented by" a slice of any other type. The elements of a slice of interfaces can be anything that implements the interface, but the slice itself is of a strict and specific type.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T17:12:58.617" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44315096      <row Id="44315096" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44315254" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44315096" CreationDate="2017-06-01T19:05:20.807" Score="3" Body="<p>Use <code>fmt.Sprintf()</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    i := 42
    ip := &amp;i
    strValue := fmt.Sprintf("%p", &amp;ip)
    fmt.Println(strValue)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="963881" LastActivityDate="2017-06-01T19:05:20.807" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44320960      <row Id="44320960" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44321451" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44320960" CreationDate="2017-06-02T05:31:03.473" Score="2" Body="<p>From the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Struct values encode as JSON objects. Each exported struct field becomes a member of the object unless</p>
  
  <ul>
  <li>the field's tag is "-", or</li>
  <li>the field is empty and its tag specifies the "omitempty" option.</li>
  </ul>
  
  <p>The empty values are false, 0, any nil pointer or interface value, and any array, slice, map, or string of length zero.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The reason it is not omitting is stated <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#nil_error" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a> </p>

<blockquote>
  <p>An interface value is nil only if the inner value and type are both
  unset, (nil, nil). In particular, a nil interface will always hold a
  nil type. If we store a nil pointer of type *int inside an interface
  value, the inner type will be *int regardless of the value of the
  pointer: (*int, nil). Such an interface value will therefore be
  non-nil even when the pointer inside is nil.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/q297qL5vjF" rel="nofollow noreferrer">eg</a>: </p>

<pre><code>var s []string
s = nil
var temp interface{}
fmt.Println(temp==nil) // true
temp = s
fmt.Println(temp==nil) // false
</code></pre>

<p>For your case, you can do</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ZZ_Vzwq4QF" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/ZZ_Vzwq4QF</a><br>
or<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/S5lMgqVXuB" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/S5lMgqVXuB</a>  </p>
" OwnerUserId="2809739" LastEditorUserId="2809739" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T06:39:10.743" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T06:39:10.743" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44310982      <row Id="44310982" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44322300" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44310982" CreationDate="2017-06-02T06:33:26.357" Score="2" Body="<p>Depending on the nature of this writer and how you use it, keeping everything in memory (to be able to re-play everything for readers joining later) is very risky and might demand a lot of memory, or cause your app to crash due to out of memory.</p>

<p>Using it for a "low-traffic" logger keeping everything in memory is probably ok, but for example streaming some audio or video is most likely not.</p>

<p>If the reader implementations below read all the data that was written to the buffer, their <code>Read()</code> method will report <code>io.EOF</code>, properly. Care must be taken as some constructs (such as <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#Scanner" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>bufio.Scanner</code></a>) may not read more data once <code>io.EOF</code> is encountered (but this is not the flaw of our implementation).</p>

<p>If you want the readers of our buffer to wait if no more data is available in the buffer, to wait until new data is written instead of returning <code>io.EOF</code>, you may wrap the returned readers in a "tail reader" presented here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31120987/go-tail-f-like-generator/31122253#31122253">Go: &quot;tail -f&quot;-like generator</a>.</p>

<h1>"Memory-safe" file implementation</h1>

<p>Here is an extremely simple and elegant solution. It uses a file to write to, and also uses files to read from. The synchronization is basically provided by the operating system. This does not risk out of memory error, as the data is solely stored on the disk. Depending on the nature of your writer, this may or may not be sufficient.</p>

<p>I will rather use the following interface, because <code>Close()</code> is important in case of files.</p>

<pre><code>type MyBuf interface {
    io.WriteCloser
    NewReader() (io.ReadCloser, error)
}
</code></pre>

<p>And the implementation is extremely simple:</p>

<pre><code>type mybuf struct {
    *os.File
}

func (mb *mybuf) NewReader() (io.ReadCloser, error) {
    f, err := os.Open(mb.Name())
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    return f, nil
}

func NewMyBuf(name string) (MyBuf, error) {
    f, err := os.Create(name)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    return &amp;mybuf{File: f}, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Our <code>mybuf</code> type embeds <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>*os.File</code></a>, so we get the <code>Write()</code> and <code>Close()</code> methods for "free".</p>

<p>The <code>NewReader()</code> simply opens the existing, backing file for reading (in read-only mode) and returns it, again taking advantage of that it implements <code>io.ReadCloser</code>.</p>

<p>Creating a new <code>MyBuf</code> value is implementing in the <code>NewMyBuf()</code> function which may also return an <code>error</code> if creating the file fails.</p>

<p><strong>Notes:</strong></p>

<p>Note that since <code>mybuf</code> embeds <code>*os.File</code>, it is possible with a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_assertions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">type assertion</a> to "reach" other exported methods of <code>os.File</code> even though they are not part of the <code>MyBuf</code> interface. I do not consider this a flaw, but if you want to disallow this, you have to change the implementation of <code>mybuf</code> to not embed <code>os.File</code> but rather have it as a named field (but then you have to add the <code>Write()</code> and <code>Close()</code> methods yourself, properly forwarding to the <code>os.File</code> field).</p>

<h1>In-memory implementation</h1>

<p>If the file implementation is not sufficient, here comes an in-memory implementation.</p>

<p>Since we're now in-memory only, we will use the following interface:</p>

<pre><code>type MyBuf interface {
    io.Writer
    NewReader() io.Reader
}
</code></pre>

<p>The idea is to store all byte slices that is ever passed to our buffer. Readers will provide the stored slices when <code>Read()</code> is called, each reader will keep track of how many of the stored slices were served by its <code>Read()</code> method. Synchronization must be dealt with, we will use a simple <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#RWMutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sync.RWMutex</code></a>.</p>

<p>Without further ado, here is the implementation:</p>

<pre><code>type mybuf struct {
    data [][]byte
    sync.RWMutex
}

func (mb *mybuf) Write(p []byte) (n int, err error) {
    if len(p) == 0 {
        return 0, nil
    }
    // Cannot retain p, so we must copy it:
    p2 := make([]byte, len(p))
    copy(p2, p)
    mb.Lock()
    mb.data = append(mb.data, p2)
    mb.Unlock()
    return len(p), nil
}

type mybufReader struct {
    mb   *mybuf // buffer we read from
    i    int    // next slice index
    data []byte // current data slice to serve
}

func (mbr *mybufReader) Read(p []byte) (n int, err error) {
    if len(p) == 0 {
        return 0, nil
    }
    // Do we have data to send?
    if len(mbr.data) == 0 {
        mb := mbr.mb
        mb.RLock()
        if mbr.i &lt; len(mb.data) {
            mbr.data = mb.data[mbr.i]
            mbr.i++
        }
        mb.RUnlock()
    }
    if len(mbr.data) == 0 {
        return 0, io.EOF
    }

    n = copy(p, mbr.data)
    mbr.data = mbr.data[n:]
    return n, nil
}

func (mb *mybuf) NewReader() io.Reader {
    return &amp;mybufReader{mb: mb}
}

func NewMyBuf() MyBuf {
    return &amp;mybuf{}
}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that the general contract of <code>Writer.Write()</code> is that it must not retain the passed slice, so we have make a copy of it before "storing" it.</p>

<p>Also note that the <code>Read()</code> of readers attempts to lock for minimal amount of time. That is, it only locks if we need new data slice from buffer, and only does read-locking, meaning if the reader has a partial data slice, will send that in <code>Read()</code> without locking and touching the buffer.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T09:35:50.107" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T09:35:50.107" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44323087      <row Id="44323087" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44323647" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44323087" CreationDate="2017-06-02T07:55:20.997" Score="2" Body="<p>You are calling your method <code>Scan</code> of type <code>*custMap</code> on a unitialised map. Initialize <code>d.vals</code> either like</p>

<pre><code>d.vals = custMap{}
</code></pre>

<p>or</p>

<pre><code>d.vals = make(custMap)
</code></pre>

<p>Other answers already provide an explanation.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7824574" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T07:55:20.997" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44319906      <row Id="44319906" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44323999" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44319906" CreationDate="2017-06-02T08:14:56.647" Score="2" Body="<p><code>interface{}</code> is stored as a two word pair, one word describing the underlying type information and one word describing the data within that interface:</p>

<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/lrSQz.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/lrSQz.png" alt="enter image description here"></a></p>

<p><a href="https://research.swtch.com/interfaces" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://research.swtch.com/interfaces</a></p>

<p>Here we see the first word stores the type information and the second the data within <code>b</code>.</p>

<p>Struct types are stored differently, they do not have this pairing. Their fields of a struct are laid out next to one another in memory.</p>

<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/MbeRi.png" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/MbeRi.png" alt="enter image description here"></a></p>

<p><a href="https://research.swtch.com/godata" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://research.swtch.com/godata</a></p>

<p>You cannot convert one to the other because they do not have the same representation in memory. </p>

<blockquote>
  <p>It is necessary to copy the elements individually to the destination
  slice.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#convert_slice_of_interface" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/faq#convert_slice_of_interface</a></p>

<p>To answer your last question, you could have <code>[]interface</code> which is a slice of interfaces, where each interface is represented as above, or just <code>interface{}</code> where the underlying type held in that interface is <code>[]MyStruct</code></p>

<pre><code>var y interface{}
y = x 
</code></pre>

<p>or</p>

<pre><code>y := make([]interface{}, len(x))
for i, v := range x {
    y[i] = v
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6376471" LastEditorUserId="6376471" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T08:20:01.623" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T08:20:01.623" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44324792      <row Id="44324792" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44325051" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44324792" CreationDate="2017-06-02T09:11:02.437" Score="4" Body="<p>This is an implementation detail.</p>

<p>In this line</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println("In two days.", today + 2)
</code></pre>

<p><code>today</code> is of type <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Weekday" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>time.Weekday</code></a> which has <code>int</code> as its underlying type, <code>2</code> is an untyped integer constant, which will be converted to <code>time.Weekday</code> and the addition will be carried out.</p>

<p>The implementation of <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#Println" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>fmt.Println()</code></a> will check if values passed to it implement <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#Stringer" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>fmt.Stringer</code></a>, and because <code>time.Weekday</code> does, its <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Weekday.String" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>String()</code></a> method will be called whose implementation is:</p>

<pre><code>// String returns the English name of the day ("Sunday", "Monday", ...).
func (d Weekday) String() string { return days[d] }
</code></pre>

<p>Where <code>days</code> is an array of 7 elements:</p>

<pre><code>var days = [...]string{
    "Sunday",
    "Monday",
    "Tuesday",
    "Wednesday",
    "Thursday",
    "Friday",
    "Saturday",
  }
</code></pre>

<p>There is no range check in <code>Weekday.String()</code> because <code>time.Saturday + 2</code> for example is not a weekday. <code>Weekday.String()</code> only guarantees to work properly for the constants defined in the <code>time</code> package:</p>

<pre><code>type Weekday int

const (
    Sunday Weekday = iota
    Monday
    Tuesday
    Wednesday
    Thursday
    Friday
    Saturday
)
</code></pre>

<p>If you want to make it work, you have to use the remainder after dividing by 7, like this:</p>

<pre><code>switch day {
case (today + 0) % 7:
    fmt.Println("Today.")
case (today + 1) % 7:
    fmt.Println("Tomorrow.", (today+1)%7)
case (today + 2) % 7:
    fmt.Println("In two days.", (today+2)%7)
default:
    fmt.Println("Too far away.", (today+2)%7)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T14:27:19.653" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T14:27:19.653" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44325232      <row Id="44325232" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44326377" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44325232" CreationDate="2017-06-02T10:11:50.853" Score="3" Body="<p>It's really easy to test it:</p>

<pre><code>func Test1(t *testing.T) {
    fmt.Println("Test1 start")
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
    fmt.Println("Test1 end")
}

func Test2(t *testing.T) {
    fmt.Println("Test2 start")
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
    fmt.Println("Test2 end")
}

func Test3(t *testing.T) {
    fmt.Println("Test3 start")
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
    fmt.Println("Test3 end")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Running it with <code>go test</code>, the output shows it's sequential:</p>

<pre><code>Test1 start
Test1 end
Test2 start
Test2 end
Test3 start
Test3 end
</code></pre>

<p>So normal tests are executed one after the other, sequentially, but don't forget that order is not defined: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31201858/how-to-run-golang-tests-sequentially/31204016#31204016">How to run golang tests sequentially?</a></p>

<p>Also note that a test function can mark itself eligible for parallel execution, paralell with other tests that also do the same using the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#T.Parallel" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>T.Parallel()</code></a> method:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Parallel signals that this test is to be run in parallel with (and only with) other parallel tests.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So if we modify the above testing code to:</p>

<pre><code>func Test1(t *testing.T) {
    t.Parallel()
    fmt.Println("Test1 start")
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
    fmt.Println("Test1 end")
}

func Test2(t *testing.T) {
    t.Parallel()
    fmt.Println("Test2 start")
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
    fmt.Println("Test2 end")
}

func Test3(t *testing.T) {
    fmt.Println("Test3 start")
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
    fmt.Println("Test3 end")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Running it again with <code>go test</code>, the output is:</p>

<pre><code>Test3 start
Test3 end
Test1 start
Test2 start
Test2 end
Test1 end
</code></pre>

<p>What does this prove? The order of tests is not defined, <code>Test3</code> was executed first this time. And then <code>Test1</code> and <code>Test2</code> were run <em>parallel</em>.</p>

<p>There are some testing flags that control parallel execution. For example the <code>-parallel</code> flag specifies how many of these may run parallel. If you execute it with <code>go test -parallel=1</code>, the output will again become sequential, but the order will be <code>Test3</code>, <code>Test1</code>, <code>Test2</code>.</p>

<p>Also note that <a href="https://golang.org/doc/go1.7#testing" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go 1.7 introduced subtests and subbenchmarks</a>. You can read more about this in blog post <a href="https://blog.golang.org/subtests" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Using Subtests and Sub-benchmarks</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>In Go 1.7, the <code>testing</code> package introduces a Run method on the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#T.Run" rel="nofollow noreferrer">T</a> and <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#B.Run" rel="nofollow noreferrer">B</a> types that allows for the creation of subtests and sub-benchmarks. The introduction of subtests and sub-benchmarks enables better handling of failures, fine-grained control of which tests to run from the command line, control of parallelism, and often results in simpler and more maintainable code.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Subtests and subbenchmarks may run parallel, and there are a number of flags that may control their execution, e.g. <code>-parallel</code>, <code>-p</code>, <code>-cpu</code>. Run <code>go help testflag</code> to see the complete list of testing flags.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T11:39:57.023" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T11:39:57.023" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44301262      <row Id="44301262" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44326496" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44301262" CreationDate="2017-06-02T10:17:57.693" Score="1" Body="<p>If you actually want to convert a file content to a <code>[]string</code>, you can use <code>bufio.Scanner</code> which is cleaner (IMO) and more efficient than the code you posted:</p>

<pre><code>func readFile(filename string) ([]string, error) {
    file, err := os.Open(filename)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }   
    defer file.Close()

    scanner := bufio.NewScanner(file)

    var data []string

    for scanner.Scan() {
        line := scanner.Text()
        data = append(data, line)
    }   
    if err = scanner.Err(); err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }   

    return data, nil 
}
</code></pre>

<p>Here's a benchmark* comparing the original function (<code>readFile1</code>) and my function (<code>readFile2</code>):</p>

<pre><code>BenchmarkReadFile1-8         300       4632189 ns/op     3035552 B/op      10570 allocs/op
BenchmarkReadFile2-8        1000       1695820 ns/op     2169655 B/op      10587 allocs/op
</code></pre>

<p>*the benchmark read a sample file of 1.2 MiB and ~10K lines</p>

<p>The new code runs in 36% of the time and 71% of the memory used by the original function.</p>
" OwnerUserId="38333" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T10:17:57.693" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44330146      <row Id="44330146" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44330549" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44330146" CreationDate="2017-06-02T13:49:02.650" Score="0" Body="<p>On top of @Adrian's suggestions, if you have to ensure one way communication on a channel, you can always use an anonymous function:</p>

<pre><code>for a:=0; a &lt;=2; a++{
  go func f(ch &lt;-string) {
    SomeFunc(ch)
  }(slcChanStruct[a].chMessages)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that you'll have to pass the channel to <code>SomeFunc</code> instead of the struct.</p>

<p>If you still want to perform both way communication on your channel, you can re assign the channel to a one directional type:</p>

<pre><code>type ChanStruct struct {
    chMessages chan string
}

type ChanStructRecv struct {
    chMessages &lt;-chan string
}

// Update SomeFunc type:

func SomeFunc(s ChanStructRecv) {
  // ...
}
</code></pre>

<p>Finally, the loop can be modified similarly:</p>

<pre><code>for a:=0; a &lt;=2; a++{
  go func f(s ChanStruct) {
    var sr ChanStructRecv
    sr.chMessages = s.chMessages
    SomeFunc(sr)
  }(slcChanStruct[a])
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3129778" LastEditorUserId="3129778" LastEditDate="2017-06-02T13:58:22.977" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T13:58:22.977" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44324800      <row Id="44324800" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44331242" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44324800" CreationDate="2017-06-02T14:22:54.427" Score="6" Body="<p>You just need to teach your <code>MyT</code> type that you want it to consider equality in terms of its composite fields:</p>

<pre><code>julia&gt; immutable MyT
           A::String
           B::Int64
       end
       import Base: ==, hash
       ==(x::MyT, y::MyT) = x.A == y.A &amp;&amp; x.B == y.B
       hash(x::MyT, h::UInt) = hash(x.A, hash(x.B, hash(0x7d6979235cb005d0, h)))

julia&gt; a = Dict(MyT("Tom",191)=&gt;1,MyT("Bob",20)=&gt;1,MyT("Jo",315)=&gt;1,MyT("Luc",493)=&gt;1)
Dict{MyT,Int64} with 4 entries:
  MyT("Jo", 315)  =&gt; 1
  MyT("Luc", 493) =&gt; 1
  MyT("Tom", 191) =&gt; 1
  MyT("Bob", 20)  =&gt; 1

julia&gt; haskey(a, MyT("Tom",191))
true

julia&gt; in((MyT("Tom",191) =&gt; 1), a)
true
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="176071" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T14:22:54.427" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44331078      <row Id="44331078" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44331759" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44331078" CreationDate="2017-06-02T14:50:25.097" Score="1" Body="<p>As @JimB noted, converting a relative path to an absolute path is not only OS-specific, it's context-specific: the same relative path on different systems (regardless of OS) can yield different paths; in fact, even on <em>the same system</em>, converting relative to absolute from different working directories can yield different paths. Again as @JimB noted, you can use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/path/#Clean" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>path.Clean</code></a> to remove any unnecessary or reduntant relative path components (e.g. turn <code>/dir/../otherDir/./subDir/</code> into <code>/otherDir/subDir/</code>), but that's the closest you'll get to anything not context-sensitive.</p>

<p>If you just want to convert the <em>representation</em>, there's <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/path/filepath/#ToSlash" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>filepath.ToSlash</code></a> which will replace all platform-specific separators with forward slashes. If you're trying to re-use a path across systems, you could run <code>ToSlash</code> on the input, store the "generic" path using forward slashes, then on the target system use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/path/filepath/#FromSlash" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>filepath.FromSlash</code></a> to convert it back to the platform-specific path separator.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T14:50:25.097" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44333467      <row Id="44333467" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44334620" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44333467" CreationDate="2017-06-02T17:41:15.573" Score="2" Body="<p>You can use the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/#hdr-Functions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">index</a> function to access a map.</p>

<pre><code>{{ range .Database }} 
    {{ index $.Status . }}
{{ end }}
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/cJebtPvRMX" rel="nofollow noreferrer">play</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8023512" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T17:41:15.573" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44338582      <row Id="44338582" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44338853" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44338582" CreationDate="2017-06-02T23:49:31.090" Score="2" Body="<p>You just need to parse the time using the input layout and then print it using the output layout. The layout always specifies how the reference time (Mon Jan 2 15:04:05 MST 2006) would look in the given format. I think this is what you want:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    value := "April 20, 1996"
    layout := "January 2, 2006"
    t, _ := time.Parse(layout, value)
    fmt.Println(t)
    fmt.Println("time:", t.Format("2006-01-02"))
}
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/time/</a> for more information.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3068258" LastActivityDate="2017-06-02T23:49:31.090" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44196113      <row Id="44196113" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44342358" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44196113" CreationDate="2017-06-03T09:20:46.323" Score="1" Body="<p>Thanks to @alex-blex's answer which gave me the start. But this is what finally worked for me:</p>

<pre><code>session, err := mgo.Dial("rs1.example.net?connect=direct")
if err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
defer session.Close()
session.SetMode(mgo.Monotonic, true)

config := bson.M{
    "_id": "my_replica_set",
    "members": []bson.M{
        {"_id": 0, "host": "rs1.example.net:27017"},
        {"_id": 1, "host": "rs2.example.net:27017", "priority": 2},
        {"_id": 2, "host": "rs3.example.net", "arbiterOnly": true},
    },
}
result := bson.M{}
if err := session.Run(bson.M{"replSetInitiate": config}, &amp;result); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Notice the following:</p>

<ol>
<li><p><code>?connect=direct</code> in the connection string. </p>

<p>If not specified, the connection will timeout, probably because the replica set has not been initialized yet.</p></li>
<li><p><code>session.SetMode(mgo.Monotonic, true)</code> </p>

<p>Session mode should be <code>monotonic</code> as the default session used by mgo is <code>primary</code> which performs all operations on primary. Since the replica set has not been initialized yet, there wont be a primary and the operation (in this case, <code>replSetInitiate</code>) will just timeout</p></li>
<li><p><code>"_id": "my_replica_set"</code> in the config</p>

<p>For this to work, the mongo servers will have to be started with the replica set name <code>my_replica_set</code>. One way of doing that would be:</p>

<pre><code>mongod --replSet my_replica_set
</code></pre></li>
<li>As per <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2#Session.Run" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Mgo docs</a> use session.Run() for commands on the "admin" database</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="1351876" LastActivityDate="2017-06-03T09:20:46.323" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44341662      <row Id="44341662" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44342940" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44341662" CreationDate="2017-06-03T10:31:28.067" Score="3" Body="<p>You're using a capture variable <code>fn</code> across <code>goroutine</code>, in which the variable will be overridden during iteration. What is seen by all <code>goroutines</code> is the latest job in the <code>funcs</code>. Change your code in <code>Pipe</code> function to the following:</p>

<pre><code>for _, fn := range funcs {
    out = make(chan interface{})
    wg.Add(1)
    go func(f job, inx, outx chan interface{}) {
        f(inx, outx)
        close(outx)
        wg.Done()
    }(fn, in, out)

    in = out
}
</code></pre>

<p>It's one of <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/CommonMistakes" rel="nofollow noreferrer">common mistake</a> in golang. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-03T10:31:28.067" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44290770      <row Id="44290770" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44343600" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44290770" CreationDate="2017-06-03T11:50:17.417" Score="0" Body="<p>As the connection is instantly closed after sending the message the close handshake is not completed. One way to fix it is by adding a <code>sleep</code> call. Though it would be better to implement the close handshake correctly.</p>
" OwnerUserId="562465" LastEditorUserId="562465" LastEditDate="2017-06-03T17:01:05.533" LastActivityDate="2017-06-03T17:01:05.533" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44340192      <row Id="44340192" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44345955" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44340192" CreationDate="2017-06-03T16:09:41.163" Score="3" Body="<p>When you upgrade HTTP connection to a WebSocket connection using Gorilla, it hijacks that connection and net/http server stops serving it. This means, that you can't rely on a net/http events from that moment.</p>

<p>Check this: <a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/issues/123" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/issues/123</a></p>

<p>So, what you can do here is to start new goroutine for every new WebSocket connection, which will read data from this connection and write a message to a <code>quit</code> channel on a failure.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8099995" LastActivityDate="2017-06-03T16:09:41.163" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44346123      <row Id="44346123" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44348099" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44346123" CreationDate="2017-06-03T20:03:39.027" Score="1" Body="<p>You would generally define different types that implement your <code>Solver</code> interface and then define the <code>Solve</code> function on those types.</p>

<pre><code>func (s *BackTrackSolver) Solve() {  }
func (s *PermutateSolver) Solve() {  }
</code></pre>

<p>Because the types have distinct names there is no name clash. 
You can try it out online in <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/39Mgo9rkSh" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the go playground</a>.</p>

<p>About your package convention question: I think a good approach is to start with all code in a single package and only export the types and functions you actually want to expose to your callers. Then later when you your <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohesion_(computer_science)" rel="nofollow noreferrer">code cohesion</a> drops you should start splitting out code into multiple packages.</p>

<p>Also have a look at the "Organizing Go code" article from the <a href="https://blog.golang.org/organizing-go-code" rel="nofollow noreferrer">go blog</a>, subsection "What to put into a package" (short read).</p>
" OwnerUserId="645974" LastActivityDate="2017-06-03T20:03:39.027" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44347100      <row Id="44347100" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44349462" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44347100" CreationDate="2017-06-03T23:33:34.663" Score="2" Body="<p>Use gin's <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/gin-gonic/gin#Context.File" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Context.File</code></a> to serve file content. This method internally calls <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#ServeFile" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http.ServeFile</a> builtin function. The code snippets will be:</p>

<pre><code>import "path/filepath"


// ...
router := gin.Default()
// ... 

router.GET("/book/cover/:filename", func(c *gin.Context) {
    rootDir := "/uploads/img/"
    name := c.Param("filename")
    filePath, err :=  filepath.Abs(rootDir + name)
    if err != nil {
        c.AbortWithStatus(404)
    }

    //Only allow access to file/directory under rootDir
    //The following code is for ilustration since HasPrefix is deprecated.
    //Replace with correct one when https://github.com/golang/dep/issues/296 fixed
    if !filepath.HasPrefix(filePath, rootDir) {
        c.AbortWithStatus(404)
    }

    c.File(filePath)
})
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Update</strong></p>

<p>As pointed by zerkms, the path name <strong>must be sanitized</strong> before passing it <code>Context.File</code>. Simple sanitizer is added in the snippet. Please adapt to your needs. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-04T03:34:03.940" LastActivityDate="2017-06-04T03:34:03.940" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44347093      <row Id="44347093" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44350662" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44347093" CreationDate="2017-06-04T04:02:07.133" Score="2" Body="<p>Go doesn't support this directly like C, partially because you should be reading a line and using something like <code>strings.FieldsFunc</code>. But that's naturally a very simplistic view. For data formatted in a homogeneous manner, you could use <code>bufio.Scanner</code> to essentially do the same thing with any <code>io.Reader</code>. However, if you had to deal with something like this format:</p>

<pre><code>// Name; email@domain
//
// Anything other than ';' is valid for name.
// Anything before '@' is valid for email.
// For domain, only A-Z, a-z, and 0-9, as well as '-' and '.' are valid.
sscanf("%[^;]; %[^@]@%[-." ALNUM "]", name, email, domain);
</code></pre>

<p>then you'd run into trouble because you're now dealing with a particular state. In such a case, you might prefer working with <code>bufio.Reader</code> to manually parse things. There's also the option of implementing <code>fmt.Scanner</code>. Here's some sample code to give you an idea of how easy it can be to implement <code>fmt.Scanner</code>:</p>

<pre><code>// Scanset acts as a filter when scanning strings.
// The zero value of a Scanset will discard all non-whitespace characters.
type Scanset struct {
    ps        *string
    delimFunc func(rune) bool
}

// Create a new Scanset to filter delimiter characters.
// Once f(delimChar) returns false, scanning will end.
// If s is nil, characters for which f(delimChar) returns true are discarded.
// If f is nil, !unicode.IsSpace(delimChar) is used
// (i.e. read until unicode.IsSpace(delimChar) returns true).
func NewScanset(s *string, f func(r rune) bool) *Scanset {
    return &amp;Scanset{
        ps:        s,
        delimFunc: f,
    }
}

// Scan implements the fmt.Scanner interface for the Scanset type.
func (s *Scanset) Scan(state fmt.ScanState, verb rune) error {
    if verb != 'v' &amp;&amp; verb != 's' {
        return errors.New("scansets only work with %v and %s verbs")
    }
    tok, err := state.Token(false, s.delimFunc)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    if s.ps != nil {
        *s.ps = string(tok)
    }
    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Y2vLSOk7ob" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Playground example</a></p>

<p>It's not C's scansets, but it's close enough. As mentioned, you should be validating your data anyway, even with formatted input, because formatting lacks context (and adding it while dealing with formatting violates the KISS principle and worsens the readability of your code).</p>

<p>For example, a short regex like <code>[A-Za-z]([A-Za-z0-9-]?.)[A-Za-z0-9]</code> isn't enough to validate a domain name, and a simplistic scanset would simply be the equivalent of <code>[A-Za-z0-9.-]</code>. The scanset, however, would be enough to scan the string from a file or whatever other reader you might be using, but it wouldn't be enough to validate the string alone. For that, a regex or even a proper library would be a much better option.</p>
" OwnerUserId="539810" LastActivityDate="2017-06-04T04:02:07.133" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44351159      <row Id="44351159" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44351176" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44351159" CreationDate="2017-06-04T05:54:28.500" Score="4" Body="<p>It usually not good practice to use pointers to channels.</p>

<p>The size of a channel value is equal to the size of a pointer. The size is independent of the number of values in the channel. </p>

<p>You do not reduce copying by using a pointer to a channel because copying the pointer has the same cost as copying the channel.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-06-04T06:03:26.200" LastActivityDate="2017-06-04T06:03:26.200" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44349115      <row Id="44349115" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44353086" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44349115" CreationDate="2017-06-04T10:32:30.367" Score="2" Body="<p>Let's say you want to fetch a set of <a href="https://api.github.com/users?since=135" rel="nofollow noreferrer">github users</a> and want to print their nicknames (<code>Login</code> field in <code>api.github.com</code>).</p>

<p>Given a User array example:</p>

<pre><code>[{
  "login": "simonjefford",
  "id": 136,
  "avatar_url": "https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/136?v=3",
  "gravatar_id": "",
  "url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford",
  "html_url": "https://github.com/simonjefford",
  "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/followers",
  "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/following{/other_user}",
  "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/gists{/gist_id}",
  "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
  "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/subscriptions",
  "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/orgs",
  "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/repos",
  "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/events{/privacy}",
  "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/simonjefford/received_events",
  "type": "User",
  "site_admin": false
}]
</code></pre>

<p>You need a proper struct to handle it:</p>

<pre><code>type Users []struct {
  Login string `json:"login"`
  ID int `json:"id"`
  AvatarURL string `json:"avatar_url"`
  GravatarID string `json:"gravatar_id"`
  URL string `json:"url"`
  HTMLURL string `json:"html_url"`
  FollowersURL string `json:"followers_url"`
  FollowingURL string `json:"following_url"`
  GistsURL string `json:"gists_url"`
  StarredURL string `json:"starred_url"`
  SubscriptionsURL string `json:"subscriptions_url"`
  OrganizationsURL string `json:"organizations_url"`
  ReposURL string `json:"repos_url"`
  EventsURL string `json:"events_url"`
  ReceivedEventsURL string `json:"received_events_url"`
  Type string `json:"type"`
  SiteAdmin bool `json:"site_admin"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>I suggest you to use <a href="https://mholt.github.io/json-to-go/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">json-to-go</a> to have a nice a clean struct given a json.</p>

<p>Then you can do the following:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
  "fmt"
  "encoding/json"
  "net/http"
  "log"
  "io/ioutil"
)

func main() {

  response, err := http.Get("https://api.github.com/users?since=135")
  if err != nil {
     log.Fatal(err)
  } else {

    defer response.Body.Close()
    users := UnmarshalUsers(response)
    for _, u := range users {
        //Print each user's Login nickname
        fmt.Println(u.Login)
    }

  }

}
</code></pre>

<p>Where <code>UnmarshalUsers</code> is</p>

<pre><code>func UnmarshalUsers(r *http.Response) Users {
    body, err := ioutil.ReadAll(r.Body)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    var users Users
    err = json.Unmarshal(body, &amp;users)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    return users
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4684539" LastActivityDate="2017-06-04T10:32:30.367" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44359812      <row Id="44359812" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44359942" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44359812" CreationDate="2017-06-04T23:49:38.203" Score="4" Body="<p>String literals are not <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">addressable</a>.</p>

<p>Take the address of variable containing the empty string:</p>

<pre><code>s := ""
t.value = &amp;s
</code></pre>

<p>or use new:</p>

<pre><code>t.value = new(string)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-06-04T23:57:15.823" LastActivityDate="2017-06-04T23:57:15.823" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44359916      <row Id="44359916" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44359968" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44359916" CreationDate="2017-06-04T23:55:17.920" Score="5" Body="<p>You need to allocate memory for the <code>Student</code> <code>struct</code>. For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type Student struct {
    Name string
}

func main() {
    var newStudent *Student

    newStudent = new(Student)
    newStudent.Name = "John"
    fmt.Println(*newStudent)

    newStudent = &amp;Student{}
    newStudent.Name = "Jane"
    fmt.Println(*newStudent)

    newStudent = &amp;Student{Name: "Jill"}
    fmt.Println(*newStudent)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>{John}
{Jane}
{Jill}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-06-05T05:41:15.527" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T05:41:15.527" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44361778      <row Id="44361778" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44361889" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44361778" CreationDate="2017-06-05T04:55:06.127" Score="2" Body="<pre><code>//Crypto is the currency object
type Crypto struct {
    Iso           string //this is the key (ex: BTC_BCN)
    Id            int
    Last          string
    LowestAsk     string
    HighestBid    string
    PercentChange string
    BaseVolume    string
    QuoteVolume   string
    IsFrozen      int
    High24hr      string
    Low24hr       string
}
</code></pre>

<p>You need to to export the fields by capitalising first character. On top of that, your <code>float64</code> datas are in type: <code>string</code>,hence either you read as string or format before assign to object  <code>Crypto</code>.</p>

<hr>

<p><strong>Updated:</strong></p>

<p>As pointed by @skomp, you may use a tag to annotate the type you're receiving from json file.</p>

<pre><code>type Crypto struct {
    CryptoKey
    Id            int
    Last          float64 `json:"last,string"`
    LowestAsk     float64 `json:"lowestAsk,string"`
    HighestBid    float64 `json:"highestBid,string"`
    PercentChange float64 `json:"percentChange,string"`
    BaseVolume    float64 `json:"baseVolume,string"`
    QuoteVolume   float64 `json:"quoteVolume,string"`
    IsFrozen      int
    High24hr      float64 `json:"high24hr,string"`
    Low24hr       float64 `json:"low24hr,string"`
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1248913" LastEditorUserId="1248913" LastEditDate="2017-06-06T00:47:01.247" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T00:47:01.247" CommentCount="2" />

<row Id="44364375" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44363096" CreationDate="2017-06-05T08:03:21.300" Score="1" Body="<blockquote>

<p>refers to HTTP Handlers that have already been called as part of incoming connections. All these handlers need to be closed / returned, usually by calling <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#ResponseWriter" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>w.Write or w.WriteHeader</code></a></p>

question:
44358275      <row Id="44358275" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44365728" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44358275" CreationDate="2017-06-05T09:26:12.343" Score="0" Body="<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/users/6207052/" title="@putu">@putu</a> pointed me to the right direction, all I had to do was tune <code>CFLAGS</code> to include <code>musl</code>.</p>

<p>Cleaned up <code>C</code> comment in <code>lua.go</code>:</p>

<pre><code>/*
#cgo CFLAGS: -I/usr/include/luajit-2.0 -I/usr/local/musl/include/
#cgo LDFLAGS: -L/usr/local/lib -lluajit-5.1
#include &lt;lua.h&gt;
#include &lt;stdlib.h&gt;
#include "golua.h"
*/
import "C"
</code></pre>

<p>Looks like everything builds just fine:</p>

<pre><code>$ CC="/usr/local/musl/bin/musl-gcc" go build --ldflags '-linkmode external -extldflags "-static"' basic.go
$ file basic
basic: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, not stripped
$ ./basic 
Hello World!
test2 arg: 42
from bottom: 42
hello world! from go!
hello world! from go!
hello world! from go!
Ciao [string "test2(42)"]:1: attempt to call global 'test2' (a nil value)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1011543" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T09:26:12.343" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44368901      <row Id="44368901" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44368984" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44368901" CreationDate="2017-06-05T12:29:45.763" Score="1" Body="<p>You only read from <code>operationOutcomes</code> up to <code>writeOpCount</code> times, even though in <code>writeWorker</code> each execution can result in up to 3 messages being written on that channel (none of your error cases causes the function to return, to it continues processing). Because it's unbuffered and it stops being read, at some point the workers writing to it can no longer add messages and so lock forever.</p>

<p>Also, since you only call <code>WriteC</code> once and it does not loop, it will only ever read and process one message from the <code>inputs</code>. If <code>writeOpCount</code> is > 1, then it will lock forever within the first loop when it tries to queue a second message.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-06-05T12:32:57.820" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T12:32:57.820" CommentCount="3" />

question:

<p>You are treating the <code>XMLEntry</code> and <code>XMLLink</code> tags as attributes.</p>

question:
44371865      <row Id="44371865" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44372148" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44371865" CreationDate="2017-06-05T15:16:35.913" Score="1" Body="<p>Posts is an array of Post struct but you defined Post as array it is your first mistake, also Unmarshal doesn't returns result it returns only error and fills given parameter.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "net/http"
    "log"
    "fmt"
    "io/ioutil"
    "encoding/json"
)

type Post struct {
        UserId int `json:"userId"`
        ID int `json:"id"`
        Title string `json:"title"`
        Body string `json:"body"`
}

type Posts []Post


func main (){
    resp, err := http.Get("https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com/posts")

    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    content, _ := ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)

    var posts Posts

    err = json.Unmarshal(content, &amp;posts)

    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }


    fmt.Println(posts[0].Body)

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2232794" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T15:16:35.913" CommentCount="0" />

Probably not the cleanest solution but it allowed me to customize the struct to the degree I wanted.</p>

question:
44371691      <row Id="44371691" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44372936" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44371691" CreationDate="2017-06-05T16:00:37.367" Score="0" Body="<p>Looking at @jimt's answer on <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6807590/how-to-stop-a-goroutine">how to stop a goroutine</a> and the helpful comments by @JimB. I figured out what I needed to do to translate my example to Go.</p>

<p>Here is a pseudo-go implementation of my example:</p>

<pre><code>main() {
    numworkers := 10
    jobqueue := make(string[])

    loop numworkers
        go checkwork(jobqueue)

    findwork('/home/work/todo')
    //join goroutines
    close(jobqueue)
}

checkwork(jobqueue chan) {
    for j := range jobqueue {
        dowork(j)
    }
}

dowork(job) {
    //huray, we have work!
}

findwork(rootPath) {
    recurse files f in rootPath
        if isdir(f) == false
            jobqueue &lt;- f.path
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4135670" LastEditorUserId="4135670" LastEditDate="2017-06-05T21:34:54.677" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T21:34:54.677" CommentCount="16" />

question:
44370277      <row Id="44370277" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44372954" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44370277" CreationDate="2017-06-05T16:01:37.447" Score="5" Body="<p>So you're confusing two concepts here.  A pointer to a struct and a pointer to an interface are not the same.  An interface can store either a struct directly <em>or</em> a pointer to a struct.  In the latter case, you still just use the interface directly, <em>not</em> a pointer to the interface.  For example:</p>

<pre><code>type Fooer interface {
    Foo()
}

type Foo struct{}

func (f Foo) Foo() {}

func main() {
    var f1 Foo
    var f2 *Foo = &amp;Foo{}

    DoFoo(f1)
    DoFoo(f2)
}

func DoFoo(f Fooer) {
    fmt.Printf("[%T] %+v\n", f, f)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/BGV9d1-IRW" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/BGV9d1-IRW</a></p>

<p>In both cases, the <code>f</code> variable in <code>DoFoo</code> is just an interface, <em>not</em> a pointer to an interface.  However, when storing <code>f2</code>, the interface <em>holds</em> a pointer to a <code>Foo</code> structure.</p>

<p>Pointers to interfaces are almost <em>never</em> useful.  In fact, the Go runtime was specifically changed a few versions back to no longer automatically dereference interface pointers (like it does for structure pointers), to discourage their use.  In the overwhelming majority of cases, a pointer to an interface reflects a misunderstanding of how interfaces are supposed to work.</p>

<p>However, there is a limitation on interfaces.  If you pass a structure directly into an interface, only <em>value</em> methods of that type (ie. <code>func (f Foo) Foo()</code>, not <code>func (f *Foo) Foo()</code>) can be used to fulfill the interface.  This is because you're storing a copy of the original structure in the interface, so pointer methods would have unexpected effects (ie. unable to alter the original structure).  Thus the default rule of thumb is to <strong>store pointers to structures in interfaces</strong>, unless there's a compelling reason not to.</p>

<p>Specifically with your code, if you change the AddFilter function signature to:</p>

<pre><code>func (fp *FilterMap) AddFilter(f FilterInterface) uuid.UUID
</code></pre>

<p>And the GetFilterByID signature to:</p>

<pre><code>func (fp *FilterMap) GetFilterByID(i uuid.UUID) FilterInterface
</code></pre>

<p>Your code will work as expected.  <code>fieldfilter</code> is of type <code>*FieldFilter</code>, which fullfills the <code>FilterInterface</code> interface type, and thus <code>AddFilter</code> will accept it.</p>

<p>Here's a couple of good references for understanding how methods, types, and interfaces work and integrate with each other in Go:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.goinggo.net/2014/05/methods-interfaces-and-embedded-types.html" rel="noreferrer">https://www.goinggo.net/2014/05/methods-interfaces-and-embedded-types.html</a></li>
<li><a href="https://blog.golang.org/laws-of-reflection" rel="noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/laws-of-reflection</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="4551301" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T16:01:37.447" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44374829      <row Id="44374829" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44374878" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44374829" CreationDate="2017-06-05T17:56:04.703" Score="2" Body="<p><code>pic.Show</code> takes a single argument of type <code>func(int, int) [][]uint8</code> - you need to pass it a function. You're passing the <em>result of executing</em> a <code>func(int, int) [][]uint8</code>, i.e. a <code>[][]uint8</code>. What you want would be:</p>

<pre><code>pic.Show(Pic)
</code></pre>

<p>Passing in your function <code>Pic</code> itself, which meets the requirements.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T17:56:04.703" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44376517      <row Id="44376517" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44377226" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44376517" CreationDate="2017-06-05T20:32:54.423" Score="3" Body="<p>You may use a simple <code>\b"\b</code> regex that matches a double quote only when preceded <em>and</em> followed with word boundaries:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "regexp"
)

func main() {
    var a = "\"test1\",\"test2\",\"tes\"t3\""
    fmt.Println(RemoveQuotes(a))
}

func RemoveQuotes(s string) string {
    re := regexp.MustCompile(`\b"\b`)
    return re.ReplaceAllString(s, "")
}
</code></pre>

<p>See the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/3WS3Bgxr-E" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go demo</a> printing <code>"test1","test2","test3"</code>.</p>

<p>Also, see the <a href="https://regex101.com/r/AjJPLy/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">online regex demo</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3832970" LastActivityDate="2017-06-05T20:32:54.423" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44380836      <row Id="44380836" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44380935" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44380836" CreationDate="2017-06-06T03:27:42.703" Score="4" Body="<p>The <code>Init</code> method receiver <code>(fb foobar)</code> is a value. It should be a pointer <code>(fb *foobar)</code>. For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

type profile map[string]float64

type foobar struct {
    foo profile
    bar map[string]profile
}

func (fb *foobar) Init() {
    fb.foo = make(profile)
    fb.bar = make(map[string]profile)
}

func (fb foobar) Set() {
    fb.bar["foo1"] = make(profile)
}

func main() {
    test := foobar{}
    test.Init()
    test.Set()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Reference:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#methods_on_values_or_pointers" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Should I define methods on values or pointers?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-06-06T03:33:56.467" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T03:33:56.467" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44381350      <row Id="44381350" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44381489" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44381350" CreationDate="2017-06-06T04:36:12.550" Score="3" Body="<p>The token is defined by the scanner's <a href="https://godoc.org/bufio#SplitFunc" rel="nofollow noreferrer">split function</a>. Scan() returns when the split function finds a token or there's an error.</p>

<p>The String() and Bytes() methods both return the current token. The String() method <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/2d86f4942868c1309051062237cf4d424d588e9c/src/bufio/scan.go#L107" rel="nofollow noreferrer">returns a copy of the token</a>. The Bytes() method does not allocate memory and <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/2d86f4942868c1309051062237cf4d424d588e9c/src/bufio/scan.go#L101" rel="nofollow noreferrer">returns a slice</a> that may use a backing array that's overwritten on a subsequent call to Scan().</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/SliceTricks#copy" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Copy the slice</a> returned from Bytes() to avoid this issue:</p>

<pre><code>for scanner.Scan() {
    bs = append(bs, append([]byte(nil), scanner.Bytes()...))
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-06-06T11:11:22.837" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T11:11:22.837" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44380031      <row Id="44380031" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44382863" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44380031" CreationDate="2017-06-06T06:33:24.877" Score="2" Body="<p>Capture the symbols you need to keep and replace with <code>$1</code> backreference to restore the captured part in the resulting string:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "regexp"
)

func main() {
    s := "^Hello, my #friend @%%   !!."
    re := regexp.MustCompile(`([#@])|[\p{P}\p{S}\d]`)
    s = re.ReplaceAllString(s, "$1")
    fmt.Println(s)
}
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/LLUEtpmUby" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this Go demo</a> printing <code>Hello my #friend @   </code>.</p>

<p>Note that <code>^</code> does not belong to the <code>\p{P}</code>  category, thus, I added <code>\p{S}</code> one.</p>

<p>The pattern is <code>([#@])|[\p{P}\p{S}\d]</code>, see <a href="https://regex101.com/r/VQ2ZZh/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">its online demo</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Details</strong>:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>([#@])</code> - Capturing group 1 (referred to with <code>$1</code> / <code>${1}</code> from the replacement pattern) matching a <code>#</code> or <code>@</code></li>
<li><code>|</code> - or </li>
<li><code>[\p{P}\p{S}\d]</code> - a punctuation, symbol or digit char.</li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="3832970" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T06:33:24.877" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44385203      <row Id="44385203" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44385285" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44385203" CreationDate="2017-06-06T08:41:34.633" Score="4" Body="<p>You have 2 JSON inputs, and you're trying to unmarshal one into the other. That doesn't make any sense.</p>

<p>Model your JSON input (the object) with a type (struct), and unmarshal into that. For example:</p>

<pre><code>type Obj struct {
    Num  float64  `json:"num"`
    Strs []string `json:"strs"`
}

func main() {
    byt := []byte(`{"num":6.13,"strs":["a","b"]}`)

    var obj Obj
    if err := json.Unmarshal(byt, &amp;obj); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Println(obj)

}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/NJrNBUogGn" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>{6.13 [a b]}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T08:41:34.633" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44379851      <row Id="44379851" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44385791" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44379851" CreationDate="2017-06-06T09:05:51.397" Score="1" Body="<p>Try using <code>pq.StringArray</code> type for []string</p>

<pre><code>type MyStruct struct {
    Id   int
    Data pq.StringArray
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2180770" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T09:05:51.397" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44380054      <row Id="44380054" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44385800" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44380054" CreationDate="2017-06-06T09:06:13.990" Score="3" Body="<p>I think, you should implement it by yourself, because <code>filepath.Walk</code> doesn't allow you to set order.</p>

<p>Look at <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/34b455da4484dee20e8c355b50d24680224b58f2/src/path/filepath/path.go#L393" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Walk</a> method. It calls <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/34b455da4484dee20e8c355b50d24680224b58f2/src/path/filepath/path.go#L350" rel="nofollow noreferrer">walk</a>, which is relying on file names from <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/34b455da4484dee20e8c355b50d24680224b58f2/src/path/filepath/path.go#L408" rel="nofollow noreferrer">readDirNames</a>. So basically, you should make your own <code>Walk</code> method with another <code>readDirNames</code> logic.</p>

<p>Here's how you get files in the order of last-modified date (note, that I'm ignoring errors):</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "os"
    "sort"
)

type ByModTime []os.FileInfo

func (fis ByModTime) Len() int {
    return len(fis)
}

func (fis ByModTime) Swap(i, j int) {
    fis[i], fis[j] = fis[j], fis[i]
}

func (fis ByModTime) Less(i, j int) bool {
    return fis[i].ModTime().Before(fis[j].ModTime())
}

func main() {
    f, _ := os.Open("/")
    fis, _ := f.Readdir(-1)
    f.Close()
    sort.Sort(ByModTime(fis))

    for _, fi := range fis {
        fmt.Println(fi.Name())
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8099995" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T09:06:13.990" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44388292      <row Id="44388292" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44391691" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44388292" CreationDate="2017-06-06T13:42:04.473" Score="0" Body="<p>Gorilla <code>mux.Router</code> is supposed to be used to create mapping between a set of predefined rules (e.g. host, path, protocol, scheme, etc...) and it's handler (<code>http.Handler</code> or <code>http.HandlerFunc</code>). Gorilla mux can be used to replace standard server mux. If you combine <code>gorilla/mux</code> with built in http server mux as your original question, i.e.</p>

<pre><code>func main () {
    http.Handle("/v1", controllers.V1Router)
    if err := http.ListenAndServe(":8000", nil); err != nil {
        log.Fatal("Serving error.")
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>what actually happen when a client access <code>/v1</code> is <code>controllers.V1Router</code> will be called with request path <code>/v1</code> passed to <code>V1Router1</code>. In the <code>controllers.V1Router</code>, you defined that <code>/</code> will be handled by <code>BaseHandler</code>. However, since incoming request path is <code>/v1</code>, it won't match to your routing table. If you want to define sub routing, you can do as follows (this is what I mean in first comment):</p>

<pre><code>func main () {
    r := mux.NewRouter()
    v1 := r.PathPrefix("/v1").Subrouter()
    controllers.RegisterHandlers(v1)

    if err := http.ListenAndServe(":8000", r); err != nil {
        log.Fatal("Serving error.")
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then in the controllers (<code>base.controllers.go</code>) define</p>

<pre><code>//Register handlers and it's sub router
func RegisterHandlers(r *mux.Router) {
    //base handler, i.e. /v1
    r.StrictSlash(true)
    r.HandleFunc("/", BaseHandler)

    //example sub-router, i.e. /v1/example
    ex := r.PathPrefix("/example").Subrouter()
    ex.HandleFunc("/", ExampleHandler)

    //other handlers...
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-06T14:53:29.860" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T14:53:29.860" CommentCount="1" />

" OwnerUserId="615120" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T14:44:53.717" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44393995      <row Id="44393995" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44394873" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44393995" CreationDate="2017-06-06T16:05:08.783" Score="7" Body="<p>If you fail to cancel the context, the <a href="https://golang.org/src/context/context.go?s=9162:9288" rel="noreferrer">goroutine that WithCancel or WithTimeout created</a> will be retained in memory indefinitely (until the program shuts down), causing a memory leak.  If you do this a lot, your memory will balloon significantly.  It's best practice to use a <code>defer cancel()</code> immediately after calling <code>WithCancel()</code> or <code>WithTimeout()</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="4551301" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T16:05:08.783" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44395946      <row Id="44395946" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="44396164" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44395946" CreationDate="2017-06-06T17:23:16.107" Score="1" Body="<p>You can add a Go source directory to your project.  For example:</p>

   GloriousMomolith/

</code></pre>

<p>You can now import relative to the the <code>src</code> directory:</p>

<pre><code>import (
   "services/someservice"
)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T17:23:16.107" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44396155      <row Id="44396155" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44396616" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44396155" CreationDate="2017-06-06T17:49:40.737" Score="1" Body="<p>Using <a href="https://github.com/google/google-api-go-client/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Auto-generated Google APIs for Go</a> is only recommended if there is a <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Google Client Library for Go</a> developed for the service you are calling. There is not a client library yet for Dataflow.</p>

<p>To launch a Dataflow template from a Go app using default credentials:</p>

<pre><code>ctx := context.Background()
oauthClient, err := google.DefaultClient(ctx, dataflow.CloudPlatformScope)

dataflowService, err := dataflow.New(oauthClient)

if err != nil {
  panic(err)
}

templateRequest := dataflow.CreateJobFromTemplateRequest{
  GcsPath: "gcs path to template here",
  JobName: "choose a unique job name here",
  Parameters: map[string]string{
    "parameters": "for job",
  },
}

result, err := dataflowService.Projects.Templates.Create("project id", &amp;templateRequest).Do()

if err != nil {
  panic(err)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1017244" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T17:49:40.737" CommentCount="0" />
