question:
44391148      <row Id="44391148" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44399665" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44391148" CreationDate="2017-06-06T20:55:08.687" Score="2" Body="<p>So you'll need to send it to the <code>IP</code> address and <code>port</code> as provided by the <code>.torrent</code> metafile (<code>announce</code> field).</p>

<p>And once you open the <code>net.Conn</code> you can <code>conn.Write()</code> to the socket and similarly <code>conn.Read()</code> </p>

<p>So you've just about gotten i:</p>

<pre><code>    conn, err := net.Dial("udp", announceAddr:Port)
</code></pre>

<p>When connecting with <code>HTTP</code>, yeah you use the <code>/announce</code> endpoint, but not with <code>UDP</code></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.bittorrent.org/beps/bep_0015.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">specs</a> explain how many bytes to read and write (it is fixed at first, but later dynamic when it comes to reading the peer list). I've found this link, rather, the most useful: <a href="https://github.com/naim94a/udpt/wiki/The-BitTorrent-UDP-tracker-protocol" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/naim94a/udpt/wiki/The-BitTorrent-UDP-tracker-protocol</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4443226" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T20:55:08.687" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44400384      <row Id="44400384" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44400404" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44400384" CreationDate="2017-06-06T21:55:09.973" Score="2" Body="<p><code>*Dialer</code> and <code>*gomail.Dialer</code> are 2 different types. The specific error is because you don't have a <code>Dialer</code> type defined in your package, but you need to match the types in the signature, not just the name. Since <code>gomail.NewDialer</code> returns a <code>*gomail.Dialer</code>, use:</p>

<pre><code>func MyDialer() *gomail.Dialer {
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-06-06T22:00:46.647" LastActivityDate="2017-06-06T22:00:46.647" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44406213      <row Id="44406213" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44407622" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44406213" CreationDate="2017-06-07T08:38:31.937" Score="1" Body="<p>The problem is related to the type of <code>children</code> map. You are using <code>node</code> values in this map. As a result, you get new values every time you access a key and the changes are not reflected into the original 'parent' node.</p>

<p>The fault lies with this line:</p>

<pre><code>child, ok := mm[v]
</code></pre>

<p><code>child</code> is a <em>new variable</em> that is equal to the value of <code>node</code> <code>mm[v]</code>. The changes you make happen to this value while the <code>node</code> value in <code>mm</code> remains unchanged.</p>

<p>To fix this problem, you can use <code>*node</code> for values in <code>children</code>:</p>

<pre><code>type node struct {
    end      bool
    char     string
    children map[int32]*node
}
</code></pre>

<p>And fix the code accordingly:</p>

<pre><code>// ...
mm := current.children
if nil == mm {
    mm = make(map[int32]*node)
    current.children = mm
}
child, ok := mm[v]
if !ok {
    child = &amp;node{false, string(v), nil}
    mm[v] = child
}
current = child
// ...
</code></pre>

<p>Working example: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/XcmPY4Nx-O" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/XcmPY4Nx-O</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="3129778" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T08:38:31.937" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44409010      <row Id="44409010" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44410622" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44409010" CreationDate="2017-06-07T10:52:41.627" Score="3" Body="<p>For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
)

func main() {
    b := []byte{50, 48, 50, 53, 10}
    fmt.Println(b)
    b = bytes.TrimSuffix(b, []byte{10}) // Line Feed
    fmt.Println(b)

    b = []byte{50, 48, 50, 53, 10}
    fmt.Println(b)
    b = bytes.TrimSuffix(b, []byte("\n")) // Line Feed
    fmt.Println(b)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>[50 48 50 53 10]
[50 48 50 53]
[50 48 50 53 10]
[50 48 50 53]
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-06-07T11:04:18.523" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T11:04:18.523" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44406077      <row Id="44406077" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44412899" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44406077" CreationDate="2017-06-07T12:39:42.543" Score="2" Body="<p>You can't declare a new type with a pointer TypeSpec. Also declaring a new type is used specifically to remove the entire method set, so you won't have any of the original methods from the <code>*ssh.Client</code>.</p>

<p>What you want is to use composition by embedding the <code>*ssh.Client</code> in your own struct type:</p>

<pre><code>type Connection struct {
    *ssh.Client
}

func Connect(addr, user, password string) (*Connection, error) {
    sshConfig := &amp;ssh.ClientConfig{
        User: user,
        Auth: []ssh.AuthMethod{
            ssh.Password(password),
        },
        HostKeyCallback: ssh.HostKeyCallback(func(hostname string, remote net.Addr, key ssh.PublicKey) error { return nil }),
    }

    conn, err = ssh.Dial("tcp", addr, sshConfig)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    return &amp;Connection{conn}, nil
}

func (conn *Connection) SendCommand() ([]byte, error) {
    session, err := conn.NewSession()
    // ...
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-06-07T16:52:52.873" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T16:52:52.873" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44402160      <row Id="44402160" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44414202" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44402160" CreationDate="2017-06-07T13:32:58.357" Score="2" Body="<p>A <code>compute.Instance</code> is a <code>json.Marshaler</code>, so by embedding that type you are in essence giving your <code>CreateInstance</code> the <code>MarshalJSON</code> method from <code>compute.Instance</code>, which of course isn't going to output any of the fields in your <code>CreateInstance</code> struct.</p>

<p>You could define your own <code>MarshalJSON</code> method, and try to marshal the <code>Instance</code> manually or re-assign it to a new type that will use the default json output, but the API may be relying on the internal <code>MarshalJSON</code> behavior, so that's not guaranteed to be compatible, currently or with future versions.</p>

<p>Embedding types for json marshaling is is best avoided because it's all too easy to create confusing bugs like this. I would try to compose them in a different manner.</p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T13:32:58.357" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44415349      <row Id="44415349" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44415489" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44415349" CreationDate="2017-06-07T14:29:09.713" Score="4" Body="<p>The recommended thing to do is to simply access the slice as a struct field:</p>

<pre><code>type Item struct {
    Name string
}

type ItemList struct {
    PackDate time.Time
    Items    []Item
}
</code></pre>

<p>Accessing the values:</p>

<pre><code>myItemList.Items[0].Name
myItemList.PackDate
</code></pre>

<p>Iterating over the slice:</p>

<pre><code>for _, item := range myItemList.Items {
    // do something with item.Name
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T14:29:09.713" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44416645      <row Id="44416645" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44416790" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44416645" CreationDate="2017-06-07T15:22:29.667" Score="4" Body="<p>See the documentation on <code>Truncate</code>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Truncate changes the size of the file. <strong>It does not change the I/O offset</strong>. If there is an error, it will be of type *PathError. </p>
</blockquote>

<p>So you also need to seek to the beginning of the file before you write:</p>

<pre><code>configFile.Truncate(0)
configFile.Seek(0,0)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="495504" LastEditorUserId="495504" LastEditDate="2017-06-07T15:30:57.810" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T15:30:57.810" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44417913      <row Id="44417913" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44418231" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44417913" CreationDate="2017-06-07T16:30:59.440" Score="3" Body="<p>Without more context, I would dump the separate array of distinct values - generating it takes time, and using it necessitates the nested loop. Assuming there's no other purpose to the second array, I'd use something like:</p>

<pre><code>counter := make( map[string]int )    
for _, row := range StrArray {
    counter[row]++
} 
</code></pre>

<p>If you need the list of distinct strings without the counts for some separate purpose, you can easily get it afterward:</p>

<pre><code>distinctStrings := make([]string, len(counter))
i := 0
for k := range counter {
    distinctStrings[i] = k
    i++
}
</code></pre>

<p>Iterating the array of distinct strings is O(n), while map access by key is O(log(n)). That takes your overall from O(n^2) to O(n*log(n)), which should be a significant improvement with larger datasets. But, as with any optimization: test, measure, analyze, optimize.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T16:30:59.440" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44418361      <row Id="44418361" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44418411" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44418361" CreationDate="2017-06-07T16:41:13.617" Score="0" Body="<p>If you want to read line by line, and you're using a buffered reader, use the buffered reader's <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#Reader.ReadBytes" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ReadBytes method</a>.</p>

<pre><code>line,err := reader.ReadBytes('\n')
</code></pre>

<p>This will give you a full line, one line at a time, regardless of byte length.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T16:41:13.617" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44418576      <row Id="44418576" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44418893" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44418576" CreationDate="2017-06-07T17:10:46.357" Score="1" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>It's not working since it's not even loading "handlers/handler_one.go"</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Do you mean that the <code>init</code> function in <code>handlers/handler_one.go</code> is not being executed?</p>

<p>That would be expected since in the code you pasted you are not importing that package anywhere.</p>

<p>Try importing that package in your <code>main.go</code>.</p>

<p>You can import as <code>_</code> if the only reason for importing it would be for the <code>init</code> function to run.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T17:10:46.357" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44420826      <row Id="44420826" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44421114" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44420826" CreationDate="2017-06-07T19:19:10.583" Score="2" Body="<p>You cannot <code>import</code> the <code>main</code> package. Any shared code should go in a separate package, which can be imported by <code>main</code> (and other packages).</p>

question:
44036416      <row Id="44036416" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44422345" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44036416" CreationDate="2017-06-07T20:39:26.277" Score="1" Body="<p>If I read your code correctly, you are searching all captures. What you can do to save work, is to prune the hopeless captures move. It turns out that it is quite common that moves are so bad that it is safe to skip them, so the technique is quite safe.</p>

<p>For example, take a look at this position:</p>

<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZLKu9.jpg" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZLKu9.jpg" alt="enter image description here"></a></p>

<p>FEN: <code>rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/1PP1PPP1/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1</code></p>

<p>There are three captures:</p>

<ul>
<li>Rxa7</li>
<li>Qxd7+</li>
<li>Rxh7</li>
</ul>

<p>Let us assume the engine first tries the capture move with the queen. Black has four ways to capture back, but any of these moves will likely result in a cutoff.</p>

<p>For instance, black plays Bxd7. Now white has two captures in the resulting position, Rxa7 or Rxh7.</p>

<p>Here, most engines will recognize that white has already fallen back in material (in comparison to beta) that even capturing a pawn will not help. So, both of this rook captures are unlikely to result in a cutoff.</p>

<p>Here, your current search would still continue to search these moves. Detecting such cases and skipping these moves will save a lot of work.</p>

<p>There are further optimizations. For example, strong engines with <a href="https://chessprogramming.wikispaces.com/Static+Exchange+Evaluation" rel="nofollow noreferrer">static exchange evaluation</a> will immediately see that Qxd7 will win one pawn but will loose the queen. As this is a bad trade, the engine can immediately skip this move. The same goes for the other two rook captures.</p>

<p>As always, there is a trade-off, though. If you prune too aggressively, you will eventually prune good moves, too. In general, I would recommend to spend more time in the normal search, not in the quiescence search, so aggressive pruning should be fine.</p>
" OwnerUserId="783510" LastActivityDate="2017-06-07T20:39:26.277" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44426606      <row Id="44426606" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44426944" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44426606" CreationDate="2017-06-08T04:58:56.967" Score="1" Body="<p>If the browser cleanly closes the connection, then read on the webssocket connection returns an error.  Cleanup the websocket connection as you would on any read error.</p>

<p>The application must PING the connection and expect the corresponding PONGs to detect other situations.  The <a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/tree/master/examples/chat" rel="nofollow noreferrer">chat example</a> shows how to send PINGs and receive PONGs.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T04:58:56.967" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44427587      <row Id="44427587" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44428341" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44427587" CreationDate="2017-06-08T06:36:43.033" Score="7" Body="<p>You don't test in Go using <code>main</code>. Go has its own test framework.</p>

<p>First, read <a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html" rel="noreferrer">"How to Write Go Code"</a> which will explain Go's package layout and testing tools. It's best to go with them because so much of the Go tools expect that layout.</p>

<p>When creating a package, put it somewhere in <code>~/go/src</code>. I'd recommend following the convention using the repository you like to use, even for things you aren't necessarily going to upload. It makes for better organization; <code>go get</code> will put other external packages in <code>~/go/src/</code> as well.</p>

<p>For example, I'd use <code>~/go/src/github.com/schwern/newpackage/</code> even though I don't intend to upload this to Github. <code>github.com/schwern</code> acts as my "organization" within the Go source tree.</p>

<p>Put the functions into <code>newpackage.go</code> under <code>package newpackage</code>.</p>

<pre><code>$ cat ~/go/src/github.com/schwern/newpackage/newpackage.go 
package newpackage

func MyNewFunc() string {
    return "Hello!"
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then tests go in <code>newpackage_test.go</code> right next to <code>newpackage.go</code>. These should be familiar from Python, write a bunch of Test* functions. Unlike Python it doesn't use asserts.</p>

<pre><code>$ cat ~/go/src/github.com/schwern/newpackage/newpackage_test.go 
package newpackage_test

import(
    "testing"
    "github.com/schwern/newpackage"
)

func TestMyNewFunc( t *testing.T ) {
    want := "Hello!"
    have := newpackage.MyNewFunc()

    if have != want {
        t.Errorf("MyNewFunc(): have: '%v', want: '%v'", have, want )
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you run <code>go test</code> inside the package directory it will compile the current package and its dependencies, find and compile all <code>*_test.go</code> files in the package directory, and execute their <code>Test*</code> functions.</p>

<pre><code>$ pwd
/Users/schwern/go/src/github.com/schwern/newpackage
$ go test -v
=== RUN   TestMyNewFunc
--- PASS: TestMyNewFunc (0.00s)
PASS
ok      github.com/schwern/newpackage   0.013s
</code></pre>

<p>Note that the test is in a different package than what its testing. That makes it a blackbox test, it can only see the exported (ie. UpperCase) functions. You can make a glassbox test by putting the tests in the same package, it's best to do that in a separate file like <code>newpackage_internal_test.go</code>.</p>

<p>Unfortunately Go doesn't come with assert functions, the above <code>if</code> and call to <code>t.Errorf</code> is the equivalent. Rather than constantly hand-roll them, there's libraries out there which provide assert functions like <a href="https://github.com/stvp/assert" rel="noreferrer">stvp/assert</a>. After running <code>go get github.com/stvp/assert</code> you could write...</p>

<pre><code>package newpackage_test

import(
    "testing"
    "github.com/schwern/newpackage"
    "github.com/stvp/assert"
)

func TestMyNewFunc( t *testing.T ) {
    assert.Equal( t, newpackage.MyNewFunc(), "Hello!" )
}
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>If you want an executable that uses <code>newpackage</code>, it should probably go in its own package. Unless it's an integral part of <code>newpackage</code>.</p>

<pre><code>$ cat ~/go/src/github.com/schwern/newexec/main.go 
package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "github.com/schwern/newpackage"
)

func main() {
    fmt.Println(newpackage.MyNewFunc())
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you want to test <code>main</code>, <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#hdr-Main" rel="noreferrer">the <code>testing</code> package provides a special <code>TestMain</code> function</a>... though I admit I do not fully understand it. Like any other language, it's best to put as much functionality as possible into library calls and have <code>main</code> be a thin wrapper.</p>
" OwnerUserId="14660" LastEditorUserId="14660" LastEditDate="2017-06-08T06:57:55.190" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T06:57:55.190" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44428816      <row Id="44428816" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44429422" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44428816" CreationDate="2017-06-08T07:35:14.203" Score="1" Body="<p>The error is pretty clear:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>ld: library not found for -ltensorflow</p>
</blockquote>

<p>When you run <code>go test</code> you're invoking the go compiler that compiles the required libraries, your test files and then executes them.</p>

<p>When you compile a program that uses a "non-pure" go library, you have to make the compiler (and the linker) aware of the library.</p>

<p>In the compilation phase, the compiler looks for the libraries (also) in the paths listed into the environment variable:</p>

<p><code>LIBRARY_PATH</code> on OS X &amp; Linux.</p>

<p>Thus you have to add into this variable the location of the compiled library.</p>

<p>For example I have:</p>

<pre><code>TFGOLIB="${GOPATH}/src/github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/bazel-bin/tensorflow"
export LIBRARY_PATH="${TFGOLIB}:${LIBRARY_PATH}"
</code></pre>

<p>During the runtime, instead, the os looks for the library in order to perform dynamic linking.</p>

<p>Thus you have to set this other variable (<code>LD_LIBRARY_PATH</code> on Linux and <code>DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH</code> on OS X) to the same location.</p>

<p>Moreover I suggest  you to also add the CUDA library path to this variable, in order to make it available at runtime.</p>

<pre><code>export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/opt/cuda/lib64:/opt/cuda/extras/CUPTI/lib64:/opt/cudnn5.1/cuda/lib64:${TFGOLIB}"
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2891324" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T07:35:14.203" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44430621      <row Id="44430621" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44430812" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44430621" CreationDate="2017-06-08T08:44:12.293" Score="3" Body="<p>You just mistyped the header names:</p>

<pre><code>w.Header().Set("Allow-Control-Allow-Origin", "*")
                ^^^^^
</code></pre>

<p>Instead of <em>Allow-Control</em> there, you need <em>Access-Control</em>:</p>

<pre><code>w.Header().Set("Access-Control-Allow-Origin", "*")
</code></pre>

<p>and same of course for the other three headers youre setting there.</p>
" OwnerUserId="441757" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T08:44:12.293" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44434544      <row Id="44434544" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44434664" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44434544" CreationDate="2017-06-08T11:37:27.023" Score="2" Body="<p>Calling any function (or method) and passing values makes a copy of the values, and inside the function (or method) you can only modify the <em>copy</em>. Hence if you don't assign the return values in your first example to the fields of <code>Time</code>, changes made in <code>init_Time()</code> are lost when the function returns. This also answers your 2nd question.</p>

<p>If you want the caller to observe the changes, you must pass a <em>pointer</em> to your value, and have the function modify the <em>pointed</em> value. In this case it is not even required to return the (modified) value:</p>

<pre><code>func InitTime(t *Time) {
  t.hour, t.min, t.sec = time.Now().Clock()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Using it:</p>

<pre><code>t := Time{}
InitTime(&amp;t)
fmt.Printf("Time: %d:%d:%d\n", t.hour, t.min, t.sec)
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/2sUxefJj9q" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Time: 23:0:0
</code></pre>

<p>(Note that the current time on the Go Playground always starts at 23:00:00.)</p>

<p>Also it's idiomatic to create a "constructor" like function:</p>

<pre><code>func NewTime() *Time {
    t := &amp;Time{}
    t.hour, t.min, t.sec = time.Now().Clock()
    return t
}
</code></pre>

<p>Using it:</p>

<pre><code>t2 := NewTime()
fmt.Printf("Time: %d:%d:%d\n", t2.hour, t2.min, t2.sec)
</code></pre>

<p>Output is the same.</p>

<p>See related questions:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33040495/golang-operator-overloading/33040529#33040529">Golang Operator Overloading</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41477624/copy-instances-of-type-t-when-any-of-the-methods-of-a-named-type-t-have-a-point/41482152#41482152">Copy instances of type T, when any of the methods of a named type T have a pointer receiver</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-08T11:49:51.133" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T11:49:51.133" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44439087      <row Id="44439087" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44439192" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44439087" CreationDate="2017-06-08T14:57:50.720" Score="4" Body="<p>This is how embedding works, there's nothing you can do about it. <em>(Actually there is, see dirty trick at the end.)</em></p>

<p>What you want may be achieved with interfaces though. Make your structs unexported, (<code>B</code> => <code>b</code> and <code>C</code> => <code>c</code>), and create "constructor" like functions, which return interface types, containing only the methods you wish to publish:</p>

<pre><code>type b struct {
    A
}

type c struct {
    A
}

type Helloer interface {
    Hello()
}

type HelloWorlder interface {
    Helloer
    World()
}

func NewB() Helloer {
    return &amp;b{}
}

func NewC() HelloWorlder {
    return &amp;c{}
}
</code></pre>

<p>You might want to call the interfaces and functions different, this is just for demonstration.</p>

<p>Also note that while the returned <code>Helloer</code> interface does not include the <code>World()</code> method, it is still possible to "reach" it using <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_assertions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">type assertion</a>, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>h := NewB() // h is of type Helloer
if hw, ok := h.(HelloWorlder); ok {
    hw.World() // This will succeed with the above implementations
}
</code></pre>

<p>Try this on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/reRB7l1z7n" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>

<h2>Dirty trick</h2>

<p>If a type embeds the type <code>A</code>, (fields and) methods of <code>A</code> that get <em>promoted</em> will become part of the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_sets" rel="nofollow noreferrer">method set</a> of the embedder type (and thus become methods of type <code>A</code>). This is detailed in <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Struct_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Struct types:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A field or <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">method</a> <code>f</code> of an anonymous field in a struct <code>x</code> is called <em>promoted</em> if <code>x.f</code> is a legal <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Selectors" rel="nofollow noreferrer">selector</a> that denotes that field or method <code>f</code>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The focus is on the <em>promotion</em>, for which the selector must be <strong>legal</strong>. <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Selectors" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Selectors</a> describes how <code>x.f</code> is resolved:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The following rules apply to selectors:</p>
  
  <ol>
  <li>For a value <code>x</code> of type <code>T</code> or <code>*T</code> where <code>T</code> is not a pointer or interface type, <code>x.f</code> denotes the field or method at the shallowest depth in <code>T</code> where there is such an <code>f</code>. If there is not exactly <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Uniqueness_of_identifiers" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>one f</code></a> with shallowest depth, the selector expression is illegal.</li>
  </ol>
  
  <p>[...]</p>
</blockquote>

<p>What does this mean? Simply by embedding, <code>B.World</code> will denote the <code>B.A.World</code> method as that is at the shallowest depth. But if we can <em>achieve</em> so that <code>B.A.World</code> won't be the shallowest, the type <code>B</code> won't have this <code>World()</code> method, because <code>B.A.World</code> won't get promoted.</p>

<p>How can we achieve that? We may add a field with name <code>World</code>:</p>

<pre><code>type B struct {
    A
    World int
}
</code></pre>

<p>This <code>B</code> type (or rather <code>*B</code>) will not have a <code>World()</code> method, as <code>B.World</code> denotes the <em>field</em> and not <code>B.A.World</code> as the former is at the shallowest depth. Try this on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/0umHLGO7EP" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>

<p>Again, this does not prevent anyone to explicitly refer to <code>B.A.World()</code>, so that method can be "reached" and called, all we achieved is that the type <code>B</code> or <code>*B</code> does not have a <code>World()</code> method.</p>

<p>Another variant of this "dirty trick" is to exploit the end of the first rule: <em>"If there is <strong>not exactly one</strong> <code>f</code> with shallowest depth"</em>. This can be achieved to also embed another type, another struct which also has a <code>World</code> field or method, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>type hideWorld struct{ World int }

type B struct {
    A
    hideWorld
}
</code></pre>

<p>Try this variant on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/p82ttZWb8W" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-08T19:34:43.960" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T19:34:43.960" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44441091      <row Id="44441091" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44445143" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44441091" CreationDate="2017-06-08T20:39:22.943" Score="0" Body="<p><strong>Something Like This?</strong></p>

<pre><code>rows, err := db.Query("SELECT name FROM names")
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}

names := make([]string, 0)

for rows.Next() {
    var name string

    err := rows.Scan(&amp;name)
    if err != nil {
        // Handle error
        continue
    }

    names = append(names, name)
}

t := template.New("index")
t, _ = t.Parse(`{{range .}}{{.}} {{end}}`)
t.Execute(w, names)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p><strong>Things to Note</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>You should generally avoid using <code>*</code> in your sql queries to make it clear what fields are being selected</li>
<li>If any fields in your database table <strong>can be</strong> <code>NULL</code>, then use <code>sql.NullBool</code>, <code>sql.NullFloat64</code>, <code>sql.NullInt64</code> or <code>sql.NullString</code> to avoid possible errors</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<p><strong>Possible Output</strong></p>

<pre><code>Bob Jim David Henry Jerry 
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4988637" LastEditorUserId="4988637" LastEditDate="2017-06-08T20:47:02.327" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T20:47:02.327" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44445958      <row Id="44445958" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44445991" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44445958" CreationDate="2017-06-08T21:38:06.807" Score="1" Body="<p>The fields of CellValue are unexported (start with a lowercase character). <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Per the documentation</a> (emphasis mine), "Each <strong>exported</strong> struct field becomes a member of the object" - meaning unexported values are ignored when marshaling or unmarshaling.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T21:38:06.807" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44446371      <row Id="44446371" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44446435" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44446371" CreationDate="2017-06-08T22:17:43.813" Score="1" Body="<p>Your function could be implemented in a simpler, more efficient manner:</p>

<pre><code>func binToString(s []byte) string {
    output := make([]byte, len(s)/8)
    for i := 0; i &lt; len(output); i++ {
        val, err := strconv.ParseInt(string(s[i*8:(i+1)*8]), 2, 64)
        if err == nil {
            output[i] = byte(val)
        }
    }
    return string(output)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Fmo7I-rN3c" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/Fmo7I-rN3c</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastEditorUserId="142162" LastEditDate="2017-06-08T22:23:17.850" LastActivityDate="2017-06-08T22:23:17.850" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44447271      <row Id="44447271" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44447357" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44447271" CreationDate="2017-06-09T00:05:38.397" Score="4" Body="<p><code>append(foo[:i], foo[i+1:]...)</code> does the following:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>It takes the <code>foo[:i]</code> slice, which is <code>foo[:0]</code> and basically a slice with length <code>0</code> and capacity (at least) <code>3</code>.</p></li>
<li><p>As soon as the capacity is enough to append the values - the underlying array is reused</p></li>
<li><p>You write <code>b</code> and <code>c</code> into the indexes <code>0</code> and <code>1</code> correspondingly of the underlying array.</p></li>
</ol>

<p>Then you check the <code>foo</code> variable that uses the underlying array we just modified and that contains the <code>b c c</code> values.</p>

<p>Compare with the following:</p>

<pre><code>noop(append(foo[:i], "a", "a", "a", "a", "a"))
</code></pre>

<p>Here the list of values to append is longer than the current capacity. So the runtime allocates a new underlying array. And you don't mutate the <code>foo</code>. <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/RooYG_p9Z8" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/RooYG_p9Z8</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="251311" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T00:05:38.397" CommentCount="8" />

question:
44442336      <row Id="44442336" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44447831" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44442336" CreationDate="2017-06-09T01:16:32.483" Score="1" Body="<p>If you don't want to use nested loop, one solution is using recursive call and reflection to inject the attributes/properties into a struct. In the following implementation, attributes/properties to be injected is wrapped in a struct implement <code>Injectable</code> interface. Working example can be found at <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/b7_ZSqmrE4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>. </p>

<ol>
<li><p>Define the interface.</p>

<pre><code>type Injectable interface {
    InjectTo(v interface{})
}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>Define data structure that holds properties/attributes to be injected, e.g.</p>

<pre><code>type Property struct {
    AID int
    BID int
}

type C struct {
    // The properties will be injected here
    Property
    CID int
}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>Implement <code>InjectTo</code> using reflection and recursive call.</p>

<pre><code>//Method must be pointer receiver since p will be used 
//as temporary placeholder for parent properties/attributes.
func (p *Property) injectRecursive(v reflect.Value, it reflect.Type, pv reflect.Value) {
    switch v.Kind() {
    case reflect.Struct:
        vt := v.Type()
        //Embedded struct is a 'value' type implement Injectable
        if vt.Implements(it) {
            //Inject value to embedded struct
            ot := pv.Type()
            for k := 0; k &lt; pv.NumField(); k++ {
                name := ot.Field(k).Name
                f := v.FieldByName(name)
                if f.CanSet() {
                    f.Set(pv.Field(k))
                }
            }
        } else {
            for k := 0; k &lt; v.NumField(); k++ {
                fv := v.Field(k)

                //Match by field name.
                //For more robust and generic solution
                //consider using other approach, e.g. tag
                f := pv.FieldByName(vt.Field(k).Name)
                if f.CanSet() {
                    f.Set(fv)
                } else {
                    p.injectRecursive(fv, it, pv)
                }
            }
        }
    case reflect.Slice, reflect.Array:
        for k := 0; k &lt; v.Len(); k++ {
            p.injectRecursive(v.Index(k), it, pv)
        }
    case reflect.Ptr:
        if v.IsValid() {
            p.injectRecursive(v.Elem(), it, pv)
        }
    }
}

//InjectTo must be Value (not pointer) receiver
func (p Property) InjectTo(s interface{}) {
    sv := reflect.Indirect(reflect.ValueOf(s))
    pv := reflect.Indirect(reflect.ValueOf(&amp;p))
    it := reflect.TypeOf((*Injectable)(nil)).Elem()
    p.injectRecursive(sv, it, pv)
}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>You can inject the properties by:</p>

<pre><code>res := Input{...}
prop := Property{}
prop.InjectTo(&amp;res)
</code></pre></li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-09T01:23:04.990" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T01:23:04.990" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44448384      <row Id="44448384" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44448443" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44448384" CreationDate="2017-06-09T02:40:29.333" Score="2" Body="<p>You can slice off the last character:</p>

<pre><code>read_line = read_line[:len(read_line)-1]
</code></pre>

<p>Perhaps a better approach is to use the strings library:</p>

<pre><code>read_line = strings.TrimSuffix(read_line, "\n")
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1931098" LastEditorUserId="1931098" LastEditDate="2017-06-09T02:49:21.610" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T02:49:21.610" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44448472      <row Id="44448472" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44448631" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44448472" CreationDate="2017-06-09T03:03:21.797" Score="1" Body="<p>This is an issue inherent in the design of most hash tables. Here's a simple explanation hand waving a lot of unnecessary detail.</p>

<p>Under the hood, a hash table is an array. Each key is mapped onto an element in the array using a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_table#Collision_resolution" rel="nofollow noreferrer">hash function</a>. For example, "foo" might map to element 8, "bar" might map to element 4, and so on. Some elements are empty.</p>

<p><code>for k,v := range hash</code> iterates through this array in whatever order they happen to appear. The ordering is unpredictable to avoid a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_attack" rel="nofollow noreferrer">collision attack</a>.</p>

<p>When you add to a hash, it adds to the underlying array. It might even have to allocate a new, larger array. It's unpredictable where that new key will land in the hash's array.</p>

<p>So if you add more pairs while you're iterating through the hash, any pair that gets put into the array before the current index won't be seen; the iteration has already past that point. Anything that gets put after <em>might</em> be seen; the iteration has yet to reach that point, but the array might get reallocated and the pairs possibly rehashed.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><em>but I wonder why on my local it never prints more than 8</em></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Because the underlying array is probably of length 8. Go likely allocates the underlying array in powers of 2 and probably starts at 8. The <code>range hash</code> probably starts by checking the length of the underlying array and will not go further, even if it's grown.</p>

<p>Long story short: don't add keys to a hash while iterating through it.</p>
" OwnerUserId="14660" LastEditorUserId="14660" LastEditDate="2017-06-09T03:16:02.747" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T03:16:02.747" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44452499      <row Id="44452499" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="44452603" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44452499" CreationDate="2017-06-09T08:10:12.820" Score="3" Body="<p>You can use virtually the same construct as in Go:</p>

<p><div class="snippet" data-lang="js" data-hide="false" data-console="true" data-babel="false">
<div class="snippet-code">
<pre class="snippet-code-js lang-js prettyprint-override"><code>var now = new Date();

switch (true) {

    break;

question:
44441665      <row Id="44441665" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44454014" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44441665" CreationDate="2017-06-09T09:21:16.230" Score="0" Body="<p>As indicated by @Eric Pauley, I look at <code>TextTokens</code> &amp; <code>StartTagTokens</code>. 
Here is my solution</p>

<pre><code>    s := `
&lt;p&gt;Links:&lt;/p&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;a href="foo"&gt;Foo&lt;/a&gt;&lt;li&gt;
&lt;a href="/bar/baz"&gt;BarBaz&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;span&gt;TEXT &lt;b&gt;I&lt;/b&gt; WANT&lt;/span&gt;
&lt;script type='text/javascript'&gt;
/* &lt;![CDATA[ */
var post_notif_widget_ajax_obj = {"ajax_url":"http:\/\/site.com\/wp-admin\/admin-ajax.php","nonce":"9b8270e2ef","processing_msg":"Processing..."};
/* ]]&gt; */
&lt;/script&gt;`

    domDocTest := html.NewTokenizer(strings.NewReader(s))
    previousStartTokenTest := domDocTest.Token()
loopDomTest:
    for {
        tt := domDocTest.Next()
        switch {
        case tt == html.ErrorToken:
            break loopDomTest // End of the document,  done
        case tt == html.StartTagToken:
            previousStartTokenTest = domDocTest.Token()
        case tt == html.TextToken:
            if previousStartTokenTest.Data == "script" {
                continue
            }
            TxtContent := strings.TrimSpace(html.UnescapeString(string(domDocTest.Text())))
            if len(TxtContent) &gt; 0 {
                fmt.Printf("%s\n", TxtContent)
            }
        }
    }
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="710955" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T09:21:16.230" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44455197      <row Id="44455197" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44456075" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44455197" CreationDate="2017-06-09T11:00:06.843" Score="1" Body="<p>In general for any type that can be <code>nil</code> you can generate whatever string representation you like! It's because when implementing <code>fmt.Stringer</code> interface (see <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#Stringer" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>) - or any function on a type that can be <code>nil</code> - you can have a <code>nil</code> for receiver value. In other words you can call methods on <code>nil</code> objects in contrast with OOP languages. In <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/XMGSiJJLtx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this</a> sample code, you'll see <code> hey nilo!</code> for a <code>nil</code> value of the second type, but <code>BOO DATA!!! :: Hi! :)</code> when you have an element inside (it prints just the first element as a sample code).</p>

<p>And again keep in mind <code>nil</code> <a href="https://www.gmarik.info/blog/2016/understanding-golang-nil-value/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">is typed</a> in go.</p>
" OwnerUserId="54467" LastEditorUserId="54467" LastEditDate="2017-06-09T11:09:44.920" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T11:09:44.920" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44455853      <row Id="44455853" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44459305" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44455853" CreationDate="2017-06-09T13:38:17.917" Score="2" Body="<p>You're operating too low by unmarshalling at the Text Level - you're still Unmarshalling 2 Texts elements which is why you are seeing an empty second element. You could try something like this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/xml"
    "fmt"
)

type Root struct {
    Translation Text `xml:"Texts&gt;Text&gt;Text"`
}

type Text []struct {
    Language string `xml:"Language,attr"`
    Value    string `xml:"Value"`
}

func main() {
    foo := `
        &lt;Root&gt;
            &lt;Texts&gt;
                &lt;Text&gt;
                    &lt;Text Language="EN"&gt;
                        &lt;Value&gt;One&lt;/Value&gt;
                    &lt;/Text&gt;
                    &lt;Text Language="de"&gt;
                        &lt;Value&gt;Eins&lt;/Value&gt;
                    &lt;/Text&gt;
                &lt;/Text&gt;
            &lt;/Texts&gt;
        &lt;/Root&gt;
        `

    var root Root
    e := xml.Unmarshal([]byte(foo), &amp;root)
    if e != nil {
        panic(e)
    }

    fmt.Printf("%+v\n", root)
}

func (t *Text) UnmarshalXML(d *xml.Decoder, start xml.StartElement) error {
    tx := []struct{
        Language string `xml:"Language,attr"`
        Value    string `xml:"Value"`
    }{}
    d.DecodeElement(&amp;tx, &amp;start)


    tSl := *t
    for _, elem := range tx {
        switch elem.Language {
        case "EN":
            tSl = append(tSl, struct{
                Language string `xml:"Language,attr"`
                Value    string `xml:"Value"`}{elem.Language, elem.Value})
        default:
            d.Skip()
        }
    }
    *t = tSl
    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>{Translation:[{Language:EN Value:One}]}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1652623" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T13:38:17.917" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44447458      <row Id="44447458" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44459369" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44447458" CreationDate="2017-06-09T13:41:21.980" Score="0" Body="<p>From the comments, I tested this code myself without error (admittedly on 17.06-rc2 but the behavior shouldn't change). Given that a restart solved this, there appears to have been some corruption inside of docker that needed a bounce to correct (while rare, it wouldn't be the first time I've seen this). For others encountering problems in the future, I like to try the following in order:</p>

<ol>
<li>Pull fresh images and/or rebuild without caching for any issues with the layers</li>
<li>Restart docker for possible corruption inside the daemon</li>
<li>Restart the entire host for runtime configuration issues that persist outside of the docker daemon</li>
<li>With dockerd stopped, wipe <code>/var/lib/docker</code> which will destroy all containers, images, and volumes (so backup first) and start clean</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="596285" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T13:41:21.980" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44461407      <row Id="44461407" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44461997" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44461407" CreationDate="2017-06-09T15:50:29.173" Score="3" Body="<p>Using the global functions in <code>flag</code> actually passes through to a global <code>flag.FlagSet</code> called <code>flag.CommandLine</code>. Internally, this prints errors to an output, which is stderr by default. You can suppress the messages by setting this explicitly to, for example, <code>ioutil.Discard</code>:</p>

<pre><code>flag.CommandLine.SetOutput(ioutil.Discard)
flag.Parse()
</code></pre>

<p>This will discard all messages output internally by <code>flag.Parse()</code>. You could also log it to anywhere else you choose by passing in an appropriate <code>io.Writer</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T15:50:29.173" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44425067      <row Id="44425067" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44464194" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44425067" CreationDate="2017-06-09T18:04:29.093" Score="1" Body="<p>AQL is an admin and data browsing tool. It's not really Aerospike's SQL, as Aerospike doesn't natively implement a query language. Instead, all the Aerospike clients give you an API to make direct get, put, scan, query calls, and those are procedural, not declarative like SQL (where you state how you want the result and the server figures out a query plan). Piyush mentioned the predicate filtering API which is fantastic and lets you create complex queries over scans and secondary-index queries.</p>

<p>Specifically to your question about getting all the indexes, that's the type of thing you should use the info command for. Aerospike allows you to get and set config parameters through it, and get a wide range of metrics, run microbenchmark, etc. Everything you need for admin and monitoring.</p>

<p>You can run <a href="http://www.aerospike.com/docs/reference/info#sindex" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sindex</code></a> through the standalone <a href="http://www.aerospike.com/docs/tools/asinfo" rel="nofollow noreferrer">asinfo</a> tool, or you can call it using the <a href="https://github.com/aerospike/aerospike-client-go/blob/master/info.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">info command</a> that any client provides.</p>

<pre><code>asinfo -v "sindex"
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="582436" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T18:04:29.093" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44464351      <row Id="44464351" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44464880" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44464351" CreationDate="2017-06-09T18:51:09.933" Score="3" Body="<p>You can't in all cases.</p>

<p>Tests are compiled and executed by the <code>go test</code> process. The stdout and stderr are captured by the parent process, and only displayed in verbose mode.</p>

<p>The exceptions are documented in the test code:</p>

<pre><code>// stream test output (no buffering) when no package has
// been given on the command line (implicit current directory)
// or when benchmarking.
</code></pre>

<p>So if you are in the package directory, or running benchmarks, the stdout and stderr will be streamed through the parent process. </p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T18:51:09.933" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44250700      <row Id="44250700" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44466040" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44250700" CreationDate="2017-06-09T20:14:41.573" Score="1" Body="<p>Broadly speaking, yes, the behavior of Clojure's <code>go</code> macro is similar to "goroutines" when using the "parking" <code>&lt;!</code> and <code>&gt;!</code>.</p>

<p>However, any performance effects are likely to be highly-specific to both the workload and the environment: operating system, number of cores, heap size, etc.</p>

<p>Clojure's <code>go</code> macro compiles its contents into a state machine composed of lots of little functions, which are <a href="https://github.com/clojure/core.async/blob/105acd5b40a66b6d1c80271a30ae273c6933c5bd/src/main/clojure/clojure/core/async/impl/dispatch.clj#L18" rel="nofollow noreferrer">dispatched</a> through a standard Java <a href="https://github.com/clojure/core.async/blob/105acd5b40a66b6d1c80271a30ae273c6933c5bd/src/main/clojure/clojure/core/async/impl/exec/threadpool.clj#L24" rel="nofollow noreferrer">thread pool</a>. There isn't any other scheduling implemented in the Clojure implementation right now.</p>

<p>The Go language has its own internal scheduler for "goroutines," which may be able to do more sophisticated scheduling based on internal runtime knowledge. It also provides runtime inspection of "goroutines" which is not possible with Clojure's <code>go</code> macro.</p>
" OwnerUserId="63009" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T20:14:41.573" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44468048      <row Id="44468048" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44468091" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44468048" CreationDate="2017-06-09T23:50:25.877" Score="2" Body="<p>Yes, this is possible. Here is your code updated:</p>

<pre><code>func DoThing(fn interface{}) {
    // Get first arg of the function
    firstArg := reflect.TypeOf(fn).In(0)

    // Get the PtrTo to the first function parameter
    structPtr := reflect.New(firstArg)

    // Convert to Interface
    // Note that I can't assert this to .(myStruct) type
    instance := structPtr.Interface()

    // Unmarshal the JSON
    json.Unmarshal(jsonData, instance)

    // Call the function
    vfn := reflect.ValueOf(fn)
    vfn.Call([]reflect.Value{structPtr.Elem()})
}
</code></pre>

<p>Changes made:</p>

<ol>
<li>Pass <code>structPtr</code> (a pointer) to <code>json.Unmarshal</code>; pass a value and you will not see the changes</li>
<li>Remove taking the address of <code>instance</code> when passing to <code>json.Unmarshal</code>; <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#pointer_to_interface" rel="nofollow noreferrer">there is usually never a good reason to have a pointer to an interface</a></li>
<li>Use <code>structPtr</code> instead of <code>instance</code> when calling <code>fn</code></li>
</ol>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/POmOyQBJYC" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/POmOyQBJYC</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-09T23:50:25.877" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44468995      <row Id="44468995" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44469062" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44468995" CreationDate="2017-06-10T02:53:37.837" Score="2" Body="<p>One trick is by waiting user input at the end of your application. Once user press any key, exit the application. The snippet:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    //Your original code...

    fmt.Printf("Press any key to exit...")
    b := make([]byte, 1)
    os.Stdin.Read(b)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-10T02:53:37.837" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44467121      <row Id="44467121" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44469349" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44467121" CreationDate="2017-06-10T03:58:18.500" Score="0" Body="<p>I'm guessing you are just typing <code>go build</code> from the <code>cmd/codenames</code> directory, creating a binary called 'codenames' in that directory and running from there. </p>

<p>Unfortunately the app is hard-coded to look for its assets in a ./assets/ directory relative to the binary. </p>

<p>So you want your binary in the root of the app: </p>

<p>i.e</p>

<ul>
<li>from the <code>cmd/codenames</code> directory <code>go build -o ../../run-me-from-here</code>  </li>
<li><p>then from the root of the app <code>./run-me-from-here</code></p>

<p>.</p></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="1146094" LastActivityDate="2017-06-10T03:58:18.500" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44473471      <row Id="44473471" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44474781" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44473471" CreationDate="2017-06-10T15:03:54.007" Score="3" Body="<p>You may simply use:</p>

<pre><code>func myvariadic(ip ...string) {
    ip1, ip2 := ip[0], ""
    if len(ip) &gt; 1 {
        ip2 = ip[1]
    }
    fmt.Println(ip1, ip2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>But don't forget that variadic functions may be called with 0 arguments specified / passed as the value for the variadic parameter. What this means is that it is also legal (not a compile-time error) to call <code>myvariadic()</code> with zero arguments, and then even <code>ip[0]</code> will cause a runtime panic.</p>

<p>If your function must receive at least one string and optionally a second, you should change the signature of your function to this:</p>

<pre><code>func myvariadic(ip1 string, ips ...string) {
    ip2 := ""
    if len(ips) &gt; 1 {
        ip2 = ips[1]
    }
    fmt.Println(ip1, ip2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>What this guarantees is that 1 <code>string</code> will surely be passed (else it would be a compile-time error). This is also more efficient if only one argument is passed, as no slice allocation will be needed (<code>nil</code> will be used for <code>ips</code>). See more details on this here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37270743/is-it-possible-to-trigger-compile-time-error-with-custom-library-in-golang/37271129#37271129">Is it possible to trigger compile time error with custom library in golang?</a></p>

<p>If parameters are always 1 or 2 <code>string</code> values, I'm not sure variadic parameters is justified at all, you may simply use:</p>

<pre><code>func myNonVariadic(ip1, ip2 string) {
    fmt.Println(ip1, ip2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>And simply pass the empty string <code>""</code> at the caller if <code>ip2</code> is not available.</p>

<p>If you still want to stick to variadic function, another option would be to not introduce <code>ip1</code> and <code>ip2</code> inside the function, but simply use <code>ip[0]</code> and <code>ip[1]</code>. And to avoid runtime panic if less than 2 arguments is passed, you may append an empty string yourself, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>func myvariadic(ip ...string) {
    if len(ip) &lt; 2 {
        ip = append(ip, "")
    }
    fmt.Println(ip[0], ip[1])
}
</code></pre>

<p>And the version that also deals with 0 arguments:</p>

<pre><code>func myvariadic(ip ...string) {
    for len(ip) &lt; 2 {
        ip = append(ip, "")
    }
    fmt.Println(ip[0], ip[1])
}
</code></pre>

<p>This latter version makes sure the <code>ip</code> variable (of slice type) will have at least 2 elements, even if 0 is passed.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-10T15:10:53.110" LastActivityDate="2017-06-10T15:10:53.110" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44458410      <row Id="44458410" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44475583" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44458410" CreationDate="2017-06-10T16:28:18.310" Score="5" Body="<p>Ok I followed step by step this post <a href="http://moonlightbox.logdown.com/posts/2016/09/12/gitlab-ci-runner-register-x509-error" rel="noreferrer">http://moonlightbox.logdown.com/posts/2016/09/12/gitlab-ci-runner-register-x509-error</a> and then it worked like a charm.
To prevent dead link i copy the steps below:</p>

<p>First edit ssl configuration on the Gitlab server (not the runner)</p>

<pre><code>vim /etc/pki/tls/openssl.cnf

[ v3_ca ]
subjectAltName=IP:192.168.1.1 &lt;---- Add this line. 192.168.1.1 is your GitLab server IP.
</code></pre>

<p>Re-generate self-signed certificate</p>

<pre><code>cd /etc/gitlab/ssl
sudo openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 3650 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout /etc/gitlab/ssl/192.168.1.1.key -out /etc/gitlab/ssl/192.168.1.1.crt
sudo openssl dhparam -out /etc/gitlab/ssl/dhparam.pem 2048
sudo gitlab-ctl restart
</code></pre>

<p>Copy the new CA to the Gutlab-CI runner</p>

<pre><code>scp /etc/gitlab/ssl/192.168.1.1.crt root@192.168.1.2:/etc/gitlab-runner/certs
</code></pre>

<p>Thanks @Moon Light @Wassim Dhif</p>
" OwnerUserId="6766644" LastActivityDate="2017-06-10T16:28:18.310" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44476388      <row Id="44476388" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44476728" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44476388" CreationDate="2017-06-10T18:30:48.160" Score="5" Body="<p>No, that would be a really poor design (<em>read exception at the end</em>). By the way, it is very easy to check this, create a package named <code>a</code>, consisting of 2 files: <code>aa.go</code> and <code>ab.go</code>. Have both import <code>fmt</code>. Produce the executable (e.g. <code>go build</code>, must called on the <code>main</code> package) and check its size. Now move all code from <code>ab.go</code> that uses the <code>fmt</code> package to <code>aa.go</code>, and remove the <code>fmt</code> import from <code>ab.go</code>. Produce the executable again. They will have the same size.</p>

<p>Packages are identified by their full path. No matter how many <em>files</em> (of the same package) or how many (different) <em>packages</em> refer to a package, the package will only be included once in the final executable binary.</p>

<p>Also note that not everything will be included from used packages in the executable binary. Certain things that are not used / referred to may be excluded. For details see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38875016/splitting-client-server-code/38875901#38875901">Splitting client/server code</a>; and <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42825926/how-to-remove-unused-code-at-compile-time?noredirect=1&amp;lq=1">How to remove unused code at compile time?</a></p>

<p>There is one exception though, which is the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/plugin/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">plugins</a> introduced in Go 1.8. Packages referred to by plugins will be included in the compiled plugin they have to be, because the plugin has no guarantee what packages will be available in the executable binary that will load it. So if the <code>fmt</code> package is referred to by package <code>main</code>, and also by a plugin, the code of the <code>fmt</code> package will be included in both (in the executable binary and in the compiled plugin). It should be noted that even though the <code>fmt</code> package's code will be present twice (once in the executable and once in the plugin), there will still be only one "instance" of the package in the runtime (in memory) (e.g. its global variables will have one instance, and it will only be initialized once).</p>

<p>An "edge" case is <a href="https://golang.org/cmd/go/#hdr-Vendor_Directories" rel="nofollow noreferrer">vendored packages</a>. If a package is vendored in a <code>vendor</code> folder, and a package refers to this vendored package, that is considered distinct from the original (that is vendored), and if the original is also referred to by another package, both will be included in the executable binary (but they are not considered the same, the full path of the vendored is different from the full path of the original).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-11T16:39:07.273" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T16:39:07.273" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44475474      <row Id="44475474" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44477842" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44475474" CreationDate="2017-06-10T20:39:29.793" Score="1" Body="<p>One thing to consider before getting into the answer is your example code will not compile. To define a type of struct in Go, you would need to change your syntax to </p>

<pre><code>type output struct {
    index       int
    description string
}
</code></pre>

<p>In terms of a potential solution to your problem - if you already reliably have unique index's as well as the expected count of the result set - you should not have to do any sorting at all. Instead synchronize the go routines over a channel and insert the output in an allocated slice at the respective index. You can then iterate over that slice to write the contents to a file. For example:</p>

<pre><code>ch := make(chan output) //each go routine will write to this channel
wg := new(sync.WaitGroup) //wait group to sync all go routines

//execute 16 goroutines 
for i := 0; i &lt; 16; i++ {
    wg.Add(1)
    go worker(ch, wg) //this is expecting each worker func to call wg.Done() when completing its portion of work
}

//create a "quit" channel that will be used to signal to the select statement below that your go routines are all done
quit := make(chan bool)
go func() {
    wg.Wait()
    quit &lt;- true
}()

//initialize a slice with length and capacity to 1mil, the expected result size mentioned in your question
sorted := make([]string, 1000000, 1000000)

//use the for loop, select pattern to sync the results from your 16 go routines and insert them into the sorted slice
for {
    select {
        case output := &lt;-ch:
            //this is not robust - check notes below example
            sorted[output.index] = output.description
        case &lt;-quit:
            //implement a function you could pass the sorted slice to that will write the results
            // Ex:  writeToFile(sorted)
            return
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>A couple notes on this solution: it is dependent upon you knowing the size of the expected result set. If you do not know what the size of the result set is - in the select statement you will need to check if the index is read from <code>ch</code> exceeds the length of the <code>sorted</code> slice and allocate additional space before inserting our you program will crash as a result of an out of bounds error</p>
" OwnerUserId="1694885" LastEditorUserId="1694885" LastEditDate="2017-06-10T20:45:36.000" LastActivityDate="2017-06-10T20:45:36.000" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44467219      <row Id="44467219" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44478060" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44467219" CreationDate="2017-06-10T21:02:57.647" Score="0" Body="<p>I found the problem. It sat before the monitor.The data was inserted actually. Sqlite client handles the blob as text and terminates printing at the "0". Inspecting the database with sqlitebrowser showed the complete entry. </p>
