question:
44477897      <row Id="44477897" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44478116" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44477897" CreationDate="2017-06-10T21:10:49.563" Score="2" Body="<p>So your C <code>normalize</code> macro assigns <code>c</code> to <code>a</code> if <code>a</code> is not equal to <code>0xffffffff</code>, or to <code>0</code> otherwise. I'm not sure what kind of normalization it is, but it's not my concern now.</p>

<p>So given the Go function signature you provided, this would work:</p>

<pre><code>func normalize(a uint32, c *uint32) {
    if a != 0xffffffff {
        *c = a
    } else {
        *c = 0
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>However, I'm not sure why not just return a value instead of writing it via <code>c</code> pointer?</p>

<pre><code>func normalize(a uint32) {
    if a != 0xffffffff {
        return a
    }
    return 0
}
</code></pre>

<p>Side note: the same applies to your C macro. By the way, the macro evaluates <code>a</code> twice, this might come as a surprise if you ever pass some function with side effects as <code>a</code>. Any reason not to use (inline) function instead of a macro, or at least make it so that it evaluates to a new value, instead of assigning <code>c</code> to it?</p>
" OwnerUserId="1099240" LastActivityDate="2017-06-10T21:10:49.563" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44478920      <row Id="44478920" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44478956" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44478920" CreationDate="2017-06-10T23:16:42.993" Score="1" Body="<p>when you increment both j and k on the last loop go doesn't like it</p>

<p>so try to change your code to </p>

<pre><code>func naive(z, x, y []uint32, n int) {
    var i, j, k int
    var A, B uint32

    for i = 0; i &lt; n; i++ {
        B = 0

        for j = 1; j &lt;= i; j++ {
            muladd(x[j], y[i-j], &amp;A)
        }

        for k = 1; j &lt; n; j++ {
            muladd(x[j], y[n-k], &amp;B)
            k++
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>pay attention to the last loop I just moved the <code>k++</code> statement inside the loop</p>
" OwnerUserId="3553432" LastEditorUserId="3553432" LastEditDate="2017-06-12T00:02:35.463" LastActivityDate="2017-06-12T00:02:35.463" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44479847      <row Id="44479847" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44480085" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44479847" CreationDate="2017-06-11T03:21:18.160" Score="2" Body="<p>You have asked a good question.</p>

<p>The command's order in the Dockerfile really matters. Put first the things that don't change frecuently, and later those that are most likely to change in every build:</p>

<pre><code>FROM golang:1.8

RUN go get -d -v ./...
RUN go install -v ./...

COPY . /go/src/github.com/codeblooded/test1
WORKDIR /go/src/github.com/codeblooded/test1

RUN echo $PATH

RUN go build -o test1 .
CMD ["test1"]
EXPOSE 3470
</code></pre>

<p>When a layer change regarding previous build, docker discards the following cached layers an runs them again, sometimes wasting your time.</p>

<p>Pay attention to the "Using cache" sentence that docker output in each layer that is re-used from previous build.</p>

<p>Another recommendation, for your dev work, use <a href="https://github.com/pilu/fresh" rel="nofollow noreferrer">fresh</a> to re-build your go app automatically every time you change the code. Just installing it in the container and simply using <code>command: fresh</code> in your docker-compose.yml</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094246" LastEditorUserId="1094246" LastEditDate="2017-06-16T18:57:20.213" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T18:57:20.213" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44475923      <row Id="44475923" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44480324" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44475923" CreationDate="2017-06-11T04:18:41.577" Score="1" Body="<p>Go's garbage collector will not try to reclaim memory allocated using the C memory allocator.  What you are describing should be safe.  Of course, you may not be able to free the C memory, because you don't know when Go will be done with it.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2774002" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T04:18:41.577" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44480524      <row Id="44480524" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44480736" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44480524" CreationDate="2017-06-11T05:39:29.483" Score="2" Body="<p>Yes you can pass structs. But that's not the problem in your OP. </p>

<p>Channels expect the <code>receiver</code> to be blocking, waiting for the <code>sender</code>.  This is done with Goroutines.  </p>

<p>You sent a value on a channel, when there was no receiver ready to receive.  That is what caused your deadlock.</p>

<p>So wrap your sender in a goroutine, which will not execute right away. </p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

type name struct {
    name string
    age  int
}

func main() {
    c := make(chan name)

    go func() {
        c &lt;- name{"sfsaf", 1}
        close(c)
    }()

    for n := range c {
        fmt.Println(n)
    }

    fmt.Println("channel was closed (all done!).")
}
</code></pre>

<p>See it in the playground: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/uaSuCaB4Ms" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/uaSuCaB4Ms</a></p>

<p>This works because the sender's goroutine is not executing yet.  Not until the current goroutine executing gets blocked.  </p>

<p>And we get blocked on the <code>for n := range c</code> loop.  This is the receiver, sitting and waiting for values.  (It is a common pattern to use the for loop to iterate over channel values as it will sit and block, waiting for values).</p>

<p>So now that we are blocked waiting to receive values in the <code>for</code> loop, the inline gorouting will now execute, to send our value on the channel.</p>

<p>In addition, we follow safe practices and tidy up after ourselves and <code>close(c)</code> the channel, signalling the <code>for</code> loop or <code>select</code> statement that there will be no more values sent.  <strong><em>The sender always closes, never the receiver</em></strong>. This is the pattern the <code>for</code> range loop uses to exit the for loop, and continue executing the rest of your code.</p>

<hr>

<p>As a side note, you did well by passing the value of the struct - not a pointer.</p>

<p>If you passed a pointer, you'd have to implement some mutex lock around the object to prevent a R/W panic.</p>

<p><em><a href="https://blog.golang.org/share-memory-by-communicating" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Do not communicate by sharing memory; instead, share memory by communicating.</a></em></p>

<p>Stick to passing values, not pointers, around your channels and goroutines and reap the benefits.</p>
" OwnerUserId="56693" LastEditorUserId="56693" LastEditDate="2017-06-11T06:03:22.437" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T06:03:22.437" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44480989      <row Id="44480989" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44481041" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44480989" CreationDate="2017-06-11T06:33:46.260" Score="1" Body="<p>If in a map you want to store multiple values associated with the same key, the value type must be suitable for that. A struct isn't, but a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">slice</a> is a perfect choice.</p>

<p>So change your value type to <code>[]A</code>:</p>

<pre><code>letSee := map[X][]A{}
letSee[X{1}] = []A{A{"T", B{"T1", C{"T11", "T12"}}}}
letSee[X{1}] = append(letSee[X{1}], A{"L", B{"L1", C{"L11", "L12"}}})

fmt.Printf("%+v", letSee)
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/g1-aWge1IA" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>map[{key:1}:[{value1:T value2:{value3:T1 value4:{value5:T11 value6:T12}}}
    {value1:L value2:{value3:L1 value4:{value5:L11 value6:L12}}}]]
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-11T06:55:34.380" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T06:55:34.380" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44481659      <row Id="44481659" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44482304" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44481659" CreationDate="2017-06-11T09:29:51.550" Score="2" Body="<p>You should remove the <code>default</code> clauses from the <code>select</code> statements. </p>

<p>Since your <code>select</code> statement is within a <code>for</code> loop and the <code>default</code> clause prevents it from blocking, the loop has to go through a lot of cycles before any message will be received. </p>

<p>Looks like Playground detects it and stops the program.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastEditorUserId="4283005" LastEditDate="2017-06-11T09:37:05.717" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T09:37:05.717" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44482738      <row Id="44482738" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44482777" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44482738" CreationDate="2017-06-11T10:28:53.983" Score="1" Body="<p>You can generate a random number with <a href="https://godoc.org/crypto/rand#Read" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>crypto.Rand</code></a>, and then convert those bytes to an int64 using the <a href="https://godoc.org/encoding/binary" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>binary</code></a> package:</p>

<pre><code>func randint64() (int64, error) {
    var b [8]byte
    if _, err := rand.Read(b[:]); err != nil {
        return 0, err
    }
    return int64(binary.LittleEndian.Uint64(b[:])), nil
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/2Q8tvttqbJ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/2Q8tvttqbJ</a> (result is cached)</p>

<p>If you look at the <a href="https://golang.org/src/encoding/binary/binary.go#L75" rel="nofollow noreferrer">source code for <code>LittleEndian.Uint64</code></a>, you can see it's simply performing a few bit operations on the data; something that you could implemented for yourself.</p>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T10:28:53.983" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44482683      <row Id="44482683" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44482948" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44482683" CreationDate="2017-06-11T10:47:30.380" Score="0" Body="<p>I think you not only installed the <code>Golang</code> but also install/configure <code>Visual Studio Code</code> IDE with Go Extension. Those <em>alien</em> repositories were created when the extension installs needed tools. The full list of tools can be found <a href="https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/wiki/Go-tools-that-the-Go-extension-depends-on" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>. Or probably other similar IDE/extension which depends on those tools.</p>

<ol>
<li>Yes you can clear the sources, since the IDE depends only on the compiled binary, and the sources are only needed during compilation.</li>
<li>Same as (1). Refers to <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/SubRepositories" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Golang SubRepositories</a></li>
<li>Same as (1)</li>
<li>For now, you can clear the content of <code>pkg</code> directory but don't remove the directory. In the future, when you install some packages/libraries, the compiled version may be created under the directories, so don't remove it. For <code>bin</code> directory, don't remove the files inside it, because the IDE (Go Extension) depends on them. </li>
</ol>

<p>But, since I don't know exactly what else you've done, I think before you completely remove them, try just to move them outside your <code>GOPATH</code> or take a backup and see whether your <code>dev environment</code> works as expected. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T10:47:30.380" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44483409      <row Id="44483409" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44483576" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44483409" CreationDate="2017-06-11T11:56:29.643" Score="3" Body="<p>Your <code>cmplt</code> is expecting a <code>uint64</code> slice, and not a 3 element array. <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_expressions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Taking a slice</a> of <code>table[i]</code> will fix the error:</p>

<pre><code>cmplt(in, table[i][:])
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T11:56:29.643" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44365009      <row Id="44365009" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44484256" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44365009" CreationDate="2017-06-11T13:14:19.650" Score="1" Body="<p>I tried with this and works:</p>

<pre><code>type Foo struct {                                                                                                                                                    
    mock.Mock                                                                                                                                                          
}                                                                                                                                                                    

func (m *Foo) Bar() {                                                                                                                                                
    m.Called()                                                                                                                                                         
}                                                                                                                                                                    

func TestFoo(t *testing.T) {                                                                                                                                         
    m := &amp;Foo{}                                                                                                                                                        
    m.On("Bar").Return(nil)                                                                                                                                            

    m.Bar()                                                                                                                                                            
    m.AssertCalled(t, "Bar")                                                                                                                                           
}
</code></pre>

<p>As stated by <strong>Chris Drew</strong>, you've to use a receiver pointer on <em>Bar</em> method's declaration.</p>

<p>Additionally, you've to istantiate a new structure as pointer and mock the method to return a value.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5285360" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T13:14:19.650" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44486749      <row Id="44486749" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44486854" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44486749" CreationDate="2017-06-11T17:45:00.620" Score="3" Body="<p>There is no such thing as passing by reference in Go. Whenever you pass anything (pointer, slice header, map) it is always passed by value. The question is what exactly is being passed by value (i.e. what is the actual <code>value</code> of the type).  </p>

<p>When u pass a map, you pass a copy of <strong>the pointer</strong> to its header, which contains a set pointers to the buckets, as in the implementation of the HashTable. <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/runtime/hashmap.go#L106" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/runtime/hashmap.go#L106</a> </p>

<p>Therefore it rarely makes sense to pass a pointer to the map, because the operation of copying a map header pointer is extremely cheap. </p>

<p>Now why the order is different, this is simply due to internal implementation of the map, ranging over the keys occurs in a random fashion. Again this is just an implementation details. </p>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong> </p>

<p>As @icza correctly pointed out, passing a map is actually passing a copy of a <em>pointer</em> to the map header, not the map header itself. Sorry for the confusion</p>
" OwnerUserId="1597656" LastEditorUserId="1597656" LastEditDate="2017-06-11T20:42:38.167" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T20:42:38.167" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44478623      <row Id="44478623" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44487252" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44478623" CreationDate="2017-06-11T18:27:06.577" Score="1" Body="<p>Found it why your snippet doesn't work as expected.</p>

<p>Typically <code>CombinedOutput()</code> and <code>Output()</code> returns the result after completion of given command.</p>

<p>Here <code>gcloud</code> command didn't finish the execution, so we have to read it realtime. I have tested the below code snippet, it works.</p>

<pre><code>cmd := exec.Command("bash", "-c", "gcloud auth application-default login")
stderr, err := cmd.StderrPipe()
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}

// Start command
if err = cmd.Start(); err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}

// prevent main() to exit before cmd completes
defer cmd.Wait()

// read cmd output and send it to stdout
// repalce os.Stderr as per your need
go io.Copy(os.Stdout, stderr)

fmt.Println("Standby to read...")
fmt.Println()
</code></pre>

<p>This is just an approach, implement yours. Good luck!</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T18:27:06.577" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44487910      <row Id="44487910" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44488037" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44487910" CreationDate="2017-06-11T19:43:51.857" Score="1" Body="<blockquote>
  <p><em>Which one of the following methods are better performance-wise?</em></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Definitely not this.</p>

<pre><code>str := "large text"
str2 := []byte(str)
for _, s := range str2 {
  // use s
}
</code></pre>

<p>Strings are immutable. <code>[]byte</code> is mutable. That means <code>[]byte(str)</code> makes a copy. So the above will copy the entire string. I've found being unaware of when strings are copied to be a major source of performance problems for large strings.</p>

<p>If <code>str2</code> is never altered, the compiler <em>may</em> optimize away the copy. For this reason, it's better to write the above like so to ensure the byte array is never altered.</p>

<pre><code>str := "large text"
for _, s := range []byte(str) {
  // use s
}
</code></pre>

<p>That way there's no <code>str2</code> to possibly be modified later and ruin the optimization.</p>

<p>But this is a bad idea because it will corrupt any multi-byte characters. See below.</p>

<hr>

<p>As for the byte/rune conversion, performance is not a consideration as they are not equivalent. <code>c</code> will be a rune, and <code>str[i]</code> will be a byte. If your string contains multi-byte characters, you have to use runes.</p>

<p>For example...</p>

<pre><code>package main

import(
    "fmt"
)

func main() {
    str := "snow  man"
    for i, c := range str {
        fmt.Printf("c:%c str[i]:%c\n", c, str[i])
    }
}

$ go run ~/tmp/test.go
c:s str[i]:s
c:n str[i]:n
c:o str[i]:o
c:w str[i]:w
c:  str[i]: 
c: str[i]:
c:  str[i]: 
c:m str[i]:m
c:a str[i]:a
c:n str[i]:n
</code></pre>

<p>Note that using <code>str[i]</code> corrupts the multi-byte Unicode snowman, it only contains the first byte of the multi-byte character.</p>

<p>There's no performance difference anyway as <code>range str</code> already must do the work to go character-by-character, not byte by byte.</p>
" OwnerUserId="14660" LastEditorUserId="14660" LastEditDate="2017-06-11T21:09:07.677" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T21:09:07.677" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44475783      <row Id="44475783" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44489565" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44475783" CreationDate="2017-06-11T23:11:11.160" Score="0" Body="<p>OK, so, to answer my own question in case this stuff comes up again.</p>

<p>The problem is poorly javascript side and I'm afraid it has to do with the fact that the web apis for form&amp;files aren't really up to scruff.</p>

<p>This is the solution I came up with javascript side:</p>

<pre><code>const uploadFile = (form_id: string) =&gt; {
    const uploadForm: HTMLFormElement = &lt;HTMLFormElement&gt;document.getElementById(form_id);
    document.getElementById("submit_form").addEventListener("click", function(e) {
        e.preventDefault()

        let reader: FileReader = new FileReader();
        reader.readAsArrayBuffer((&lt;HTMLInputElement&gt;document.getElementById('file')).files[0]);

        reader.onload = function(evt) {

            const formData = new FormData(uploadForm);
            const isPublic: boolean = (&lt;HTMLInputElement&gt;document.getElementById('public_switch')).checked;
            formData.append('file', (&lt;any&gt;evt.target).result);
            formData.append('compression', (&lt;HTMLInputElement&gt;document.getElementById('compression')).value);
            formData.append('public', String(isPublic));
            const xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
            xhr.open("POST", "/upload/");
            xhr.send(formData);
            xhr.onreadystatechange = function() {
                console.log(xhr.responseText + '  \n status is: ' + xhr.statusText);
            }

        };
    });

}
</code></pre>

<p>Quite simple really, but it took a long time to find since in the typical javascipt-community spirit all online examples are cluttered with shit.</p>

<p>The handling of large files should be done using a FileReader object which is basically called as such:</p>

<pre><code> let reader = new FileReader();
        reader.readAsArrayBuffer(dom_element_with_file_input.files[0]);
</code></pre>

<p>Then its used much like any other async web api:</p>

<pre><code>    reader.onload = function(e) {
const your_file = e.target.result
    }
</code></pre>

<p>The variable 'your_file' is then used for whatever you want to do with the file. In my case it was appending to form data which is done like this:</p>

<pre><code>        reader.onload = function(e) {
    const your_file = e.target.result
const formData = new FormData(dom_element_of_type_form);
formData.append('my_file', your_file);
formData.append('other_stuff', 'a string with metadata');
        }
</code></pre>

<p>I'm leaving this as an example since I could not actually find any so post with a clear example of the file Reader API, expect for ones cluttered in literally hundreds of lines of code. The example I followed almost to the T is the one here:</p>

<p><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Using_files_from_web_applications" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Using_files_from_web_applications</a>. But I used 'readAsArrayBuffer' instead for speed purposes.</p>

<p>One last note is that the reader API seems to be very slow and consumes a lot of ressource, which means that for arbitrary file sizes browser may simply crash, I had this problem with chromioum and I still can't fix it, so I'm open to suggestions, if I find a fix for browser crashes (or at least a way to handle them gracefully) I will update the question and mark it as the answer, in the meanwhile if anyone find a duplicate of my answer or a way to fix the browser crashes please tell me.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7156008" LastActivityDate="2017-06-11T23:11:11.160" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44488888      <row Id="44488888" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44489637" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44488888" CreationDate="2017-06-11T23:24:19.070" Score="1" Body="<p>For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
    "image"
    "os"

    _ "image/jpeg"
)

func main() {
    fName := "ggk3Z.jpg"
    f, err := os.Open(fName)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Fprintln(os.Stderr, err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
    defer f.Close()
    img, _, err := image.Decode(f)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Fprintln(os.Stderr, err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }

    // http://www.dcode.fr/binary-image
    var txt bytes.Buffer
    bounds := img.Bounds()
    for y := bounds.Min.Y; y &lt; bounds.Max.Y; y++ {
        for x := bounds.Min.X; x &lt; bounds.Max.X; x++ {
            r, g, b, _ := img.At(x, y).RGBA()
            bin := "0"
            if float64((r+g+b))/3 &gt; 0.5 {
                bin = "1"
            }
            txt.WriteString(bin)
        }
        txt.WriteString("\n")
    }
    fmt.Fprint(os.Stdout, txt.String())
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-06-12T00:45:41.477" LastActivityDate="2017-06-12T00:45:41.477" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44490565      <row Id="44490565" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44490652" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44490565" CreationDate="2017-06-12T02:34:16.320" Score="0" Body="<p>Instead of </p>

<pre><code>const options = new RequestOptions(headers);
</code></pre>

<p>Do:</p>

<pre><code>const options = new RequestOptions({ headers: headers });
</code></pre>

<p>The <a href="https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/4.0.0/packages/http/src/base_request_options.ts#L84" rel="nofollow noreferrer">constructor for <code>RequestOptions</code></a> requires a <code>RequestOptionsArgs</code>, not a <code>Headers</code>.</p>

<hr>

<p>Also, it seems you are not quite understanding CORS. You don't really need to send any header from the front-end to the back end (the browser will append what you need automatically when it notices it is a CORS request). Those headers (<code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code>) should be sent by the server only.</p>

<p>For your back-end, here's an improved suggestion (should handle most cases):</p>

<pre><code>func Cors() gin.HandlerFunc {
    log.Println("CORS Middleware")
    return func(c *gin.Context) {
        c.Writer.Header().Set("Access-Control-Allow-Origin", "*")
        c.Writer.Header().Set("Access-Control-Allow-Methods", "POST, GET, OPTIONS, PUT, DELETE, UPDATE")
        c.Writer.Header().Set("Access-Control-Allow-Headers", "Origin, Content-Type, Content-Length, Accept-Encoding, X-CSRF-Token, Authorization")
        c.Writer.Header().Set("Access-Control-Expose-Headers", "Content-Length")
        c.Writer.Header().Set("Access-Control-Allow-Credentials", "true")
        c.Writer.Header().Set("Access-Control-Max-Age", "86400")
        // c.Writer.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json") // uncomment if needed

         if c.Request.Method == "OPTIONS" {
             fmt.Println("OPTIONS")
             c.AbortWithStatus(200)
         } else {
             c.Next()
         }
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1850609" LastEditorUserId="1850609" LastEditDate="2017-06-12T02:45:24.647" LastActivityDate="2017-06-12T02:45:24.647" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44495489      <row Id="44495489" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44495620" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44495489" CreationDate="2017-06-12T09:13:03.123" Score="0" Body="<p>I think the doc is pretty clear on this. Both <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.Marshal()</code></a>
and <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#MarshalIndent" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.MarshalIndent()</code></a> produces a JSON text result (in the form of a <code>[]byte</code>), but while the former does a compact output without indentation, the latter applies (somewhat customizable) indent. Quoting from doc of <code>json.MarshalIndent()</code>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>MarshalIndent is like Marshal but applies Indent to format the output.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>See this simple example:</p>

<pre><code>type Entry struct {
    Key string `json:"key"`
}

e := Entry{Key: "value"}
res, err := json.Marshal(e)
fmt.Println(string(res), err)

res, err = json.MarshalIndent(e, "", "  ")
fmt.Println(string(res), err)
</code></pre>

<p>The output is (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ASeuLtLWa0" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>{"key":"value"} &lt;nil&gt;
{
  "key": "value"
} &lt;nil&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>There is also <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Encoder" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.Encoder</code></a>:</p>

<pre><code>type Entry struct {
    Key string `json:"key"`
}
e := Entry{Key: "value"}

enc := json.NewEncoder(os.Stdout)
if err := enc.Encode(e); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}

enc.SetIndent("", "  ")
if err := enc.Encode(e); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try this one on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/v1s9YkwA8w" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>{"key":"value"}
{
  "key": "value"
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-06-12T09:13:03.123" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44471749      <row Id="44471749" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44501303" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44471749" CreationDate="2017-06-12T13:59:08.433" Score="0" Body="<p>I managed to fix this issue by making use of the <code>session.StdoutPipe()</code> and <code>session.StdinPipe()</code>. I wrote a go routine which scans each byte and checks if the last written line starts with <code>"[sudo] password for "</code> and ends with <code>": "</code>. It will write the <code>password + "
"</code> to the <code>session.StdinPipe()</code> which continues execution of the script.</p>

<p><strong>Here's all of the code I have for this.</strong></p>

<pre><code>package ssh

import (
    "bufio"
    "io"
    "log"
    "net"
    "strings"

    "golang.org/x/crypto/ssh"
)

type Connection struct {
    *ssh.Client
    password string
}

func Connect(addr, user, password string) (*Connection, error) {
    sshConfig := &amp;ssh.ClientConfig{
        User: user,
        Auth: []ssh.AuthMethod{
            ssh.Password(password),
        },
        HostKeyCallback: ssh.HostKeyCallback(func(hostname string, remote net.Addr, key ssh.PublicKey) error { return nil }),
    }

    conn, err := ssh.Dial("tcp", addr, sshConfig)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    return &amp;Connection{conn, password}, nil

}

func (conn *Connection) SendCommands(cmds ...string) ([]byte, error) {
    session, err := conn.NewSession()
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    defer session.Close()

    modes := ssh.TerminalModes{
        ssh.ECHO:          0,     // disable echoing
        ssh.TTY_OP_ISPEED: 14400, // input speed = 14.4kbaud
        ssh.TTY_OP_OSPEED: 14400, // output speed = 14.4kbaud
    }

    err = session.RequestPty("xterm", 80, 40, modes)
    if err != nil {
        return []byte{}, err
    }

    in, err := session.StdinPipe()
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    out, err := session.StdoutPipe()
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    var output []byte

    go func(in io.WriteCloser, out io.Reader, output *[]byte) {
        var (
            line string
            r    = bufio.NewReader(out)
        )
        for {
            b, err := r.ReadByte()
            if err != nil {
                break
            }

            *output = append(*output, b)

            if b == byte('
') {
                line = ""
                continue
            }

            line += string(b)

            if strings.HasPrefix(line, "[sudo] password for ") &amp;&amp; strings.HasSuffix(line, ": ") {
                _, err = in.Write([]byte(conn.password + "
"))
                if err != nil {
                    break
                }
            }
        }
    }(in, out, &amp;output)

    cmd := strings.Join(cmds, "; ")
    _, err = session.Output(cmd)
    if err != nil {
        return []byte{}, err
    }

    return output, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>And an example of how you could use it.</strong></p>

<pre><code>// ssh refers to the custom package above
conn, err := ssh.Connect("0.0.0.0:22", "username", "password")
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}

output, err := conn.SendCommands("sleep 2", "echo Hello!")
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}

fmt.Println(string(output))
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4988637" LastActivityDate="2017-06-12T13:59:08.433" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44504354      <row Id="44504354" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44505268" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44504354" CreationDate="2017-06-12T17:21:34.427" Score="1" Body="<p>From <a href="https://dave.cheney.net/2012/01/18/why-go-gets-exceptions-right" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Dave Cheney</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><code>panics</code> are always fatal to your program. In panicing you never assume
  that your caller can solve the problem. Hence <code>panic</code> is only used in
  exceptional circumstances, ones where it is not possible for your
  code, or anyone integrating your code to continue.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>You should assume that a panic will be immediately fatal, for the entire program, or at the very least for the current goroutine. Ask yourself "when this happens, should the application immediately crash?" If yes, use a panic; otherwise, use an error.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-06-13T13:09:37.967" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T13:09:37.967" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44452679      <row Id="44452679" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44509434" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44452679" CreationDate="2017-06-12T22:05:38.783" Score="0" Body="<p>@radoslav-stoyanov before use my example do</p>

<p><code># docker rmi busybox</code></p>

<p>then run code</p>

<pre class="lang-golang prettyprint-override"><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "github.com/docker/distribution/context"
    docker "github.com/docker/engine-api/client"
    "github.com/docker/engine-api/types"
    "io"
    "strings"
)

func main() {
    // DOCKER
    cli, err := docker.NewClient("unix:///var/run/docker.sock", "v1.28", nil, map[string]string{"User-Agent": "engine-api-cli-1.0"})
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    imageName := "busybox:latest"

    events, err := cli.ImagePull(context.Background(), imageName, types.ImagePullOptions{})
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    d := json.NewDecoder(events)

    type Event struct {
        Status         string `json:"status"`
        Error          string `json:"error"`
        Progress       string `json:"progress"`
        ProgressDetail struct {
            Current int `json:"current"`
            Total   int `json:"total"`
        } `json:"progressDetail"`
    }

    var event *Event
    for {
        if err := d.Decode(&amp;event); err != nil {
            if err == io.EOF {
                break
            }

            panic(err)
        }

        fmt.Printf("EVENT: %+v\n", event)
    }

    // Latest event for new image
    // EVENT: {Status:Status: Downloaded newer image for busybox:latest Error: Progress:[==================================================&gt;]  699.2kB/699.2kB ProgressDetail:{Current:699243 Total:699243}}
    // Latest event for up-to-date image
    // EVENT: {Status:Status: Image is up to date for busybox:latest Error: Progress: ProgressDetail:{Current:0 Total:0}}
    if event != nil {
        if strings.Contains(event.Status, fmt.Sprintf("Downloaded newer image for %s", imageName)) {
            // new
            fmt.Println("new")
        }

        if strings.Contains(event.Status, fmt.Sprintf("Image is up to date for %s", imageName)) {
            // up-to-date
            fmt.Println("up-to-date")
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>You can see API formats to create your structures (like my <code>Event</code>) to read them here <a href="https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.27/#operation/ImageCreate" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://docs.docker.com/engine/api/v1.27/#operation/ImageCreate</a></p>

<p>I hope it helps you solve your problem, thanks.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1653085" LastEditorUserId="1653085" LastEditDate="2017-06-19T10:14:29.250" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T10:14:29.250" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44510661      <row Id="44510661" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44510724" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44510661" CreationDate="2017-06-13T00:45:40.627" Score="4" Body="<p>Set the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Disposition" rel="nofollow noreferrer">content disposition</a> header before serving the content:</p>

<pre><code>f, err := os.Open(file.Path)
if err != nil {
    // handle error
}
defer f.Close()
fi, err := f.Stat()
if err != nil {
     // handle error
}
w.Header().Set("Content-Disposition", "attachment; filename=YOURNAME")
http.ServeContent(w, r, file.Name, fi.ModTime(), f)
</code></pre>

<p>Note that this code passes an *os.File directly to ServeContent instead of reading the entire file to memory.</p>

<p>The code can be simplified further by calling <a href="https://godoc.org/net/http#ServeFile" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ServeFile</a>:</p>

<pre><code>w.Header().Set("Content-Disposition", "attachment; filename=YOURNAME")
http.ServeFile(w, r, file.Name)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="142162" LastEditDate="2017-06-13T12:52:23.977" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T12:52:23.977" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44512567      <row Id="44512567" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44513396" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44512567" CreationDate="2017-06-13T06:00:56.510" Score="1" Body="<p>Duplicate of <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13255907/in-go-http-handlers-why-is-the-responsewriter-a-value-but-the-request-a-pointer">In Go HTTP handlers, why is the ResponseWriter a value but the Request a pointer?</a></p>

<p>Mainly the ResponseWriter is an interface (you may want to understand more about interfaces, just in case you haven't gone over it). Just to add, the request is a pointer to a struct - there's no point in having a copy of the request struct (which happens when passed by value), so it's not passed as a struct (think of it esp. when you pass it downstream to other functions, you can just pass this down directly)</p>
" OwnerUserId="2969090" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T06:00:56.510" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44515710      <row Id="44515710" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44516160" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44515710" CreationDate="2017-06-13T08:31:11.743" Score="2" Body="<p>The root element of XML is unmarshalled into the type of the pointer provided. In your case, this is <code>XMLCS</code>. Since <code>version</code> is an attribute of the root element, it will go into a field named <code>version</code> in <code>XMLCS</code>, if present.</p>

<p>So changing your struct as below should fix the problem,</p>

<pre><code>type XMLCS struct {
    XMLName string `xml:"container"`
    Version string `xml:"version,attr"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Read the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/#Marshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation of Marshal</a> for details on how XML is mapped to structs.</p>
" OwnerUserId="195130" LastEditorUserId="195130" LastEditDate="2017-06-15T05:17:47.707" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T05:17:47.707" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44516601      <row Id="44516601" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44518998" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44516601" CreationDate="2017-06-13T10:32:34.303" Score="2" Body="<p>You need to be more precise when defining the regex. <code>.*</code> is too greedy and matches across commas and other stuff.</p>

<p>I suggest using</p>

<pre><code>var latencyPattern = regexp.MustCompile(`(round-trip|rtt)\s+\S+\s*=\s*([0-9.]+)/([0-9.]+)/([0-9.]+)/([0-9.]+)\s*ms`)
</code></pre>

<p>See the <a href="https://regex101.com/r/B2ESZj/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">regex demo</a>.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/drI2b8poLK" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go lang demo</a>:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "regexp"
    "strings"
    "strconv"
)

func main() {
    strOutput := `1-&gt;5 packets transmitted, 5 packets received, 0.0% packet loss
round-trip min/avg/max/stddev = 0.067/0.078/0.087/0.007 ms 
        2-&gt;5 packets transmitted, 5 received, 0% packet loss, time 801ms
rtt min/avg/max/stddev = 0.019/0.034/0.044/0.010 ms, ipg/ewma 200.318/0.038 ms`
    latencyPattern := regexp.MustCompile(`(round-trip|rtt)\s+\S+\s*=\s*([0-9.]+)/([0-9.]+)/([0-9.]+)/([0-9.]+)\s*ms`)
    matches := latencyPattern.FindAllStringSubmatch(strOutput, -1)
    for _, item := range matches {
        latency, _ := strconv.ParseFloat(strings.TrimSpace(item[3]), 64)
            jitter, _ := strconv.ParseFloat(strings.TrimSpace(item[5]), 64)
            fmt.Printf("AVG = %.3f, STDDEV = %.3f\n", latency, jitter)

        }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Result:</p>

<pre><code>AVG = 0.078, STDDEV = 0.007
AVG = 0.034, STDDEV = 0.010
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Pattern details</strong>:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>(round-trip|rtt)</code> - <code>round-trip</code> or <code>rtt</code> substrings</li>
<li><code>\s+</code> - 1+ whitespaces</li>
<li><code>\S+</code> - 1+ non-whitespace symbols</li>
<li><code>\s*=\s*</code> - a <code>=</code> enclosed with 0+ whitespaces</li>
<li><code>([0-9.]+)</code> - Group 1: the first number</li>
<li><code>/</code> - a <code>/</code></li>
<li><code>([0-9.]+)</code> - Group 2: the second number</li>
<li><code>/</code> - a <code>/</code></li>
<li><code>([0-9.]+)</code> - Group 3: the third number</li>
<li><code>/</code> - a <code>/</code></li>
<li><code>([0-9.]+)</code> - Group 4: the fourth number</li>
<li><code>\s*</code> - 0+ whitespaces</li>
<li><code>ms</code> - a substring <code>ms</code></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="3832970" LastEditorUserId="3832970" LastEditDate="2017-06-13T11:03:24.890" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T11:03:24.890" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44512577      <row Id="44512577" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44523442" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44512577" CreationDate="2017-06-13T13:47:47.503" Score="1" Body="<p>According to <a href="https://github.com/shirou/gopsutil/issues/339" rel="nofollow noreferrer">similar issue</a>, and also in <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/19734" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Golang issue #19734</code></a>, <code>cgo</code> command broken on darwin after performing c tool-chain (Xcode 8.3) update from Apple.</p>

<p>The solution: <code>upgrade to go1.8.1 or above</code> or add <code>-ldflags=-s</code> to <code>build</code> or <code>test</code> command, e.g. <code>go build -ldflags=-s</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T13:47:47.503" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44527223      <row Id="44527223" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44527543" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44527223" CreationDate="2017-06-13T17:03:06.710" Score="3" Body="<p>Go's <code>string</code> type stores the UTF-8 encoded byte sequence of the text. This is a design decision that has been made and it won't change.</p>

<p>If you want to efficiently get a <code>rune</code> from it at an arbitrary index, you have to decode the bytes, you can't do anything about that (the <code>for ... range</code> does this decoding). There is no "shortcut". The chosen representation just doesn't provide this out of the box.</p>

<p>If you have to do this frequently / many times, you should change your input and not use <code>string</code> but a <code>[]rune</code>, as it's a slice and can be efficiently indexed. <code>string</code> in Go is not <code>[]rune</code>. <code>string</code> in Go is effectively a read-only <code>[]byte</code> (UTF-8). Period.</p>

<p>If you can't change the input type, you may build an internal cache mapped from <code>string</code> to its <code>[]rune</code>:</p>

<pre><code>var cache = map[string][]rune{}

func RuneAt(s string, idx int) rune {
    rs := cache[s]
    if rs == nil {
        rs = []rune(s)
        cache[s] = []rune(s)
    }
    if idx &gt;= len(rs) {
        return 0
    }
    return rs[idx]
}
</code></pre>

<p>It depends on case whether this is worth it: if <code>RuneAt()</code> is called with a small set of <code>string</code>s, this may improve performance a lot. If the passed strings are more-or-less unique, this will result in worse performance and a lot of memory usage. Also this implementation is not safe for concurrent use.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T04:36:05.057" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T04:36:05.057" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44515677      <row Id="44515677" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44528288" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44515677" CreationDate="2017-06-13T17:47:47.527" Score="1" Body="<p>You're code looks alright. However it can be simplified-</p>

<pre><code>var b bytes.Buffer // you could use buffer pool here
err := jsonapi.MarshalManyPayload(&amp;b, albumList())
if err != nil {
    return err
}
return c.JSONBlob(http.StatusOK, b.Bytes())
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Following approaches for your thoughts:</p>

<p>Approach 1 -</p>

<pre><code>c.Response().Header().Set(echo.HeaderContentType, jsonapi.MediaType)
c.Response().WriteHeader(http.StatusOK)
return jsonapi.MarshalManyPayload(c.Response(), albumList())
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Approach 2 -</p>

<pre><code>var b bytes.Buffer // you could use buffer pool here
err := jsonapi.MarshalManyPayload(&amp;b, albumList())
if err != nil {
    return err
}
c.Response().Header().Set(echo.HeaderContentType, jsonapi.MediaType)
c.Response().WriteHeader(http.StatusOK)
_, err := b.WriteTo(c.Response())
return err
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="434792" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T12:00:59.140" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T12:00:59.140" CommentCount="2" />

question:
43796314      <row Id="43796314" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44529216" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="43796314" CreationDate="2017-06-13T18:43:41.387" Score="1" Body="<p>[Disclaimer: I work at <a href="http://www.lightstep.com" rel="nofollow noreferrer">LightStep]</a></p>

<p>Sorry you're having trouble getting Java and Go to play well together.  I suspect this is caused by time-correction being enabled in Java but not being used in Go.  </p>

<p>You can disable time correction in Java using the <code>withClockSkewCorrection(boolean clockCorrection)</code> 
option to turn off clockCorrection when passing in options to the LightStep tracer</p>

<p>Here is the updated <a href="https://github.com/lightstep/lightstep-tracer-java#disabling-default-clock-correction" rel="nofollow noreferrer">README</a> and a link to the <a href="https://github.com/lightstep/lightstep-tracer-java/blob/271ab07d6757c160273d37d3564ea2e8698aa38e/common/src/main/java/com/lightstep/tracer/shared/Options.java#L289" rel="nofollow noreferrer">option code</a></p>

<p>If you contact us via the [Support] button in LightStep, we should be able to get you sorted out.  Please send us a note so that we can confirm that this is solved for you.   </p>

<p>We'll start monitoring SO more carefully so that we catch these things earlier.  </p>

<p>Thanks and happy tracing!  </p>

<p>Will</p>
" OwnerUserId="1359408" LastEditorUserId="1359408" LastEditDate="2017-06-13T20:47:13.053" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T20:47:13.053" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44531857      <row Id="44531857" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44532120" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44531857" CreationDate="2017-06-13T21:47:05.453" Score="2" Body="<p><code>error</code> is a built-in interface, and <code>*MyError</code> implements that interface. Even though the value of <code>err2</code> is nil, when you pass it to <code>isNil</code>, the function gets a non-nil interface value. That value contains information about the type (<code>*MyError</code>) and the value itself, which is a nil pointer.</p>

<p>If you try printing <code>err</code> in <code>isNil</code>, you'll see that in the second case, you get "some error" even though <code>err2</code> is nil. This demonstrates why <code>err</code> is not nil in that case (it has to contain the type information).</p>
" OwnerUserId="3068258" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T21:47:05.453" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44532365      <row Id="44532365" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44532400" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44532365" CreationDate="2017-06-13T22:09:12.787" Score="3" Body="<p>You <em>are</em> doubling <code>i</code>, but you're creating a new <code>i</code> every iteration, with with the value from the <code>i</code> used in the for loop clause.</p>

<p>You probably want something like</p>

<pre><code>x := 1
for i := 1; i &lt; 10; i++ {
    fmt.Println(x)
    x *= 2
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-06-13T22:26:44.133" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T22:26:44.133" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44533029      <row Id="44533029" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44533130" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44533029" CreationDate="2017-06-13T23:30:53.843" Score="3" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>which shows that the channel is holding 2 values at a time.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Thats not the case. This is how the code executes:</p>

<ol>
<li>The <strong>main</strong> goroutine blocks on a read on the channel</li>
<li>The second goroutine writes to the channel <em>and continues executing</em>.</li>
<li>The second goroutine blocks <em>at the second write attempt</em> because noone is reading</li>
<li>The <strong>main</strong> goroutine continues executing, prints the read number</li>
<li>The <strong>main</strong> goroutine reads another number since someone is writing to it</li>
<li>The <strong>main</strong> goroutine prints the read number and blocks on the next read</li>
<li>The second goroutine continues executing at step <strong>2.</strong></li>
</ol>

<p>There is no buffer, just concurrency.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1080064" LastActivityDate="2017-06-13T23:30:53.843" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44532017      <row Id="44532017" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44533710" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44532017" CreationDate="2017-06-14T00:52:21.027" Score="2" Body="<p>Another solution is by changing the template definition to</p>

<pre><code>// Define Template
t := template.Must(template.New("t2").Parse(`
    Hello World!
    The table name is {{with .table_name}}{{index . 0}}{{else}}DefaultTableName{{end}}
`))
</code></pre>

<p>But, the value won't be stored in a variable, so if you want to reuse it in other places, you need to write it again. The main purpose of the standard template package is for rendering <em>precomputed</em> value, and <em>logic</em> related operations/functions have limited capability. However, you can define your own <code>function</code> then register it to the template's <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/#FuncMap" rel="nofollow noreferrer">FuncMap</a> e.g. the <code>default</code> function mentioned by @jeevatkm.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T00:52:21.027" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44535260      <row Id="44535260" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44536004" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44535260" CreationDate="2017-06-14T05:19:11.213" Score="1" Body="<p>A better way to solve your problem would be to use closures.</p>

<p>For example, change the type of <code>retryer</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func retryer(f func() error, maxRetry int, waitBetween time.Duration) error {
    // retry and wait logic
    err := f()
    // error handling, retry, and wait logic
    return err
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now call functions to be retried as:</p>

<pre><code>// ...
classId := "some value"
// ...

var st []Student
var errors []error
err := retryer(func() error {
    st, errors = GetTopStudent(classId)
    // handle errors
    return nil
}, numTries, waitTime)
// use st here
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3129778" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T05:19:11.213" CommentCount="0" />

You can expand it by adding this line to <code>CreateUserID</code>:</p>

</code></pre>

question:
44539107      <row Id="44539107" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="44539590" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44539107" CreationDate="2017-06-14T08:36:42.543" Score="1" Body="<p>Given that it's not known the implementation of <code>hub</code>, sending messages to the <code>hub.Broadcast</code> channel is blocking, therefore if nobody is consuming messages from it it will wait, preventing the loop to continue.</p>

question:
44539789      <row Id="44539789" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44540053" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44539789" CreationDate="2017-06-14T08:56:33.880" Score="1" Body="<p>You may use <code>fmt.Sprint</code></p>

<p><code>fmt.Sprint</code> retunrs string format of any vriable passed to it</p>

question:
44536740      <row Id="44536740" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44543414" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44536740" CreationDate="2017-06-14T11:24:37.107" Score="2" Body="<p>Your proposed solution is not valid code, it has multiple errors.</p>

<p>For example <code>GetSize()</code> has no result type, so you couldn't return anything.</p>

<p>Next, the expression you return is also a syntax error, it attempts to convert an <code>*int</code> pointer to <code>int</code> which is not valid.</p>

<p>You need to dereference the pointer first, so the correct syntax would be:</p>

<pre><code>func GetSize(T interface{}) int {
    size := reflect.TypeOf(T).Size()
    return int(*(*int)(unsafe.Pointer(size)))
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>But.</strong> It makes no sense. <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#Type" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect.Type.Size()</code></a> already returns the size (the number of bytes needed to store a value of the given type), so there is no need of that <code>unsafe</code> magic. What may be confusing is that its return type is <code>uintptr</code>, but you may simply use that value after converting it to <code>int</code> for example.</p>

<p>Simply use:</p>

<pre><code>func GetSize(v interface{}) int {
    return int(reflect.TypeOf(v).Size())
}
</code></pre>

<p>Testing it:</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println("Size of int:", GetSize(int(0)))
fmt.Println("Size of int64:", GetSize(int64(0)))
fmt.Println("Size of [100]byte:", GetSize([100]byte{}))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/vaKGKyMuFp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Size of int: 4
Size of int64: 8
Size of [100]byte: 100
</code></pre>

<p>One thing you must not forget: this <code>GetSize()</code> will not recurisvely examine the size of the passed value. So for example if it's a struct with a pointer field, it will not "count" the size of the pointed value, only the size of the pointer field.</p>

<p>Constructing a <code>GetSize()</code> that recurisvely counts the total size of a complex data structure is non-trivial due to types like <code>map</code>. For details, see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44257522/how-to-get-variable-memory-size-of-variable-in-golang/44258164#44258164">How to get variable memory size of variable in golang?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T11:47:11.233" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T11:47:11.233" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44543374      <row Id="44543374" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44543748" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44543374" CreationDate="2017-06-14T11:39:44.397" Score="3" Body="<p>The <code>Vector3.Normalize()</code> method has a <em>pointer</em> receiver, so in order to call this method, a pointer to <code>Vector3</code> value is required (<code>*Vector3</code>). In your first example you store the return value of <code>Vector3.Minus()</code> in a variable, which will be of type <code>Vector3</code>.</p>

<p>Variables in Go are addressable, and when you write <code>diff.Normalize()</code>, this is a shortcut, and the compiler will automatically take the address of the <code>diff</code> variable to have the required receiver value of type <code>*Vector3</code> in order to call <code>Normalize()</code>. So the compiler will "transform" it to</p>

<pre><code>(&amp;diff).Normalize()
</code></pre>

<p>This is detailed in <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Calls" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Calls:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A method call <code>x.m()</code> is valid if the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_sets" rel="nofollow noreferrer">method set</a> of (the type of) <code>x</code> contains <code>m</code> and the argument list can be assigned to the parameter list of <code>m</code>. If <code>x</code> is <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">addressable</a> and <code>&amp;x</code>'s method set contains <code>m</code>, <code>x.m()</code> is shorthand for <code>(&amp;x).m()</code>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The reason why your second example doesn't work is because return values of function and method calls are <strong>not addressable</strong>, so the compiler is not able to do the same here, the compiler is not able to take the address of the return value of the <code>Vector3.Minus()</code> call.</p>

<p>What is addressable is exactly listed in the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Address operators:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The operand must be <em>addressable</em>, that is, either a variable, pointer indirection, or slice indexing operation; or a field selector of an addressable struct operand; or an array indexing operation of an addressable array. As an exception to the addressability requirement, <code>x</code> [in the expression of <code>&amp;x</code>] may also be a (possibly parenthesized) <a href="http://golang.org/ref/spec#Composite_literals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">composite literal</a>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>See related questions:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/30744965/how-to-get-the-pointer-of-return-value-from-function-call/30751102#30751102">How to get the pointer of return value from function call?</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34197248/how-can-i-store-reference-to-the-result-of-an-operation-in-go/34197367#34197367">How can I store reference to the result of an operation in Go?</a></p>

<h3>Possible "workarounds"</h3>

<p>"Easiest" (requiring the least change) is simply to assign to a variable, and call the method after that. This is your first working solution.</p>

<p>Another way is to modify the methods to have a value receiver (instead of pointer receiver), so that there is no need to take the address of the return values of the methods, so calls can be "chained". Note that this might not be viable if a method needs to modify the receiver, as that is only possible if it is a pointer (as the receiver is passed just like any other parameters  by making a copy , and if it's not a pointer, you could only modify the copy).</p>

<p>Another way is to modify the return values to return pointers (<code>*Vector3</code>) instead of <code>Vector3</code>. If the return value is already a pointer, no need to take its address as it's good as-is for the receiver to a method that requires a pointer receiver.</p>

<p>You may also create a simple helper function which returns its address. It could look something like this:</p>

<pre><code>func pv(v Vector3) *Vector3 {
    return &amp;v
}
</code></pre>

<p>Using it:</p>

<pre><code>dir := pv(projected.Minus(c.Origin)).Normalize()
</code></pre>

<p>This could also be a method of <code>Vector3</code>, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>func (v Vector3) pv() *Vector3 {
    return &amp;v
}
</code></pre>

<p>And then using it:</p>

<pre><code>dir := projected.Minus(c.Origin).pv().Normalize()
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Some notes:</strong></p>

<p>If your type consists of 3 <code>float64</code> values only, you should not see significant performance differences. But you should be consistent about your receiver and result types. If most of your methods have pointer receivers, so should all of them. If most of your methods return pointers, so should all of them.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T19:54:14.043" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T19:54:14.043" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44546106      <row Id="44546106" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44546724" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44546106" CreationDate="2017-06-14T13:49:28.090" Score="0" Body="<p>If you're mocking out clients for HTTP APIs, you might want to just use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/httptest/#Server" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>httptest.Server</code></a>, which would simplify this tremendously. Rather than mocking out the client, mock out the server the client connects to. It's really easy to use, and you can still record the request method, path, body, etc., as well as returning arbitrary response values the same way you're doing with the mock client.</p>

<p>If that's not an option, you can abstract out your mock method to make it reusable:</p>

<pre><code>type TestClient struct {
     recordedArgs [][]interface{}
     returnValues []interface{}
}

func (c *TestClient) mock(args ...interface{}) interface{} {
    c.recordedArgs = append(c.recordedArgs, args)
    if len(c.returnValues) != 0 {
        last := c.returnValues[0]
        c.returnValues = c.returnValues[1:]
        return last
    }
    return nil
}

func (c *TestClient) Request(body io.Reader, method string, endpoint string, headers []Header) ([]byte, error) {
    return c.mock(body,method,endpoint,headers).([]byte), nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>This cuts your usage-specific method down to one line.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T13:49:28.090" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44552057      <row Id="44552057" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44552180" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44552057" CreationDate="2017-06-14T18:32:32.897" Score="1" Body="<p>Yes, you can use the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/runtime/#Stack" rel="nofollow noreferrer">runtime.Stack</a> to print the stack of all goroutines:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Stack formats a stack trace of the calling goroutine into buf and returns the number of bytes written to buf. If all is true, Stack formats stack traces of all other goroutines into buf after the trace for the current goroutine.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Simple GoPlay here:<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/sB-ynAVwmU" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/sB-ynAVwmU</a></p>

<p>It also looks like you can print out the stack of a specific goroutine by using debug.PrintStack in conjunction with the runtime library. Credit from another S.O. answer here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19094099/how-to-dump-goroutine-stacktraces">How to dump goroutine stacktraces?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4746361" LastEditorUserId="4746361" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T19:20:59.517" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T19:20:59.517" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44553318      <row Id="44553318" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44553408" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44553318" CreationDate="2017-06-14T19:42:12.577" Score="2" Body="<p>Couple of issues:</p>

<ul>
<li>You have to make a slice with a length of 5 before you can access elements in it. You'll panic if you simply do var tempArr1 []int</li>
<li>You can use slices instead of arrays, and your return types will match with []int</li>
</ul>

<p>You'll find your fix here:<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/5E2hL0796o" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/5E2hL0796o</a></p>

<p>Edit: to allow you to keep your data types as an array, simply change your return types to match. Your function signature should look like this:</p>

<pre><code>func reverseReverse(first [5]int, second [5]int) ([5]int, [5]int)
</code></pre>

<p>GoPlay here:<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/_eV3Q0kspQ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/_eV3Q0kspQ</a></p>

<p>To answer your question, you cannot have a function take in an array of arbitrary size. You would have to specify the length. There is a fundamental difference in Go for []int and [5]int.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4746361" LastEditorUserId="4746361" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T20:03:38.727" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T20:03:38.727" CommentCount="8" />

question:
44554951      <row Id="44554951" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44555137" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44554951" CreationDate="2017-06-14T21:36:25.417" Score="2" Body="<p>This can be done much simpler by realizing there's no need to actually swap the individual elements. Instead, reverse each array and swap their order. Much simpler!</p>

<pre><code>func reverseReverse( a, b []int ) ([]int, []int) {
    return reverse(b), reverse(a)
}

func reverse( a []int ) []int {
    end := len(a) - 1

    // Allocate a new array slice of the same length to copy to.
    ret := make( []int, len(a) )

    // Copy each element of a into ret, reversed.
    for i := range a {
        ret[end-i] = a[i]
    }

    return ret
}
</code></pre>

<p>With that revelation, there's little need for the very specialized <code>reverseReverse</code> function. Swap the order yourself.</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println(reverse(sliceH), reverse(sliceF))
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Note that if you just want to take a slice of an array, it's sufficient to write <code>sliceH []int := h[:]</code> without specifying the start and end. The start is assumed to be 0 and the end is the end. Also note there's no need to declare the type, <code>:=</code> takes care of that for you.</p>

<p>Even better, you can declare and initialize them directly.</p>

<pre><code>sliceF:= []int{1,2,3,4,5}
sliceH:= []int{6,7,8,9,10}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="14660" LastEditorUserId="14660" LastEditDate="2017-06-14T21:42:46.743" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T21:42:46.743" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44488526      <row Id="44488526" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44555600" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44488526" CreationDate="2017-06-14T22:19:12.163" Score="0" Body="<p>I updated my code, as per the comment from @AniSkywalker to the following code, using the UnmarshalText:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
)

type Priority int

const (
    VERYLOW = Priority(iota)
    LOW
    MEDIUM
    HIGH
    VERYHIGH
)

const (
    verylow  = "verylow"
    low      = "low"
    medium   = "medium"
    high     = "high"
    veryhigh = "veryhigh"

    // ANSI color constants.
    RESET      = "\x1b[0m"
    BRIGHT     = "\x1b[1m"
    DIM        = "\x1b[2m"
    UNDERSCORE = "\x1b[4m"
    BLINK      = "\x1b[5m"
    REVERSE    = "\x1b[7m"
    HIDDEN     = "\x1b[8m"
    FGBLACK    = "\x1b[30m"
    FGRED      = "\x1b[31m"
    FGGREEN    = "\x1b[32m"
    FGYELLOW   = "\x1b[33m"
    FGBLUE     = "\x1b[34m"
    FGMAGENTA  = "\x1b[35m"
    FGCYAN     = "\x1b[36m"
    FGWHITE    = "\x1b[37m"
    BGBLACK    = "\x1b[40m"
    BGRED      = "\x1b[41m"
    BGGREEN    = "\x1b[42m"
    BGYELLOW   = "\x1b[43m"
    BGBLUE     = "\x1b[44m"
    BGMAGENTA  = "\x1b[45m"
    BGCYAN     = "\x1b[46m"
    BGWHITE    = "\x1b[47m"

    TITLE_COLOUR = BRIGHT + FGGREEN
    NUMBER_COLOR = FGGREEN

    //color constants
    BLACK         = "BLACK"
    RED           = "RED"
    GREEN         = "GREEN"
    YELLOW        = "YELLOW"
    BLUE          = "BLUE"
    MAGENTA       = "MAGENTA"
    CYAN          = "CYAN"
    WHITE         = "WHITE"
    BRIGHTBLACK   = "BRIGHTBLACK"
    BRIGHTRED     = "BRIGHTRED"
    BRIGHTGREEN   = "BRIGHTGREEN"
    BRIGHTYELLOW  = "BRIGHTYELLOW"
    BRIGHTBLUE    = "BRIGHTBLUE"
    BRIGHTMAGENTA = "BRIGHTMAGENTA"
    BRIGHTCYAN    = "BRIGHTCYAN"
    BRIGHTWHITE   = "BRIGHTWHITE"
    NOCOLOR       = ""
)

type Config struct {
    Name     string
    FGColors map[Priority]string
}

type MarshalableConfig struct {
    Name     string
    FGColors map[string]string
}

var priorityMapFromString = map[string]Priority{
    veryhigh: VERYHIGH,
    high:     HIGH,
    medium:   MEDIUM,
    low:      LOW,
    verylow:  VERYLOW,
}

var priorityToString = map[Priority]string{
    VERYHIGH: veryhigh,
    HIGH:     high,
    MEDIUM:   medium,
    VERYLOW:  verylow,
    LOW:      low,
}

func (p Priority) String() string {
    return priorityToString[p]
}

func PriorityFromString(priority string) Priority {
    if p, ok := priorityMapFromString[priority]; ok {
        return p
    }
    return MEDIUM
}

func (priority *Priority) UnmarshalText(data []byte) error {
    *priority = PriorityFromString(string(data))
    return nil
}

func main() {
    fgColors := map[string]string{
        verylow:  RED,
        low:      BLUE,
        medium:   GREEN,
        high:     BRIGHTBLUE,
        veryhigh: BRIGHTMAGENTA,
    }

    m := MarshalableConfig{"Alice", fgColors}
    b, err := json.Marshal(m)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    emptyConfig := Config{}
    err = json.Unmarshal(b, &amp;emptyConfig)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Printf("Got a error from unmarshalling: %+v \n", err)
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Printf("%+v \n", emptyConfig)
    var x interface{} = emptyConfig.FGColors[VERYHIGH]
    fmt.Println(x.(string))

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2992311" LastActivityDate="2017-06-14T22:19:12.163" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44557109      <row Id="44557109" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44558055" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44557109" CreationDate="2017-06-15T03:31:14.990" Score="4" Body="<p>Yes, it is possible. If you are going to modify the value, you must define <code>Add</code> method on pointer receiver, e.g. </p>

<pre><code>func (c *Clock) Add(minutes int) Clock{
    *c =New(0,minutes + int(*c))

    return *c
}
</code></pre>

<p>Basic rule is: use pointer receiver if you're going to change the receiver value (except for <code>slice</code> and <code>map</code> which act as reference). Take a look at the following materials for better understanding on method receiver:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>The Go tour on <a href="https://tour.golang.org/methods/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Methods</a></p></li>
<li><p>FAQ: <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#methods_on_values_or_pointers" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Should I define methods on values or pointers?</a></p></li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T03:31:14.990" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44559516      <row Id="44559516" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44559883" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44559516" CreationDate="2017-06-15T06:13:27.420" Score="0" Body="<p><a href="https://go-review.googlesource.com/c/29954/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">It's checking for overflow</a>.</p>

<pre><code>// bytes.Repeat(make([]byte, 255), int((^uint(0))/255+1)) panics with the test.
// Without the test, it returns a bad result.

b := make([]byte, 255)
count := int((^uint(0))/255 + 1)

fmt.Println("count:", count)    // prints 16843010 on the playground
fmt.Println("len(b):", len(b))  // prints 255
fmt.Println("count * len(b): ", count*len(b))  // prints 254 
fmt.Println("len(b) * count / count != len(b):", len(b)*count/count != len(b)) // prints false
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/3OQ0vB0WC4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/3OQ0vB0WC4</a></p>
