question:
44560390      <row Id="44560390" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44563025" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44560390" CreationDate="2017-06-15T08:52:59.040" Score="1" Body="<p>Drafting answer from my comments discussion with @Glavi.</p>

<p>Utilize the <code>SetMaxOpenConns</code> and <code>SetMaxIdleConns</code> settings to keep <code>TIME_WAIT</code> status and connections under control. If needed use <code>SetConnMaxLifetime</code> too, generally it's not needed.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T08:52:59.040" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44563029      <row Id="44563029" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44564082" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44563029" CreationDate="2017-06-15T09:37:57.073" Score="2" Body="<p>Yes, there might be a huge performance difference (might be several order of magnitude depending on the nature of queries you run and on system and server configuration).</p>

<p>The <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/jmoiron/sqlx#DB" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sqlx.DB</code></a> type wraps (embeds) an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/database/sql/#DB" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sql.DB</code></a> type, which manages a pool of connections:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>DB is a database handle representing a pool of zero or more underlying connections. It's safe for concurrent use by multiple goroutines.</p>
  
  <p>The sql package creates and frees connections automatically; it also maintains a free pool of idle connections. If the database has a concept of per-connection state, such state can only be reliably observed within a transaction. </p>
</blockquote>

<p>Every time you open a new connection, a lot of things have to happen in the "background": connection string has to be parsed, a TCP connection has to be estabilished, authentication / authorization must be performed, resources must be allocated at both sides (client and server) etc. These are just the main, obvious things. Even though some of these may be provided / implemented optimized, cached, there is still a significant overhead compared to having a single <code>DB</code> instance which might have multiple established, authenticated connections ready in a pool, waiting to be used / utilized.</p>

<p>Also quoting from <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/database/sql/#Open" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sql.Open()</code></a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The returned DB is safe for concurrent use by multiple goroutines and maintains its own pool of idle connections. <strong>Thus, the Open function should be called just once. It is rarely necessary to close a DB.</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/jmoiron/sqlx#Connect" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sqlx.Connect()</code></a> which you used calls <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/jmoiron/sqlx#Open" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sqlx.Open()</code></a> which is <em>"the same as sql.Open, but returns an *sqlx.DB instead"</em>.</p>

<p>So all in all, use a single, global <code>sqlx.DB</code> or <code>sql.DB</code> instance, and share / use that everywhere. It provides you automatic connection- and connection pool management. This will provide you the best performance. You may fine-tune the connection pool with the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/database/sql/#DB.SetConnMaxLifetime" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>DB.SetConnMaxLifetime()</code></a>, <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/database/sql/#DB.SetMaxIdleConns" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>DB.SetMaxIdleConns()</code></a> and <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/database/sql/#DB.SetMaxOpenConns" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>DB.SetMaxOpenConns()</code></a> methods.</p>

<p>Idle connections (<code>DB.SetMaxIdleConns()</code>) are those that are not in-use currently, but sitting in the pool, waiting for someone to pick them up. You should definitely have some of these, e.g. 5 or 10 of them, or even more. <code>DB.SetConnMaxLifetime()</code> controls how long a new connection may be used. Once it grows older than this, it will be closed (and a new one will be opened if needed). You shouldn't change this, default behavior is never to expire connections. Basically all defaults are sensible, you should only play with them if you experience performance problems. Also, read docs of these methods to have a clear picture.</p>

<p>See this similar, possible duplicate question:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40999637/mgo-query-performance-seems-consistently-slow-500-650ms/41000876#41000876">mgo - query performance seems consistently slow (500-650ms)</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-15T11:31:06.327" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T11:31:06.327" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44563162      <row Id="44563162" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44567211" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44563162" CreationDate="2017-06-15T12:13:10.160" Score="1" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>What should I use to implement DropColumn (if the column exists, otherwise not.)</p>
</blockquote>

<p>To answer your question...</p>

<p>Go ahead with that. You can use <code>db.Model(&amp;User{}).DropColumn("description")</code>.  </p>

<p><strong>Just handle the errors gracefully.</strong>  Remember, in Golang, <a href="https://blog.golang.org/errors-are-values" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Errors are values</a>.</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    db.AutoMigrate(&amp;User{})

    err := db.Model(&amp;User{}).DropColumn("description").Error
    if err != nil {
        // Do whatever you want to do!
        log.Print("ERROR: We expect the description column to be 
drop-able")
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Under the Hood, gorm will <a href="https://github.com/jinzhu/gorm/blob/2a041971f90398b736ee91c32503d4563d1d0d9e/scope.go#L348" rel="nofollow noreferrer">execute</a> raw postgresql <a href="https://github.com/jinzhu/gorm/blob/2a041971f90398b736ee91c32503d4563d1d0d9e/scope.go#L1136" rel="nofollow noreferrer">query</a> if it <a href="https://github.com/jinzhu/gorm/blob/2a041971f90398b736ee91c32503d4563d1d0d9e/scope.go#L351" rel="nofollow noreferrer">has no error</a>. Otherwise, it will <a href="https://github.com/jinzhu/gorm/blob/2a041971f90398b736ee91c32503d4563d1d0d9e/scope.go#L93" rel="nofollow noreferrer">return the error</a>.  </p>

<p>I hope this will answer your question. :)</p>
" OwnerUserId="4039768" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T12:13:10.160" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44566297      <row Id="44566297" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44567702" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44566297" CreationDate="2017-06-15T12:35:43.803" Score="1" Body="<p>This will pull out the <code>img</code> element from the read in file and then unmarshal the src attribute from the element. This is making the assumption that you will only ever need to grab the first <code>img</code> element from the file.</p>

<pre><code>XMLContent, err = ioutil.ReadFile("./uploads/moby-dick/OPS/cover.xhtml")
CheckError(err)

//Parse the XMLContent to grab just the img element
strContent := string(XMLContent)
imgLoc := strings.Index(strContent, "&lt;img")
prefixRem := strContent[imgLoc:]
endImgLoc := strings.Index(prefixRem, "/&gt;")
//Move over by 2 to recover the '/&gt;'
trimmed := prefixRem[:endImgLoc+2]

var coverFile CPSRCS
err = xml.Unmarshal([]byte(trimmed), &amp;coverFile)
CheckError(err)
fmt.Println(coverFile)
</code></pre>

<p>This will produce the result of {covers/9781449328030_lrg.jpg} for the first input file and {@public@vhost@g@gutenberg@html@files@54869@54869-h@images@cover.jpg} for the second input file you provided.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2483507" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T12:35:43.803" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44567728      <row Id="44567728" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44567980" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44567728" CreationDate="2017-06-15T12:49:30.577" Score="5" Body="<p>It is not possible for you to create such functions. Functions that have this generic, magic "gene" are builtin functions covered by the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec" rel="noreferrer">language specification</a>, listed in section <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Predeclared_identifiers" rel="noreferrer">Predeclared identifiers</a>.</p>

<p>Quoting from <a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#append" rel="noreferrer">Effective Go: Append:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The signature of <code>append</code> [...] schematically, it's like this:</p>

<pre><code>func append(slice []T, elements ...T) []T
</code></pre>
  
  <p>where <code>T</code> is a placeholder for any given type. <strong>You can't actually write a function in Go where the type <code>T</code> is determined by the caller. That's why <code>append</code> is built in: it needs support from the compiler.</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p>See related questions:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39073756/go-functions-accessed-through-variables/39073811#39073811">Go functions accessed through variables</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28487036/return-map-like-ok-in-golang-on-normal-functions/28487270#28487270">Return map like &#39;ok&#39; in Golang on normal functions</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-15T12:55:23.180" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T12:55:23.180" CommentCount="0" />

question:

<row Id="44568708" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44512343" CreationDate="2017-06-15T13:22:26.120" Score="3" Body="<p>In go1.9 the <code>go test</code> command accepts a new <code>-list</code> flag, which takes a regular expression as an argument and prints to stdout the name of any tests, benchmarks, or examples that match it, without running them.</p>

<p>The <a href="https://tip.golang.org/cmd/go/#hdr-Description_of_testing_flags" rel="nofollow noreferrer">test flags documentation</a> can be found under <a href="https://tip.golang.org" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tip.golang.org</a> until the official go1.9 release. </p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T13:22:26.120" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44563088      <row Id="44563088" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44570361" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44563088" CreationDate="2017-06-15T14:38:37.473" Score="0" Body="<p>I believe you are looking for <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/path/#Base" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>path.Base</code></a>: "Base returns the last element of path."</p>

fmt.Println(path.Base(r.URL.Path))

question:
44567386      <row Id="44567386" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44571596" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44567386" CreationDate="2017-06-15T15:35:52.847" Score="1" Body="<p>Try this approach based on the <a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/tree/master/examples/chat#chat-example" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Gorilla Chat Example</a>:</p>

<p>In the server main loop:</p>

<pre><code>select {
    case player.sendChan &lt;- somepacket:
    default:
       // The player cannot receive the packet. Close channel to
       // signal the player to exit. 
       close(player.sendChan)

       // Remove the player from server's collection of players
       // to avoid sending to closed channel.
       ...

       // Let the player's sending loop close the connection 
       // and do other cleanup.
}
</code></pre>

<p>This is sendChan:</p>

<pre><code>p.sendChan := make(chan Packet, 100)
</code></pre>

<p>In server player's sending loop (in their own goroutine):</p>

<pre><code>// Loop will exit when p.sendChan is closed.
for packet := range p.sendChan {
    // Always write with a deadline.
    p.conn.SetWriteDeadline(time.Now().Add(writeWait))
    err := sendPacket(packet)
    // Break out of write loop on any error.
    if err != nil {
       break
    }
}
// We reach this point on error sending packet or close on p.sendChan.
// Remove the player from the server's collection, close the connection and
// do any necessary cleanup for the player.
...
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T15:35:52.847" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44572067      <row Id="44572067" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44572492" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44572067" CreationDate="2017-06-15T16:22:56.903" Score="6" Body="<p>You're not doing what you think you're doing; it looks like you WANT to call a method on a memory struct, but the compiler is looking for a function named WriteRam within the memory package because of how you're calling that method.</p>

<p>Look at your signature in memory.go:</p>

<pre><code>func (memory *Memories) WriteRAM(position uint16, value uint8)
</code></pre>

<p>You have a receiver <code>func (memory *Memories)</code>. This means that in order to call this method, you need to have a memory.Memories variable declared somewhere.</p>

<p>I think you might want your main to look like this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "gogoboy/cpu"
    "gogoboy/memory"
)

func main() {
    cpu.InitializeRegisters()
    mem := memory.Memories{}
    mem.WriteRAM(0x00, 0xFF)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4746361" LastEditorUserId="4746361" LastEditDate="2017-06-15T16:30:55.187" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T16:30:55.187" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44573301      <row Id="44573301" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44573342" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44573301" CreationDate="2017-06-15T17:19:07.940" Score="1" Body="<p>You can convert an <code>[]string</code> to a string` by doing:</p>

<pre><code>import "strings"

//...

if strings.Join(s, "") == "a10" {
      fmt.Println("Worked", s)
} else {
      fmt.Println(s)
}
</code></pre>

<p>You also need to convert <code>i</code> (an int) to a <code>string</code>, most likely you would use <code>strconv.Itoa</code>.  In the end, you code would look something like this: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/gD5b5XFimJ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/gD5b5XFimJ</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "strconv"
    "strings"
)

func main() {
    var s []string
    s = append(s, "a")
    fmt.Println(s)
    for i := 0; i &lt;= 1000; i++ {
        s = append(s, strconv.Itoa(i))
        if strings.Join(s, "") == "a01" {
            fmt.Println("Worked", s)
            return
        } else {
            fmt.Println(s)
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Although, you could also just not use an array and append to the string (or an []byte) directly...</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "strconv"
)

func main() {
    var s := "a"
    fmt.Println(s)
    for i := 0; i &lt;= 1000; i++ {
        s += strconv.Itoa(i)
        if s == "a01" {
            fmt.Println("Worked", s)
            return
        } else {
            fmt.Println(s)
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>To reset the array every time, just make the main method:</p>

<pre><code>for i := 0; i &lt;= 1000; i++ {
    s := []string{"a"}
    s = append(s, strconv.Itoa(i))
    if strings.Join(s, "") == "a10" {
        fmt.Println("Worked", s)
        return
    } else {
        fmt.Println(s)
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2082673" LastEditorUserId="2082673" LastEditDate="2017-06-15T17:50:24.423" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T17:50:24.423" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44575225      <row Id="44575225" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44575837" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44575225" CreationDate="2017-06-15T19:50:27.390" Score="0" Body="<p>With <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2#Query.Select" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Query.Select()</code></a> you may specify which fields of the queried document(s) you want to retrieve, but the retrieved entities <strong>will not be the values of the selected fields, they will still be the values of the queried documents!</strong></p>

<p>So since you are querying the <code>"users"</code> collection, you should pass a value of <code>*User</code> to <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/mgo.v2#Query.One" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Query.One()</code></a>:</p>

<pre><code>name := "anything"
u := models.User{}
c := s.DB("ep2").C("users")
err := c.Find(bson.M{"name": name}).Select(bson.M{"wallet": 1}).One(&amp;u)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
    return
}

// Wallet is in u.Wallet
fmt.Printf("Result wallet: %+v", u.Wallet)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T19:50:27.390" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44575201      <row Id="44575201" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44576369" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44575201" CreationDate="2017-06-15T20:20:49.533" Score="0" Body="<p><strong>Short answer:</strong> You shouldn't do that.</p>

<p>Combining tests like that makes your code easier to write, but <em>less readable</em>.  More importantly, it makes a test failure harder to diagnose.  Suppose that 6 months from now, one of those tests starts failing. How will you know if the failure is due to <code>c.operation</code> not matching expectations, or <code>c.change</code>?</p>

<p><strong>Longer answer:</strong> Consider doing a deep-equal comparison, with a textual diff output.</p>

<p>By combining <code>reflect.DeepEqual</code>, <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/davecgh/go-spew/spew" rel="nofollow noreferrer">go-spew</a>, and a diff library, you can easily put together an assertion method that does a deep equal comparison of two structs, and if they don't match, produces a textual diff output that will make it easy to diagnose a failure.</p>

<p>I have a library that does this for use in my own personal projects. <a href="http://godoc.org/github.com/flimzy/diff" rel="nofollow noreferrer">github.com/flimzy/diff</a> It's not really intended for public consumption--I suggest just using it only for inspiration. But using it as an example:</p>

<pre><code>row := tx.QueryRow("select operation, primary_key, before_change, change, changed_at from foo.bar = 'I' order by 1 desc limit 1;")

c := columns{}
row.Scan(&amp;c.operation, &amp;c.primaryKey, &amp;c.beforeChange, &amp;c.change, &amp;c.changedAt)
expected := columns{
    operation: "I",
}
if d := diff.Interface(expected, c); d != "" {
    t.Error(d)
}
</code></pre>

<p>I leave it as an exercise for the reader how to handle the <code>changedAt</code> column in such tests.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T20:20:49.533" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44577539      <row Id="44577539" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44577611" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44577539" CreationDate="2017-06-15T21:51:51.170" Score="7" Body="<p>You can do it the same way it's done with e.g. <code>http.Pusher</code> or <code>io.Closer</code>. You create a new interface with the "optional" method, and pass around the original interface. When you want to execute the optional method, you use a type assertion to check if the value you have implements the other interface, and if it does, call the method.</p>

<pre><code> type eventHandle interface {
     eventHookTypeA
     eventHookTypeB
     // DON'T add TypeC interface.
     someOtherMethod() results
 }
 type eventHookTypeA interface {
     // method definitions
     HandleEventA() results
 }
 type eventHookTypeB interface {
     // method definitions
     HandleEventB() results
 }
 type eventHookTypeC interface {
     HandleEventC() results
 }

 func handleEvents(eventType string, handle eventHandle) results {
      if eventType == "eventA" {
         return handle.HandleEventA()
      } else if eventType == "eventB" {
         return handle.HandleEventB()
      } else if eventType == "eventC" {
         if c,ok := handle.(eventHookTypeC); ok {
             return c.HandleEventC()
         } else {
             log.Println("somewhat bad happen")
         }
      }
      return nil
 }
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-06-15T22:04:58.280" LastActivityDate="2017-06-15T22:04:58.280" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44571744      <row Id="44571744" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44580206" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44571744" CreationDate="2017-06-16T03:14:20.780" Score="0" Body="<p>Let's read how the golang official guys look at strings in go(<a href="https://blog.golang.org/strings" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/strings</a>):</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>In Go, a string is in effect a read-only slice of bytes. If you're at all uncertain about what a slice of bytes is or how it works, please read the previous blog post; we'll assume here that you have.</p>
  
  <p>It's important to state right up front that a string holds arbitrary bytes. It is not required to hold Unicode text, UTF-8 text, or any other predefined format. As far as the content of a string is concerned, it is exactly equivalent to a slice of bytes.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So, apparently in your case, s[0] is a byte type, you need explicit case if you really need the assignment.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3765983" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T03:14:20.780" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44580389      <row Id="44580389" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44580715" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44580389" CreationDate="2017-06-16T04:14:59.043" Score="0" Body="<p>Issue is struct you're passing doesn't have element in the XML hierarchy (<code>XMLName  xml.Name</code> mapping).</p>

<p>Change these two lines to-</p>

<pre><code>var rpc Rpc_reply
err2 := xml.Unmarshal(b, &amp;rpc)

question:
44586280      <row Id="44586280" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44586468" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44586280" CreationDate="2017-06-16T10:03:14.430" Score="2" Body="<p>You are creating a new <code>Queue</code> instead of accessing the one in the <code>Config</code> structure, and this new value prevents modification to the <code>Queue</code> in <code>Config.Queues</code>. Try direct assignment:</p>

<pre><code>// ...

t.Config.Queues[j].Connections = make([]*redis.Client, queue.Concurrent)

// ...
</code></pre>

<p>Or if you want to use an auxillary variable, change <code>Config.Queues</code> type to <code>[]*Queue</code>:</p>

<pre><code>type Config struct {
  Queues    []*Queue
  RedisAddr string
  RedisDB   int
}

// ...

config := Config{
  RedisAddr: "10.1.1.59:6379",
  RedisDB:   8,
  Queues: []*Queue{
    &amp;Queue{Name: "default", Concurrent: 1},
    &amp;Queue{Name: "mail", Concurrent: 2},
  },
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now your original code should work.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3129778" LastEditorUserId="3129778" LastEditDate="2017-06-16T10:08:21.717" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T10:08:21.717" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44588674      <row Id="44588674" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44588877" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44588674" CreationDate="2017-06-16T12:06:14.383" Score="2" Body="<p>Yes, you can 'cause <code>request</code> is a regular variable.
It's passed by pointer, so if you will change <code>request</code> in <code>getName</code> it will change in <code>Say</code> too.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "net/http"

func main() {
    http.HandleFunc("saySomething", Say)
}

func Say(responseW http.ResponseWriter, request *http.Request) {
    name := getName(request) // passing request value to another function
    println(name)
}

func getName(request *http.Request) string {
    request.ParseForm()
    return request.Form.Get("name")
}
</code></pre>

<p>See Golang tour <a href="https://tour.golang.org/moretypes/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tour.golang.org/moretypes/1</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="433041" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T12:06:14.383" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44588826      <row Id="44588826" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44589101" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44588826" CreationDate="2017-06-16T12:18:55.893" Score="3" Body="<p>The language specification says:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If the capacity of s is not large enough to fit the additional values, append allocates a new, sufficiently large underlying array that fits both the existing slice elements and the additional values. Otherwise, append re-uses the underlying array.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you want the slice to point to a different underlying array you need to always make a copy.</p>
" OwnerUserId="939410" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T12:18:55.893" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44594289      <row Id="44594289" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44594347" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44594289" CreationDate="2017-06-16T16:52:31.787" Score="2" Body="<p>You're looking at two separate data structures, so to unmarshal them with a single <code>struct</code> type, you'd need to account for both:</p>

<pre><code>type Owner struct {
    Name string
    Pet
    Pets []Pet `json:"Pet"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then, if you want the slice to be authoritative, after you unmarshall, move the embedded to the slice:</p>

<pre><code>// owner := unmarshall blah blah
if owner.Pet != Pet{} {
    owner.Pets = append(owner.Pets, owner.Pet)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T16:52:31.787" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44589854      <row Id="44589854" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44594408" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44589854" CreationDate="2017-06-16T16:56:04.310" Score="1" Body="<p>Yes it's possible. </p>

<ol>
<li>Suppose that the <code>GOPATH</code> is <code>C:\Work\golang</code></li>
<li>Revel project name is <code>myapp</code>, thus the location of the project (workspace) will be <code>C:\Work\golang\src\myapp</code>. </li>
<li>Make some changes to the controllers etc...</li>
<li>Run the application with <code>revel run myapp</code>, then press <code>CTRL+C</code> to exit. This step is necessary to generate corresponding go files. The generated file, i.e. the <code>main</code> package will be available under <code>${workspaceRoot}/app/tmp/main.go</code> </li>
<li><p>Configure <code>launch.json</code> as follows:</p>

<pre><code>{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch",
            "type": "go",
            "request": "launch",
            "mode": "debug",
            "remotePath": "",
            "port": 2345,
            "host": "127.0.0.1",
            "env": {},
            "showLog": true,
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app/tmp/",
            "args": ["-importPath", "myapp", "-srcPath", "c:\\work\\golang\\src",  "-runMode", "dev"]
        }
    ]
}
</code></pre></li>
<li><p>The important parts are <code>program</code> and <code>args</code> parameters, while the other parameters are unmodified. </p></li>
<li><p>Set <code>breakpoint</code> and start the <code>delve</code> debugger...</p></li>
</ol>

<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/CW1XT.jpg" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/CW1XT.jpg" alt="Debug revel application"></a></p>

<h2>EDIT:</h2>

<ol>
<li>Setting <code>args</code> parameter to <code>["-importPath", "myapp", "-srcPath", "${workspaceRoot}/..",  "-runMode", "dev"]</code> also work, and I think this should work in other platforms (Mac, Linux) too. </li>
<li>The error message is related to <code>delve</code> issue. See <a href="https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/986" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/986</a></li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-17T01:07:37.997" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T01:07:37.997" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44594659      <row Id="44594659" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44594682" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44594659" CreationDate="2017-06-16T17:13:13.997" Score="2" Body="<p>There's no difference. The interface is the type of your variable/field/parameter; the value is still (most likely) a struct. This is the same as in Java, where you can specify that a method argument is of an interface type, but you must still pass in a concretion. Calling methods on the interface-typed argument is the same as calling the method on a concrete type.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T17:13:13.997" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44596373      <row Id="44596373" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44596771" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44596373" CreationDate="2017-06-16T19:36:50.593" Score="1" Body="<p>It seems you have problem at this line-</p>

<pre><code>t := A{B_j: []B{X: name.text, Y: name.type }}
</code></pre>

<p>You're not creating a slice properly. Try following-</p>

<pre><code>t := A{B_j: []B{{X: name.text, Y: name.type}}}
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Let's do it better way-</p>

<pre><code>var bj []B
for _, name := range t.name{
  bj = append(bj, B{X: name.text,Y: name.type})
}

t := A{B_j: bj}
s, _ := json.MarshalIndent(t,"", " ")      
os.Stdout.Write(s)
</code></pre>

<p>Sample program with static values <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/a2ZDV8lgWP" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/a2ZDV8lgWP</a></p>

<p>Note: <code>type</code> is language keyword, do not use it as variable name.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-16T20:07:40.507" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T20:07:40.507" CommentCount="3" />

question:
42690138      <row Id="42690138" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44598106" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="42690138" CreationDate="2017-06-16T21:14:34.887" Score="1" Body="<p>you can solve this with <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup" rel="nofollow noreferrer">sync.WaitGroup</a></p>

<ol>
<li>You can start listening your channels in separate goroutines.</li>
<li><code>WaitGroup</code> will coordinate how many goroutines do you have.</li>
</ol>

<p><code>wg.Add(1)</code> says that we're going to start new goroutine.</p>

<p><code>wg.Done()</code> says that goroutine is finished.</p>

<p><code>wg.Wait()</code> blocks goroutine, until all started goroutines aren't finished yet.</p>

<p>This 3 methods allows you to coordinate goroutines.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/HnFG366v-C" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go playground link</a></p>

<p>PS. you might be interested in <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#RWMutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer">sync.RWMutex</a> for your <code>SafeCache</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="433041" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T21:14:34.887" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44597248      <row Id="44597248" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44598343" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44597248" CreationDate="2017-06-16T21:35:20.803" Score="2" Body="<p>ListenAndServe is a helper function that opens a listening socket and then serves connections on that socket. Write the code directly in your application to signal when the socket is open:</p>

<pre><code>l, err := net.Listen("tcp", ":8080")
if err != nil {
    // handle error
}

// Signal that server is open for business. 

if err := http.Serve(l, rootHandler); err != nil {
    // handle error
}
</code></pre>

<p>If the signalling step does not block, then http.Serve will easily consume any backlog on the listening socket.</p>

<p>Related question: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/32742904/5728991">https://stackoverflow.com/a/32742904/5728991</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-06-16T23:05:55.720" LastActivityDate="2017-06-16T23:05:55.720" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44531822      <row Id="44531822" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44600783" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44531822" CreationDate="2017-06-17T04:30:33.140" Score="1" Body="<p>I use VSCode 1.13.1 on Windows 10, and I launch or debug without any issue.</p>

<p>Launching involves in your workspace a <code>${workspaceroot}/.vscode/tasks.json</code> file.<br>
To be sure of the GOPATH value, mine includes:</p>

<pre><code>{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "build",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "options": {
                "env": {
                    "GOROOT": "D:/prgs/go/latest",
                    "GOPATH": "${workspaceRoot}"
                }
            },
            "echoCommand": false,
            "taskName": "install",
            "isBuildCommand": true
        },
</code></pre>

<p>You can replace <code>"${workspaceRoot}"</code> by <code>C:/work/go</code> in your case.<br>
That way, a <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>B</kbd> triggers a compilation+installation (<code>go install</code>)</p>

<p>And the debugger involves:</p>

<ul>
<li>having a <code>dlv.exe</code> in the %PATH%</li>
<li>a <code>${workspaceroot}/.vscode/launch.json</code> file</li>
</ul>

<p>Here is mine</p>

<pre><code>{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "name": "Launch",
            "type": "go",
            "request": "launch",
            "mode": "debug",
            "remotePath": "",
            "port": 2345,
            "host": "127.0.0.1",
            "program": "${fileDirname}",
            "env": {
                "GOPATH": "${workspaceRoot}"
            },
            "args": [],
            "showLog": true
        }
    ]
}
</code></pre>

<p>Again you can replace <code>"${workspaceRoot}"</code> by <code>C:/work/go</code> in your case (both in <code>GOPATH</code> and <code>cwd</code>). </p>

<p>Note that I specificy GOPATH <em>as well as</em> cwd (current working directory)
I open my file relative from the workspace root (that way, the breakpoints are recognized). A simple <kbd>F5</kbd> from <code>main.go</code> does run delve successfully (on Windows!)</p>

<p>With that, I can launch VSCode from a <code>cmd</code> Windows shell which has no <code>GOROOT</code> or <code>GOPATH</code> set, and it still works. (because my local user settings do include <code>"go.goroot": "D:/prgs/go/latest"</code>)</p>
" OwnerUserId="6309" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T04:30:33.140" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44602568      <row Id="44602568" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44602970" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44602568" CreationDate="2017-06-17T09:33:55.713" Score="4" Body="<p>I think you're looking for the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#Stringer" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Stringer</a> interface.</p>

<pre><code>type Stringer interface {
    String() string
}
</code></pre>

<p>Any type that implements this interface will be automatically stringified using it by many different libraries, obviously including the <code>fmt</code> package, and will indeed work in your example of <code>fmt.Println</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T09:33:55.713" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44602741      <row Id="44602741" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44606795" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44602741" CreationDate="2017-06-17T16:23:53.800" Score="2" Body="<p>In addition to Go's refusal to convert slices along these variance relationships addressed in other answers here, it's useful to think through <em>why</em> Go refuses to do so, even when the in-memory representation would be the same between the two types.</p>

<p>In your example, supplying a slice of <code>woofRunners</code>s as a parameter of type <code>[]woofer</code> is asking for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covariance_and_contravariance_(computer_science)#Arrays" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><em>covariant</em> treatment</a> of the slice's element type. When <strong>reading</strong> from the slice, indeed, since a <code>woofRunner</code> <em>is a</em> <code>woofer</code>, you know that every element present in a <code>[]woofRunner</code> will satisfy a reader looking for <code>[]woofer</code>. </p>

<p>However, in Go, a slice is a reference type. When passing a slice as an argument to a function, the slice is copied, but the copy used in the invoked function body continues to refer to the same backing array (absent reallocation necessary before <code>append</code>ing beyond its capacity). The mutable view of an arraymore generally, inserting an item into a collectionrequires <em>contravariant</em> treatment of the element type. That is, when it comes to demanding a function parameter with the intention of <strong>inserting into</strong> or <strong>overwriting</strong> an element of type <code>woofRunner</code>, it's acceptable to supply a <code>[]woofer</code>.</p>

<p>The question is whether the function is demanding the slice parameter for</p>

<ul>
<li>reading from it (for reading <code>woofer</code>s, a <code>[]woofRunner</code> is just as good as a <code>[]woofer</code>),</li>
<li>writing to it (for writing <code>woofRunner</code>s, a <code>[]woofer</code> is just as good as a <code>[]woofRunner</code>),</li>
<li>or both (neither is an acceptable substitute for the other).</li>
</ul>

<p>Consider what would happen if Go did accept slice parameters in covariant fashion, and someone came along and changed <code>allWoof</code> as follows:</p>

<pre><code>// Another type satisfying `woofRunner`:
type wolf struct{}
func (*wolf) run()  {}
func (*wolf) woof() {}

func allWoof(ws []woofer) {
  if len(ws) &gt; 0 {
    ws[0] = &amp;wolf{}
  }
}

dogs := []*dog{&amp;dog{}, &amp;dog{}}
allWoof(dogs)  // Doesn't compile, but what if it did?
</code></pre>

<p>Even if Go was willing to treat a <code>[]*dog</code> as a <code>[]woofer</code>, we would wind up with a <code>*wolf</code> in our array of <code>*dog</code> here. Some languages defend against such an accident with run-time type checks on the attempted array insertion or overwrite, but because Go precludes us from even making it this far, it doesn't need these additional checks.</p>
" OwnerUserId="31818" LastEditorUserId="31818" LastEditDate="2017-06-17T18:40:37.483" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T18:40:37.483" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44606910      <row Id="44606910" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44607216" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44606910" CreationDate="2017-06-17T17:05:06.713" Score="2" Body="<p>You can do this <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/27eKFmBCHY" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/27eKFmBCHY</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "encoding/json"

)

func main() {
    const input = `{
        "kind": "ServiceAccount",
        "apiVersion": "v1",
        "metadata": {
            "name": "default",
            "namespace": "mynamespace",
            "selfLink":      "/api/v1/namespaces/mynamespace/serviceaccounts/default",
            "uid": "483d1043-4d68-11e7-be08-3a3f3b149220",
            "resourceVersion": "425039",
            "creationTimestamp": "2017-06-09T23:06:34Z"
        },
        "secrets": [
            {
                "name": "default-token-k99mq"
            }
         ]
    }`
    type NameStruct struct {
        Name string `json:"name"`
    }
    type Secret struct {
        Secrets []NameStruct `json:"secrets"`
    }

    secret := Secret{}
    json.Unmarshal([]byte(input), &amp;secret)
    fmt.Println(secret.Secrets[0].Name)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="615120" LastEditorUserId="615120" LastEditDate="2017-06-17T17:16:53.707" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T17:16:53.707" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44608929      <row Id="44608929" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44609465" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44608929" CreationDate="2017-06-17T21:18:06.047" Score="6" Body="<p>You're not just benchmarking Go vs D. You're also benchmarking your particular choice of non-standard Go and D libraries against each other: <code>cbor</code>, <code>vibe</code>, <code>iris</code>, etc. And you're benchmarking your particular implementation <a href="https://github.com/schwern/adventofcode.go/commit/60a05776c4c6ff7b9af9867ceaa88ee371955c2a" rel="noreferrer">which can easily vary by 1000x in performance</a>.</p>

<p>With this many variables, the raw benchmark numbers are pretty meaningless for comparing the performance of two languages. It's possible any one of those 3rd party libraries are causing a performance problem. Really you're comparing just those two particular programs. This is the core problem of trying to compare anything but trivial programs across languages: there's too many variables.</p>

<hr>

<p>You can reduce the impact of some of these variables with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Profiling_(computer_programming)" rel="noreferrer">performance profiling</a>; in Go this would be <code>go tool pprof</code>. This will tell you what functions and lines are being called how many times and taking how much resources. With that you can find bottlenecks, places in the code which are consuming a lot of resources, and focus optimization efforts there.</p>

<p>As you do profile and optimization rounds for each version, you'll get closer to comparing real, optimized implementations. Or you'll have a better understanding of what each language and library does efficiently, and what they don't.</p>

<hr>

<p>The problem of comparing languages is heavily influenced by the particular problem and the particular programmer. X programmers invariably find X to be the best language not because X is the best language, but because X programmers are their best when writing in X and probably chose a problem they're comfortable with. Because of this, there are a number of projects to crowd source the best implementation for each language.</p>

<p>The one which immediately comes to mind is <a href="http://benchmarksgame.alioth.debian.org/" rel="noreferrer">The Computer Language Benchmarks Game</a>. They do Go, but not D. Maybe you can add it?</p>
" OwnerUserId="14660" LastActivityDate="2017-06-17T21:18:06.047" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44611696      <row Id="44611696" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44611754" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44611696" CreationDate="2017-06-18T04:30:24.170" Score="3" Body="<p>Issue is <code>InventoryItem</code> struct fields have to be exported -</p>

<pre><code>type InventoryItem struct {
   ID                 int    `json:"id"`
   ProductID          string `json:"product_id"`
   ProductCost        int    `json:"product_cost"`
   ProductAvailabilty int    `json:"product_availability"`
   ProductSubcat      string `json:"product_subact"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Read more about <a href="https://www.goinggo.net/2014/03/exportedunexported-identifiers-in-go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">exported and un-exported fields</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-18T04:53:00.067" LastActivityDate="2017-06-18T04:53:00.067" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44612487      <row Id="44612487" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44613109" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44612487" CreationDate="2017-06-18T08:27:34.823" Score="1" Body="<p>With glide you can specify a certain version of the package you want to install. This is done in the glide.yaml</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>TIP: The version is either VCS dependent and can be anything that can
  be checked out or a semantic version constraint that can be parsed by
  the github.com/ Masterminds/semver package. For example, with Git this
  can be a branch, tag, or hash. This varies and depends on what's
  supported in the VCS.</p>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>package: github.com/YOUR/PACKAGE
import:
  - package: github.com/onsi/ginkgo/ginkgo
    version: master
    repo: git@github.com:onsi/ginkgo.git
</code></pre>

<p>This will download the latest master commit.</p>

<p><a href="https://glide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/versions/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Here</a> are further information about versioning with glide. </p>
" OwnerUserId="8167759" LastActivityDate="2017-06-18T08:27:34.823" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44604261      <row Id="44604261" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44613689" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44604261" CreationDate="2017-06-18T09:41:35.890" Score="0" Body="<p>Here's an example of <b>bad</b> code just to illustrate the issue:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "sync"
)

type SafeCounter struct {
    lock      sync.Mutex
    count     int
    enabled   bool
    NextValue func(int) int
}

const maxCount = 10

func (c *SafeCounter) Count() int {
    return c.count
}

func (c *SafeCounter) Increment() {
    c.lock.Lock()
    if c.enabled {
        c.count = c.NextValue(c.count)
    }
    c.lock.Unlock()
}

func (c *SafeCounter) SetEnabled(enabled bool) {
    c.lock.Lock()
    c.enabled = enabled
    if !enabled {
        c.count = 0
    }
    c.lock.Unlock()
}

func main() {
    var counter SafeCounter
    counter.SetEnabled(true)
    counter.NextValue = func(value int) int {
        if counter.Count() &gt; maxCount {
            // Safe counter doesn't expect this here!
            // The program will panic in SetEnabled
            counter.SetEnabled(false)
        }
        return value + 1
    }
    for i := 0; i &lt; 100; i++ {
        doAction()
        counter.Increment()
    }
    fmt.Println(counter.Count())
}

func doAction() {
    // some action
}
</code></pre>

<p>Both <code>Increment</code> and <code>SetEnabled</code> acquire locks because they can't allow the values of <code>enabled</code> and <code>count</code> to change while they're in the middle of something. However, if the lock was re-entrant (recursive), then it would be allowed (since both calls run on the same goroutine).</p>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastEditorUserId="4283005" LastEditDate="2017-06-18T21:45:03.713" LastActivityDate="2017-06-18T21:45:03.713" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44613920      <row Id="44613920" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44614124" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44613920" CreationDate="2017-06-18T10:39:05.070" Score="1" Body="<p>You're not closing your <code>gz</code> writer. It's possible issue. <code>gzip.Writer</code> <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/compress/gzip/#NewWriter" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a> says:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>It is the caller's responsibility to call Close on the WriteCloser when done. Writes may be buffered and not flushed until Close.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So, try to add <code>gz.Close()</code> after you've completed writing data.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8099995" LastActivityDate="2017-06-18T10:39:05.070" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44614413      <row Id="44614413" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44614615" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44614413" CreationDate="2017-06-18T11:44:31.247" Score="5" Body="<p>From the <a href="https://github.com/rzcoder/node-rsa" rel="noreferrer">Node-RSA pages</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>signingScheme  scheme used for signing and verifying. Can be <code>'pkcs1'</code> or <code>'pss'</code> or 'scheme-hash' format string (eg <code>'pss-sha1'</code>). <strong>Default <code>'pkcs1-sha256'</code></strong>, or, if chosen pss: <code>'pss-sha1'</code>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So the NodeJS implementation uses PKCS#1 v1.5 padding with SHA-256 while Go uses PSS padding with SHA-256.</p>

<p>You basically need to make sure that your signature algorithms and their parameters match. Note that you may also want to make sure that the hash function used for MGF1 (the mask generation function within PSS) matches if you go for PSS and the code keeps failing.</p>
" OwnerUserId="589259" LastActivityDate="2017-06-18T11:44:31.247" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44619606      <row Id="44619606" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44619735" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44619606" CreationDate="2017-06-18T21:33:33.293" Score="2" Body="<p>Updates: Just referred <a href="https://dev.twitter.com/rest/reference/post/media/upload#Parameters" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Twitter API Upload parameter</a>. As per your code snippet you're using both fields <code>media</code> and <code>media_data</code>. You have to use only one -</p>

<ul>
<li>Upload using base64 -> field name is <code>media_data</code></li>
<li>Upload using raw -> field name is <code>media</code></li>
</ul>

<p>And, you have to add <code>Content-Type</code> header.</p>

<pre><code>req, err := http.NewRequest("POST",
    "https://upload.twitter.com/1.1/media/upload.json",
    body)
req.Header.Set("Content-Type", writer.FormDataContentType())
if err := writer.Close(); err != nil {
   log.Println(err)
}
// Now fire the http request
</code></pre>

<p><em>PS: While composing an answer, in 30 secs gap, @cerise-limn added comment, also close the multipart writer as mentioned by @cerise-limn.</em></p>

<hr>

<p><strong>Asked in the comment:</strong></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Twitter accepts application/octet-stream, you may not need below approach.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Adding multi-part with user supplied <code>Content-Type</code> instead of <code>application/octet-stream</code>. Basically you have to do same implementation as convenience wrapper with your content-type.</p>

<pre><code>writer := multipart.NewWriter(body)
h := make(textproto.MIMEHeader)
h.Set("Content-Disposition", fmt.Sprintf(`form-data; name="%s"; filename="%s"`,
        escapeQuotes(fieldname), escapeQuotes(filename)))
h.Set("Content-Type", "image/png")
part, err := writer.CreatePart(h)
// use part same as before
</code></pre>

<p>Definition of <code>escapeQuotes</code> from multiple-part package.</p>

<pre><code>var quoteEscaper = strings.NewReplacer("\\", "\\\\", `"`, "\\\"")
func escapeQuotes(s string) string {
    return quoteEscaper.Replace(s)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-18T22:39:57.110" LastActivityDate="2017-06-18T22:39:57.110" CommentCount="9" />

question:
44626931      <row Id="44626931" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44627139" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44626931" CreationDate="2017-06-19T09:43:11.673" Score="0" Body="<p>From the <a href="https://golang.org/src/net/http/server.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a>, address value should be a string.</p>

<pre><code>// ListenAndServe always returns a non-nil error.
func ListenAndServe(addr string, handler Handler) error {
    server := &amp;Server{Addr: addr, Handler: handler}
    return server.ListenAndServe()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Can you try?</p>

<pre><code>external := http.Server{
    Addr:    ":10001",
    Handler: stack,
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="615120" LastEditorUserId="615120" LastEditDate="2017-06-19T12:19:45.577" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T12:19:45.577" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44629731      <row Id="44629731" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44629839" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44629731" CreationDate="2017-06-19T11:51:27.433" Score="5" Body="<p>Your <code>json</code> <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10858787/what-are-the-uses-for-tags-in-go/30889373#30889373">tag specification</a> is incorrect, that's why the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>encoding/json</code></a> library defaults to the field name which is <code>Name</code>. But since there is no JSON field with <code>"Name"</code> key, <code>Animal.Name</code> will remain its zero value (which is the empty string <code>""</code>).</p>

<p>Unmarshaling <code>Order</code> will still work, because the <code>json</code> package will use the field name if <code>json</code> tag specification is missing (tries with both lower and upper-case). Since the field name is identical to the JSON key, it works without extra JSON tag mapping.</p>

<p>You can't have a space in the tag specification after the colon and before the quotation mark:</p>

<pre><code>type Animal struct {
    Name  string `json:"Na me"`
    Order string `json:"Order,omitempty"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>With this simple change, it works (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ij_EunyeJB" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground)</a>:</p>

<pre><code>[{Name:Platypus Order:Monotremata} {Name:Quoll Order:Dasyuromorphia}]
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-19T15:19:43.823" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T15:19:43.823" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44592333      <row Id="44592333" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44637860" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44592333" CreationDate="2017-06-19T18:50:04.550" Score="1" Body="<p>You can try and follow the <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/43641355/6309">recommendation of this answer</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If your install is messed up beyond reason (happened to me once), just remove the cloud SDK and any references to it in your <code>$PATH</code>. Also completely uninstall the regular Go installation. </p>
  
  <p>Then start from scratch. <a href="https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/go/download" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Install Go, unpack google-cloud-sdk</a>, run installer (add to <code>$PATH</code> if needed), <code>gcloud components install app-engine-go</code>.<br>
  Voila.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>As mentioned in that same answer, you don't set <code>GOROOT</code> anywhere, <a href="https://dave.cheney.net/2013/06/14/you-dont-need-to-set-goroot-really" rel="nofollow noreferrer">it is set for you</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6309" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T18:50:04.550" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44637932      <row Id="44637932" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44638530" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44637932" CreationDate="2017-06-19T19:33:58.257" Score="3" Body="<p>You should get used to using '?' placeholders in your sql to allow for proper escaping and prevent any potential SQL injection attacks. </p>

<p>You should always check the error in Go before using the returned value. </p>

<pre><code>ip := "192.168.0.1"
rows, err := db.Query("SELECT * FROM Ip_ipdata WHERE ipHost=?", ip)
if err != nil {
    // handle error
}
// this will ensure that the DB connection gets put back into the pool
defer rows.Close()

for rows.Next() {
    // scan here
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1817176" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T19:33:58.257" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44638610      <row Id="44638610" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44638706" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44638610" CreationDate="2017-06-19T19:44:23.413" Score="0" Body="<p>Found the solution, <code>Scanner</code> and <code>Valuer</code> should be implemented on the actual value and not a pointer to the <code>customTime</code></p>

<pre><code>func (ct customTime) Scan(value interface{}) error {
    ct.Time = value.(time.Time)
    return nil
}

func (ct customTime) Value() (driver.Value, error) {
    return ct.Time, nil
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2171758" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T19:44:23.413" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44641199      <row Id="44641199" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44641440" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44641199" CreationDate="2017-06-19T23:29:05.967" Score="2" Body="<p>I have not used the bigquery, however I had a look at the <a href="https://godoc.org/cloud.google.com/go/bigquery#hdr-Schemas" rel="nofollow noreferrer">godoc</a> and <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-go/blob/master/bigquery/schema.go#L202" rel="nofollow noreferrer">source code</a>.</p>

<p>It seems, you have to use data type <code>civil.DateTime</code> <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-go/blob/master/civil/civil.go#L196" rel="nofollow noreferrer">reference</a> in the struct.</p>

<p><strong>For e.g:</strong> </p>

<p>As per godoc and source code, following should create <a href="https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/reference/standard-sql/data-types#datetime-type" rel="nofollow noreferrer">DateTime</a> field.</p>

<pre><code>type data_pix struct {
   Id      string
   IdC     string
   Stamp   civil.DateTime
   Tag     []string
}

schema, err := bigquery.InferSchema(data_pix{})
// now schema should represent DateTime Field
</code></pre>

<p>There is a <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-go/blob/9aed268b14ec7c57a2aa86795c0e63e138084524/civil/civil.go#L204" rel="nofollow noreferrer">function</a> to get <code>civil.DateTime</code> from <code>time.Time</code>. I would suggest you have a look at this <a href="https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-go/blob/master/civil/civil.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">go sourcecode</a> to know more.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-06-19T23:29:05.967" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44641643      <row Id="44641643" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44641834" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44641643" CreationDate="2017-06-20T00:20:30.457" Score="6" Body="<p>Default printing verb <code>fmt.Println</code> uses is <code>%v</code>. While printing it <a href="https://golang.org/src/fmt/print.go?s=7388:7437#L841" rel="nofollow noreferrer">differentiates</a> value vs pointer value, that's why you see <code>&amp;</code> in front of <code>cx</code>.</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println(cx)
</code></pre>

<p>Next, you specifically tell <code>fmt.Printf</code> to use the verb <code>%p</code>, refer to <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#hdr-Printing" rel="nofollow noreferrer">printing</a> section and it prints <code>base 16 notation, with leading 0x</code>.</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Printf("%p\n", cx)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="147175" LastEditDate="2017-06-21T14:06:10.590" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T14:06:10.590" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44641663      <row Id="44641663" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44641923" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44641663" CreationDate="2017-06-20T00:32:30.187" Score="3" Body="<p>You're modifying the slice, but you never assign it back to the pointer. </p>

<pre><code>func (ptr *Set) AppendElements(elements []*Element) {
    set := *ptr
    set = append(set, elements...)
    *ptr = set
}
</code></pre>

<p>Usually though, one would dereference the pointer directly in the <code>append</code> statement: </p>

<pre><code>func (set *Set) AppendElements(elements []*Element) {
    *set = append(*set, elements...)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T00:37:18.350" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T00:37:18.350" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44642132      <row Id="44642132" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44642209" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44642132" CreationDate="2017-06-20T01:08:17.543" Score="1" Body="<p>To achieve your output, define struct as follows-</p>

<pre><code>type Identification struct {
   ID    string
   Phone int64
   Email string
}
</code></pre>

<p>And perform operation as follows-</p>

<pre><code>// define slice of Identification
var idents []Identification

// Unmarshall it
err := json.Unmarshal([]byte(jsonText), &amp;idents)

// add further value into it
idents = append(idents, Identification{ID: "ID", Phone: 15555555555, Email: "Email"})

// now Marshal it
result, error := json.Marshal(idents)

// now result has your targeted JSON structure
</code></pre>

<p>Sample program of above explanation <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/67dqOaCWHI" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/67dqOaCWHI</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T01:19:08.783" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T01:19:08.783" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44642241      <row Id="44642241" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44642449" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44642241" CreationDate="2017-06-20T01:37:50.113" Score="2" Body="<p>You need to include the hostname in the dial function, otherwise it's looking at localhost which is unique to each container (docker creates a separate networking namespace for containers by default). Change the following:</p>

<pre><code>backendPort := "neo4bacon:50051"
</code></pre>

<p>Edit: you also need to setup a network and connect the containers to that network because the default bridge does not include DNS discovery:</p>

<pre><code>docker network create baconnet
docker run --rm -d --net baconnet --name neo4bacon neo4bacon
docker run --rm -d --net baconnet -p 8080:8080 --name bacon-api bacon-api
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="596285" LastEditorUserId="596285" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T01:43:11.463" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T01:43:11.463" CommentCount="0" />

Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44644123" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44643839" CreationDate="2017-06-20T04:57:45.330" Score="1" Body="<p>Yes. As per the documentation for <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/#Marshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>xml.Marshal</code></a>, you can use the tag <code>",chardata"</code>.</p>

<pre><code>type number struct {
    Number int64 `xml:",chardata"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>This outputs <code>&lt;number&gt;2&lt;/number&gt;</code>, as seen at <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Aoqfs04OTx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/Aoqfs04OTx</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="790070" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T04:57:45.330" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44642570      <row Id="44642570" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44644832" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44642570" CreationDate="2017-06-20T05:53:39.823" Score="10" Body="<h2>Summary</h2>

<p>This code is slower because of the type assertion, and reduntant data.</p>

<p>Go doesn't encourage you to write type assertions in hot places:</p>

<pre><code>tree.Value.(int) 
</code></pre>

<p>Take out this type assertion (and accordingly change <code>Value</code> to an <code>int</code> type), and your code will perform about twice as fast (which should be around the speed of your node example). </p>

<p>Take out the redundant data as well, and your code will perform about three times as fast. See the playground example at the end of the post. </p>

<h2>Details</h2>

<p>I think this is a mistake of design, rather than implementation. Reading your question, I think there is some confusion about how Go's type system works.</p>

<p>Go's object model doesn't encourage you to do polymorphism using catch-all types (see the top half of <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/41592747/790070">this excellent answer</a> for a discussion of Go's polymorphism). </p>

<p>In a JavaScript world, each object is a specific type. In Go, a <code>struct</code> can be treated as a specific interface type if it fulfils the <code>interface</code>'s contract. Note that <code>structs</code> are not objects - what you called constructors are just <code>struct</code> initialisers. </p>

<p>It is possible to write Go code that operates on <code>interface{}</code> as a placeholder for all types, but the language doesn't really encourage you to write code this way (as you pointed out in your question, it was a challenge to write clean code in the way you would write it in JavaScript).</p>

<p>Because Go doesn't really have objects, trying to write code that feels very object-oriented in Go will be challenging (additionally, Go doesn't have standard inheritance or method overloading). For this reason, I don't think that your code is the kind of code that Go encourages the programmer to write. So, it's not a fair test.</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28024884/does-a-type-assertion-type-switch-have-bad-performance-is-slow-in-go">Type assertion is slow</a>. (I'm not across the design of Go's internals, but certainly this indicates that the programmer is not expected to write a lot of type assertions). Because of this, it's not surprising that your code is not performant. I changed your code to:</p>

<pre><code>type Tree struct {
  IsLeaf bool
  Left *Tree
  Value int
  Right *Tree
} 
 .....
func sum(tree *Tree) int {
  if (tree.IsLeaf) {
    return tree.Value
  } else {
    return sum(tree.Left) + sum(tree.Right)
  }
}
</code></pre>

<p>And achieved a 2x speed up on my machine.</p>

<p>There are probably other optimisations - you might be able to remove <code>IsLeaf</code>, and you don't need to store values at non-leaf nodes (or alternatively, you could distribute values throughout the tree, so never waste the <code>Value</code>). I don't know whether JavaScript optimises out these unnecessary <code>Value</code>s, but I don't believe Go does. </p>

<p>So, I think your code is using much more memory than it needs, which won't help performance either.</p>

<h2>Does it matter?</h2>

<p>I'm not personally convinced by "I wrote this program in X and Y, and found that Y was slower", especially as it's hard to compare fairly across frameworks. There are so many other sources of variance - programmer knowledge, machine load, spin-up time, etc.</p>

<p>To do a fair test you'd need to write code that's idiomatic in each language, but also use the same code. I don't think it's realistic to achieve both.</p>

<p>If this code is your specific scenario, and performance is the primary goal, then this test might be helpful. But, otherwise I don't think it's a very meaningful comparison.</p>

<p>At scale, I would expect other considerations to beat how fast you can create and traverse a tree. There are technical concerns like data throughput and performance under load, but also softer concerns like programmer time, and maintenance effort.</p>

<p>The academic exercise is interesting, though. And writing code like this is a good way to find the edges of a framework.</p>

<hr>

<p>Edit: I tried making your code more Go-like, which has the added advantage of a 3x speedup over the original.:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/mWaO3WR6pw" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/mWaO3WR6pw</a></p>

<p>The tree is a bit heavy for the playground, but you can copy and paste the code to run locally.</p>

<p>There are more optimisations possible that I haven't tried, such as parallel construction of the tree.</p>

<p>You may be able to extend this design to have the polymorphic behaviour that you want (by providing alternative <code>Leaf</code> implementations), but I'm not sure what <code>Sum()</code> means for non-number types. Not knowing how to define <code>Sum()</code> is a good example of the kind of thinking that leads to not deciding to include polymorphism through generics.</p>
" OwnerUserId="790070" LastEditorUserId="790070" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T07:25:55.303" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T07:25:55.303" CommentCount="11" />

question:
44646378      <row Id="44646378" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44646637" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44646378" CreationDate="2017-06-20T07:32:55.010" Score="7" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#generics" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go doesn't have generic types</a>, so you're stuck with the options you listed. Sorry.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Meanwhile, Go's built-in maps and slices, plus the ability to use the empty interface to construct containers (with explicit unboxing) mean in many cases it is possible to write code that does what generics would enable, if less smoothly.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you know more about the elements you want to store in the container, you may use a more specialized interface type (instead of the empty interface <code>interface{}</code>), which</p>

<ul>
<li>could help you avoid using <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_assertions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">type assertions</a> (<strong>keep good performance</strong>)</li>
<li>and still <strong>keep type safety</strong></li>
<li>and it can be used for all types that (implicitly) implement your interface (<strong>code "re-usability"</strong>, no need to duplicate for multiple types).</li>
</ul>

<p>But that's about it. See an example of this here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39092925/why-are-interfaces-needed-in-golang/39100038#39100038">Why are interfaces needed in Golang?</a></p>

<p>Also just in case you missed it, the standard library already has a doubly linked list implementation in the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/container/list/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>container/list</code></a> package (which also uses <code>interface{}</code> type for the values).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T08:36:03.433" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T08:36:03.433" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44647225      <row Id="44647225" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44647299" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44647225" CreationDate="2017-06-20T08:05:05.367" Score="3" Body="<p>You can write a function that accepts a function, runs it and prints the time:</p>

<pre><code>import (
  "time"
  "fmt"
)

func TimeIt(f func(), description string) {
   start := time.Now()
   f()
   fmt.Printf("Running %s took %v\n", description, time.Since(start))
}
</code></pre>

<p>And then trigger it like so:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    TimeIt(doSomething, "Doing something")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Or just sprinkle it on pieces of code as a closure:</p>

<pre><code>TimeIt(func() {
     do()
     some()
     stuff()
   },
   "whatever")
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1239701" LastEditorUserId="1239701" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T08:14:21.680" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T08:14:21.680" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44647342      <row Id="44647342" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44647417" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44647342" CreationDate="2017-06-20T08:11:16.090" Score="0" Body="<p>Those two lines in your main function shadow your global variable declaration:</p>

<pre><code>optQuit := getopt.BoolLong("quit", 0, "Help")
optRun  := getopt.BoolLong("run", 'r', "Help")
</code></pre>

<p>If you only use them, to get a nice usage, why not create a usage function
yourself?</p>

<p>If you insist on using <code>getopt</code> just to create a usage, do</p>

<pre><code>_ = getopt.BoolLong("quit", 0, "Help")
_ = getopt.BoolLong("run", 'r', "Help")
</code></pre>

<p>instead.</p>

<p>You also need to call <code>getopt.Parse()</code> before using <code>*optHelp</code>.</p>

<p>The resulting message</p>

<pre><code>Usage: test [-hr] [--quit] [parameters ...]
 -h, --help  Help
     --quit  Help
 -r, --run   Help
</code></pre>

<p>seems to be less than helpful. Why not just do</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Printf(`
Usage: test
  This program will start a daemon service, which you can use like this ...
`)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7824574" LastEditorUserId="7824574" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T08:31:00.000" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T08:31:00.000" CommentCount="1" />

question:
41277465      <row Id="41277465" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44648319" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="41277465" CreationDate="2017-06-20T08:54:35.357" Score="1" Body="<p>As of now there is no direct way to do that in Go; I would recommend using <code>net use</code>, which of course limits the functionality to Windows, but that's actually what you need.</p>

<p>So, when you open a command prompt in Windows you can map network shares to Windows drives by using:</p>

<p><code>net use Q: \\SERVER\SHARE /user:Alice pa$$word /P</code></p>

<p><code>Q:</code> represents your windows drive, <code>\\SERVER\SHARE</code> is the network address, <code>/user:Alice pa$$word</code> are your credentials, and <code>/P</code> is for persistence.</p>

<p>Executing this in Go would look something like:</p>

<pre><code>func mapDrive(letter string, address string, user string, pw string) ([]byte, error) {
  // return combined output for std and err
  return exec.Command("net use", letter, address, fmt.Sprintf("/user:%s", user), pw, "/P").CombinedOutput()
}

func main() {
  out, err := mapDrive("Q:", `\\SERVER\SHARE`, "Alice", "pa$$word")
  if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
  }
  // print whatever comes out
  log.Println(string(out))
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1188357" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T08:54:35.357" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44648409      <row Id="44648409" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44650954" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44648409" CreationDate="2017-06-20T10:47:14.260" Score="0" Body="<ol>
<li>Copy the <code>asm_amd64.s</code> contents over to your package</li>
<li>Define the functions somewehere in that package</li>
<li>Use those functions in the package</li>
</ol>

<p>Example (with the asm_amd64.s in the same package):</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

func encryptBlockAsm(nr int, xk *uint32, dst, src *byte)
func decryptBlockAsm(nr int, xk *uint32, dst, src *byte)
func expandKeyAsm(nr int, key *byte, enc *uint32, dec *uint32)

func main() {
    var nr int
    var xk uint32
    var dst byte
    var src byte

    fmt.Printf("Before:\t%v, %v, %v, %v\n", nr, xk, dst, src)

    encryptBlockAsm(nr, &amp;xk, &amp;dst, &amp;src)

    fmt.Printf("After:\t%v, %v, %v, %v\n", nr, xk, dst, src)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Yields:</p>

<pre><code>Before: 0, 0, 0, 0
After:  0, 0, 231, 173
</code></pre>

<p>I have no idea what the inputs should be but at least it demonstrates this does something :)</p>
" OwnerUserId="248922" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T10:47:14.260" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44651266      <row Id="44651266" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44654689" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44651266" CreationDate="2017-06-20T13:38:32.273" Score="1" Body="<p>You can stub functions like <code>time.Now()</code> in your <code>_test.go</code> files, via the <code>init()</code> function, this will give deterministic time values:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "time"
)

var timeNow = time.Now

func main() {
    fmt.Println(timeNow())
}

func init() {
    // Uncomment and add to _test.go init()
    // timeNow = func() time.Time {
    //  t, _ := time.Parse("2006-01-02 15:04:05", "2017-01-20 01:02:03")
    //  return t
    // }
}
</code></pre>

<p>See: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/hI6MrQGyDA" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/hI6MrQGyDA</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="687438" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T13:38:32.273" CommentCount="1" />
