question:
44648735      <row Id="44648735" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44659126" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44648735" CreationDate="2017-06-20T17:04:26.797" Score="3" Body="<p>The new Go 1.8 feature only works if the structures have the same field names and <em>types</em>. Despite the fact that your Test2 and Test4 structures are identical by fields, they are two separate types, and thus the compiler disallows their assignment. One might argue that structures should be deep-compared instead of a simple type comparison, but that's not how it's implemented currently. You have three options: use the same struct type for the struct field in each, use an anonymous struct in each (<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Hw7HANwqbZ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/Hw7HANwqbZ</a>), or make a helper function to convert the two manually.</p>

<p>There's currently a proposal out to allow deeply-equivalent structures to be converted without a field-by-field helper method, but it is currently slated for Go 2.x: <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20621" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20621</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4551301" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T17:04:26.797" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44656095      <row Id="44656095" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44659129" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44656095" CreationDate="2017-06-20T17:04:35.883" Score="2" Body="<p>This is a perfect use case for the <code>MULTI-EXEC</code> functionality:</p>

<pre><code>MULTI
GET key
DELETE key
EXEC
</code></pre>

<p>Or in go:</p>

<pre><code>pipe := client.TxPipeline()

get := pipe.Get("key")
pipe.Del("key")

_, err := pipe.Exec()
fmt.Println(incr.Val(), err)
</code></pre>

<p>This will ensure that both commands execute in a transaction, so the key will either be retrieved and deleted or not retrieved at all.</p>
" OwnerUserId="495504" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T17:04:35.883" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44659210      <row Id="44659210" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44659348" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44659210" CreationDate="2017-06-20T17:18:38.740" Score="2" Body="<p>A semaphore or mutex controls synchronization, not order of operations. The order of concurrent operations, regardless of whether or not they're synchronized, is not controllable or predictable. If you need a controlled order of operations, you should not execute those operations concurrently.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T17:18:38.740" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44659343      <row Id="44659343" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44659426" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44659343" CreationDate="2017-06-20T17:22:52.850" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to "Seed" the random number generator. This is like the code that tells the pseudo random number generator how to generate your numbers. Now, you can't just give this any number, or you are going to generate the same set every time. Often a good practice is to seed with the current time.</p>

<pre><code>package main
import (
    "fmt"
    "math/rand"
    "time"    #ADDED
)

func main() {
    // Seed should be set once, better spot is func init()
    rand.Seed(time.Now().UTC().UnixNano())   #ADDED
    fmt.Println(randInt(1, 1000))
}

func randInt(min int, max int) int {
    return min + rand.Intn(max-min)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now every time you call your <code>randInt()</code> function, it will use the time from when the seed function was called to generate the random number. </p>
" OwnerUserId="8121683" LastEditorUserId="8121683" LastEditDate="2017-06-22T14:16:30.927" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T14:16:30.927" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44659422      <row Id="44659422" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44659479" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44659422" CreationDate="2017-06-20T17:26:15.710" Score="4" Body="<p>Theoretically, <code>struct{}{}</code> should be the most efficient because it requires no memory. In practice, a) results may vary between Go versions, operating systems, and system architectures; and b) I can't think of any case where maximizing the execution-time efficiency of empty values is relevant.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T17:26:15.710" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44641773      <row Id="44641773" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44662067" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44641773" CreationDate="2017-06-20T20:03:37.100" Score="1" Body="<p>I had a look on your <a href="https://github.com/utiq/go-in-5-minutes/commit/268f2d3adc8a90b643ff5dfed34205a92d25e6b4#diff-4c44d7542df3ff4221e5fcf36d8ef0b4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">commit changes</a> of <code>episode4</code>. </p>

<p><strong>My observations as follows:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>You're creating <code>hub</code> instance on every incoming request at <a href="https://github.com/utiq/go-in-5-minutes/blob/master/episode4/connection.go#L52" rel="nofollow noreferrer">stream handler</a>. <code>hub</code> instance used to keeps track connections, etc. so you're losing it on every request.</li>
<li>You have removed index/home handler (may be you wanted to convert to gin handler or something, I don't know).</li>
</ul>

<p>Now, let's bring <code>episode4</code> into action. Please do following changes (as always improve it as you like). I have tested your <code>episode4</code> with below changes, it's working fine.</p>

<p>Make <code>/ws</code> handler work on <code>server.go</code>:</p>

<pre><code>h := newHub()
wsh := wsHandler{h: h}
r.GET("/ws", func(c *gin.Context) {
    wsh.ServeHTTP(c.Writer, c.Request)
})
</code></pre>

<p>Remove the stream handler on <code>connection.go</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func stream(c *gin.Context) {
    h := newHub()
    wsHandler{h: h}.ServeHTTP(c.Writer, c.Request)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Adding index HTML handler on <code>server.go</code>: (added it to test episode4 at my end)</p>

<pre><code>r.SetHTMLTemplate(template.Must(template.ParseFiles("index.html")))
r.GET("/", func(c *gin.Context) {
    c.HTML(200, "index.html", nil)
})
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-20T20:26:41.610" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T20:26:41.610" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44662456      <row Id="44662456" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44662633" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44662456" CreationDate="2017-06-20T20:42:24.527" Score="5" Body="<p>This line: </p>

<pre><code>router.Handle("/files/", http.StripPrefix("/files/", http.FileServer(http.Dir("."))))
</code></pre>

<p>Means that requests coming in for URLs under "/files/" will be served from files on disk in the current directory, with the "/files/" prefix removed.
So if you want a file in the current directory named <code>app2.js</code>, then the URL must be <code>/files/app2.js</code>.</p>

<p><code>router.Handle</code> defines what handler will handle a given path. In this case, that path is <code>/files/</code>. Because of the trailing slash, the same handler will be used for all URLs beginning with <code>/files/</code>.</p>

<p><code>http.StripPrefix</code> is a handler <em>wrapper</em>. It takes the incomming request, strips of the given prefix (in this case, <code>/files/</code>), removes it from the URL path, and then passes the request on to the handler passed to <code>StripPrefix</code>.</p>

<p><code>http.FileServer</code> serves files out of a <code>http.FileSystem</code>, in this case provided by <code>http.Dir</code>. <code>http.Dir</code> exposes the files in a directory, in this case the current working directory (<code>"."</code>).</p>

<p>So, in total: requests beginning with <code>/files/</code>, will have the <code>/files/</code> part removed, then whatever is left, that file path will be looked for in the current working directory, and if it is found, it will be served. So, <code>/files/app2.js</code> will serve <code>./app2.js</code>. Your HTML must reference <code>/files/app2.js</code>, <strong>not</strong> <code>app.js</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-20T20:42:24.527" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44663496      <row Id="44663496" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44663794" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44663496" CreationDate="2017-06-20T22:07:35.253" Score="1" Body="<p><a href="https://github.com/pressly/chi/blob/master/render/render.go#L20" rel="nofollow noreferrer">render.Bind</a>'s purpose is to perform decode and execute <code>Bind(r)</code> to do post decode operations.</p>

<p>For eg.:</p>

<pre><code>type Test struct {
   Name string `json:"name"`
}

func (p *Test) Bind(r *http.Request) error {
   // At this point, Decode is already done by `chi`
   p.Name = p.Name + " after decode"
  return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you have to do only JSON decode no other actions needs to be done after decode with respect to decoded values. Just use:</p>

<pre><code>// Use Directly JSON decoder of std pkg
err := json.NewDecoder(r.Body).Decode(&amp;p)
</code></pre>

<p>OR</p>

<pre><code>// Use wrapper method from chi DecodeJSON
err := render.DecodeJSON(r.Body, &amp;p)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="13860" LastEditDate="2017-06-21T09:16:25.537" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T09:16:25.537" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44665834      <row Id="44665834" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44666860" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44665834" CreationDate="2017-06-21T04:23:40.057" Score="2" Body="<p><em>Access permission</em> is checked when</p>

<ol>
<li>You're creating/declaring a variable. The compiler will check the visibility of <em>the name of the type identifier</em>.</li>
<li>Using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect</code></a> package to modify a variable. </li>
<li>Calling a constant, global variable, or a function. The visibility of constant/variable/function name will be checked.</li>
</ol>

<p>Once the variable is created/defined, and when you pass this variable as a function/method argument, the copy (If it is a value, the value is being copied. If it is a pointer, the address is being copied) will be passed to the function/method, and <strong>always accessible</strong> from the function body through the argument name and type. In <code>encoding/json</code> package, the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Decoder.Decode" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Decoder.Decode</code></a> method is defined as,</p>

<pre><code>func (dec *Decoder) Decode(v interface{}) error
</code></pre>

<p>thus, anything you passed to the <code>Decoder.Decode</code> method, is always accessible from inside the method body through argument <code>v</code>. Note that the type of <code>v</code> is <code>interface{}</code> not <code>_Sample</code> struct. The visibility is checked when you defined the variable as</p>

<pre><code>var sample _Sample
</code></pre>

<p>which was <em>OK</em> since it is done from within the same package. Even an anonymous struct (i.e. no type name identifier is defined for the struct)</p>

<pre><code>aSample := struct {
    first  string // this will not be filled because it starts with lower case letter
    Second string // it is OK.
}{}

//...
err := decoder.Decode(&amp;aSample)
</code></pre>

<p>will works. Next, when the <code>decoder</code> fills the struct (through reflection), the visibility of struct members will be checked, and <code>_Sample.first</code> is not visible from inside the <code>json</code> package. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T04:23:40.057" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44667733      <row Id="44667733" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44668669" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44667733" CreationDate="2017-06-21T06:47:14.417" Score="0" Body="<p>By default, <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>os.File</code></a> will be finalized by the Garbage Collector (GC) when application exit. From <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/runtime/#SetFinalizer" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>SetFinalizer</code></a> documentation</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The finalizer for obj is scheduled to run at some arbitrary time after obj becomes unreachable. There is no guarantee that finalizers will run before a program exits, so typically they are useful only for releasing non-memory resources associated with an object during a long-running program. For example, an os.File object could use a finalizer to close the associated operating system file descriptor when a program discards an os.File without calling Close, but it would be a mistake to depend on a finalizer to flush an in-memory I/O buffer such as a bufio.Writer, because the buffer would not be flushed at program exit.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you don't want to rely on GC, you can close it manually in the <code>main</code> function as follows:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    //Close log writer when exit
    defer func(){
        if file, ok := Logger.Out.(*os.File); ok {
            file.Sync()
            file.Close()
        } else if handler, ok := Logger.Out.(io.Closer); ok {
            handler.Close()
        }
    }()

    //Your original codes
    //...
}
</code></pre>

<p>In the above code, we use <code>defer</code> statement to ensure the <em>handler</em> will be closed when the application exit. Since <code>Logger.Out</code> may be defined as <code>io.Writer</code>, we need to test whether the <code>Logger.Out</code> also implements <code>io.Closer</code>, and if yes, it will be closed. If <code>Logger.Out</code> is an <code>os.File</code>, we also call <code>Sync()</code> to ensure all the content is written to disk.</p>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong><br>
Quote documentation and add <code>file.Sync()</code> to ensure file content is written to disk. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-21T07:01:39.190" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T07:01:39.190" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44669384      <row Id="44669384" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44670306" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44669384" CreationDate="2017-06-21T08:08:34.527" Score="2" Body="<p>Refer to <a href="http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-go/api/service/ses/#example_SES_SendRawEmail_shared00" rel="nofollow noreferrer">AWS example</a> for Sending RAW email with attachment.</p>

<p>Implementation Suggestion: for an easy to compose email and get email as bytes and send it to SES as mentioned in the above reference example.</p>

<p>Use library <code>gopkg.in/gomail.v2</code> to compose your email message with attachment and then call <a href="https://godoc.org/gopkg.in/gomail.v2#Message.WriteTo" rel="nofollow noreferrer">WriteTo</a> method.</p>

<pre><code>var emailRaw bytes.Buffer
emailMessage.WriteTo(emailRaw)

// while create instance of RawMessage
RawMessage: &amp;ses.RawMessage{
    Data: emailRaw.Bytes(),
}
</code></pre>

<p>Good luck!</p>

<hr>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong> For the comment.</p>

<p>Compose the email-</p>

<pre><code>msg := gomail.NewMessage()
msg.SetHeader("From", "alex@example.com")
msg.SetHeader("To", "bob@example.com", "cora@example.com")
msg.SetHeader("Subject", "Hello!")
msg.SetBody("text/html", "Hello &lt;b&gt;Bob&lt;/b&gt; and &lt;i&gt;Cora&lt;/i&gt;!")
msg.Attach("/home/Alex/lolcat.jpg")

var emailRaw bytes.Buffer
msg.WriteTo(emailRaw)

message := ses.RawMessage{ Data: emailRaw.Bytes() }

// Remaining is same as what you mentioned the question.
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T06:07:32.620" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T06:07:32.620" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44669550      <row Id="44669550" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44671550" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44669550" CreationDate="2017-06-21T09:05:14.560" Score="1" Body="<p>Channels are just variables in Go, like <code>int</code>, <code>[]byte</code> or <code>bool</code>.  If you can pass any variables between packages, you can obviously then pass channels between packages as well.  And once you've passed a channel from one package to another, you are of course free to use it there, just as you would any other variable.  That means you can send data in one package, and receive it in another.</p>

<p>Ultimately channels wouldn't be very useful if they couldn't be shared between packages.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T09:05:14.560" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44675087      <row Id="44675087" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44676179" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44675087" CreationDate="2017-06-21T12:29:47.933" Score="2" Body="<h2>The recommended way</h2>

<p>First, the recommended way is <strong>not to rely on whether a struct field exists</strong>. Of course there might be optional parts of the template, but the condition to decide whether to render a part should rely on fields that exist in all cases.</p>

<h2>The issue, and avoiding it using a map</h2>

<p>If the type of the template data is a <code>struct</code> (or a pointer to a struct) and there is no field or method with the given name, the template engine returns an error for that.</p>

<p>You could easily get rid of this error if you were to use a map, as maps can be indexed with keys they don't contain, and the result of that <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Index_expressions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">index expression</a> is the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#The_zero_value" rel="nofollow noreferrer">zero value</a> of the value type (and not an error).</p>

<p>To demonstrate, see this example:</p>

<pre><code>s := `{{if .Email}}Email is: {{.Email}}{{else}}Email is NOT set.{{end}}`

t := template.Must(template.New("").Parse(s))
exec := func(name string, param interface{}) {
    fmt.Printf("
%s:
  ", name)
    if err := t.Execute(os.Stdout, param); err != nil {
        fmt.Println("Error:", err)
    }
}

exec("Filled map", map[string]interface{}{"Email": "as@as"})
exec("Empty map", map[string]interface{}{})

exec("Filled struct", struct {
    Email string
}{Email: "as@as.com"})
exec("Empty struct", struct{}{})
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/_nT3IvT5GW" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Filled map:
  Email is: as@as
Empty map:
  Email is NOT set.
Filled struct:
  Email is: as@as.com
Empty struct:
  Error: template: :1:5: executing "" at &lt;.Email&gt;: can't evaluate field Email in type struct {}
</code></pre>

<h2>Sticking to <code>struct</code> and providing "isset"</h2>

<p>If you must or want to stick to a <code>struct</code>, this "isset" can be implemented and provided, I'll call it <code>avail()</code>.</p>

<p>This implementation uses reflection, and in order to check if the field given by its name exists (is available), the (wrapper) data must also be passed to it:</p>

<pre><code>func avail(name string, data interface{}) bool {
    v := reflect.ValueOf(data)
    if v.Kind() == reflect.Ptr {
        v = v.Elem()
    }
    if v.Kind() != reflect.Struct {
        return false
    }
    return v.FieldByName(name).IsValid()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Example using it:</p>

<pre><code>s := `{{if (avail "Email" .)}}Email is: {{.Email}}{{else}}Email is unavailable.{{end}}`

t := template.Must(template.New("").Funcs(template.FuncMap{
    "avail": avail,
}).Parse(s))
exec := func(name string, param interface{}) {
    fmt.Printf("
%s:
  ", name)
    if err := t.Execute(os.Stdout, param); err != nil {
        fmt.Println("Error:", err)
    }
}

exec("Filled struct", struct {
    Email string
}{Email: "as@as.com"})
exec("Empty struct", struct{}{})
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/43hIY_Vfzf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Filled struct:
  Email is: as@as.com
Empty struct:
  Email is unavailable.
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-21T17:25:35.080" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T17:25:35.080" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44678216      <row Id="44678216" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44678217" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44678216" CreationDate="2017-06-21T13:57:27.583" Score="0" Body="<p>Thanks to @JimB, I understand the nature of the problem better. Here's what he said:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The actual error is because you're calling Read from an unbounded number of goroutines. The net package assumes there's no reason to ever have more than 1&lt;&lt;20 concurrent operations on a net.Conn.  JimB</p>
</blockquote>

<hr>

<p>Some bad code was here, which wasn't quite a fix for the problem at hand. I removed it so it won't mislead anyone, as advised by JimB. </p>

<p>What I learned from JimB:</p>

<ol>
<li>You shouldn't use goroutines unless it is necessary (<code>echo</code> function shouldn't be a goroutine, as reading is a blocking operation, and we can't really do anything with the connection until we understand what the client is sending to us, so no concurrency is needed; <code>handleConnection</code>, on the other hand, is run inside a goroutine because it's supposed to handle multiple connections simultaneously).</li>
<li>Errors are precious things, handle them gracefully, do not ignore them.</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="7459528" LastEditorUserId="7459528" LastEditDate="2017-06-22T13:45:56.207" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T13:45:56.207" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44676895      <row Id="44676895" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44683482" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44676895" CreationDate="2017-06-21T18:20:29.530" Score="2" Body="<p>When you want to send HTTP response to client not immediately but after some event, it's called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Push_technology#Long_polling" rel="nofollow noreferrer">long polling</a>.</p>

<p>Here's simple example of long polling with request cancellation on client disconnect:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "context"
    "fmt"
    "net/http"
    "time"
)

func doLongOperation(w http.ResponseWriter, ctx context.Context, done chan&lt;- bool) {
    flusher, ok := w.(http.Flusher)
    if !ok {
        panic("Expected http.ResponseWriter to be an http.Flusher")
    }

    select {
    case &lt;-time.After(time.Second * 3):
    case &lt;-ctx.Done():
        done &lt;- false // Cancel job.
        return
    }

    fmt.Fprint(w, "Sup dude?") // Write chunk.
    flusher.Flush()            // Send it to client.
    done &lt;- true               // Finish job.
}

func handler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    done := make(chan bool)
    closeNotifier, ok := w.(http.CloseNotifier)
    if !ok {
        panic("Expected http.ResponseWriter to be an http.CloseNotifier")
    }

    ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
    defer cancel()

    go doLongOperation(w, ctx, done)
    select {
    case &lt;-done:
    case &lt;-time.After(time.Second * 10):
        cancel()
        if !&lt;-done {
            fmt.Fprint(w, "Server is busy.")
        }
    case &lt;-closeNotifier.CloseNotify():
        cancel()
        fmt.Println("Client has disconnected.")
        &lt;-done
    }
}

func main() {
    http.HandleFunc("/", handler)
    http.ListenAndServe("localhost:8080", nil)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Additional links:</p>

<ol>
<li><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20793568/golang-anonymous-struct-and-empty-struct">Golang : anonymous struct and empty struct</a>.</li>
<li><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26769626/send-a-chunked-http-response-from-a-go-server">Send a chunked HTTP response from a Go server</a>.</li>
<li><a href="https://blog.golang.org/context" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Concurrency Patterns: Context</a>.</li>
</ol>

<p>Gists:</p>

<ol>
<li><a href="https://gist.github.com/berserkk/5bd1bd8fd8e78bb8b8dd536de0a9a3ff" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Simple example of long polling in Go</a>.</li>
<li><a href="https://gist.github.com/berserkk/9f8b32413c24c620271004fed264a12f" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Simple example of long polling in Go with request cancellation</a>.</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="8099995" LastEditorUserId="8099995" LastEditDate="2017-06-21T21:19:32.853" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T21:19:32.853" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44654020      <row Id="44654020" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44684143" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44654020" CreationDate="2017-06-21T18:56:10.143" Score="0" Body="<p>To get the database object (db) from the gin context (c) <code>c.MustGet("db").(*mgo.Database)</code> you have to first set it using a gin middleware function</p>

<pre><code>func ConnectMiddleware(c *gin.Context) {
    c.Set("db", Session.DB(Mongo.Database))
    c.Next()
}
</code></pre>

<p>and then use this middleware through the following code</p>

<pre><code>router := gin.Default()
router.Use(ConnectMiddleware)
router.GET("/", func(c *gin.Context) {
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, gin.H{"message": "OK"})

})
router.GET("/polls", allPolls)
</code></pre>

<p>You are using a outdated version of gin library other things are fine in your code</p>

<p>import the latest package form <code>github.com/gin-gonic/gin</code> </p>

<p>Use this to get the data from the database</p>

<pre><code>func allPolls(c *gin.Context) {
    db := c.MustGet("db").(*mgo.Database)
    polls := []Poll{}
    err := db.C(CollectionPoll).Find(nil).All(&amp;polls)
    if err != nil {
        c.Error(err)
    }
    result := gin.H{"payload": polls}
    c.Writer.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
    c.JSON(200, result)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7190910" LastEditorUserId="7190910" LastEditDate="2017-06-22T20:33:52.157" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T20:33:52.157" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44685206      <row Id="44685206" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44685274" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44685206" CreationDate="2017-06-21T20:00:23.793" Score="4" Body="<p>A go binary only includes code reachable from its <code>main()</code> entry point. For test binaries <code>main()</code> is the test runner.</p>

<p>As to "how much of a problem" it is if it were included... none. It would increase the binary size and compilation time somewhat but otherwise have no impact - code that isn't executed, by definition, does nothing.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T20:00:23.793" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44684788      <row Id="44684788" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44685647" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44684788" CreationDate="2017-06-21T20:24:33.440" Score="1" Body="<p>Issue is the way you create an sub routes <code>/admin</code>. Complete reference code is here <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/zb_79oHJed" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/zb_79oHJed</a></p>

<pre><code>// Admin
adminBase := mux.NewRouter()
router.PathPrefix("/admin").Handler(negroni.New(
    // This logger only applicable to /admin routes
    negroni.HandlerFunc(justTestLogger),
    // add your handlers here which is only appilcable to `/admin` routes
    negroni.Wrap(adminBase),
))

adminRoutes := adminBase.PathPrefix("/admin").Subrouter()
adminRoutes.HandleFunc("/articles/new", articleNewHandler).Methods("GET")
</code></pre>

<p>Now, access these URLs. You will see logs only for <code>/admin</code> sub routes.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-06-21T20:24:33.440" CommentCount="3" />

<row Id="44686822" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44667906" CreationDate="2017-06-21T21:49:17.040" Score="0" Body="<p>Your code looks ok, but check, how you receive and store files. If you store them in memory, then you shouldn't call <code>Seek</code> method.</p>

<p>If you want to calculate hash of uploaded file and in the same time save it locally or upload to the cloud, then you can use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#MultiWriter" rel="nofollow noreferrer">MultiWriter</a>.</p>

question:
44690196      <row Id="44690196" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44690327" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44690196" CreationDate="2017-06-22T04:44:20.987" Score="4" Body="<p>You can do this:</p>

<pre><code>type Car interface { IAmACar() }

type MyCarA struct {
  specificToA int
}
func (MyCarA) IAmACar() {}

type MyCarB struct {
  specificToB int
}
func (MyCarB) IAmACar() {}
</code></pre>

<p>You test for the marker using a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_assertions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">type assertion</a>:</p>

<pre><code>_, itIsACar := v.(Car)
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/J0rfOjztAV" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground example</a></p>

<p>The Car interface can also be used to detect errors statically:</p>

<pre><code>var c Car
c = MyCarA{0} // ok
c = 0 // error, int is not a car
</code></pre>

<p>The <a href="http://godoc.org/go/ast" rel="nofollow noreferrer">go/ast</a> package does something similar. See uses of the function <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/b3301865a025fda72b8d327fad4461bb7bf68600/src/go/ast/ast.go#L488-L489" rel="nofollow noreferrer">exprNode</a> in the file <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/go/ast/ast.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ast.go</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-06-22T14:03:57.930" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T14:03:57.930" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44696881      <row Id="44696881" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44697073" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44696881" CreationDate="2017-06-22T10:41:07.320" Score="2" Body="<p>You are comparing the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Pointer_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">pointers</a> to the <code>big.Int</code> values, and not the internal <code>big.Int</code> values. Comparing <code>big.Int</code> values must be done using the <a href="https://godoc.org/math/big#Int.Cmp" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Int.Cmp</code> method</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
<pre><code>func (x *Int) Cmp(y *Int) (r int)
</code></pre>
  
  <p>Cmp compares x and y and returns:</p>

<pre><code>-1 if x &lt;  y
0 if x == y
+1 if x &gt;  y
</code></pre>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>if a.Cmp(b) != 0 {
    fmt.Println("foo")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T10:41:07.320" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44697906      <row Id="44697906" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44699604" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44697906" CreationDate="2017-06-22T12:36:16.430" Score="8" Body="<p>The signature of <code>Do</code> is:</p>

<p><code>Do(commandName string, args ...interface{}) (reply interface{}, err error)</code></p>

<p>Because <code>args</code> is a variadic (slice of) <code>interface{}</code> it's heap allocated.</p>

<p>I believe there could be some optimisations in the pipeline for simple cases like this in future versions of Go: <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/15528" rel="noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/issues/15528</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="687438" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T12:36:16.430" CommentCount="0" />

question:
39518237      <row Id="39518237" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44700761" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="39518237" CreationDate="2017-06-22T13:26:27.593" Score="0" Body="<p>The server requires a token string without added strings in my case I have added Bearer string to the token string in the header when sending request to the web server i.e. </p>

<pre><code>'Authorization':'Bearer' + localStorage.getItem('id_token')
</code></pre>

<p>At the web server we need to split only the valid token without the Bearer string</p>

<pre><code>reqToken := r.Header.Get("Authorization")
splitToken := strings.Split(reqToken, "Bearer")
reqToken = splitToken[1]
</code></pre>

<p>As a result it becomes valid token without nil. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6814094" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T13:26:27.593" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44695539      <row Id="44695539" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44700821" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44695539" CreationDate="2017-06-22T13:28:59.087" Score="1" Body="<p>Per <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/cmd/go/#hdr-Generate_Go_files_by_processing_source" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the documentation</a>: </p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The generator is run in the package's source directory.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So, whatever command is run with generate will be run in the same directory as the file containing the generate directive.</p>

<p>Multiple generate directives in one file are executed one at a time in source code order.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T13:28:59.087" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44705094      <row Id="44705094" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44705529" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44705094" CreationDate="2017-06-22T17:08:01.053" Score="1" Body="<p>The problem is that the decoder can buffer data from the next message. When this happens, the next new decoder starts in the middle of a message.  The fix is to use a single encoder and decoder.</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    ...
    dec := gob.NewDecoder(conn) // Will read from network.
    enc := gob.NewEncoder(serverConn)
    go func() {
        for !done {
            recieveMessage(dec)
        }
    }()

    for i := 1; i &lt; 1000; i++ {
        sent := Message{strconv.Itoa(i)}
        sendMessage(sent, enc)
    }
    ...
}

func sendMessage(msg Message, enc *gob.Encoder) {
    err := enc.Encode(msg)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
    }
}

func recieveMessage(dec *gob.Decoder) {
    msg := new(Message)
    err := dec.Decode(msg)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
    }
    fmt.Println("Client recieved:", msg.Msg)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/nKuMozXYd6" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Run it in the playground</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-06-22T17:15:14.017" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T17:15:14.017" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44705817      <row Id="44705817" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44707002" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44705817" CreationDate="2017-06-22T18:33:59.423" Score="1" Body="<p>I had the same problem and ended up creating a custom type for <code>time.Time</code></p>

<pre><code>package genericfields

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "time"
    "strings"

    "gopkg.in/mgo.v2/bson"
)

// ANYTIME //

// AnyTime accepts any time format for its unmarshaling //
type AnyTime struct{ time.Time }

func (t AnyTime) MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) {
    return json.Marshal(t.Time)
}

func (t *AnyTime) UnmarshalJSON(b []byte) error {
    err := json.Unmarshal(b, &amp;t.Time)
    if err != nil { //assume non tz time input
        bstr := strings.Trim(string(b), `"`)
        t.Time, err = time.Parse("2006-01-02T15:04:05", bstr)
        if err != nil {
            return err //TODO add more formats to try
        }
    }
    return nil
}

func (t AnyTime) GetBSON() (interface{}, error) {
    return t.Time, nil
}

func (t *AnyTime) SetBSON(raw bson.Raw) error {
    var tm time.Time
    err := raw.Unmarshal(&amp;tm)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    t.Time = tm.UTC()
    return nil
}

func (t AnyTime) ToTime() time.Time {
    return t.Time
}
</code></pre>

<p>Usage:</p>

<pre><code>type MyStruct struct {
  StartedAt genericfields.AnyTime `json:"startedAt" bson:"startedAt"`
  ...
}
</code></pre>

<p>You might need to tweak the input for <code>time.Parse</code> somewhat.</p>
" OwnerUserId="248922" LastEditorUserId="248922" LastEditDate="2017-06-22T19:35:24.903" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T19:35:24.903" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44699307      <row Id="44699307" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44709520" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44699307" CreationDate="2017-06-22T21:15:41.053" Score="0" Body="<p>You need to do <code>f.Seek</code> to jump over first bytes and than do regular reading, see example:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "io"
    "io/ioutil"
    "os"
)

func main() {
    f, err := os.Open(os.Args[1])            // open file from argument
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }

    var skipBytes int64 = 5                  // how many bytes to skip

    _, err = f.Seek(skipBytes, io.SeekStart) // skipping first bytes
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }

    buffer := make([]byte, 1024)               // allocating buffer to read
    for {
        n, err := f.Read(buffer)               // reading
        fmt.Print(string(buffer[:n]))          // writing to console
        if err != nil {
            fmt.Printf("Err: %v\n", err)
            return
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="433041" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T21:15:41.053" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44709489      <row Id="44709489" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44709534" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44709489" CreationDate="2017-06-22T21:16:48.090" Score="2" Body="<p>The golang <code>ecdsa.Sign</code> and <code>ecdsa.Verify</code> functions are expected to take the output of a cryptographic hash function, rather than the message itself. So you are correct that only the first 32 bytes are being examined, in this case.</p>

<p>To resolve the problem first hash the messages using a cryptographic hash function such as SHA-2</p>
" OwnerUserId="152148" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T21:16:48.090" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44709945      <row Id="44709945" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44710073" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44709945" CreationDate="2017-06-22T22:07:54.223" Score="1" Body="<p><code>syslog</code> is a platform-specific service, so <a href="https://github.com/sirupsen/logrus/blob/master/hooks/syslog/syslog.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the Logrus syslog hook code</a> has a special comment, called a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/go/build/#hdr-Build_Constraints" rel="nofollow noreferrer">build tag</a>, to 
tell the Go tools not to build it on Windows (or Native Client or <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_9_from_Bell_Labs" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Plan9</a>):</p>

<pre><code>// +build !windows,!nacl,!plan9
</code></pre>

<p>Unless you don't want syslog integration even on Linux, you probably want to fork the application code that currently always imports <code>hooks/syslog</code> into two versions, one for platforms with syslog, one for those without. If the file importing <code>hooks/syslog</code> is currently, say, <code>logconfig.go</code>, you could create two files <code>logconfig_syslog.go</code> and <code>logconfig_nosyslog.go</code>, the <code>syslog</code> version with a constraint like the one above, and the <code>nosyslog</code> version with the opposite (<code>// +build windows,nacl,plan9</code>).</p>

<p><a href="https://dave.cheney.net/2013/10/12/how-to-use-conditional-compilation-with-the-go-build-tool" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Dave Cheney wrote a bit more about build tags and the various flavors of Go conditional compilation.</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="2714852" LastEditorUserId="2714852" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T19:01:29.593" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T19:01:29.593" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44709898      <row Id="44709898" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44710371" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44709898" CreationDate="2017-06-22T22:36:33.073" Score="3" Body="<p>When you do this:</p>

<pre><code> http.FileServer(http.Dir("."))
</code></pre>

<p>You are telling it to serve files from the current directory (where all your source code lives).</p>

<p>What I typically do is have a folder <code>/public</code>, where any static, web accessible files will live.  Then you can do:</p>

<pre><code>router.PathPrefix("/tmpfiles/").Handler(
    http.StripPrefix("/tmpfiles/", http.FileServer(http.Dir("./public"))))
</code></pre>

<p>Which will remove the <code>/tmpfiles/</code> from the url, and then serve that file from the <code>public</code> directory.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2082673" LastActivityDate="2017-06-22T22:36:33.073" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44699710      <row Id="44699710" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44711760" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44699710" CreationDate="2017-06-23T01:37:30.713" Score="1" Body="<p>According to documentation, the latest parameter of <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa814450(v=vs.85).aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">NotifyIpInterfaceChange</a> is both <code>in/out</code> and need to be <strong>a pointer</strong> to <code>HANDLE</code>. Change the system call to:</p>

<pre><code>ret, _, errNum := procNotifyIpInterfaceChange.Call(syscall.AF_UNSPEC,
    syscall.NewCallback(callback),
    uintptr(unsafe.Pointer(context)), 
    0, 
    uintptr(unsafe.Pointer(&amp;interfaceChange)))   //this must be pointer
</code></pre>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong><br>
As mentioned in the comment and <a href="https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/golang-nuts/h91eDx27vrQ/PJ0rveQ9vRYJ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this go-nuts discussion</a>, for multi-threaded callback, <code>import "C"</code> need to be added, even if we don't use <code>cgo</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T03:15:23.190" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T03:15:23.190" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44706042      <row Id="44706042" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44711856" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44706042" CreationDate="2017-06-23T01:52:28.630" Score="1" Body="<p>Create type alias to the struct with <code>typedef</code> as follows:</p>

<pre><code>/*

typedef const struct libvlc_event_t clibvlc_event_t;
extern void goCallback(clibvlc_event_t*, void*);
*/
import "C"

//export goCallback
func goCallback(event *C.clibvlc_event_t, userData unsafe.Pointer) {
    log.Fatal("TODO goCallback")
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you want to know <code>go</code> type definition which is compatible to <code>C.clibvlc_event_t</code>, run <code>cgo</code> with <code>-godefs</code> options, i.e.</p>

<pre><code>go tool cgo -godefs &lt;YOUR-GO-FILE&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>For example, if the struct is defined as in <a href="https://docs.libreoffice.org/avmedia/html/Types_8hxx_source.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://docs.libreoffice.org/avmedia/html/Types_8hxx_source.html</a></p>

<pre><code>struct libvlc_event_t
{
    int   type;  // event type
    void *p_obj; // object emitting that event

    union // so far we don't need this.
    {
     struct {
        const char *dummy1;
        const char *dummy2;
      } padding;
    } u;
};
</code></pre>

<p>then, the compatible struct in <code>go</code> will be:</p>

<pre><code>type VLCEvent struct {
    Type      int32
    Pad_cgo_0 [4]byte
    Obj       *byte
    U         [16]byte
}

//Cast C struct to Go struct
ev := (*VLCEvent)(unsafe.Pointer(event))

//Cast Go struct to C struct
p := (*C.clibvlc_event_t)(unsafe.Pointer(&amp;VLCEvent{}))
</code></pre>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong><br>
Add example struct.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T02:39:16.963" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T02:39:16.963" CommentCount="3" />

<row Id="44712720" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44712481" CreationDate="2017-06-23T03:42:34.583" Score="0" Body="<p>Yes you can, define the out parameter as pointer <code>*VoucherUsageEvent</code>.</p>

</code></pre>

</code></pre>

</code></pre>

<pre><code>return nil, err
</code></pre>

question:
44715882      <row Id="44715882" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44716068" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44715882" CreationDate="2017-06-23T07:57:45.033" Score="3" Body="<p>The problem with <code>loop1()</code> is that you store a function literal in the <code>actions</code> map that references the <strong>loop variable</strong> <code>cmd</code>. There is only one instance of this loop variable, so when after the loop you call the functions stored in the <code>actions</code> map, all will refer to this single loop variable (which is kept because the functions / closures still have a reference to it), but its value <em>at the time of execution</em> will be the last value set by the <code>for</code> loop, which is the last value in the <code>cmds</code> slice (that is, <code>"update"</code>, so you'll see <code>"update"</code> printed 3 times).</p>

<p>An easy workaround is to make a copy of this loop variable, so each iteration, each function literal will have its own copy, which is "detached" from the loop variable:</p>

<pre><code>func loop1() {
    actions := make(map[string]func())

    for _, cmd := range cmds {
        cmd2 := cmd
        actions[cmd] = func() {
            fmt.Println(cmd2) // Refer to the detached, copy variable!
        }
    }
    for _, action := range actions {
        action()
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>With this, output of <code>loop1()</code> (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/TZEsDyFMfz" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>update
create
delete
</code></pre>

<p>This it's not an issue of the <code>for ... range</code>, it's because the closures refer to the same variable, and you don't use the value of the variable right away, only after the loop. And when you print the value of this variable, all print the same, last value of it.</p>

<p>Also see this possible duplicate: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44044245/golang-register-multiple-routes-using-range-for-loop-slices-map/44045012#44045012">Golang: Register multiple routes using range for loop slices/map</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T08:04:16.963" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T08:04:16.963" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44716125      <row Id="44716125" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44716350" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44716125" CreationDate="2017-06-23T08:13:43.383" Score="5" Body="<p><code>[2]int</code> is an <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Array_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">array</a>, <code>[]int</code> is a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">slice</a>.</p>

<p>Arrays and slices are completely different types: you can't pass an array where a slice is required, and you can't pass a slice where an array is expected. Since the length is part of the array type, you can't even use array values where the length differs, e.g. you can't use an array value of type <code>[3]int</code> for something that expects <code>[2]int</code>.</p>

<p>Everything in Go is passed by value. Slices too. But a slice value is a <em>header</em>, describing a contiguous section of a backing array, and a slice value only contains a pointer to the array where the elements are actually stored. The slice value does not include its elements (unlike arrays). When you pass a slice, only the slice header is copied (pointing to the same backing array), and so modifying its elements modifies elements in the same backing array, so the caller will observe the changes. Read more about this here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39993688/are-golang-slices-pass-by-value/39993797#39993797">Are golang slices pass by value?</a> To see what's in a slice header: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#SliceHeader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect.SliceHeader</code></a>.</p>

<p>Unlike slices, arrays are not headers. An array value means all its elements, so when you pass an array value, all its elements are copied, and inside the function it is passed to you can only modify this copy array; the caller won't observe the changes made to the array (e.g. changing its elements).</p>

<p>Note that however it is very easy to obtain a slice value from an array, you may simply use <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">slicing</a>:</p>

<pre><code>var a [2]int = [2]int{1, 2}
var s []int = a[:]
fmt.Println(s) // Prints [1 2]
</code></pre>

<p>Recommended blog post: <a href="https://blog.golang.org/go-slices-usage-and-internals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Slices: usage and internals</a></p>

<p>More insight into arrays vs slices: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38645175/why-have-arrays-in-go/38645895#38645895">Why have arrays in Go?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T12:17:21.263" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T12:17:21.263" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44719156      <row Id="44719156" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44719269" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44719156" CreationDate="2017-06-23T10:32:49.237" Score="7" Body="<p>You need some kind of random information, and based on its value, you can return <code>true</code> in half of its possible cases, and <code>false</code> in the other half of the cases.</p>

<p>A very simple example using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#Float32" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.Float32()</code></a> of the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>math/rand</code></a> package:</p>

<pre><code>func rand1() bool {
    return rand.Float32() &lt; 0.5
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Don't forget to properly seed the <code>math/rand</code> package for it to be different on each app run using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#Seed" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.Seed()</code></a>:</strong></p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
    fmt.Println(rand1())
}
</code></pre>

<p>This is mentioned in the package doc of <code>math/rand</code>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Use the Seed function to initialize the default Source if different behavior is required for each run.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you don't seed, the same pseudo-random information is returned on each application run.</p>

<p>Some variations:</p>

<pre><code>func rand2() bool {
    return rand.Int31()&amp;0x01 == 0
}

func rand3() bool {
    return rand.Intn(2) == 0
}
</code></pre>

<p>And an interesting solution without using the <code>math/rand</code> package. It uses  the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Select_statements" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>select</code></a> statement:</p>

<pre><code>func rand9() bool {
    c := make(chan struct{})
    close(c)
    select {
    case &lt;-c:
        return true
    case &lt;-c:
        return false
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Explanation:</strong></p>

<p>The <code>select</code> statement chooses one <em>random</em> case from the ones that can proceed without blocking. Since <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Receive_operator" rel="nofollow noreferrer">receiving</a> from a closed channel can proceed immediately, one of the 2 cases will be chosen randomly, returning either <code>true</code> or <code>false</code>. Note that however this is far from being perfectly random, as that is not a requirement of the <code>select</code> statement.</p>

<p>The channel can also be moved to a global variable, so no need to create one and close one in each call:</p>

<pre><code>var c = make(chan struct{})

func init() {
    close(c)
}

func rand9() bool {
    select {
    case &lt;-c:
        return true
    case &lt;-c:
        return false
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T11:01:42.500" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T11:01:42.500" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44719451      <row Id="44719451" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44719794" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44719451" CreationDate="2017-06-23T11:00:13.613" Score="1" Body="<p>There is no specific guideline for this and even stdlib packages does not follow the same way. But as a rule of thumb you should:</p>

<ul>
<li>Put exported, global constants and variables (like errors) near the top.</li>
<li>Keep structs together with their methods rather than grouping structs together and then their methods separately.</li>
<li>Group logical parts together (whenever structs, their methods, package functions (exported or not)). It will make easier splitting your package into multiple files later on. It makes reading easier as well as you don't have to jump all over the file.</li>
<li>Last, but not least: if you generate documentation from your package with <code>godoc</code> and can read it from top to bottom with understanding, then your order is probably correct :)</li>
</ul>

<p>When in doubt, check some popular stdlib packages, like <a href="https://golang.org/src/net/http/server.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/src/net/http/server.go</a>.</p>

<p>Other useful code style guidelines can be found here:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://blog.golang.org/organizing-go-code" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/organizing-go-code</a></li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/CodeReviewComments" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/CodeReviewComments</a></li>
<li><a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="3201908" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T11:00:13.613" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44723188      <row Id="44723188" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44723209" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44723188" CreationDate="2017-06-23T13:56:18.270" Score="4" Body="<p>You must first initialize your map:</p>

<pre><code>keyval := make(map[string]int)
</code></pre>

<p>According to <a href="https://blog.golang.org/go-maps-in-action" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this</a> blog post:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Map types are reference types, like pointers or slices, and so the
  value of m above is nil; it doesn't point to an initialized map.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>GoPlay here:<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/2JuPS1J7KK" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/2JuPS1J7KK</a></p>

<p>Edit to answer OP's followup. If you're looking to use the strings from your slice as the key to the map, you need to make an additional change:</p>

<pre><code>keyval[x[i]] = 0
</code></pre>

<p>GoPlay here:<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/feMSwvbEGS" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/feMSwvbEGS</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4746361" LastEditorUserId="4746361" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T14:12:24.800" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T14:12:24.800" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44722580      <row Id="44722580" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44723383" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44722580" CreationDate="2017-06-23T14:04:30.933" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to add the xml tags to your <code>interface{}</code>, ie.</p>

<pre><code>Content interface{} `xml:"http://e-conomic.com Debtor_GetNameResponse"`
</code></pre>

<p><code>Address interface{}</code> in your other example works because its name is the same of the xml tag <code>&lt;Address&gt;&lt;/Address&gt;</code> and <code>Unmarshal</code> lookups by it.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3658660" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T14:04:30.933" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44727616      <row Id="44727616" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44728209" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44727616" CreationDate="2017-06-23T18:53:25.780" Score="2" Body="<p>You need to install the dependencies using the "go get" command.  </p>

<p>You don't have the dependencies installed, as stated in the error message.
Look a little closer at the error messages, you are getting three different errors.  One for each package that is not part of the go standard libary.</p>

<p>When you try to import a package that is not part of the go standard library, the go compiler looks under the $GOROOT path and the $GOPATH path to try to find a package matching the name that you tried to import.  If it is not found the compiler throws the error that you were seeing above.  As @Adrian said, you can run:</p>

<p><code>go get ./...</code><br></p>

<p>to automatically download all of your dependencies.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8157369" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T18:53:25.780" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44728201      <row Id="44728201" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44728247" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44728201" CreationDate="2017-06-23T18:55:37.250" Score="3" Body="<p>Run your tests with the <a href="https://golang.org/doc/articles/race_detector.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Race detector</a>.  In short, run:</p>

<pre><code>go test -race
</code></pre>

<p>Or to build a normal binary, such as to run on a staging server, use:</p>

<pre><code>go build -race
</code></pre>

<p>But there are many more options, so best to read up on it :)</p>

<p>If your goal is to test under realistic load, your best option is to compile your code with <code>go build -race</code>, then run it under realistic load. This probably means on a staging server.  But don't confuse this with unit testing!</p>

<p>Unit testing is for testing units--small parts of code, usually individual functions. Load/race testing is a different beast, and requires different tools and an entirely different approach.</p>

<p>The fact that Go will easily run unit tests with the race detector is nice, and often catches races. But it will not, nor should not be expected to, catch <em>all</em> races, since the nature of unit test execution is entirely different from that of production execution.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastEditorUserId="13860" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T19:07:48.247" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T19:07:48.247" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44729587      <row Id="44729587" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44730447" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44729587" CreationDate="2017-06-23T21:55:19.590" Score="3" Body="<p>I appreciate @KelvinS' approach, there already exists a <code>math.Pow</code> (though it deals in float64s.  Never-the-less, his approach breaks down what you are really after, which is raising each successive number (from the right) by an order of magnitude and summing the numbers.  As such, the most straight forward approach I can think of is</p>

<pre><code>func sliceToInt(s []int) int {
    res := 0
    op := 1
    for i := len(s) - 1; i &gt;= 0; i-- {
        res += s[i] * op
        op *= 10
    }
    return res
}

func main() {
    nums := []int{1, 2, 3}
    fmt.Println(sliceToInt(nums))
}
</code></pre>

<p><code>sliceToInt</code> is poorly named, but you should get the idea.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/JS96Nq_so-" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/JS96Nq_so-</a></p>

<p>It may be a micro optimization to try to get this as fast as possible, but if it happens to be in a hot path it might be worth it</p>

<pre><code>BenchmarkPow-8              100000000           13.5 ns/op         0 B/op          0 allocs/op
BenchmarkJoin-8              5000000           272 ns/op           8 B/op          5 allocs/op
BenchmarkBuffer-8            2000000           782 ns/op         160 B/op          8 allocs/op
BenchmarkSliceToInt-8       200000000            8.65 ns/op        0 B/op          0 allocs/op
PASS
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="141555" LastEditorUserId="141555" LastEditDate="2017-06-23T22:09:46.663" LastActivityDate="2017-06-23T22:09:46.663" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44732508      <row Id="44732508" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44732655" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44732508" CreationDate="2017-06-24T04:09:53.223" Score="4" Body="<p>If you have read <code>resp.Body</code> before the JSON <code>Decode</code> then it has no input to decode.</p>

<p>Try only -</p>

<pre><code>response := &amp;Response{}
json.NewDecoder(resp.Body).Decode(response)
fmt.Println("response struct:", response)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-06-24T04:09:53.223" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44734529      <row Id="44734529" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44734585" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44734529" CreationDate="2017-06-24T08:43:42.107" Score="3" Body="<p>The problem is that the <code>{{range}}</code> action changes (sets) the dot (<code>.</code>) even if you use loop variables (<code>$key</code> and <code>$value</code>) in your case. Inside a <code>{{range}}</code> the dot is set to the current element.</p>

<p>And inside <code>{{range}}</code> you write:</p>

<pre><code>{{ if eq $key .Res.Type }}
</code></pre>

<p>Since values in your loop are <code>string</code> values, <code>.Res.Type</code> is an error, because there is no <code>Res</code> field or method of a <code>string</code> value (the current element denoted by the dot <code>.</code>).</p>

<p>Use the <code>$</code> sign to not refer to the loop value, but to the param passed to the template execution:</p>

<pre><code>{{ if eq $key $.Res.Type }}
</code></pre>

<p>This will work, but won't give you the desired output, as you have a typo:</p>

<pre><code>res := &amp;Result{Type: "findAllString"}
</code></pre>

<p>Use capital letter in <code>Result</code> as your <code>types</code> map also contains values with capital letter:</p>

<pre><code>res := &amp;Result{Type: "FindAllString"}
</code></pre>

<p>With this you get the desired output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ZtZAoeOtF3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>2009/11/10 23:00:00 
    &lt;select name="type"&gt;
                &lt;option value="FindAllString" selected&gt;FindAllString&lt;/option&gt;
                &lt;option value="FindString"&gt;FindString&lt;/option&gt;
                &lt;option value="FindStringSubmatch"&gt;FindStringSubmatch&lt;/option&gt;
    &lt;/select&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that you could simply write the loop like this:</p>

<pre><code>{{range $key, $value := .Types}}
    &lt;option value="{{$key}}"{{if eq $key $.Res.Type}} selected{{end}}&gt;{{.}}&lt;/option&gt;
{{end}}
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that for testing purposes you may simply pass <code>os.Stdout</code> as the writer for template execution, and you'll see the result on your console without having to create and use a buffer, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>err = t.Execute(os.Stdout, struct {
    Types map[string]string
    Res   *Result
}{types, res})
</code></pre>

<p>Try the simplified version on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/pEvOsU-bNS" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>

<p>Read this answer for more insights: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42507958/golang-template-engine-pipelines/42508255#42508255">golang template engine pipelines</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-24T09:39:07.123" LastActivityDate="2017-06-24T09:39:07.123" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44735281      <row Id="44735281" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44735512" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44735281" CreationDate="2017-06-24T10:42:42.890" Score="1" Body="<p>One thing to remember while you were defining methods is:</p>

<p>Methods are like normal functions, and when you were calling <code>setValue()</code> function, what's happening is this.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type vertex struct {
    x int
    y int
}

func main() {
    var v vertex
    fmt.Println(v.setVertex(1, 2))
    fmt.Println(v)
/*  v = v.setVertex(1,2)
    // we are assigning the returned variable address to v.
    fmt.Println(v)
*/

}


// With a value receiver, the setVertex method operates on a copy of the 
// original vertex value. (This is the same behavior as for any other
// function argument.) 
// This methods has a value as a reciver, so it gets the copy not the 
// original vertex.

func (v vertex) setVertex(x, y int) vertex {
// Here it is similar to creating a new variable with name 'v',
// Go is lexically scoped using blocks, so this variable exists only 
// in this block, while it is returned we are printing it but we didn't
// store it in another variable.
    v.x = x
    v.y = y
    return v
}

// If you want to change any variable or struct, we need to pass its 
// address, else only copy of that variable is received by the called
// function.
</code></pre>

<p>This is clearly explained in <a href="https://tour.golang.org/methods/4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">gotour</a></p>
" OwnerDisplayName="user5952594" LastActivityDate="2017-06-24T10:42:42.890" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44738878      <row Id="44738878" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44739875" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44738878" CreationDate="2017-06-24T18:53:19.360" Score="0" Body="<p>You can utilize the Go conditional build via build tags and target your compilation of main.go. </p>

<p>Refer this <a href="https://dave.cheney.net/2014/09/28/using-build-to-switch-between-debug-and-release" rel="nofollow noreferrer">article</a> and put your thoughts into action.</p>

<p><strong>For Example:</strong></p>

<p>Directory structure </p>

<pre><code>build-tags
 build-tags
 dummy
  dummy.go
 main_dummy.go
 main_postgres.go
 postgres
     postgres.go
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Sample implementation:</strong></p>

<p>dummy/dummy.go</p>

<pre><code>package dummy

import "fmt"

func PrintName() {
    fmt.Println("My name is dummy package")
}
</code></pre>

<p>postgres/postgres.go</p>

<pre><code>package postgres

import "fmt"

func PrintName() {
    fmt.Println("My name is postgres package")
}
</code></pre>

<p>main_dummy.go</p>

<pre><code>// +build dummy

package main

import "build-tags/dummy"

func main() {
    dummy.PrintName()
}
</code></pre>

<p>postgres.go</p>

<pre><code>// +build postgres

package main

import "build-tags/postgres"

func main() {
    postgres.PrintName()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now let's build targeting <code>dummy</code> tag, same way you can do for <code>postgres</code> tag.</p>

<pre><code>go build --tags="dummy"

# run the program
./build-tags

My name is dummy package
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-24T21:51:48.803" LastActivityDate="2017-06-24T21:51:48.803" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44741975      <row Id="44741975" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44742254" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44741975" CreationDate="2017-06-25T00:59:49.623" Score="2" Body="<p>Both of your examples has data race issue. You can find out data race in following ways.</p>

<ol>
<li><code>go run -race program.go</code></li>
<li><code>go test -race &lt;package-name&gt;</code> or <code>go test -race -run=&lt;testcase-func-name&gt;</code></li>
<li><code>go build -race program.go</code> then execute the program</li>
<li><code>go install -race &lt;package-name&gt;</code> then execute the program</li>
</ol>

<p><strong>Example 1:</strong> data race info</p>

<pre><code>$ go build -race datarace-try1.go
$ ./datarace-try1
8
==================
WARNING: DATA RACE
Read at 0x00c4200761a8 by goroutine 7:

Goroutine 7 (running) created at:
  main.main()
      /Users/jeeva/go_playground/datarace-try1.go:25 +0xee

Goroutine 6 (running) created at:
  main.main()
      /Users/jeeva/go_playground/datarace-try1.go:25 +0xee
==================
187410
Found 1 data race(s)
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Example 2:</strong> data race info</p>

<pre><code>$ go build -race datarace-try2.go
$ ./datarace-try2
==================
WARNING: DATA RACE
Read at 0x00c420078178 by main goroutine:
  main.main()
      /Users/jeeva/go_playground/datarace-try2.go:10 +0x12e

Previous write at 0x00c420078178 by goroutine 6:
  main.main.func1()

Goroutine 6 (finished) created at:

Read at 0x00c420078178 by goroutine 7:

Previous write at 0x00c420078178 by goroutine 6:

Goroutine 7 (running) created at:

      /Users/jeeva/go_playground/datarace-try2.go:23 +0x11d
