" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-06-25T01:05:24.653" LastActivityDate="2017-06-25T01:05:24.653" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44746083      <row Id="44746083" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44746197" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44746083" CreationDate="2017-06-25T12:06:03.357" Score="0" Body="<p>Ok apparently </p>

<pre><code>&lt;-gocron.Start()
</code></pre>

<p>will start jobs that were already startet again so to fix my issue, I had to change the script to this:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    for i := 0; i &lt; 3; i++ {
        taskCron(i)
    }
    channel2 := make(chan int)
    go startCron(channel2)

    time.Sleep(time.Second * 5)
    gocron.Clear()
    fmt.Println("stop this")
}

func task(i int) {
    fmt.Println("still running...", i)
}

func taskCron(i int) {
    gocron.Every(4).Seconds().Do(task, i)
}

func startCron(channel chan int) {
    &lt;-gocron.Start()
}
</code></pre>

<p>I hope this helps anybody who had the same Problem!</p>
" OwnerUserId="5799860" LastActivityDate="2017-06-25T12:06:03.357" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44755089      <row Id="44755089" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44755496" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44755089" CreationDate="2017-06-26T08:15:52.423" Score="3" Body="<p>The current implementation is deterministic, e.g. for structs see <a href="https://golang.org/src/encoding/json/encode.go#L629" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/src/encoding/json/encode.go#L629</a> which gives struct order (and maps are by sorted keys).</p>

<p>But as this is <em>not</em> guaranteed by the documentation you should consider this an implementation detail.</p>

<p>If you want to hash the output you'll face more problems, e.g. there are several equivalent representations of characters in strings and JSON has no notion of an int (floats only). It really depends on what you try to do wirh that hash.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1266756" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T08:15:52.423" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44755921      <row Id="44755921" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44756120" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44755921" CreationDate="2017-06-26T08:56:46.353" Score="4" Body="<p>First, your code is invalid.  You need a valid array expression for your <code>aData</code> declaration, and you need to specify the type when assigning to <code>bData</code>.</p>

<pre><code>aData := []A{{"bob", 3, 4}, {"mary", 5, 2}}
bData := make([]B, len(aData))

for i, aItem := range aData {
    bData[i] = B{
        Field1: aItem.Field1,
        Field2: aItem.Field2,
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>So aside from your syntax errors, this is more idiomatic because:</p>

<ol>
<li>It uses <code>range</code> instead of a <code>for</code> loop, which is perfect for iterating over an array, and more readable.</li>
<li><code>bData</code> is preallocated to the exact size needed.</li>
<li>Field names are specified in the declaration of <code>bData</code>'s values.  It would be more idiomatic to do the same for <code>aData</code> as well, but it gets a bit verbose.</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T08:56:46.353" CommentCount="0" />

question:
35997995      <row Id="35997995" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44757772" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="35997995" CreationDate="2017-06-26T10:32:59.943" Score="1" Body="<p>Here a solution to make cross-compile super easy even with CGO.</p>

<p>I stumbled upon it recently after wasting a lot of time getting a new windows build server to build my Go app.
Now I just compile it on my Mac and will create a Linux build server with it:</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/karalabe/xgo" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/karalabe/xgo</a></p>

<p>Many thanks to Pter Szilgyi alias karalabe for this really great package!</p>

<p>How to use:</p>

<ul>
<li>have Docker running</li>
<li>go get github.com/karalabe/xgo</li>
<li>xgo --targets=windows/amd64 ./</li>
</ul>

<p>There are lots more options!</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T10:32:59.943" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44759185      <row Id="44759185" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44759462" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44759185" CreationDate="2017-06-26T12:13:39.670" Score="2" Body="<p>As the error describes, you are trying to store a <code>*io.PipeReader</code> value in a <code>io.PipeReader</code> field. You can fix this by updating your struct definition to the correct type:</p>

<pre><code>type ProgressPipeReader struct {
        *io.PipeReader
        progress int64
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T12:13:39.670" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44759016      <row Id="44759016" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44759792" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44759016" CreationDate="2017-06-26T12:30:26.997" Score="3" Body="<p>This is not possible with Go. As a statically compiled language you can only compile a binary if all its dependencies exist.
Can you give us some more details on why you need this in the first place? Maybe there is a simpler or more idiomatic way to achieve your idea.</p>
" OwnerUserId="11792" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T12:30:26.997" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44763440      <row Id="44763440" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44763544" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44763440" CreationDate="2017-06-26T15:46:45.477" Score="4" Body="<p>It is defined in assembly for various architectures in the <code>*.s</code> files located in the same package.</p>

<p>Per <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Function_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the spec</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A function declaration may omit the body. Such a declaration provides the signature for a function implemented outside Go, such as an assembly routine.</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-06-26T15:59:42.703" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T15:59:42.703" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44764596      <row Id="44764596" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44764648" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44764596" CreationDate="2017-06-26T16:49:54.273" Score="2" Body="<p>You have a couple of issues. First, you want to accept your incoming connections <em>inside</em> your for loop. Then, you're likely going want to spawn off a goroutine to handle the requests coming in.:</p>

<pre><code>for {
    // Listen for an incoming connection.
    conn, err := l.Accept()
    if err != nil {
        log.Println("Error accepting: ", err.Error())
        continue
    }

    // Handle connections in a new goroutine.
    go myHandler(conn)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Resources:<br>
<a href="https://tour.golang.org/concurrency" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tour.golang.org/concurrency</a></p>

<p>GoPlay:<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/7EovqNWJIx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/7EovqNWJIx</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4746361" LastEditorUserId="4746361" LastEditDate="2017-06-26T17:18:52.647" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T17:18:52.647" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44764485      <row Id="44764485" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44765128" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44764485" CreationDate="2017-06-26T17:18:05.377" Score="0" Body="<p>This code:</p>

<pre><code>lenghts3:= int64(len(buffer.Bytes()))
</code></pre>

<p>Is a concurrency problem: two routines may get the length at the same time, getting the same start position, and both proceed to write to the buffer with the same start position, stepping on each other's toes.</p>

<p>Since you're already retrieving whole objects in memory and not streaming to the combined buffer, you may as well just send the full contents of each file on a channel, and have a receiver on that channel append each result to a shared byte buffer as they come in, synchronously.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T17:18:05.377" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44766284      <row Id="44766284" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44766472" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44766284" CreationDate="2017-06-26T18:37:45.160" Score="5" Body="<p>So you're using an interface, and you need some sort of guarantee that you can set the value of a member of the struct?  Sounds like you should make that guarantee part of the interface, so something like:</p>

<pre><code>type Settable interface {
    SetVal(val int)
}

func (c *check) SetVal(val int) {
    c.Val = val
}

func some(te Settable) {
    te.SetVal(20)
}

type check struct {
    Val int
}

func main() {
    a := check{Val: 100}
    p := &amp;a
    some(p)
    fmt.Println(*p)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2082673" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T18:37:45.160" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44767424      <row Id="44767424" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44767697" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44767424" CreationDate="2017-06-26T19:56:04.823" Score="2" Body="<p>Your desired XML has 2 elements: <code>&lt;environment&gt;</code> and <code>&lt;temperature&gt;</code>, so you should have 2 types (structs) to model them. And you may use the tag <code>",chardata"</code> to tell the encoder to write the field's value as character data and not as an XML element.</p>

<pre><code>type environment struct {
    Temperature temperature `xml:"temperature"`
}

type temperature struct {
    Temperature string `xml:",chardata"`
    Type        string `xml:"type,attr"`
    Units       string `xml:"unit,attr"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Testing it:</p>

<pre><code>x := &amp;environment{
    Temperature: temperature{Temperature: "-11.3", Type: "float", Units: "c"},
}

enc := xml.NewEncoder(os.Stdout)
enc.Indent("", "  ")
if err := enc.Encode(x); err != nil {
    fmt.Printf("error: %v\n", err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>It produces the desired output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/oicKa9U38K" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>&lt;environment&gt;
  &lt;temperature type="float" unit="c"&gt;-11.3&lt;/temperature&gt;
&lt;/environment&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Note that you get the same result if you use the <code>",innerxml"</code> tag which tells the encoder to write the value verbatim, not subject to the usual marshaling procedure:</p>

<pre><code>type temperature struct {
    Temperature string `xml:",innerxml"`
    Type        string `xml:"type,attr"`
    Units       string `xml:"unit,attr"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output is the same. Try this one on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/lWQlohI3RT" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-26T20:01:23.613" LastActivityDate="2017-06-26T20:01:23.613" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44769538      <row Id="44769538" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44770471" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44769538" CreationDate="2017-06-27T00:09:20.283" Score="1" Body="<p>It's just a matter of casting the unsafe.Pointer back to an array (which is indexable) in the proper way.</p>

<p>After trying various casts, this is the one that worked (assuming <code>wid</code> and <code>hgt</code> are each declare as <code>const</code>):</p>

<pre><code>pixels := (*[wid*hgt*4]uint8)(ptr)
</code></pre>

<p>then I was able to change them with:</p>

<pre><code>pixels[(y*wid+x)*4+0] = 0x00 // Blue
pixels[(y*wid+x)*4+1] = 0x00 // Green
pixels[(y*wid+x)*4+2] = 0x00 // Red
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1475548" LastEditorUserId="1475548" LastEditDate="2017-07-06T16:25:01.577" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T16:25:01.577" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44768451      <row Id="44768451" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44770957" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44768451" CreationDate="2017-06-27T01:16:48.827" Score="1" Body="<p>Have a look at some http tests I've written: <a href="https://github.com/eamonnmcevoy/go_web_server/blob/master/pkg/server/user_router_test.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/eamonnmcevoy/go_web_server/blob/master/pkg/server/user_router_test.go</a></p>

<pre><code>    // Arrange
    us := mock.UserService{}
    testUserRouter := NewUserRouter(&amp;us, mux.NewRouter())
...
    w := httptest.NewRecorder()
    r, _ := http.NewRequest("PUT", "/", payload)
    r.Header.Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
    testUserRouter.ServeHTTP(w, r)
</code></pre>

<p>Simply create an instance of your router and call the endpoints using go's <code>httptest</code>. This snippet will perform a <code>PUT</code> request at the default endpoint <code>/</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="588734" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T01:16:48.827" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44770962      <row Id="44770962" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44771040" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44770962" CreationDate="2017-06-27T01:29:18.587" Score="6" Body="<p>The difference between expressions and statements is that expressions produce a value and thus can be used in places where values are required. So expressions can be used as values for variables, arguments to functions or operands to operators. Statements can't.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>and what does he mean that "you need values rather than variables" in his question?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I assume that by vals he means constants (which are called <code>val</code>s in Scala for example).</p>

<p>If <code>if</code> were an expression, you could do this:</p>

<pre><code>const myValue = if condition { value1 } else { value2 }
</code></pre>

<p>As it is, you have to do this:</p>

<pre><code>var myValue
if condition {
    myValue = value1
} else {
    myValue = value2
}
</code></pre>

<p>So you needed to make your variable mutable (use <code>var</code> instead of <code>const</code>), which is what the person asking the question likely meant.</p>
" OwnerUserId="149392" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T01:29:18.587" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44771078      <row Id="44771078" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44771757" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44771078" CreationDate="2017-06-27T03:19:18.700" Score="4" Body="<p>You have to experiment a bit with this stuff, but I don't think the main concern is <em>goroutines running at once</em>. As the answer @reticentroot linked to says, <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8509152/max-number-of-goroutines">it's not necessarily a problem to run a lot of simultaneous goroutines</a>.</p>

<p>I think your main concern should be <em>total number of goroutine launches</em>. The current implementation could theoretically start a goroutine to sort just a few items, and that goroutine would spend a lot more time on startup/coordination than actual sorting. </p>

<p>The ideal is you only start as many goroutines as you need to get good utilization of all your CPUs. If your work items are ~equal size and your cores are ~equally busy, then starting one task per core is perfect. </p>

<p>Here, tasks <em>aren't</em> evenly sized, so you might split the sort into <em>somewhat</em> more tasks than you have CPUs and distribute them. (In production you would typically use a <a href="https://gobyexample.com/worker-pools" rel="nofollow noreferrer">worker pool</a> to distribute work without starting a new goroutine for every task, but I think we can get away with skipping that here.)</p>

<p>To get a workable number of tasks--enough to keep all cores busy, but not so many that you create lots of overhead--you can set a minimum size (initial array size/100 or whatever), and only split off sorts of arrays larger than that. </p>

<hr>

<p>In slightly more detail, there is a bit of cost every time you send a task off to the background. For starters:</p>

<ul>
<li>Each goroutine <em>launch</em> spends a little time setting up the stack and doing scheduler bookkeeping</li>
<li>Each <em>task switch</em> spends some time in the scheduler and may incur <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CPU_cache#CACHE-MISS" rel="nofollow noreferrer">cache misses</a> when the two goroutines are looking at different code or data</li>
<li>Your own <em>coordination code</em> (channel sends and <code>sync</code> ops) takes time</li>
</ul>

<p>Other things can prevent ideal speedups from happening: you could hit a systemwide limit on e.g. memory bandwidth as Volker pointed out, some sync costs can increase as you add cores, and you can run into <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/False_sharing" rel="nofollow noreferrer">various</a> trickier <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-uniform_memory_access" rel="nofollow noreferrer">issues</a> sometimes. But the setup, switching, and coordination costs are a good place to start.</p>

<p>The benefit that can outweigh the coordination costs is, of course, other CPUs getting work done when they'd otherwise sit idle.</p>

<p>I think, but haven't tested, that your problems at 50 goroutines are 1) you already reached nearly-full utilization long ago, so adding more tasks adds more coordination work without making things go faster, and 2) you're creating goroutines for <em>tiny</em> sorts, which may spend more of their time setting up and coordinating than they actually do sorting. And at 10 goroutines your problem might be that you're no longer achieving full CPU utilization. </p>

<p>If you wanted, you could test those theories by counting the number of total goroutine launches at various goroutine limits (in <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/atomic/#AddInt64" rel="nofollow noreferrer">an atomic global counter</a>) and measuring CPU utilization at various limits (e.g. by running your program under the Linux/UNIX <code>time</code> utility).</p>

<p>The approach I'd suggest for a divide-and-conquer problem like this is <em>only fork off a goroutine for large enough subproblems</em> (for quicksort, that means large enough subarrays). You can try different limits: maybe you only start goroutines for pieces that are more than 1/64th of the original array, or pieces above some static threshold like 1000 items.</p>

<hr>

<p>And you meant this sort routine as an exercise, I suspect, but there are various things you can do to make your sorts faster or more robust against weird inputs. <a href="https://golang.org/src/sort/sort.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">The standard libary sort</a> falls back to insertion sort for small subarrays and uses heapsort for the unusual data patterns that cause quicksort problems. </p>

<p>You can also look at other algorithms like radix sort for all or part of the sorting, <a href="https://github.com/twotwotwo/sorts/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">which I played with</a>. That sorting library is also parallel. I wound up using a minimum cutoff of 127 items before I'd hand a subarray off for other goroutines to sort, and I used <a href="https://github.com/twotwotwo/sorts/blob/master/parallel.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">an arrangement with a fixed pool of goroutines and a buffered chan to pass tasks between them</a>. That produced decent practical speedups at the time, though I'm far from sure I found the optimal approach, and Go's scheduler has evolved since I wrote the package. Experimentation is interesting!</p>
" OwnerUserId="2714852" LastEditorUserId="2714852" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T20:32:30.443" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T20:32:30.443" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44772499      <row Id="44772499" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44772562" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44772499" CreationDate="2017-06-27T05:01:36.233" Score="6" Body="<p>The problem is that the filename ends in a newline:</p>

<pre><code>panic: open a.jpg
: no such file or directory
</code></pre>

<p>That should be:</p>

<pre><code>panic: open a.jpg: no such file or directory
</code></pre>

<p>This is because <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#Reader.ReadString" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>ReadString()</code></a> (emphasis mine):</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>reads until the first occurrence of delim in the input, returning a string containing the data up to and <strong>including the delimiter</strong>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Use <code>input = strings.TrimSpace(input)</code> to remove the newline.</p>

<hr>

<p>Extra tip 1: Instead of using <code>fmt.Println(input)</code> to debug stuff, you should use <code>fmt.Printf("%#v\n", input)</code>. This will show whitespace and unprintable characters clearer.</p>

<p>Extra tip 2: Go 1.2.1 is quite old; you should consider using a more recent version. <a href="https://golang.org/doc/go1compat" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go is very compatible</a> and upgrading to a newer version is usually not a problem.</p>
" OwnerUserId="660921" LastEditorUserId="660921" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T05:46:31.437" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T05:46:31.437" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44771474      <row Id="44771474" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44772811" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44771474" CreationDate="2017-06-27T05:29:51.550" Score="1" Body="<p>Like the error message says, you need to implement the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/#BinaryMarshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>BinaryMarshaler</code></a> interface for your <code>ArticleCovers</code> type:</p>

<pre><code>type ArticleCovers struct {
    ID             int
    Covers         ArticleCovers
    ArticleTypeID  int
    Address        Address     `gorm:"ForeignKey:AddressID"`
}

func (ac ArticleCovers) MarshalBinary() ([]byte, error) {
    return []byte(fmt.Sprintf("%v-%v", ac.ID, ac.ArticleTypeID)), nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that this only adds the <code>ID</code> and <code>ArticleTypeID</code> fields. I don't know what
the <code>ArticleCovers</code> and <code>Address</code> types look like, but often you want to call
the same methods on that:</p>

<pre><code>func (ac ArticleCovers) MarshalBinary() ([]byte, error) {
    covers, err := ac.Covers.MarshalBinary()
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    address, err := ac.Address.MarshalBinary()
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    return []byte(fmt.Sprintf("%v-%v-%v-%v",
        ac.ID, ac.ArticleTypeID, covers, address)
}
</code></pre>

<p>I don't know if this format makes sense for your data. You may want to use a
defined encoding format such as json.</p>

<p>You will probably also want to implement the <code>BinaryUnmarshaler</code> interface.
Doing that is left as an exercise ;-)</p>
" OwnerUserId="660921" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T05:29:51.550" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44773082      <row Id="44773082" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44773645" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44773082" CreationDate="2017-06-27T06:33:54.260" Score="1" Body="<ul>
<li>If you don't know the keys, you can use <code>map[string]interface{}</code> to unmarshal your JSON payload.</li>
<li>If you use <code>json:"-"</code> tag for the <code>struct</code> fields, those fields will be ignored during JSON Marshal/Unmarshal.</li>
</ul>

<p>You can try following options: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/30ko3Z14Mx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground link</a></p>

<p><strong>Option 1:</strong></p>

<pre><code>var grades map[string]interface{}

err := json.Unmarshal([]byte(jsonString), &amp;grades)
fmt.Println(err)

fmt.Printf("%#v\n", grades)
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Option 2:</strong> if you want have <code>struct</code></p>

<pre><code>var gradesData GradeData
err := json.Unmarshal([]byte(jsonString), &amp;gradesData.Grades)
fmt.Println(err)

fmt.Printf("%#v\n", gradesData)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T06:33:54.260" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44774514      <row Id="44774514" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44774651" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44774514" CreationDate="2017-06-27T07:36:41.077" Score="2" Body="<p>If I understand correctly, the issue you're having is that the random number appears to always have the same number of digits as the maximum allowed value, right? When I run the code, this is not the case. Here's an output I just observed:</p>

<pre><code>3859736307910539847452366166956263595094585475969163479420172104717272049811
65719900872761032562423535702578352960653752260368991759410130265294153783
</code></pre>

<p>In the playground, I believe the random seed and clock time are fixed, so you'll see the same result repeatedly. But running locally, I see the expected variation in the length of the output.</p>

<p><strong>UPDATE</strong></p>

<p>You may wonder why you can run this code a bunch of times and observe that the length of the random number is very often close to the length of the maximum value.</p>

<p>A little math explains this. Let's imagine we're picking a number between 0 and 999. How many numbers in that range have:</p>

<ol>
<li>3 digits? 900 (100-999)</li>
<li>2 digits? 90 (10-99)</li>
<li>1 digit? 10 (0-9)</li>
</ol>

<p>Similarly, with your very large maximum value, most of the numbers that can be picked will be very close to that maximum length. It will be rare to see a number two digits short of that length. (You should see them on the order of 1% of the time.)</p>
" OwnerUserId="94559" LastEditorUserId="94559" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T07:45:33.953" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T07:45:33.953" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44779319      <row Id="44779319" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44779409" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44779319" CreationDate="2017-06-27T11:41:43.793" Score="3" Body="<p>The <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>encoding/json</code></a> package can't magically guess what type you want the result unmarshaled into, unless you tell it to.</p>

<p>One way of telling what to unmarsal into is to pass value of that type to the <code>json.Unmarshal()</code> function.</p>

<p>And unfortunately there is no other way. If you pass a value of <code>interface{}</code> type, the <code>json</code> package implementation is free to choose a type of its choice, and it will choose <code>map[string]interface{}</code> for JSON objects, and <code>[]interface{}</code> for JSON arrays. This is documented at <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Unmarshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.Unmarshal()</code></a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>To unmarshal JSON into an interface value, Unmarshal stores one of these in the interface value:</p>

<pre><code>bool, for JSON booleans
float64, for JSON numbers
string, for JSON strings
[]interface{}, for JSON arrays
map[string]interface{}, for JSON objects
nil for JSON null
</code></pre>
</blockquote>

<p>If you know the type beforehand, create a value of that type, and pass that for unmarshaling. Whether your store this in an <code>interface{}</code> variable beforehand does not matter; if the passed value is suitable for unmarshaling, it will be used. Note that the passed value will be wrapped in an <code>interface{}</code> if not already of that type, as that is the parameter type of <code>json.Unmarshal()</code>.</p>

<p>The problem why your code fails is because you pass a value of type <code>*interface{}</code> which wraps a non-pointer <code>Foo</code> value. Since the <code>json</code> package can't use this, it creates a new value of its choice (a map).</p>

<p>Instead you should wrap a <code>*Foo</code> value in an <code>interface{}</code>, and pass that:</p>

<pre><code>func getFoo() interface{} {
    return &amp;Foo{"bar"}
}

func main() {
    fooInterface := getFoo()

    myJSON := `{"bar":"This is the new value of bar"}`
    jsonBytes := []byte(myJSON)

    err := json.Unmarshal(jsonBytes, fooInterface)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
    }
    fmt.Printf("%T %+v", fooInterface, fooInterface)
}
</code></pre>

<p>This results in (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Ys4AesTgAA" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>*main.Foo &amp;{Bar:This is the new value of bar}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T12:02:39.843" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T12:02:39.843" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44780166      <row Id="44780166" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44780779" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44780166" CreationDate="2017-06-27T12:51:27.070" Score="2" Body="<p>The Go template is executed and rendered at <strong>server side</strong>, in / by your Go app.</p>

<p><em>When</em> you select something in the School drop-down list, that happens at <strong>client side</strong>, in the browser.</p>

<p>The browser cannot execute Go templates. So basically you have 2 options:</p>

<p>1) When the user changes selection of the Schools drop-down, re-render the page. This involves sending a new HTTP request, you may provide the ID of the selected Scool in a URL parameter for example, and the Go template may render only the Students of the selected school in the 2nd drop-down list.</p>

<p>2) You may implement this at client side, using JavaScript code. For this, you would need to include all students of all schools in the rendered HTML page, e.g. in JavaScript arrays, and use JavaScript code to change the content of the Students drop-down list.</p>

<p>Read related questions:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28751637/referencing-go-array-in-javascript/28753476#28753476">Referencing Go array in Javascript</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41197376/interactive-web-pages-in-go/41198615#41198615">Interactive web pages in Go</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37118281/dynamically-refresh-a-part-of-the-template-when-a-variable-is-updated-golang/37119014#37119014">Dynamically refresh a part of the template when a variable is updated golang</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41136000/creating-load-more-button-in-golang-with-templates/41138344#41138344">Creating load more button in Golang with templates</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T13:55:26.550" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T13:55:26.550" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44782807      <row Id="44782807" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44783161" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44782807" CreationDate="2017-06-27T14:39:58.130" Score="1" Body="<p>You have a few issues.</p>

<ol>
<li>You aren't importing the <strong>testing</strong> package. This should be in the bootstrap file generated by Ginkgo.</li>
<li>The bootstrap file should also include as a parameter the testing.T function. e.g. <code>(t *testing.T)</code>.</li>
<li>It looks like you skipped a step or two in the Ginkgo process, resulting in a prior dependency not existing. e.g. the bootstrap/stub.</li>
</ol>

<p>Additionally, after a lot of comments by several people. You likely need to read the Ginkgo docs, to be sure you are following their process properly to get your tests setup properly.</p>
" OwnerUserId="584547" LastEditorUserId="584547" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T15:24:11.990" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T15:24:11.990" CommentCount="7" />

question:
44782680      <row Id="44782680" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44783465" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44782680" CreationDate="2017-06-27T14:52:41.417" Score="0" Body="<p>Does the directory <code>/assets</code> exist? Note that <code>/assets</code> is an absolute path, so it must be at the root of your filesystem. If you want something in the working directory where you're executing your program, you should use <code>./assets</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T14:52:41.417" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44784676      <row Id="44784676" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44784809" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44784676" CreationDate="2017-06-27T15:54:45.730" Score="1" Body="<p>When doing this:</p>

<pre><code>now := MysqlTime(time.Now())
</code></pre>

<p>It tries to convert a <code>Time</code> to your <code>MysqlTime</code> type (which throws an error).</p>

<p>Did you mean to actually initialize the inner <code>Time</code> attribute, like so?</p>

<pre><code>now := MysqlTime{time.Now()}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T15:54:45.730" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44786643      <row Id="44786643" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44786690" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44786643" CreationDate="2017-06-27T17:44:35.087" Score="2" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/exec/#Command" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Per the documentation</a>, the first argument passed to <code>exec.Command</code> is the name of an executable - that's it. It's not interpreted by the shell; it's the name of an executable you want to fork. If you need to pass in arguments, you can pass them in as <em>additional</em> parameters to <code>Command</code>, or you can pass them to the returned object afterward.</p>

<p>In your case, you're using two commands and piping the stdout of one to the stdin of another. You could do this in pure Go (piping the Stdout reader of one to the Stdin writer of the other), or you could rely on the shell to do it. In the latter case, your executable would be <code>sh</code> or <code>bash</code>, and the arguments would be <code>["-c", "pidof tor | xargs kill -HUP"]</code>. For example:</p>

<pre><code>cmd := exec.Command("bash", "-c", "pidof tor | xargs kill -HUP")
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T17:44:35.087" CommentCount="0" />

answer:
<row Id="44787609" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44787465" CreationDate="2017-06-27T18:40:50.350" Score="1" Body="<pre><code> gofmt -w -r '"FOO_common/server/src/foo/bar" -&gt; "foo/bar"' *.go
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://github.com/rogpeppe/govers" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/rogpeppe/govers</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-06-27T18:45:39.207" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T18:45:39.207" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44790504      <row Id="44790504" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44790925" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44790504" CreationDate="2017-06-27T22:28:28.463" Score="0" Body="<p>Thanks to @JimB's comment I realized my Mac had an old version of the <code>ipv4</code> package installed. After updating I was able to fix the code.</p>

<p>Here's a complete working version:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
  "fmt"
  "net"
  "bufio"
  "golang.org/x/net/ipv4"
)

const Host = "google.com"

func main() {
  var err error
  conn, err := net.Dial("tcp4", Host + ":80")
  if err != nil {
    panic(err)
  }
  defer conn.Close()

  if err = ipv4.NewConn(conn).SetTTL(5); err != nil {
      panic(err)
  }

  fmt.Fprint(conn, fmt.Sprintf("GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: %v

", Host))
  firstLine, err := bufio.NewReader(conn).ReadString('
')
  if err != nil {
    panic(err)
  }
  fmt.Println(firstLine)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Here is the output:</p>

<pre><code>HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8222849" LastEditorUserId="8222849" LastEditDate="2017-06-28T00:07:26.853" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T00:07:26.853" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44699463      <row Id="44699463" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44791273" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44699463" CreationDate="2017-06-27T23:04:23.303" Score="2" Body="<p>The context you received contains the cancellation and timeout, so it would be good to use the same context to make the new RPC. Otherwise you need to manually pass these signals.</p>

<p>A side on the metadata, metadata in the received context will not be automatically forwarded to the new RPC, see:</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/issues/1148" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/issues/1148</a></p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/pull/1157" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/pull/1157</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="7371810" LastActivityDate="2017-06-27T23:04:23.303" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44785181      <row Id="44785181" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44791823" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44785181" CreationDate="2017-06-28T00:12:31.423" Score="0" Body="<p>I hope this helps! Runnable version is at <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/-8shx_IcLV" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/-8shx_IcLV</a>. Also note that you'll need to fix your <code>%x</code> (should be <code>%s</code>) so you're sending the right challenge down to the client. Right now I think you're trying to hex-encode your base64 string.</p>

<p>Once you've fixed that, I believe this code should help you to construct the right response string on the server and compare it to what the client sent.</p>

<pre><code>// Example values taken from http://susam.in/blog/auth-cram-md5/

challenge := []byte("&lt;17893.1320679123@tesseract.susam.in&gt;")
username := []byte("alice")
password := []byte("wonderland")
clientResponse := []byte("YWxpY2UgNjRiMmE0M2MxZjZlZDY4MDZhOTgwOTE0ZTIzZTc1ZjA=")

// hash the challenge with the user's password
h := hmac.New(md5.New, password)
h.Write(challenge)
hash := h.Sum(nil)

// encode the result in lowercase hexadecimal
hexEncoded := hex.EncodeToString(hash)

// prepend the username and a space
toEncode := []byte(string(username) + " " + hexEncoded)

// base64-encode the whole thing
b64Result := make([]byte, base64.StdEncoding.EncodedLen(len(toEncode)))
base64.StdEncoding.Encode(b64Result, toEncode)

// check that this is equal to what the client sent
if hmac.Equal(b64Result, clientResponse) {
    fmt.Println("Matches!")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="94559" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T00:12:31.423" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44793019      <row Id="44793019" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44794861" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44793019" CreationDate="2017-06-28T06:11:50.137" Score="2" Body="<p>As <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Ticker.Stop" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a> says, ticker.Stop doesn't close channel. So you must not expect break-loop. You can add new channel for quit.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "time"
)

func main() {
    intChan := make(chan int, 2)
    ticker := time.NewTicker(time.Second)
    quit := make(chan bool)
    go func() {
    loop:
        for {
            select {
            case &lt;-ticker.C:
                select {
                case intChan &lt;- 1:
                case intChan &lt;- 2:
                case intChan &lt;- 3:
                }
            case &lt;-quit:
                break loop
            }
        }
        /*defer */
        fmt.Println("End. [sender]")
        close(intChan)
    }()
    var sum int
    for e := range intChan {
        fmt.Printf("Received: %v\n", e)
        sum += e
        if sum &gt; 10 {
            fmt.Printf("Got: %v\n", sum)
            quit &lt;- true
            //break
            //ticker.Stop()
        }
    }
    fmt.Println("End. [receiver]")
    //time.Sleep(10)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="720391" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T06:11:50.137" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44795041      <row Id="44795041" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44796528" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44795041" CreationDate="2017-06-28T07:47:26.993" Score="1" Body="<p>You're using two different <code>logrus.Logger</code> variables in your code. The first, which is called in <code>init()</code> is the global default Logger that gets exported from logrus. Later, in your custom initialization function <code>Init(logLevel int)</code>, you're creating a new Logger via <code>logrus.New()</code> which is from then on used for logging  but hasn't been configured to use a different output.</p>

<p>I'd suggest to get rid of the init() function and do all the initialization in your <code>Init(logLevel int)</code> (please note the different API for setting the output).</p>

<pre><code>func Init(logLevl int) {
    log = logrus.New()
    log.Formatter = &amp;logrus.TextFormatter{FullTimestamp: true}
    switch logLevl {
    case DEBUG:
        log.Level = logrus.DebugLevel
    case INFO:
        log.Level = logrus.InfoLevel
    case WARNING:
        log.Level = logrus.WarnLevel
    case ERROR:
        log.Level = logrus.ErrorLevel
    }

    env := os.Getenv("ENV")
    if env != "test" {
        return
    }
    log.Out = ioutil.Discard
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4445" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T07:47:26.993" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44797043      <row Id="44797043" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44797934" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44797043" CreationDate="2017-06-28T08:54:53.987" Score="1" Body="<p>So I figured out what I was doing wrong. I initially had the data as a <code>string</code>, but if I cast it to a <code>byte[]</code> then I can update it in place. </p>

<p>This allowed me to use a simple <code>for</code> loop below to solve the issue without relying on any other metric other than nth character instance</p>

<pre><code>for i := 0; i &lt; len(dat); i++ {
    if dat[i] == ',' {
        count += 1
    }
    if count%6 == 0 &amp;&amp; dat[i] == ',' {
        dat[i] = '\n'
        count = 0
    }
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5050584" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T08:54:53.987" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44800093      <row Id="44800093" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44800253" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44800093" CreationDate="2017-06-28T10:42:52.740" Score="1" Body="<p>The Go documentation of the <code>html/template</code> package explains the behaviour (<a href="https://golang.org/pkg/html/template/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/html/template/</a>):</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The security model used by this package assumes that template authors are trusted, while Execute's data parameter is not. More details are provided below.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The thing about this is that you should really think twice about <strong>why</strong> you don't want Go to apply this security behaviour to your template.</p>

<p>Then, if you're really sure you don't want to escape the string use <code>template.URL</code> intead of a string: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/kfv2tH6WDG" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/kfv2tH6WDG</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="302646" LastEditorUserId="302646" LastEditDate="2017-06-28T11:13:17.363" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T11:13:17.363" CommentCount="3" />

Take a look at the example for <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/context/#WithCancel" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>context.WithCancel</code></a>, it shows how to do exactly what you describe.</p>

question:
44804276      <row Id="44804276" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44804675" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44804276" CreationDate="2017-06-28T13:59:55.627" Score="0" Body="<p>The results in PHP and Go are different because, as the documentation for each states, <a href="http://php.net/manual/en/function.chr.php" rel="nofollow noreferrer">PHP's chr</a> returns the ASCII character for its argument, whereas <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Conversions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go's rune</a> <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Rune_literals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">uses UTF-8</a>. Below 127, ASCII and UTF-8 are the same, but above that, they differ.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T13:59:55.627" CommentCount="0" />

<row Id="44806148" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44805907" CreationDate="2017-06-28T14:59:53.933" Score="0" Body="<p>If you're already using Nginx, you can very easily set up named-based reverse proxy vhosts for the apps that aren't on port 80:</p>

<pre><code>server {
    listen *:80;
    server_name nodeapp.mydomain.com;
    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:3000;
    }
}

server {
    listen *:80;
    server_name goapp.mydomain.com;
    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:5000;
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="453002" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T14:59:53.933" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44806362      <row Id="44806362" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44807928" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44806362" CreationDate="2017-06-28T16:24:11.633" Score="2" Body="<p>I think the error you're making is treating binary as character data and using character data APIs. Many of those APIs <strong>stop</strong> at the first nil byte (0), but that is a totally valid value in protobuf binary.</p>

<p>You need to make sure you don't use any such APIs basically - stick purely to binary safe APIs.</p>

<p>Since you indicate that <code>size</code> is 27, this all fits.</p>

<p>Basically, the binary representation of 5.0 includes 0 bytes, but you could easily have seen the same problem for other values in time.</p>
" OwnerUserId="23354" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T16:24:11.633" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44790847      <row Id="44790847" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44811887" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44790847" CreationDate="2017-06-28T20:21:33.037" Score="1" Body="<p>Vertex attributes are conceptually always 4 component vectors. There is no requirement that the number of components you use in the shader and the one you set up for the attribute pointer have to match. If your array has more components than your shader consumes, the additional components are just ignored. If your array supplies less components, the attribute is filled to a vector of the form (0,0,0,1) (which makes sense for homogeneous position vectors as well as RGBA colors).</p>

<p>In the usual case, you want <code>w=1</code> for every input position anyway, there is no need to store that in an array. But you usually need the full 4D form when applying the transformation matrices (or even when directly forwarding the value as <code>gl_Position</code>). So your shader could conceptually do</p>

<pre><code>in vec3 pos;
gl_Position=vec4(pos,1);
</code></pre>

<p>but that would be equivalent of just writing</p>

<pre><code>in vec4 pos;
gl_Position=pos;
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2327517" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T20:21:33.037" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44812324      <row Id="44812324" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44812828" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44812324" CreationDate="2017-06-28T21:27:38.280" Score="7" Body="<p>You could use a <code>map[string]command</code> similar to how the <code>net/http</code> package registers handlers. Something akin to this:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/9YzHyLodAQ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/9YzHyLodAQ</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "errors"
)

type BotFunc func(string) (string, error)

type BotMap map[string]BotFunc

var Bot = BotMap{}

func (b BotMap) RegisterCommand(command string, f BotFunc) error {
    if _, exists := b[command]; exists {
        return errors.New("command already exists")
    }
    b[command] = f
    return nil
}

func (b BotMap) Execute(statement string) (string, error) {
    // parse out command and query however you choose (not this way obviously)
    command := statement[:9]
    query := statement[10:]

    return b.ExecuteQuery(command, query)
}

func (b BotMap) ExecuteQuery(command, query string) (string, error) {
    if com, exists := b[command]; exists {
        return com(query)
    }
    return "", errors.New("command doesn't exist")

}

func main() {
    err := Bot.RegisterCommand("search me", func(query string) (string, error) {
        fmt.Println("search", query)
        return "searched", nil
    })
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }
    err = Bot.RegisterCommand("thesaurus me", func(query string) (string, error) {
        fmt.Println("thesaurus", query)
        return "thesaurused", nil
    })
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }

    result, err := Bot.Execute("search me please")
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }
    fmt.Println(result)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Obviously there's a lot of checks missing here, but this is the basic idea.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastEditorUserId="1276480" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T11:19:50.253" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T11:19:50.253" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44805984      <row Id="44805984" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44813472" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44805984" CreationDate="2017-06-28T22:22:32.787" Score="2" Body="<p>Adrian is correct. To take it a step further, you can only do anything with interfaces if you know the type that implements that interface. The empty interface, <code>interface{}</code> isn't really an "anything" value like is commonly misunderstood; it is just an interface that is immediately satisfied by all types.</p>

<p>Therefore, you can only get values from it or create a new "interface" with added values by knowing the type satisfying the empty interface before and after the addition.</p>

<p>The closest you can come to doing what you want, given the static typing, is by embedding the before type in the after type, so that everything can still be accessed at the root of the after type. The following illustrates this.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/JdF7Uevlqp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/JdF7Uevlqp</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

type Before struct {
    m map[string]string
}

type After struct {
    Before
    s []string
}

func contrivedAfter(b interface{}) interface{} {
    return After{b.(Before), []string{"new value"}}
}

func main() {
    b := Before{map[string]string{"some": "value"}}
    a := contrivedAfter(b).(After)
    fmt.Println(a.m)
    fmt.Println(a.s)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Additionally, since the data you are passing to the template does not require you to specify the type, you could use an anonymous struct to accomplish something very similar.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/3KUfHULR84" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/3KUfHULR84</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

type Before struct {
    m map[string]string
}

func contrivedAfter(b interface{}) interface{} {
    return struct{
        Before
        s []string
    }{b.(Before), []string{"new value"}}
}

func main() {
    b := Before{map[string]string{"some": "value"}}
    a := contrivedAfter(b)
    fmt.Println(a)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2081835" LastEditorUserId="2081835" LastEditDate="2017-06-28T22:29:45.630" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T22:29:45.630" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44813598      <row Id="44813598" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44813913" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44813598" CreationDate="2017-06-28T23:09:07.883" Score="0" Body="<p>You have two problems:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>A variadic function takes multiple args (fmt.Println, for example, takes multiple interface{}). You're sending an array.</p></li>
<li><p>An array which is size [2] is not the same as size [] (yes, size of array is part of the type in go).</p></li>
</ol>

<p>What you want is something like:</p>

<pre><code>    for n := range merge(res[:]) {
</code></pre>

<p>...</p>

<pre><code>func merge(cs []&lt;-chan int) &lt;-chan int {
out := make(chan int)
var wg sync.WaitGroup
wg.Add(len(cs))
for _, c := range cs {
    go func(ch &lt;-chan int) {
        for n := range ch {
            out &lt;- n
        }
        wg.Done()
    }(c)
}
go func() {
    wg.Wait()
    close(out)
}()
return out
</code></pre>

<p>}</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/zTrrsRkKJV" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/zTrrsRkKJV</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5849285" LastEditorUserId="5849285" LastEditDate="2017-06-28T23:12:31.900" LastActivityDate="2017-06-28T23:12:31.900" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44814963      <row Id="44814963" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44815038" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44814963" CreationDate="2017-06-29T01:40:45.473" Score="1" Body="<p>The <code>InitStmt</code> (initialization statement) of your <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#For_statements" rel="nofollow noreferrer">For Statement</a> isn't actually doing any initialization.  You're asking the compiler to evaluate <code>n</code> but not do anything with it, which is what the compiler is complaining about.  Since you don't need to initialize <code>n</code> for you loop, just do:</p>

<pre><code>for ; n &lt; localMax; n++ {
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1427098" LastActivityDate="2017-06-29T01:40:45.473" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44818867      <row Id="44818867" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44820581" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44818867" CreationDate="2017-06-29T08:57:48.643" Score="1" Body="<p>It's intended behavior, and is configurable. By default, <code>Gorilla</code> mux will do path cleaning, i.e. removing double slash etc. for new router. You can left the double slash as is by:</p>

<pre><code>router.SkipClean(true)
</code></pre>

<p>The <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/gorilla/mux#Router.SkipClean" rel="nofollow noreferrer">SkipClean</a> documentation says:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>...<br>
  When true, if the route path is "/path//to", it will remain with the double slash. This is helpful if you have a route like: <code>/fetch/http://xkcd.com/534/</code></p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-06-29T08:57:48.643" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44822381      <row Id="44822381" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44822438" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44822381" CreationDate="2017-06-29T10:19:24.303" Score="2" Body="<p>Check the bool value return from <a href="https://godoc.org/context#Context" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>context.Deadline</code></a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Deadline returns the time when work done on behalf of this context
  should be canceled. Deadline returns ok==false when no deadline is
  set. Successive calls to Deadline return the same results.</p>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>func (c *Client) Send(ctx context.Context, r *http.Request) (int, []byte, error) {
    if _, deadlineSet := ctx.Deadline(); !deadlineSet {
        ctx, _ = context.WithTimeout(ctx, c.timeout)
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-06-29T10:19:24.303" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44829665      <row Id="44829665" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44829959" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44829665" CreationDate="2017-06-29T15:56:09.710" Score="1" Body="<p>As far as I know, It's impossible since go can't unload shared library. When created some objects in the plugin, and it's referenced from program, it can't do garbage collect. See this issue: <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/11100" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/issues/11100</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="720391" LastActivityDate="2017-06-29T15:56:09.710" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44833044      <row Id="44833044" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44833099" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44833044" CreationDate="2017-06-29T19:06:17.913" Score="6" Body="<p><code>del</code> is not an executable, it's a built-in command. <code>exec.Command</code> allows you to fork out to another executable. To use shell commands, you would have to call the shell executable, and pass in the built-in command (and parameters) you want executed:</p>

<pre><code>cmd := exec.Command("cmd.exe", "/C", "del C:\\trial\\now.txt")
</code></pre>

<p>Note that you also have to escape backslashes in strings as above, or use backtick-quoted strings:</p>

<pre><code>cmd := exec.Command("cmd.exe", "/C", `del C:\trial\now.txt`)
</code></pre>

<p>However, if you just want to delete a file, you're probably better off using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#Remove" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>os.Remove</code></a> to directly delete a file rather than forking out to the shell to do so.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-06-29T19:34:37.690" LastActivityDate="2017-06-29T19:34:37.690" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44816003      <row Id="44816003" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44839876" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44816003" CreationDate="2017-06-30T06:22:26.920" Score="2" Body="<p>I think the example code you're referring to uses an outdated API of <a href="https://github.com/dgrijalva/jwt-go/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">jwt-go</a>. The RS256 signing method requires the key to be a <code>rsa.PrivateKey</code> and not a byte buffer. This means, that the private key first has to be parsed using the <code>jwt.ParseRSAPrivateKeyFromPEM</code>function.</p>

<p>I've updated your example below:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    tokenString, err := createSignedTokenString()
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Printf("Signed token string:
%v
", tokenString)

    token, err := parseTokenFromSignedTokenString(tokenString)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Printf("Parsed token valid = %v, raw token:
%v
", token.Valid, token.Raw)
}

func createSignedTokenString() (string, error) {
    privateKey, err := ioutil.ReadFile("demo.rsa")
    if err != nil {
        return "", fmt.Errorf("error reading private key file: %v
", err)
    }

    key, err := jwt.ParseRSAPrivateKeyFromPEM(privateKey)
    if err != nil {
        return "", fmt.Errorf("error parsing RSA private key: %v
", err)
    }

    token := jwt.New(jwt.SigningMethodRS256)
    tokenString, err := token.SignedString(key)
    if err != nil {
        return "", fmt.Errorf("error signing token: %v
", err)
    }

    return tokenString, nil
}

func parseTokenFromSignedTokenString(tokenString string) (*jwt.Token, error) {
    publicKey, err := ioutil.ReadFile("demo.rsa.pub")
    if err != nil {
        return nil, fmt.Errorf("error reading public key file: %v
", err)
    }

    key, err := jwt.ParseRSAPublicKeyFromPEM(publicKey)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, fmt.Errorf("error parsing RSA public key: %v
", err)
    }

    parsedToken, err := jwt.Parse(tokenString, func(token *jwt.Token) (interface{}, error) {
        if _, ok := token.Method.(*jwt.SigningMethodRSA); !ok {
            return nil, fmt.Errorf("unexpected signing method: %v", token.Header["alg"])
        }
        return key, nil
    })
    if err != nil {
        return nil, fmt.Errorf("error parsing token: %v", err)
    }

    return parsedToken, nil
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4445" LastEditorUserId="4445" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T20:08:18.583" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T20:08:18.583" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44842132      <row Id="44842132" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44842353" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44842132" CreationDate="2017-06-30T08:48:52.887" Score="1" Body="<p>The API paginates the results. You should fetch the whole list in multiple requests by specifying <code>start</code> and <code>limit</code>.</p>

<p>E.g. request the list of first 30 documents with <code>start=0&amp;limit=30</code>, then the next 30 with <code>start=30&amp;limit=30</code>, and so on, until you get a response with empty list.</p>

<p>You can read more details in <a href="https://developer.atlassian.com/confdev/confluence-server-rest-api/pagination-in-the-rest-api" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the docs on pagination</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6444852" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T08:48:52.887" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44842722      <row Id="44842722" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44843162" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44842722" CreationDate="2017-06-30T09:30:28.753" Score="4" Body="<p><code>*Item</code> is a golang pointer to a struct. It cannot contain a <code>int16</code> (that is a "pointer" in your json semantic).</p>

<p>You can handle this programmatically <em>after</em> Unmarshaling.</p>

<p>Struct must be:</p>

<pre><code>type Item struct {
    ID         int16 `json:"id"`
    SubItem    *Item
    SubItemInt int16 `json:"sub_item"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>and then you should do something like this:</p>

<pre><code>items := make(map[int16]*Item)
[...]
for k := range items {
    items[k].SubItem = items[items[k].SubItemInt]
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1273924" LastEditorUserId="1273924" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T09:58:22.167" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T09:58:22.167" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44823580      <row Id="44823580" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44843649" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44823580" CreationDate="2017-06-30T09:54:38.730" Score="0" Body="<p>It seems, like to reference system libs of another OS, 
for example linux system libs when compiling from windows - 
the linux system libs must be present on the windows system.</p>

<p>The same would be the case, when using special libs, for example when calling c-libs using "cgo", which maybe could implement some device specific functions.
For example on a coffee machine - the functions which starts making coffee or cleaning the machine.</p>
" OwnerUserId="513393" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T09:54:38.730" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44844654      <row Id="44844654" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44847571" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44844654" CreationDate="2017-06-30T13:22:37.237" Score="2" Body="<p>Here is an example producer-consumer type. I only use the <code>WaitGroup</code> here so that the main goroutine wouldn't exit instantly. Theoretically your application could either wait, or do some other interesting stuff in the mean time.</p>

<p>Note that you could also use a buffered channel using <code>c := make(chan(*Feed, n))</code> where <code>n</code> is the number you want buffered. Just be aware that in a typical producer-consumer scenario, there is sometimes a lot of resources allocated per job. So depending on that you could buffer just a few, or all of them if you wanted. </p>

<p>Without a buffered channel, it acts as a sync between the goroutines. Producers block at <code>c &lt;-</code> waiting for a consumer's <code>&lt;- c</code> to hand off to, so only one of each routine execute these lines at a time.</p>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong> I added a pause before printing "started" to make the output less synchronized. It previously always output:</p>

<pre><code>created
started
created
started
...
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/FmWqegr-CR" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/FmWqegr-CR</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "math/rand"
    "sync"
    "time"
)

type Feed struct {
    title, descr, link string
    published          time.Time
}

func CreateFeed() *Feed {
    r := rand.Int() % 500
    time.Sleep(1000 + time.Duration(r)*time.Millisecond)
    fmt.Println("Feed created")
    return &amp;Feed{
        published: time.Now(),
    }
}

func UseFeed(f *Feed) {
    time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
    fmt.Println("Feed started")
    time.Sleep(1600 * time.Millisecond)
    fmt.Printf("Feed consumed: %s\n", f.published)
}

func main() {
    numFeeds := 10

    var wg sync.WaitGroup
    wg.Add(10)

    c := make(chan (*Feed))
    for i := 0; i &lt; numFeeds; i++ {
        go func() { c &lt;- CreateFeed() }()
    }

    for i := 0; i &lt; numFeeds; i++ {
        go func() {
            f := &lt;-c
            UseFeed(f)
            wg.Done()
        }()
    }

    wg.Wait()
}
</code></pre>

<p>I'm hoping this is what you are looking for.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastEditorUserId="1276480" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T13:34:59.437" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T13:34:59.437" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44848112      <row Id="44848112" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44848233" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44848112" CreationDate="2017-06-30T13:55:25.293" Score="2" Body="<p>This part of the function signature is exactly what the function returns.</p>

<pre><code>(*PutRecordOutput, error)
</code></pre>

<p>So this one will return a pointer to a <code>PutRecordOutput</code> plus an <code>error</code> (which by convention is returned as <code>nil</code> if no error occurred).</p>

<p>If you look at the source code for the function, <code>return</code> statements will have to be consistent with that, so that can also help you understand how the return values are built.</p>

<p>But, please note that in some cases you could have named output arguments, like:</p>

<pre><code>(output *PutRecordOutput, err error)
</code></pre>

<p>In that case, <code>output</code> and <code>err</code> will be valid local variables inside the function, and you might see a plain return statement like this:</p>

<pre><code>return
</code></pre>

<p>Just keep in mind that one would implicitly be like doing:</p>

<pre><code>return output, err
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T13:55:25.293" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44847460      <row Id="44847460" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44848560" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44847460" CreationDate="2017-06-30T14:13:20.963" Score="1" Body="<p>You're using different variant (the constructor that takes UTF-8 <code>string</code>) when initializing C# instance. In addition, as already pointed by zaph, you need to use same iteration count for both C# and <code>golang</code> codes. The <code>golang</code> version takes <code>[]byte</code> arguments both for <em>password</em> and <em>salt</em>, and the C# counterpart is <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms148161(v=vs.110).aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Rfc2898DeriveBytes Constructor (Byte[] password,Byte[] salt,Int32 iterations)</code></a>.</p>

<pre><code>byte[] passBytes = new byte[]
    {164,176,124,62,244,154,226,211,177,90,202,180,12,142,25,225};

byte[] saltBytes = new byte[]
    {173,205,190,172,239,190,242,63,219,205,173,196,218,171,142,214};

var pbkdf2 = new Rfc2898DeriveBytes(passBytes, saltBytes, 1000);
var key = Convert.ToBase64String(pbkdf2.GetBytes(16));
</code></pre>

<p>The output of above code is the same with <code>golang</code> version.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T14:48:02.400" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T14:48:02.400" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44848595      <row Id="44848595" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44849043" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44848595" CreationDate="2017-06-30T14:38:45.003" Score="3" Body="<p>Looking at the assembly output (<code>go run -gcflags '-S' test.go</code>) there is some difference:</p>

<p>Bool:</p>

<pre><code>0x0075 00117 (test.go:11)   MOVBLZX (AX)(BX*1), DI
0x0079 00121 (test.go:11)   TESTB   DIB, DIB
</code></pre>

<p>Int:</p>

<pre><code>0x0075 00117 (test.go:28)   MOVQ    (AX)(BX*8), DI
0x0079 00121 (test.go:28)   CMPQ    DI, $1
</code></pre>

<p>Byte/uint8:</p>

<pre><code>0x0075 00117 (test.go:28)   MOVBLZX (AX)(BX*1), DI
0x0079 00121 (test.go:28)   CMPB    DIB, $1
</code></pre>

<p>The rest of the assembly is near-identical for me on Go 1.8.*.</p>

<p>So: 1) data types are sized different 2) operations are different</p>
" OwnerUserId="687438" LastEditorUserId="687438" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T15:04:56.083" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T15:04:56.083" CommentCount="9" />

question:
44850023      <row Id="44850023" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44852808" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44850023" CreationDate="2017-06-30T18:28:09.213" Score="3" Body="<p>Try encrypting from Python like this.</p>

<p>The result can then be unencrypted from Go successfully.</p>

<pre><code> #!/usr/bin/env python3
import base64
from Crypto.Cipher import AES

MODE = AES.MODE_CFB
BLOCK_SIZE = 16
SEGMENT_SIZE = 128

def _pad_string(value):
    length = len(value)
    pad_size = BLOCK_SIZE - (length % BLOCK_SIZE)
    return value.ljust(length + pad_size, '\x00')

def encrypt(key, iv, plaintext):
    aes = AES.new(key, MODE, iv, segment_size=SEGMENT_SIZE)
    plaintext = _pad_string(plaintext)
    encrypted_text = aes.encrypt(plaintext)
    return encrypted_text

key = 'TfvY7I358yospfWKcoviZizOShpm5hyH'
iv = 'mb13KcoviZizvYhp'
original_message = 'This is not encrypted'

encryptedpayload = base64.b64encode(encrypt(key, iv, original_message))

print('Going to encrypt and base64 "{}" result:\n{}\n'.format(original_message,encryptedpayload))
</code></pre>

<p>Source: <a href="http://chase-seibert.github.io/blog/2016/01/29/cryptojs-pycrypto-ios-aes256.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://chase-seibert.github.io/blog/2016/01/29/cryptojs-pycrypto-ios-aes256.html</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T18:28:09.213" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44853839      <row Id="44853839" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44854439" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44853839" CreationDate="2017-06-30T20:33:21.280" Score="1" Body="<p>I really didn't like how <code>nextPassword</code> was written, so I made a variation. Rather than starting at 0 and repeatedly returning the next value, this one takes an integer and converts it to the corresponding "password." E.g. <code>toPassword(0, 2, []rune("ABCDE"))</code> is <code>AA</code>, and <code>toPassword(5, ...)</code> is <code>BA</code>.</p>

<p>From there, it's easy to loop over whatever range you want. But I also wrote a <code>nextPassword</code> wrapper around it that behaves similarly to the one in the original code. This one uses <code>toPassword</code> under the cover and takes a starting <code>n</code>.</p>

<p>Runnable version here: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/fBo6mx4Mji" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/fBo6mx4Mji</a></p>

<p>Code below:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

func toPassword(n, length int, alphabet []rune) string {
    base := len(alphabet)

    // This will be our output
    result := make([]rune, length)

    // Start filling from the right
    i := length - 1

    // This is essentially a conversion to base-b, where b is
    // the number of possible letters (5 in the case of "ABCDE")
    for n &gt; 0 {
        // Filling from the right, put the right digit mod b
        result[i] = alphabet[n%base]

        // Divide the number by the base so we're ready for
        // the next digit
        n /= base

        // Move to the left
        i -= 1
    }

    // Fill anything that's left with "zeros" (first letter of
    // the alphabet)
    for i &gt;= 0 {
        result[i] = alphabet[0]
        i -= 1
    }

    return string(result)
}

// Convenience function that just returns successive values from
// toPassword starting at start
func nextPassword(start, length int, alphabet []rune) func() string {
    n := start
    return func() string {
        result := toPassword(n, length, alphabet)
        n += 1
        return result
    }
}

func main() {
    for i := 5; i &lt; 11; i++ {
        fmt.Println(toPassword(i, 2, []rune("ABCDE")))
    } // BA, BB, BC, BD, BE, CA

    // Now do the same thing using nextPassword
    np := nextPassword(5, 2, []rune("ABCDE"))
    for i := 0; i &lt; 6; i++ {
        fmt.Println(np())
    } // BA, BB, BC, BD, BE, CA
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="94559" LastEditorUserId="94559" LastEditDate="2017-06-30T20:41:01.387" LastActivityDate="2017-06-30T20:41:01.387" CommentCount="0" />

question:
43421062      <row Id="43421062" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44857027" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="43421062" CreationDate="2017-07-01T03:14:26.470" Score="0" Body="<p><strong>fmt.Scanln stops reading after the spaces.</strong></p>

<p>Two Approaches to solve this Problem </p>

<p><strong>1st Approach: USE Scanf</strong></p>

<pre><code>var in string
fmt.Scanf("%q", &amp;in)
</code></pre>

<p>But then your input should be enclosed within the double quotes like <code>"2 3"</code></p>

<p><strong>2nd Approach: USE bufio</strong></p>

<p>The best way I consider</p>

<pre><code>scanner := bufio.NewScanner(os.Stdin)
for scanner.Scan(){
   in = scanner.Text()
   break  //optional line if your input has a single line
}
fmt.Println(in)
</code></pre>

<p>This shall solve the problem in the best way</p>
" OwnerUserId="6789776" LastActivityDate="2017-07-01T03:14:26.470" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44857538      <row Id="44857538" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44857672" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44857538" CreationDate="2017-07-01T05:29:43.400" Score="6" Body="<p>That will install any "<code>main</code>" packages found in the current or subdirectories, </p>

<p>"subdirectories": that is what the <code>./...</code> syntax means.<br>
It forces <code>go install</code> to consider not just the current folder/package ('.'), but also the ones in the sub-folders: "<code>...</code>"</p>

<p>See "<a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/14870666/6309">What is a sensible way to layout a Go project</a>": you can have multiple packages "<code>main</code>", in a library driven development:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Moving the <code>main.go</code> file out of your root allows you to build your application from the perspective of a library. Your application binary is simply a client of your applications library.</p>
  
  <p>Sometimes you might want users to interact in multiple ways so you create multiple binaries.<br>
  For example, if you had an adder package that that let users add numbers together, you may want to release a command line version as well as a web version.<br>
  You can easily do this by organizing your project like this:</p>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>adder/
  adder.go
  cmd/
    adder/
      main.go
    adder-server/
      main.go
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>Users can install your adder application binaries with go get using an ellipsis:</p>

<pre><code>$ go get github.com/benbjohnson/adder/...
</code></pre>
  
  <p>And voila, your user has adder and adder-server installed!</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Similarly, a <code>go install -v ./...</code> would install adder and adder-server as well.</p>

<p>Note: the <code>-v</code> print the names of packages as they are compiled.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6309" LastEditorUserId="6309" LastEditDate="2017-07-01T05:36:37.207" LastActivityDate="2017-07-01T05:36:37.207" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44857638      <row Id="44857638" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44857811" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44857638" CreationDate="2017-07-01T05:51:57.263" Score="1" Body="<p>There is a problem in your <code>golang</code> code, the following lines:</p>

<pre><code>decoder := json.NewDecoder(r.Body)
Info.Println(r.Body)
err := decoder.Decode(&amp;geoRec)
</code></pre>

<p>Both <code>Info.Println</code> and <code>decoder.Decode</code> read from request body which is an <code>io.Reader</code>. After the execution of <code>Info.Println</code>, the reader is at <code>EOF</code> state. From this point, any further <code>Read</code> will result in <code>EOF</code> error, the error you saw in your application. If you remove (comment out) <code>Info.Println</code>, you will be able to decode the data to the struct. </p>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong><br>
I forgot and didn't paying attention that JSONP is <code>GET</code> request. The JSON data is embedded in the query. Try the following approach to extract JSON data (please adapt to your need).</p>

<pre><code>//snippet inside recordGeo function
//...

callback := ""
geoRec := geoData{}
queries := r.URL.Query()

//See http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/
//for 'jsonp' data type parameters.
for key, val := range queries {
    if key == "callback" {
        callback = val[0]
    } else if key == "_" {
        //the Timestamp
    } else {
        //JSON data in the key
        dec := json.NewDecoder(bytes.NewBufferString(key))
        err := dec.Decode(&amp;geoRec)
        if err != nil {
            log.Println(err)
        }
        log.Printf("DATA=%#v", geoRec)
    }
}

//...
//do some processing
response := "{YOUR RESPONSE DATA}"
if callback != "" {
    w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/javascript")
    response = fmt.Printf("%s(%s);", callback, response)
}
w.Write([]byte(response))
</code></pre>

<p>If in the client side you set the data as <code>data: pfg</code> (without <code>JSON.stringify</code>), then in the server side, each parameter will be accessible through query parameter: </p>

<pre><code>//
lon := queries.Get("lo")
lat := queries.Get("la")
acc := queries.Get("ac")
</code></pre>

<p>OR, if you set the AJAX request data as <code>data: "mydata=" + JSON.stringify(pfg)</code>, then you can extract the data as:</p>

<pre><code>mydata := queries.Get("mydata")
dec := json.NewDecoder(bytes.NewBufferString(mydata))
err := dec.Decode(&amp;geoRec)
</code></pre>

<p>After processing, you need to send a proper JSONP response to the client, i.e. <code>callback(DATA);</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-07-01T14:35:50.820" LastActivityDate="2017-07-01T14:35:50.820" CommentCount="4" />
