question:
44911902      <row Id="44911902" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44912429" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44911902" CreationDate="2017-07-04T18:46:43.027" Score="2" Body="<p>You don't have to learn these methods and functions by heart, whenever you look for something, check the package documentation. The doc of the package in question can be found here: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/big/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>math/big</code></a>.</p>

<p>As you can see in the doc, there is a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/big/#Rat.SetString" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Rat.SetString()</code></a> method for the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/big/#Rat" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>big.Rat</code></a> type too which you can use for this purpose:</p>

<blockquote>
<pre><code>func (z *Rat) SetString(s string) (*Rat, bool)
</code></pre>
  
  <p>SetString sets z to the value of s and returns z and a boolean indicating success. s can be given as a fraction "a/b" or as a floating-point number optionally followed by an exponent. The entire string (not just a prefix) must be valid for success. If the operation failed, the value of z is un- defined but the returned value is nil.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Example using it:</p>

<pre><code>r := big.NewRat(1, 1)
if _, ok := r.SetString("2023930943509509"); !ok {
    fmt.Println("Failed to parse the string!")
}
fmt.Println(r)
fmt.Println(r.FloatString(2))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/XRr_Hajhui" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>2023930943509509/1
2023930943509509.00
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-07-04T18:46:43.027" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44895747      <row Id="44895747" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44913616" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44895747" CreationDate="2017-07-04T20:26:14.437" Score="1" Body="<p>Let's assume your tree has <code>N</code> nodes on the final (most numerous) row.</p>

<p>If you do store the nodes that are only propagated upwards, your tree has between <code>2*N-1</code> and <code>2*N-1+log2(N)</code> nodes, total. The exact total number of nodes is given by <a href="http://oeis.org/A120511" rel="nofollow noreferrer">OEIS A120511</a>. Of these, at most <code>floor(2 + log2(N-1))</code> are copied/propagated nodes.</p>

<p>The tree has <code>floor(2 + log2(N-1))</code> rows. The number of rows as a function of  <code>N</code> (the number of elements on the final row) is <a href="http://oeis.org/A070941" rel="nofollow noreferrer">OEIS A070941</a>.</p>

<p>The number of rows in such trees is quite low. For example, if you have 2<sup>40</sup>  1,000,000,000,000 nodes in the final row, you only have 42 rows in the tree. For 2<sup>64</sup> nodes, you have just 66. Therefore, if you need some operation per row, it is not a high overhead.</p>

<p>A simple logarithmic-time function can compute the number of rows and the total number of nodes, given the number of nodes in the final row <code>N</code>:</p>

<pre><code># Account for the root node
rows = 1
total = 1

curr_left = N
While (curr_left &gt; 1):
    rows = rows + 1
    total = total + curr_left
    curr_left = (curr_left + 1) / 2
End While
</code></pre>

<p>where <code>/</code> denotes integer division, i.e. any fractional part is discarded/truncated/rounded towards zero. Again, for 2<sup>64</sup> nodes in the final row, the above loops only 65 times.</p>

<p>When we know the total number of nodes in the tree, and the number of rows, we can use another logarithmic-time loop to compute the offset of the first element on each row of the tree, and the number of nodes on that row:</p>

<pre><code>first_offset = []
nodes = []

curr_row = rows - 1
curr_offset = total - N
curr_left = N

While (curr_left &gt; 1):
    nodes[curr_row] = curr_left
    first_offset[curr_row] = curr_offset
    curr_row = curr_row - 1
    curr_left = (curr_left + 1) / 2
    curr_offset = curr_offset - curr_left
}

first_offset[0] = 0
nodes[0] = 1
</code></pre>

<p>As before, for 2<sup>64</sup> nodes in the final row, the above loops only 65 times.</p>

<p>All elements on a row are consecutive in memory, and if we use zero-based indexing, and <code>N</code> is the number of nodes on the final row, and we apply the above, then</p>

<ul>
<li><p><code>rows</code> is the number of rows in the tree</p></li>
<li><p><code>total</code> is the total number of nodes in the tree</p></li>
<li><p>There are <code>nodes[r]</code> nodes on row <code>r</code>, if <code>r &gt;= 0</code> and <code>r &lt; rows</code></p></li>
<li><p>Array index for node on row <code>r</code>, column <code>c</code> is <code>first_offset[r] + c</code></p></li>
<li><p>Node on row <code>r</code>, column <code>c</code>, with <code>r &gt; 0</code>, has a parent on row <code>r-1</code>, column <code>c/2</code>, at array index <code>first_offset[r-1] + c/2</code></p></li>
<li><p>Node on row <code>r</code>, column <code>c</code>, with <code>r &lt; rows - 1</code>, has a left child on row <code>r+1</code>, column <code>2*c</code>, at array index <code>first_offset[r+1] + 2*c</code></p></li>
<li><p>Node on row <code>r</code>, column <code>c</code>, with <code>r &lt; rows - 1</code> and <code>c &lt; nodes[r] - 1</code>, has a right child on row <code>r+1</code>, column <code>2*c+1</code>, at array index <code>first_offset[r+1] + 2*c + 1</code></p></li>
<li><p>Node on row <code>r</code>, column <code>c</code>, with <code>r &lt; rows - 1</code> and <code>c &lt; nodes[r] - 1</code>, has both a left and a right child</p></li>
</ul>

<p>This array is compact, and other than the nodes that get propagated upwards (so, maybe a few dozen nodes for a terabyte-sized dataset), wastes no storage.</p>

<p>If the number of nodes in the final row is stored with the array (for example, as an extra <code>uint64_t</code> following the array data), all readers can recover <code>total</code>, <code>rows</code>, <code>first_offset[]</code>, and <code>nodes[]</code>, and easily navigate the tree. (However, note that instead of just the array index, you use the "column" and "row" instead, and derive the array index using those.)</p>

<p>Because <code>first_offset[]</code> and <code>nodes[]</code> arrays have at most a few dozen entries, they should stay hot in caches, and using them should not harm performance.</p>

<p>Note that not all tree sizes are valid for the rules stated in the second paragraph above. For example, a tree with two nodes makes no sense: why would you duplicate the root node?</p>

<p>If you do know that the tree size (<code>total</code>) is valid, you can find <code>N</code> based on <code>total</code> in <code>O(log2(total)*log2log2(total))</code> time complexity using a binary search, or in <code>O((log2(total)))</code> if you use a simple loop. Remember, <code>total</code> is between <code>2*N-1</code> and <code>2*N-1+log2(N)</code>. Conversely, <code>N</code> cannot be greater than <code>(N + 1)/2</code>, or smaller than <code>(N + 1)/2 - log2(total)</code>, because <code>total</code> is greater than <code>N</code>, and therefore <code>log2(N)</code> is less than <code>log2(total)</code>. So, a binary search could be implemented as</p>

<pre><code>Function Find_N(total):
    Nmax = (total + 1) / 2
    Nmin = Nmax - log2(total)

    t = Total(Nmin)
    If t == total:
        Return Nmin
    Else if t &lt; total:
        Return "Bug!"
    End if

    t = Total(Nmax)
    if t == total:
        Return Nmax
    Else if t &gt; total:
        Return "Bug!"
    End if

    Loop:

        N = (Nmin + Nmax) / 2
        If N == Nmin:
            Return "Invalid tree size!"
        End If

        t = Total(N)
        If t &gt; total:
            Nmax = N
        Else if t &lt; total:
            Nmin = N
        Else:
            return N
        End If            
    End Loop
End Function
</code></pre>

<p>Keep in mind that even with 2<sup>64</sup> nodes in the tree, the above function makes at most <code>1 + log2(64)</code> = 6 calls to <code>Total</code>, a function implementing the first pseudocode snippet in this answer. Since you typically need this only once per program invocation, the overhead is truly irrelevant.</p>

<p>You can calculate <code>log2(x)</code> using <code>log(x)/log(2)</code>, using the <code>log2()</code> function from <code>&lt;math.h&gt;</code> since C99 (but since <code>double</code> has less precision than <code>uint64_t</code>, I would add <code>+1</code> to the result, or round it towards positive infinity using <code>ceil()</code>, just to be sure), or even using a simple loop:</p>

<pre><code>Function ulog2(value):
    result = 0
    While (value &gt; 0):
        result = result + 1
        value = value / 2
    End While
    Return result
End Function
</code></pre>

<p>where once again, <code>/</code> denotes integer division.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1475978" LastEditorUserId="1475978" LastEditDate="2017-07-09T02:40:48.997" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T02:40:48.997" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44911961      <row Id="44911961" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44914055" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44911961" CreationDate="2017-07-04T21:12:58.213" Score="1" Body="<p>First to make things easier:</p>

<p>As far as I can see you do not need a global register for the quit channels. Just create a <code>ch := make(chan bool)</code> in main, pass it to <code>ListenToTable</code> (instead of the whole map of channels) and use it in the select. In main <code>close(ch)</code> it if you want to exit. But as you said, that doesn't solve your problem.</p>

<p>Theoretically you are on the right track with closing the go routine. I took your sample code and made the following runnable code from it:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "time"
)

func main() {

    chClose := make(chan bool)
    channel := make(chan string)

    ListenToTable("somestring", channel, chClose)

    time.Sleep(3 * time.Second)
    chClose &lt;- true
    time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)
}

func ListenToTable(name string, ch chan string, chClose chan bool) {
    go func(name string) {
        for {
            select {
            case &lt;-chClose:
                fmt.Println("QUIT GOROUTINE")
                return  // VERY IMPORTANT: not break!
            default:
            }
        }
    }(name)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The problem must be with something else in you code, probably blocked by something in the <code>default</code> section and not even executing the select. Try printing <code>fmt.Println("something")</code> before the <code>select {</code>. If that is not printed regularly then you have your answer.</p>

<p>One more thing: As commented in the code above you cannot break out of a <code>for { select { ... } }</code> with a single <code>break</code>. You need to use a <code>return</code> (to exit the function) or another tactic (like a break with a label as Adrian suggested in the comments). The <code>break</code> will only exit the <code>select</code>, but not the <code>for</code> loop.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastEditorUserId="6220193" LastEditDate="2017-07-06T08:53:49.780" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T08:53:49.780" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44915201      <row Id="44915201" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44915321" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44915201" CreationDate="2017-07-04T23:54:18.237" Score="2" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>./main.go:40: homePage(db) used as value</p>
</blockquote>

<p>homePage is void function. So you can't use it in function arguments.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>./main.go:50: func literal evaluated but not used</p>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>func homePage(db *sql.DB) {
    func(ctx context.Context) {
        ...
    }
    return ""
}
</code></pre>

<p>This is broken syntax. I suggest you to go <a href="https://tour.golang.org/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tour.golang.org/</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>./main.go:79: too many arguments to return
      have (string)
      want ()</p>
</blockquote>

<p>As I said in above, homePage is void function. So you can't use return with value. Below is code which I could suppose your code should be.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "database/sql"
    "log"

    "github.com/get-ion/ion"
    "github.com/get-ion/ion/context"
    "github.com/get-ion/ion/view"
    _ "github.com/go-sql-driver/mysql"
)

func main() {
    app := ion.New()
    app.RegisterView(view.HTML("./templates", ".html"))

    db, err := sql.Open("mysql", "root:password@/database?charset=utf8&amp;parseTime=true&amp;loc=Local")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatalln(err)
        panic("There was an error handling mysql connection!")
    }
    defer db.Close()

    allRoutes := app.Party("/", logThisMiddleware)
    {
        allRoutes.Get("/", homePage(db))
    }

    //app.Run(ion.Addr(":8080"))
}

func logThisMiddleware(ctx context.Context) {
    ctx.Application().Logger().Infof("Path: %s | IP: %s
", ctx.Path(), ctx.RemoteAddr())
    ctx.Next()
}

func homePage(db *sql.DB) context.Handler {
    return func(ctx context.Context) {
        var (
            id             int
            title          string
            featured_image string
            created_at     string
        )
        rows, err := db.Query("SELECT id, title, featured_image, created_at from blogs order by crated_at desc limit 0,5")
        if err != nil {
            ctx.Application().Logger().Fatalf("MySQL Error fetching row %s
", err)
        }
        defer rows.Close()
        blogData := map[int]map[int]string{}
        for rows.Next() {
            err := rows.Scan(&amp;id, &amp;title, &amp;featured_image, &amp;created_at)
            if err != nil {
                ctx.Application().Logger().Fatalf("Error while fetching row from blog: %s
", err)
            }
            blogData[id][0] = title
            blogData[id][1] = featured_image
            blogData[id][2] = created_at
        }
        err = rows.Err()
        if err != nil {
            ctx.Application().Logger().Fatalf("Error while scanning Row : %s
", err)
        }
        ctx.ViewData("blog", blogData)
        ctx.View("homepage.html")
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="720391" LastEditorUserId="3767643" LastEditDate="2017-07-05T00:21:36.587" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T00:21:36.587" CommentCount="7" />

question:
44921193      <row Id="44921193" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44921845" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44921193" CreationDate="2017-07-05T09:12:53.617" Score="3" Body="<p>It is precision issue of 32bit variable. This is not an issue of Go. See following URLs.</p>

<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_754" rel="nofollow noreferrer">IEEE 754 - Wikipedia</a></p>

<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-precision_floating-point_format" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Single-precision floating-point format - Wikipedia</a></p>

<p>You will understand what happen with 1.59 in this C code.</p>

<pre><code>#include &lt;stdio.h&gt;

int
main(int argc, char* argv[]) {
  float f = 1.59;
  if (f == 1.59) {
    puts("float: equal!");
  } else {
    puts("float: not equal!");
  }

  double d = 1.59;
  if (d == 1.59) {
    puts("double: equal!");
  } else {
    puts("double: not equal!");
  }
  return 0;
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="http://ideone.com/WobYbU" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://ideone.com/WobYbU</a></p>

<p>1.590000033378601 is 1.59 in 32bit variables. So you can use the value with cast to float32. i.e. float32(1.590000033378601)</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "strconv"
)

func main() {
    str := `1.59`
    f64, err := strconv.ParseFloat(str, 32)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println("err: ", err)
    }
    f32 := float32(f64)
    fmt.Printf("%T -&gt; %+v\n", f32, f32)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ml4O8CtjOK" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a></p>

<h1>UPDATE</h1>

<p>On Most of computer, floating point value is stored as following elements.</p>

<ul>
<li>Sign (zero or one)</li>
<li>Significand (Coefficient)</li>
<li>Exponent</li>
</ul>

<p>For example, representations 0.75 is <code>+1.1 x 2^-1</code></p>

<p><code>+</code> is Sign, <code>.1</code> is Significand, <code>-1</code> is Exponent. This is stored like below on 32bit memory space. </p>

<pre><code>Sign                                 Significand
+-+               +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |
  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
      Exponent
</code></pre>

<p>For example, <code>0.75</code> is stored like below</p>

<pre><code>0-01111110-10000000000000000000000

     +- Significand
     |
+ 1[.1] x 2 ^ -1
|         |    |
+- Sign   |    +- Exponent
          |
          +------ Base
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>+ 1.1 x 2^-1 = 1 x 2^0 + 1 x 2^-1 x 2^-1 = 0.75</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Since floating point value is represented as above, it is different between the mathematical value and the computer's value. This is precision issue.</p>
" OwnerUserId="720391" LastEditorUserId="720391" LastEditDate="2017-07-05T10:12:55.660" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T10:12:55.660" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44923323      <row Id="44923323" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44924219" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44923323" CreationDate="2017-07-05T10:51:52.517" Score="1" Body="<p>You can DRY it using closures:</p>

<pre><code>func GetUser2(i int, s string) (*User, error) {
    var u *User
    err := do(func() error {
        var err error
        u, err = getUser(i, s)
        return err
    })
    return u, err
}

func CheckUser2(i int) (bool, error) {
    var b bool
    err := do(func() error {
        var err error
        b, err = checkUser(i)
        return err
    })
    return b, err
}

func do(f func() error) error {
    CommonMethod1()
    CommonMethod2()

    err := f()
    if err != nil {
        CommonMethod3()
    }
    return err
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1892060" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T10:51:52.517" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44921623      <row Id="44921623" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44925130" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44921623" CreationDate="2017-07-05T11:34:54.250" Score="1" Body="<p>The methods are defined in a big generated file that is not indexed by Gogland. To change the limit you should change <a href="https://intellij-support.jetbrains.com/hc/en-us/articles/206544869-Configuring-JVM-options-and-platform-properties" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>idea.max.intellisense.filesize</code></a>.</p>

<p>To do this, open custom properties file via <code>Help | Edit Custom Properties</code> menu and add something like this: <code>idea.max.intellisense.filesize=4500</code> for 4.5 MB limit. The size is in Kilobytes.</p>

<p>Please use carefully, indexing large files may influence index update speed dramatically.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5462132" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T11:34:54.250" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44932806      <row Id="44932806" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44933147" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44932806" CreationDate="2017-07-05T18:05:42.717" Score="1" Body="<p>The error message indicates that <code>ClientID</code> is not initialized.</p>

<p>That looks consistent with the code, since <code>var</code> declarations are executed before the <code>init</code> functions.</p>

<p>So when your <code>var</code> requests <code>os.Getenv("CLIENT_ID")</code> the value is blank since <code>init</code> has not executed yet.</p>

<p>From the documentation:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A package with no imports is initialized by assigning initial values to all its package-level variables followed by calling all init functions in the order they appear in the source, possibly in multiple files, as presented to the compiler</p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Package_initialization" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/ref/spec#Package_initialization</a></p>

<p>To fix this, either put the string directly in the <code>var</code> initialization, or trigger the initialization from the <code>init</code> after you set the values.</p>

<p>Like:</p>

<pre><code>var (
    googleOauthConfig *oauth2.Config
)

func init() {
     // init ENV
     // initialize the variable using ENV values
     googleOauthConfig = &amp;oauth2.Config{ ... }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Alternatively, you can set those <code>ENV</code> values at the OS level before executing the actual Go program. </p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-07-05T19:02:20.680" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T19:02:20.680" CommentCount="7" />

question:
44933295      <row Id="44933295" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44933584" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44933295" CreationDate="2017-07-05T18:32:48.720" Score="2" Body="<p>The common idiom is to have a <code>Done</code> channel shared between the calling code and the goroutines.</p>

<p>Then each goroutine would check that channel via a <code>select</code> each time they 
send a new value to the calling code.</p>

<p>You can find a good example in Go's blog:</p>

<p><a href="https://blog.golang.org/pipelines" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/pipelines</a></p>

<p>(look for "Explicit Cancellation" there)</p>

<p>Later, they incorporated a <code>context</code> package to the standard library, and that is now the most "standard" way to manage cancellation of goroutines.</p>

<p>You can find a good example in the documentation for the package itself:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/context/#example_WithCancel" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/context/#example_WithCancel</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T18:32:48.720" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44933674      <row Id="44933674" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44933956" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44933674" CreationDate="2017-07-05T18:54:09.203" Score="1" Body="<p>If it works then it's not wrong, but it doesn't validate much, only that the response body is non-empty - not even that it's successful. I'm not sure why it prints out <code>http.StatusOK</code>, which is a constant, and doesn't tell you what the status code in the response was.</p>

<p>Personally when I do this level of test I check, at the very least, that the response code is as expected, the response body unmarshals correctly (if it's JSON or XML), the response data is basically sane, etc. For more complex payloads I might use a <a href="http://jonnyreeves.co.uk/2016/integration-testing-with-golden-masters/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">golden file</a> test. For critical code I might use a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzing" rel="nofollow noreferrer">fuzz (aka monte carlo) test</a>. For performance-critical code I'll likely add benchmarks and load tests. There are practically infinite ways to test code. You'll have to figure out what your needs are and how to meet them.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T18:54:09.203" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44928032      <row Id="44928032" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44933965" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44928032" CreationDate="2017-07-05T18:54:37.107" Score="0" Body="<p>You need to <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/jinzhu/gorm#DB.Preload" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Preload</a> the resources field before querying for services:</p>

<pre><code>services := []model.Service{}
db.Preload("Resources").Find(&amp;services) // error checking ommited
</code></pre>

<p>This correctly populates the <code>Resources</code> field of every service.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4322228" LastEditorUserId="4322228" LastEditDate="2017-07-05T19:00:51.443" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T19:00:51.443" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44934457      <row Id="44934457" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44934634" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44934457" CreationDate="2017-07-05T19:37:33.423" Score="1" Body="<p>To access your struct field on template, it must be exported fields. Update your struct to-</p>

<pre><code>type blogs struct {
    ID             int
    Title          string
    Featured_image string
    Created_at     string
}
</code></pre>

<p>Read more about <a href="https://www.goinggo.net/2014/03/exportedunexported-identifiers-in-go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Exported/Unexported Identifiers In Go</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-05T19:46:47.987" LastActivityDate="2017-07-05T19:46:47.987" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44937567      <row Id="44937567" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44938501" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44937567" CreationDate="2017-07-06T01:43:13.623" Score="1" Body="<p>No real workaround there, that's the nature of the beast.</p>

<p>The language was designed after struggling with C++ for some time, and the idea of the creators was simplifying all non-vital things but at the same time make key additions to make the language more expressive.</p>

<p>You can read a bit about their reasoning here, which I believe is quite interesting even if you don't agree with all the decisions they made:</p>

<p><a href="https://commandcenter.blogspot.com.ar/2012/06/less-is-exponentially-more.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://commandcenter.blogspot.com.ar/2012/06/less-is-exponentially-more.html</a></p>

<p>In your example, if you wanted to, you could make your maps and functions use <code>interface{}</code> (which by the way is called the empty interface and not "nil" interface).</p>

<p>But of course you would lose compile-time type checking and would have to add casts all around.</p>

<p>You can also try to find an interface to express the commonalities of the types you want to use (which might not be so easy or even possible at all), and then build your mapping API around that interface.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T01:43:13.623" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44938050      <row Id="44938050" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44938513" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44938050" CreationDate="2017-07-06T01:45:22.647" Score="0" Body="<p>I'm slightly confused by your question, but think you're trying to do the following:</p>

<pre><code>replace      printf("yada yada yada") with println("yada yada yada")
not replace  printf("print speed = %d", speed)
</code></pre>

<p>If that is the case, I would do something like the following:</p>

<pre><code>sed -i '/Printf(\".*\")/ s/Printf/Println/g' *.go
</code></pre>

<p>That should leave cases intact where you actually want to use formatting. Here is an example:</p>

<pre><code>[sborza@msandn]:~$ cat tester.go
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
        speed = 1
        fmt.Printf("vim-go")
        fmt.Printf("speed = %d\n", speed)
}

[sborza@msandn]:~$ sed '/Printf(\".*\")/ s/Printf/Println/g' tester.go
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
        speed = 1
        fmt.Println("vim-go")
        fmt.Printf("speed = %d\n", speed)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8092543" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T01:45:22.647" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44934156      <row Id="44934156" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44938834" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44934156" CreationDate="2017-07-06T02:25:27.747" Score="0" Body="<p>In golang, there is only one iteration construct and that's the for loop. There are multiple ways to configure the for loop itself, but overall there is just the single construct:</p>

<p><a href="https://tour.golang.org/flowcontrol/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tour.golang.org/flowcontrol/1</a></p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/wBSGJqHuLK" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/wBSGJqHuLK</a></p>

<pre><code>The C method -- for i := 0; i &lt; 10; i++ { }
The python method -- for k, v := range map[string]string{"key": "val"} { }
The python method -- for idx, val := range []string{"one", "two"} { }
The empty for -- for { }
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8092543" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T02:25:27.747" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44939881      <row Id="44939881" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44940030" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44939881" CreationDate="2017-07-06T04:50:23.030" Score="3" Body="<p>The <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/#Sqrt" rel="nofollow noreferrer">math.Sqrt</a> function signature:</p>

<pre><code>func Sqrt(x float64) float64
</code></pre>

<p>requires that you pass <code>float64</code></p>

<p>In this case:</p>

<pre><code>var f float64 = math.Sqrt(float64(x*x + y*y))
</code></pre>

<p>You are converting to <code>float64</code> directly</p>

<p>In this case:</p>

<pre><code>var f = math.Sqrt(x*x + y*y)
</code></pre>

<p>you are passing an <code>int</code>, when <code>float64</code> is required.</p>

<p>In this case:</p>

<pre><code>var f = math.Sqrt(9 + 16)
</code></pre>

<p>The compiler is able to infer the type, and pass <code>float64</code> for you.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1078084" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T04:50:23.030" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44940822      <row Id="44940822" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44940966" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44940822" CreationDate="2017-07-06T06:07:06.880" Score="3" Body="<p>No, there isn't any better way than looping. Not only is it cleaner than any other approach, it's also the fastest.</p>

<pre><code>values := []int{4, 20, 0, -11, -10}

min := values[0]
for _, v := range values {
        if (v &lt; min) {
            min = v
        }
}

fmt.Println(min)
</code></pre>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong></p>

<p>Since there has been some discussion in the comments about error handling and how to handle empty slices, here is a basic function that determines the minimum value. Remember to import <code>errors</code>.</p>

<pre><code>func Min(values []int) (min int, e error) {
    if len(values) == 0 {
        return 0, errors.New("Cannot detect a minimum value in an empty slice")
    }

    min = values[0]
    for _, v := range values {
            if (v &lt; min) {
                min = v
            }
    }

    return min, nil
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2329663" LastEditorUserId="2329663" LastEditDate="2017-07-06T07:02:48.830" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T07:02:48.830" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44944959      <row Id="44944959" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44944960" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44944959" CreationDate="2017-07-06T09:28:02.463" Score="3" Body="<p>As far as I can find there is no simple check for this, but when <code>-race</code> is enabled the <code>race</code> <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/go/build/#hdr-Build_Constraints" rel="nofollow noreferrer">build tag</a> is set, so you can take advantage of that.</p>

<p>I made a new directory <code>israce</code>, and put two files there:</p>

<p><code>israce/race.go</code>:</p>

<pre><code>// +build race

// Package israce reports if the Go race detector is enabled.
package israce

// Enabled reports if the race detector is enabled.
const Enabled = true
</code></pre>

<p><code>israce/norace.go</code>:</p>

<pre><code>// +build !race

// Package israce reports if the Go race detector is enabled.
package israce

// Enabled reports if the race detector is enabled.
const Enabled = false
</code></pre>

<p>Due to the build tag only one of the two files will get compiled.</p>

<p>As far as I've been able to find this is the easiest way.</p>
" OwnerUserId="660921" LastEditorUserId="660921" LastEditDate="2017-07-07T07:31:50.177" LastActivityDate="2017-07-07T07:31:50.177" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44949467      <row Id="44949467" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44950096" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44949467" CreationDate="2017-07-06T13:17:56.060" Score="2" Body="<p>It's good practice to keep the mutex close to the data it destined to protect. If a mutex ought to protect concurrent access to fields of a struct value, it's very convenient to add the mutex as a field of that struct, so its purpose is obvious.</p>

<p>If in your app there is only a single "instance" of <code>A</code>, it's fine to make the mutex a global variable too.</p>

<p>If your app is to create multiple values of <code>A</code>, all of which needs to be protected from concurrent access (but only individually, multiple values may be accessed concurrently), then obviously a global mutex is a bad choice, it would limit the concurrent access to a single value of <code>A</code> in any point in time.</p>

<p>Adding the mutex to the struct as a field, you will <em>naturally</em> have a separate mutex for each distinct struct values, responsible to guard that single, containing struct value (or its fields).</p>

<p>Although adding a mutex as in your example is not embedding, it's a regular, named field. An <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Struct_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">embedded field declaration</a> omits the field name.</p>

<p>It's known and used to a lesser extent, but it's also handy that you can "truly" embed a mutex in a struct, and you can call <code>Lock()</code> and <code>Unlock()</code> as if they would be part of the struct itself. It looks like this:</p>

<pre><code>var hits struct {
    sync.Mutex
    n int
}

hits.Lock()
hits.n++
hits.Unlock()
</code></pre>

<p>(This example is taken from <a href="https://talks.golang.org/2012/10things.slide#3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">10 things you (probably) don't know about Go, slide #3</a>.)</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-06T17:39:38.017" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T17:39:38.017" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44954705      <row Id="44954705" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44955022" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44954705" CreationDate="2017-07-06T17:02:12.227" Score="3" Body="<p>Use the <a href="http://www.gorillatoolkit.org/pkg/mux#Router.Walk" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Walk</code></a> method:</p>

<pre><code>router.Walk(func(route *mux.Route, router *mux.Router, ancestors []*mux.Route) error {
    tpl, err1 := route.GetPathTemplate()
    met, err2 := route.GetMethods()
    fmt.Println(tpl, err1, met, err2)
    return nil
})
</code></pre>

<p>Alternatively, you can just put all your routes into a slice of structs and just do</p>

<pre><code>for _, r := range routes {
    router.HandleFunc(r.tpl, r.func).Methods(r.methods...)
}
</code></pre>

<p>on the initialisation step.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1892060" LastEditorUserId="1892060" LastEditDate="2017-07-06T17:15:53.820" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T17:15:53.820" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44956031      <row Id="44956031" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44956924" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44956031" CreationDate="2017-07-06T18:59:29.403" Score="1" Body="<p>Yes there are a few different ways to go about it.. Here's an example that can be optimized.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

func intersection(a []string, b []string) (inter []string) {
    // interacting on the smallest list first can potentailly be faster...but not by much, worse case is the same
    low, high := a, b
    if len(a) &gt; len(b) {
        low = b
        high = a
    }

    done := false
    for i, l := range low {
        for j, h := range high {
            // get future index values
            f1 := i + 1
            f2 := j + 1
            if l == h {
                inter = append(inter, h)
                if f1 &lt; len(low) &amp;&amp; f2 &lt; len(high) {
                    // if the future values aren't the same then that's the end of the intersection
                    if low[f1] != high[f2] {
                        done = true
                    }
                }
                // we don't want to interate on the entire list everytime, so remove the parts we already looped on will make it faster each pass
                high = high[:j+copy(high[j:], high[j+1:])]
                break
            }
        }
        // nothing in the future so we are done
        if done {
            break
        }
    }
    return
}

func main() {
    slice1 := []string{"foo", "bar", "hello", "bar"}
    slice2 := []string{"foo", "bar"}
    fmt.Printf("%+v\n", intersection(slice1, slice2))
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now the intersection method defined above will only operate on <code>slices</code> of <code>strings</code>, like your example.. You can in theory create a definition that looks like this <code>func intersection(a []interface, b []interface) (inter []interface)</code>, however you would be relying on reflection and type casting so that you can compare, which will add latency and make your code harder to read. It's probably easier to maintain and read to write a separate function for each type you care about.</p>

<p><code>func intersectionString(a []string, b []string) (inter []string)</code>,</p>

<p><code>func intersectionInt(a []int, b []int) (inter []int)</code>,</p>

<p><code>func intersectionFloat64(a []Float64, b []Float64) (inter []Float64)</code>, ..ect</p>

<p>You can then create your own package and reuse once you settle how you want to implement it.</p>

<pre><code>package intersection

func String(a []string, b []string) (inter []string)

func Int(a []int, b []int) (inter []int)

func Float64(a []Float64, b []Float64) (inter []Float64)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4639336" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T18:59:29.403" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44957724      <row Id="44957724" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44957799" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44957724" CreationDate="2017-07-06T19:56:28.720" Score="2" Body="<p>The <code>ListObjects</code> calls return a <code>[]Object</code> for the actual object list in the result, and <code>Object</code> does not include the expiration. However, <code>GetObject</code> returns <a href="http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-go/api/service/s3/#GetObjectOutput" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>GetObjectOutput</code></a> which does have an <code>Expiration</code> field. So you could iterate your returned <code>Object</code>s and get the expiration for each, though this could be time-consuming if there are many of them.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-06T19:56:28.720" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44960183      <row Id="44960183" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44960557" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44960183" CreationDate="2017-07-06T23:57:09.673" Score="1" Body="<p><strong>EDIT:</strong> After comment interaction. </p>

<p>Yes you can. Let's say</p>

<p>XML:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;series&gt;
    &lt;value&gt;123456&lt;/value&gt;
&lt;/series&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Struct definition:</p>

<pre><code>type FloatHolder struct {
    Value float32 `xml:",chardata"`
}

type pv struct {
    XMLName xml.Name    `xml:"series"`
    Test2   FloatHolder `xml:"value"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Go Playground link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/9sWQaw0HlS" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/9sWQaw0HlS</a></p>

<hr>

<p>Actually it's not a nested field, as per your XML. It belongs to <code>series</code> element.</p>

<p>Update your struct to following:</p>

<pre><code>type pv struct {
    XMLName xml.Name    `xml:"series"`
    Test1   float32     `xml:"value"`
    Test2   FloatHolder `xml:"nested"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Go Playground Link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/-mWrUMJXxX" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/-mWrUMJXxX</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-07T04:55:31.487" LastActivityDate="2017-07-07T04:55:31.487" CommentCount="5" />

<row Id="44964773" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44964648" CreationDate="2017-07-07T07:17:06.943" Score="2" Body="<p>You have problem with your struct definition. You need use Exported identifier, like-</p>

question:
44970723      <row Id="44970723" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44971508" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44970723" CreationDate="2017-07-07T13:04:42.387" Score="2" Body="<p>Here are the issues I spotted in the code, and below a working version based on your implementation.</p>

<ul>
<li><p>If a goroutine tries to write to an "unbuffered" channel, it will block until someone reads from it. Since you are not reading until they finish writing to the channel, you have a deadlock there.</p></li>
<li><p>Closing the channel while they are blocked breaks the deadlock, but gives an error since they now can't write to a closed channel.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>Solution involves:</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Creating a buffered channel so that they can write without blocking.</p></li>
<li><p>Using a <code>sync.WaitGroup</code> so that you wait for the goroutines to finish before closing the channel.</p></li>
<li><p>Reading from the channel at the end, when all is done.</p></li>
</ul>

<p>See here, with comments:</p>

<pre><code>    package main

    import (
        "fmt"
        "time"
        "sync"
    )

    func addCount(num int, counter chan&lt;- int, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
        // clear one from the sync group
        defer wg.Done()
        time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
        counter &lt;- num * 2
    }

    func main() {
        int_slice := []int{2, 4}
        // make the slice buffered using the slice size, so that they can write without blocking
        counter := make(chan int, len(int_slice))

        var wg sync.WaitGroup

        for _, item := range int_slice {
            // add one to the sync group, to mark we should wait for one more
            wg.Add(1)
            go addCount(item, counter, &amp;wg)
        }

        // wait for all goroutines to end
        wg.Wait()

        // close the channel so that we not longer expect writes to it
        close(counter)

        // read remaining values in the channel
        for item := range counter {
            fmt.Println(item)
        }

    }
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-07T13:04:42.387" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44601971      <row Id="44601971" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44972334" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44601971" CreationDate="2017-07-07T13:42:34.977" Score="0" Body="<p>I found an solution with some help of the developers at GitHub. </p>

<p>You may see the processing of the config in the following way, similar to an if statement with AND and OR declarations. </p>

<p>Alertmanager applies the config to a up-down, left-right principle. Where the up-down is similar to the OR statement you will use in a regular if statement. </p>

<p>When you're going from left to right, you could compare it with the AND statement in if commands.</p>

<p>Further you should keep in mind that when the first statement matches, and there are no 'AND' parts declared, alertmanager pushes the alert to the receiver without looking further for any other match. So in the example above, if prometheus fires an alert with the following labels {severity: "warning", application: "barfoo"}, the alert is sent to hipchat-teamX.</p>

<p>Note the following, the label value of application matches the route for hipchat-teamY. So why it isn't sent to that route? The answer is not that diffucult, it's because the first one matches, and there are no subroutes declared, so it will stop looking for any other match. </p>

<p>However, if the alertmanager has config like the code below, the alert will be sent to the receiver 'hipchat-teamY'.</p>

<pre><code>routes:

match:
  severity:"warning"
receiver: "hipchat-teamX"

  routes:
  match_re:
    application:"(barfoo.*)"
  receiver: "hipchat-teamY"

match_re:
  application:"(foo|bar)"
receiver: "hipchat-teamX"

match_re:
  application:"(barfoo.*)"
receiver: "hipchat-teamY"
</code></pre>

<p>To make it a bit more advanced, asume prometheus sends a new alert with the following labels {severity: "critical", application: "barfoo"}. With the following config, the alert is routed to hipchat-teamX.</p>

<p>And with the labels {severity: "critical", application: "foo"}, the alert is sent to hipchat-teamY.</p>

<pre><code>routes:

match:
  severity:"warning"
receiver: "hipchat-teamX"

  routes:
  match_re:
    application:"(barfoo.*)"
  receiver: "hipchat-teamY"

  match_re:
    application:"(foo|bar)"
  receiver: "hipchat-teamX"

match:
  severity:"critical"
receiver: "hipchat-teamY"

  routes: 
  match_re:
    application:"(barfoo.*)"
  receiver: "hipchat-teamX"

  match_re:
    application:"(foo|bar)"
  receiver: "hipchat-teamY"
</code></pre>

<p>I hope this explanation will help others who are experiencing the same issue or question.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8026626" LastActivityDate="2017-07-07T13:42:34.977" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44976862      <row Id="44976862" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44976881" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44976862" CreationDate="2017-07-07T17:49:25.897" Score="2" Body="<p>It assigns a nil pointer to a concrete type to a variable of the interface type. This is a common practice to prove that the concrete type fulfills the interface - if it doesn't, that line won't compile, giving an error that the concrete type can't be assigned to a variable of the interface type and why.</p>

<p>As @JimB noted, "interface assertion" is a term made up by the author. Go has no such term. This is, specifically, a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Conversions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">type conversion</a>, converting <code>nil</code> to a pointer to <code>tmLogger</code>, then assigning the typed nil pointer to a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Blank_identifier" rel="nofollow noreferrer">blank identifier</a> variable of the interface type <code>Logger</code>. If <code>*tmLogger</code> does not satisfy <code>Logger</code>, the assignment won't compile; but, at runtime, this takes no memory because it's using a nil value.</p>

<p>Presumably the author uses this term more in the unit-testing sense of "assertion" than the "type assertion" sense - that line of code asserts that the type implements the interface, and if it doesn't, the line will fail.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-07-07T18:00:49.443" LastActivityDate="2017-07-07T18:00:49.443" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44979276      <row Id="44979276" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44979550" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44979276" CreationDate="2017-07-07T21:01:19.603" Score="1" Body="<p>First a little about the "template" concept:</p>

<p>A <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/#Template" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>template.Template</code></a> value is <em>"the representation of a parsed template"</em>. But the wording here is a little "imperfect". A <code>template.Template</code> value may be (and usually is) a <em>collection of multiple, associated templates</em>. <code>template.Template</code> has an unexported field:</p>

<pre><code>tmpl   map[string]*Template // Map from name to defined templates.
</code></pre>

<p>This <code>tmpl</code> field holds all other associated templates, templates that are visible to the template, and which can be referred to by their names.</p>

<p>You can read more about this in this answer: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41176355/go-template-name/41187671#41187671">Go template name</a></p>

<p>Back to the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/#Template.ParseFiles" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Template.ParseFiles()</code></a> method. This method parses multiple templates from the files passed to it as parameters. The templates parsed form the files will be named after the file names (without folders, just the file name), and they will be added to the internal, associated templates map of the <code>t</code> template designated by the method receiver.</p>

<p>The parsed templates will not be appended. Multiple, separate <code>template.Template</code> values will be created for them, but they will be associated (so they can refer to each other, e.g. they can include each other).</p>

<p>Let's see an example. Let's assume we have these 2 template files:</p>

<p><code>a.html</code> is:</p>

<pre><code>I'm a.
</code></pre>

<p>And <code>b.html</code>:</p>

<pre><code>I'm b.
</code></pre>

<p>And an example code:</p>

<pre><code>t := template.New("a.html")
if _, err := t.ParseFiles("a.html", "b.html"); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
if err := t.Execute(os.Stdout, nil); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>This example creates a new, empty template named <code>a.html</code>, then parses 2 files: <code>a.html</code> and <code>b.html</code>.</p>

<p>What will be the result? <code>t</code> will denote the <code>a.html</code> template, because we created it prior with that specific name. Running the code, the output will be:</p>

<pre><code>I'm a.
</code></pre>

<p>Now if we change the first line to:</p>

<pre><code>t := template.New("x.html")
</code></pre>

<p>And leave the rest unchanged, running it we see something similar:</p>

<pre><code>panic: template: "x.html" is an incomplete or empty template
</code></pre>

<p>The reason is that <code>t</code> denotes a template named <code>x.html</code> but it's empty, as we didn't parse anything "into" it, and the parsed files also didn't match the name <code>x.html</code>. So attempting to execute it results in an error.</p>

<p>Now if we try to execute one of its associated, named template:</p>

<pre><code>if err := t.ExecuteTemplate(os.Stdout, "a.html", nil); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>It succeeds, and again gives:</p>

<pre><code>I'm a.
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-07T22:42:33.800" LastActivityDate="2017-07-07T22:42:33.800" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44980906      <row Id="44980906" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44981208" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44980906" CreationDate="2017-07-08T00:05:08.847" Score="1" Body="<p><code>Improving speed?</code> this is subjective one; depends on many factors such as server uplink, client uplink, etc.</p>

<p><strong>Instead, I will provide my inputs to improve your code snippets:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Let's start with <code>sync.WaitGroup</code> - I do not see a benefit as per your code flow, you just create and wait for goroutine to complete. Instead use without WaitGroup. <code>Tip:</code> Do not use feature for sake/buzz; use it when needed.</li>
<li>Do not create multiple <code>bytes.Buffer</code> and <code>Reader</code>, when you can accomplish without it. For e.g. getting fileSize after the resize, just do <code>buf.Len()</code>.</li>
<li>If you want to offload the AWS upload then extract upload code part into separate <code>func</code> and call it as goroutine.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>I have updated your code snippet (I have not tested your code, so please fix/improve it as required):</strong></p>

<pre><code>func UploadStreamImage(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    file, handler, err := r.FormFile("file")
    if err != nil {
        log_errors(" error on upload", err.Error(), w)
        fmt.Println("Error Uploading Image")
        return
    }
    defer file.Close()

    // Suggestion: You can calculate the file size from bytes.
    // instead getting it from form; since after resize image will change
    imgSize, err := strconv.Atoi(r.FormValue("imgsize"))
    if err != nil {
        println("Error converting to integer")
        log_errors("Error converting to integer", err.Error(), w)
        return
    }

    img, err := imaging.Decode(file)
    if err != nil {
        print("Imaging Open error")
        log_errors("Error decoding", err.Error(), w)
        return
    }

    b := img.Bounds()
    heightImg := b.Max.Y
    widthImg := b.Max.X

    // resize image
    height := int(float64(heightImg) * .23)
    width := int(float64(widthImg) * .23)

    if imgSize &lt; 401 {
        height = int(float64(heightImg) * 1)
        width = int(float64(widthImg) * 1)

    } else if imgSize &gt;= 401 &amp;&amp; imgSize &lt; 900 {
        height = int(float64(heightImg) * .68)
        width = int(float64(widthImg) * .68)
        println("Middle Image")
    } else if imgSize &gt;= 900 &amp;&amp; imgSize &lt; 1300 {
        height = int(float64(heightImg) * .45)
        width = int(float64(widthImg) * .45)
    } else if imgSize &gt;= 1301 &amp;&amp; imgSize &lt; 1700 {
        height = int(float64(heightImg) * .40)
        width = int(float64(widthImg) * .40)
    }

    new_img := imaging.Resize(img, width, height, imaging.Lanczos)
    // end resize

    var buf bytes.Buffer
    err = imaging.Encode(&amp;buf, new_img, imaging.JPEG)
    if err != nil {
        log.Println(err)
        log_errors(" error encoding file", err.Error(), w)
        return
    }

    fileType := http.DetectContentType(buf.Bytes())
    fileSize := buf.Len()
    path := handler.Filename
    params := &amp;s3.PutObjectInput{
        Bucket: aws.String("bucket name"),
        Key:    aws.String(path),
        Body:   bytes.NewReader(buf.Bytes()),

        ContentLength: aws.Int64(fileSize),
        ContentType:   aws.String(fileType),
    }

    resp, err := svc.PutObject(params)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Printf("bad response: %s", err)
        log_errors("error in putObject", err.Error(), w)
        return
    }

    fmt.Println("Done", resp)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T00:05:08.847" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44980953      <row Id="44980953" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44981225" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44980953" CreationDate="2017-07-08T00:08:08.873" Score="0" Body="<p>Yes, you should create a temporary array to Unmarshal the contents of each JSON, then append the items to your final result array in order to return the whole collection as one item.</p>

<p>See here an example of doing that.</p>

<p>In your case <code>input</code> would come from each of the S3 files you mention. Also, you would probably put that unmarshal logic in its own function to be able to call it for each input JSON.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "log"
)

type Record struct {
    Author string `json:"author"`
    Title  string `json:"title"`
}

func main() {
    var allRecords []Record

    input := []byte(`[{
      "author": "Nirvana",
      "title":  "Smells like teen spirit"
    }, {
      "author": "The Beatles",
      "title":  "Help"
    }]`)

    var tmpRecords []Record
    err := json.Unmarshal(input, &amp;tmpRecords)
    if (err != nil) {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    allRecords = append(allRecords, tmpRecords...)  

    fmt.Println("RECORDS:", allRecords)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ZZGhy4UNhP" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/ZZGhy4UNhP</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-07-08T00:16:47.237" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T00:16:47.237" CommentCount="2" />

question:
43748751      <row Id="43748751" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44981367" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="43748751" CreationDate="2017-07-08T00:31:29.197" Score="4" Body="<p>In the case of a REST API, you'll typically deal with at least three different implementation layers:</p>

<ul>
<li>HTTP handler</li>
<li>some sort of business logic/use case</li>
<li>persistent storage/database interface</li>
</ul>

<p>You can treat and build each of these separately which does not only decouple it but makes it just a lot more testable, too. These parts then are put together by injecting the necessary bits since they conform to interfaces you define. Usually this ends up leaving the <code>main</code> or a separate configuration mechanism the only place that's aware of <em>what</em> is combined and injected <em>how</em>.</p>

<p>The article <a href="http://manuel.kiessling.net/2012/09/28/applying-the-clean-architecture-to-go-applications" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Applying The Clean Architecture to Go applications</a> illustrates very well how the various parts can be separated. How strictly you should follow this approach depends a little on the complexity of your project.</p>

<p>Below is a very basic breakdown, separating the handler from logic and database layer.</p>

<h2>HTTP handler</h2>

<p>The handler does nothing else than mapping the request values into local variables or possibly custom data structures if needed. In addition to that it just runs the use case logic and maps the result before writing it to the response. This is also a good place to map different errors to different response objects.</p>

<pre><code>type Interactor interface {
    Bar(foo string) ([]usecases.Bar, error)
}

type MyHandler struct {
    Interactor Interactor
}

func (handler MyHandler) Bar(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    foo := r.FormValue("foo")
    res, _ := handler.Interactor.Bar(foo)

    // you may want to map/cast res to a different type that is encoded
    // according to your spec
    json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(res)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Unit tests are a great way to test that the HTTP response contains the correct data for different results and errors.</p>

<h2>Use case / business logic</h2>

<p>Since the repository is just specified as an interface it's very easy to create unit tests for the business logic with different results returned by a mock repository implementation that also conforms to <code>DataRepository</code>.</p>

<pre><code>type DataRepository interface {
    Find(f string) (Bar, error)
}

type Bar struct {
    Identifier string
    FooBar     int
}

type Interactor struct {
    DataRepository DataRepository
}

func (interactor *Interactor) Bar(f string) (Bar, error) {
    b := interactor.DataRepository.Find(f)

    // ... custom logic

    return b
}   
</code></pre>

<h2>Database interface</h2>

<p>The part talking to the database implements the <code>DataRepository</code> interface but is otherwise totally independent on how it turns the data into the expected types.</p>

<pre><code>type Repo {
    db sql.DB
}

func NewDatabaseRepo(db sql.DB) *Repo {
    // config if necessary...

    return &amp;Repo{db: db}
}

func (r Repo)Find(f string) (usecases.Bar, error) {
    rows, err := db.Query("SELECT id, foo_bar FROM bar WHERE foo=?", f)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    defer rows.Close()

    for rows.Next() {
        var id string, fooBar int
        if err := rows.Scan(&amp;id, &amp;fooBar); err != nil {
            log.Fatal(err)
        }
        // map row value to desired structure
        return usecases.Bar{Identifier: id, FooBar: fooBar}
    }

    return errors.New("not found")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Again, this allows testing the database operations separately without the need of any mock SQL statements.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><strong>Note:</strong> The code above is very much pseudo code and incomplete.</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="486998" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T00:31:29.197" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44980688      <row Id="44980688" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44983360" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44980688" CreationDate="2017-07-08T06:45:32.713" Score="1" Body="<p>There are probably many ways to approach this. Here's one.</p>

<p>Bleve indexes documents which are collections of key/value metadata pairs. </p>

<p>In your case, a document could be represented by 2 key/value pairs: name of .xml file (to uniquely identify the document) and content of the file.</p>

<pre><code>type Doc struct {
    Name string
    Body string
}
</code></pre>

<p>The issue is that body is XML and Bleve doesn't support XML out-of-the-box.</p>

<p>A way to address it would be to pre-process XML file by stripping unwanted tags and content. You can do it using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">encoding/xml</a> standard library.</p>

<p>For an example of a similar task you can see the code of <a href="https://github.com/blevesearch/fosdem-search/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/blevesearch/fosdem-search/</a></p>

<p>In there they index file in custom format (<a href="https://github.com/blevesearch/fosdem-search/blob/master/fosdem.ical" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/blevesearch/fosdem-search/blob/master/fosdem.ical</a>) by parsing it into a format they can submit to Bleve for indexing (<a href="https://github.com/blevesearch/fosdem-search/blob/master/ical.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/blevesearch/fosdem-search/blob/master/ical.go</a>).</p>
" OwnerUserId="2898" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T06:45:32.713" CommentCount="0" />

Here is a fixed version <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/KNLS0y8xLg" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/KNLS0y8xLg</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="7331997" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T14:56:17.460" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44988903      <row Id="44988903" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44989457" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44988903" CreationDate="2017-07-08T18:25:11.027" Score="1" Body="<p>This appears to be a bug in Cloud SDK which is affecting <code>dev_appserver.py</code> when using with <code>App Engine Managed VMs</code>. It does not seem to be affecting App Engine Standard or App Engine Flex environments.</p>

<p>Until Google releases a new Cloud SDK with the fix, you can modify the <code>CLOUD_SDK_INSTALL_DIR//platform/google_appengine/google/appengine/tools/devappserver2/go_managedvm.py</code> file locally as shown below (added both the patchable unified diff as well as before/after just for convenience).</p>

<p>Also consider moving to App Engine Flex since <a href="https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/flexible/go/upgrading" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Managed VMs are deprecated and will not be supported after October 27, 2017</a>.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><strong>Warning</strong>: The Managed VMs beta environment (applications deployed with
  <code>vm:true</code>) is deprecated and will be decommissioned. This page is for
  users who are already using the flexible environment with <code>vm:true</code> in
  their <code>app.yaml</code> and want to upgrade to the latest release. If you are
  updating your application from the standard environment, see the
  <a href="https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/flexible/go/migrating" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Migrating Services from the Standard Environment to the Flexible
  Environment instead</a>.</p>
</blockquote>

<h2>Diff in patchable format</h2>

<pre><code>--- /Users/tuxdude/google-cloud-sdk-orig/platform/google_appengine/google/appengine/tools/devappserver2go_managedvm.py     2017-07-08 11:11:11.000000000 -0700
+++ /Users/tuxdude/google-cloud-sdk/platform/google_appengine/google/appengine/tools/devappserver2/go_managedvm.py      2017-07-08 11:11:11.000000000 -0700
@@ -152,15 +152,9 @@
     logging.debug('Build succeeded:\n%s\n%s', stdout, stderr)
     self._go_executable = exe_name

-  def maybe_build(self, maybe_modified_since_last_build):
+  def maybe_build(self):
     """Builds an executable for the application if necessary.

-    Args:
-      maybe_modified_since_last_build: True if any files in the application root
-          or the GOPATH have changed since the last call to maybe_build, False
-          otherwise. This argument is used to decide whether a build is Required
-          or not.
-
     Returns:
       True if compilation was successfully performed (will raise
         an exception if compilation was attempted but failed).
@@ -173,9 +167,6 @@
       self._work_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp('appengine-go-bin')
       atexit.register(_rmtree, self._work_dir)

-    if self._go_executable and not maybe_modified_since_last_build:
-      return False
-
     if self._go_executable:
       logging.debug('Rebuilding Go application due to source modification')
     else:
</code></pre>

<h2>Before:</h2>

<pre><code>  def maybe_build(self, maybe_modified_since_last_build):
    """Builds an executable for the application if necessary.

    Args:
      maybe_modified_since_last_build: True if any files in the application root
          or the GOPATH have changed since the last call to maybe_build, False
          otherwise. This argument is used to decide whether a build is Required
          or not.

    Returns:
      True if compilation was successfully performed (will raise
        an exception if compilation was attempted but failed).
      False if compilation was not attempted.

    Raises:
      BuildError: if building the executable fails for any reason.
    """
    if not self._work_dir:
      self._work_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp('appengine-go-bin')
      atexit.register(_rmtree, self._work_dir)

    if self._go_executable and not maybe_modified_since_last_build:
      return False

    if self._go_executable:
      logging.debug('Rebuilding Go application due to source modification')
    else:
      logging.debug('Building Go application')
    self._build()
    return True
</code></pre>

<h2>After:</h2>

<pre><code>  def maybe_build(self):
    """Builds an executable for the application if necessary.

    Returns:
      True if compilation was successfully performed (will raise
        an exception if compilation was attempted but failed).
      False if compilation was not attempted.

    Raises:
      BuildError: if building the executable fails for any reason.
    """
    if not self._work_dir:
      self._work_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp('appengine-go-bin')
      atexit.register(_rmtree, self._work_dir)

    if self._go_executable:
      logging.debug('Rebuilding Go application due to source modification')
    else:
      logging.debug('Building Go application')
    self._build()
    return True
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="380757" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T18:25:11.027" CommentCount="5" />

question:
44989924      <row Id="44989924" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44990051" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44989924" CreationDate="2017-07-08T19:31:40.473" Score="7" Body="<p>Because <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#error" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>error</code></a> is just an interface. It may hold a value of any concrete type that implements it.</p>

<p>In your example you used <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#Errorf" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>fmt.Errorf()</code></a> to create an <code>error</code> value. That calls <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/errors/#example_New" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>errors.New()</code></a> which returns a pointer to a value of the unexported <code>errors.errorString</code> struct. Its definition is:</p>

<pre><code>type errorString struct {
    s string
}
</code></pre>

<p>This struct value will be marshaled, but since it has no exported fields (only exported fields are marshaled), it will be an empty JSON object: <code>{}</code>.</p>

<p>The "fix" is: don't marshal values of "general" interfaces, relying on that the dynamic values can be marshaled into JSON meaningfully. Instead you should add a field that stores the error string (the result of <code>error.Error()</code>), and omit the <code>Error error</code> field from marshaling, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>type TemplateResponse struct {
    Message  string
    Error    error `json:"-"`
    ErrorMsg string
    Template Template
}
</code></pre>

<p>Of course then you also need to set / fill the <code>ErrorMsg</code> field before marshaling.</p>

<p>Or if you don't need to store the <code>error</code> value in the struct, remove that field completely:</p>

<pre><code>type TemplateResponse struct {
    Message  string
    ErrorMsg string
    Template Template
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you still want to keep the <code>Error error</code> field (and not the <code>ErrorMsg</code> field), then you need to implement a custom marshaling logic by implementing the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.Marshaler</code></a> interface where you can "convert" the <code>error</code> value to a meaningful <code>string</code> for example (or into another value that can be marshaled properly).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="734040" LastEditDate="2017-07-09T06:54:19.667" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T06:54:19.667" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44988530      <row Id="44988530" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44990195" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44988530" CreationDate="2017-07-08T19:51:50.153" Score="1" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>Is there a relation between Sleep() and synchronization?</p>
  
  <p>NO</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Synchronization happens between value sent to channel and retrieve from channel.</p>

<pre><code>var c = make(chan string)
</code></pre>

<p>Channel <code>c</code> can hold one value of type string at a time. Until the value is retrieve from channel <code>&lt;- c</code>; function <code>pinger</code>, <code>ponger</code> cannot send value to channel <code>c</code> (i.e. pinger and ponger is waiting to send value to channel till the time you read from printer function).</p>

<p>So in your example, you introduced the time delay via <code>Sleep</code> func to read the value from channel <code>c</code> on printer function. </p>

<p>That's why you get nice and slow read with the help of <code>Sleep</code> func :) </p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-08T22:50:58.827" LastActivityDate="2017-07-08T22:50:58.827" CommentCount="6" />

question:
44991854      <row Id="44991854" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44991933" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44991854" CreationDate="2017-07-09T00:36:22.187" Score="3" Body="<p>I would say option 1 you mention is the more idiomatic way to define such functions, if they don't need any state that would warrant to tie them to an underlying struct.</p>

<p>If there is some state you'd like to have as context for the function, then option 2 would be the way to go.</p>

<p>Note that in Go, functions are "first class citizens", so you don't have Java's constraints of needing to define a class for static methods.</p>

<p>And yes, if you want a separate namespace you'd need to define separate packages (just as in Java you'd need to define separate classes and/or packages).</p>

<p>If you want your implementation to be idiomatic, I'd suggest you take a look at Go's standard libraries (pick a few packages and explore how they implement their functions) to get a better feeling of the usual ways to structure this.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T00:36:22.187" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44979398      <row Id="44979398" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44992313" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44979398" CreationDate="2017-07-09T02:01:07.553" Score="0" Body="<p>In <code>net/rpc</code> godoc example it just shows how to use global defaults. Instead create your own rpc and http server instances.</p>

<pre><code>import "net/rpc"
import "net/http"

rpcServer := rpc.NewServer()
// rpc stuff
httpServer := &amp;http.Server{
    Handler: rpcServer,
}
// graceful shutdown stuff
</code></pre>

<p>For graceful shutdown, there's a few packages. I know of this one. </p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/tylerb/graceful" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/tylerb/graceful</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="824377" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T02:01:07.553" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44997314      <row Id="44997314" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44997821" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44997314" CreationDate="2017-07-09T15:04:59.057" Score="4" Body="<p>Because the spec allows converting a <code>string</code> value to a <code>rune</code> slice (<code>[]rune</code>), and <code>rune</code> is an <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Numeric_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">alias</a> to <code>int32</code> (they are one and the same). This is what the first <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Conversions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">conversion</a>
 does:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Converting a value of a string type to a slice of runes type yields a slice containing the individual Unicode code points of the string.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Basically a <code>string</code> => <code>[]rune</code> conversion decodes the UTF-8 bytes of the text (this is how Go stores strings in memory) to Unicode code points (<code>rune</code>s).</p>

<p>And the spec does not allow converting a <code>string</code> to an <code>int</code> slice, so the second is a compile-time error.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-09T16:09:09.757" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T16:09:09.757" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44874705      <row Id="44874705" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="44999537" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44874705" CreationDate="2017-07-09T18:12:11.473" Score="0" Body="<p>In your playground example, you're using <code>for {}</code> to keep the server running for forever.
This seems to deprive the goroutines from ever getting to run.
Try using e.g. a <code>WaitGroup</code> to yield control from the <code>main()</code> routine and let the <code>flow()</code> routines handle the incoming UDP packets.</p>

<pre><code>import (
    ...
    "sync"
    ...
)

...

func main() {

    fmt.Print("Starting server.")
    for i := *Start; i &lt;= *End; i++ {
        x := strconv.Itoa(i)
        go flow(x)
    }

    var wg sync.WaitGroup
    wg.Add(1)
    wg.Wait()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2350684" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T18:12:11.473" CommentCount="2" />

question:
44999853      <row Id="44999853" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45000214" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44999853" CreationDate="2017-07-09T19:30:05.710" Score="0" Body="<p>Give to printf the expected format, in most cases, <code>%v</code> is fine.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "strings"
)

func main() {
    str := "fulltext"
    var slice []string
    slice = strings.Split(str, "")

    fmt.Printf("anwer: %v", slice)
}
</code></pre>

<p>see <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/</a> for more info.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7925197" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T19:30:05.710" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45000982      <row Id="45000982" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45001093" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45000982" CreationDate="2017-07-09T21:16:11.847" Score="2" Body="<p>Little endian:</p>

<pre><code>n := int(uint(b[0]) | uint(b[1])&lt;&lt;8 | uint(b[2])&lt;&lt;16))
</code></pre>

<p>Big endian:</p>

<pre><code>n := int(uint(b[2]) | uint(b[1])&lt;&lt;8 | uint(b[0])&lt;&lt;16))
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T21:16:11.847" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45001221      <row Id="45001221" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45001256" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45001221" CreationDate="2017-07-09T21:35:49.323" Score="1" Body="<p>Defining variable is <code>var &lt;variable-name&gt; &lt;type&gt;</code>, learn more <a href="https://www.golang-book.com/books/intro/4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">about variables</a>.</p>

<pre><code>var file *os.File
var err error
</code></pre>

<p>Your updated code:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
  path := "list.txt"

  var file *os.File
  var err error

  // Check if file exists
  if err = os.Stat(path); os.IsNotExist(err) {
    file, err = os.Create(path)
  } else { // If file exists, open it
    file, err = os.Open(path)
  }

  // Check errors opening and creating file
  if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
    return
  }

  // Defer closing file
  defer file.Close()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-09T21:41:24.153" LastActivityDate="2017-07-09T21:41:24.153" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45004854      <row Id="45004854" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45005304" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45004854" CreationDate="2017-07-10T06:41:47.533" Score="2" Body="<p>Refer: <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Appending_and_copying_slices" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Appending to and copying slices</a></p>

<p>In Go, arguments are passed by value.</p>

<p>Typical <code>append</code> usage is:  </p>

<pre><code>a = append(a, x)
</code></pre>

<p>You need to write:</p>

<pre><code>func main(){
    var array [10]int
    sliceA := array[0:5]
    // append(sliceA, 4)  // discard
    sliceA = append(sliceA, 4)  // keep
    fmt.Println(sliceA)
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Output</strong>:  </p>

<pre><code>[0 0 0 0 0 4]
</code></pre>

<p>I hope it helps.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4039768" LastActivityDate="2017-07-10T06:41:47.533" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45006269      <row Id="45006269" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
