question:
45007100      <row Id="45007100" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45007271" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45007100" CreationDate="2017-07-10T08:32:40.013" Score="3" Body="<p>You could do something like this to avoid having to explicitly pass <code>frob</code> over and over, while still being able to avoid making those functions methods on <code>frob</code>.</p>

<pre><code>type frobChecker struct {
    frob some.Frob
}

func (fc frobChecker) discountLimit(maxDiscount float64) (RuleStatus, string) 
func (fc frobChecker) discountPercentageLimit(maxDiscountPercentage float64) (RuleStatus, string) 
func (fc frobChecker) usageLimit(interval valueInterval) (RuleStatus, string) 
func (fc frobChecker) permanentExpiryLimit() (RuleStatus, string) 
func (fc frobChecker) voucherValidity(maxValidityDays uint) (RuleStatus, string) 

func doChecks(frob some.Frob) {
    fc := frobChcker{frob}

    status, message := fc.discountLimit(100)

    if status != PASSED {
       ....
    }

    ... evaluate all remaining rules here ...
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="10322" LastEditorUserId="10322" LastEditDate="2017-07-10T08:40:43.587" LastActivityDate="2017-07-10T08:40:43.587" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45002024      <row Id="45002024" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45007571" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45002024" CreationDate="2017-07-10T08:49:44.547" Score="1" Body="<p>The code is compiled only once, when you deploy the app. </p>

<p>Quote from the The App Engine Standard Environment <a href="https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">doc</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Your app is automatically re-built on the server side whenever you upload new code, and if you are running the local development server the SDK automatically recompiles sources on-the-fly when you change them.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Also, the Go Runtime Environment <a href="https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/go/runtime" rel="nofollow noreferrer">doc</a> states:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Andas with the Python SDKyour app will be automatically re-built whenever you change the source.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>When an instance is started, app engine only loads and runs the executable binary. This fact doesn't seem to be mentioned in the documentation, but it's indicated by the following known <a href="https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/35892182" rel="nofollow noreferrer">issue</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Request failed because the app binary was missing</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastActivityDate="2017-07-10T08:49:44.547" CommentCount="0" />

<row Id="45010850" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45010627" CreationDate="2017-07-10T11:28:02.813" Score="0" Body="<p>This is not supported by <code>go get</code>, you need to download the files manually to your <code>GOPATH</code> or to your <code>vendor/</code> folder.</p>

question:
45016646      <row Id="45016646" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45019509" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45016646" CreationDate="2017-07-10T18:43:08.487" Score="2" Body="<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/45016810/14660">@Adrian already explained what's wrong with using <code>interface{}</code> here</a>.</p>

<p>Instead, use the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adapter_pattern" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Adapter Pattern</a>. Create your own Shape interface and make adapters for the pre-made shapes.</p>

<p>The Shape interface (it should probably be called Shape2D because 3D shapes behave differently) might look like this. This gives you the advantages of the type system, and having a unified shape interface.</p>

<pre><code>type Shape interface {
    Area() float32
    Perimeter() float32
    X() int
    Y() int
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then create adapters around the existing objects. No wrapper is necessary, you can define an alias for the type. (<code>external</code> here represents that Circle and Square come from some other package).</p>

<pre><code>type ShapeCircle external.Circle

func (self ShapeCircle) Area() float32 {
    return math.Pi * float32(self.Radius) * float32(self.Radius)
}

...and so on...

type ShapeSquare external.Square

func (self ShapeSquare) Area() float32 {
    return float32(self.W) * float32(self.H)
}

...and so on...
</code></pre>

<p>Now you can <em>copy</em> Circle and Square objects to their Shape adapters and use them as Shape.</p>

<pre><code>c := external.Circle{ Radius: 10, X: 0, Y: 0 }

shape := ShapeCircle(c)

fmt.Println(shape.Area())
</code></pre>

<p>You can also go the other way.</p>

<pre><code>external.Function( external.Circle(shape) )
</code></pre>

<p>Again, this creates a copy.</p>

<hr>

<p>Alternatively, if you don't like the copying, you can embed Circle inside ShapeCircle and Square inside ShapeSquare.</p>

<pre><code>type ShapeCircle struct {
    external.Circle
}
type ShapeSquare struct {
    external.Square
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then you can use ShapeCircle as before, but you have to give it a Circle. Might want to make New function to take care of that.</p>

<pre><code>c := ShapeCircle{
    Circle: external.Circle{ Radius: 10, X: 0, Y: 0 }
}
</code></pre>

<p>It can be used as a Shape.</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println(c.Area())
</code></pre>

<p>And <code>c.Circle</code> can be used as a Circle. No copying necessary.</p>

<pre><code>external.Function( c.Circle )
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="14660" LastEditorUserId="14660" LastEditDate="2017-07-11T21:31:36.203" LastActivityDate="2017-07-11T21:31:36.203" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45020481      <row Id="45020481" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45020558" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45020481" CreationDate="2017-07-10T19:57:25.603" Score="2" Body="<p>Range only stops when the channel is closed. You're hitting a deadlock because nothing is writing to the channel, but you're sitting waiting for something to be written. You could add a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sync.WaitGroup</code></a> and close the channel after all of the goroutines writing to it have finished.</p>

<p>You should probably also change the loop as there is potential for the wrong values to be passed because you're closing over the loop variable which can change concurrently; this will be more reliable:</p>

<pre><code>for _, s := range l {
    go func(s rune) {
        ch &lt;- Frequency(s)
    }(s)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-10T19:57:25.603" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45024152      <row Id="45024152" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45024418" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45024152" CreationDate="2017-07-11T02:32:54.717" Score="1" Body="<p>Let's start with using <code>interface{}</code>, when you define interface don't use pointer definition, <a href="https://medium.com/@agileseeker/go-interfaces-pointers-4d1d98d5c9c6" rel="nofollow noreferrer">good read here</a>.</p>

<pre><code>type DockerUtil struct{
    Client        DockerClient
}
</code></pre>

<p>And moby <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/moby/moby/client#Client" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Client</a> implements lot of methods and you would like to do <code>interface</code> for selective methods.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Right way to do is via Type assertion. Good read <a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#interface_conversions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Effective Go - Type assertions</a> and <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_assertions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec - Type assertion</a>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><strong><em>Note:</strong> try this code, I don't have docker env in my machine to test.</em></p>

<pre><code>func NewDockerUtil() (*DockerUtil, error) {
    dockerClient, err := client.NewEnvClient()
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    return &amp;DockerUtil{
        Client:        dockerClient.(DockerClient),
    }, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>

<p>Using <code>DockerUtil.Client</code>, you can call only <code>Ping</code> method since your interface <code>DockerClient</code> has definition of <code>Ping</code> method.</p>

<hr>

<p>If you would like to call all the methods supported by <code>client.Client</code> later on then you have to do type assertion-</p>

<pre><code>dockerClient := DockerUtil.Client.(*client.Client)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-11T02:32:54.717" CommentCount="6" />

question:

" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-11T02:52:58.537" CommentCount="2" />

answer:
<row Id="45026053" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45025447" CreationDate="2017-07-11T05:29:10.943" Score="0" Body="<p>In two ways you can do, as per <a href="https://www.firebase.com/docs/rest/guide/saving-data.html#section-update" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Firebase doc</a> with firego client library. Drafted answer based on from firego <a href="https://github.com/zabawaba99/firego/blob/v1/README.md" rel="nofollow noreferrer">README.md</a>. </p>

<p><em>Note: You have not provided the complete path of the structure, I have drafted the answer based on screenshot. So update your JSON path accordingly.</em> </p>

<p>Approach 1:</p>

<pre><code>f := firego.New("https://my-firebase-app.firebaseIO.com/active-chat/Koja8GuFpIEN3kjbfPO.json", nil)

x := map[string]string{
   "Status": "OFF",
}
if err := f.Update(x); err != nil {
  log.Fatal(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Approach 2:</p>

<pre><code>f := firego.New("https://my-firebase-app.firebaseIO.com", nil)
f = f.Ref("/active-chat/Koja8GuFpIEN3kjbfPO.json")

x := map[string]string{
   "Status": "OFF",
}
if err := f.Update(x); err != nil {
  log.Fatal(err)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-11T05:29:10.943" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45030618      <row Id="45030618" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45031417" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45030618" CreationDate="2017-07-11T10:04:06.317" Score="1" Body="<p>Examples of how to generate a random <code>bool</code> value can be found here (not necessarily the fastest solutions, as that wasn't a requirement there):</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44719156/how-can-i-let-a-function-randomly-return-either-a-true-or-a-false-in-go/44719269#44719269">How can I let a function randomly return either a true or a false in go</a></p>

<p>The slowest part of such algorithms is always getting the random data (random information). For example a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#Int31" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.Int31()</code></a> call returns 31 random bits, but if we only use it to "generate" a random <code>bool</code> value (which is 1 bit of information), we waste 30 bits (which could be 30 additional random <code>bool</code> values!).</p>

<p>Using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#Source" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.Source</code></a> is a good choice, as we don't need all the "code kung-fu" that <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#Rand" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.Rand</code></a> does on the random data. We just need a source of random information.</p>

<p><code>rand.Source</code> defines one method to obtain random information:</p>

<pre><code>Int63() int64
</code></pre>

<p>This <code>Source.Int63()</code> method returns 63 random bits; to be fast(est), we should use all. Of course to generate a single <code>bool</code> value requires only 1 of its bits, but we should store the remaining and use them when subsequent random <code>bool</code>s are asked from us.</p>

<p>This is how it can be done:</p>

<pre><code>type boolgen struct {
    src       rand.Source
    cache     int64
    remaining int
}

func (b *boolgen) Bool() bool {
    if b.remaining == 0 {
        b.cache, b.remaining = b.src.Int63(), 63
    }

    result := b.cache&amp;0x01 == 1
    b.cache &gt;&gt;= 1
    b.remaining--

    return result
}
</code></pre>

<p>Creating such a <code>boolgen</code> is like this:</p>

<pre><code>func New() *boolgen {
    return &amp;boolgen{src: rand.NewSource(time.Now().UnixNano())}
}
</code></pre>

<p>Example usage:</p>

<pre><code>r := New()
for i := 0; i &lt; 100; i++ {
    if i%10 == 0 {
        fmt.Println()
    }
    fmt.Print(r.Bool(), " ")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Example output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/oucs3zxcr_" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>false false true true false false false false false false 
false false false true false false true false true true 
false false true false true false false true true true 
false false false false false false false true true false 
true true true true false false false false true false 
true true true false true true true true true true 
true true false true true false false true false true 
true true false false false true true true true false 
true false false true true true true false false true 
true false false false false false false false true false 
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Some notes:</strong></p>

<p>The <code>Source</code> returned by <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#NewSource" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.NewSource()</code></a> is not safe for concurrent use by multiple goroutines, so our <code>boolgen</code> is also not safe for concurrent use. On one hand this is <em>good</em>, as it will be faster (as no synchronization takes place) than using the default source of the <code>rand</code> package which is safe in this manner (which is by the way unexported, so can only be "reached" indirectly through functions of the <code>rand</code> package).</p>

<p>If you need to use this from multiple goroutines, <em>fastest</em> (as in spirit of the question) would be for all goroutines to create their own <code>boolgen</code>, so no synchronization is needed.</p>

<p>If <code>boolgen</code> itself must be made safe for concurrent use, simply its <code>Bool()</code> method should be protected with a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#Mutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sync.Mutex</code></a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-11T10:22:29.800" LastActivityDate="2017-07-11T10:22:29.800" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45029816      <row Id="45029816" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45032040" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45029816" CreationDate="2017-07-11T10:32:56.503" Score="0" Body="<p>I would like to help you as it seems you are genuinely trying to learn go. I've made few changes in your code. I've moved the menu listing in each handler. You may keep it global. Find the changed code below.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "io"
    "net/http"
    "net/url"
    "strconv"
)

type Menu struct {
    Name        string
    Price       int
    description string
}

func (m Menu) String() string {
    return fmt.Sprintf("%s: %s", m.Name, m.Price)
}

func main() {
    fmt.Println(x)

    http.HandleFunc("/getall", getall)
    http.HandleFunc("/get", get)
    http.ListenAndServe(":8080", nil)

}

func getall(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {

    x := []Menu{
        {Name: "Crispy", Price: 31},
        {Name: "Burger", Price: 42},
        {Name: "Superstar", Price: 17},
    }

    for _, m := range x {

        io.WriteString(w, "&lt;p&gt;"+m.Name+" Price "+strconv.Itoa(m.Price)+"&lt;/p&gt;")
    }

}

func get(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {

    x := []Menu{
        {Name: "Crispy", Price: 31},
        {Name: "Burger", Price: 42},
        {Name: "Superstar", Price: 17},
    }

    url := url.URL{}
    println(url.String())
    attr := r.URL.Query()
    fmt.Println(attr)
    id := attr["id"][0]
    fmt.Println("id of request " + id)
    v := id
    if a, err := strconv.Atoi(v); err == nil {
        io.WriteString(w, "&lt;p&gt; "+x[a-1].Name+" price "+strconv.Itoa(x[a-1].Price)+"&lt;/p&gt;")
    }

}
</code></pre>

<p>Try visiting: <a href="http://localhost:8080/getall" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://localhost:8080/getall</a> OR <a href="http://localhost:8080/get?id=1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://localhost:8080/get?id=1</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="387670" LastEditorUserId="387670" LastEditDate="2017-07-11T11:10:24.850" LastActivityDate="2017-07-11T11:10:24.850" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45046093      <row Id="45046093" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45046353" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45046093" CreationDate="2017-07-12T00:16:08.707" Score="1" Body="<p>A <code>Scanner</code> is a complicated structure, and one that embeds a buffer.  The buffer can grow dynamically (depending on what the <code>scan</code> function requests) up to 64kB (<code>MaxScanTokenSize</code>).</p>

<p>So in general it is not a good idea to keep redundant <code>Scanner</code>s around, as the buffers cannot be released until the <code>Scanner</code>s are discarded.  But perhaps a few extra kilobytes of memory don't matter much in your case.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4127569" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T00:16:08.707" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45046680      <row Id="45046680" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45046927" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45046680" CreationDate="2017-07-12T01:37:51.140" Score="1" Body="<p><strong>EDIT:</strong></p>

<p>I just did <code>go get -v github.com/bitly/oauth2_proxy</code> on my machine. </p>

<p>Verbose Details: <a href="http://pasted.co/60e2b56d" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://pasted.co/60e2b56d</a></p>

<p>Binary is produced under <code>$GOPATH/bin/oauth2_proxy</code>.</p>

<pre><code>-rwxr-xr-x  1 jeeva  staff    10M Jul 11 19:02 oauth2_proxy
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Let's start from basis. First setup your Go workspace (<a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">How to Write Go Code</a>) pick a directory for GOPATH. </p>

<p>For example: /Users/matt/dev</p>

<pre><code>export GOPATH=/Users/matt/dev
</code></pre>

<p>Then do <code>go get</code> to get the <code>oauth2_proxy</code>. Typically go get is git clone of that repository.</p>

<pre><code>go get github.com/bitly/oauth2_proxy
</code></pre>

<p>It will get the source code and runs <code>go install</code>. After successful execution of this command. You will see binary file in <code>$GOPATH/bin</code>.</p>

<p>Now modified the source code as you need and run go install to build the binary.</p>

<pre><code>go install github.com/bitly/oauth2_proxy

OR
cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/bitly/oauth2_proxy
go install
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>If you would like to manually instead of <code>go get</code>. Then pick a directory for <code>GOPATH</code> and export it (as mentioned above) then</p>

<pre><code>mkdir -p $GOPATH/src/github.com/bitly
cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/bitly
git clone https://github.com/bitly/oauth2_proxy.git
cd oauth2_proxy
go get ./...
go install 
</code></pre>

<p>Now binary will be in <code>$GOPATH/bin</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-12T02:05:21.543" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T02:05:21.543" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45052597      <row Id="45052597" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45053535" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45052597" CreationDate="2017-07-12T09:18:39.457" Score="2" Body="<p>Use recover().</p>

<pre><code>func Testgood_PanicStatement(t *testing.T) {
  Convey("And Invalid Json return error",t, func() {
    defer func() {
      if r := recover(); r != nil {
        So(func() {},shouldPanic)
        So(actual ,ShouldEqual,"")
      }
    }()
    actual := good("garbage json")
  }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Lear more about:</p>

<ol>
<li><a href="https://blog.golang.org/defer-panic-and-recover" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Golang blog</a></li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="3476121" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T09:18:39.457" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45048049      <row Id="45048049" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45054213" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45048049" CreationDate="2017-07-12T09:47:59.800" Score="5" Body="<p>This is due to a <em>tricky</em> padding.</p>

<p>First please allow me to slightly rename the structs and fields so it'll be easier to talk about them:</p>

<pre><code>type bar1 struct {
    A [0]byte
    I int
}

type bar2 struct {
    I int
    A [0]byte
}
</code></pre>

<p>This of course doesn't change the size and offsets as can be verified on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/NcTeFpDrJi" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>:</p>

<pre><code>bar1 size:     4
bar1.A offset: 0
bar1.I offset: 0

bar2 size:     8
bar2.I offset: 0
bar2.A offset: 4
</code></pre>

<p>The size of a value of type <code>[0]byte</code> is zero, so it is perfectly valid in  <code>bar1</code> to not reserve any space for the first field (<code>bar1.A</code>), and lay out the <code>bar1.I</code> field with 0 offset.</p>

<p>The question is: why can't the compiler do the same in the 2nd case (with <code>bar2</code>)?</p>

<p>A field must have an address that must be after the memory area reserved for the previous field. In the first case the first field <code>bar1.A</code> has 0 size, so the 2nd field may have 0 offset, it will not "overlap" with the first field.</p>

<p>In case of <code>bar2</code>, the second field cannot have an address (and therefore an offset) that overlaps with the first field, so its offset cannot be less than the size of <code>int</code> which is 4 bytes in case of 32-bit architectures (and 8 bytes in case of 64-bit arch).</p>

<p>This still seems ok. But since <code>bar2.A</code> has zero size, why can't the size of the struct <code>bar2</code> be just that: 4 bytes (or 8 in 64-bit arch)?</p>

<p>This is because it is perfectly <strong>valid to take the address of fields (and variables) that have 0 size</strong>. Ok, so what?</p>

<p>In case of <code>bar2</code>, the compiler has to insert a 4 (or 8) byte padding, else taking the address of a <code>bar2.A</code> field would point <strong>outside of the memory area</strong> reserved for a value of type <code>bar2</code>.</p>

<p>As an example, <strong>without padding</strong> a value of <code>bar2</code> may have an address of <code>0x100</code>, size 4, so memory reserved for the struct value has address range <code>0x100 .. 0x103</code>. Address of <code>bar2.A</code> would be <code>0x104</code>, that is outside of the struct's memory. In case of an array of this struct (e.g. <code>x [5]bar2</code>), if the array starts at <code>0x100</code>, address of <code>x[0]</code> would be <code>0x100</code>, address of <code>x[0].A</code> would be <code>0x104</code>, and address of the subsequent element <code>x[1]</code> would also be <code>0x104</code> but that's the address of another struct value! Not cool.</p>

<p>To avoid this, the compiler inserts a padding (which will be 4 or 8 bytes depending on the arch), so that taking the address of <code>bar2.A</code> will not result in an address being outside of the struct's memory, which otherwise could raise questions and cause problems regarding garbage collection (e.g. if only address of <code>bar2.A</code> is kept but not the struct or another pointer to it or its other fields, the whole struct should not be garbage collected, but since no pointer points to its memory area, it would seem to be valid to do so). The inserted padding will be 4 (or 8) bytes, because <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Size_and_alignment_guarantees" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Size and alignment guarantees:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>For a variable <code>x</code> of struct type: <code>unsafe.Alignof(x)</code> is the largest of all the values <code>unsafe.Alignof(x.f)</code> for each field <code>f</code> of <code>x</code>, but at least <code>1</code>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If this is so, adding an additional <code>int</code> field would make the size of both structs equal:</p>

<pre><code>type bar1 struct {
    I int
    A [0]byte
    X int
}

type bar2 struct {
    A [0]byte
    I int
    X int
}
</code></pre>

<p>And truly they both have 8 bytes on 32-bit arch (and 16 bytes on 64-bit arch) (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/SBweaAzE2b" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>bar1 size:     8
bar1.I offset: 0
bar1.A offset: 4
bar1.X offset: 4

bar2 size:     8
bar2.A offset: 0
bar2.I offset: 0
bar2.X offset: 4
</code></pre>

<p>See related question: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34219232/struct-has-different-size-if-the-field-order-is-different/34219916#34219916">Struct has different size if the field order is different</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-15T09:11:50.720" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T09:11:50.720" CommentCount="0" />

45054533      <row Id="45054533" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="45054765" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45054533" CreationDate="2017-07-12T10:11:38.453" Score="2" Body="<p><code>pattern</code> and <code>handler</code> are parameter/variable names. Unlike C, the declaration of types in Go is left to right. i.e. name of variable comes first and then its type. Read more at <a href="https://blog.golang.org/gos-declaration-syntax" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go's declaration syntax</a> </p>

<p>Yes, the <code>handler</code> is like JavaScript callback function. Read more at "<a href="https://blog.golang.org/first-class-functions-in-go-and-new-go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">First class functions in Go</a>"</p>

question:
45053785      <row Id="45053785" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45055502" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45053785" CreationDate="2017-07-12T10:45:19.590" Score="0" Body="<p>All files in one folder belong to the same package (must have the same package name at the top of the file!).</p>

<p>You do not need to import other files that belong to the same package (the same folder).</p>

<p>Just remove the import and you should still have access to product in user_product and vice versa.</p>

question:
45055327      <row Id="45055327" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45056888" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45055327" CreationDate="2017-07-12T11:48:46.147" Score="3" Body="<p>There is a proposal for golang 1.9 on this: <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/15314" rel="nofollow noreferrer">proposal: some way to reject unknown fields in encoding/json.Decoder</a></p>

<p>Till then you could try something like this <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Ia_zOMdlXT" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground</a> (code also below).
The key idea is to parse the json into a map[string]interface{} and then work with the keys. This will of course get much more complicated if you have nested structs.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
)

type Foo struct {
    Bar int `json:"id,omitempty"`
}
var allowedFooKeys = []string{"id"}

func main() {
    b := []byte(`{
      "id": 12,
      "hey": "hey"
    }`)
    m := map[string]interface{}{}

    if err := json.Unmarshal(b, &amp;m); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    for k, _ := range m {
        if !keyExists(k, allowedFooKeys) {
            fmt.Println("Disallowed key in JSON:", k)
        }
    }
}

func keyExists(key string, keys []string) bool {
    for _, k := range keys {
        if k == key {
            return true
        }
    }
    return false
}
</code></pre>

<p>You can even get rid of the variable <code>allowedFooKeys</code> by getting the allowed keys directly from the <code>Foo</code> struct using reflect. For more info on that see here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23840362/how-to-read-struct-field-decorators">How to read struct field ` ` decorators?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T11:48:46.147" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45055953      <row Id="45055953" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45057403" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45055953" CreationDate="2017-07-12T12:12:57.507" Score="2" Body="<p>You <em>could</em> achieve it in this way:</p>

<pre><code>type Generatorer interface {
    getValue() interface{}
}

type StringGenerator struct {
    length         int
}

type IntGenerator struct {
    min            int
    max            int
}

func (g StringGenerator) getValue() interface{} {
    return "randomString"
}

func (g IntGenerator) getValue() interface{} {
    return 1
}
</code></pre>

<p>The empty interface allows every value. This allows for generic code but basically stops you from using the very powerful type system of Go.</p>

<p>In your example if you use the <code>getValue</code> function, you will get a variable of type <code>interface{}</code> and if you want to work with it, you need to know if it actually is a string or an int: you will need a lot of <code>reflect</code> making your code slow.</p>

<p>Coming from Python I was used to code very generic. When learning Go I had to stop thinking that way.</p>

<p>What that means in your specific case I can't say because I don't know what <code>StringGenerator</code> and <code>IntGenerator</code> are being used for.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastEditorUserId="6220193" LastEditDate="2017-07-12T14:32:55.447" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T14:32:55.447" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45059243      <row Id="45059243" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45059339" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45059243" CreationDate="2017-07-12T13:39:25.567" Score="2" Body="<p>You may "reverse" the regex to <em>match</em> the strings you need. You want to match any 1+ chars other than <code>;</code> followed with <code>;</code> that are not followed with <code>I</code> or <code>D</code>.</p>

<p>Use</p>

<pre><code>[^;]+(?:;[^ID;][^;]*)*
</code></pre>

<p>See the <a href="https://regex101.com/r/w7zf2w/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">regex demo</a></p>

<p><strong>Details</strong>:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>[^;]+</code> - 1 or more chars other than <code>;</code></li>
<li><code>(?:;[^ID;][^;]*)*</code> - zero or more sequences of:

<ul>
<li><code>;</code> - a <code>;</code></li>
<li><code>[^ID;]</code> - a char other than <code>I</code>, <code>D</code> or <code>;</code> (that is in order not to match empty values)</li>
<li><code>[^;]*</code> - zero or more chars other than <code>;</code></li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>See a <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ccd52O_rus" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go demo</a>.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "regexp"
    "fmt"
)

func main() {
    var re = regexp.MustCompile(`[^;]+(?:;[^ID;][^;]*)*`)
    var str = `I.E.viewability:-2;D.ua:Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 7.0; SM-G920W8 Build/NRD90M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/59.0.3071.125 Mobile Safari/537.36;D.G.city:Burnaby;D.G.zip:V5C;D.G.region:BC;D.G.E.country_code2:CA;`

    for _, match := range re.FindAllString(str, -1) {
        fmt.Println(match)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>I.E.viewability:-2
D.ua:Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 7.0; SM-G920W8 Build/NRD90M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/59.0.3071.125 Mobile Safari/537.36
D.G.city:Burnaby
D.G.zip:V5C
D.G.region:BC
D.G.E.country_code2:CA
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3832970" LastEditorUserId="3832970" LastEditDate="2017-07-12T13:44:59.457" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T13:44:59.457" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45061019      <row Id="45061019" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45061125" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45061019" CreationDate="2017-07-12T14:53:35.730" Score="3" Body="<p>Don't use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/log/#Fatal" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>log.Fatal</code></a> - by using that function you're explicitly telling it to crash when it encounters an error:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Fatal is equivalent to Print() followed by a call to os.Exit(1).</p>
</blockquote>

<p>"Fatal" means what it says, it kills the process.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T14:53:35.730" CommentCount="9" />

question:
45061595      <row Id="45061595" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45061738" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45061595" CreationDate="2017-07-12T15:19:57.530" Score="2" Body="<p>Receiving from 2 channels is not atomic. You can check the number of elements queued in a channel's buffer using the builtin <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#len" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>len()</code></a> function, but you can't do a 2-channel atomic receive.</p>

<p>Meaning by the time you receive a value from one channel, the other channel might not be ready to receive from (e.g. another goroutine might already have received from it).</p>

<p>If there is only one goroutine that consumes and processes these values, simply receive a value from both channels, it will block if a value is not ready (if channel is not ready to receive from):</p>

<pre><code>v1 := &lt;- ch1
v2 := &lt;- ch2

// process v1 and v2
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that receiving also succeeds if the channel is closed.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-12T16:26:20.470" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T16:26:20.470" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45061568      <row Id="45061568" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45062472" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45061568" CreationDate="2017-07-12T15:52:55.233" Score="2" Body="<p>Try this:</p>

<pre><code>var x *Foo
var y interface{} = x
fmt.Printf("Before: %#v
", y)
fmt.Printf("Goal: %#v
", interface{}(&amp;Foo{}))

// Must take address of y to set it. Dereference with Elem() to get value for y
rv := reflect.ValueOf(&amp;y).Elem()

// Interface element type is *main.Foo, dereference with Elem() to get main.Foo
t := rv.Elem().Type().Elem()
rv.Set(reflect.New(t))
fmt.Printf("After: %#v
", y)
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/n39yPzJVpe" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground example</a></p>

<p>You can also assign <code>y</code> instead of setting it via reflection:</p>

<pre><code>var x *Foo
var y interface{} = x
fmt.Printf("Before: %#v
", y)
fmt.Printf("Goal: %#v
", interface{}(&amp;Foo{}))
rv := reflect.ValueOf(y)
t := rv.Type().Elem()
y = reflect.New(t).Interface()
fmt.Printf("After: %#v
", y)
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/qDlmg32z4c" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground example</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-07-12T16:33:14.010" LastActivityDate="2017-07-12T16:33:14.010" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45065678      <row Id="45065678" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45067198" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45065678" CreationDate="2017-07-12T20:43:56.963" Score="1" Body="<p><strong>EDIT:</strong></p>

<p>After comment interaction and with updated question. Before we move forward, I would like to mention.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>I just looked at your <code>example-2</code> Remember one thing. Mapping is from one form to another form. Basically <code>one known format to targeted format</code>. Each data type have to handled. You cannot do <code>generic</code> to <code>generic</code> mapping logically (technically feasible though, would take more time &amp; efforts, you can play around on this).</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I have created sample working program of one approach; it does a mapping of source to targeted format. Refer this program as a start point and use your creativity to implement yours.</p>

<p>Playground link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/MEk_nGcPjZ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/MEk_nGcPjZ</a></p>

<p><strong>Explanation:</strong> Sample program achieves two different source format to one target format. The program consist of -</p>

<ul>
<li>Targeted Mapping definition of Provider 1</li>
<li>Targeted Mapping definition of Provider 2</li>
<li>Provider 1 JSON</li>
<li>Provider 2 JSON</li>
<li>Mapping function</li>
<li>Targeted JSON marshal</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Key elements from program:</strong> refer play link for complete program.</p>

<pre><code>type MappingInfo struct {
    TargetKey     string
    SourceKeyPath string
    DataType      string
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Map function:</strong></p>

<pre><code>func mapIt(mapping []*MappingInfo, parsedResult gjson.Result) map[string]interface{} {
    mappedData := make(map[string]interface{})
    for _, m := range mapping {
        switch m.DataType {
        case "time":
            mappedData[m.TargetKey] = parsedResult.Get(m.SourceKeyPath).Time()
        case "string":
            mappedData[m.TargetKey] = parsedResult.Get(m.SourceKeyPath).String()
        }
    }
    return mappedData
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Output:</strong> </p>

<pre><code>Provider 1 Result: map[date:2017-05-17 08:52:36.024 +0000 UTC clientName:provider1 username]
Provider 1 JSON: {
  "clientName": "provider1 username",
  "date": "2017-05-17T08:52:36.024Z"
}

Provider 2 Result: map[date:2017-05-12 06:32:46.014 +0000 UTC clientName:provider2 username]
Provider 2 JSON: {
  "clientName": "provider2 username",
  "date": "2017-05-12T06:32:46.014Z"
}
</code></pre>

<p>Good luck, happy coding!</p>

<hr>

<p>Typically Converting/Transforming one structure to another structure, you will have to handle this with application logic.</p>

<p>As you mentioned in the question:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>my problem is I have different apis, every api have own json schema</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This is true for every <code>aggregation</code> system.</p>

<hr>

<p>One approach to handle this requirement effectively; is to keep mapping of keys for each provider JSON structure and targeted JSON structure.</p>

<p><strong>For example:</strong> This is an approach, please go with your design as you see fit.</p>

<p><strong>JSON structures from various provider:</strong></p>

<pre><code>// Provider 1 : JSON structrure
{
  "createdAt": "2017-05-17T08:52:36.024Z",
  "data": {
    "user": {
      "name": "xxx"
    }
  }
}

// Provider 2 : JSON structrure
{
  "username": "yyy"
  "since": "2017-05-17T08:52:36.024Z",
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Mapping for target JSON structure:</strong></p>

<pre><code>jsonMappingByProvider := make(map[string]string)

// Targeted Mapping for Provider 1
jsonMappingByProvider["provider1"] = `
{
    "date": "createdAt",
    "clientName": "data.user.name"
}
`

// Targeted Mapping for Provider 2
jsonMappingByProvider["provider2"] = `
{
    "date": "since",
    "clientName": "username"
}
`
</code></pre>

<p>Now, based the on the provider you're handling, get the mapping and map the response JSON into targeted structure.</p>

<pre><code>// get the mapping info by provider
mapping := jsonMappingByProvider["provider1"]

// Parse the response JSON 
// Do the mapping
</code></pre>

<p>This way you can control each provider and it's mapping effectively.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-14T18:13:36.550" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T18:13:36.550" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45067382      <row Id="45067382" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45067544" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45067382" CreationDate="2017-07-12T21:08:09.683" Score="1" Body="<p>Type assertions:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type Test struct {
    foo int
}

func isTest(t interface{}) bool {
    switch t.(type) {
    case Test:
        return true
    default:
        return false
    }
}

func main() {
    t := Test{5}
    fmt.Println(isTest(t))
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/dotXc8BTcU" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Playground</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="3521243" LastEditorUserId="3521243" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T16:47:41.187" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T16:47:41.187" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45068666      <row Id="45068666" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45068974" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45068666" CreationDate="2017-07-12T23:16:33.300" Score="3" Body="<p>Use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#New" rel="nofollow noreferrer">reflect.New</a> with <code>struct</code> type. In Go you have to use type to create a new instance dynamically not string.</p>

<p>Example: To create struct instance dynamically, you can do</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "reflect"

import (
   "github.com/collector/package1"
   "github.com/collector/package2"
)

func main() {
    sliceOfCollector := make([]reflect.Type, 0)
    sliceOfCollector = append(sliceOfCollector, reflect.TypeOf((*package1.NewRule)(nil)).Elem()})
    sliceOfCollector = append(sliceOfCollector, reflect.TypeOf((*package2.OldRule)(nil)).Elem()})

    for _, collectorType := range slice sliceOfCollector {
        col := reflect.New(collectorType)
        fmt.Printf("%#v\n", col)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>You can use <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Type_assertions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">type assertions</a> after that <code>col.Interface().(*package1.NewRule)</code></p>

<hr>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong></p>

<p>After comment interaction, added following.</p>

<p>Creating a instance using factory method. Just an idea.</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    sliceOfCollector := []string{"NewRule", "OldRule"}

    for _, col := range sliceOfCollector {
        rule := CreateRuleByName(col)
        fmt.Printf("%#v\n", rule)
    }
}

func CreateRuleByName(name string) interface{} {
    switch name {
    case "NewRule":
       return &amp;package1.NewRule{}
    case "OldRule":
       return &amp;package2.OldRule{}
    default:
       return nil
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T00:40:23.653" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T00:40:23.653" CommentCount="5" />

question:

answer:
<row Id="45071441" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45071362" CreationDate="2017-07-13T04:32:04.493" Score="3" Body="<p>You get this error because <code>else</code> statement must be on the same line as the closing <code>}</code> of the first condition.</p>

<pre><code>func getKeyNameFromDeploymentAndSubnet(subnetType SubnetType, deploymentType DeploymentType, keyNameMap map[SubnetType]string) string {
    if deploymentType == NoDeployment || deploymentType == PDBAWindows || deploymentType == AgentDeployment {
        return keyNameMap[subnetType]

    }

}

question:
45071659      <row Id="45071659" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45071716" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45071659" CreationDate="2017-07-13T04:58:24.950" Score="1" Body="<p>Try this:</p>

<pre><code>t := reflect.TypeOf((*FooService)(nil)).Elem()
var s []string
for i := 0; i &lt; t.NumMethod(); i++ {
    s = append(s, t.Method(i).Name)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/-AHYGJnxvb" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground example</a></p>

<p>Getting the reflect.Type for the interface type is the tricky part. See <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7132848/how-to-get-the-reflect-type-of-an-interface">How to get the reflect.Type of an interface?</a> for an explanation.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T05:04:29.027" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T05:04:29.027" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45074481      <row Id="45074481" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45074594" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45074481" CreationDate="2017-07-13T07:52:48.603" Score="0" Body="<p>For it to be <code>time.RFC1123Z</code> the day must be <code>02</code> not <code>2</code>.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "time"
)

func main() {
    d := "Thu, 02 Mar 2017 10:44:13 +0100"
    da, _ := time.Parse(time.RFC1123Z, d)
    fmt.Println(da)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/JFtErfZTtk" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/JFtErfZTtk</a></p>

<p>If you cannot change the source time string you can alternatively parse it with the <code>Mon, 2 Jan 2006 15:04:05 -0700</code> format:</p>

<pre><code>da, _ := time.Parse("Mon, 2 Jan 2006 15:04:05 -0700", d)
</code></pre>

<p>References:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#pkg-constants" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/time/#pkg-constants</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="251311" LastEditorUserId="251311" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T08:01:17.977" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T08:01:17.977" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45050191      <row Id="45050191" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45076738" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45050191" CreationDate="2017-07-13T09:33:29.040" Score="2" Body="<p>Assuming you are facing difficulty to mock http.Client, I would like to suggest following options.</p>

<p><strong>1. Refactor the code</strong></p>

<p>You need to refactor the code in such a way that you can pass the mockable dependencies to function that you would like to test. </p>

<p>For example,</p>

<p>Refactor <code>func send_api(client *http.Client,url string) map[string]string,error</code> so that it does api request and getting/parsing data, but call another function from it, which does the further processing (that actually you would like to test and not the http.Client part).</p>

<p>But, with this approach, you may not be able to test end to end flow. But you can test those functions separately.</p>

<p><strong>2. Mock http.Client</strong></p>

<p>Again, you may need to refactor your code. Some related article can be found <a href="http://webiphany.com/2014/06/23/mocking-out-client-http-requests-with-go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>   </p>

<p>Update: Recommending to watch <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hVFEV-ieeew" rel="nofollow noreferrer">justforfunc #16: unit testing HTTP servers</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="387670" LastEditorUserId="387670" LastEditDate="2017-08-04T11:50:11.817" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T11:50:11.817" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45076887      <row Id="45076887" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45077588" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45076887" CreationDate="2017-07-13T10:09:24.640" Score="5" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>The append built-in function appends elements to the end of a slice.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Read more in <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#append" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the docs</a>.</p>

<p>The <code>...</code> is used in variadic functions (of which <code>append</code> is an example), to pass all of the elements of the preceding variable.</p>

<p>So given a variable <code>x := []int{1, 2, 3}</code>, the expression <code>foo(x...)</code> will pass it to a function as if you had called <code>foo(1, 2, 3)</code> in contrast to <code>foo(x)</code> which would equivalent to <code>foo([]int{1, 2, 3})</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastEditorUserId="13860" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T11:09:23.297" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T11:09:23.297" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45004791      <row Id="45004791" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45078797" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45004791" CreationDate="2017-07-13T11:05:53.263" Score="1" Body="<p>Yes, by default all http requests can be executed concurrently. </p>

<p>If you are executing a python script, then indeed a separate process will be spawned and they will execute concurrently. </p>

<p>Please note that this carries the potential risk of spawning too many processes and running out of resources.</p>
" OwnerUserId="326736" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T11:05:53.263" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45082449      <row Id="45082449" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45082700" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45082449" CreationDate="2017-07-13T13:51:51.433" Score="0" Body="<p>From Golang's <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Reader documentation</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Read reads up to len(p) bytes into p. It returns the number of bytes read (0 &lt;= n &lt;= len(p)) and any error encountered. Even if Read returns n &lt; len(p), it may use all of p as scratch space during the call. If some data is available but not len(p) bytes, Read conventionally returns what is available instead of waiting for more.</p>
  
  <p>When Read encounters an error or end-of-file condition after successfully reading n > 0 bytes, it returns the number of bytes read. It may return the (non-nil) error from the same call or return the error (and n == 0) from a subsequent call. An instance of this general case is that a Reader returning a non-zero number of bytes at the end of the input stream may return either err == EOF or err == nil. The next Read should return 0, EOF. </p>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>//Reader interface from package documentation showing 'p' is the input byte slice.
type Reader interface {
    Read(p []byte) (n int, err error)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Since you are never initializing your slice, <code>len(bytes)</code> is always 0 so it only reads 0 bytes. To do it manually like you are trying to do, you would have to initialize the slice to be non-empty and then call read multiple times until it finally returns 0 and EOF while appending bytes to some buffer that you maintain. That is why <a href="http://godoc.org/io/ioutil#ReadAll" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ioutil.ReadAll</a> is desired, it guarantees that everything is read correctly and you don't have to worry about handling that.</p>

<p>Also note <code>defer resp.Body.Close()</code> in the example. It is important to always remember to close Readers and Writers after using them.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1495050" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T13:51:51.433" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45084622      <row Id="45084622" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45084931" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45084622" CreationDate="2017-07-13T15:19:54.987" Score="6" Body="<p>It's not the limit of the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>fmt</code></a> package or <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#Scanf" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>fmt.Scanf()</code></a>, this example properly scans more than 3KB:</p>

<pre><code>// src is a looooong text (&gt;3KB)

var s string
fmt.Println(len(src))
fmt.Sscanf(src, "%s", &amp;s)
fmt.Println(len(s))
</code></pre>

<p>Try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/dK7SE2gCo0" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a></p>

<p>It's most likely the limit of your terminal. I also tried your unmodified version, pasted more than 10KB of text, and the result was 4096 bytes (Ubuntu linux 16.04, Bash).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T17:13:24.977" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T17:13:24.977" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45073014      <row Id="45073014" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45085020" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45073014" CreationDate="2017-07-13T15:23:36.647" Score="1" Body="<p>Use a <a href="http://godoc.org/github.com/garyburd/redigo/redis#DialNetDial" rel="nofollow noreferrer">network dial</a> function like this with <a href="http://godoc.org/github.com/garyburd/redigo/redis" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Redigo</a>: </p>

<pre><code>func dial(network, addr string) (net.Conn, error) {
        user := "user"
        password := "password"
        sshAddr := "example.com:22"
        redisAddr := ":6379"
        config := &amp;ssh.ClientConfig{
            User: user,
            Auth: []ssh.AuthMethod{
                ssh.Password(passord),
            },
        }
        netConn, err := net.Dial("tcp", sshAddr)
        if err != nil {
            return nil, err
        }
        clientConn, chans, reqs, err := ssh.NewClientConn(netConn, sshAddr, config)
        if err != nil {
            netConn.Close()
            return nil, err
        }
        client := ssh.NewClient(clientConn, chans, reqs)
        conn, err := client.Dial("tcp", redisAddr)
        if err != nil {
            client.Close()
            return nil, err
        }
        conn, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>If the application creates multiple connections to the server, then create <code>client</code> once and reuse on each dial.</p>

<p>The code above is uncompiled and untested.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T15:23:36.647" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45022651      <row Id="45022651" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45085569" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45022651" CreationDate="2017-07-13T15:47:38.077" Score="0" Body="<p>So turns out the log were there but not where I'd expect them.</p>

<p>Using the gcloud CLI I could see those logs got the resource type <code>gce_instance</code> and therefore appears in the <code>GCE VM Instance</code> category</p>

<p>To figure this out:</p>

<pre><code>  $ gcloud beta logging logs list
  projects/&lt;PROJECT&gt;/logs/&lt;LOG_NAME&gt;
  ...
</code></pre>

<p>then</p>

<pre><code>$ gcloud beta logging read projects/&lt;PROJECT&gt;/logs/&lt;LOG_NAME&gt;
---
insertId: ...
jsonPayload:
   ...
logName: ...
receiveTimestamp: ...
resource:
  labels:
    instance_id: ...
    project_id: ...
    zone: ...
  type: gce_instance
timestamp: ...
</code></pre>

<p>Note <code>type</code> being <code>gce_instance</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="101969" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T15:47:38.077" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45086082      <row Id="45086082" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45086175" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45086082" CreationDate="2017-07-13T16:18:11.900" Score="4" Body="<p>It's possible if you omit the type:</p>

<pre><code>var i, s = 2, "hi"
fmt.Println(i, s)
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/A8oVANLTQn" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>2 hi
</code></pre>

<p>Note that the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Short_variable_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">short variable declaration</a> is exactly a shorthand for this:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A <em>short variable declaration</em> uses the syntax:</p>

<pre><code>ShortVarDecl = IdentifierList ":=" ExpressionList .
</code></pre>
  
  <p>It is shorthand for a regular <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Variable_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">variable declaration</a> with initializer expressions but no types:</p>

<pre><code>"var" IdentifierList = ExpressionList .
</code></pre>
</blockquote>

<p>Without omitting the type it's not possible, because the syntax of the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Variable_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">variable declaration</a> is:</p>

<pre><code>VarSpec = IdentifierList ( Type [ "=" ExpressionList ] | "=" ExpressionList ) .
</code></pre>

<p>(There is only one optional type for an identifier list with an expression list.)</p>

<p>Also I assume you don't count this as 1 line (which otherwise is valid syntax, but gofmt breaks it into multiple lines):</p>

<pre><code>var (i int = 2; s string = "hi")
</code></pre>

<p>Also if you only want to be able to explicitly state the types, you may provide them on the right side:</p>

<pre><code>var i, s = int(2), string("hi")
</code></pre>

<p>But all in all, just use 2 lines for 2 different types, nothing to lose, readability to win.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T16:45:07.730" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T16:45:07.730" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45089248      <row Id="45089248" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45089362" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45089248" CreationDate="2017-07-13T19:22:57.873" Score="3" Body="<p>That's what the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>bufio</code></a> package is for. It lets you turn any <code>io.Reader</code> into a buffered reader with <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#NewReader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>NewReader</code></a>, or any <code>io.Writer</code> into a buffered writer with <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#NewWriter" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>NewWriter</code></a>.</p>

<p>(Whether buffered IO will actually help with your specific problem, I have no idea...)</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T19:22:57.873" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45088229      <row Id="45088229" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45089928" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45088229" CreationDate="2017-07-13T20:00:01.720" Score="2" Body="<p>Trying to make Go generic is one of the great pitfalls for new Go devs. Stop. You're saving <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/VYzzSS92Yi" rel="nofollow noreferrer">five of lines of code</a>:</p>

<pre><code>for i := len(foos) - 1; i &gt;= 0; i-- {
    if foos[i] == foo1 {
        foos = append(foos[:i], foos[i+1:]...)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Yes, in generic languages, you would wrap those five lines up in to a nice stdlib method, but Go is not a generic language. Trying to do this with reflection is slow, but that's not the reason to avoid it. Reflection is very complicated. It's hard to get it right. You'll spend much more time figuring out <code>Value</code> and chasing weird corner cases than you'll spend rewriting those five lines of code 12 times (including fixing the time you accidentally cut/paste it wrong, and the one time you mess up <code>i--</code>). Just write them.</p>

<p>Just writing the code lets you decide what equality means. It lets you decide whether to stop searching at the first match, or keep going through the whole list. It lets you do what this program needs rather than focusing on what some generic program might someday need.</p>

<p>I love generic programming. Few things make me happier than creating an elegant fold in Haskell. But that's not the way of Go. In Go you generally just write the code, keep it simple and obvious, and move on.</p>

<p>Andy makes a good point that if you have to do this a lot, <code>list</code> may be a better data structure. And I often find that when I have three types that all seem to have parallel methods, it turns out that they should all have been part of a single struct (do you really need separate lists here at all?) But in any case, stay away from reflection unless you have a very specialized problem where you really mean "anything" rather than "one of these short list of things."</p>

<p>(It's noteworthy that you call out <code>append()</code>. I don't think it's possible to write <code>append()</code> in Go. That's why it had to be part of the language rather than a stdlib function. When I started working in Go, I took that as a significant flaw in the language. The longer I've worked in Go, the more I've found it not to matter so much. You just write the code and move on.)</p>
" OwnerUserId="97337" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T20:00:01.720" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45079074      <row Id="45079074" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45091261" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45079074" CreationDate="2017-07-13T21:33:47.170" Score="1" Body="<p>Your best bet is the use the standard library's strconv.. You can make your own wrappers and locale stuff.. Eventually I'd add more error checking and turn this into it's own package, but here is an idea.  If you haven't found a package yet there is a good chance you will have to write your own. For a more general solution, you'd have to think about every possible input.. normalize that per locale and enforce those rules when others are using your tools... That would be a more complex solution given the number of if statements and pieces of logic.. The good part is that you know the type of input <code>strconv.ParseFloat</code> expects.. So all you really have to do is take the user input and transform it to the programmic  standard <a href="http://floating-point-gui.de/formats/fp/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://floating-point-gui.de/formats/fp/</a>. Given numbers are mostly universal, with the exception of commas and decimal points, there shouldn't be many use cases.  You might even be able to generalize further and say there are two main formats.. <a href="https://www.quora.com/Why-do-some-countries-use-a-period-and-others-use-a-comma-to-separate-large-numbers" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://www.quora.com/Why-do-some-countries-use-a-period-and-others-use-a-comma-to-separate-large-numbers</a>, which is largely broken down to Europe et al and British/American.. where German uses the standard almost all of Europe does. Under that assumption there isn't really much to do as the use cases comes down to 2.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "strconv"
    "strings"
)

func normalizeGerman(old string) string {
    s := strings.Replace(old, ",", ".", -1)
    return strings.Replace(s, ".", "", 1)
}
func normalizeAmerican(old string) string {
    return strings.Replace(old, ",", "", -1)
}

var locale map[string]func(string) string

func init() {
    locale = make(map[string]func(string) string)
    locale["DE-DE"] = normalizeGerman
    locale["US"] = normalizeAmerican
}

func main() {
    var f, f2 float64
    var err error
    // german
    if val, ok := locale["DE-DE"]; ok {
        f, err = strconv.ParseFloat(val("1.234,87"), 64)
        if err != nil {
            log.Fatal("german fail", err)
        }
    }
    //american
    if val, ok := locale["US"]; ok {
        f2, err = strconv.ParseFloat(val("1,234.87"), 64)
        if err != nil {
            log.Fatal("american fail", err)
        }
    }

    fmt.Println(f, f2)

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4639336" LastEditorUserId="4639336" LastEditDate="2017-07-13T21:48:05.880" LastActivityDate="2017-07-13T21:48:05.880" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45093551      <row Id="45093551" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45093638" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45093551" CreationDate="2017-07-14T02:23:31.677" Score="2" Body="<p>Declare methods on A that satisfy the interface:</p>

<pre><code>func (a *A) SetName(s string) {
    a.Name = s
}

func (a *A) SetAddress(s string) {
    a.Address = s
}
</code></pre>

<p>Use a slice of that interface in the range:</p>

<pre><code>for _, s := range []myinterface{&amp;B{}, &amp;C{}, &amp;D{}} {
   ...
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/eJV-jnF5jD" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground example</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T02:23:31.677" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45093908      <row Id="45093908" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45093934" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45093908" CreationDate="2017-07-14T03:09:08.897" Score="1" Body="<p>The code in the question is updating the local variable <code>v</code>.  Either change the slice to *model.Post or update the value in the slice using the index operator. The former requires changes to the caller.</p>

<pre><code>func incrementViews(posts []*model.Post) []*model.Post {
    for _, v := range posts { 
        v.Views++
    }
    return posts
}

func incrementViews(posts []model.Post) []model.Post {
    for i := range posts { 
        posts[i].Views++
    }
    return posts
}
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong></p>

<p>Both approaches works, see here: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/90BNOFYaKL" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/90BNOFYaKL</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-07-14T04:27:18.150" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T04:27:18.150" CommentCount="8" />

question:
45093599      <row Id="45093599" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45094163" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45093599" CreationDate="2017-07-14T03:35:39.123" Score="3" Body="<p>The operator <code>:=</code> is used for <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Short_variable_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">short variable declaration</a>. It declares and initializes the variable. </p>

<p>In your first example, you have declared <code>Session</code> variable in global scope and in <code>main</code> function you've declared a new variable having same name in the main scope (as you have used <code>:=</code> operator). Therefore, the <code>Session</code> variable declared in the global scope is unused and hence the error.</p>

<p>In your second example, you have assigned global variable a value using assignment operator <code>=</code> and hence it is not declaring a new <code>Session</code> variable but assigning a value to existing global variable.</p>

<p>Please find an <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/3p1o7ji3yI" rel="nofollow noreferrer">example</a> showing difference between global and local variable.</p>
" OwnerUserId="387670" LastEditorUserId="387670" LastEditDate="2017-07-14T06:56:37.257" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T06:56:37.257" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45075598      <row Id="45075598" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:

question:
45099221      <row Id="45099221" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45099524" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45099221" CreationDate="2017-07-14T09:33:38.600" Score="5" Body="<p>There is an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/crypto/md5/#example_New_file" rel="noreferrer">example</a> in the Golang documentation, which covers your case.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "crypto/md5"
    "fmt"
    "io"
    "log"
    "os"
)

func main() {
    f, err := os.Open("file.txt")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    defer f.Close()

    h := md5.New()
    if _, err := io.Copy(h, f); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    fmt.Printf("%x", h.Sum(nil))
}
</code></pre>

<p>For your case, just make sure to close the files in the loop and not defer them. Or put the logic into a function.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1188357" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T09:33:38.600" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45100021      <row Id="45100021" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45101194" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45100021" CreationDate="2017-07-14T10:53:10.997" Score="1" Body="<p>here is example how you can Unmarshal to string list without any struct.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"
import "encoding/json"

func main() {
    src_json := []byte(`{"fruits":["apple","banana","cherry","date"]}`)
    var m map[string][]string
    err := json.Unmarshal(src_json, &amp;m)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Printf("%v", m["fruits"][0]) //apple
 }
</code></pre>

<p>Or instead of String list you can use
<code>map[string][]interface{}</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="4015178" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T10:53:10.997" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45105177      <row Id="45105177" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45105255" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45105177" CreationDate="2017-07-14T14:20:20.367" Score="2" Body="<p>For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "math"
)

func main() {
    const f = math.MaxFloat64
    fmt.Printf("%[1]T %[1]v\n", f)
    const c = complex(math.MaxFloat64, math.MaxFloat64)
    fmt.Printf("%[1]T %[1]v\n", c)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>float64 1.7976931348623157e+308
complex128 (1.7976931348623157e+308+1.7976931348623157e+308i)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Package math</a></p>

<pre><code>import "math" 
</code></pre>
  
  <p>Floating-point limit values. Max is the largest finite value
  representable by the type. SmallestNonzero is the smallest positive,
  non-zero value representable by the type.</p>

<pre><code>const (
        MaxFloat32             = 3.40282346638528859811704183484516925440e+38  // 2**127 * (2**24 - 1) / 2**23
        SmallestNonzeroFloat32 = 1.401298464324817070923729583289916131280e-45 // 1 / 2**(127 - 1 + 23)

        MaxFloat64             = 1.797693134862315708145274237317043567981e+308 // 2**1023 * (2**53 - 1) / 2**52
        SmallestNonzeroFloat64 = 4.940656458412465441765687928682213723651e-324 // 1 / 2**(1023 - 1 + 52)
)
</code></pre>
</blockquote>

<hr>

<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec" rel="nofollow noreferrer">The Go Programming Language Specification</a></p>
  
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Numeric_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Numeric types</a></p>
  
  <p>A numeric type represents sets of integer or floating-point values.
  The predeclared architecture-independent numeric types are:</p>

<pre><code>uint8       the set of all unsigned  8-bit integers (0 to 255)
uint16      the set of all unsigned 16-bit integers (0 to 65535)
uint32      the set of all unsigned 32-bit integers (0 to 4294967295)
uint64      the set of all unsigned 64-bit integers (0 to 18446744073709551615)

int8        the set of all signed  8-bit integers (-128 to 127)
int16       the set of all signed 16-bit integers (-32768 to 32767)
int32       the set of all signed 32-bit integers (-2147483648 to 2147483647)
int64       the set of all signed 64-bit integers (-9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807)

float32     the set of all IEEE-754 32-bit floating-point numbers
float64     the set of all IEEE-754 64-bit floating-point numbers

complex64   the set of all complex numbers with float32 real and imaginary parts
complex128  the set of all complex numbers with float64 real and imaginary parts

byte        alias for uint8
rune        alias for int32
</code></pre>
  
  <p>The value of an n-bit integer is n bits wide and represented using
  two's complement arithmetic.</p>
  
  <p>There is also a set of predeclared numeric types with
  implementation-specific sizes:</p>

<pre><code>uint     either 32 or 64 bits
int      same size as uint
uintptr  an unsigned integer large enough to store the uninterpreted bits of a pointer value
</code></pre>
  
  <p>To avoid portability issues all numeric types are distinct except
  byte, which is an alias for uint8, and rune, which is an alias for
  int32. Conversions are required when different numeric types are mixed
  in an expression or assignment. For instance, int32 and int are not
  the same type even though they may have the same size on a particular
  architecture.</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-07-14T14:54:53.060" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T14:54:53.060" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45106090      <row Id="45106090" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45106183" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45106090" CreationDate="2017-07-14T15:03:55.697" Score="4" Body="<p>"Reading" has more meanings, one of which is reading the contents of a file.</p>

<p>Another meaning is if the file denotes a directory, you may read its content, which is the list of the files / subfolders in it, using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Readdir" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Readdir()</code></a> or <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Readdirnames" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Readdirnames()</code></a>. This is perfectly valid for an opened file whose name denotes a directory.</p>

<p>Also you may do a lot more with an opened <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>os.File</code></a> even if it denotes a folder, e.g. call its <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Chdir" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Chdir()</code></a> (exclusive for directories) or <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Chmod" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Chmod()</code></a> methods, or get statistics about it using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Stat" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Stat()</code></a>. I don't see why "opening" a folder should be disallowed. The wording in the doc may not be perfect (or it could be extended to mention this though).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-14T15:13:00.563" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T15:13:00.563" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45085866      <row Id="45085866" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45106524" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45085866" CreationDate="2017-07-14T15:21:10.400" Score="2" Body="<p>When using JWT, the client typically have to specify the token itself. To make the token handling to be seamless for the client, you can send the token back as a cookie. You can configure echo's middleware to extract the token from a cookie:</p>

<pre><code>// ...
r.Use(middleware.JWTWithConfig(middleware.JWTConfig{
    SigningKey: []byte("secret"),
    TokenLookup: "cookie:Authorization",
}))
</code></pre>

<p>For this to work you will need to send the token back as a cookie in your login handler:</p>

<pre><code>// ...
c.SetCookie(http.Cookie{
    Name: "Authorization",
    Value: t,
    Path: "/root/path",
    Domain: "your.domain.com",
    HttpOnly: true,
})
return c.JSON(http.StatusOK, map[string]string{
    "token": t,
})
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1147580" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T15:21:10.400" CommentCount="1" />

question:

<row Id="45107236" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45106922" CreationDate="2017-07-14T16:00:25.143" Score="2" Body="<pre><code>fmt.Printf(string([]byte{0x1b,'[', '3', 'J'}))
</code></pre>
