try <a href="https://www.xfree86.org/4.8.0/ctlseqs.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">xterm-docu</a> but your
mileage may vary, as you use different terminal emulators.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7824574" LastEditorUserId="7824574" LastEditDate="2017-07-14T16:08:06.737" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T16:08:06.737" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45105654      <row Id="45105654" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45107659" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45105654" CreationDate="2017-07-14T16:24:52.953" Score="1" Body="<p>Use a map for dynamic keys:</p>

<pre><code>type ElvisEvent struct {
    Timestamp int64  `json:"timestamp"`
    Type      string `json:"type"`
    AssetID   string `json:"assetId"`
    Metadata  struct {
    } `json:"metadata"`

    ChangedMetadata map[string]struct {
        OldValue interface{} `json:"oldValue"`
        NewValue interface{} `json:"newValue"`
    } `json:"changedMetadata"`
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/7_9VS_hcfM" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground example</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-07-17T00:55:47.337" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T00:55:47.337" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45108777      <row Id="45108777" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45109737" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45108777" CreationDate="2017-07-14T18:42:07.393" Score="4" Body="<p>Writing unit tests consists of:</p>

<ul>
<li>Providing known state for all of your inputs.</li>
<li>Testing that, given all meaning combinations of those inputs, you receive the expected outputs.</li>
</ul>

<p>So you need to first identify your inputs:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>s Summoner</code></li>
<li><code>name string</code></li>
<li><code>region string</code></li>
</ul>

<p>Plus a "hidden" inputs, by way of globals:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>client := &amp;http.Client{}</code></li>
</ul>

<p>And your outputs are:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>summoner *Summoner</code></li>
<li><code>err error</code></li>
</ul>

<p>(There can also be "hidden" outputs, if you write files, or change global variables, but you don't appear to do that here).</p>

<p>Now the first three inputs are easy to create from scratch for your tests:  Just provide an empty <code>Summoner{}</code> (since you don't read or set that at all in your function, there's no need to set it other than to an empty value).  <code>name</code> and <code>region</code> can simply be set to strings.</p>

<p>The only part remaining is your <code>http.Client</code>.  At minimum, you should probably pass that in as an argument. Not only does this give you control over your tests, but it allows you to use easily use different client in production in the future.</p>

<p>But to ease testing, you might consider actually passing in a client-like interface, which you can easily mock. The only method you call on <code>client</code> is <code>Do</code>, so you could easily create a <code>Doer</code> interface:</p>

<pre><code>type doer interface {
    Do(req *Request) (*Response, error)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then change your function signature to take that as one argument:</p>

<pre><code>func (s Summoner) ByName(client doer, name string, region string) (summoner *Summoner, err error) {
</code></pre>

<p>Now, in your test you can create a custom type that fulfills the <code>doer</code> interface, and responds with any <code>http.Response</code> you like, without needing to use a server in your tests.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T18:42:07.393" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45107175      <row Id="45107175" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45109903" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45107175" CreationDate="2017-07-14T18:54:19.827" Score="1" Body="<p>The <code>c-shared</code> <a href="https://golang.org/cmd/go/#hdr-Description_of_build_modes" rel="nofollow noreferrer">buildmode</a> is currently only supported on Linux. </p>

<p>As seen here, <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40573401/building-a-dll-with-go-1-7">Building a dll with Go 1.7</a>, you may be able to build a DLL or shared lib using gcc, but it's not supported directly by the Go toolchain.</p>

<p>However, if you're looking to create a "plugin" architecture, you don't want to create a C shared library, in which each instance creates a new Go runtime. There is already a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/plugin/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>plugin</code> package</a> which is intended for that purpose. </p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T18:54:19.827" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45110223      <row Id="45110223" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45110421" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45110223" CreationDate="2017-07-14T19:34:04.867" Score="2" Body="<p>You can use <a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#embedding" rel="nofollow noreferrer">struct embeding</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

type foo struct {
    a int
}

func (f *foo) bar() {
    f.a = 42
}

type foo2 struct {
    foo
}

func main() {
    f := foo{12}
    f.bar()
    f2 := foo2{}
    f2.a = 0
    f2.bar()
    fmt.Println(f)
    fmt.Println(f2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Just create struct and use foo as one of its members. Don't give it explicit name</p>

<pre><code>type foo2 struct {
    foo
}
</code></pre>

<p>That way all methods of foo will be available for foo2.</p>

<p>Note that output of this program will be:</p>

<pre><code>{42}
{{42}}
</code></pre>

<p>More effective way of achieving what I suppose you want to do, will come with new Go 1.9: <a href="https://tip.golang.org/doc/go1.9#language" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tip.golang.org/doc/go1.9#language</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8307258" LastActivityDate="2017-07-14T19:34:04.867" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45111605      <row Id="45111605" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45114054" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45111605" CreationDate="2017-07-15T03:02:33.613" Score="4" Body="<p>Yes. </p>

<p>Here's an example of having 2 fields in json and only decoding one:</p>

<pre><code>jsonString := `{"a": 1, "b": 2}`
var rec struct {
    A int `json:"a"`
}
err := json.Unmarshal([]byte(jsonString), &amp;rec)
if err != nil {
    log.Fatalf("json.Unmarshal() failed with '%s'\n", err)
}
fmt.Printf("rec: %+v\n", rec)
</code></pre>

<p>When run it prints:</p>

<pre><code>rec: {A:1}
</code></pre>

<p>i.e. field "a" in json was decoded and field "b" was discarded.</p>

<p>See <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/89tu-ZC4pR" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/89tu-ZC4pR</a> for full example.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2898" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T03:02:33.613" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45115860      <row Id="45115860" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45116062" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45115860" CreationDate="2017-07-15T08:15:18.707" Score="1" Body="<p>Go-kit and go-micro are for writing microservices, it won't solve your problem.</p>

<p>You should use a reverse proxy in front of your applications, for instance Nginx: <a href="https://www.nginx.com/resources/admin-guide/reverse-proxy/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://www.nginx.com/resources/admin-guide/reverse-proxy/</a></p>

<p>Here is an example of a nginx configuration file that does what you want:</p>

<pre><code>server {
   listen 80 default_server;
   server_name your-domain;

   location /app1 {
      proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
      proxy_pass http://localhost:3000;
   }

   location /app2 {
      proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
      proxy_pass http://localhost:4000;
   }
}
</code></pre>

<p>This way, you still deploy your applications on different ports, but they will only be exposed through the port 80.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1061579" LastEditorUserId="1061579" LastEditDate="2017-07-15T10:52:47.507" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T10:52:47.507" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45116232      <row Id="45116232" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45116673" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45116232" CreationDate="2017-07-15T09:32:14.350" Score="2" Body="<p>The instruction</p>

<pre><code>var points = make(chan float64)
</code></pre>

<p>creates an unbuffered channel, which in turn means that </p>

<pre><code>points &lt;- contributions_sum(input, distance, input[i][x_ln])
</code></pre>

<p>will block until another go-routine reads from points.</p>

<p>Considering that all the go-routines in the code you posted perform a send on the channel before reading from it, they will all block waiting for a read on the same channel that will never happen (unless this is done in the code you didn't post, which you should have). As a result, you have a deadlock (which is usually written, is the error you quoted everything the console displays?). </p>
" OwnerUserId="4866324" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T09:32:14.350" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45113907      <row Id="45113907" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45116926" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45113907" CreationDate="2017-07-15T10:01:23.300" Score="1" Body="<p>The problem appears to be the <code>,</code> char in your first regex.  You can see in the validator <a href="https://github.com/go-validator/validator/blob/v2/validator.go#L332" rel="nofollow noreferrer">source code</a> that the tag is split on <code>,</code>. By UTSLing, I see no support for escaped commas in the tags; this is probably an oversight on the part of the project author. I suggest filing a bug/feature request.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T10:01:23.300" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45117214      <row Id="45117214" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45117401" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45117214" CreationDate="2017-07-15T10:58:51.370" Score="3" Body="<p>The way to fix this is to force colors from the minecraft server. It's not a problem with your Go program at all.  It's very common for command-line programs to detect whether they're running on an interactive terminal, and disable certain features (such as color output, paging, etc) when they are not, under the assumption that they're being passed through a script (as indeed it is, in your case).</p>

<p>If the minecraft server doesn't have this option, you may be able to <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/1401002/13860">fool it into thinking it's running on an interactive terminal</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T10:58:51.370" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45109397      <row Id="45109397" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45118253" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45109397" CreationDate="2017-07-15T12:33:09.463" Score="2" Body="<p>you can do what you want by using, this packages <a href="https://github.com/tidwall/gjson" rel="nofollow noreferrer">gjson</a>,  and <a href="https://github.com/tidwall/sjson" rel="nofollow noreferrer">sjson</a>.</p>

<p>example: </p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "strconv"

    "github.com/tidwall/gjson"
    "github.com/tidwall/sjson"
)

func main() {
    bJSON := []byte(`       
            [
                {
                    "name": "abc",
                    "age": 25
                },
                {
                    "name": "xyz",
                    "age": 26
                }
            ]
    `)

    newJSON := bJSON
    var err error

    result := gjson.GetBytes(bJSON, "#.age")

    for i := range result.Array() {
        newJSON, err = sjson.DeleteBytes(newJSON, strconv.Itoa(i)+".age")
        if err != nil {
            log.Println(err)
        }
    }

    fmt.Println(string(newJSON))
}
</code></pre>

<p>output:</p>

<pre><code>[
  {
    "name": "abc"
  },
  {
    "name": "xyz"
  }
]
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5427367" LastEditorUserId="5427367" LastEditDate="2017-07-23T13:43:43.953" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T13:43:43.953" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45120927      <row Id="45120927" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45121313" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45120927" CreationDate="2017-07-15T18:10:31.070" Score="2" Body="<p>Are you sure key is <code>artists</code> in the yaml? Do you mean to supply <code>artist</code>?</p>

<p>Working example:</p>

<pre><code>str := []byte(`artist:
  name: The Beatles
  albums:
  - name: The White Album
    year: 1968
  - name: Abbey Road
    year: 1969
`)

    viper.SetConfigType("yaml")
    viper.ReadConfig(bytes.NewBuffer(str))

    var artist Artist
    err := viper.UnmarshalKey("artist", &amp;artist)

    fmt.Printf("%v, %#v\n", err, artist)
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;nil&gt;, main.Artist{Name:"The Beatles", Albums:[]main.Album{main.Album{Name:"The White Album", Year:1968}, main.Album{Name:"Abbey Road", Year:1969}}}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T18:10:31.070" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44961304      <row Id="44961304" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45122016" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44961304" CreationDate="2017-07-15T19:29:02.410" Score="0" Body="<p>After hours of reading BeeGo and Sentry codes I figured out how to implement this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "errors"
    "fmt"
    "net/http"
    "runtime"

    "github.com/astaxie/beego"
    "github.com/astaxie/beego/context"
    "github.com/astaxie/beego/logs"
    "github.com/getsentry/raven-go"
)

func init() {
    raven.SetDSN(beego.AppConfig.String("SentryDSN"))

    if !beego.BConfig.RecoverPanic {
        beego.BConfig.RecoverFunc = recoverPanic
    }
}

func recoverPanic(ctx *context.Context) {
    if err := recover(); err != nil {
        if err == beego.ErrAbort {
            return
        }
        if !beego.BConfig.RecoverPanic {
            errStr := fmt.Sprint(err)
            packet := raven.NewPacket(errStr, raven.NewException(errors.New(errStr), raven.NewStacktrace(2, 3, nil)), raven.NewHttp(ctx.Request))
            raven.Capture(packet, nil)
            ctx.ResponseWriter.WriteHeader(http.StatusInternalServerError)
        }

        //if beego.BConfig.EnableErrorsShow {
        //  if _, ok := beego.ErrorMaps[fmt.Sprint(err)]; ok {
        //      exception(fmt.Sprint(err), ctx)
        //      return
        //  }
        //}
        var stack string
        logs.Critical("the request url is ", ctx.Input.URL())
        logs.Critical("Handler crashed with error", err)
        for i := 1; ; i++ {
            _, file, line, ok := runtime.Caller(i)
            if !ok {
                break
            }
            logs.Critical(fmt.Sprintf("%s:%d", file, line))
            stack = stack + fmt.Sprintln(fmt.Sprintf("%s:%d", file, line))
        }
        //if beego.BConfig.RunMode == beego.DEV &amp;&amp; beego.BConfig.EnableErrorsRender {
        //  showErr(err, ctx, stack)
        //}

    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2837388" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T19:29:02.410" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45122513      <row Id="45122513" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45122607" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45122513" CreationDate="2017-07-15T20:48:40.440" Score="3" Body="<p>You write to <code>io.Pipe</code> but you never read from it (in a parallel go routine), hence the deadlock. Here is what the docs say:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Reads and Writes on the pipe are matched one to one except when multiple Reads are needed to consume a single Write. That is, <strong>each Write to the PipeWriter blocks until it has satisfied one or more Reads from the PipeReader</strong> that fully consume the written data. The data is copied directly from the Write to the corresponding Read (or Reads); there is no internal buffering.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Pipe" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Pipe</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="2788297" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T20:48:40.440" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45064827      <row Id="45064827" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45122748" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45064827" CreationDate="2017-07-15T21:08:38.517" Score="0" Body="<p>Generally speaking validation functions are meant to validate any configs (possibly combined with variables). These run as part of <code>terraform plan</code>, <code>terraform apply</code> and <code>terraform destroy</code>. The user can also trigger explicit validation via <code>terraform validate</code> which is commonly used in CI.</p>

<p>Assuming that "Range" is meant to limit minimum &amp; maximum number of characters in a given string you can use <a href="https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform/blob/master/helper/validation/validation.go#L93" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>StringLenBetween</code> from the validation package</a>.</p>

<pre><code>Schema: map[string]*schema.Schema{
    "number_of_servers": {
        Type:     schema.TypeString,
        Required: true,
        ValidateFunc: validation.StringLenBetween(1, 5),
    },
</code></pre>

<p>You can see it being used in practice here:
<a href="https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-aws/blob/46bff11/aws/resource_aws_cloudwatch_event_target.go#L71-L75" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-aws/blob/46bff11/aws/resource_aws_cloudwatch_event_target.go#L71-L75</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="335717" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T21:08:38.517" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45122905      <row Id="45122905" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45123114" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45122905" CreationDate="2017-07-15T22:05:06.470" Score="7" Body="<p><code>struct</code> is a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Keywords" rel="nofollow noreferrer">keyword</a> in Go. It is used to define <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Struct_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">struct types</a>, which is a sequence of named elements.</p>

<p>For example:</p>

<pre><code>type Person struct {
    Name string
    Age  int
}
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>struct{}</code> is a <code>struct</code> type with zero elements. It is often used when no information is to be stored. It has the benefits of being 0-sized, so usually no memory is required to store a value of type <code>struct{}</code>.</p>

<p><code>struct{}{}</code> on the other hand is a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Composite_literals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">composite literal</a>, it constructs a value of type <code>struct{}</code>. A composite literal constructs values for types such as structs, arrays, maps and slices. Its syntax is the type followed by the elements in braces. Since the "empty" struct (<code>struct{}</code>) has no fields, the elements list is also empty:</p>

<pre><code> struct{}  {}
|  ^     | ^
  type     empty element list
</code></pre>

<p>As an example let's create a "set" in Go. Go does not have a builtin set data structure, but it has a builtin map. We can use a map as a set, as a map can only have at most one entry with a given key. And since we want to only store keys (elements) in the map, we may choose the map value type to be <code>struct{}</code>.</p>

<p>A map with <code>string</code> elements:</p>

<pre><code>var set map[string]struct{}
// Initialize the set
set = make(map[string]struct{})

// Add some values to the set:
set["red"] = struct{}{}
set["blue"] = struct{}{}

// Check if a value is in the map:
_, ok := set["red"]
fmt.Println("Is red in the map?", ok)
_, ok = set["green"]
fmt.Println("Is green in the map?", ok)
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/zvQU9E6m6J" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Is red in the map? true
Is green in the map? false
</code></pre>

<p>Note that however it may be more convenient to use <code>bool</code> as the value type when creating a set out of a map, as the syntax to check if an element is in it is simpler. For details, see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33207197/how-can-i-create-an-array-that-contains-unique-strings/33207265#33207265">How can I create an array that contains unique strings?</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-15T23:15:49.487" LastActivityDate="2017-07-15T23:15:49.487" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45122496      <row Id="45122496" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45123370" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45122496" CreationDate="2017-07-15T22:40:50.307" Score="3" Body="<p>As stated in the documentation:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Unmarshal uses the inverse of the encodings that Marshal uses, allocating maps, slices, and pointers as necessary, with ... </p>
</blockquote>

<p><code>Unmarshal</code> may allocates the variable(map, slice, etc.). If we pass a <code>map</code> instead of <em>pointer</em> to a <code>map</code>, then the newly allocated <code>map</code> won't be visible to the caller. The following examples (<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/LHBEFiK_Hj" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>) demonstrates this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

func mapFunc(m map[string]interface{}) {
    m = make(map[string]interface{})
    m["abc"] = "123"
}

func mapPtrFunc(mp *map[string]interface{}) {
    m := make(map[string]interface{})
    m["abc"] = "123"

    *mp = m
}

func main() {
    var m1, m2 map[string]interface{}
    mapFunc(m1)
    mapPtrFunc(&amp;m2)

    fmt.Printf("%+v, %+v\n", m1, m2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>in which the output is:</p>

<pre><code>map[], map[abc:123]
</code></pre>

<p>If the requirement says that a function/method may allocate a variable when necessary and the newly allocated variable need to be visible to the caller, the solution will be: (a) the variable must be in function's <em>return</em> statement <strong>or</strong> (b) the variable can be assigned to the function/method argument. Since in <code>go</code> <em>everything</em> is pass by value, in case of (b), the argument must be a <em>pointer</em>. The following diagram illustrates what happen in the above example:</p>

<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/J3WUp.jpg" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/J3WUp.jpg" alt="Illustration of variable allocation"></a>   </p>

<ol>
<li>At first, both map <code>m1</code> and <code>m2</code> point to <code>nil</code>.</li>
<li>Calling <code>mapFunc</code> will copy the value pointed by <code>m1</code> to <code>m</code> resulting <code>m</code> will also point to <code>nil</code> map.</li>
<li>If in (1) the map already allocated, then in (2) the address of <em>underlying map data structure</em> pointed by <code>m1</code> (<em>not the address of <code>m1</code></em>) will be copied to <code>m</code>. In this case both <code>m1</code> and <code>m</code> point to the same <em>map data structure</em>, thus modifying map items through <code>m1</code> will also be <em>visible</em> to <code>m</code>. </li>
<li>In the <code>mapFunc</code> function, new map is allocated and assigned to <code>m</code>. There is no way to assign it to <code>m1</code>. </li>
</ol>

<p>In case of pointer:</p>

<ol>
<li>When calling <code>mapPtrFunc</code>, the address of <code>m2</code> will be copied to <code>mp</code>.  </li>
<li>In the <code>mapPtrFunc</code>, new map is allocated and assigned to <code>*mp</code> (not <code>mp</code>). Since <code>mp</code> is pointer to <code>m2</code>, assigning the new map to <code>*mp</code> will change the value pointed by <code>m2</code>. Note that the value of <code>mp</code> is unchanged, i.e. the address of <code>m2</code>.  </li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-07-16T00:58:21.930" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T00:58:21.930" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45124213      <row Id="45124213" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45124551" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45124213" CreationDate="2017-07-16T02:58:10.910" Score="2" Body="<p>About (1), I think the issue is related to your benchmarks not doing what the Go tools expect them to do.</p>

<p>From the documentation (<a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#hdr-Benchmarks" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#hdr-Benchmarks</a>):</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The benchmark function must run the target code b.N times. During benchmark execution, b.N is adjusted until the benchmark function lasts long enough to be timed reliably.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>I don't see your code using <code>b.N</code>, so while the benchmark tool <em>thinks</em> you run the code <code>b.N</code> times, you are managing the repeats by yourself. Depending on the values the tools are actually using for <code>b.N</code>, the results will vary unexpectedly.</p>

<p>You can actually do things 10, 100 and 1,000 times, but in all cases do them <code>b.N</code> times (make that <code>b.N * 10</code>, <code>b.N * 100</code>, etc) so that the reported benchmark is adjusted properly.</p>

<p>About (2), when some systems rather use a sequential log to store operations to the replay them, it's not because appending to a file is faster than overwriting a single file.</p>

<p>In a database system, if you need to update a specific record, you must first find what's the actual file (and position in the file) you need to update.</p>

<p>That might require several index lookups, and once you update the record, you might need to update those indexes to reflect the new values.</p>

<p>So the right comparison is appending to a single log vs making several reads plus then several writes.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T02:58:10.910" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45125118      <row Id="45125118" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45125756" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45125118" CreationDate="2017-07-16T06:30:19.543" Score="0" Body="<p>Firebase is the simplest way to deploy your frontend on Google's infrastructure.  It handles certificate provisioning for you, so you get HTTPS out of the box.  I'm not sure why you think Cloud Functions is the only backend you can use with it.  You can use any backend you like, including Amazon's ElasticBeanstalk.  I use both App Engine and Compute Engine backends with a Firebase frontend.</p>

<p>You could also do it the "old way" (how it was done when App Engine was Google's only cloud offering), and deploy your frontend to App Engine; it handles static content just fine.</p>

<p>There's not a single right way to do it.  Your options are vast, and choosing one service to serve your frontend content in no way limits your choice for running your backend.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1427098" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T06:30:19.543" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45125542      <row Id="45125542" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45125797" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45125542" CreationDate="2017-07-16T06:35:41.790" Score="1" Body="<p>You may use the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/path/filepath/#Glob" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>filepath.Glob()</code></a> function where you can specify a <em>pattern</em> to list files.</p>

<p>The pattern to be used is basically the name you wish to check if used, extended with the <em>any extension</em> pattern.</p>

<p>Example:</p>

<pre><code>func filenameUsed(name string) (bool, error) {
    matches, err := filepath.Glob(name + ".*")
    if err != nil {
        return false, err
    }
    return len(matches) &gt; 0, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Using / testing it:</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Print("Filename foo used: ")
fmt.Println(filenameUsed("uploads/foo"))
fmt.Print("Filename bar used: ")
fmt.Println(filenameUsed("uploads/bar"))
</code></pre>

<p>Example output:</p>

<pre><code>Filename foo used: true &lt;nil&gt;
Filename bar used: false &lt;nil&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>However, note that <code>filenameUsed()</code> returning <code>false</code> (and <code>nil</code> error) does not mean a file with that name won't exist if you attempt to create one after. Meaning checking it and attempting to create such a file does not guarantee atomicity. If your purpose is to create a file if the name is not used, then simply try to create the file in the proper mode (do not overwrite if exists), and handle the (creation) error returned by that call.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-16T06:41:40.723" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T06:41:40.723" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45126312      <row Id="45126312" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45126402" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45126312" CreationDate="2017-07-16T08:08:38.317" Score="1" Body="<p>You may create and use an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#Request" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>http.Request</code></a> forged by you, which deliberately returns an error when reading its body. You don't necessarily need a whole new request, a faulty body is enough (which is an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#ReadCloser" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.ReadCloser</code></a>).</p>

<p>Simplest achieved by using the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/httptest/#NewRequest" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>httptest.NewRequest()</code></a> function where you can pass an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Reader</code></a> value which will be used (wrapped to be an <code>io.ReadCloser</code>) as the request body.</p>

<p>Here's an example <code>io.Reader</code> which deliberately returns an error when attempting to read from it:</p>

<pre><code>type errReader int

func (errReader) Read(p []byte) (n int, err error) {
    return 0, errors.New("test error")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Example that will cover your error case:</p>

<pre><code>func HandlePostRequest(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    body, err := ioutil.ReadAll(r.Body)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Printf("Error reading the body: %v\n", err)
        return
    }
    defer r.Body.Close()
    fmt.Printf("No error, body: %s\n", body)
}

func main() {
    testRequest := httptest.NewRequest(http.MethodPost, "/something", errReader(0))
    HandlePostRequest(nil, testRequest)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/i0Rd9Z6rnE" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>): </p>

<pre><code>Error reading the body: test error
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="797194" LastEditDate="2017-07-23T07:37:50.740" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T07:37:50.740" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45127882      <row Id="45127882" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45128040" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45127882" CreationDate="2017-07-16T11:30:40.587" Score="1" Body="<p>The <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/strings/#Join" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><strong>strings.Join</strong></a> method expects a slice of strings as first argument, but you are giving it a rune type.</p>

<p>You can use the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/strings/#Split" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><strong>strings.Split</strong></a> method to obtain a slice of strings from a string. <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/P4Bfac30uJ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Here is an example</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1513091" LastEditorUserId="1513091" LastEditDate="2017-07-16T11:45:16.457" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T11:45:16.457" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44826376      <row Id="44826376" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45128688" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44826376" CreationDate="2017-07-16T12:36:21.367" Score="0" Body="<p>Following my own question, I researched how one could implement UnmarshalJSON for interface lists. Ultimately this led me to publish a blog post on how to do this properly. Basically there are 2 main solutions:</p>

<ol>
<li>Parse the required JSON string into a <code>map[string]*json.RawMessage</code> and work your way from there.</li>
<li>Make an alias for the interface list and implement UnmarshalJSON for that alias. However, you'll still need to work with <code>map[string]*json.RawMessage</code> and some manual work. Nothing comes without a price!</li>
</ol>

<p>I highly suggest taking the seconds approach. While these two solutions may result in the same amount of code lines, taking advantage of type aliasing and being less dependent on <code>json.RawMessage</code> types will make a more easy to manage code, especially when it is required to support multiple interfaces on the UnmarshalJSON implementation</p>

<p>To directly answer the question, start with making a type alias for the interface list:</p>

<pre><code>type Filterers []Filterer
</code></pre>

<p>Now continue with implementing the decoding of the JSON:</p>

<pre><code>func (f *Filterers) UnmarshalJSON(b []byte) error {
    var FilterFields map[string]*json.RawMessage
    if err := json.Unmarshal(b, &amp;FilterFields); err != nil {
        return err
    }
    for LFKey, LFValue := range FilterFields {
        if LFKey == "FieldFilter" {
            var MyFieldFilters []*json.RawMessage
            if err := json.Unmarshal(*LFValue, &amp;MyFieldFilters); err != nil {
                return err
            }
            for _, MyFieldFilter := range MyFieldFilters {
                var filter FieldFilter
                if err := json.Unmarshal(*MyFieldFilter, &amp;filter); err != nil {
                    return err
                }
                *f = append(*f, &amp;filter)
            }
        }
    }
    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>A detailed explanation (with some examples and a full working code snippets) of the second approach is available <a href="https://0rka.blog/2017/07/13/unmarshalling-json-structs-containing-interfaces-in-go/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">on my own blog</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="6691722" LastEditorUserId="6691722" LastEditDate="2017-07-16T12:51:12.963" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T12:51:12.963" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45130826      <row Id="45130826" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45133431" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45130826" CreationDate="2017-07-16T21:24:09.617" Score="1" Body="<p>AFAIK there is no ready solution yet to access location on both Android and iOS in  a platform independent way. But in theory you could make separate packages using the <code>gomobile</code> tool to generate bindings for each platform. </p>

<p>For example on Android you would use something like:</p>

<pre><code>import "Java/android/content/Context"
import "Java/android/location/LocationManager"

locationManager := ctx.GetSystemService(Context.LOCATION_SERVICE)
// nil check omitted.
location := locationManager.GetLastKnownLocation(LocationManager.GPS_PROVIDER)
// nil check omitted.
lat := location.GetLatitude()
lng := location.GetLongitude()
</code></pre>

<p>Where <code>ctx</code> is the context (an activity, service, etc.) that you receive in one of their lifecycle callbacks.</p>

<p>Also you can use other providers (network, fused).</p>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastEditorUserId="4283005" LastEditDate="2017-07-16T21:39:06.013" LastActivityDate="2017-07-16T21:39:06.013" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45134172      <row Id="45134172" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45134241" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45134172" CreationDate="2017-07-16T23:35:15.323" Score="1" Body="<p>You can compare function like this, Read more about the representation of functions here: <a href="http://golang.org/s/go11func" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://golang.org/s/go11func</a></p>

<pre><code>func funcEqual(a, b interface{}) bool {
    av := reflect.ValueOf(&amp;a).Elem()
    bv := reflect.ValueOf(&amp;b).Elem()
    return av.InterfaceData() == bv.InterfaceData()
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>For example:</strong> This is just an idea for your start point.</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    a := []someFunc{sf1, sf2}
    b := []someFunc{sf1, sf2}

    for idx, f := range a {
        fmt.Println("Index: ", idx, funcEqual(f, b[idx]))
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>Index:  0 true
Index:  1 true
</code></pre>

<p>Play link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/6cSVXSYfa5" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/6cSVXSYfa5</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-17T01:30:13.747" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T01:30:13.747" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45134378      <row Id="45134378" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45134481" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45134378" CreationDate="2017-07-17T00:20:59.477" Score="4" Body="<p>Typically import path starts after <code>$GOPATH/src</code>, refer to <a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html#ImportPaths" rel="nofollow noreferrer">doc</a>.</p>

<p>Let's say you have directory structure:</p>

<pre><code>$GOPATH/src/github.com/hithubuser/app/utils

# your import path is 'github.com/hithubuser/app/utils'
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>Do you write a full the path for all the imports or you avoid to make it?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Yes, generally full import is used, since it enables you to distribute your code as go library. So that you can develop reusable code and import it in any project as needed or you can publish it to Go community.</p>

<hr>

<p>Let's say you have standalone project, not referred to any other Go project and you're distributing as binary instead of go library. Then you can to something like this (it is not commonly used/recommended though).</p>

<p>Just git clone your repo at <code>$GOPATH/src</code> like <code>git clone github.com/hithubuser/app</code></p>

<pre><code>$GOPATH/src/app/utils

# then import path is app/utils
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-17T06:52:48.290" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T06:52:48.290" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45134127      <row Id="45134127" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45135395" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45134127" CreationDate="2017-07-17T03:06:58.760" Score="3" Body="<p>In order to be able to modify what <code>t.A</code> points to, you need to send a reference to it to your <code>CopyValue</code> function.</p>

<pre><code>CopyValue(vptr, &amp;t.A) // (note the &amp;)
</code></pre>

<p>You can then assign the pointer to the new address:</p>

<pre><code>func CopyValue(src interface{}, dest interface{}) {
    srcRef := reflect.ValueOf(src)
    vp := reflect.ValueOf(dest)
    vp.Elem().Set(srcRef)
}
</code></pre>

<p>See the 3rd "law of reflection" here: <a href="https://blog.golang.org/laws-of-reflection" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/laws-of-reflection</a></p>

<p>Full working code:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "reflect"
)

type T struct {
    A *int
}

func main() {
    t := &amp;T{}
    v := 1
    vptr := &amp;v
    CopyValue(vptr, &amp;t.A) // we pass a reference to t.A since we want to modify it
    fmt.Printf("%v\n", *t.A)
}

func CopyValue(src interface{}, dest interface{}) {
    srcRef := reflect.ValueOf(src)
    vp := reflect.ValueOf(dest)
    vp.Elem().Set(srcRef)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T03:06:58.760" CommentCount="0" />

<row Id="45140610" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45140270" CreationDate="2017-07-17T09:33:16.880" Score="1" Body="<p>You can try this: ( <a href="http://ideone.com/ncDO0t" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Run here</a> )</p>

question:
45139954      <row Id="45139954" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45140983" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45139954" CreationDate="2017-07-17T09:50:11.710" Score="1" Body="<p>You could use an interface like this and an if statement to get it back to whatever struct it orginated as tho.</p>

<pre><code>import (
    "fmt"
)

type ReturnValue struct {
   Status string
   CustomStruct interface{}
} 

func GetReturn(status string, class interface{}){
   var result = ReturnValue {Status : status, CustomStruct: class}

   fmt.Println(result)

   msg, ok := result.CustomStruct.(Message1)
   if ok {
      fmt.Printf("Message1 is %s\n", msg.message)
   }
}

type Message1 struct {
   message string
}

type Message2 struct {
   message string
}

func main(){
   var m1 = Message1 {message: "Hello1"}
   GetReturn("success",  m1)

   var m2 = Message2 {message: "Hello2"}
   GetReturn("success",  m2)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/L6VYV80x27" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/L6VYV80x27</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="450333" LastEditorUserId="436560" LastEditDate="2017-07-17T10:17:20.430" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T10:17:20.430" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45145873      <row Id="45145873" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45146212" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45145873" CreationDate="2017-07-17T13:55:46.147" Score="-1" Body="<p>"c" is an interface{} type, Having an interface in function parameter, you can able to pass any struct or any data types into it.</p>

<pre><code>In your case you want c to use the function write
if err := c.Write(bp); err != nil {
        log.Print("write failed " + err)
    }
</code></pre>

<p>The compiler doesn't know the type of c, so you need to type assert it.  </p>

<p>Try this, It will work  </p>

<pre><code>newC,ok:=  c.(type of c)    type of C -&gt; a struct or any type which has a method write

if ok {
    if err := newC.Write(bp); err != nil {
            log.Print("write failed " + err)
        }

}     
</code></pre>

<p>Or Change your function like this</p>

<pre><code>func writeToInflux(c client.Client, host string, service string, state string) bool
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7064515" LastEditorUserId="1147580" LastEditDate="2017-07-17T16:14:45.220" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T16:14:45.220" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45148775      <row Id="45148775" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45148776" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45148775" CreationDate="2017-07-17T16:02:10.547" Score="4" Body="<p>This can be achieved using the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/flag/#VisitAll" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>VisitAll</code></a> function.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>VisitAll visits the command-line flags in lexicographical order, calling fn for each. It visits all flags, even those not set.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Sample code (add after <code>flag.Parse()</code>): </p>

<pre><code>flag.VisitAll(func (f *flag.Flag) {
    if f.Value.String()=="" {
        fmt.Println(f.Name, "not set!")
    }
})
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4926817" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T16:02:10.547" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45084589      <row Id="45084589" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45151842" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45084589" CreationDate="2017-07-17T19:06:49.477" Score="0" Body="<p>For the sake of ensuring this has a marked answer, I'll take the advice of @reticentroot and format the comment into an answer.</p>

<p>It would be more idiomatic for your POST endpoint to accept the request regardless of whether a corresponding /v1/photo or /v1/data entry has been created. The process that's interfacing with these pieces of data could easily check whether it has both pieces of data, and act accordingly.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4746361" LastActivityDate="2017-07-17T19:06:49.477" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45142452      <row Id="45142452" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45151974" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45142452" CreationDate="2017-07-17T19:14:57.380" Score="2" Body="<p>It is because you try to use a pointer to the interface to unmarshal into. You need return a pointer in a function </p>

<pre><code>func newAnchor() resource {
    return &amp;anchor{}
}
</code></pre>

<p>And you don't need to get address in this line:
<code>err := dcdr.Decode(&amp;res)</code></p>

<p>Here is small working example: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/3E0RmGTURO" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/3E0RmGTURO</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastEditorUserId="142162" LastEditDate="2017-07-21T18:24:00.907" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T18:24:00.907" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45158059      <row Id="45158059" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45158178" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45158059" CreationDate="2017-07-18T05:24:39.013" Score="0" Body="<p>The assignment <code>cdf[i] = s</code> performs an implicit conversion to <code>uint64_t</code>.  It's hard to tell if this is intended without the calculations you omitted.</p>

<p>In practice, <code>long double</code> as a type has considerable variance across architectures.  Whether Go's <code>float64</code> is an appropriate replacement depends on the architecture you are porting from.  For example, on x86, <code>long double</code> is an 80-byte extended precision type, but <a href="https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/830" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Windows systems are usually configured in such a way to compute results only with the 53-bit mantissa</a>, which means that <code>float64</code> could still be equivalent for your purposes.</p>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong> In this particular case, the values computed by the sources appear to be static and independent of the input.  I would just use <code>float64</code> on the Go side and see if the computed values are identical to those of the C version, when run on a x86 machine under real GNU/Linux (virtualization should be okay), to work around the Windows FPU issues.  The choice of x86 is just a guess because it is likely what the original author used.  I do not understand the underlying cryptography, so I can't say whether a difference in the computed values impact the security.  (Also note that the C code does not seem to properly seed its PRNG.)</p>
" OwnerUserId="8316315" LastEditorUserId="8316315" LastEditDate="2017-07-18T12:11:38.993" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T12:11:38.993" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45156553      <row Id="45156553" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45159309" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45156553" CreationDate="2017-07-18T06:39:37.487" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to change your "ColInfo" struct keys so that "json" package can read them. I'm attaching a working code snippet</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "io/ioutil"
    "os"
)

type ColInfo struct {
    Key string `json:"key"`
    Col []int  `json:"data"`
}
type Config struct {
    colInfos []ColInfo
}

func main() {
    file, err := ioutil.ReadFile("configurtaion.txt")
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Printf("File error: %v\n", err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
    cfg := Config{}
    json.Unmarshal(file, &amp;cfg.colInfos)
    fmt.Println(cfg.colInfos[0])
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2488951" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T06:39:37.487" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45147353      <row Id="45147353" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45162597" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45147353" CreationDate="2017-07-18T09:23:13.027" Score="2" Body="<p>You wrote that <code>CalcualteBallCycle()</code> modifies the slice by design.</p>

<p>I can't speak to correctness of that approach, but it is why benchmark time of <code>BenchmarkCalculateBallCycle123</code> is so different.</p>

<p>On first run it does the expected thing but on subsequent runs it does something completely different, because you're passing different data as input.</p>

<p>Benchmark this modified code:</p>

<pre><code>func BenchmarkCalculateBallCycle123v2(b *testing.B) {
    m := []int{8, 62, 42, 87, 108, 35, 17, 6, 22, 75, 116, 112, 39, 119, 52, 60, 30, 88, 56, 36, 38, 26, 51, 31, 55, 120, 33, 99, 111, 24, 45, 21, 23, 34, 43, 41, 67, 65, 66, 85, 82, 89, 9, 25, 109, 47, 40, 0, 83, 46, 73, 13, 12, 63, 15, 90, 121, 2, 69, 53, 28, 72, 97, 3, 4, 94, 106, 61, 96, 18, 80, 74, 44, 84, 107, 98, 93, 103, 5, 91, 32, 76, 20, 68, 81, 95, 29, 27, 86, 104, 7, 64, 113, 78, 105, 58, 118, 117, 50, 70, 10, 101, 110, 19, 1, 115, 102, 71, 79, 57, 77, 122, 48, 114, 54, 37, 59, 49, 100, 11, 14, 92, 16}
    for n := 0; n &lt; b.N; n++ {
        tmp := append([]int{}, m...)
        CalculateBallCycle(tmp)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>This works-around this behavior by making a copy of m, so that <code>CalculateBallCycle</code> modifies a local copy.</p>

<p>The running time becomes more like the others:</p>

<pre><code>BenchmarkCalculateBallCycle123-8         3000000           500 ns/op
BenchmarkCalculateBallCycle123v2-8           100      10483347 ns/op
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2898" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T09:23:13.027" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45164649      <row Id="45164649" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45165250" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45164649" CreationDate="2017-07-18T11:16:45.437" Score="1" Body="<p>First of all, values are <strong>not</strong> passed by reference for slices/arrays.</p>

<p>At the same time, if you were passing a slice value to some function, the receiver would be able to modify the same underlying array, because a slice value contains a pointer.</p>

<p>In your case, you are not passing a slice itself, but rather copies of the dereferenced <code>int64</code> values. And <code>fmt.Scanf</code> is not updating <code>mapIsh</code>. Only passing addresses are you able to use the scanned values. </p>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T11:16:45.437" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45158754      <row Id="45158754" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45168144" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45158754" CreationDate="2017-07-18T13:26:03.383" Score="2" Body="<p>See the <a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/tree/master/examples/chat" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Gorilla Chat Application</a> for an example of how to avoid blocking on a client.</p>

<p>The key parts are:</p>

<ul>
<li><p><a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/blob/462d5c5828f6203e4047c47be2920315937be380/examples/chat/client.go#L130" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Use a buffered channel for sending to the client</a>. Your application is already doing this.</p></li>
<li><p><a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/blob/462d5c5828f6203e4047c47be2920315937be380/examples/chat/hub.go#L43-L49" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Send to the client using select/default</a> to avoid blocking. Assume that the client is blocked on write when the client cannot immediately receive a message. Close the client's channel in this situation to cause the client's write loop to exit.</p></li>
<li><p><a href="https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/blob/462d5c5828f6203e4047c47be2920315937be380/examples/chat/client.go#L91" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Write with a deadline</a>.</p></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-07-18T13:54:41.330" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T13:54:41.330" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45088651      <row Id="45088651" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45169415" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45088651" CreationDate="2017-07-18T14:17:49.373" Score="5" Body="<p>At least on the second page, all of the paths seem wrong. You supplied the path to the <em>source code</em> where the dialog asks for the path to the <em>executable</em>.</p>

<p>To make sure you have all the tools installed run the following commands in the terminal:</p>

<pre><code>go get -u github.com/nsf/gocode
go get -u golang.org/x/tools/cmd/guru
go get -u github.com/rogpeppe/godef
</code></pre>

<p>Now, for each of the tools run</p>

<pre><code>which &lt;tool&gt;
# example:
which guru
# =&gt; /Users/user/gocode/bin/gocode
</code></pre>

<p>Copy the output into the <code>Executable:</code> field in the config screen.</p>

<p>For gofmt you should be able to simply tick "Use default location"</p>
" OwnerUserId="405454" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T14:17:49.373" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45171642      <row Id="45171642" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45172168" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45171642" CreationDate="2017-07-18T16:13:45.340" Score="5" Body="<p>If you come from Java, the empty interface (<code>interface{}</code>) is actually closer to working with <code>Object</code> variables in Java than with generics.</p>

<p>You can assign anything to an <code>interface{}</code> (like you can do with an <code>Object</code> variable in Java).</p>

<p>But you should then "cast" or "type assert" back if you want to use the actual type you stored there (same that you need to do with <code>Object</code> variables in Java).</p>

<p>Generics in Java are quite different, since they allow you to keep type checking at compile time. The different is precisely that you don't need to resort to reflection or type switches if you work with Generics.</p>

<p>You can read more about Java generics here:</p>

<p><a href="https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/generics/" rel="noreferrer">https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/generics/</a></p>

<p>And then follow this and the next 2 or 3 steps of the Go tour here for more on how the empty interface works:</p>

<p><a href="https://tour.golang.org/methods/14" rel="noreferrer">https://tour.golang.org/methods/14</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-07-18T16:18:55.773" LastActivityDate="2017-07-18T16:18:55.773" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45177878      <row Id="45177878" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45179938" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45177878" CreationDate="2017-07-19T02:22:49.117" Score="4" Body="<p>If you are converting your <code>byt</code> to <code>map[string]interfaec{}</code> the default value of the number will be <code>float64</code>.</p>

<pre><code>func main(){
    byt := []byte(`{"status": "USER_MOVED_LEFT", "id":1, "x":5, "y":3}`)
    var dat map[string]interface{}
    if err := json.Unmarshal(byt, &amp;dat); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    fmt.Println(reflect.TypeOf(dat["id"])) // print the type of value
    num := dat["id"].(float64)
    fmt.Println(num)
}
</code></pre>

<p>But you can also change this behavior by converting your <code>byt</code> which is your data to a <code>struct</code> like this :</p>

<pre><code>type myStruct struct {
    Status string
    Id     int
    x      int
    y      int
}

func main() {
    byt := []byte(`{"status": "USER_MOVED_LEFT", "id":1, "x":5, "y":3}`)
    dat := myStruct{}
    if err := json.Unmarshal(byt, &amp;dat); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    fmt.Println(reflect.TypeOf(dat.Id))
    fmt.Printf("%+v\n", dat.Id)

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2652524" LastEditorUserId="2652524" LastEditDate="2017-07-19T13:43:14.070" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T13:43:14.070" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45180082      <row Id="45180082" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45182039" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45180082" CreationDate="2017-07-19T05:58:17.487" Score="6" Body="<p>It is explained in the Go os package source code comments.</p>

<p>For example, this is safe:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "os"

func main() {
    f, err := os.Create("/tmp/atestfile")
    if err != nil {
        *f = os.File{}
    }
    // finalizer runs
}
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>Package os</p>

<pre><code>go/src/os/types.go:

// File represents an open file descriptor.
type File struct {
  *file // os specific
}

go/src/os/file_plan9.go:

// file is the real representation of *File.
// The extra level of indirection ensures that no clients of os
// can overwrite this data, which could cause the finalizer
// to close the wrong file descriptor.
type file struct {
  fd      int
  name    string
  dirinfo *dirInfo // nil unless directory being read
}

go/src/os/file_unix.go:

// +build darwin dragonfly freebsd linux nacl netbsd openbsd solaris

// file is the real representation of *File.
// The extra level of indirection ensures that no clients of os
// can overwrite this data, which could cause the finalizer
// to close the wrong file descriptor.
type file struct {
  pfd      poll.FD
  name     string
  dirinfo  *dirInfo // nil unless directory being read
  nonblock bool     // whether we set nonblocking mode
}

go/src/os/file_windows.go:

// file is the real representation of *File.
// The extra level of indirection ensures that no clients of os
// can overwrite this data, which could cause the finalizer
// to close the wrong file descriptor.
type file struct {
  pfd     poll.FD
  name    string
  dirinfo *dirInfo // nil unless directory being read
}
</code></pre>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-07-19T07:10:36.337" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T07:10:36.337" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45183253      <row Id="45183253" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45184001" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45183253" CreationDate="2017-07-19T07:40:57.933" Score="3" Body="<p><code>os.Stdin</code> is an exported variable of the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>os</code></a> package, it is of type <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>*os.File</code></a>.</p>

<p>You may call <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Stat" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Stat()</code></a> on it to see if it's available and also to get additional info about it (e.g. if it is being piped or its source is a terminal):</p>

<pre><code>if _, err := os.Stdin.Stat(); err != nil {
    fmt.Println("Stdin not available:", err)
} else {
    fmt.Println("Stdin available.")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Let's see an example when it's not available. It won't be if we close it first e.g. with the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#File.Close" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>File.Close()</code></a> method:</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println("Closing:", os.Stdin.Close())

if _, err := os.Stdin.Stat(); err != nil {
    fmt.Println("Stdin not available:", err)
} else {
    fmt.Println("Stdin available.")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/r_R5MAWNqi" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Stdin available.
Closing: &lt;nil&gt;
Stdin not available: stat /dev/stdin: Bad file number
</code></pre>

<p>Also check related question: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22744443/check-if-there-is-something-to-read-on-stdin-in-golang">Check if there is something to read on STDIN in Golang</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T07:40:57.933" CommentCount="6" />

<row Id="45185777" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45151679" CreationDate="2017-07-19T09:03:08.237" Score="0" Body="<p>I got answer here: <a href="https://github.com/vmware/govmomi/issues/790" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/vmware/govmomi/issues/790</a></p>

<pre><code>spec := types.VirtualMachineConfigSpec{}

question:
45181087      <row Id="45181087" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45186174" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45181087" CreationDate="2017-07-19T09:19:03.463" Score="1" Body="<h1>Correctness</h1>

<p>As discussed in the comment section, there are a family of string matching algorithms, which normally categorized into single pattern and multiple pattern matching algorithm. In your case it belongs to single pattern string matching problem. </p>

<p>From my knowledge, the most well-known algorithm is KMP algorithm which uses dynamic programming, and an alternative named Rabin-Karp's algorithm which uses rolling hash technique to speed up the process. Both runs in <code>O(max(a,b))</code>.</p>

<p>However, your code is not very alike to these algorithm's normal implementation, at least to my experience. Therefore I suspect the correctness of your code at the first place. You can try cases like <code>a = {1, 2, 1, 2, 1}, b { 1, 1, 2, 2, 1, 2, 1 }</code> to see it is not giving correct result.</p>

<p>Therefore you can</p>

<ol>
<li>Abandon current algorithm and learn those standard one, implement them</li>
<li>Outline the logic and sketch a proof of your current algorithm, compared it with the logic behind those standard algorithms to verify its correctness</li>
</ol>

<p>I will leave this part to you</p>

<h1>Complexity</h1>

<p>To directly answer your OP: </p>

<p>No, <code>O(max(a,b))</code> is the optimal you can achieve in this problem, which is also the complexity of the standard known algorithms mentioned above.</p>

<p>My understanding is that, it actually makes sense as at worst case, you HAVE TO read each character of the longer string at least 1 time.</p>

<p>Your current algorithm is also <code>O(b)</code> clearly, as you loop using <code>i</code> from 0 to length of <code>b</code>, and no matter which condition you fall into <code>i</code> will increase by 1, giving total <code>O(b)</code></p>

<hr>

<p>Therefore complexity is actually not the problem, the correctness is the problem.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2185825" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T09:19:03.463" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45189605      <row Id="45189605" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45189658" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45189605" CreationDate="2017-07-19T11:48:47.623" Score="4" Body="<p>Embedded types are (unnamed) fields, referred to by the unqualified type name.</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Struct_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Struct types:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A field declared with a type but no explicit field name is an <em>anonymous field</em>, also called an <em>embedded</em> field or an embedding of the type in the struct. An embedded type must be specified as a type name <code>T</code> or as a pointer to a non-interface type name <code>*T</code>, and <code>T</code> itself may not be a pointer type. <strong>The unqualified type name acts as the field name.</strong></p>
</blockquote>

<p>So try:</p>

<pre><code>e := ErrorValue{NamedValue: NamedValue{Name: "fine", Value: 33}, Error: err}
</code></pre>

<p>Also works if you omit the field names in the composite literal:</p>

<pre><code>e := ErrorValue{NamedValue{"fine", 33}, err}
</code></pre>

<p>Try the examples on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Nn9Myd3nb5" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-19T11:53:48.627" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T11:53:48.627" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45195127      <row Id="45195127" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="45195333" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45195127" CreationDate="2017-07-19T15:44:28.297" Score="2" Body="<p>Turn <code>result</code> into an array of <code>*Volume</code></p>

<pre><code>result := []*Volume{}
</code></pre>

<p>and then append new <code>Volume</code> records:</p>

<pre><code>result = append(result, &amp;Volume{Id: id,Name:name,Description: description})
</code></pre>

<p>and in the end use <code>Marshal(result)</code> to get the JSON result.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2350684" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T15:44:28.297" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45196950      <row Id="45196950" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45197671" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45196950" CreationDate="2017-07-19T17:50:23.107" Score="1" Body="<p>I would have had the same assumptions you did, and browsing the source, it looks like it should work as you described. You might try debugging and stepping through it, particularly the <code>New</code> method for the store you're using (e.g. <a href="https://github.com/gorilla/sessions/blob/master/store.go#L189" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>FilesystemStore.New</code></a> or <a href="https://github.com/boj/redistore/blob/v1.2/redistore.go#L232" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>RediStore.New</code></a>). If that method successfully reads the cookie and finds the session in the store, it should set <code>IsNew = false</code>, according to the source.</p>

<p>Also note that just checking the session ID is not a good way of validating this behavior. If you look at the source, it decodes the session ID from the cookie, <em>then</em> tries to look that up in the backing store. If the lookup fails, then the session ID will match, but <code>IsNew</code> will be <code>true</code> and there won't be any values in the session. Make sure you're setting some value in the session and check for that instead of the session ID. The behavior is different for the <code>CookieStore</code> since it stores the session data in the cookie itself.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T17:50:23.107" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45196147      <row Id="45196147" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45197769" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45196147" CreationDate="2017-07-19T17:55:02.140" Score="0" Body="<p>The problem I am seeing , which I may be incorrect, you are creating tokenAuth for each user that is logging in. There should be one instance of tokenAuth and you encode and decode using that instance. I believe the sign key should be the same for all the users, so you can verify from the tokenAuth instance. You might also want to look into signing it with RS256, because of issues in the past with HS256.</p>

<p><a href="https://auth0.com/blog/brute-forcing-hs256-is-possible-the-importance-of-using-strong-keys-to-sign-jwts/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://auth0.com/blog/brute-forcing-hs256-is-possible-the-importance-of-using-strong-keys-to-sign-jwts/</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4807063" LastEditorUserId="4807063" LastEditDate="2017-07-19T18:02:19.737" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T18:02:19.737" CommentCount="0" />
