question:
45200429      <row Id="45200429" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45200690" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45200429" CreationDate="2017-07-19T20:45:27.280" Score="3" Body="<p>The definitive section is <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Primary_expressions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Primary Expressions</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Primary expressions are the operands for unary and binary expressions.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>It goes on to define primary expressions, but basically, this includes slice expressions, meaning that the slice expression <code>a[0]</code> is the operand for the unary operator <code>*</code>. A special case was made for pointers to arrays (see below).</p>

<p>According to <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Address Operators</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>For an operand x of type T, the address operation &amp;x generates a pointer of type *T to x. The operand must be addressable, that is, either a variable, pointer indirection, or slice indexing operation; or a field selector of an addressable struct operand; or an array indexing operation of an addressable array. As an exception to the addressability requirement, x may also be a (possibly parenthesized) composite literal. If the evaluation of x would cause a run-time panic, then the evaluation of &amp;x does too.</p>
  
  <p>For an operand x of pointer type *T, the pointer indirection *x denotes the variable of type T pointed to by x. If x is nil, an attempt to evaluate *x will cause a run-time panic.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This <em>implies</em>, but does not explicitly state, that a slice indexing expression or field selector expression to the right of the pointer indirection operator is evaluated as a whole before the indirection is evaluated.</p>

<p>Also, pointer indirection (<code>*x</code>) <em>is</em> an operator, specifically, an <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Address Operator</a>. The slice index reference is <em>not</em> an operator but rather an <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Index_expressions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Index <em>Expression</em></a>.</p>

<p>Also note that:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>For a of pointer to array type:</p>
  
  <p><code>a[x]</code> is shorthand for <code>(*a)[x]</code></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Though the same cannot be said of pointers to slice types.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T13:18:45.170" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T13:18:45.170" CommentCount="12" />

question:
45201570      <row Id="45201570" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45201659" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45201570" CreationDate="2017-07-19T21:52:02.217" Score="5" Body="<p>One common way to distinguish between the zero value and an unset value is with pointers:</p>

<pre><code>type Test struct {
    FieldInt    *int
    FieldBool   *bool
    FieldString *string
}
</code></pre>

<p>This won't be an appropriate solution for every situation, though, but since you haven't told us your precise situation, I offer this simply as one possible solution.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-07-19T21:52:02.217" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45203052      <row Id="45203052" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45203310" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45203052" CreationDate="2017-07-20T00:43:49.640" Score="4" Body="<p>In your example there are no real differences as you are Sprintf to simply concaternate strings. That is indeed something which can be solved more easily by using the '+' operator.</p>

<p>Take the following example, where you want to print a clear error message like "Product with ID '42' could not be found.". How does that look with your bottom approach?</p>

<pre><code>productID := 42;
myString := "Product with ID '" + productID + "' could not be found."
</code></pre>

<p>This would give an error (mismatched types string and int), because Go does not have support for concatenate different types together. </p>

<p>So you would have to transform the type to a string first.</p>

<pre><code>productID := 42
myString := "Product with ID '" + strconv.Itoa(productID) + "' could not be found."
</code></pre>

<p>And, this you would have to do for every single data type other than strings.</p>

<p>The <code>fmt</code> package in Go and similar formatting packages in almost any other language solve this by helping you with the conversions and keeping your strings clear of mass '+' operators.</p>

<p>Here is how the example would look like using <code>fmt</code></p>

<pre><code>product := 42
myString := fmt.Sprintf("Product with ID '%d' could not be found.", product)
</code></pre>

<p>Here <code>%d</code> is the formatting verb for 'print the argument as a number'. See <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#hdr-Printing" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/#hdr-Printing</a> the various other ways of printing other types. </p>

<p>Compared to concatenating <code>fmt</code> allows you to write your strings in a clear way, separating the template/text from the variables. And, it simplifies printing data types other than strings a lot.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1716567" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T00:43:49.640" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45177958      <row Id="45177958" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45204797" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45177958" CreationDate="2017-07-20T03:49:38.250" Score="1" Body="<p>Your problem is twofold:</p>

<ol>
<li>Improperly configured <code>libsecp256k1</code> package</li>
<li>Your C compiler not searching <code>/usr/local</code> directories for installed headers/libs</li>
</ol>

<h2>Fixing the improperly libsecp256k1 configured package</h2>

<p>Your "undefined symbols" issue when it comes to linking C libraries sometimes points to an improperly configured package (in the sense of an Autotools package or a CMake package, not a Go package). Running <code>./configure --help</code>, I see there is an option named <code>--enable-module-recovery</code>. Judging by names like <code>_secp256k1_ecdsa_sign_<strong>recoverable</strong></code> and <code>_secp256k1_ecdsa_<strong>recover</strong></code>, you need to add that option when configuring, meaning instead of executing the simpler <code>./configure</code>, you should execute this:</p>

<pre><code>./configure --enable-module-recovery
</code></pre>

<h2>Is the C compiler broken?</h2>

<p>Since the <code>secp256k1.h</code> header file isn't found in <code>/usr/local/include</code>, despite the fact that the header file most definitely exists after <code>sudo make install</code> is finished, it means <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/23905661/539810">your compiler doesn't search <code>/usr/local</code></a>.</p>

<p>Barring any fixes in the linked question, you can work around the issue by altering the source of the Go package as needed to add/modify the <code>CFLAGS</code> and <code>LDFLAGS</code> used when dealing with <code>import "C"</code> statements like this:</p>

<pre><code>// #cgo CFLAGS: -I/usr/local/include
// #cgo LDFLAGS: -L/usr/local/lib -lsecp256k1
// #include &lt;secp256k1.h&gt;
import "C"
</code></pre>

<p>If you have <code>pkg-config</code> installed, you can use that instead of setting <code>CFLAGS</code> and <code>LDFLAGS</code> manually:</p>

<ol>
<li>Export the <code>PKG_CONFIG_PATH</code> environment variable with a custom set of paths. Because no prefix (i.e. directory serving as the install root) was specified, <code>/usr/local</code> is assumed, meaning <code>/usr/local/include</code> will contain headers and <code>/usr/local/lib</code> will contain libraries. This means you need to export <code>PKG_CONFIG_PATH</code> on your command line as in <code>export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig:/usr/local/share/pkgconfig:/usr/lib/pkgconfig:/usr/share/pkgconfig</code>. The default setting of <code>PKG_CONFIG_PATH</code> when unset includes <code>/usr/lib/pkgconfig</code> and <code>/usr/share/pkgconfig</code> in that order on Linux and are specified as a fallback for other packages that might be used, though it may not be necessary in this case. The default set of paths may differ on OS X, so consult your <code>pkg-config</code> man page for reference.</li>
<li>Use <code>// #cgo pkg-config: libsecp256k1</code>, and <code>CFLAGS</code> and <code>LDFLAGS</code> will be set as necessary without you needing to do anything to them. Since not all systems have <code>pkg-config</code> installed, relying on this is perhaps a bad idea if you want a package to remain portable. Then again, I think it'd be preferable to the mess you dealt with since <code>pkg-config</code> simply wouldn't be found.</li>
<li>Change to the upvote directory and type <code>make</code> to build a working upvote binary.</li>
</ol>

<h2>Additional customization</h2>

<h3>Custom prefix</h3>

<p>If you use something other than <code>/usr/local</code> as your prefix (e.g. <code>./configure --enable-module-recovery --prefix=/opt/libsecp256k1</code>), then you'll need to adjust some things accordingly:</p>

<pre><code>// #cgo CFLAGS: -I/opt/libsecp256k1/include
// #cgo LDFLAGS: -L/opt/libsecp256k1/lib -lsecp256k1
// #include "secp256k1.h"
import "C"

// or just use pkg-config and export the PKG_CONFIG_PATH environment
// variable containing the following paths:
//   /opt/libsecp256k1/lib/pkgconfig
//   /opt/libsecp256k1/share/pkgconfig
//   /usr/lib/pkgconfig
//   /usr/share/pkgconfig
</code></pre>

<p>You'll also need to modify the provided Makefile in the upvote directory to set the runtime path of the binary that gets built, else <code>libsecp256k1.0.dylib</code> will not be found:</p>

<pre><code># If you copy and paste this, replace the spaces in front of `go build`
# with a single horizontal tab character, else `make` will fail.
#
# Note that the "ldflags" specified are for the Go linker (go tool link),
# not the system's linker (ld).
build:
    go build -ldflags="-r /opt/libsecp256k1/lib"
</code></pre>

<p>For more information about working with cgo, check out the following resources:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://blog.golang.org/c-go-cgo" rel="nofollow noreferrer">"C? Go? Cgo!" introduction to cgo on The Go Blog</a></li>
<li><a href="https://golang.org/cmd/cgo/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Cgo documentation</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="539810" LastEditorUserId="539810" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T03:57:00.583" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T03:57:00.583" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45204814      <row Id="45204814" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45205399" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45204814" CreationDate="2017-07-20T04:48:04.220" Score="1" Body="<p>Welcome to Go, happy learning.</p>

<p>You're doing good, you can improve your program many ways (such as json decoder, less no of chan, etc). Following is one of the approach. Execution time is between 352-446ms (take it with grain of salt, since network call is involved in your code. Might vary based on server response time).</p>

<p>Your updated code:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "net/http"
    "sync"
    "time"
)

type user struct {
    User userData `json:"user"`
}

type userData struct {
    Followers count `json:"followed_by"`
}

type count struct {
    Count int `json:"count"`
}

func getFollowerCount(username string, result chan&lt;- int, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
    defer wg.Done()
    reqURL := "https://www.instagram.com/" + username + "/?__a=1"
    resp, err := http.Get(reqURL)
    if err != nil {
        log.Println(err)
        return
    }
    defer resp.Body.Close()

    var u user
    if err := json.NewDecoder(resp.Body).Decode(&amp;u); err != nil {
        log.Println(err)
        return
    }
    result &lt;- u.User.Followers.Count
}

func execute(users []string, result chan&lt;- int) {
    wg := &amp;sync.WaitGroup{}
    for _, username := range users {
        wg.Add(1)
        go getFollowerCount(username, result, wg)
    }
    wg.Wait()
    result &lt;- -1
}

func main() {
    start := time.Now()
    fmt.Println("STARTING UP")
    usrs := []string{"kanywest", "kimkardashian", "groovyq", "kendricklamar", "barackobama", "asaprocky", "champagnepapi", "eminem", "drdre", "g_eazy", "skrillex"}

    result := make(chan int)
    go execute(usrs, result)

    for v := range result {
        if v == -1 {
            break
        }
        fmt.Println(v)
    }

    elapsed := time.Since(start)
    fmt.Println("runtime:", elapsed)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T04:48:04.220" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45205475      <row Id="45205475" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45205576" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45205475" CreationDate="2017-07-20T05:03:39.393" Score="2" Body="<p>The examples would me in the mariadb docs. What you are missing is the <code>on</code> clause that tells mariadb how to join the 2 tables. You cannot use the old-school join syntax with <code>left join</code> putting the join criteria into the <code>where</code> clause.</p>

<pre><code>SELECT * FROM joke
LEFT JOIN jokevote ON joke.user_id=jokevote.user_id
WHERE jokevote.vote=?
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5389997" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T05:03:39.393" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45204275      <row Id="45204275" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45208227" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45204275" CreationDate="2017-07-20T07:32:21.677" Score="2" Body="<p>The line</p>

<pre><code>a = append(a[:i], a[i+1:]...)
</code></pre>

<p>creates a new slice by removing the item at position <code>i</code> in <code>a</code>, by combining the items from 0 to i (not included), and from i+1 to the end.</p>

<p>Your second question is what is the purpose of <code>...</code>. <code>append</code> accepts a slice as first argument, and an unlimited number of arguments, all with a type <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Assignability" rel="nofollow noreferrer">assignable</a> to the type of its elements.</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#append" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>append</code></a> is defined as</p>

<pre><code>func append(slice []Type, elems ...Type) []Type
</code></pre>

<p>Writing </p>

<pre><code>a = append(a[:i], a[i+1:]...)
</code></pre>

<p>is equivalent as writing</p>

<pre><code>a = append(a[:i], a[i+1], a[i+2], a[i+3], a[i+4]) //and so on, until the end of the slice.
</code></pre>

<p>Using <code>a[i+1:]...</code> is basically a shorthand syntax, as the Go spec describes in <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Passing_arguments_to_..._parameters" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/ref/spec#Passing_arguments_to_..._parameters</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If f is variadic with a final parameter p of type ...T, then within f the type of p is equivalent to type []T. If f is invoked with no actual arguments for p, the value passed to p is nil. Otherwise, the value passed is a new slice of type []T with a new underlying array whose successive elements are the actual arguments, which all must be assignable to T</p>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/cqeMkemn62" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Playground</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="205039" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T07:32:21.677" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45207920      <row Id="45207920" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45209033" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45207920" CreationDate="2017-07-20T08:11:09.563" Score="2" Body="<p>It's called <em>conversion</em> in Go (not casting), and this is covered in <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Conversions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Conversions:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Specific rules apply to (non-constant) conversions between numeric types or to and from a string type. These conversions may change the representation of <code>x</code> and incur a run-time cost. All other conversions only change the type but not the representation of <code>x</code>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So generally converting does not make a copy, only changes the type. Converting to / from <code>string</code> usually does, as <code>string</code> values are immutable, and for example if converting a <code>string</code> to <code>[]byte</code> would not make a copy, you could change the content of the <code>string</code> by changing elements of the resulting byte slice.</p>

<p>See related question: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32253768/does-convertion-between-alias-types-in-go-create-copies/32253871#32253871">Does convertion between alias types in Go create copies?</a></p>

<p>There are some exceptions (compiler optimizations) when converting to / from <code>string</code> does not make a copy, for details see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43470284/golang-bytestring-vs-bytestring/43470344#43470344">golang: []byte(string) vs []byte(*string)</a>.</p>

<p>If you already have your JSON content as a <code>string</code> value which you want to unmarshal, you should not convert it to <code>[]byte</code> just for the sake of unmarshaling. Instead use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/strings/#NewReader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>strings.NewReader()</code></a> to obtain an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Reader</code></a> which reads from the passed <code>string</code> value, and pass this reader to <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#NewDecoder" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.NewDecoder()</code></a>, so you can unmarshal without having to make a copy of your big input JSON string.</p>

<p>This is how it could look like:</p>

<pre><code>input := "BIG JSON INPUT"
dec := json.NewDecoder(strings.NewReader(input))

var result YourResultType
if err := dec.Decode(&amp;result); err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that this solution can further be optimized if the big JSON string is read from an <code>io.Reader</code>, in which case you can completely omit reading it first, just pass that to <code>json.NewDecoder()</code> directly, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>dec := json.NewDecoder(jsonSource)

var result YourResultType
if err := dec.Decode(&amp;result); err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T09:08:20.753" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T09:08:20.753" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45208178      <row Id="45208178" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45209909" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45208178" CreationDate="2017-07-20T08:54:20.657" Score="0" Body="<p>The key point in this quote is <code>method set consistency</code>. Types T and *T are different types in Go and may have different method sets (explanation is also in the <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#different_method_sets" rel="nofollow noreferrer">FAQ</a>).</p>

<p>One of the reasons it's important, is because interface satisfaction is implicit in Go. So if some of your type's methods have a pointer receiver, while others don't, this can result in a situation, when you expect that your object satisfies some interface, but now that depends on whether you are using it's pointer or value.</p>

<p>So it's good practice to avoid this kind of confusion.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastEditorUserId="4283005" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T12:21:02.037" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T12:21:02.037" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45208654      <row Id="45208654" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45210683" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45208654" CreationDate="2017-07-20T09:27:07.463" Score="1" Body="<p><code>sqlx</code> is just a wrapper around <code>database/sql</code> package. The query you're trying to perform is driver specific. Thus, it depends on the driver you're using to connect to the MSSQL server. If you're using <a href="https://github.com/denisenkom/go-mssqldb" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/denisenkom/go-mssqldb</a>, based on <a href="https://github.com/denisenkom/go-mssqldb/issues/78" rel="nofollow noreferrer">issue #78</a>, you can try the following:</p>

<pre><code>rows, err := db.Queryx(`EXEC [SP_NAME] @Input, @Result OUTPUT; 
          SELECT Result = @Result;`, sql.Named("Input", "Some Text"))
//do something with rows...
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T09:27:07.463" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45213365      <row Id="45213365" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45213441" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45213365" CreationDate="2017-07-20T11:30:10.100" Score="2" Body="<p>You can only use <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Composite_literals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">composite literals</a> to create values of struct types defined in another package if you use <em>keyed values</em> in the literal, because then you are not required to provide initial values for all fields, and so you can leave out unexported fields (which only the declaring package can set / change).</p>

<p>If the type is declared in the same package, you can set unexported fields too:</p>

<pre><code>t := Thing{
    Name:           "the name",
    someUnexported: 23,
}
</code></pre>

<p>But you can only provide initial values for exported fields if the type is declared in another package, which is not a surprise I guess:</p>

<pre><code>t := otherpackage.Thing{
    Name: "the name",
    // someUnexported will implicitly be its zero value
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you need values of the struct where the unexported fields have values other than the zero value of their types, the package itself must export some kind of constructor or initializer (or setter method), because from the outside (of the package), you can't change / set unexported fields.</p>

<p>See related question: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38369350/how-to-clone-a-structure-with-unexported-field/38370382#38370382">How to clone a structure with unexported field?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T11:41:32.030" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T11:41:32.030" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45214860      <row Id="45214860" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45215205" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45214860" CreationDate="2017-07-20T12:46:31.697" Score="2" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>it is the fact that the response body is of type io.closer</p>
</blockquote>

<p>No, it is not. Declaration of <code>Request.Body</code> is at <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#Request" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>http.Request</code></a>:</p>

<pre><code>Body io.ReadCloser
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>Request.Body</code> field is of type <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#ReadCloser" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.ReadCloser</code></a>, it is both an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Reader</code></a> and an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Closer" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Closer</code></a>.</p>

<p>Since it is an <code>io.Reader</code> (dynamic value of <code>Request.Body</code> implements <code>io.Reader</code>), you may use / pass it where an <code>io.Reader</code> is required, e.g. to <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/ioutil/#ReadAll" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>ioutil.ReadAll()</code></a>.</p>

<p>Since it also implements <code>io.Closer</code>, you can also pass it where <code>io.Closer</code> is required, like your <code>convert()</code> function.</p>

<p>But inside convert the <code>closer</code> param has static type <code>io.Closer</code>, you can't use <code>closer</code> where an <code>in.Reader</code> is required. It might be (and in your case it is) that the dynamic type stored in <code>closer</code> also implements <code>io.Reader</code>, but there is no guarantee for this. Like in this example:</p>

<pre><code>type mycloser int

func (mycloser) Close() error { return nil }

func main() {
    var m io.Closer = mycloser(0)
    convert(m)
}
</code></pre>

<p>In the above example <code>closer</code> inside <code>convert()</code> will hold a value of type <code>mycloser</code>, which truly does not implement <code>io.Reader</code>.</p>

<p>If your <code>convert()</code> function intends to treat its parameter also as an <code>io.Reader</code>, the parameter type should be <code>io.ReadCloser</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func convert(rc io.ReadCloser) ([]byte, error) {
    body, err := ioutil.ReadAll(rc)
    if err != nil {
        return body, err
    }
    err = rc.Close()
    return body, err
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T13:03:22.253" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T13:03:22.253" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45209168      <row Id="45209168" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45216548" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45209168" CreationDate="2017-07-20T13:43:19.717" Score="1" Body="<p>The server is closing the connection for some reason; the backend closed, timed out, etc. There's not much you can do except retry, just as if you had any other connection error. There is some discussion in a arelated issue (<a href="https://golang.org/issue/18639" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/issue/18639</a>) about retrying this automatically, but it generally looks like the client is working as intended. </p>

<p><code>Response.Body.Close</code> does not close a connection, otherwise it would defeat the purpose of http1.1 and http2 using persistent connections. Reading and closing the response body is how you allow the connection to be reused by the http client. </p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T13:43:19.717" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45216349      <row Id="45216349" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45216989" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45216349" CreationDate="2017-07-20T14:01:17.740" Score="4" Body="<p>No, that's the way to do it. You're basically doing a pivot, there's no way I know of to do that automagically. Given that you've done it in just a couple of lines of code, I don't see a problem with your solution.</p>

<p>Since you're scanning into a variable per column, you don't actually need the <code>StructSingle</code> type at all - you could just use two local <code>string</code> variables, which would make it even simpler:</p>

<pre><code>for rows.Next() {
    var col1, col2 string
    db.Scan(&amp;col1, &amp;col2)

    s.Column1 = append(s.Column1, col1)
    s.Column2 = append(s.Column2, col2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>And get rid of the <code>StructSingle</code> type entirely.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T14:01:17.740" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45214857      <row Id="45214857" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45217221" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45214857" CreationDate="2017-07-20T14:11:11.957" Score="2" Body="<p>You are declaring <code>sq</code> as a function, not a method. If you want to attach <code>sq</code> to <code>MyFloat</code>, you should declare it like:</p>

<pre><code>func (f MyFloat) sq() string {
    return fmt.Sprintln("The square is: ", f*f)
}
</code></pre>

<p>This way you will be able to do <code>a.sq()</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1147580" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T14:11:11.957" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45216783      <row Id="45216783" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45217550" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45216783" CreationDate="2017-07-20T14:24:36.340" Score="2" Body="<p>When you execute "SELECT * FROM joke INNER JOIN jokevote" you will get columns from both joke and jokevote tables. 
Try to query "SELECT joke.* FROM joke INNER JOIN jokevote" to get only columns from joke table.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4071273" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T14:24:36.340" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45221912      <row Id="45221912" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45226598" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45221912" CreationDate="2017-07-20T23:13:44.003" Score="1" Body="<p>It seems you hit a subtle issue with the <code>append</code> function.</p>

<p>You should not be using <code>append</code> to create new arrays as you are doing in your function.</p>

<p>Instead, copy them and append the values to the copied array.</p>

<p>If you replace your calls to <code>append</code> to <code>copyAndAppend</code> as defined here:</p>

<pre><code>func copyAndAppend(i []int, vals ...int) []int {
    j := make([]int, len(i), len(i)+len(vals))
    copy(j, i)
    return append(j, vals...)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Your code seems to work correctly.</p>

<p>See here for more details:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35276022/unexpected-slice-append-behaviour">unexpected slice append behaviour</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-07-20T23:43:10.193" LastActivityDate="2017-07-20T23:43:10.193" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45222362      <row Id="45222362" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45227087" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45222362" CreationDate="2017-07-21T00:20:47.333" Score="1" Body="<p>Unfortunately no, you can't recover from a call to os.Exit(). The documentation says that it exits immediately, and not even differed functions are called. I recommend to not use a package if it has an exit in it, as that is a pretty bad design.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6398020" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T00:20:47.333" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45227703      <row Id="45227703" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45227818" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45227703" CreationDate="2017-07-21T02:00:22.177" Score="1" Body="<p>It seems your server is using old codebase of gin. Just checked the gin commit history.</p>

<p>The method <code>SaveUploadedFile</code> added <a href="https://github.com/gin-gonic/gin/commit/93b3a0d7ec95c33dc327397ab1756c36853328ee" rel="nofollow noreferrer">5 days ago</a>. So execute below command to pull the latest codebase on your server.</p>

<pre><code>go get -u github.com/gin-gonic/gin
</code></pre>

<p>Then compile it.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T02:00:22.177" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45226991      <row Id="45226991" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45231694" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45226991" CreationDate="2017-07-21T07:32:18.003" Score="4" Body="<p>To extend putu's answer, comparing the returned color model to the "prepared" models of the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/image/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>image</code></a> package only works if one of those models is used, else all comparison will result in <code>false</code>. Also it is quite inconvenient to list and compare to all possible models.</p>

<p>Instead to find out a talkative form of the color model, we may use this little trick: try to convert any color using the color model of the image. A concrete color model converts all color values (implementations) to the color type / implementation used by the image. Printing the type of the resulting color will tell you what you are looking for.</p>

<p>Example:</p>

<pre><code>col := color.RGBA{} // This is the "any" color we convert
var img image.Image

img = &amp;image.NRGBA{}
fmt.Printf("%T
", img.ColorModel().Convert(col))

img = &amp;image.Gray16{}
fmt.Printf("%T
", img.ColorModel().Convert(col))

img = &amp;image.NYCbCrA{}
fmt.Printf("%T
", img.ColorModel().Convert(col))

img = &amp;image.Paletted{}
fmt.Printf("%T
", img.ColorModel().Convert(col))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/nLpXPe-h4l" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>color.NRGBA
color.Gray16
color.NYCbCrA
&lt;nil&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>As can be seen, an image of type <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/image/#NRGBA" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>*image.NRGBA</code></a> models colors using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/image/color/#NRGBA" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>color.NRGBA</code></a>, an image of type <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/image/#Gray16" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>*image.Gray16</code></a> models colors using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/image/color/#Gray16" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>color.Gray16</code></a> etc. As a last example I used <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/image/#Paletted" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>*image.Paletted</code></a>, where the result was <code>nil</code>, because the image's palette was empty.</p>

<p>To quickly fix the <code>nil</code> palette, let's provide an initial palette:</p>

<pre><code>img = &amp;image.Paletted{Palette: []color.Color{color.Gray16{}}}
fmt.Printf("%T
", img.ColorModel().Convert(col))
</code></pre>

<p>Now the output will be (try this on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/N8MaWzDCc2" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>color.Gray16
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-21T07:50:04.347" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T07:50:04.347" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45233208      <row Id="45233208" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45233749" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45233208" CreationDate="2017-07-21T09:14:42.407" Score="1" Body="<p>You don't need to call <code>http.ListenAndServeTLS</code> on App Engine.  If you have your <code>app.yaml</code> set up correctly, traffic will be served over SSL for you.  A minimal App Engine app might be something like this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "net/http"
)

func init() {
    http.HandleFunc("/", handler)
}

func handler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    fmt.Fprint(w, "Hi")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1427098" LastEditorUserId="1427098" LastEditDate="2017-07-21T09:20:00.503" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T09:20:00.503" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45224545      <row Id="45224545" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45234484" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45224545" CreationDate="2017-07-21T09:49:21.427" Score="2" Body="<p>You need to define <code>clone</code> and <code>set</code> method in <code>mather</code> interface, i.e.:</p>

<pre><code>type mather interface {
    add(mather) mather
    sub(mather) mather
    get() interface{}
    clone() mather
    set(v mather)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The implementation of <code>get</code>, <code>set</code> and <code>clone</code> in <code>float</code> type looks like:</p>

<pre><code>func (f *float) get() interface{} {
    return f.value
}

func (f *float) clone() mather {
    return &amp;float{f.value}
}

func (f *float) set(v mather) {
    switch v := v.(type) {
    case *float:
        f.value = v.value
    //handle other possible types...
    default:
        //handle unknown types
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/NaORzziSwh" rel="nofollow noreferrer">working example in Playground</a>. The only complicated parts is <code>set</code> in which you should determined the underlying type. Here you can use <code>type switch</code> to get underlying type, then assign it to <code>float</code>. Similar codes need to be added in the other underlying types (you mention that there are 10 possible types). </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T09:49:21.427" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45236350      <row Id="45236350" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45236766" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45236350" CreationDate="2017-07-21T11:40:52.893" Score="1" Body="<p>When you build reusable pieces of code, you will develop a package as a shared library. But when you develop executable programs, you will use the package main for making the package as an executable program. The package main tells the Go compiler that the package should compile as an executable program instead of a shared library. The main function in the package main will be the entry point of our executable program.</p>

<p>That's why you should use the following structure:</p>

<pre><code>awsomeProject
    -&gt;src
        -&gt;awsomeProject
            -&gt;configuration.go
        -&gt;main.go
</code></pre>

<p>with <em>main.go</em></p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

func main(){
    var cfg awsomeProject.Config
    cfg.Data = 1
    fmt.Println("lalala")
}
</code></pre>

<p>and <em>configuration.go</em></p>

<pre><code>package awsomeProject

type Config struct {
    Data int
}
</code></pre>

<p>For more details:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/code.html</a></li>
<li><a href="https://thenewstack.io/understanding-golang-packages" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://thenewstack.io/understanding-golang-packages</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="3805062" LastEditorUserId="3805062" LastEditDate="2017-07-21T13:20:38.973" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T13:20:38.973" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45216035      <row Id="45216035" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45238171" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45216035" CreationDate="2017-07-21T12:50:53.183" Score="0" Body="<p>Thanks again Imperalix for the hint. The basic idea is to use the exact parameters which were used to create the record. This is what is now working for me to delete <code>CNAME</code> records.</p>

<pre><code>func deleteRecord(svc *route53.Route53) {
    dnsName := "vikas027.something.net"

    request := &amp;route53.ChangeResourceRecordSetsInput{
        ChangeBatch: &amp;route53.ChangeBatch{
            Changes: []*route53.Change{
                {
                    Action: aws.String("DELETE"),
                    ResourceRecordSet: &amp;route53.ResourceRecordSet{
                        Name: aws.String(dnsName),
                        Type: aws.String("CNAME"),
                        ResourceRecords: []*route53.ResourceRecord{
                            {
                                Value: aws.String(AliasName),
                            },
                        },
                        TTL:           aws.Int64(ttl),
                        Weight:        aws.Int64(weight),
                        SetIdentifier: aws.String(setIdentifier),
                    },
                },
            },
        },
        HostedZoneId: aws.String(zoneID),
    }
    resp, err := svc.ChangeResourceRecordSets(request)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println("Unable to delete DNS Record", err)
    }
    fmt.Println(resp)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3438276" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T12:50:53.183" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45232107      <row Id="45232107" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45239352" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45232107" CreationDate="2017-07-21T13:46:50.550" Score="0" Body="<p>In the code you posted:</p>

if err != nil {

question:
45239409      <row Id="45239409" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45239509" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45239409" CreationDate="2017-07-21T13:52:59.147" Score="5" Body="<p>The function uses a "named" return value.</p>

<p>From <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Return_statements" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the spec</a> on return statements:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The expression list may be empty if the function's result type
  specifies names for its result parameters. The result parameters act
  as ordinary local variables and the function may assign values to them
  as necessary. The "return" statement returns the values of these
  variables.</p>
  
  <p>Regardless of how they are declared, all the result values are
  initialized to the zero values for their type upon entry to the
  function. A "return" statement that specifies results sets the result
  parameters before any deferred functions are executed.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Using named returns allows you to save some code on manually allocating local variables, and can sometimes clean up messy if/else statements or long lists of return values. </p>

<pre><code>func a()(x []string, err error){
    return
}
</code></pre>

<p>is really just shorthand for</p>

<pre><code>func a() ([]string,error){
  var x []string
  var err error
  return x,err
}
</code></pre>

<p>Its a bit shorter, and I agree that it may be less obvious.</p>

<p>Named returns are sometimes needed, as it allows things like accessing them inside a deferred function, but the naked return is just syntactic sugar as far as I can tell, and is never strictly required.</p>

<p>One place I see it commonly is in error return cases in functions that have many return values. </p>

<pre><code>if(err != nil){
   return
}
return a,b,c,nil
</code></pre>

<p>is easier than </p>

<pre><code>if(err != nil){
   return nil,nil,nil,err
}
return a,b,c,nil
</code></pre>

<p>when you have to write it a bunch of times. And you don't have to modify those returns if you change the signature to have additional "real" return values.</p>

<p>Most places I am using them in the codebase I just searched, they definitely seem to be hiding other smells, like overly complex multi-purpose functions, too deep if/else nesting and stuff like that.</p>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastEditorUserId="121660" LastEditDate="2017-07-21T14:10:52.687" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T14:10:52.687" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45229951      <row Id="45229951" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45239520" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45229951" CreationDate="2017-07-21T13:53:19.740" Score="0" Body="<p>Solution.</p>

<p>You may test function <code>main()</code> from package <code>main</code> the same way, just do not name it <code>TestMain</code>. I launch it as a separate goroutine, than try to connect to it and perform any request.</p>

<p>I decided to connect to auxilary handler which should respond with a simple json <code>{"status": "ok"}</code>.
In my case:</p>

<pre><code>func TestMainExecution(t *testing.T) {
    go main()
    resp, err := http.Get("http://127.0.0.1:8080/checkHealth") 
    if err != nil {
            t.Fatalf("Cannot make get: %v
", err)
    }
    bodySb, err := ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    if err != nil {
            t.Fatalf("Error reading body: %v
", err)
    }
    body := string(bodySb)
    fmt.Printf("Body: %v
", body)
    var decodedResponse interface{}
    err = json.Unmarshal(bodySb, &amp;decodedResponse)
    if err != nil {
            t.Fatalf("Cannot decode response &lt;%p&gt; from server. Err: %v", bodySb, err)
    }
    assert.Equal(t, map[string]interface{}{"status": "ok"}, decodedResponse,
            "Should return status:ok")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5165332" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T13:53:19.740" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45242755      <row Id="45242755" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45242858" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45242755" CreationDate="2017-07-21T16:49:55.227" Score="3" Body="<p>Go does not support inheritance, and the only polymorphism it supports is interfaces. What you've got in the example code is called embedding, and it does not offer polymorphism; if you embed <code>Parent</code> in <code>Foo</code>, that does not let you assign a <code>Foo</code>-type value to a <code>Parent</code>-type variable or slice.</p>

<p>The closest you can get to what you describe would be using interfaces. If <code>Parent</code> implements some interface (let's say <code>Baz</code>), then embedding <code>Parent</code> in <code>Foo</code> and <code>Bar</code> means that both will also implement that same interface. This in turn means that you can have a slice of the interface type <code>[]Baz</code> into which you could put values of type <code>Parent</code>, <code>Foo</code>, or <code>Bar</code>. Note that interfaces can only specify methods, not fields, so when using values of the interface type, you'll only be able to access the methods of the interface, not any fields that might be specified in <code>Parent</code>, <code>Foo</code>, or <code>Bar</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T16:49:55.227" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45240642      <row Id="45240642" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45243755" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45240642" CreationDate="2017-07-21T17:45:36.893" Score="0" Body="<p>As pointed out, <code>Do</code> does not work with maps.  This is one way you could fix it.</p>

<pre><code>} else if e.Command == "HMSET" {
    // Build up a string slice to hold the key value pairs
    args := make([]string, 0, len(e.MapData) * 2)
    for k, v := range e.MapData {
        args = append(args, k, v)
    }
    _,err := redis.StringMap(client.Do("HMSET", e.Key, args...))
    checkErr(err, "hmset error:")
}
</code></pre>

<p>The Do method maps to the Redis command set and arguments are expected in the same way.  For example.</p>

<pre><code>127.0.0.1:6379&gt; HMSET myKey foo bar baz boff
OK
127.0.0.1:6379&gt; HGETALL myKey
1) "foo"
2) "bar"
3) "baz"
4) "boff"
127.0.0.1:6379&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>The same map-set operation using the redis client in your code would be</p>

<pre><code>client.Do("HMSET", "myKey", "foo", "bar", "baz", "boff")
</code></pre>

<p>When the arguments for keys and values of the map are dynamic, the most straight forward way is</p>

<pre><code>client.Do("HMSET", "myKey", []string{"foo", "bar", "baz", "boff"}...)
</code></pre>

<p>which is exactly what the first code block above does.</p>
" OwnerUserId="141555" LastEditorUserId="141555" LastEditDate="2017-07-21T17:52:36.773" LastActivityDate="2017-07-21T17:52:36.773" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45248144      <row Id="45248144" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45250332" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45248144" CreationDate="2017-07-22T03:23:52.057" Score="2" Body="<p>From the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/exec/#Command" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Command</code> documentation</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The returned Cmd's Args field is constructed from the command name followed by the elements of arg, so arg should not include the command name itself. For example, Command("echo", "hello"). Args[0] is always name, not the possibly resolved Path. </p>
</blockquote>

<p>So, you should do something like:</p>

<pre><code>argChatID := fmt.Sprintf(`'set mybuddy to a reference to text chat id "%s"'`, chatid)
argMessage := fmt.Sprintf(`'send "%s" to mybuddy'`, message)

exec.Command("/usr/bin/osascript", "-e", `'tell application "Messages"'`, 
    "-e", argChatID, "-e", argMessage,  "-e", "'end tell'").Run()
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-07-22T04:02:58.853" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T04:02:58.853" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45250120      <row Id="45250120" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45250515" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45250120" CreationDate="2017-07-22T04:00:14.553" Score="2" Body="<p>I think instead of <em>fasthttp is single process?</em>, you're asking whether fasthttp handles client requests concurrently or not?</p>

<p>I'm pretty sure that any server (including <em>fasthttp</em>) package will handle client requests concurrently. You should write a test/benchmark instead of manually access the server through <em>several</em> browsers. The following is an example of such test code:</p>

<pre><code>package main_test

import (
    "io/ioutil"
    "net/http"
    "sync"
    "testing"
    "time"
)

func doRequest(uri string) error {
    resp, err := http.Get(uri)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    defer resp.Body.Close()

    _, err = ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }

    return nil
}

func TestGet(t *testing.T) {
    N := 1000
    wg := sync.WaitGroup{}
    wg.Add(N)

    start := time.Now()
    for i := 0; i &lt; N; i++ {
        go func() {
            if err := doRequest("http://127.0.0.1:82"); err != nil {
                t.Error(err)
            }
            wg.Done()
        }()
    }
    wg.Wait()

    t.Logf("Total duration for %d concurrent request(s) is %v", N, time.Since(start))
}
</code></pre>

<p>And the result (in my computer) is</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>fasthttp_test.go:42: Total duration for 1000 concurrent request(s) is 10.6066411s</p>
</blockquote>

<p>You can see that the answer to your question is <strong>No, it handles the request concurrently</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>UPDATE:</strong>  </p>

<p>In case the requested URL is the same, your browser may perform the request sequentially. See <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/9189591/multiple-ajax-requests-for-same-url">Multiple Ajax requests for same URL</a>. This explains why the response times are <code>X*10s</code>. </p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-07-22T04:50:55.270" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T04:50:55.270" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45247226      <row Id="45247226" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45252978" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45247226" CreationDate="2017-07-22T09:35:26.540" Score="3" Body="<p>Because <code>p</code> points to nothing (<code>nil</code>). You must first allocate some memory and make <code>p</code> point to it before being allowed to deference <code>p</code>. You can use the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Allocation" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>new</code></a> builtin to allocate memory initialised to the zero value of the pointed type.</p>

<pre><code>p = &amp;box{val: 2}
</code></pre>

<p>has the same result as:</p>

<pre><code>p = new(box)
*p = box{val: 2}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="328115" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T09:35:26.540" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45252693      <row Id="45252693" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45252998" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45252693" CreationDate="2017-07-22T09:36:37.630" Score="1" Body="<p>You can create an instance of your new <code>Vertex</code> type in a variety of ways:</p>

<p>1: <code>var c Circle</code>  You can access fields using the <code>.</code> operator:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type Vertex struct {
    X, Y int
}
func main() {
    var f Vertex
    f.X = 1
    f.Y = 2
    fmt.Println(f) // should be {1, 2}
}
</code></pre>

<p>2: Using <code>:=</code> operator</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type Vertex struct {
    X, Y int
}
func main() {
    f := Vertex{1, 2}
    fmt.Println(f) // should be {1, 2}
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6422317" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T09:36:37.630" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45253939      <row Id="45253939" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45254046" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45253939" CreationDate="2017-07-22T11:32:51.273" Score="2" Body="<p>For the purpose of variable scoping, files have no meaning in Go. Think of all files in a package as if they would be concatenated, which (simplified) is exactly what happens before compilation.</p>

<p>That means: No, there is no way of scoping a variable to a file.</p>

<p>If you need two global <code>WaitGroup</code>s, you need to define them as individual variables.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1296707" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T11:32:51.273" CommentCount="4" />

45244386      <row Id="45244386" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="45254815" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45244386" CreationDate="2017-07-22T12:55:52.750" Score="0" Body="<p>I have wrote a small function that might be helpful for you. 
Please take a look at <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/P3hb7FzJUD" rel="nofollow noreferrer">limited parallel operations</a></p>

question:
45256166      <row Id="45256166" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45256366" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45256166" CreationDate="2017-07-22T15:43:16.967" Score="1" Body="<p>Your call to <code>srv.ListenAndServe</code> can be, and apparently is, called after <code>srv.Shutdown</code>. You can verify this by adding a logging statement the goroutine just before the call to <code>srv.ListenAndServe</code>. To see that the shutdown works when called after <code>ListenAndServe</code>, you can uncomment your <code>time.Sleep(1 * time.Second)</code>. Here a typical use of <code>Shutdown</code> would be to call it right after your <code>&lt;-quit</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    // stop on ^c
    quit := make(chan os.Signal)
    signal.Notify(quit, os.Interrupt)

    // router
    mux := http.NewServeMux()
    mux.HandleFunc("/", func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
        log.Println("serving request")
        io.WriteString(w, "Hello, world!\n")
    })

    // start server
    srv := &amp;http.Server{Addr: ":8080", Handler: mux}
    go func() {
        log.Println("server starting")
        if err := srv.ListenAndServe(); err != nil {
            log.Fatalf("listenAndServe failed: %v", err)
        }
    }()
    fmt.Println("server started")

    &lt;-quit
    // gracefully stop server
    ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(context.Background(), 60 * time.Second)
    defer cancel()
    if err := srv.Shutdown(ctx); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    log.Println("server stopped")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1147580" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T15:43:16.967" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45256433      <row Id="45256433" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45257068" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45256433" CreationDate="2017-07-22T16:56:33.023" Score="1" Body="<p>I think you mean the Fluent API design pattern. You return the same Object, or struct in Go, over and over.</p>

<p>This pattern does not allow you to return a tuple, or multiple return types though.  You can only return one object.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/9PceZwi1a3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/9PceZwi1a3</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

type Object struct {
    Value string
    Error error
}

func (o *Object) Before(s string) *Object {
    o.Value = s + o.Value
    // add an error if you like
    // o.Error = error.New(...)
    return o
}

func (o *Object) After(s string) *Object {
    // could check for errors too
    if o.Error != nil {
        o.Value = o.Value + s
    }
    return o
}

func main() {
    x := Object{}

    x.
        Before("123").
        After("456").
        After("789").
        Before("0")

    if x.Error != nil {
        // handle error
    }
    fmt.Println(x.Value)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Edit: sberry's answer had a good idea.  Add an Error state on the <code>Object</code> struct itself which could allow u to check for errors in each func call.</p>

<hr>

<p>Since you are new, please remember to evaluate all answers and mark the best one you believe lead you the answer.</p>
" OwnerUserId="56693" LastEditorUserId="56693" LastEditDate="2017-07-22T17:10:16.093" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T17:10:16.093" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45257237      <row Id="45257237" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45257463" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45257237" CreationDate="2017-07-22T17:39:55.617" Score="4" Body="<p>The key here is that you are using a pointer receiver in your definition of <code>Simplify()</code> with respect to <code>UnaryExpression</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func (a *UnaryExpression) Simplify()
</code></pre>

<p>The other methods you are implementing don't use a pointer receiver:</p>

<pre><code>// One example
func (a IdentExpression) Simplify() {}
</code></pre>

<p>Typically, in Go, it is considered best practice to have all methods on the same type use the same type of receiver (i.e. if one method uses a pointer receiver, they all should. Likewise, if one method uses a non-pointer receiver, they all should for that particular type).</p>

<p>In this case, the code will compile if you remove the pointer receiver from the <code>Simplify</code> method of <code>UnaryExpression</code>. Hope this helps!</p>

<p>Edit: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/40824044/2909262">Here is a more comprehensive answer that explains exactly why this error happens, it's really a good read.</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="2909262" LastEditorUserId="2909262" LastEditDate="2017-07-22T17:51:36.560" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T17:51:36.560" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45258055      <row Id="45258055" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45258190" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45258055" CreationDate="2017-07-22T19:05:13.217" Score="3" Body="<p>No, that is not safe. It doesn't matter if the keys are unique. You need to avoid concurrent writes or writes concurrent with reads. Concurrent reads are OK.</p>

<p>You can use the race detector to find problems like this by running <code>go run -race myprog.go</code>. See <a href="https://golang.org/doc/articles/race_detector.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/articles/race_detector.html</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3068258" LastEditorUserId="3068258" LastEditDate="2017-07-22T19:10:54.940" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T19:10:54.940" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45254738      <row Id="45254738" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45258790" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45254738" CreationDate="2017-07-22T20:16:30.193" Score="1" Body="<p>I think that it is probably better to write your own converter, because you will always have some cases that are not covered by existing libs\tools for that.</p>

<p>My initial implementation of it would be something like this: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/UBCq0waIEe" rel="nofollow noreferrer">basic impl of structs merger</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastActivityDate="2017-07-22T20:16:30.193" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45261101      <row Id="45261101" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45262453" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45261101" CreationDate="2017-07-23T07:09:33.347" Score="0" Body="<p>Here is the solution.</p>

<pre><code># detect GOPATH if not set
ifndef $(GOPATH)
    $(info GOPATH is not set, autodetecting..)
    TESTPATH := $(dir $(abspath ../../..))
    DIRS := bin pkg src
    # create a ; separated line of tests and pass it to shell
    MISSING_DIRS := $(shell $(foreach entry,$(DIRS),test -d "$(TESTPATH)$(entry)" || echo "$(entry)";))
    ifeq ($(MISSING_DIRS),)
        $(info Found GOPATH: $(TESTPATH))
        export GOPATH := $(TESTPATH)
    else
        $(info ..missing dirs "$(MISSING_DIRS)" in "$(TESTDIR)")
        $(info GOPATH autodetection failed)
    endif
endif
</code></pre>

<p>What I've learned:</p>

<ul>
<li>variables are defines in a separate block</li>
<li>tabs are not allowed in the block that defines variables</li>
<li><code>echo</code> doesn't work in this block, need to use <code>$(info)</code></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="239247" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T07:09:33.347" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45262846      <row Id="45262846" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45263383" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45262846" CreationDate="2017-07-23T09:06:23.343" Score="1" Body="<p>In order to mock the <code>userRepository</code> dependency of your <code>UserService</code>, you are correct in thinking the best approach would be to use an interface.</p>

<p>Firstly, create your interface:</p>

<pre><code>type UserRepository interface {
    FindAll() []Users
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then build a mock:</p>

<pre><code>type MockUserRepository struct{}

func (mock MockUserRepository) FindAll() []Users {
    // here you would manually build a slice of users and return it
    return []Users
}
</code></pre>

<p>Finally, use this mock as as a dependency in your test case:</p>

<pre><code>func TestMaleUsers(t *testing.T) {
    // compose service using mock
    service := UserService {
        userRepository: MockUserRepository,
    }

    // get output of method call
    users := service.MaleUsers()

    // perform assertions on output
}
</code></pre>

<p>This way you have created a mock of your interface which can be used in your tests without having to perform any database calls on your repository.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4506781" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T09:06:23.343" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45266393      <row Id="45266393" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45266853" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45266393" CreationDate="2017-07-23T15:34:38.030" Score="2" Body="<p>Race conditions are, by definition, nondeterministic. This means that while you may get a particular answer most of the time, it will not always be so.</p>

<p>By running racy code on multiple cores you greatly increases the number of possibilities, hence you get a broader selection of results.</p>

<p>See <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34510/what-is-a-race-condition">this post</a> or <a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_condition" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this Wikipedia article</a> for more information on race conditions.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T15:34:38.030" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45267409      <row Id="45267409" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45267644" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45267409" CreationDate="2017-07-23T16:55:42.130" Score="4" Body="<p>Expanding my comment with example.</p>

<p>It is feasible, you have to implement <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Marshal</a> interface.</p>

<p>For example:</p>

<pre><code>func (u *MyStruct) MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) {
    return json.Marshal(&amp;struct {
        Name   string `json:"name"`
        Scheme string `json:"scheme"`
    }{
        Name:   u.Name,
        Scheme: u.Scheme,
    })
}
</code></pre>

<p>Play Link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/LLchuOdYvf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/LLchuOdYvf</a></p>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>{"name":"Bob","scheme":"http"}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T16:55:42.130" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45268293      <row Id="45268293" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45268398" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45268293" CreationDate="2017-07-23T18:13:44.067" Score="4" Body="<p>You cannot use a variable before it is declared, and it is not yet declared inside its initialization statement.</p>

<p>So yes, the declaration line is required, and no, there is no way to avoid it.</p>
