question:
45267983      <row Id="45267983" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45268501" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45267983" CreationDate="2017-07-23T18:25:33.313" Score="0" Body="<p>The problem with your program is not the algorithm itself but this line:</p>

<pre><code>newSet := append(existingSet, element)
</code></pre>

<p>You should not <code>append</code> and assign to a different variable.</p>

<p>As the <a href="https://godoc.org/builtin#append" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a> states (emphasis mine), "The append built-in function appends elements to the end of a slice. <strong>If it has sufficient capacity, the destination is resliced to accommodate the new elements</strong>. If it does not, a new underlying array will be allocated.".</p>

<p>So, there might be cases where <code>newSet := append(existingSet, element)</code> will actually modify <code>existingSet</code> itself, which would break your logic.</p>

<p>If you change that to instead create a new array and append to that one, it works as you expect it.</p>

<pre><code>newSet := make([]string, 0)
newSet = append(newSet, existingSet...) 
newSet = append(newSet, element)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-07-23T18:38:22.177" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T18:38:22.177" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45268998      <row Id="45268998" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45269323" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45268998" CreationDate="2017-07-23T19:53:59.127" Score="3" Body="<p>By default <code>rand.Intn</code> uses the <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/math/rand/rand.go#L277" rel="nofollow noreferrer">globalRand.Intn</a>. Its created internally, <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/math/rand/rand.go#L236" rel="nofollow noreferrer">refer here</a>. So when you set via <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/math/rand/rand.go#L243" rel="nofollow noreferrer">rand.Seed</a></p>

<pre><code>rand.Seed(time.Now().UTC().UnixNano())
</code></pre>

<p>Then <code>globalRand</code> uses the new seed value.</p>

<p>When needed you can create your own rand generator with seed value. Refer to <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#example__rand" rel="nofollow noreferrer">godoc example</a>.</p>

<hr>

<p>Play Link (without seed): <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/2yg7xjvHoJ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/2yg7xjvHoJ</a></p>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>My favorite number is 1
My favorite number is 7
My favorite number is 7
My favorite number is 9
My favorite number is 1
My favorite number is 8
My favorite number is 5
My favorite number is 0
My favorite number is 6
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Play Link (with seed): <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/EpW6R5rvM4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/EpW6R5rvM4</a></p>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>My favorite number is 0
My favorite number is 8
My favorite number is 7
My favorite number is 2
My favorite number is 3
My favorite number is 9
My favorite number is 4
My favorite number is 7
My favorite number is 8
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong></p>

<p>As @AlexanderTrakhimenok mentioned, in playground program execution is <code>deterministic</code>. However playground is doest stop you from supplying <code>rand.Seed</code> value. </p>

<p>Remember Seed value is <code>int64</code>.</p>

<p>When you <code>rand.Intn</code>, it uses default seed value <code>1</code> for <code>globalRand</code>.</p>

<pre><code>var globalRand = New(&amp;lockedSource{src: NewSource(1).(Source64)})
</code></pre>

<p>And in playground <code>time.Now().UTC().UnixNano()</code> gives you same value <code>1257894000000000000</code> since <code>the start time is locked to a constant</code>. But it is different from default seed value, <strong><em>that's why second playground link produces the different result</em></strong>.</p>

<p>So above two would produce the same result always.</p>

<p><strong>How should we change the result in playground?</strong></p>

<p>Yes, we can. Let's supply <code>UnixNano()</code> value <code>1500909006430687579</code> to <code>rand.Seed</code>, which is generated from my machine.</p>

<p>Play Link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/-nTydej8YF" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/-nTydej8YF</a></p>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>My favorite number is 3
My favorite number is 5
My favorite number is 3
My favorite number is 8
My favorite number is 0
My favorite number is 5
My favorite number is 4
My favorite number is 7
My favorite number is 1
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-24T15:27:05.743" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T15:27:05.743" CommentCount="8" />

question:
45269506      <row Id="45269506" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45269823" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45269506" CreationDate="2017-07-23T20:54:26.337" Score="4" Body="<p><strong>Option 1</strong></p>

<p>Return a new slice as suggested by @zerkms.<br>
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/uGJiD3WApS" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/uGJiD3WApS</a></p>

<pre><code>package main
import "fmt"

func main() {
    a := []int{0, 1, 1, 3, 3, 3}
    a = removeDup(a)
    fmt.Println(a)
}

func removeDup(s []int) []int {
    n := len(s)
    tmp := make([]int, 0, n)
    tmp = append(tmp, s[0])
    for i := 1; i &lt; n; i++ {
        if s[i] != s[i-1] {
            tmp = append(tmp, s[i])
        }
    }
    return tmp
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Option 2</strong><br>
Use pointers for pass-by-reference.<br>
The same thing in effect as that of option1.  </p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/80bE5Qkuuj" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/80bE5Qkuuj</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    a := []int{0, 1, 1, 3, 3, 3}
    removeDup(&amp;a)
    fmt.Println(a)
}

func removeDup(sp *[]int) {
    s := *sp
    n := len(s)
    tmp := make([]int, 0, n)
    tmp = append(tmp, s[0])
    for i := 1; i &lt; n; i++ {
        if s[i] != s[i-1] {
            tmp = append(tmp, s[i])
        }
    }
    *sp = tmp
}
</code></pre>

<p>Also, refer to following SO thread:
<a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16748330/does-go-have-no-real-way-to-shrink-a-slice-is-that-an-issue">Does Go have no real way to shrink a slice? Is that an issue?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="2837627" LastEditorUserId="2837627" LastEditDate="2017-07-23T21:49:05.547" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T21:49:05.547" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45270023      <row Id="45270023" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45270134" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45270023" CreationDate="2017-07-23T21:38:38.457" Score="4" Body="<p><code>Open</code> opens a file in read-only mode.<br>
Refer to documentation: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#Open" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/os/#Open</a></p>

<p>Instead, use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#OpenFile" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>OpenFile</code></a>.</p>

<p>Also, always check for errors whenever you code. It'll save you at least weeks of work-hours in your lifetime.</p>

<p>Here is a working code:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bufio"
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
    "os"
)

func main() {
    fn := os.Args[1]
    var input bytes.Buffer
    scanner := bufio.NewScanner(os.Stdin)

    for scanner.Scan() {
        fmt.Fprintf(&amp;input, scanner.Text())
        fmt.Fprintf(&amp;input, "\n")
    }

    fmt.Println(input.Bytes())
    fi, err := os.OpenFile(fn, os.O_RDWR|os.O_CREATE, 0755)

    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println("Error with Open()",err)
    }
    defer fi.Close()

    n, err := fi.Write(input.Bytes())
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println("Error with Write()", err)
    }
    fmt.Println("Bytes written to file: ",n)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a class='doc-link' href="https://stackoverflow.com/documentation/go/1033/file-i-o#t=201707232252120358363">Stack overflow documentation</a> for this will also help you.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2837627" LastEditorUserId="2837627" LastEditDate="2017-07-23T22:53:55.750" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T22:53:55.750" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45267060      <row Id="45267060" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45270754" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45267060" CreationDate="2017-07-23T23:25:13.820" Score="1" Body="<p>At the moment this is not possible. Nor do I see how it could be possible in the future. Mounting a volume in docker means you "hide" the contents of that folder from the container and use the files on the host instead. As such, any time you'll mount the directory from your machine, your container files from that instance won't be available to the machine. This means you can't have Go installed in the container and then mount a folder and use that location for the Go sources. If you are thinking: I'll just mount things in another place, do some symlink magic / copy files around, that's just a bad idea that leads to nowhere.</p>

<p>Gogland supports remote debugging as of EAP 10, released a a few weeks ago. This allows you to debug applications running in containers or on remote hosts. As such, you can install Go, and the source code on your machine but have them running in containers.</p>
" OwnerUserId="951414" LastActivityDate="2017-07-23T23:25:13.820" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45271052      <row Id="45271052" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45271090" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45271052" CreationDate="2017-07-24T00:24:50.420" Score="4" Body="<p>It seems to be because <code>Parse</code> is returning a pointer to the struct.</p>

<p>Try with this (note the <code>*</code>):</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Printf("%+v\n", *u)
</code></pre>

<p>Modified playground:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Grjrp2QriK" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/Grjrp2QriK</a></p>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong></p>

<p>To expand on this, the reason for this is that <code>fmt</code> treats structs that implement <code>Stringer</code> differently when doing <code>%+v</code>.</p>

<p>This is the relevant code: <a href="https://golang.org/src/fmt/print.go?s=4772:4849#L577" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/src/fmt/print.go?s=4772:4849#L577</a></p>

<p>Since <code>*URL</code> implements Stringer: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/url/#URL.String" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/net/url/#URL.String</a></p>

<p>That's the string being used.</p>

<p>By dereferencing the pointer, we get an <code>URL</code>, which does not implement the interface (cause the receiver in the <code>String</code> method is a pointer).</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-07-24T19:32:47.623" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T19:32:47.623" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45272267      <row Id="45272267" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45274110" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45272267" CreationDate="2017-07-24T06:41:01.467" Score="1" Body="<p>See how you build the <code>nameComponentRegexp</code>: you start with <code>alphaNumericRegexp</code> and then match 1 or 0 occurrences of 1 or more sequences of <code>separatorRegexp</code>+<code>alphaNumericRegexp</code>.</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/docker/distribution/blob/master/reference/regexp.go#L118" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>optional()</code></a> does the following:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>// optional wraps the expression in a non-capturing group and makes the<br/>
  // production optional.<br/></p>

<pre>func optional(res ...*regexp.Regexp) *regexp.Regexp {
  return match(group(expression(res...)).String() + `?`)
}</pre>
</blockquote>

<p><a href="https://github.com/docker/distribution/blob/master/reference/regexp.go#L118" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>repeated()</code></a> does this:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>// repeated wraps the regexp in a non-capturing group to get one or more<br/>
  // matches.<br/></p>

<pre>func repeated(res ...*regexp.Regexp) *regexp.Regexp {
  return match(group(expression(res...)).String() + `+`)
}</pre>
</blockquote>

<p>Thus, what you need is</p>

<pre><code>/^[a-z0-9]+(?:(?:[._]|__|-*)[a-z0-9]+)*$/
</code></pre>

<p>See the <a href="https://regex101.com/r/cm1qY3/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">regex demo</a></p>

<p><strong>Details</strong>:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>^</code> - start of string</li>
<li><code>[a-z0-9]+</code> - 1 or more alphanumeric symbols</li>
<li><code>(?:(?:[._]|__|-*)[a-z0-9]+)*</code> - zero or more sequences of:

<ul>
<li><code>(?:[._]|__|-*)</code> - a <code>.</code>, <code>_</code>, <code>__</code>, or 0+ hyphens</li>
<li><code>[a-z0-9]+</code>- 1 or more alphanumeric symbols</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>If you want to disallow strings like <code>aaaa</code>, you need to replace all <code>*</code> in the pattern (2 occurrences) with <code>+</code> (<a href="https://regex101.com/r/Bcmdjb/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">demo</a>).</p>

<p>JS demo:</p>

<p><div class="snippet" data-lang="js" data-hide="false" data-console="true" data-babel="false">
<div class="snippet-code">
<pre class="snippet-code-js lang-js prettyprint-override"><code>var ss = ['a.a','a_a','a__a','a-a','a--a','a---a'];
var rx = /^[a-z0-9]+(?:(?:[._]|__|-*)[a-z0-9]+)*$/;
for (var s of ss) {
 console.log(s,"=&gt;", rx.test(s));
}</code></pre>
</div>
</div>
</p>
" OwnerUserId="3832970" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T06:41:01.467" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45273724      <row Id="45273724" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45274122" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45273724" CreationDate="2017-07-24T06:41:45.060" Score="2" Body="<p>It's because you <strong>do not</strong> have <em>any</em> dedicated route that handles requests for <em>any</em> images.</p>

<p>My recommendation would be to initialize an HTTP handler that serves file based on the URI pathname. You can use that handler as a way to serve images.</p>

<pre><code>fs := http.FileServer(http.Dir("images"))
</code></pre>

<p>And then to bind it:</p>

<pre><code>http.Handle("/images/", http.StripPrefix("/images/", fs))
</code></pre>

<p>Here's your full code with my suggestions:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
  "fmt"
  "html/template"
  "net/http"
)

func main() {
  // We're creating a file handler, here.
  fs := http.FileServer(http.Dir("images"))

  http.HandleFunc("/images", images)

  // We're binding the handler to the `/images` route, here.
  http.Handle("/images/", http.StripPrefix("/images/", fs))

  http.ListenAndServe(":8080", nil)
}

func images(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
  t, err := template.ParseFiles("templates/link.html")
  if err != nil {
    fmt.Fprintf(w, err.Error())
    return
  }

  t.ExecuteTemplate(w, "link", nil)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="538570" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T06:41:45.060" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45275185      <row Id="45275185" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45275278" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45275185" CreationDate="2017-07-24T08:07:15.203" Score="4" Body="<p>The message you send:</p>

<pre><code>message := `{"status": "OK"}`
</code></pre>

<p>Is already a valid JSON text, you don't need any further JSON encoding / processing on it. Just send it as-is:</p>

<pre><code>func Index(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request){
    message := `{"status": "OK"}`
    w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json;charset=UTF-8")
    io.WriteString(w, message)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that if your response code is <code>http.StatusOK</code>, you don't need to set that explicitly, as that is the default if you don't set it.</p>

<p>And then simply expect the following response:</p>

<pre><code>expected := `{"status": "OK"}`
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Explaining your original code:</strong></p>

<p>In your original code you JSON-marshaled a single <code>string</code> value, whose content was <code>{"status": "OK"}</code>. JSON encoding will quote this text into a valid JSON string (prefix quotation marks with a backslash), put inside quotes, and also appends a newline character. So this becomes the raw string:</p>

<pre><code>expected := `"{\"status\": \"OK\"}"
`
</code></pre>

<p>Using this <code>expected</code> value, your test passes, but again, what you want is in the first part of this answer.</p>

<p>If you want to use an interpreted string literal to describe the <code>expected</code> value, this is how it could look like:</p>

<pre><code>expected := "\"{\\\"status\\\": \\\"OK\\\"}\"\n"
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-24T08:34:12.793" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T08:34:12.793" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45278540      <row Id="45278540" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45278760" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45278540" CreationDate="2017-07-24T10:54:28.740" Score="8" Body="<p>This question may be somewhat opinion based, but using multiple package <code>init()</code> functions can make your code easier to read and maintain.</p>

<p>If your source files are large, usually you arrange their content (e.g. types, variable declarations, methods etc.) in some logical order. Allowance of multiple <code>init()</code> functions give you the possibility to put initialization code near to the parts they ought to initialize. If this would not be allowed, you would be forced to use a single <code>init()</code> function per package, and put everything in it, far from the variables they need to initialize.</p>

<p>Yes, having multiple <code>init()</code> functions may require some care regarding to execution order, but know that using multiple <code>init()</code> functions is not a requirement, it's just a possibility. And you can write <code>init()</code> functions to not have "side" effects, to not rely on the completion of other <code>init()</code> functions.</p>

<p>If that is unavoidable, you can create one "master" <code>init()</code> which explicitly controls the order of other, "child" <code>init()</code> functions.</p>

<p>Relevant section from spec: <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Program_initialization_and_execution" rel="noreferrer">Package initialization</a>.</p>

<p>Also see related question: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31650965/what-does-lexical-file-name-order-mean/31651094#31651094">What does lexical file name order mean?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-24T12:05:47.530" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T12:05:47.530" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45278840      <row Id="45278840" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45279233" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45278840" CreationDate="2017-07-24T11:16:48.560" Score="0" Body="<p>In Go you can use a slice for a variadic parameter. However, the slice must contain all the parameters you need to pass to the function. You cannot expand a slice and pass additional parameters as well.</p>

<p>Hence your code should be something like:</p>

<pre><code>args := make([]interface{}, 0, len(e.MapData) * 2 + 1)
args = append(args, e.Key)
for k, v := range e.MapData {
    args = append(args, k, v)
}
_,err := redis.StringMap(client.Do("HMSET", args...))
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastEditorUserId="8356442" LastEditDate="2017-07-24T11:37:16.240" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T11:37:16.240" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45211395      <row Id="45211395" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45279330" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45211395" CreationDate="2017-07-24T11:22:17.723" Score="0" Body="<p>In the end I've just realized that I needed to invert the order:</p>

<pre><code>r.Methods("GET").Path("/general/baz/bro").Handler(bazBroHandler)
r.Methods("GET").PathPrefix("/general").Handler(defaultHandler)
</code></pre>

<p>now everything is working!</p>
" OwnerUserId="847818" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T11:22:17.723" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45282409      <row Id="45282409" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45282661" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45282409" CreationDate="2017-07-24T14:02:34.357" Score="3" Body="<p>Unfortunately you can't pass C types between packages. You'll need to perform any necessary type conversions within the package that is importing the C types. As per the <a href="https://golang.org/cmd/cgo/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Cgo translates C types into equivalent unexported Go types. Because
  the translations are unexported, a Go package should not expose C
  types in its exported API: a C type used in one Go package is
  different from the same C type used in another.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you have common C translation methods that you use, consider using <code>go generate</code> with a helper script to create these in each package where it is required from a master source file. Not as nice as solution as having a common library but much better than manually updating files in multiple packages. </p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T14:02:34.357" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45282854      <row Id="45282854" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45283308" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45282854" CreationDate="2017-07-24T14:34:11.047" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to create a service account in your project and furnish a new JSON private key. </p>

<p>Then ensure that the <code>GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS</code> environmental variable is set to the full path of this file. For example, on Linux:</p>

<pre><code>GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS=/home/user/Downloads/key.json go run main.go
</code></pre>

<p>As an aside, it is best practice to make sure you protect access to this private key file and ensure the service account has the minimum privileges required to perform its role.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T14:34:11.047" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45286540      <row Id="45286540" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45286582" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45286540" CreationDate="2017-07-24T17:26:07.307" Score="5" Body="<p>Through the closures all the goroutines share the same variable <code>i</code>. Try that instead:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "sync"
)

func main() {
    a := []string{
        "apple",
        "orange",
        "grape",
        "peach",
        "lemon",
    }

    wg := sync.WaitGroup{}
    wg.Add(len(a))
    for i, v := range a {
        go func(a string, j int) {
            fmt.Println(a, j)
            wg.Done()
        }(v,j)
    }
    wg.Wait()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Generally: In the program you posted you are reading <code>i</code> and writing <code>i</code> from different goroutines without any synchronisation. That is a data race. Anything could happen in that scenario.</p>

<p>The go race detector even yells at you</p>

<pre><code>go run -race test.go
apple 0
==================
WARNING: DATA RACE
Read at 0x00c420010268 by goroutine 7:
  main.main.func1()
      /home/erwo/test.go:22 +0x6d

Previous write at 0x00c420010268 by goroutine 6:
  main.main.func1()
      /home/erwo/test.go:23 +0x191

Goroutine 7 (running) created at:
  main.main()
      /home/erwo/test.go:25 +0x15f

Goroutine 6 (finished) created at:
  main.main()
      /home/erwo/test.go:25 +0x15f
==================
orange 1
==================
WARNING: DATA RACE
Read at 0x00c420010268 by goroutine 8:
  main.main.func1()
      /home/erwo/test.go:22 +0x6d

Previous write at 0x00c420010268 by goroutine 6:
  main.main.func1()
      /home/erwo/test.go:23 +0x191

Goroutine 8 (running) created at:
  main.main()
      /home/erwo/test.go:25 +0x15f

Goroutine 6 (finished) created at:
  main.main()
      /home/erwo/test.go:25 +0x15f
==================
peach 2
grape 2
lemon 4
Found 2 data race(s)
exit status 66
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7824574" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T17:26:07.307" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45287348      <row Id="45287348" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45288698" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45287348" CreationDate="2017-07-24T19:35:52.913" Score="1" Body="<p>Your first option is fine and perhaps simplest to do. However, it could lead to poor performance with many readers as it could struggle to obtain a write lock.</p>

<p>As the comments on your question have stated, your second option (as-is) can cause a race condition and lead to unpredictable behaviour.</p>

<p>You could implement your second option by using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/atomic/#Value" rel="nofollow noreferrer">atomic.Value</a>. This would allow you to store the pointer to some data struct and atomically update this for the next readers to use. For example:</p>

<pre><code>// Data shared with readers
type data struct {
   // all the fields
}

// Manager
type manager struct {
    v atomic.Value
}

// Method used by readers to obtain a fresh copy of data to 
// work with, e.g. inside loop
func (m *manager) Data() *data {
    return m.v.Load().(*data)
}

// Internal method called to set new data for readers
func (m *manager) update() {
    d:=&amp;data{
        // ... set values here
    }
    m.v.Store(d)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T19:35:52.913" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45287088      <row Id="45287088" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45289727" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45287088" CreationDate="2017-07-24T20:44:06.467" Score="1" Body="<p>Maybe this will work for you. Now you can get rid of your concurrent map. Here is a code snippet: </p>

<pre><code>func myFunc() {
    //10 concurrent API calls
    sem := make(chan bool, 10)
    respCh := make(chan YOUR_RESP_TYPE, 10)
    var responses []YOUR_RESP_TYPE

    for i := 0; i &lt; N; i++ {
        sem &lt;- true
        go func(i int) {
            defer func() {
                &lt;-sem
            }()
            resp := slowAPICall(fmt.Sprintf("http://slow-api.me?%d",i))
            respCh &lt;- resp
        }(i)
    }

    respCollected := make(chan struct{})
    go func() {
        for i := 0; i &lt; N; i++ {
            responses = append(responses, &lt;-respCh)
        }
        close(respCollected)
    }()

    &lt;-respCollected
    tx,_ := db.Begin()
    for _, data := range responses {
        tx.Exec("Insert data into database")
    }
    tx.Commit()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Than we need to use one more goroutine that will collect all responses in some slice or map from a response channel.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastEditorUserId="8279560" LastEditDate="2017-07-25T08:00:22.380" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T08:00:22.380" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45228766      <row Id="45228766" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45290518" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45228766" CreationDate="2017-07-24T21:38:53.150" Score="0" Body="<p>Solution:</p>

<p>1) Remove the "context" import</p>

<p>2) Import "google.golang.org/appengine"; see</p>

<pre><code>    [https://github.com/golang/appengine/blob/master/README.md][1]
</code></pre>

<p>for more details re: the local appengine package installation</p>

<p>3) This function</p>

<pre><code>    http.HandleFunc("/", bqPage)
</code></pre>

<p>calls</p>

<pre><code>    bqPage(w http.ResponseWriter, req *http.Request)
</code></pre>

<p>as the handler function. Pass that second req parameter down to the code that builds / calls the bigquery client:</p>

<pre><code>    ctx := appengine.NewContext(req)

    // Get the projectID value from the Google Cloud Console:

    projectID := "--------------"

    // Create a client.

    client, err := bigquery.NewClient(ctx, projectID)
</code></pre>

<p>Once you have the client object, you're in business.</p>

<p>4) From a DOS window pointed to the directory hosting the main.go file, run</p>

<pre><code>    gcloud app deploy
</code></pre>

<p>and then run the app with</p>

<pre><code>    gcloud app browse
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3176071" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T21:38:53.150" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45290144      <row Id="45290144" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45291474" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45290144" CreationDate="2017-07-24T23:11:20.427" Score="3" Body="<p>Below is a working example. The crux is to declare a struct type that matches your JSON.</p>

<p>You need to use a map type for your item since the key is not consistent.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "net/http"
)

type Inventory struct {
    Success      bool                    `json:"success"`
    Items        map[string]*Item        `json:"rgInventory"`
    Descriptions map[string]*Description `json:"rgDescriptions"`
}

type Item struct {
    ID         string `json:"id"`
    ClassID    string `json:"classid"`
    InstanceID string `json:"instanceid"`
    Amount     string `json:"amount"`
    Pos        int    `json:"pos"`
}

type Description struct {
    Descriptions []struct {
        Value string `json:"value"`
    } `json:"descriptions"`
}

func main() {
    res, err := http.Get("http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198096365603/inventory/json/730/2")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    inventory := &amp;Inventory{}
    if err := json.NewDecoder(res.Body).Decode(&amp;inventory); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    for _, item := range inventory.Descriptions {
        for _, d := range item.Descriptions {
            fmt.Printf(d.Value)
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1817176" LastEditorUserId="1817176" LastEditDate="2017-07-24T23:19:57.620" LastActivityDate="2017-07-24T23:19:57.620" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45293123      <row Id="45293123" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45294505" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45293123" CreationDate="2017-07-25T05:21:25.297" Score="1" Body="<p>Plan internal data format to suit purpose of your application first, it should be convenient for next operations. All the application should work with internal data format and only specific input-output adapters should know about specific customers formats.
Then write adapters from custom data formats A, B, C, ... to convert to basic internal format. These adapters should be as thin as possible, they should have minimal logics - just convert data and nothing more. This way it will be easier to maintain them. 
You are right - if you change internal format you have to review and possibly change all adapters. That's why they should be very thin.
Think which defaults can you have?
I recommend to start with few customer formats to debug all concepts. 
Wheather make the solution as a set of microservices of as modules in a single monilith - has no much sense in this way. </p>
" OwnerUserId="5165332" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T05:21:25.297" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45295185      <row Id="45295185" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

</blockquote>

question:
45288751      <row Id="45288751" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45297016" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45288751" CreationDate="2017-07-25T07:46:54.397" Score="4" Body="<p>The goal to pass a pointer to something is if there is <em>need</em> to modify the pointed value. (We also use pointers to avoid copying large data structures when passing, but that is just for optimization.)</p>

<p>Like in this example:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    var i int
    fmt.Println(i)
    inc(&amp;i)
    fmt.Println(i)
}

func inc(i *int) {
    *i++
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output is the expected (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/r339Y4Z5N6" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>0
1
</code></pre>

<p>If parameter of <code>inc()</code> would receive an <code>int</code> only, it could only modify the copy and not the original value, and so the caller would not observe the changed value.</p>

<p>Same goes with pointer to pointer to something. We use pointer to pointer to something, if we need to modify the pointed value, that is the pointed pointer. Like in this example:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    var i *int
    fmt.Println(i)
    alloc(&amp;i, 1)
    fmt.Println(i, *i)

    setToNil(&amp;i)
    fmt.Println(i)
}

func alloc(i **int, initial int) {
    *i = new(int)
    **i = initial
}

func setToNil(i **int) {
    *i = nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/97eCWAp8H2" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>&lt;nil&gt;
0x1040a130 1
&lt;nil&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>The reason why pointer to pointer is not really used is because modifying a pointed value can be substituted by returning the value, and assigning it at the caller:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    var i *int
    fmt.Println(i)
    i = alloc(1)
    fmt.Println(i, *i)

    i = setToNil()
    fmt.Println(i)
}

func alloc(initial int) *int {
    i := new(int)
    *i = initial
    return i
}

func setToNil() *int {
    return nil // Nothing to do here, assignment happens at the caller!
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output is the same (address might be different) (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Ajog_7R37I" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>&lt;nil&gt;
0x1040a130 1
&lt;nil&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>This variant is easier to read and maintain, so this is clearly the favored and wide-spread alternative to functions having to modify a pointer value.</p>

<p>In languages where functions and methods can only have 1 return value, it usually requires additional "work" if the function also wants to return other values besides the pointer, e.g. a wrapper is to be created to accommodate the multiple return values. But since Go supports multiple return values, need for pointer to pointer basically drops to zero as it can be substituted with returning the pointer that would be set to the pointed pointer; and it does not require additional work and does not make code less readable.</p>

<p>This is a very similar case to the builtin <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/builtin/#append" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>append()</code></a> function: it appends values to a slice. And since the slice value changes (its length increases, also the pointer in it may also change if a new backing array needs to be allocated), <code>append()</code> returns the new slice value which you need to assign (if you want to keep the new slice).</p>

<p>See this related question where a pointer to pointer is proposed (but also returning a pointer is also viable / preferred): <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35421495/golang-can-the-pointer-in-a-struct-pointer-method-be-reassigned-to-another-inst/35426997#35426997">Golang: Can the pointer in a struct pointer method be reassigned to another instance?</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-25T08:01:50.743" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T08:01:50.743" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45296230      <row Id="45296230" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45297485" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45296230" CreationDate="2017-07-25T08:10:31.897" Score="2" Body="<p>There are two possible approaches. Unit testing a handler isn't really viable as you would need to create a <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/valyala/fasthttp#RequestCtx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">RequestCtx</a> and stub/mock all necessary fields.</p>

<p>Instead, I would unit test the code that your fasthttp handlers call out 
to. I would do e2e testing of the actual handlers themselves. </p>

<p>There is an <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/valyala/fasthttp/fasthttputil#InmemoryListener" rel="nofollow noreferrer">in memory listener</a> implementation that you could use to avoid actually listening on a TCP port or Unix socket. You would initialise the server but serve on this listener instead of on a network connection.</p>

<p>You would then create a HTTP client and call the relevant methods as normal but use this listener as the transport.</p>

<p>If you stub/fake anything that your handlers interact with then you could make this in-memory only with no external dependencies, i.e. like a unit test but it will actually doing a full system test. </p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T08:10:31.897" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45293485      <row Id="45293485" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45299068" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45293485" CreationDate="2017-07-25T09:22:56.033" Score="3" Body="<p>You can use the <code>"bytes".Join</code> function from the standard library:</p>

<pre><code>result := bytes.Join(chunks, nil)
</code></pre>

<p>First argument is your slice of slices (<code>[][]byte</code>), second argument is the separator (aka glue). In your case, the separator is an empty slice of bytes (<code>nil</code> works as well).</p>

<p>In the playground: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/8pquRk7PDo" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/8pquRk7PDo</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1147580" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T09:22:56.033" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45299133      <row Id="45299133" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45299316" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45299133" CreationDate="2017-07-25T09:33:06.777" Score="2" Body="<p>You can use the <code>map[string]interface{}</code> result and typecast the relevant parts, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>o["ret"].([]interface{})
</code></pre>

<p>would get the array and continue so on. However, this is tedious and you need to check for values being set etc as well.</p>

<p>Instead, I'd recommend you use the handy <a href="https://mholt.github.io/json-to-go/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">JSON to Go tool</a> that can automatically generate a struct definition for you to paste into your Go code when given some input JSON. </p>

<p>Obviously you might need to amend this to suit your needs as you know what valid formats the input can take. However, this tool saves a lot of tedious boilerplate code writing!</p>

<p>For example, for the JSON above, it generates:</p>

<pre><code>type AutoGenerated struct {
    Profile struct {
        ExecutionTime int `json:"execution_time"`
        ServerName string `json:"server_name"`
    } `json:"profile"`
    Result string `json:"result"`
    Ret []struct {
        Alias string `json:"alias"`
        AllParents []int `json:"all_parents"`
        Bankrupt bool `json:"bankrupt"`
        Block bool `json:"block"`
        Card interface{} `json:"card"`
    } `json:"ret"`
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T09:33:06.777" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45279385      <row Id="45279385" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45302415" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45279385" CreationDate="2017-07-25T11:50:09.750" Score="1" Body="<p><strong>Use -trimpath flags to remove path information:</strong></p>

<pre><code>CGO_ENABLED=0 go build -v -a -ldflags="-w -s" \
    -gcflags=-trimpath=/Users/myuser/dev/go/src \
    -asmflags=-trimpath=/Users/myuser/dev/go/src \
    -o ./fooapi spikes/mongoapi.go
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p><strong>More Information:</strong></p>

<p>Passing <code>-trimpath</code> to <code>-gcflags</code> and <code>-asmflags</code> will remove any path information from the elf binary.</p>

<pre><code>$ go tool asm -help 2&gt;&amp;1 | grep -A1 trimpath
-trimpath string
    remove prefix from recorded source file paths

$ go tool compile -help|grep -A1 trimpath
-trimpath string
    remove prefix from recorded source file paths
</code></pre>

<p><strong>You can check the result with <code>go tool objdump</code>:</strong></p>

<pre><code>$ go tool objdump ./fooapi
.
.
TEXT main.init(SB) api/spikes/mongoapi.go
mongoapi.go:60  0x12768c0   65488b0c25a0080000  GS MOVQ GS:0x8a0, CX
mongoapi.go:60  0x12768c9   483b6110        CMPQ 0x10(CX), SP
mongoapi.go:60  0x12768cd   7663            JBE 0x1276932
.
.
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>Using <code>strip</code> tool has still some controversies in go community, although it's been said that it's been fixed. Some say that unknown and unpredictable bugs occur sometimes. Read <a href="https://github.com/moby/moby/blob/2a95488f7843a773de2b541a47d9b971a635bfff/project/PACKAGERS.md#stripping-binaries" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a> and <a href="https://go-review.googlesource.com/c/20584/3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a> for examples.</p>
" OwnerUserId="115363" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T11:50:09.750" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45300938      <row Id="45300938" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45302652" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45300938" CreationDate="2017-07-25T12:00:56.027" Score="3" Body="<p>You can use the <code>ioutil.ReadFile</code> function for this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "io/ioutil"
)

func main() {
    fd, err := ioutil.ReadFile("/var/run/utmpx")
    fmt.Println(string(fd), err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The problem in your original code is that you read into <code>data</code> that is 0 bytes long. Since the reader interface reads only reads up to <code>len(data)</code>, it reads nothing. More on that: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="248922" LastEditorUserId="248922" LastEditDate="2017-07-25T12:07:28.767" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T12:07:28.767" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45268681      <row Id="45268681" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45302920" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45268681" CreationDate="2017-07-25T12:11:48.693" Score="1" Body="<p>Switch is not a bunch of ifs. It's more akin to <code>if {} else if {}</code> construct, but with a couple of twists - namely <code>break</code> and <code>fallthrough</code>. It's not possible to make switch execute first and third cases - a switch does not check each condition, it finds first match and executes it. That's all.</p>

<p>It's primary purpose is to walk through a list of possible values and execute a different code for each value. In fact, in C (where switch statement came from) switch expression can only be of integral type and case values can only be constants that switch expression will be compared too. It's only relatively recently, languages started adding support for strings, boolean expressions etc in switch cases.</p>

<p>As to fallthrough logic it also comes from C. There is no fallthrough operator in C. In C execution falls through into next case (without checking case values) unless break operator encountered. The reason for this design is that sometimes you need to do something special and then do same steps as in another case. So, this design merely allows that. Unfortunately, it's rather rarely useful, so falling through by default was causing more trouble when programmer forgotten to put a break statement in, then actually helping when truly omitted that break intentionally. So, many modern languages change this logic to never fall through by default and to require explicit fallthrough statement if falling through is actually required.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, it's a it hard to come up with a non contrived example of fallthrough being useful that would be short enough to fit into an answer. As I said it's relatively rare. But sometimes you need to write code similar to this:</p>

<pre><code>if x == a || x == b {
  if x == a {
    // do action a
  }
  // do action ab
} else if x == c {
   // do action c
} else if x == d {
  // do action d
}
</code></pre>

<p>In fact, I needed code of similar structure quite recently in one of my projects. So, I used switch statement instead. And it looked like this:</p>

<pre><code>switch x {
  case a: // do action a
          fallthrough
  case b: // do action ab
  case c: // do action c
  case d: // do action d
}
</code></pre>

<p>And your switch from the question is functionally equivalent to this:</p>

<pre><code>if 1 == 1 || 2 == 1 {
    if 1 == 1 {
        fmt.Println("1 == 1")
    }
    fmt.Println("2 == 1")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6375498" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T12:11:48.693" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45302935      <row Id="45302935" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45302980" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45302935" CreationDate="2017-07-25T12:14:43.713" Score="6" Body="<p>If you want it to work on values, don't call <code>Type.Elem()</code> on the reflect type. To handle both (pointers and non-pointers), check if it is of pointer type, and only then call <code>Type.Elem()</code>:</p>

<pre><code>elemsType := reflect.TypeOf(obj)
if elemsType.Kind() == reflect.Ptr {
    elemsType = elemsType.Elem()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T12:14:43.713" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45302931      <row Id="45302931" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45303050" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45302931" CreationDate="2017-07-25T12:17:17.933" Score="3" Body="<p>It's because you you don't close the stdin. Add <code>stdin.Close()</code> after <code>io.Copy</code>. <code>cat</code> will then terminate.</p>

<p>Also, I know it's just an example but there is absolutely no error checking. I assume that's just for illustration purposes. :-)</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T12:17:17.933" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45302708      <row Id="45302708" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45303524" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45302708" CreationDate="2017-07-25T12:37:12.073" Score="3" Body="<p>Slices in Go are dynamically-sized, you shouldn't treat them like arrays.</p>

<p>In the first loop don't use <code>len(dadhu)</code> to initialize the slice if you don't know the exact size. </p>

<p>Instead, make an empty slice:</p>

<pre><code>patu[c.DadID] = make([]map[string]string, 0)
</code></pre>

<p>In the second loop, append maps to it:</p>

<pre><code>patu[c.DadID] = append(patu[c.DadID], map[string]string{"id": cID, "name": c.Name})
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4283005" LastEditorUserId="4283005" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T07:43:38.567" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T07:43:38.567" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45303326      <row Id="45303326" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45304122" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45303326" CreationDate="2017-07-25T12:59:05.140" Score="5" Body="<p>That's a case when you need to implement custom marshal und unmarshal functions.</p>

<pre><code>UnmarshalJSON(b []byte) error { ... }

MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) { ... }
</code></pre>

<p>By following the example in the Golang documentation of <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#pkg-overview" rel="nofollow noreferrer">json package</a> you get something like:</p>

<pre><code>// first create a type alias
type JsonBirthDate time.Time

// Add that to your struct
type Person struct {
    Name string `json:"name"`
    BirthDate JsonBirthDate `json:"birth_date"`
}

// imeplement Marshaler und Unmarshalere interface
func (j *JsonBirthDate) UnmarshalJSON(b []byte) error {
    s := strings.Trim(string(b), "\"")
    t, err := time.Parse("2006-01-02", s)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    *j = JB(t)
    return nil
}

func (j JsonBirthDate) MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) {
    return json.Marshal(j)
}

// Maybe a Format function for printing your date
func (j JsonBirthDate) Format(s string) string {
    t := time.Time(j)
    return t.Format(s)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1188357" LastEditorUserId="1188357" LastEditDate="2017-07-25T13:12:30.263" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T13:12:30.263" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45306497      <row Id="45306497" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45306574" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45306497" CreationDate="2017-07-25T14:41:59.153" Score="5" Body="<p>Deadlock may easily occur if one method of <code>cache</code> calls another method, and both contain the <code>Lock()</code> call.</p>

<p>See this example:</p>

<pre><code>func (this *cache) f1() {
    this.mutex.Lock()
    defer this.mutex.Unlock()
    this.f2()
}

func (this *cache) f2() {
    this.mutex.Lock()
    defer this.mutex.Unlock()
}

func main() {
    c := &amp;cache{}
    c.Init()
    c.f1()
    fmt.Println("Hello, playground")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/RR_ohOhnot" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>fatal error: all goroutines are asleep - deadlock!

goroutine 1 [semacquire]:
sync.runtime_SemacquireMutex(0x1040a12c, 0x8)
    /usr/local/go/src/runtime/sema.go:62 +0x40
sync.(*Mutex).Lock(0x1040a128, 0x10429f5c)
    /usr/local/go/src/sync/mutex.go:87 +0xa0
main.(*cache).f2(0x10429f94, 0x1100c0)
    /tmp/sandbox647646735/main.go:23 +0x40
main.(*cache).f1(0x10429f94, 0xdf6e0)
    /tmp/sandbox647646735/main.go:19 +0xa0
main.main()
    /tmp/sandbox647646735/main.go:30 +0x60
</code></pre>

<p>Note that there does not need to have a direct call from one method to the other, it may also be a transitive call. For example <code>cache.f1()</code> may call <code>foo()</code> which may be a "standalone" function, and if <code>foo()</code> calls <code>cache.f2()</code>, we're at the same deadlock.</p>

<p><strong>Improvements:</strong></p>

<p>Don't name your receiver <code>this</code>, it is not idiomatic. You may simply call it <code>c</code>. Read more about it here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23482068/in-go-is-naming-the-receiver-variable-self-misleading-or-good-practice/23494386#23494386">In Go is naming the receiver variable &#39;self&#39; misleading or good practice?</a></p>

<p>You may embed mutexes, making it convenient to use and eliminate the need for initialization. Read more about it here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44949467/when-do-you-embed-mutex-in-struct-in-go/44950096#44950096">When do you embed mutex in struct in Go?</a></p>

<pre><code>type cache struct {
    sync.Mutex
}

func (c *cache) f1() {
    c.Lock()
    defer c.Unlock()
    c.f2()
}

func (c *cache) f2() {
    c.Lock()
    defer c.Unlock()
}

func main() {
    c := &amp;cache{}
    c.f1()
    fmt.Println("Hello, playground")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Of course this also causes a deadlock. Try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/6RICGd0Fwm" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>. Also note that this inherently exposes the mutex (as the embedded type starts with lowecae letter), so anyone will be able to call the <code>Lock()</code> and <code>Unlock()</code> methods. Depends on case whether this is a problem.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-25T15:31:50.147" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T15:31:50.147" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45308108      <row Id="45308108" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45308172" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45308108" CreationDate="2017-07-25T15:52:29.743" Score="6" Body="<p>From the <a href="https://caddyserver.com/docs/proxy" rel="noreferrer">caddy docs</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p><strong>to</strong> is the destination endpoint to proxy to. At least one is required,
  but multiple may be specified. If a scheme (http/https) is not
  specified, http is used. Unix sockets may also be used by prefixing
  "unix:".</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So maybe it is sending <strong>http</strong> requests to the proxied <strong>https</strong> endpoint.</p>

<p>Does </p>

<pre><code>mysite.com {
    proxy / https://localhost:9000 {
        max_fails 1
    }
    log logfile
}
</code></pre>

<p>fix it?</p>

<p>If that is the case, you may not strictly need your app on :9000 to listen https. It may simplify your deployment or cert management to just have it listen http and have caddy manage all the certs.</p>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T15:52:29.743" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45310156      <row Id="45310156" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45310432" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45310156" CreationDate="2017-07-25T17:53:08.537" Score="2" Body="<p>That definitely won't work. GOPATH isn't just the path of some project; it's the root of a directory, which contains <code>bin</code>, <code>pkg</code>, and <code>src</code> directories; the <code>src</code> directory contains package-named directories for projects. So you should be running <code>godep</code> from your project directory, which (given your current GOPATH) should be <code>/Users/sarath/project/src/&lt;repopath&gt;</code> - e.g. <code>/Users/sarath/project/src/github.com/sarath/myproject</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T17:53:08.537" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45310329      <row Id="45310329" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45310587" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45310329" CreationDate="2017-07-25T18:01:32.390" Score="3" Body="<p>They are related but not identical.</p>

<p><code>InDelta</code> receives an absolute value and checks that the difference is less than that value.</p>

<p><code>InEpsilon</code> receives a % of difference that would be acceptable.</p>

<p>The behaviour of <code>InDelta</code> is quite straightforward:</p>

<pre><code>InDelta(t, 100, 101, 2) // that's OK
InDelta(t, 100, 103, 2) // fail!
</code></pre>

<p>But sometimes, you just care that the actual value is not too far away from the expected value.</p>

<p>Depending on how small or large the expected value is "not too far away" might get tricky with <code>InDelta</code>.</p>

<p>It might be a problem to use the same <code>delta</code> value for any number:</p>

<pre><code>InDelta(t, 100, 101, 2) // ok, 101 is "not too far away" from 100
InDelta(t,   1,   2, 2) // hm, 2 sounds "too far away" from 1...
</code></pre>

<p>If you use <code>InEpsilon</code>, you can always use the same %:</p>

<pre><code>InEpsilon(t, 100, 101, 0.02) // ok, up to 102 would be acceptable
InEpsilon(t,   1,   2, 0.02) // will not pass.. this time up to 1.02 would be acceptable
</code></pre>

<p>In summary, the use case for <code>nEpsilon</code> is to discard small differences (and making "small" relative to the actual values compared).</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T18:01:32.390" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45287975      <row Id="45287975" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45310694" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45287975" CreationDate="2017-07-25T18:06:38.353" Score="0" Body="<p>I like to do this way:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>Establish Continuous Integration. If your project is Open Source, you may use services like <a href="https://travis-ci.org/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Travis CI</a> - it has very easy installation. This helps you to see how changes affect code.</p></li>
<li><p>Set code test coverage. It allows you to see what  source code lines are covered with tests and what are not and where very possible bugs will emerge. Of course, code coverage tool is not a panacea. And if line was checked it doesn't mean it is absolutely ok, and it will not fail with other input. But it helps much to maintain good code and look for bugs. For open source you may use coveralls.io. There's a special <a href="https://github.com/mattn/goveralls" rel="nofollow noreferrer">goveralls</a> plugin for it.</p></li>
<li><p>To help the problem above you may use so-called Fuzzy testing - exploratory tests with random input to find a root cause. There're standard <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/quick/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/testing/quick/</a> and non-standard packages <a href="https://github.com/dvyukov/go-fuzz" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/dvyukov/go-fuzz</a>.</p></li>
</ol>

<p>Then I experiment with tests, they are both positive and negative. I try check situation with errors, timeouts, incorrect replies.</p>

<p>For my tests I've used as usual client <code>http</code> so <code>httptest</code> package.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5165332" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T18:06:38.353" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45313167      <row Id="45313167" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45313209" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45313167" CreationDate="2017-07-25T20:47:24.290" Score="2" Body="<p>Fields need to be exported (declared with an uppercase first letter) or the reflection library cannot edit them. Since the JSON (un)marshaller uses reflection, it cannot read or write unexported fields.</p>

<p>So yes, it is expected, and no, you cannot change it. Sorry.</p>

<p>You can add tags to a field to change the name the marshaller uses:</p>

<pre><code>Model string `json:"model"`
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the documentation</a> for more info on the field tags "encoding/json" supports.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T20:47:24.290" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45313231      <row Id="45313231" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45313967" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45313231" CreationDate="2017-07-25T21:41:06.023" Score="1" Body="<p>I think you want:</p>

<pre><code>for _ , i := range result {
    for  _, j := range i.Host {
        if j.Status == "good" {
            server := j.Ip
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastEditorUserId="1094529" LastEditDate="2017-07-25T21:48:18.460" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T21:48:18.460" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45314609      <row Id="45314609" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45314992" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45314609" CreationDate="2017-07-25T23:24:32.303" Score="1" Body="<p>Your problem here is that the test engine is not running your executable with the working directory you expect. Instead of using the working directory defined by your shell or IDE, it is setting it to the source directory of the code being tested. (I had this bite me too once, long ago :) I had almost forgotten about that...)</p>

<p>The simple solution is to change <code>DerivePath</code> so that you can set the prefix externally, then change it to a the path you need at the beginning of your tests. There are other (possibly better?) solutions of course.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-07-25T23:24:32.303" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45317074      <row Id="45317074" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45317241" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45317074" CreationDate="2017-07-26T04:03:06.360" Score="1" Body="<p>First, it's a slice not an array. Arrays and slices in Go are very different, arrays have a fixed size that is part of the type. I had trouble with this at first too :)</p>

<ol>
<li>Not really. Any if the three is correct, and any difference should be too small to worry about. In my own code I generally use whatever is easiest in a particular case.</li>
<li>0</li>
<li>Nothing, until you need to add an item, then whatever it costs to allocate the storage needed.</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T04:03:06.360" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45316699      <row Id="45316699" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45319489" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45316699" CreationDate="2017-07-26T06:50:12.503" Score="0" Body="<p>You do not need to create a local variables for each field, just create a struct and use it to read data into and use a slice to accumulate results:</p>

<pre><code>// struct definition must be out of functions body
type newR struct {
    id string
    eventid string
    excel_id string
    userid string
    hallid string
}

var newRs []newR
for rows.Next() {
    var current newR
    err = rows.Scan(&amp;current.id, &amp;current.eventid, &amp;current.excel_id, &amp;current.userid, &amp;current.hallid)
    newRs = append(newRs, r)
}
</code></pre>

<p>And also it is better to check for errors after <code>rows.Next()</code> and <code>rows.Scan(...)</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T06:50:12.503" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45318603      <row Id="45318603" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45321654" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45318603" CreationDate="2017-07-26T08:39:24.917" Score="2" Body="<p>I think you're going about this the wrong way. If you were wanting to use the C library, you would use the C library to read the file.</p>

<p>Don't use cgo purely to have struct definitions, you should create these in Go yourself. You could then write the appropriate marshal / unmarshal code to read from the raw bytes. </p>

<p>A quick Google shows that someone has already done the work required to convert a look of the relevant C library to Go. See the <a href="https://github.com/ericlagergren/go-gnulib/tree/master/utmp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">utmp repository</a>.</p>

<p>A short example of how this could be used is:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
    "log"

    "github.com/ericlagergren/go-gnulib/utmp"
)

func handleError(err error) {
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}

func byteToStr(b []byte) string {
    i := bytes.IndexByte(b, 0)
    if i == -1 {
        i = len(b)
    }
    return string(b[:i])
}

func main() {
    list, err := utmp.ReadUtmp(utmp.UtmpxFile, 0)
    handleError(err)
    for _, u := range list {
        fmt.Println(byteToStr(u.User[:]))
    }
} 
</code></pre>

<p>You can view the <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/ericlagergren/go-gnulib/utmp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">GoDoc</a> for the <code>utmp</code> package for more information.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastEditorUserId="8356442" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T09:09:51.767" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T09:09:51.767" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45321981      <row Id="45321981" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45322853" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45321981" CreationDate="2017-07-26T09:28:43.843" Score="1" Body="<p>On the assumption that your input is space separated signed integers (in base 10), try the following:</p>

<pre><code>s := bufio.NewScanner(os.StdIn)
s.Split(bufio.ScanWords)
i := 0
for s.Scan() &amp;&amp; i &lt; n {
    dest[i], _ = strconv.ParseInt(s.Text(), 10, 64)
    i++
}
</code></pre>

<p>This shows with a quick benchmark to be about 5 times faster than using <code>fmt.Scanf</code>. It could probably be further optimised by writing a custom split function that did not worry about parsing UTF-8 runes and simply split on <code>' '</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T09:28:43.843" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45323772      <row Id="45323772" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45323824" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45323772" CreationDate="2017-07-26T10:07:49.050" Score="3" Body="<p>You have to use forward slashes <code>/</code> in import paths (of import declarations), even if you're on Windows.</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Import_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Import declarations:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Implementation restriction: A compiler may restrict ImportPaths to non-empty strings using only characters belonging to <a href="http://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode6.3.0/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Unicode's</a> L, M, N, P, and S general categories (the Graphic characters without spaces) and <strong>may also exclude the characters <code>!"#$%&amp;'()*,:;&lt;=&gt;?[\]^</code>{|}` and the Unicode replacement character U+FFFD</strong>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Any compiler may exclude the backslash <code>\</code> character among others. Even if you would use one that doesn't, your code would not be portable.</p>

<p>So instead try:</p>

<pre><code>import (
    pb "github.com/sewelol/sgx-decryption-service/decryptionservice"
    dev "github.com/sewelol/sgx-decryption-service/device"
    "google.golang.org/rpc"
)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T13:03:58.267" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T13:03:58.267" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45314871      <row Id="45314871" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45324345" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45314871" CreationDate="2017-07-26T10:29:14.587" Score="0" Body="<p>Make sure you have your sort pipeline stage <em>before</em> your limit &amp; skip stages. You can only reliably obtain the same results with limit/skip on sorted input. </p>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong></p>

<p>Realised that you are using <code>bson.M {"pro": -1, "check": -1}</code> to define your sort order. The iteration order of a map is unspecified in Go and can change. Hence this is probably why you are getting inconsistent results.</p>

<p>Try changing this to a <code>bson.D</code> so that the order of columns to sort by is maintained.</p>

<p>It make help to see how the query <a href="http://bazaar.launchpad.net/+branch/mgo/v2/view/head:/session.go#L2130" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Sort</a> method constructs this from the strings you provide.</p>

<p>For your use case, you would change the <code>or</code> variable to:</p>

<pre><code>or := bson.M{
    "$sort": bson.D{
        bson.DocElem{Name: "pro", Value: -1},
        bson.DocElem{Name: "check", Value: -1},
     },
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastEditorUserId="8356442" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T13:39:50.383" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T13:39:50.383" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45326078      <row Id="45326078" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45326273" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45326078" CreationDate="2017-07-26T11:56:33.607" Score="2" Body="<p>You can find a few examples in the <a href="https://github.com/olivere/elastic/blob/504b3df94cbedf3cd45dc543e93fd33f603d1809/bulk_test.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">test classes</a> and is pretty well <a href="https://github.com/olivere/elastic/wiki/BulkIndex" rel="nofollow noreferrer">explained in the wiki</a>. It goes like this:</p>

<pre><code>indexName := "someindex"
typeName  := "sometype"
index1Req := NewBulkIndexRequest().Index(indexName).Type(typeName).Id("existing_id").Doc({...})
index2Req := NewBulkIndexRequest().Index(indexName).Type(typeName).Id("existing_id2").Doc({...})

bulkRequest := client.Bulk()
bulkRequest = bulkRequest.Add(index1Req)
bulkRequest = bulkRequest.Add(index2Req)

bulkResponse, err := bulkRequest.Do(context.TODO())
if err != nil {
    t.Fatal(err)
}
...
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4604579" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T11:56:33.607" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45328119      <row Id="45328119" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45328195" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45328119" CreationDate="2017-07-26T13:17:42.363" Score="5" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Struct_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Embedding</a> a type in a struct adds a field to the struct, and you can use the unqualified type name to refer to it (unqualified means omit the package name and the optional pointer sign).</p>

<p>For example:</p>

<pre><code>box := rated.Box
fmt.Printf("%T %+v", box, box)
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/JCd4XNt2rC" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>main.Box {Name:foo}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Assignments" rel="nofollow noreferrer">assignment</a> copies the value, so the <code>box</code> local variable will hold a copy of the value of the <code>RatedBox.Box</code> field. If you want them to be the "same" (to point to the same <code>Box</code> value), use a pointer, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>box := &amp;rated.Box
fmt.Printf("%T %+v", box, box)
</code></pre>

<p>But here of course type of <code>box</code> will be <code>*Box</code>.</p>

<p>Or you may choose to embed the pointer type:</p>

<pre><code>type RatedBox struct {
    *Box
    Points int
}
</code></pre>

<p>And then (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/HkVjCyb3e4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>rated := RatedBox{Box: &amp;Box{Name: "foo"}, Points: 10}

box := rated.Box
fmt.Printf("%T %+v", box, box)
</code></pre>

<p>Output of the last 2:</p>

<pre><code>*main.Box &amp;{Name:foo}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T13:25:38.467" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T13:25:38.467" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45333364      <row Id="45333364" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45333669" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45333364" CreationDate="2017-07-26T17:23:07.967" Score="2" Body="<p>Its important to check the returned error always. </p>

<pre><code>if err := xml.Unmarshal([]byte(xmlRawData), &amp;xmlData); err != nil {
    fmt.Println(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The error you're getting is</p>

<pre><code>cannot unmarshal into interface {}
</code></pre>

<p>Empty interface cannot be unmarshalled since the empty interface doesn't have any exported fields to map the xml keys/values to.</p>

<p>However there is way to get around. Implementing <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/#Unmarshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer">xml.Unmarshaler</a> interface on your <code>VendorMapInfo</code> struct.</p>

<p>Example: Your updated code</p>

<pre><code>type VendorMapInfo struct {
    MapHierarchyString string      `xml:"mapHierarchyString,attr"`
    FloorRefID         interface{} `xml:"floorRefId,attr"`
    Image              Image       `xml:"Image"`
    FloorDimension     VendorFloorDimension
}

type Image struct {
    Name string `xml:"imageName,attr"`
}

func (mf *VendorMapInfo) UnmarshalXML(d *xml.Decoder, start xml.StartElement) error {
    // Attributes
    for _, attr := range start.Attr {
        switch attr.Name.Local {
        case "mapHierarchyString":
            mf.MapHierarchyString = attr.Value
        case "floorRefId":
            mf.FloorRefID = findFloorRefIDType(attr.Value)
        }
    }

    for {
        token, err := d.Token()
        if err != nil {
            return err
        }

        switch el := token.(type) {
        case xml.StartElement:
            if el.Name.Local == "Image" {
                item := new(Image)
                if err = d.DecodeElement(item, &amp;el); err != nil {
                    return err
                }
                mf.Image = *item
            }
        case xml.EndElement:
            if el == start.End() {
                return nil
            }
        }
    }

    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Complete code, play link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/wZQOsQv0Nq" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/wZQOsQv0Nq</a></p>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>{Locations:{Space: Local:} WirelessClientLocation:[{MacAddress:00:00:00:00:00:00 MapInfo:{MapHierarchyString:Head office&gt;Ground floor&gt;Store FloorRefID:-1122334455667789 Image:{Name:floorPlan1.png} FloorDimension:{Length:0 Width:0 Height:0 OffsetX:0 OffsetY:0 Unit:}}} {MacAddress:11:11:11:11:11:11 MapInfo:{MapHierarchyString:Head office&gt;Ground floor&gt;Store FloorRefID:-1122334455667789 Image:{Name:floorPlan1.png} FloorDimension:{Length:0 Width:0 Height:0 OffsetX:0 OffsetY:0 Unit:}}} {MacAddress:26:cd:96:46:0b:2b MapInfo:{MapHierarchyString: FloorRefID:0 Image:{Name:} FloorDimension:{Length:0 Width:0 Height:0 OffsetX:0 OffsetY:0 Unit:}}}]}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T18:30:21.990" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T18:30:21.990" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45334244      <row Id="45334244" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45334395" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45334244" CreationDate="2017-07-26T18:03:46.717" Score="3" Body="<p>If you need to support arbitrary levels of pointers then you can use reflection to get the value object:</p>

<pre><code>v:=reflect.ValueOf(obj)
for v.Kind() == reflect.Ptr {
    v = v.Elem()
}
v.Interface()
</code></pre>

<p>However, this is quite unusual to actually need to do in practice. </p>

<p>For your function, this could work as something like:</p>

<pre><code>func TestFunc(obj interface{}){
    rv := reflect.ValueOf(obj)
    switch rv.Kind() {
        case reflect.Struct:
            // code here
            return
        case reflect.Ptr:
            TestFunc(rv.Elm().Interface()) 
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastEditorUserId="8356442" LastEditDate="2017-07-26T18:24:55.503" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T18:24:55.503" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45334968      <row Id="45334968" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45335515" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45334968" CreationDate="2017-07-26T19:09:09.453" Score="1" Body="<p>What's going to be calling these? At some point there is an actual consumer, and that consumer will (presumably, based on your code) be using an interface (either <code>layer</code> or an identical interface). If there's middleware, that interface will <em>necessarily be as generic as the middleware</em> - i.e., taking a <code>interface{}</code> as a parameter to <code>Run</code>. So making something downstream more specific (besides not compiling as you've seen) doesn't make any sense: the actual consumer won't see the more-specific interface, it will see <code>Run(Context,interface{}) (interface{},error)</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T19:09:09.453" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45335327      <row Id="45335327" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45337334" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45335327" CreationDate="2017-07-26T20:59:57.497" Score="1" Body="<p>This is possibly the answer you are looking for. First off, you aren't using <code>termui</code> correctly. You need to call it's <code>Loop</code> function to start the <code>Event</code> loop so that it can actually start listening for the <code>q</code> key. <code>Loop</code> is called last because it essentially takes control of the main goroutine from then on until <code>StopLoop</code> is called and it quits.</p>

<p>In order to stop the goroutines, it is common to have a "stop" channel. Usually it is a <code>chan struct{}</code> to save memory because you don't ever have to put anything in it. Wherever you want the goroutine to possibly stop and shutoff (or do something else perhaps), you use a <code>select</code> statement with the <code>channel</code>s you are using. This <code>select</code> is ordered, so it will take from them in order unless they block, in which case it tries the next one, so the <code>stop</code> <code>channel</code> usually goes first. The <code>stop</code> channel normally blocks, but to get it to take this path, simply <code>close()</code>ing it will cause this path to be chosen in the <code>select</code>. So we <code>close()</code> it in the <code>q</code> keyboard handler.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "github.com/gizak/termui"
    "strconv"
    "time"
)

func getData(ch chan string, stop chan struct{}) {
    i := 0
    for {
        select {
        case &lt;-stop:
            break
        case ch &lt;- strconv.Itoa(i):
        }
        i++
        time.Sleep(time.Second)
        if i == 20 {
            break
        }
    }
}

func Display(ch chan string, stop chan struct{}) {

    for {
        var elem string
        select {
        case &lt;-stop:
            break
        case elem = &lt;-ch:
        }
        par := termui.NewPar(elem)
        par.Height = 5
        par.Width = 37
        par.Y = 4
        par.BorderLabel = "term ui example with chan"
        par.BorderFg = termui.ColorYellow
        termui.Render(par)
    }
}

func main() {
    ch := make(chan string)
    stop := make(chan struct{})
    err := termui.Init()
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    defer termui.Close()
    termui.Handle("/sys/kbd/q", func(termui.Event) {
        fmt.Println("q captured")
        close(stop)
        termui.StopLoop()
    })
    go getData(ch, stop)
    go Display(ch, stop)
    termui.Loop()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T20:59:57.497" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45337881      <row Id="45337881" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45338208" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45337881" CreationDate="2017-07-26T22:05:07.210" Score="1" Body="<p>I might do something like this..</p>

<pre><code>func sendUser(user string, ch chan&lt;- string, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
    defer wg.Done()
    resp, err := http.Get("URL/" + user)
    if err != nil {
        log.Println("err handle it")
    }
    defer resp.Body.Close()
    b, err := ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    if err != nil {
        log.Println("err handle it")
    }
    ch &lt;- string(b)
}

func AsyncHTTP(users []string) ([]string, error) {
    ch := make(chan string)
    var responses []string
    var user string
    var wg sync.WaitGroup
    for _, user = range users {
        wg.Add(1)
        go sendUser(user, ch, &amp;wg)
    }

    // close the channel in the background
    go func() {
        wg.Wait()
        close(ch)
    }()
    // read from channel as they come in until its closed
    for res := range ch {
        responses = append(responses, res)
    }

    return responses, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>It allows to read from the channel as they are sent.  By using a waitgroup I'll know when to close the channel. By putting the waitgroup and close in a goroutine I can read from the channel in "realtime" without blocking.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4639336" LastActivityDate="2017-07-26T22:05:07.210" CommentCount="4" />

45338830      <row Id="45338830" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
