question:
45342640      <row Id="45342640" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45342748" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45342640" CreationDate="2017-07-27T06:18:28.013" Score="3" Body="<p>You should create a Repository struct by cloning a repo: </p>

<pre><code>import {
  git "github.com/src-d/go-git"
}

repo, err := git.Clone(memory.NewStorage(), nil, &amp;git.CloneOptions{
    URL: "https://github.com/src-d/go-siva",
})
</code></pre>

<p>And then on the repo struct call Pull.</p>

<pre><code>err := repo.Pull(&amp;git.PullOptions{
    RemoteName: "origin"
})
</code></pre>

<p>You cannot call <code>git.Pull</code> directly.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3310285" LastEditorUserId="3310285" LastEditDate="2017-07-27T06:57:13.740" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T06:57:13.740" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45345006      <row Id="45345006" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45346007" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45345006" CreationDate="2017-07-27T09:00:43.043" Score="1" Body="<p>What are you passing into <code>NewSession</code> as the <code>ca</code> parameter? This needs to be the PEM encoded CA certificate bytes, not the file name of the CA certificate.  <code>AppendCertsFromPEM</code> will return <code>true</code> if it managed to add any certificates to the pool.</p>

<p>The article already shows code to do this:</p>

<pre><code>if ca, err := ioutil.ReadFile("myPEM"); err == nil { 
    roots.AppendCertsFromPEM(ca)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The SSL error means that the client is rejecting the server certificate. I suspect it is because your self-signed certificate was not added to the pool correctly.</p>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong></p>

<p>I ran a copy of mongo locally with your config. Using docker, this was:</p>

<pre><code>docker run --rm -ti -v $(pwd):/data/mongo --net=host mongo -f /data/mongo/mongo.yaml
</code></pre>

<p><em>When ran from where your configuration was extracted</em></p>

<p>Using your <code>NewSession</code> func inside Go showed that the <code>tls.Dial</code> was returning an error due to the lack of any Subject Access Name (SAN) extensions as per my comment below.</p>

<p>You will need to correct your server certificate to have the appropriate host name (or IP address) SAN entries required. </p>

<p>You can debug this and any other TLS connection errors that occur with:</p>

<pre><code>dialInfo.DialServer = func(addr *mgo.ServerAddr) (net.Conn, error) {
    conn, err := tls.Dial("tcp", addr.String(), tlsConfig)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
    }
    return conn, err
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastEditorUserId="8356442" LastEditDate="2017-07-27T11:47:02.230" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T11:47:02.230" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45347894      <row Id="45347894" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45348025" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45347894" CreationDate="2017-07-27T10:24:13.497" Score="3" Body="<p>There is an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/crypto/sha1/#New" rel="nofollow noreferrer">example</a> of how to use it properly. You should do:</p>

<pre><code>c := sha1.New()
io.WriteString(c, "hello")
myBytes := c.Sum(nil)
fmt.Println(base64.StdEncoding.EncodeToString(myBytes))
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/sELsWTcrdd" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/sELsWTcrdd</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1892060" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T10:24:13.497" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45350097      <row Id="45350097" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45350225" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45350097" CreationDate="2017-07-27T12:01:33.807" Score="5" Body="<p>An interface value is a wrapper under the hood, a pair of the concrete value stored in the interface value and its type descriptor.</p>

<p>Read this for more information: <a href="https://blog.golang.org/laws-of-reflection#TOC_3." rel="nofollow noreferrer">The Laws of Reflection #The representation of an interface</a></p>

<p>So if you want to return a value of <code>interface{}</code> type, an <code>interface{}</code> value will be implicitly created (if the value being returned is not already of that type), which will hold the integer number and its type descriptor denoting the <code>int64</code> type. You can't avoid this.</p>

<p><code>interface{}</code> is a special interface type (having 0 methods). Its value is only 8 bytes as you see on the benchmark output. Other interface types have larger size (double) as they also have to identify the static method set of the interface type (besides the dynamic type and value).</p>

<p>Also be sure to check out this informative answer: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23148812/go-whats-the-meaning-of-interface/23148998#23148998">Go: What&#39;s the meaning of interface{}?</a></p>

<p>If you want more information about the implementation / internals, I recommend this post: <a href="http://www.tapirgames.com/blog/golang-interface-implementation" rel="nofollow noreferrer">How Interfaces Work in Golang</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-27T16:30:03.400" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T16:30:03.400" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45351208      <row Id="45351208" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45351271" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45351208" CreationDate="2017-07-27T12:47:47.997" Score="4" Body="<p>If you want to capture the bytes as they are written, use an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#MultiWriter" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.MultiWriter</code></a> with a <code>bytes.Buffer</code> as the second writer.</p>

<pre><code>var buf bytes.Buffer
w := io.MultiWriter(codeFile, &amp;buf)
</code></pre>

<p>or to see the file on stdout as it's written:</p>

<pre><code>w := io.MultiWriter(codeFile, os.Stdout)
</code></pre>

<p>Otherwise, if you want to re-read the same file, you need to seek back to the start after writing:</p>

<pre><code>codeFile.Seek(0, 0)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-07-27T14:06:46.717" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T14:06:46.717" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45332625      <row Id="45332625" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45352445" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45332625" CreationDate="2017-07-27T13:36:51.473" Score="1" Body="<p>You've stumbled onto a non-trivial problem. There are a lot of possible solutions, with different user experiences, implementation complexities, and side effects. This is a pretty big topic so this answer is intended mostly as a starting point for further research.</p>

<h1>The Simplest Option</h1>

<p>First, pretty much regardless of solution, you're going to have to give each long-running task a unique ID that the browser can use to get status updates later. The task runner itself can just flag jobs as complete, or it can periodically issue progress updates if you want to present progress to the user.</p>

<p>The easiest to implement is likely to have your form submission immediately respond with a page, with the task ID included in the URL, whose handler checks the task status and either a) returns a page with "still working" or something to that effect and auto-refreshes after a few seconds, or b) returns a page saying "completed" and does not refresh. This isn't terribly difficult to implement, but it's not particularly smooth, either. If this is a simple internal-use project with simple UX and operational requirements, I'd just do this. Otherwise, further down the rabbit hole we go!</p>

<h1>Live Updates</h1>

<p>You could do live updates without reloading the page by a few different methods:</p>

<ul>
<li>Regular AJAX requests to check the status of the task, updating the UI based on the response. This would have a REST-style handler on the back end.</li>
<li>You can use <a href="https://godoc.org/golang.org/x/net/websocket" rel="nofollow noreferrer">WebSockets</a> to do the same thing over a single connection.</li>
<li>You can use HTTP long-polling to simulate WebSocket-like behavior, but this has generally been supplanted by WebSockets.</li>
</ul>

<p>Either option will require both a handler to serve the status update information and some JavaScript wizardry on the front-end to call the handler, parse the response, and update the page.</p>

<h1>Side-Effects</h1>

<p>Depending on the scale and requirements of this service, there are some side-effects to consider; mainly that a long-running task is effectively a kind of application state, making your application stateful, which has some severe operational downsides when it comes to availability, scaling, and deployment. If you're running multiple load-balanced instances you'll have to use sticky sessions or share task status between instances somehow.</p>

<p>The most common way to handle long-running tasks at scale is to separate the worker from the web application, using some kind of work queue (either in a database or a dedicated message broker like Rabbit or Kafka) to manage the tasks. This makes it a little more complicated to get status updates because you're working across processes, but it gives you a lot more flexibility operationally.</p>

<p>I'm guessing this is a more complicated answer than you expected to "requests are timing out", but this is a case of a trivial issue with a non-trivial solution. You're certainly not alone in tackling this issue; researching handling long-running tasks in web applications will yield a ton of information you can leverage.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T13:36:51.473" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45351644      <row Id="45351644" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45353346" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45351644" CreationDate="2017-07-27T14:12:14.017" Score="1" Body="<p>Since you're dealing with ids from your own database and if you are certain there is no way someone could inject malicious "ids" into that code, don't use the placeholder <code>?</code> and just use the <code>fmt</code> package.</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Sprintf("SELECT * from table2 where id in (%s)", asID)
</code></pre>

<p>this will result in <code>SELECT * from table2 where id in (1,2,3,4...)</code> as opposed to <code>SELECT * from table2 where id in ('1,2,3,4...')</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="965900" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T14:12:14.017" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45346641      <row Id="45346641" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45354151" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45346641" CreationDate="2017-07-27T14:45:51.027" Score="0" Body="<p>The only reason your slice is sorted is because you're appending items in already sorted order. If you appended items in an unsorted order like this</p>

<pre><code>var mySlice = make([]string, 0)
mySlice = append(mySlice, "mnop")
mySlice = append(mySlice, "efgh")
mySlice = append(mySlice, "uvwxyz")
mySlice = append(mySlice, "ijkl")
mySlice = append(mySlice, "abcd")
mySlice = append(mySlice, "qrst")
</code></pre>

<p>(or populated a slice by pulling keys from a map, which would be unsorted), then the order on iteration would be unsorted (consistent, yes, but consistently unsorted). So, if your objective is to use the slice to pull items from a map in sorted order, then you need to first sort the slice, unless you can guarantee the slice items were inserted in an already sorted order.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1949322" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T14:45:51.027" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45355483      <row Id="45355483" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45355593" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45355483" CreationDate="2017-07-27T15:52:09.447" Score="4" Body="<p>The best practices is to "mock" or fake all the external dependencies. For example, all the calls of the gmail API should be to a faked interface. You only test that the API has been called with the proper arguments... There a lot of librairies to do the mocks....</p>
" OwnerUserId="4641455" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T15:52:09.447" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45348256      <row Id="45348256" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45357522" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45348256" CreationDate="2017-07-27T17:36:07.480" Score="1" Body="<p>With regard to your last comment (for which I don't have enough reputation to reply to):</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Ok, this works: <a href="http://[play.golang.org/p/TYk67p6i_b" rel="nofollow noreferrer">play.golang.org/p/TYk67p6i_b</a> But then I have a mix of
  string and *string in my struct definition. And I also can't "fill"
  the value without having the <code>var emptyString = ""</code>, right?</p>
</blockquote>

question:
45359250      <row Id="45359250" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45359304" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45359250" CreationDate="2017-07-27T19:19:36.117" Score="4" Body="<p>There is no real limit on the number of matches. The reason your regex is not getting more matches is because it needs to be <code>regexp.MustCompile(" [0-9]+ ")</code> to match numbers with more than one digit, surrounded by spaces. Right now it only matches <code>" 0 "</code> through to <code>" 9 "</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="119081" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T19:19:36.117" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45360045      <row Id="45360045" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45360553" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45360045" CreationDate="2017-07-27T20:35:43.327" Score="2" Body="<p>You can take use the fact that <code>r.PostForm</code> is actually a map where keys are the field names and values are an array of strings, so you can do something along these lines (I didn't test it, but the concept should work).</p>

<p>We iterate over all values for the <code>"userid"</code> field to know how many users there are. Also, you can use <code>append</code> to add users dynamically to the slice.</p>

<pre><code>userFormData := []UserFormData{}
for i, userId := range r.PostForm["userid"] {
     user := UserFormData{
        UserID: userId,
        Thumbnail: r.PostForm["thumbnail"][i],
     }
     userFormData = append(userFormData, user)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T20:35:43.327" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45360582      <row Id="45360582" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45360689" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45360582" CreationDate="2017-07-27T20:45:07.750" Score="3" Body="<p>I sounds like you need <code>map[string]reflect.Type</code></p>

<pre><code>val := map[string]reflect.Type{}{}

val["int"] = reflect.TypeOf(int(0))
pointer_to_new_item := reflect.New(val["int"])
</code></pre>

<p>If you need a non-pointer value you then use <code>Indirect</code>:</p>

<pre><code>new_item := reflect.Indirect(pointer_to_new_item)
</code></pre>

<p>Using reflect to create a value will give you a <code>reflect.Value</code>, which you then need to unpack the actual value you want from using other reflect functions. See <a href="http://golang.org/pkg/reflect" rel="nofollow noreferrer">The reflect documentation</a> for more info.</p>

<p>Keep in mind that <code>reflect.New</code> only makes simple types, structures, etc. If you need channels, maps, or slices there are other, similar functions that work like the <code>make</code> builtin.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastEditorUserId="1094529" LastEditDate="2017-07-27T21:45:06.210" LastActivityDate="2017-07-27T21:45:06.210" CommentCount="8" />

question:
45361921      <row Id="45361921" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45362091" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45361921" CreationDate="2017-07-27T22:34:52.197" Score="3" Body="<p>See <a href="https://blog.golang.org/errors-are-values" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Errors are values</a> on <em>The Go Blog</em>. This article, written by Rob Pike, has an interesting and powerful method of handling errors in a group of functions that works very well.</p>

<p>I have used this technique before several times, and it really works.</p>

<p>For reference, the code used for this technique looks like this (copied from the article):</p>

<blockquote>
<pre><code>// Helper type
type errWriter struct {
    w   io.Writer
    err error
}

func (ew *errWriter) write(buf []byte) {
    if ew.err != nil {
        return
    }
    _, ew.err = ew.w.Write(buf)
}

//Usage:
ew := &amp;errWriter{w: fd}
ew.write(p0[a:b])
ew.write(p1[c:d])
ew.write(p2[e:f])
// and so on
if ew.err != nil {
    return ew.err
}
</code></pre>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastEditorUserId="366904" LastEditDate="2017-08-25T09:58:59.387" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T09:58:59.387" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45363790      <row Id="45363790" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45363829" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45363790" CreationDate="2017-07-28T02:19:27.057" Score="1" Body="<p>To put it simply, you goofed the syntax of a slice literal slightly. Your mistake is fairly logical, but sadly it doesn't work.</p>

<p>The following is a fixed version:</p>

<pre><code>v := &amp;important{ client: "xyz", Response: []Summary{
        {
            Name: "test",
            Metadata: Clientdata { "404040"},
        },
    },
}
</code></pre>

<p>A slice literal is defined like so:</p>

<pre><code>[]type{ items... }
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T02:19:27.057" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45366954      <row Id="45366954" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45367783" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45366954" CreationDate="2017-07-28T07:48:05.103" Score="1" Body="<p>You can create two types of channels: buffered channels and unbuffered channels.<br>
Buffered channel are those that has capacity: <code>make(chan int, 10)</code><br>
Buffered channels allow you to send into them same amount of messages as their capacity without being blocked.<br>
Unbuffered channels has no capacity and that is why your sending goroutine will be blocked until another goroutine receive from it.  </p>

<p><strong>1.</strong> It is unbuffered channel. You main goroutine is blocked on receiving from channel until new goroutine send message to it.  </p>

<p><strong>2.</strong> Because you are using unbuffered channel your sending goroutine is blocked until another receive from it, but you have no other goroutines except that main one, so the program is in deadlock.  </p>

<p><strong>3.</strong> Because of buffered goroutine. It has capacity of 1, so it is won't be problem to send one message to it and then receive it in the same goroutine. But you will be blocked if you try to send more than 1 message to it. <code>ch &lt;- 233; ch &lt;- 233</code> - this code will cause a deadlock.  </p>

<p><strong>4.</strong> Did get what you mean..., but if you try to receive or send to a nil channel you will be blocked: <code>var ch chan int; &lt;-ch</code> or <code>var ch chan int; ch &lt;- 1</code> </p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastEditorUserId="141555" LastEditDate="2017-07-28T08:23:18.703" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T08:23:18.703" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45367649      <row Id="45367649" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45367825" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45367649" CreationDate="2017-07-28T07:50:23.740" Score="1" Body="<p>It is a type assertion:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A type assertion provides access to an interface value's underlying concrete value.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><code>t := i.(T)</code></p>

<p><a href="https://tour.golang.org/methods/15" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://tour.golang.org/methods/15</a></p>

<p>If the asserion does not hold it will trigger a panic. To test if the value is of specific type T you can use this:</p>

<p><code>t, ok := i.(T)</code></p>

<p>Ok is a boolean that is <code>true</code> if the assertion holds and <code>false</code> otherwise.</p>
" OwnerUserId="128186" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T07:50:23.740" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45368204      <row Id="45368204" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45368455" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45368204" CreationDate="2017-07-28T08:23:47.357" Score="3" Body="<p>There's not really a "nicer" way of doing this. To convert a slice you have to basically do what you've already discovered.</p>

<p>If you are simply returning these errors to a client, you could probably avoid the need to typecast this at all. </p>

<p>Implement the JSON <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Marshaler</a> interface and you can make your type will automatically output the JSON in the format you desire. For example, for the format you gave above this would be:</p>

<pre><code>func (e BadField)  MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) {
   return json.Marshal([]string{"field_name",e.Field,e.Err.Error()})
}
</code></pre>

<p>I suspect however that you would probably rather have a response something like:</p>

<pre><code>[  
   {  
      "field":"age",
      "error":"msg1"
   },
   {  
      "field":"name",
      "error":"msg2"
   }
]
</code></pre>

<p>To do this, you could simply add the JSON tags to the struct definition, e.g.</p>

<pre><code>type BadField struct {
    Field string `json:"field"`
    Err   error `json:"error"`
} 
</code></pre>

<p>This would mean calling <code>json.Marshal</code> on a slice of <code>[]error</code> which contains <code>BadField</code> instances would result in the JSON above.</p>

<p>It might be helpful to read more about <a href="https://blog.golang.org/json-and-go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">JSON &amp; Go</a></p>

<p><em>PS Consider if you want your methods to be <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#methods_on_values_or_pointers" rel="nofollow noreferrer">value or pointer receivers</a></em></p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T08:23:47.357" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45365972      <row Id="45365972" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45369003" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45365972" CreationDate="2017-07-28T08:52:01.507" Score="3" Body="<p>The problem is that you have created a buffered channel with <code>var record = make(chan List, 3)</code>. Hence this code:</p>

<pre><code>record &lt;- *list
pool.Put(list)
</code></pre>

<p>May return immediately and the entry will be placed back into the pool before it has been consumed. Hence the underlying slice will likely be modified in another loop iteration before your consumer has had a chance to consume it. Although you are sending <code>List</code> as a value object, remember that the <code>[]bson.M</code> is a pointer to an allocated array and will still be pointing to the same memory when you send a new <code>List</code> value. Hence why you are seeing the duplicate output.</p>

<p>To fix, modify your channel to send the List pointer <code>make(chan *List, 3)</code> and change your consumer to put the entry back in the pool once finished, e.g:</p>

<pre><code>for r := range record {
    fmt.Printf("first: %v\n", r.L[0])
    // do the insert etc
    pool.Put(r) // Even if error occurs
}
</code></pre>

<p>Your producer should then sent the pointer with the <code>pool.Put</code> removed, i.e.</p>

<pre><code>record &lt;- list
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T08:52:01.507" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45372490      <row Id="45372490" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45372998" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45372490" CreationDate="2017-07-28T12:00:56.483" Score="2" Body="<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Package time</a></p>
  
  <p>These are predefined layouts for use in Time.Format and Time.Parse.
  The reference time used in the layouts is the specific time:</p>

<pre><code>Mon Jan 2 15:04:05 MST 2006
</code></pre>
  
  <p>which is Unix time 1136239445. Since MST is GMT-0700, the reference
  time can be thought of as</p>

<pre><code>01/02 03:04:05PM '06 -0700
</code></pre>
  
  <p>To define your own format, write down what the reference time would
  look like formatted your way; see the values of constants like ANSIC,
  StampMicro or Kitchen for examples.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Use <code>format := "2006-01-02"</code> for yyyy-mm-dd.</p>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T12:00:56.483" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45374658      <row Id="45374658" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45375727" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45374658" CreationDate="2017-07-28T14:14:19.513" Score="1" Body="<p>From the sounds of it, you want to your result to look like:</p>

<pre><code>[
  {"Name":"QA1","Server":"BOT1","Description":"Tools","Apps": ["Duo","Git","php"]
]
</code></pre>

<p>Hence you want your Volumes struct to look like:</p>

<pre><code>type Volume struct {
    Name        string
    Server      string
    Description string
    Services    []Apps
}
</code></pre>

<p><em>If you want the Apps to actually output</em> <code>Duo|Git|php</code> <em>then you could create a custom type instead of <code>[]Apps</code> with a JSON <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Marshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Marshaler</a> implementation. This could simply return <code>json.Marshal(strings.join(names,"|"))</code></em></p>

<p>Rather than run two separate queries, it would be more efficient to run a single query that selects the product of volumes &amp; apps together. It is important that this query is sorted by volume so all volume rows are contiguous. Example query output would be:</p>

<pre><code>Name | Server | Desc  | App
---- | ------ | ----- | ---
Vol1 | Srv1   | Desc1 | App1 
Vol1 | Srv1   | Desc1 | App2
Vol2 | Srv2   | Desc2 | App3
</code></pre>

<p>You would then loop over this and detect if you are looking at a new volume. If so, create a new entry in the result. If not, add the App to the list of apps. For example:</p>

<pre><code>var (
   volnm string 
   srvrnm string
   descr string
   appnm string 
   v     *Volume
   result []*Volume
)

for srvrrows.Next() {
    if err = srvcrows.Scan(&amp;volnm, &amp;srvrnm, &amp;descr, &amp;appnm);err!=nil {
       // Handle error
    }

    // Add App to current volume if same, otherwise start a new volume
    if v!=nil &amp;&amp; v.Name == volnm {
       v.Services = append(v.Services,Apps{appnm}) 
    } else {
       v = &amp;Volume{
          Name: volnm, 
          Server: svrnm, 
          Description: descr, 
          Services: []Apps{appnm}}
       result = append(result,v)
    }
}

// Finished, return result etc...
</code></pre>

<p>When taking this approach, you need an appropriate parent record discriminator. I'd just used <code>v.Name == volnm</code> for illustration purposes but this should really be checking the <strong>primary key</strong>. You can make this an unexported (lowercase) field in the struct if you do not wish to export it through the API.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastEditorUserId="8356442" LastEditDate="2017-07-28T14:23:43.203" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T14:23:43.203" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45377224      <row Id="45377224" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object

<row Id="45378004" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45377224" CreationDate="2017-07-28T16:08:22.463" Score="0" Body="<p>I think it is because you are using <code>DefaultServer</code> as your RPC server. Instead you should create different servers for each: RICHARD and BENNY.
Please take a look on your code modified by me to work as expected here: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/cS5mITDafw" rel="nofollow noreferrer">RPC calls on one machine</a> </p>

question:
45377132      <row Id="45377132" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45378010" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45377132" CreationDate="2017-07-28T16:08:30.343" Score="0" Body="<p>That's a PEM encoded key, it's just missing the BEGIN &amp; END headers. The key is simple Base64 encoded, you can decode and unmarshal into a RSA key as follows:</p>

<pre><code>base64Data := []byte(``)
d := make([]byte, base64.StdEncoding.DecodedLen(len(base64Data)))
n, err := base64.StdEncoding.Decode(d, base64Data)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
d = d[:n]
key,err:=x509.ParsePKIXPublicKey(d)
if err != nil {
    // Handle error
}
fmt.Println(key)
</code></pre>

<p>If you need the key in PEM encoded form, simple add the appropriate header and footer, e.g. <code>-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----</code> &amp; <code>-----END PUBLIC KEY-----</code>. Note that the BEGIN header must start on its own line and end in a new line (<code>"\n"</code>). The END header must also be proceeded by a new line.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T16:08:30.343" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45378157      <row Id="45378157" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="45378527" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45378157" CreationDate="2017-07-28T16:39:05.720" Score="0" Body="<p>I think this <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/P2a8RLEYlF" rel="nofollow noreferrer">solution</a> can give you a hint what you suppose to do to extract <code>key</code>s from this JSON without any additional <code>type</code> creation.</p>

question:
45378566      <row Id="45378566" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45378656" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45378566" CreationDate="2017-07-28T16:47:38.947" Score="0" Body="<p>I would just register your handler twice.</p>

<pre><code>router.Path("/articles/{id:[0-9]+}").Queries("key", "{[0-
9]*?}").HandlerFunc(YourHandler).Name("YourHandler")

router.Path("/articles/{id:[0-9]+}").HandlerFunc(YourHandler)
</code></pre>

<p>Here is a working program to demonstrate. Notice that I am using <code>r.FormValue</code> to get the query parameter. </p>

<p><em>Note: make sure you have an up to date version <code>go get -u github.com/gorilla/mux</code> since a bug of query params not getting added the built URLs was fixed recently.</em></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "net/http"

    "github.com/gorilla/mux"
)

var router = mux.NewRouter()

func main() {
    router.Path("/articles/{id:[0-9]+}").Queries("key", "{key}").HandlerFunc(YourHandler).Name("YourHandler")
    router.Path("/articles/{id:[0-9]+}").HandlerFunc(YourHandler)

    if err := http.ListenAndServe(":9000", router); err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}

func YourHandler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    id := mux.Vars(r)["id"]
    key := r.FormValue("key")

    u, err := router.Get("YourHandler").URL("id", id, "key", key)
    if err != nil {
        http.Error(w, err.Error(), 500)
        return
    }

    // Output:
    // /articles/10?key=[key]
    w.Write([]byte(u.String()))
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1817176" LastEditorUserId="1817176" LastEditDate="2017-07-28T19:49:21.273" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T19:49:21.273" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45378537      <row Id="45378537" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45379296" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45378537" CreationDate="2017-07-28T17:31:41.073" Score="1" Body="<p>OK let me clarify some things and help you.</p>

<p>You don' t need to return modified map from here because your
function gets reference to map not copy of it. (Let's silence the fact
that you are completly ignoring return value)</p>

<pre><code>func add_to_map(m map[string] string, word string) map[string]string {
    added_word := word + " plus more letters"
    m[word] = added_word
    return m
}
</code></pre>

<p>Next thing is that you need to synchronize access to map. You can use
<a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#Mutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer">mutex</a> for this.</p>

<pre><code>import "sync"

var mutex sync.Mutex //glabal variable but can be created as local also

func add_to_map(m map[string] string, word string) {
    added_word := word + " plus more letters"
    // here you can do long to compute task and calculate result
    // calc here
    mutex.Lock() //result ready lock mutex
    defer mutex.Unlock() // unlock mutex when we return from function
    m[word] = added_word // result write to shared map
}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that in Go 1.9 there will be <a href="https://tip.golang.org/doc/go1.9#sync-map" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Concurrent Map</a> type.</p>

<p><strong>Edit</strong>:
You need to wait for all gorutines to finish beacause your main now finishes beafore them. You can do this by using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup" rel="nofollow noreferrer">WaitGroup</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "sync"
)

var mutex sync.Mutex
var wg sync.WaitGroup

func add_to_map(m map[string] string, word string) {
    defer wg.Done()
    added_word := word + " plus more letters"
    // do heavy work here
    //
    mutex.Lock()
    defer mutex.Unlock()
    m[word] = added_word
}


func main() {
    words_map := make(map[string]string)
    words := []string{"giraffe", "cat", "dog", "turtle"}
    for _, this_word := range words {
        wg.Add(1)
        go add_to_map(words_map, this_word)
    }
    wg.Wait()
    fmt.Println(words_map)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8307258" LastEditorUserId="8307258" LastEditDate="2017-07-28T19:05:00.723" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T19:05:00.723" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45379494      <row Id="45379494" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45379652" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45379494" CreationDate="2017-07-28T17:55:45.820" Score="0" Body="<p>If you want to write to the sub-process standard input, you should use <code>StdinPipe</code>.</p>

<p>Like:</p>

<pre><code>subStdin, err := cmd.StdinPipe()
// check err
defer subStdin.Close()
io.WriteString(subStdin, "Hello World")
</code></pre>

<p>See the docs for a complete example:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/exec/#Cmd.StdinPipe" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/os/exec/#Cmd.StdinPipe</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T17:55:45.820" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45361846      <row Id="45361846" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45379942" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45361846" CreationDate="2017-07-28T18:15:03.453" Score="0" Body="<p>This is maybe related to some docker-compose bug.</p>

<p>Try cleaning containers</p>

<pre><code>docker-compose down
</code></pre>

</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1094246" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T18:15:03.453" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45381407      <row Id="45381407" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45381522" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45381407" CreationDate="2017-07-28T19:59:36.493" Score="1" Body="<p>I'd remove the <code>vendor</code> folder below <code>B</code>, and put <code>C</code> in the root <code>vendor</code> folder (for application <code>A</code> if I am getting your structure correctly).</p>

<p>That way, you only end up with one place for each type.</p>

<p>Not sure why <code>B</code> would have a <code>vendor</code> folder in the first place, since Glide's recommendations are clear on this:</p>

<p><a href="http://glide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/vendor/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://glide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/vendor/</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Libraries (codebases without a main package) should not store outside packages in a vendor/ folder</p>
</blockquote>

<p>and</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>In applications (codebases with a main package) there should only be one vendor/ directory at the top level</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T19:59:36.493" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45381104      <row Id="45381104" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45382150" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45381104" CreationDate="2017-07-28T20:46:58.703" Score="1" Body="<p>Directives in Go are kinda fragile, you need to get them exactly right or they will fail silently.</p>

<p>In this case you have this:</p>

<pre><code>// export add_all_items_to_map
</code></pre>

<p>But need this:</p>

<pre><code>//export add_all_items_to_map
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://golang.org/cmd/cgo/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">the cgo docs</a> for more information.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-07-28T20:46:58.703" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45383927      <row Id="45383927" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45383955" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45383927" CreationDate="2017-07-29T00:06:51.167" Score="0" Body="<p>Maybe I'm not seeing something, but this is usually how I do it:</p>

<pre><code>actual, err := GetKey(v.Key)
if err != v.Err {
    t.Errorf("Unexpected error: %s", err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Or, if the returned error might not be a specific known error value, I might flatten to a string:</p>

<pre><code>actual, err := GetKey(v.Key)
var errMsg string
if err != nil {
    errMsg = err.Error()
}
if errMsg != v.errMsg {
    t.Errorf("Unexpected error: %s", errMsg)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T00:06:51.167" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45379453      <row Id="45379453" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45385166" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45379453" CreationDate="2017-07-29T04:10:43.067" Score="1" Body="<p>The issue comes from the fact that your using <code>elastic.v3</code> which <a href="https://github.com/olivere/elastic#elastic-30" rel="nofollow noreferrer">targets ES 2.x</a>.</p>

<p>Since you're using ES 5.3.1, you need to use <a href="https://github.com/olivere/elastic#elastic-50" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>elastic.v5</code></a>, so simply replace this line</p>

<pre><code>elastic "gopkg.in/olivere/elastic.v3"
</code></pre>

<p>by </p>

<pre><code>elastic "gopkg.in/olivere/elastic.v5"
</code></pre>

<p>and you should be fine.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4604579" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T04:10:43.067" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45386644      <row Id="45386644" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45386720" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45386644" CreationDate="2017-07-29T07:38:20.627" Score="2" Body="<p>The fields in <code>pingDataFormat</code> need to be exported (start with a capital letter)</p>

<pre><code>type pingDataFormat struct {
    UserAccessToken          string `json:"userAccessToken"`
    UploadStartTimeInSeconds int    `json:"uploadStartTimeInSeconds"`
    UploadEndTimeInSeconds   int    `json:"uploadEndTimeInSeconds"`
    CallbackURL              string `json:"callbackURL"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>That should solve your problem</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Z3yszFl01L" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/Z3yszFl01L</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="141555" LastEditorUserId="141555" LastEditDate="2017-07-29T07:57:42.760" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T07:57:42.760" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45387108      <row Id="45387108" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45387452" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45387108" CreationDate="2017-07-29T09:02:44.793" Score="1" Body="<p>NTLM Authentication and Basic Authentication are not the same. NTLM is a protocol which is more complicated than just user:password string in header.<br>
If you want to make a request from Golang code to authenticate you should use one of existing libraries, like: <a href="https://github.com/Azure/go-ntlmssp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">go-ntlmssp</a></p>

<p>Also you can read more about NTLM protocol itself <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc236621.aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T09:02:44.793" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45388963      <row Id="45388963" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45389058" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45388963" CreationDate="2017-07-29T12:03:47.193" Score="1" Body="<p>I don't understand why to do <code>SET @query</code> and pass it inside of it when You can do it by using bind parameter using <code>?</code>.</p>

<p>So here is solution (I'm not familiar with <code>go</code> so please sorry if something wrong with <code>go</code> code):</p>

<pre><code>var taxes []Tax
query := "%something%youre%looking%for%"
err := r.db.Select(&amp;taxes, `

    SELECT tax.*
    FROM tax
    JOIN user_tax
        ON user_tax.tax_id = tax.id
    WHERE user_tax.user_id = ?
        AND tax.deleted_at IS NULL
        AND user_tax.deleted_at IS NULL
        AND (
              tax.name LIKE ? 
              OR 
              tax.rate LIKE ?
            )

`, q, userId, query, query)
</code></pre>

<p>OR try this (I'm not sure if it will work) :</p>

<pre><code>var taxes []Tax
query := "something"
err := r.db.Select(&amp;taxes, `
    SET @query = CONCAT('%', ?, '%');

    SELECT tax.*
    FROM tax
    JOIN user_tax
        ON user_tax.tax_id = tax.id
    WHERE user_tax.user_id = ?
        AND tax.deleted_at IS NULL
        AND user_tax.deleted_at IS NULL
        AND (
              tax.name LIKE @query
              OR 
              tax.rate LIKE @query
            )

`, q, query, userId)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3706693" LastEditorUserId="3706693" LastEditDate="2017-07-29T12:19:15.577" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T12:19:15.577" CommentCount="11" />

question:
45389802      <row Id="45389802" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45390194" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45389802" CreationDate="2017-07-29T14:08:08.937" Score="2" Body="<p>There is not a way to concatenate strings with an operator because Go templates do not have operators.</p>

<p>Use the <code>printf</code> function as shown in the question or combine the calls in a single template expression:</p>

<pre><code>{{ TestFunc (printf "%s%s" "x" "y") }}
</code></pre>

<p>If you always need to concatenate strings for the TestFunc argument, then write TestFunc to handle the concatenation:</p>

<pre><code>func TestFunc(strs ...string) string {
   return strings.Trim(strings.Join(strs, ""), " ")
}

{{ TestFunc "x"  $var }}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-07-29T14:12:56.067" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T14:12:56.067" CommentCount="1" />

question:
44781327      <row Id="44781327" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45390729" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44781327" CreationDate="2017-07-29T15:03:25.117" Score="0" Body="<p>The problem here is related with the abbreviation change for <code>Europe/Istanbul</code>. </p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Turkey switched from EET/EEST (+02/+03) to permanent +03,
  effective 2016-09-07. (Thanks to Burak AYDIN.) Use "+03" rather
  than an invented abbreviation for the new time.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Time package currently does not accept +03 as EET/EEST and this problem occurs when using a datetime string that contains <code>+03</code> as timezone to parse in form of <code>2006-01-02 15:04:05.999999999 -0700 MST</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3416136" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T15:03:25.117" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45391686      <row Id="45391686" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45394312" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45391686" CreationDate="2017-07-29T21:38:42.633" Score="0" Body="<p>As I can see you have a bunch f dependencies in your code. I have found that library <code>github.com/tendermint/tmlibs/log</code> has a dependency to a package <code>testing</code> from standard library: <a href="https://github.com/tendermint/tmlibs/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&amp;q=testing&amp;type=" rel="nofollow noreferrer">searches for testing</a>. And this standard library has all flags you are wondered about: <a href="https://golang.org/src/testing/testing.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">testing package</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T21:38:42.633" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45286908      <row Id="45286908" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

" OwnerUserId="8359202" LastEditorUserId="8359202" LastEditDate="2017-07-30T05:14:05.063" LastActivityDate="2017-07-30T05:14:05.063" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45394684      <row Id="45394684" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45394743" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45394684" CreationDate="2017-07-29T22:43:22.307" Score="9" Body="<p>A couple of reasons why you'll see the same result in the playground</p>

<ol>
<li>Golang playground will cache the results </li>
<li>The time in the playground always starts at the same time to make the playground deterministic. </li>
</ol>

<p>Last but not least, the <code>rand</code> package default seed is <code>1</code> which will make the result deterministic. If you place a <code>rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())</code> you'll receive different results at each execution. Note that this won't work on the playground for the second reason above. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1261399" LastEditorUserId="1261399" LastEditDate="2017-07-29T22:54:53.993" LastActivityDate="2017-07-29T22:54:53.993" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45372101      <row Id="45372101" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45395394" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45372101" CreationDate="2017-07-30T00:54:47.757" Score="0" Body="<p>I found the solution. Turns out creating a new pseudo-TTY was the wrong approach and I can actually use the standard Go libraries to achieve what I wanted:</p>

<pre><code>cmd := exec.Command(name, parameters...)

cmd.SysProcAttr = &amp;syscall.SysProcAttr{
    Ctty: int(os.Stdout.Fd()) // set the TTY
}

// These must be the respective Std os.File as using a Reader/Writer 
// wouldn't work if you're trying to assign a TTY to your terminal
// emulator.
cmd.Stdin = os.Stdin
cmd.Stdout = os.Stdout
cmd.Stderr = os.Stderr
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2236853" LastActivityDate="2017-07-30T00:54:47.757" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45395861      <row Id="45395861" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45395923" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45395861" CreationDate="2017-07-30T02:57:10.960" Score="1" Body="<p>The variable <code>inner</code> is declared using a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Short_variable_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">short variable declaration</a>.  The variable <code>inner</code> has type <code>func(in []reflect.Value) []reflect.Value</code>. The value is the function literal in the code.</p>

<p>The type  <code>func(in []reflect.Value) []reflect.Value</code> represents a generic function implemented by reflection. The function takes a possibly empty slice of arguments and returns a possibly empty slice of results.</p>

<p>The <code>reflect.Value</code> for a function is not directly callable. The <code>Call</code> method is used to call the function in the value.</p>

<p>The <code>.(func(a, b int) int)</code> is a type assertion.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-07-30T02:57:10.960" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45389410      <row Id="45389410" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45399504" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45389410" CreationDate="2017-07-30T11:53:12.757" Score="2" Body="<p>You can do it as documented at <a href="https://godoc.org/labix.org/v2/mgo#Collection.EnsureIndex" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><strong><code>Collection.EnsureIndex</code></strong></a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Other kinds of indexes are also supported through that API. Here is an example:</p>
</blockquote>

<pre><code>index := Index{
    Key: []string{"$2d:loc"},
    Bits: 26,
}
err := collection.EnsureIndex(index)
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
  <p>The example above requests the creation of a "2d" index for the "loc" field.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So basically, you have the format <strong><code>$&lt;indexType&gt;:&lt;indexedField&gt;</code></strong>, as shown below:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import mgo "gopkg.in/mgo.v2"

const (
    db   = "so_hashed_idx"
    coll = "testcoll"
)

func main() {
    var s *mgo.Session
    var err error

    if s, err = mgo.Dial("127.0.0.1:27017"); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    // An index spec is nothing more than a fancy word for the keys
    // or the key/value pairs handed over to the Key slice of the
    // Index type.
    idx := mgo.Index{
        Key: []string{"$hashed:_id"},
    }

    if err := s.DB(db).C(coll).EnsureIndex(idx); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Building and running the above results in <code>so_hashed_idx.testcoll</code> showing its indices as follows</p>

<pre><code>&gt; db.testcoll.getIndices()
[
    {
        "v" : 1,
        "key" : {
            "_id" : 1
        },
        "name" : "_id_",
        "ns" : "so_hashed_idx.testcoll"
    },
    {
        "v" : 1,
        "key" : {
            "_id" : "hashed"
        },
        "name" : "_id_hashed",
        "ns" : "so_hashed_idx.testcoll"
    }
]
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1296707" LastActivityDate="2017-07-30T11:53:12.757" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45395982      <row Id="45395982" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45400830" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45395982" CreationDate="2017-07-30T14:24:57.483" Score="2" Body="<p>Look for inspiration in <a href="https://golang.org/src/io/io.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/src/io/io.go</a></p>

<p>You will see: </p>

<p>a. "Atomic" interfaces: <code>Reader</code>, <code>Writer</code>, <code>Closer</code>, <code>Seeker</code></p>

<p>b. Composed interfaces: <code>ReaderWriter</code>, <code>ReaderWriterSeeker</code>, <code>ReaderSeekerCloser</code> etc.</p>

<p>Golang will not complaint about gigantic interfaces, it's you and your collegues will have complaints about big monolithic interfaces. </p>

<p>I recomend  divide your interface to 4 (maybe 2) interfaces: <code>FooOps</code>, <code>FoosOps</code>, <code>BarOps</code>, <code>BarsOps</code> and then define composed interfaces from them.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1168212" LastActivityDate="2017-07-30T14:24:57.483" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45407283      <row Id="45407283" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45407483" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45407283" CreationDate="2017-07-31T04:31:46.610" Score="0" Body="<p>Docker passes signals to PID 1 process. In your case, since you are spawning a child process, you are not getting the signal.
If there is only 1 processing in CMD, you can do something like:</p>

<pre><code>CMD ["/bin/ping","localhost"]
</code></pre>

<p>If you are doing multiple operations like what you have put above, you can run a script in CMD and have signal processing in the script and pass it to your background process. The other option is to have only 1 command processing in CMD. You can do "go install" in previous step and just run executable in CMD. </p>
" OwnerUserId="2998542" LastActivityDate="2017-07-31T04:31:46.610" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45405626      <row Id="45405626" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45408538" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45405626" CreationDate="2017-07-31T06:08:23.510" Score="1" Body="<p>Function <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/dgrijalva/jwt-go#ParseWithClaims" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>jwt.ParseWithClaims</code></a> accept an interface of <code>jwt.Claims</code> as the second argument. Besides struct-based custom claims, the package also provides <code>map</code>-based claims, i.e. <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/dgrijalva/jwt-go#MapClaims" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>jwt.MapClaims</code></a>. 
So, you can simply decode the token into a <code>MapClaims</code>, e.g.</p>

<pre><code>tokenString := "&lt;YOUR TOKEN STRING&gt;"    
claims := jwt.MapClaims{}
token, err := jwt.ParseWithClaims(tokenString, claims, func(token *jwt.Token) (interface{}, error) {
    return []byte("&lt;YOUR VERIFICATION KEY&gt;"), nil
})
// ... error handling

// do something with decoded claims
for key, val := range claims {
    fmt.Printf("Key: %v, value: %v\n", key, val)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-07-31T06:08:23.510" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45405468      <row Id="45405468" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45412153" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45405468" CreationDate="2017-07-31T09:31:54.320" Score="3" Body="<p>You're using the wrong command: <code>:read</code> <em>appends</em> lines to the buffer (with <code>! {cmd}</code>: from an external command). Instead, you want to <em>filter</em> the current buffer contents through an external command. This is done via <code>:help :range!</code>. The <code>gofmt</code> command reads from stdin when no file is passed (some other commands take a special <code>-</code> argument for that. Ergo:</p>

<pre><code>:nnoremap &lt;C-r&gt; :%! gofmt&lt;CR&gt;
</code></pre>

<h3>Notes</h3>

<ul>
<li><a href="http://learnvimscriptthehardway.stevelosh.com/chapters/05.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">You should use <code>:noremap</code></a>; it makes the mapping immune to remapping and recursion.</li>
<li>I've limited the mapping to <em>normal mode</em>; I don't think is necessary to directly launch this from visual mode or operator-pending mode.</li>
<li>As mentioned in the comments, there's probably a plugin that already provides this out of the box.</li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="813602" LastActivityDate="2017-07-31T09:31:54.320" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45412089      <row Id="45412089" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45412336" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45412089" CreationDate="2017-07-31T09:40:55.810" Score="2" Body="<p>There is no support for this in the standard lib. You have to make one yourself.</p>

<p>A simple implementation can be like this:</p>

<pre><code>func split(s string, size int) []string {
    ss := make([]string, 0, len(s)/size+1)
    for len(s) &gt; 0 {
        if len(s) &lt; size {
            size = len(s)
        }
        ss, s = append(ss, s[:size]), s[size:]

    }
    return ss
}
</code></pre>

<p>This loops until the string is consumed, and in each iteration cuts of <code>size</code> chars (bytes) from the beginning.</p>

<p>Note that this works on base64 texts as that only uses characters which map 1-to-1 to bytes in the UTF-8 encoded form (which is how Go stores strings in memory). If you would want to use this on arbitrary strings, slicing could break valid UTF-8 sequences, and also chunks would not necessarily be <code>size</code> characters.</p>

<p>Testing it:</p>

<pre><code>s := strings.Repeat("1", 2*76+3)
for _, chunk := range split(s, 76) {
    fmt.Println(chunk)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/lsGRJn3B92" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>1111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111
1111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111
111
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-07-31T10:38:59.493" LastActivityDate="2017-07-31T10:38:59.493" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45410422      <row Id="45410422" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45412604" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45410422" CreationDate="2017-07-31T09:52:19.267" Score="0" Body="<p>Because the correct package name is a full path starting from <code>/src</code> directory in you project you should use <code>"go_test/long"</code> instead on just <code>"long"</code> in you <code>import</code> statement. And because it is your own code and not a vendor dependency it must not be under <code>vendor</code> directory.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastActivityDate="2017-07-31T09:52:19.267" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45324473      <row Id="45324473" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45413716" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45324473" CreationDate="2017-07-31T10:43:16.173" Score="0" Body="<p>Because you are using regexp to check <code>PhoneNumber</code> that won't be matching if the value is empty it is better to remove <code>nonzero</code> from the validation.<br>
I have checked out documentation and haven't found examples where you can use both: <code>nonzero</code> and <code>regexp</code>.<br>
Also you need to make your regex symbol-escaped, otherwise it won't be detected by reflection. It means you should use <code>(0|\\+62|062|62)[0-9]+$</code> in your code. Here is example where problem is: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/h0xIzZiXpP" rel="nofollow noreferrer">symbol escaping in struct tags</a><br>
And also, please try to use this regexp: <code>^\\+{0,1}0{0,1}62[0-9]+$</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastEditorUserId="8279560" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T05:57:11.873" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T05:57:11.873" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45423667      <row Id="45423667" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45423692" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45423667" CreationDate="2017-07-31T19:18:19.283" Score="10" Body="<p>A slice is really just a fancy way to manage an underlying array. It automatically tracks size, and re-allocates new space as needed.</p>

<p>As you append to a slice, its capacity doubles in size every time it exceeds its current capacity. It has to copy all of the elements to do that. If you know how big it will be before you start, you can avoid a few copy operations and memory allocations by grabbing it all up front.</p>

<p>When you <code>make</code> a slice providing capacity, you set tht <strong>initial capacity</strong>, not any kind of <strong>limit</strong>.</p>

<p>See <a href="https://blog.golang.org/go-slices-usage-and-internals#TOC_5." rel="nofollow noreferrer">this blog post on slices</a> for some interesting internal details of slices.</p>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastEditorUserId="121660" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T12:56:20.513" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T12:56:20.513" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45426891      <row Id="45426891" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45427032" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45426891" CreationDate="2017-08-01T00:03:23.227" Score="2" Body="<p>if you have golang installed correctly just issue this in the dir where your golang code lives</p>

<pre><code>go get -v -t ./...
</code></pre>

<p>which will install the upstream libraries ...  then you can compile your code ... for details issue</p>

<pre><code>go help packages
</code></pre>

<p>the short of it is <code>./...</code> will install all packages [ and recursively its upstream packages, etc, etc.] mentioned in any go file's <code>import</code> in your current dir</p>

<p>If you have ever spent days manually installing upstream libraries for any other language you will appreciate how much of a lifesaver this really is</p>
" OwnerUserId="147175" LastEditorUserId="147175" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T01:23:06.650" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T01:23:06.650" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45428126      <row Id="45428126" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45428754" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45428126" CreationDate="2017-08-01T04:00:48.703" Score="1" Body="<p>Use package <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/big/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>math/big</code></a> and <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/crypto/rand/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>crypto/rand</code></a>. The snippet looks like:</p>

<pre><code>//Max random value, a 130-bits integer, i.e 2^130 - 1
max := new(big.Int)
max.Exp(big.NewInt(2), big.NewInt(130), nil).Sub(max, big.NewInt(1))

//Generate cryptographically strong pseudo-random between 0 - max
n, err := rand.Int(rand.Reader, max)
if err != nil {
    //error handling
}

//String representation of n in base 32
nonce := n.Text(32)
</code></pre>

<p>A working example can be found at <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ssET5KZQuj" rel="nofollow noreferrer">The Go Playground</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastEditorUserId="6207052" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T06:13:31.463" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T06:13:31.463" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45428744      <row Id="45428744" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45429321" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45428744" CreationDate="2017-08-01T05:05:37.347" Score="3" Body="<p>See <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/GithubCodeLayout" rel="nofollow noreferrer">GitHub code layout</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p><code>$GOPATH</code> is the root of the project - each of your Github repos will be checked out several folders below <code>$GOPATH</code>.<br>
  Your <code>$GOPATH</code> variable will point to the root of your Go workspace, as described in <a href="http://golang.org/doc/code.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">How to Write Go Code</a>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>In your case, below your <code>GOPATH</code> folder, you should have</p>

<pre><code>src/github.com/minio/minio
</code></pre>

<p>Anf only <em>then</em> "all minio directories, including vendor"</p>
" OwnerUserId="6309" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T05:05:37.347" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45430126      <row Id="45430126" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45431290" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45430126" CreationDate="2017-08-01T07:16:41.033" Score="1" Body="<p>You are sending the content of summary as a string so, instead you need to send it as a slice of maps</p>

<pre><code>k := [...]common.MapStr{
    {"name": "cpu", "status": m.cpu_status},
    {"name": "LTE", "status": m.lte_status},
    {"name": "Network", "status": m.network_status},
    {"name": "Memory", "status": m.memory_status},
}
event := common.MapStr{
    "cpu_status":     (m.cpu_status % 4),
    "memory_status":  (m.memory_status % 4),
    "lte_status":     (m.lte_status % 4),
    "network_status": (m.network_status % 4),
    "summary":        k,
}
</code></pre>

<p>See <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/yTSXnNKclG" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/yTSXnNKclG</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="7616" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T07:16:41.033" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45429276      <row Id="45429276" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45431649" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45429276" CreationDate="2017-08-01T07:35:05.710" Score="1" Body="<p>In the method <code>ContainerCreate</code> the third parameter is <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/moby/moby/api/types/container#HostConfig" rel="nofollow noreferrer">HostConfig</a> that you need to use. If you are interested in setting ports then you should take a look at <code>PortBindings</code> field. Also you need to specify exposed ports for container. You can do this by providing <code>ExposedPorts</code> into <a href="https://godoc.org/github.com/moby/moby/api/types/container#Config" rel="nofollow noreferrer">container configuration</a> (second parameter).<br>
And I assume that you container will be started in a <code>daemon</code> mode by default because you are using API instead of <code>cli</code> tool.</p>

<p>Here is a working example:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "context"

    "github.com/docker/docker/api/types"
    "github.com/docker/docker/api/types/container"
    "github.com/docker/docker/client"
    "github.com/docker/go-connections/nat"
)

func main() {
    cli, err := client.NewEnvClient()
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    ctx := context.Background()
    resp, err := cli.ContainerCreate(ctx, &amp;container.Config{
        Image:        "mongo",
        ExposedPorts: nat.PortSet{"8080": struct{}{}},
    }, &amp;container.HostConfig{
        PortBindings: map[nat.Port][]nat.PortBinding{nat.Port("8080"): {{HostIP: "127.0.0.1", HostPort: "8080"}}},
    }, nil, "mongo-go-cli")
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    if err := cli.ContainerStart(ctx, resp.ID, types.ContainerStartOptions{}); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>And in the output for <code>docker ps --all</code> I can see my port: <code>PORTS 127.0.0.1:8080-&gt;8080/tcp, 27017/tcp</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="8279560" LastEditorUserId="8279560" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T17:37:30.917" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T17:37:30.917" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45432924      <row Id="45432924" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45433106" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45432924" CreationDate="2017-08-01T08:47:41.713" Score="2" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Time" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>time.Time</code></a> has no exported field <code>Second</code>, so <code>startTime.Second</code> is invalid.</p>

<p>There is a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Time.Add" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Time.Add()</code></a> method which you may use to add a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Duration" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>time.Duration</code></a> value to a <code>time.Time</code> value. And to subtract a duration from it, simply multiply the value you add with <code>-1</code>.</p>

<pre><code>func (bt *Hc34) getStartDate(endTime time.Time, duration int) time.Time {
    return endTime.Add(time.Duration(-duration) * time.Second)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Example with a <code>getStartDate()</code> function (not method):</p>

<pre><code>now := time.Now()
fmt.Println(now)
fmt.Println(getStartDate(now, 60))
</code></pre>

<p>Output on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/4sBbetvX92" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>:</p>

<pre><code>2009-11-10 23:00:00 +0000 UTC
2009-11-10 22:59:00 +0000 UTC
</code></pre>

<p>I also recommend to read this answer about using <code>time.Duration</code> values constructed from integers: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41503758/conversion-of-time-duration-type-microseconds-value-to-milliseconds-in-golang/41503910#41503910">Conversion of time.Duration type microseconds value to milliseconds</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T11:20:39.227" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T11:20:39.227" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45432904      <row Id="45432904" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45433958" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45432904" CreationDate="2017-08-01T09:26:14.833" Score="2" Body="<p>For "why" see the <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12753805/type-converting-slices-of-interfaces-in-go">link posted by mkopriva</a>. The following answer is regarding your original case.</p>

<p>In the first case you could cast each <code>map[string]interface{}</code> individually (looping over them) and then cast <code>[]Row</code> to <code>Rows</code>. You cannot cast the whole thing at once. The cast from []Row to Rows can be done implicitly.</p>

<p>Here your <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/WDWl7W070I" rel="nofollow noreferrer">test snippet</a> with the described ways to cast it.</p>

<pre><code>package main

type (
    Row  map[string]interface{}
    Rows []Row
)

func do(data Rows) {}

func main() {
    var (
        data []map[string]interface{}
        rws []Row
        rows Rows
    )
    for _, r := range data {
        rws = append(rws, Row(r))
        rows = append(rows, Row(r))
    }
    do(Rows(rws))  // possible but not necessary
    do(rws)        // this works just fine
    do(rows)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T09:26:14.833" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45433986      <row Id="45433986" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45434916" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45433986" CreationDate="2017-08-01T10:07:24.243" Score="0" Body="<p>have a look at <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/T-8l0voCDC" rel="nofollow noreferrer">this solution</a>. It is one possible solution.</p>

<p>Generally: you want to work with interfaces here. In the sample I use the interface <code>DataRow</code> to store data of a row of any table. All table structs have to implement 2 functions as you can see in my example. (Also see my note about a general function in a base class with generics)</p>

<p>Here the code again:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type Foo struct {
    Id string
}

func (s *Foo) Fill(m map[string]string) {
    // If you want to build a general Fill you can build a base struct for Foo, Bar, etc. that works with reflect. 
    // Note that it will be slower than implementing the function here! Ask me if you want one I built recently.

    s.Id = m["id"]
}

func (s *Foo) GetRow() interface{} {
    return nil
}

type Bar struct {
    Id string
}

func (s *Bar) Fill(m map[string]string) {
    s.Id = m["id"]
}

func (s *Bar) GetRow() interface{} {
    return nil
}

type DataRow interface {
    Fill(m map[string]string)
    GetRow() interface{}
}

type Changeset struct {
    Table   string
    Type    string
    OldData map[string]string
    NewData map[string]string
}

type ChangesetTyped struct {
    Table   string
    Type    string
    OldData DataRow
    NewData DataRow
}

func doMap(c Changeset) ChangesetTyped {
    ct := ChangesetTyped{
        Table:   c.Table,
        Type:    c.Type,
        OldData: parseRow(c.Table, c.OldData),
    }

    if c.Type == "UPDATE" {
        ct.NewData = parseRow(c.Table, c.NewData)
    }

    return ct
}

func parseRow(table string, data map[string]string) (row DataRow) {
    if table == "foo" {
        row = &amp;Foo{}
    } else if table == "bar" {
        row = &amp;Bar{}
    }

    row.Fill(data)
    return
}

func main() {
    i := Changeset{
        Table:   "foo",
        Type:    "INSERT",
        NewData: map[string]string{"id": "1"},
    }

    u1 := Changeset{
        Table:   "foo",
        Type:    "UPDATE",
        OldData: map[string]string{"id": "20"},
        NewData: map[string]string{"id": "21"},
    }

    u2 := Changeset{
        Table:   "bar",
        Type:    "UPDATE",
        OldData: map[string]string{"id": "30"},
        NewData: map[string]string{"id": "31"},
    }

    m1 := doMap(i)
    m2 := doMap(u1)
    m3 := doMap(u2)

    fmt.Println(m1, m1.OldData)
    fmt.Println(m2, m2.OldData, m2.NewData)
    fmt.Println(m3, m3.OldData, m3.NewData)
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you want to get the actual row from <code>DataRow</code> cast to the correct type use (of type Foo in this example):</p>

<pre><code>foo, ok := dt.GetRow().(Foo)
if !ok {
    fmt.Println("it wasn't of type Foo after all")
}
</code></pre>

<p>Hope this helps you in you golang quest!</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T10:07:24.243" CommentCount="2" />

answer:
<row Id="45439443" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45439343" CreationDate="2017-08-01T13:37:15.490" Score="0" Body="<p>Annotated:</p>

<pre><code>   // format string. This returns MMdd
    final SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("MMdd");

    //redundant re-declaration of function parameter
    final int dayOfYear = quant;

    // make a date and set DAY_OF_YEAR to quant
    final Calendar calendar = Calendar.getInstance();
    calendar.set(Calendar.DAY_OF_YEAR, dayOfYear);

<p><code>1</code> would yield <code>0101</code></p>

<p>It is not clear though, how this handles leap years and other variables like that. It does not seem like very high quality code, and I'd recommend analyzing your problem, and coming up with a good spec.</p>

question:
45439883      <row Id="45439883" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45440202" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45439883" CreationDate="2017-08-01T14:10:14.960" Score="0" Body="<p>Here's my solution. It involves a few different tips:</p>

<ol>
<li><strong>Embed</strong> the shared struct in the individual structs.</li>
<li>Use <code>encoding/binary</code> package to load bytes into structs.</li>
<li>Fill header struct with first two bytes, then make a decision on which subtype to make and fill.</li>
<li>Always use fixed length int types for this kind of thing.</li>
<li>Your field names must be <code>UpperCase</code> to be fillable from <code>encoding/binary</code></li>
<li>This is a pretty brittle way to manage marshalling.unmarshalling of data, but I'm sure you know that.</li>
</ol>

<p>Here's my solution:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "encoding/binary"
    "fmt"
    "log"
)

type A struct {
    X
    Data1 int32
    Data2 int32
    Data3 int32
}

type B struct {
    X
    Data1 int32
}

type X struct {
    Tag byte
    Ver byte
}

func main() {
    var err error
    data := []byte{1, 1, 0, 0, 0, 42}
    hdr := X{}

    err = binary.Read(bytes.NewReader(data[:2]), binary.BigEndian, &amp;hdr)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    fmt.Println(hdr.Tag, hdr.Ver)

    if hdr.Tag == 1 {
        b := B{}
        err = binary.Read(bytes.NewReader(data), binary.BigEndian, &amp;b)
        if err != nil {
            log.Fatal(err)
        }
        fmt.Println(b.Data1)
    }

}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/4Djx9UYTLF" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground link</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T14:10:14.960" CommentCount="0" />

So your code should be more like</p>
