question:
45441735      <row Id="45441735" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45442842" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45441735" CreationDate="2017-08-01T16:15:05.550" Score="1" Body="<p>Here what you are looking for:</p>

<pre><code>func getHostKey(host string) (ssh.PublicKey, error) {
    file, err := os.Open(filepath.Join(os.Getenv("HOME"), ".ssh", "known_hosts"))
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    defer file.Close()

    scanner := bufio.NewScanner(file)
    var hostKey ssh.PublicKey
    for scanner.Scan() {
        fields := strings.Split(scanner.Text(), " ")
        if len(fields) != 3 {
            continue
        }
        if strings.Contains(fields[0], host) {
            var err error
            hostKey, _, _, _, err = ssh.ParseAuthorizedKey(scanner.Bytes())
            if err != nil {
                return nil, errors.New(fmt.Sprintf("error parsing %q: %v", fields[2], err))
            }
            break
        }
    }

    if hostKey == nil {
        return nil, errors.New(fmt.Sprintf("no hostkey for %s", host))
    }
    return hostKey, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then replace your hostKey definition line with</p>

<pre><code>hostKey, err := getHostKey("host.com")
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>For more information on the subject:</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/golang/crypto/blob/master/ssh/example_test.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">official sample</a> where I took parts of the code from</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/19767" rel="nofollow noreferrer">why a hostKey is necessary now</a></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T16:15:05.550" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45443414      <row Id="45443414" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45443906" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45443414" CreationDate="2017-08-01T17:09:20.693" Score="2" Body="<p>A named pipe reader will receive EOF when there are no writers left. The solution outside of this code is to make sure there is always one writer process holding the file descriptor, though it doesn't need to write anything. </p>

<p>Within the Go program, if you want to wait for a new writer, you will have to poll the <code>io.Reader</code> in your for loop. Your current code does this with a busy loop, which will consume 100% of 1 cpu core. Adding a sleep and a way to return on other errors will work around the issue:</p>

<pre><code>for {
    err := io.Copy(&amp;buff, fpipe)
    if buff.Len() &gt; 0 {
        buff.WriteTo(f)
    }

    if err != nil {
        // something other than EOF happened
        return
    }

    time.Sleep(100 * time.Millisecond)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T17:09:20.693" CommentCount="4" />

question:
44089111      <row Id="44089111" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45444023" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44089111" CreationDate="2017-08-01T17:15:26.130" Score="2" Body="<p>There is a bug in the golang standard library <code>net/http</code> that fails to handle the <code>REFUSED_STREAM</code> http/2 error properly.  This is what is likely going on:</p>

<ol>
<li><p>golang client opens a TCP connection to the HTTP/2 www server, sets the maximum number of HTTP streams in the connection to 1000 and starts uploading immediately.</p></li>
<li><p>The HTTP/2 www server tells the golang client to only use a given number of streams, but the golang client has already started more than that amount of streams.</p></li>
<li><p>The HTTP/2 www server reacts to this by resetting the excess streams.</p></li>
<li><p>The lack of proper support for a retry in the golang <code>net/http</code> code causes the stream to fail after being reset by the server, and eventually the upload fails as well.</p></li>
</ol>

<p>There is a ticket open about this issue on github: <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20985/" rel="nofollow noreferrer" title="x/net/http2: retry requests rejected with REFUSED_STREAM">x/net/http2: retry requests rejected with REFUSED_STREAM - golang/go/issues/20985</a></p>

<p>**This issue has been closed in the master branch, the fix will be included in future Golang version 1.10</p>
" OwnerUserId="5535550" LastEditorUserId="5535550" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T21:42:20.667" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T21:42:20.667" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45445263      <row Id="45445263" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45445313" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45445263" CreationDate="2017-08-01T18:34:50.940" Score="6" Body="<p>You should do <code>i = increment(i)</code>.</p>

<p>Otherwise, the <code>i</code> used in the loop is not modified.</p>

<pre><code>for i := 1; condition_true(i); i = increment(i) {
    fmt.Println(i)
}
</code></pre>

<p>That one works as you'd expect.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/dwHbV1iY0_" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/dwHbV1iY0_</a></p>

<p>Alternatively, allow <code>increment</code> to modify <code>i</code> by receiving a pointer to it:</p>

<pre><code>func increment(i *int) {
   *i++
}
</code></pre>

<p>And then use it like this in the loop:</p>

<pre><code>for i := 1; condition_true(i); increment(&amp;i) {
    fmt.Println(i)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T18:34:50.940" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45446429      <row Id="45446429" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45446477" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45446429" CreationDate="2017-08-01T19:46:59.027" Score="4" Body="<p>You never send any values to <code>stuff</code>, you execute all the default cases before you get to any of the receive operations in the <code>fmt.Println</code> statements. The <code>default</code> case is taken immediately if there is no other operation than can proceed, which means that your loop will execute and return as quickly as possible.</p>

<p>You want to block the loop, so you don't need the <code>default</code> case. You don't need the <code>close</code> at the end either, because you're not relying on the closed channel unblocking a receive or breaking from a <code>range</code> clause. </p>

<pre><code>stuff := make(chan int)
go func() {
    for i := 0; i &lt; 5; i++ {
        select {
        case stuff &lt;- i:
            fmt.Printf("Sent %v\n", i)
        }
    }
    println("Closing")
}()
time.Sleep(time.Second)
fmt.Println(&lt;-stuff)
fmt.Println(&lt;-stuff)
fmt.Println(&lt;-stuff)
fmt.Println(&lt;-stuff)
fmt.Println(&lt;-stuff)
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/k2rmRDP38f" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/k2rmRDP38f</a></p>

<p>Notice also that the last "Sent" and the "Closing" line aren't printed, because you have no other synchronization waiting for the goroutine to finish, however that doesn't effect the outcome of this example. </p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-08-01T20:08:01.647" LastActivityDate="2017-08-01T20:08:01.647" CommentCount="2" />

question:

Name: question, dtype: object

question:
45442034      <row Id="45442034" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45456407" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45442034" CreationDate="2017-08-02T09:10:23.700" Score="0" Body="<p>You need to install the libvirt development package, eg libvirt-devel on Fedora/RHEL/Centos, or libvirt-dev on Debian/Ubuntu.</p>

<p>The libvirt-go build process will just query 'pkg-config' to find out where it is installed, so if you did have it installed in a non-standard location (eg /opt/libvirt), then you would do   'export PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/opt/libvirt/lib/pkgconfig' and then libvirt-go would find that.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7126113" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T09:10:23.700" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45456344      <row Id="45456344" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45456829" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45456344" CreationDate="2017-08-02T09:28:16.747" Score="4" Body="<p>Just use <code>xml:"UsernameToken"</code> instead of <code>xml:"wsse:UsernameToken"</code>, <code>xml:"wsse:Security"</code> -> <code>xml:"Security"</code>, etc.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "encoding/xml"
)

type Envelope struct {
    XMLName xml.Name
    Header  Header
}

type Header struct {
    XMLName  xml.Name `xml:"Header"`
    Security Security `xml:"Security"`
}

type Security struct {
    XMLName        xml.Name `xml:"Security"`
    MustUnderstand string `xml:"mustUnderstand,attr"`
    WSSE           string `xml:"wsse,attr"`
    SOAP           string `xml:"soap,attr"`
    UsernameToken struct {
        XMLName  xml.Name `xml:"UsernameToken"`
        Username string `xml:"Username"`
        Password string `xml:"Password"`
    }
}

func main() {

    Soap := []byte(`&lt;SOAP-ENV:Envelope xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"&gt;

  &lt;SOAP-ENV:Header xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"&gt;
    &lt;wsse:Security soap:mustUnderstand="1" xmlns:wsse="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-wssecurity-secext-1.0.xsd" xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"&gt;
      &lt;wsse:UsernameToken&gt;
        &lt;wsse:Username&gt;USERNAME&lt;/wsse:Username&gt;
        &lt;wsse:Password Type="http://docs.oasis-open.org/wss/2004/01/oasis-200401-wss-username-token-profile-1.0#PasswordText"&gt;SECRET&lt;/wsse:Password&gt;
      &lt;/wsse:UsernameToken&gt;
    &lt;/wsse:Security&gt;
  &lt;/SOAP-ENV:Header&gt;

  &lt;SOAP-ENV:Body xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"&gt;
    &lt;OTA_HotelAvailNotifRQ xmlns="http://www.opentravel.org/OTA/2003/05" EchoToken="abc123" Version="1.0" TimeStamp="2005-08-01T09:30:47+08:00"&gt;
      &lt;AvailStatusMessages HotelCode="HOTEL"&gt;
        &lt;AvailStatusMessage BookingLimit="10"&gt;
          &lt;StatusApplicationControl Start="2010-01-01" End="2010-01-14" InvTypeCode="A1K" RatePlanCode="GLD"/&gt;
        &lt;/AvailStatusMessage&gt;
      &lt;/AvailStatusMessages&gt;
    &lt;/OTA_HotelAvailNotifRQ&gt;
  &lt;/SOAP-ENV:Body&gt;

&lt;/SOAP-ENV:Envelope&gt;`)

    res := &amp;Envelope{}
    err := xml.Unmarshal(Soap, res)

    fmt.Println(res.Header.Security.UsernameToken.Username, err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output: <code>USERNAME &lt;nil&gt;</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="3805062" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T09:28:16.747" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45457397      <row Id="45457397" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45457468" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45457397" CreationDate="2017-08-02T09:54:17.937" Score="3" Body="<p>You are right: <code>strings.Spit()</code> will never return a nil value. The result will be of type <code>[]string</code> with at least one element containing the given string.</p>

<p>Whether you can remove the if block depends: Does your code have a problem if <code>len(ips) &lt; 2</code>? If it does not you can safely remove the if block.</p>

<p>If however e.g. you are only interested in <code>ips[1]</code> then you definitely need to check first.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastEditorUserId="6220193" LastEditDate="2017-08-02T11:09:58.563" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T11:09:58.563" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45455144      <row Id="45455144" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45457928" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45455144" CreationDate="2017-08-02T10:12:42.553" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to return empty <code>model.Model</code> object in order for protobufs to be able to properly serialise the message.</p>

<p>Try</p>

<pre><code>import "google.golang.org/grpc/status"

func (Abcd) Dosomethink(c context.Context, sessionRequest *model.MyModel) (*model.Model, error) {

   return &amp;model.Model{}, status.New(400,"Default error message for 400")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="563158" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T10:12:42.553" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45436158      <row Id="45436158" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45462051" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45436158" CreationDate="2017-08-02T13:19:39.300" Score="1" Body="<p>On Windows, your first step is to try <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa373208(v=vs.85).aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>SetThreadExecutionState</code></a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Enables an application to inform the system that it is in use, thereby preventing the system from entering sleep or turning off the display while the application is running</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This is not a perfect solution but I assume this is not an issue for you:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The SetThreadExecutionState function cannot be used to prevent the user from putting the computer to sleep. Applications should respect that the user expects a certain behavior when they close the lid on their laptop or press the power button</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The Windows 8 connected standby feature is also something you might need to consider. Looking at the power related APIs we find this description of <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dd405534(v=vs.85).aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>PowerRequestSystemRequired</code></a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The system continues to run instead of entering sleep after a period of user inactivity. </p>
  
  <p>This request type is not honored on systems capable of connected standby. Applications should use PowerRequestExecutionRequired requests instead.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you are dealing with tablets and other small devices then you can try to call <a href="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dd405534(v=vs.85).aspx" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>PowerSetRequest</code></a> with <code>PowerRequestExecutionRequired</code> to prevent this although the description of that is also not ideal:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The calling process continues to run instead of being suspended or terminated by process lifetime management mechanisms. When and how long the process is allowed to run depends on the operating system and power policy settings.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>You might also want to use <code>ShutdownBlockReasonCreate</code> but I'm not sure if it blocks sleep/hibernate.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3501" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T13:19:39.300" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45337471      <row Id="45337471" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45464607" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45337471" CreationDate="2017-08-02T15:10:00.323" Score="0" Body="<p>This details what was happening: <a href="https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/issues/1438" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/issues/1438</a></p>

<ol>
<li>The main issue was that <code>CopySource</code> needs to be url-encoded and <em>not</em> the <code>Key</code> field, which was surprising to me. (I was url-encoding both.)</li>
<li>The other issue was that I was using <code>path.Join</code> which strips out trailing <code>\</code>. This is a problem because s3 keys can have trailing <code>\</code> - which represents a sort of folder.</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="1168364" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T15:10:00.323" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45465368      <row Id="45465368" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45465853" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45465368" CreationDate="2017-08-02T16:06:59.443" Score="3" Body="<p>You can use copy for the inner loop (which should be more efficient) and range for the outer loop (which results in nicer code).</p>

<p>Result:</p>

<pre><code>duplicate := make([][]int, len(matrix))
for i := range matrix {
    duplicate[i] = make([]int, len(matrix[i]))
    copy(duplicate[i], matrix[i])
}
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p>If your goal is efficiency, it may make sense to do more allocation up front. This doesn't lead to more readable code but will lead to more efficient code if you are doing this often. This code assumes you have at least one row and that all rows are of the same length. You will need to add tests for that.</p>

<pre><code>n := len(matrix)
m := len(matrix[0])
duplicate := make([][]int, n)
data := make([]int, n*m)
for i := range matrix {
    start := i*m
    end := start + m
    duplicate[i] = data[start:end:end]
    copy(duplicate[i], matrix[i])
}
</code></pre>

<p>Depending on what you are doing, it may make sense to make a "matrix type" that is implemented using only a single slice. A slice of slices is not the most efficient data structure, even if it is simpler to work with.</p>

<hr>

<p>Before deciding if you need to be efficient, make sure that you are spending a lot of time doing copying using profiling. Then, after you have determined this is in fact a hotspot, start running benchmarks. See <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#hdr-Benchmarks" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/testing/#hdr-Benchmarks</a> for details.</p>
" OwnerUserId="727643" LastEditorUserId="727643" LastEditDate="2017-08-02T17:51:23.927" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T17:51:23.927" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45466440      <row Id="45466440" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45466540" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45466440" CreationDate="2017-08-02T16:43:08.693" Score="1" Body="<p>Use a struct that contains the func and any metadata instead of just a func. Something like this.</p>

<pre><code>type NewHandler struct {
    Handler func(*indexer.Document) error
    Data string // or whatever data
}
</code></pre>

<p>Also make sure your slice holds pointers because go is pass-by-value.</p>

<pre><code>var NewHandlers []*NewHandler
</code></pre>

<p>Then when you for loop, it goes like this.</p>

<pre><code>for i, handler := range NewHandlers {
        err = handler.Handler(document)
        ....
</code></pre>

<p>And you can include your Data in the error.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastEditorUserId="1276480" LastEditDate="2017-08-02T17:56:53.220" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T17:56:53.220" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45466614      <row Id="45466614" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45466847" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45466614" CreationDate="2017-08-02T16:59:19.323" Score="2" Body="<p>In <code>appendStruct</code>, <code>container</code> is a local variable, so it's not accessible outside that function call. You could return it, which would make it accessible from the caller (in this case, <code>main</code>):</p>

<pre><code>func appendStruct() DataContainer {
    //...
    return container
}

func main() {
    container := appendStruct()
}
</code></pre>

<p>The answer you linked is an excellent starting point. A code example shouldn't really be necessary - they're basically recommending that you create a helper method/function that takes all the fields of the struct and puts them into a slice in whatever order you want them to appear in the CSV, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>func (c DataItem) ToSlice() []string {
    row := make([]string, 1, 1) // Since you only have 1 field in the struct
    row[0] = c.name
    return row
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then you can loop over these to write them to a CSV file.</p>

<p>The error output you're getting is because you're using <code>Sprintf</code>, which expects a format string as the first parameter with a reference for each other argument. You're passing an empty format string, which would only work with no other arguments (and be pointless). Perhaps you meant <code>Sprintf("%v", container)</code> or just <code>Sprint(container)</code>?</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T16:59:19.323" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45468089      <row Id="45468089" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45468253" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45468089" CreationDate="2017-08-02T18:18:17.020" Score="5" Body="<p>That's because when you use the pointers you are adding <code>&amp;w</code> to the array.</p>

<p>Note that <code>w</code> is actually the local variable used in the loop, so that's not the address you want to add to the <code>matches</code> array.</p>

<p>(even though the <em>value</em> of the variable <code>w</code> changes through the loop, it's <em>address</em> stays the same)</p>

<p>When the loop ends, <code>w</code> ends up with the last value so that's why it prints <code>12</code> two times.</p>

<p>You need to add the address of the element that matched instead.</p>

<p>If you do this:</p>

<pre><code>matches = append(matches, &amp;widgets[i])
</code></pre>

<p>Then it'd work fine with pointers as well.</p>

<p>Modified Go playground for you to test it:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/YE-cokyEHu" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/YE-cokyEHu</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T18:18:17.020" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45471843      <row Id="45471843" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45472101" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45471843" CreationDate="2017-08-02T22:37:30.303" Score="1" Body="<p>You should just check return value of Row.Scan method, just like this:</p>

<pre><code>row := db.QueryRow(
    `SELECT 
        json_build_object('Profile', array_to_json(array_agg(t))) 
    FROM
        (
            SELECT 
                p.id,
                p.fullname,
                z.thirtylatmin as latmin,
                z.thirtylatmax as latmax,
                z.thirtylonmin as lonmin,
                z.thirtylonmax as lonmax,
                p.latitudes,
                p.longitudes,
                p.location as location,
                p.picture,
                p.is_gold 
            FROM 
                profiles p 
            JOIN zips z on (z.city='Boston'AND z.state='MA') 
            WHERE 
                email=$1
        ) t`,
    email,
)

var result string
if err := Scan(&amp;result); err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}

fmt.Fprint(w, result)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8075949" LastActivityDate="2017-08-02T22:37:30.303" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45472816      <row Id="45472816" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45473728" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45472816" CreationDate="2017-08-03T02:16:14.790" Score="3" Body="<p>You can do that using Method Expressions:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_expressions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_expressions</a></p>

<p>The call is a bit different, since the method expression takes the receiver as the first argument.</p>

<p>Here's your example modified:</p>

<pre><code>package main

type someStruct struct {
    x int
}

func (s someStruct) someFunc() int {
    return s.x
}

func main() {
    m := make(map[string]func(someStruct)int, 0)
    s := someStruct{56}
    m["1"] = (someStruct).someFunc
    print(m["1"](s))
}
</code></pre>

<p>And here's a Go playground for you to test it:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/PLi5A9of-U" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/PLi5A9of-U</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T02:16:14.790" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45474896      <row Id="45474896" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45474995" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45474896" CreationDate="2017-08-03T04:43:26.360" Score="1" Body="<p>the line </p>

<pre><code>done = strings.Contains(webSlices[theSlice], string(counter))
</code></pre>

<p><code>string(counter)</code> can't work here, use <code>strconv.Itoa(counter)</code> instead</p>
" OwnerUserId="2791115" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T04:43:26.360" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45474948      <row Id="45474948" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45475191" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45474948" CreationDate="2017-08-03T05:00:25.923" Score="0" Body="<p>As @volker mentioned; you cannot as the empty interface has no methods.</p>

<p><em>Please note: <code>fmt.Sprint</code>, <code>fmt.Sprintf</code> etc. does call Stringer interface first if its exists. It is elegant way.</em></p>

<p>Example of calling stringer interface after type assertion.</p>

<pre><code>var a SomeType
if v, ok := a.(fmt.Stringer); ok {
    fmt.Println(v.String())
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T05:00:25.923" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45476506      <row Id="45476506" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45477148" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45476506" CreationDate="2017-08-03T07:06:34.787" Score="1" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>Is there a better, or more idiomatic way of doing this?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Yes: Handle the error. Log.Fatal is not error handling. If fataling is really the right thing: Encapsulate fataling only.</p>

<p>Make fataling on error a function, not the calling and please stay away from <code>interface{}</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func abortOnError(err error) {
    if err == nil {return}
    log.Fatal(err)
}

func whatever() int {
    x, err := someOp()
    abortOnError(err)
    return x+2
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1266756" LastEditorUserId="1266756" LastEditDate="2017-08-03T10:17:50.980" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T10:17:50.980" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45479236      <row Id="45479236" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45479446" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45479236" CreationDate="2017-08-03T08:56:54.400" Score="0" Body="<p>each time you copy a session, you should close it.</p>

<p>rewrite your <code>GetCollection</code> and <code>GetAllRows</code>, use one function like:</p>

<pre><code>func FetchData(session mgo.Session, queueName string) ([]Data, error) {
  fmt.Println("Creating collection ...")
  sess := session.Copy()
  collection := sess.DB(dbName).C(queueName)
  fmt.Println("Collection created!")

  defer  sess.Close() 

   var results []Data

   err := collection.Find(nil).All(&amp;results)
   if err != nil {
       panic(err)
       return nil, err
   }
   return results, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>note the line </p>

<pre><code> defer  sess.Close() 
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2791115" LastEditorUserId="2791115" LastEditDate="2017-08-03T09:02:19.467" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T09:02:19.467" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45481001      <row Id="45481001" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45481705" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45481001" CreationDate="2017-08-03T10:33:39.337" Score="1" Body="<p>It's obviously not on the path. It's a bit weird as I believe Windows installer adds it properly. You can fix it though, by going to Control Panel -> System -> Advanced (Tab) -> Environment Variables. (Actual names will likely differ in your version of windows, but should be recognizably close. In worst case, search Setting environment variables for your version of windows in google.). Then find PATH variable and add path to the go executable. You'll also need to have GOROOT variable set as well.</p>

<p>For example, I have Go installed in C:\Go folder. So, I have GOROOT variable set as C:\Go and C:\Go\bin added to PATH variable. You can have them as either User or System variables. User ones will be visible only to you, while System ones will be for everyone. That's the only difference.</p>

<p>Keep in mind though that it will only affect programs started <em>after</em> you have updated environment variables settings. So, you'll have to restart VS Code for it to take effect.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6375498" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T10:33:39.337" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45480412      <row Id="45480412" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45482855" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45480412" CreationDate="2017-08-03T11:26:46.657" Score="1" Body="<p>Your kernel reports the <code>ppc64</code> architecture.  This means it is 64-bit POWER in <em>big endian</em> mode.  The Go project only publishes <code>ppc64le</code> (64-bit POWER in <em>little endian</em> mode) builds: <a href="https://golang.org/dl/#stable" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go stable downloads</a> only offers a <code>go1.8.3.linux-ppc64le.tar.gz</code> download.</p>

<p>The Go sources contain a 64-bit POWER big-endian port, but you need to compile it yourself.  (But this is definitely off the beaten path, so you might run into issues.)  Note that Go 1.9 will require POWER8 even in big-endian mode, so depending on the hardware you have, even a self-compiled version could be a dead-end.  (<code>e6500</code> in the <code>/proc/cpuinfo</code> output suggests that this platform is <em>not</em> POWER8-compatibile.)</p>

<p>Another option is the GCC Go compiler (<code>gccgo</code>).  This Go compiler will work with many GCC targets, and the chances are good that it will remain supported to some degree in the foreseeable future.  However, few Go programmers care about <code>gccgo</code>, so you might encounter packages which do not work with it.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8316315" LastEditorUserId="8316315" LastEditDate="2017-08-03T11:46:14.417" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T11:46:14.417" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45483655      <row Id="45483655" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45483718" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45483655" CreationDate="2017-08-03T12:06:12.103" Score="1" Body="<p>So you want a json array instead of a json object?</p>

<p>Instead of loading a <code>map[int]string</code>, why not simply make a <code>[]Division</code>?</p>

<pre><code>list := []Division{}
for divisions.Next() {
    var d Division
    err := divisions.Scan(&amp;d.id, &amp;d.name)
    list = append(list, d)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err.Error())
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>You'll need to change the field names to <code>ID</code> and <code>Name</code> so that the json package can serialize them, but you should end up with somthing more like:</p>

<pre><code>[
  {"ID":1,"Name":"Games},
  ...
]
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T12:06:12.103" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45486817      <row Id="45486817" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45486922" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45486817" CreationDate="2017-08-03T14:19:38.077" Score="3" Body="<p>When <code>v</code> is a slice, there is no difference between <code>v</code> and <code>v[:]</code>. When <code>v</code> is an array, <code>v[:]</code> is a slice covering the entirety of the array.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T14:19:38.077" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45488393      <row Id="45488393" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45488562" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45488393" CreationDate="2017-08-03T15:26:37.720" Score="3" Body="<p>First, you must use the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/html/template/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>html/template</code></a> instead of <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>text/template</code></a>, as the former provides context-sensitive escaping.</p>

<p>Second, in the template the context must be clear that it is JavaScript code, e.g. it must be inside HTML <code>&lt;script&gt;</code> tag.</p>

<p>See this working example:</p>

<pre><code>type Point struct {
    Name string
    X, Y int
}

func main() {
    t := template.Must(template.New("").Parse(src))

    p := Point{"Center", 100, 200}
    pj, err := json.Marshal(p)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }

    if err = t.Execute(os.Stdout, string(pj)); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
}

const src = `&lt;script&gt;
var point = {{.}};
alert(point);
&lt;/script&gt;`
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/EmMR3MQYxi" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>&lt;script&gt;
var point = "{\"Name\":\"Center\",\"X\":100,\"Y\":200}";
alert(point);
&lt;/script&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>As you can see, the <code>point</code> JavaScript variable contains a valid JSON text, properly escaped.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-03T18:15:33.880" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T18:15:33.880" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45490107      <row Id="45490107" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45490356" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45490107" CreationDate="2017-08-03T16:52:40.917" Score="4" Body="<p>Always run your tests with -race. In your case, you forgot to recreate <code>f</code> on each iteration in <code>RunInParallel</code>:</p>

<pre><code>func RunInParallel(funcs ...func() error) error {
    var errcList [](&lt;-chan error)
    for _, f := range funcs {

        f := f // &lt;&lt; HERE

        errc := make(chan error, 1)
        errcList = append(errcList, errc)
        go func() {
            err := f()
            if err != nil {
                errc &lt;- err
            }
            close(errc)
        }()
    }
    return WaitForPipeline(errcList...)
}
</code></pre>

<p>As a result, you always launched the last <code>f</code> instead of each one.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1892060" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T16:52:40.917" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45491043      <row Id="45491043" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45491970" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45491043" CreationDate="2017-08-03T18:29:58.843" Score="2" Body="<p>The field needs to be visible (so uppercase) in order to be included in the JSON marshalling.</p>

<p>At the same time, the DB expects the JSON document to contain a <code>_key</code> attribute.</p>

<p>So you should specify it as:</p>

<pre><code>type doc struct {
    Key string `json:"_key"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Alternatively, you can try sending a <code>map</code> to the method:</p>

<pre><code>coll.CreateDocument(nil, map[string]string{"_key": "mykey"})
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T18:29:58.843" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45487377      <row Id="45487377" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45494246" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45487377" CreationDate="2017-08-03T20:48:35.380" Score="2" Body="<p>You need to declare your own type which implements the Value interface. Here is an example.</p>

<pre><code>// Created so that multiple inputs can be accecpted
type arrayFlags []string

func (i *arrayFlags) String() string {
    // change this, this is just can example to satisfy the interface
    return "my string representation"
}

func (i *arrayFlags) Set(value string) error {
    *i = append(*i, strings.TrimSpace(value))
    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>then in the main function where you are parsing the flags</p>

<pre><code>var myFlags arrayFlags

flag.Var(&amp;myFlags, "term", "my terms")
flag.Parse()
</code></pre>

<p>Now all the terms are contained in the slice <code>myFlags</code></p>
" OwnerUserId="4639336" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T20:48:35.380" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45492320      <row Id="45492320" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45494261" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45492320" CreationDate="2017-08-03T20:49:44.627" Score="1" Body="<p>The root of the problem stems from how interfaces in Go are implicitly satisfied.<br>
In this particular case, the <code>json.Marshal</code> method uses type assertion at runtime to see if the given value implements <code>json.Marshaler</code>. Effective Go <a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#blank_implements" rel="nofollow noreferrer">mentions this very case</a>.</p>

<p>You could have satisfied the <code>json.Marshaler</code> for the <code>*TextOutput</code> type using a pointer-receiver like so:</p>

<pre><code>func (t *TextOutput) MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) {
    return []byte(fmt.Sprintf(`{"data":"%s"}`, *t)), nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>And for this to work properly, pass the reference to the <code>json.Marshal</code> function:</p>

<pre><code>var t TextOutput
t = `Test test`
output, err := json.Marshal(&amp;t) 
</code></pre>

<p>However, implementing it using a value-receiver ensures that both <code>TextOutput</code> and <code>*TextOutput</code> types implement <code>json.Marshaler</code></p>

<pre><code>func (t TextOutput) MarshalJSON() ([]byte, error) {
    return []byte(fmt.Sprintf(`{"data": "%s"}`, t)), nil
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1649295" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T20:49:44.627" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45472324      <row Id="45472324" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45494634" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45472324" CreationDate="2017-08-03T21:15:25.293" Score="1" Body="<p>This is an example of how to set up a concurrent downloader. Things to be aware of are bandwidth, memory, and disk space.  You can kill your bandwidth by trying to do to much at once, the same goes for memory.  Your downloading pretty big files so memory can be an issue.  Another thing to note is that by using gorountines you are losing request order. So if the order of the returned bytes matter, then this will not work because you will have to know the byte order to assemble the file in the end, which would mean that a downloading one at a time is best, unless you implement a way to keep track of the order (maybe some kind of global map[order int][]bytes with mutex to prevent race conditions).  An alternative that doesn't involve <code>Go</code> (assuming you have a unix machine for ease) is to use <code>Curl</code> see here <a href="http://osxdaily.com/2014/02/13/download-with-curl/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://osxdaily.com/2014/02/13/download-with-curl/</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
    "io"
    "io/ioutil"
    "log"
    "net/http"
    "sync"
)

// now your going to have to be careful because you can potentially run out of memory downloading to many files at once..
// however here is an example that can be modded
func downloader(wg *sync.WaitGroup, sema chan struct{}, fileNum int, URL string) {
    sema &lt;- struct{}{}
    defer func() {
        &lt;-sema
        wg.Done()
    }()

    client := &amp;http.Client{Timeout: 10}
    res, err := client.Get(URL)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    defer res.Body.Close()
    var buf bytes.Buffer
    io.Copy(&amp;buf, res.Body)
    // write the bytes to file
    ioutil.WriteFile(fmt.Sprintf("file%d.txt", fileNum), buf.Bytes(), 0644)
    return
}

func main() {
    links := []string{
        "url1",
        "url2", // etc...
    }
    var wg sync.WaitGroup
    // limit to four downloads at a time, this is called a semaphore
    limiter := make(chan struct{}, 4)
    for i, link := range links {
        wg.Add(1)
        go downloader(&amp;wg, limiter, i, link)
    }
    wg.Wait()

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4639336" LastEditorUserId="4639336" LastEditDate="2017-08-03T21:35:38.230" LastActivityDate="2017-08-03T21:35:38.230" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45498036      <row Id="45498036" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45498528" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45498036" CreationDate="2017-08-04T04:56:08.157" Score="2" Body="<p>Where should I start? Let's start with your first code snippet and make it work properly.</p>

<pre><code>func init() {
    connectionString := "host=172.17.0.3 dbname=postgres user=postgres password=postgres port=5432 sslmode=disable"

    var err error
    connection, err = sql.Open(
        "postgres",
        connectionString,
    )
    check(err)

    err = connection.Ping()
    check(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>In the above code snippet <code>err</code> is local variable and <code>connection</code> is package variable.</p>

<hr>

<p>In your second code snippet <code>err</code> is defined as part <code>connectionString, err := ...</code> and you have <code>connection</code> package variable defined. So it works.</p>

<hr>

<p>Using short declaration operator <code>:=</code> defines local scoped variable. Such as: </p>

<ul>
<li>If you define within <code>func</code> then it is function scope.</li>
<li>If you define in <code>if</code> then it is <code>if else</code> scope.</li>
</ul>

<p>I hope it helps.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T04:56:08.157" CommentCount="2" />

answer:
<row Id="45498587" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45498274" CreationDate="2017-08-04T05:02:02.860" Score="3" Body="<p>Try instead a dependency manager: the most recent and actively developed one is <strong><a href="https://github.com/golang/dep" rel="nofollow noreferrer">golang/dep</a></strong>.<br>
Reading <a href="https://github.com/golang/dep/issues/943" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><strong>dep</strong> "issue" 943</a>, use:</p>

<pre><code>dep ensure
</code></pre>

<p>That will set up vendored dependencies through import analysis, and you can configure locking those down if need be.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6309" LastEditorUserId="6309" LastEditDate="2017-08-04T06:25:10.180" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T06:25:10.180" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45500420      <row Id="45500420" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45500563" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45500420" CreationDate="2017-08-04T07:22:02.057" Score="-1" Body="<p>This line looks problematic:</p>

<pre><code>nanoDayOfYear:=string(quant*24*60*60*1000*1000*1000) + "ns"
</code></pre>

<p>Specifically, <code>string(...)</code> doesn't do what you want. Presumably you want to convert that number to a base-10 string. Try this instead:</p>

<pre><code>nanoDayOfYear:=strconv.FormatInt(quant*24*60*60*1000*1000*1000, 10) + "ns"
</code></pre>

question:
45500836      <row Id="45500836" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45502591" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45500836" CreationDate="2017-08-04T09:04:14.517" Score="6" Body="<p>You may use the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/context/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>context</code></a> package which was created for things like this (<em>"carries deadlines, cancelation signals..."</em>).</p>

<p>You create a context capable of publishing cancelation signals with <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/context/#WithCancel" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>context.WithCancel()</code></a> (parent context may be the one returned by <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/context/#Background" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>context.Background()</code></a>). This will return you a <code>cancel()</code> function which may be used to cancel (or more precisely <em>signal</em> the cancel intent) to the worker goroutines.<br>
And in the worker goroutines you have to check if such intent has been initiated, by checking if the channel returned by <code>Context.Done()</code> is closed, easiest done by attempting to receive from it (which proceeds immediately if it is closed). And to do a non-blocking check (so you can continue if it is not closed), use the <code>select</code> statement with a <code>default</code> branch.</p>

<p>I will use the following <code>work()</code> implementation, which simulates a 10% failure chance, and simulates 1 second of work:</p>

<pre><code>func work(i int) (int, error) {
    if rand.Intn(100) &lt; 10 { // 10% of failure
        return 0, errors.New("random error")
    }
    time.Sleep(time.Second)
    return 100 + i, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>And the <code>doAllWork()</code> may look like this:</p>

<pre><code>func doAllWork() error {
    var wg sync.WaitGroup

    ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
    defer cancel() // Make sure it's called to release resources even if no errors

    for i := 0; i &lt; 2; i++ {
        wg.Add(1)
        go func(i int) {
            defer wg.Done()

            for j := 0; j &lt; 10; j++ {
                // Check if any error occurred in any other gorouties:
                select {
                case &lt;-ctx.Done():
                    return // Error somewhere, terminate
                default: // Default is must to avoid blocking
                }
                result, err := work(j)
                if err != nil {
                    fmt.Printf("Worker #%d during %d, error: %v
", i, j, err)
                    cancel()
                    return
                }
                fmt.Printf("Worker #%d finished %d, result: %d.
", i, j, result)
            }
        }(i)
    }
    wg.Wait()

    return ctx.Err()
}
</code></pre>

<p>This is how it can be tested:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano() + 1) // +1 'cause Playground's time is fixed
    fmt.Printf("doAllWork: %v
", doAllWork())
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/od8ShySgMM" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Worker #0 finished 0, result: 100.
Worker #1 finished 0, result: 100.
Worker #1 finished 1, result: 101.
Worker #0 finished 1, result: 101.
Worker #0 finished 2, result: 102.
Worker #1 finished 2, result: 102.
Worker #1 finished 3, result: 103.
Worker #1 during 4, error: random error
Worker #0 finished 3, result: 103.
doAllWork: context canceled
</code></pre>

<p>If there would be no errors, e.g. when using the following <code>work()</code> function:</p>

<pre><code>func work(i int) (int, error) {
    time.Sleep(time.Second)
    return 100 + i, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>The output would be like (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/gZKXSAa4F-" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Worker #0 finished 0, result: 100.
Worker #1 finished 0, result: 100.
Worker #1 finished 1, result: 101.
Worker #0 finished 1, result: 101.
Worker #0 finished 2, result: 102.
Worker #1 finished 2, result: 102.
Worker #1 finished 3, result: 103.
Worker #0 finished 3, result: 103.
Worker #0 finished 4, result: 104.
Worker #1 finished 4, result: 104.
Worker #1 finished 5, result: 105.
Worker #0 finished 5, result: 105.
Worker #0 finished 6, result: 106.
Worker #1 finished 6, result: 106.
Worker #1 finished 7, result: 107.
Worker #0 finished 7, result: 107.
Worker #0 finished 8, result: 108.
Worker #1 finished 8, result: 108.
Worker #1 finished 9, result: 109.
Worker #0 finished 9, result: 109.
doAllWork: &lt;nil&gt;
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Notes:</strong></p>

<p>Basically we just used the <code>Done()</code> channel of the context, so it seems we could just as easily (if not even easier) use a <code>done</code> channel instead of the <code>Context</code>, closing the channel to do what <code>cancel()</code> does in the above solution.</p>

<p>This is not true. <strong>This can only be used if only one goroutine may close the channel, but in our case any of the workers may do so.</strong> And attempting to close an already closed channel panics (see details here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39015602/how-does-a-non-initialized-channel-behave/39016004#39016004">How does a non initialized channel behave?</a>). So you would have to ensure some kind of synchronization / exclusion around the <code>close(done)</code>, which will make it less readable and even more complex. Actually this is exactly what the <code>cancel()</code> function does under the hood, hidden / abstracted away from your eyes, so <code>cancel()</code> may be called multiple times to make your code / use of it simpler.</p>

<h3>How to get and return the error(s) from the workers?</h3>

<p>For this you may use an error channel:</p>

<pre><code>errs := make(chan error, 2) // Buffer for 2 errors
</code></pre>

<p>And inside the workers when an error is encountered, send it on the channel instead of printing it:</p>

<pre><code>result, err := work(j)
if err != nil {
    errs &lt;- fmt.Errorf("Worker #%d during %d, error: %v
", i, j, err)
    cancel()
    return
}
</code></pre>

<p>And after the loop, if there was an error, return that (and <code>nil</code> otherwise):</p>

<pre><code>// Return (first) error, if any:
if ctx.Err() != nil {
    return &lt;-errs
}
return nil
</code></pre>

<p>Output this time (try this on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/J2wMOuxiTm" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Worker #0 finished 0, result: 100.
Worker #1 finished 0, result: 100.
Worker #1 finished 1, result: 101.
Worker #0 finished 1, result: 101.
Worker #0 finished 2, result: 102.
Worker #1 finished 2, result: 102.
Worker #1 finished 3, result: 103.
Worker #0 finished 3, result: 103.
doAllWork: Worker #1 during 4, error: random error
</code></pre>

<p>Note that I used a buffered channel with a buffer size equal to the number of workers, which ensures sending on it is always non-blocking. This also gives you the possibility to receive and process all errors, not just one (e.g. the first). Another option could be to use a buffered channel to hold only 1, and do a non-blocking send on it, which could look like this:</p>

<pre><code>errs := make(chan error, 1) // Buffered only for the first error

// ...and inside the worker:

result, err := work(j)
if err != nil {
    // Non-blocking send:
    select {
    case errs &lt;- fmt.Errorf("Worker #%d during %d, error: %v
", i, j, err):
    default:
    }
    cancel()
    return
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-04T10:07:24.177" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T10:07:24.177" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45500781      <row Id="45500781" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45503575" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45500781" CreationDate="2017-08-04T09:48:48.223" Score="2" Body="<p>You can add the json-mapping directly to the structure definition and use the encoder, decoder to marshal and unmarshal it. It's all built in and easier than in other languages, imho.</p>

<pre><code>type ServiceResponse struct {
    Value string`json:"nameInJsonResponse"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>here is a good example from the playground: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/4L2wMVv7tW" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/4L2wMVv7tW</a> </p>

<p>For your particular case it should be something like this:</p>

<pre><code>type ServiceResult struct {
    Status ServiceResultStatus`json:"status"`
    Type string`json:"type"`
    Hash string`json:"hash"`
    Destination string`json:"destination"`
    Metadata map[string]Metadata metadata`json:"metadata"`
}

type ExplizitServiceResult struct {
    ServiceResult
    Content SomeStruct`json:"content"`
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/FFfiq6LxVt" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/FFfiq6LxVt</a></p>

<p>If you don't want to derive every user struct from the ServiceResult you can define the content as <code>interface{}</code> so every struct can be inserted. I've updated my example for this. Maybe this is the easiest solution to your problem.
<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/LNgreqrnnw" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/LNgreqrnnw</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8383919" LastEditorUserId="8383919" LastEditDate="2017-08-04T13:17:51.667" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T13:17:51.667" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45508642      <row Id="45508642" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45508761" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45508642" CreationDate="2017-08-04T13:58:47.347" Score="4" Body="<p>You must export fields of structs, else they are ignored by the <code>mgo</code> package. Change fields of <code>users</code> to <code>User</code> and <code>Data</code>.</p>

<pre><code>type users struct {
    User string `bson:"user" json:"user"`
    Data string `bson:"data" json:"data"` 
}
</code></pre>

<p>By default when a struct value is transformed / stored / retrieved from MongoDB, the field name is used. If you want to use different names, you may use <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10858787/what-are-the-uses-for-tags-in-go/30889373#30889373">tags</a> to tell what names should the fields map to.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-04T15:29:53.210" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T15:29:53.210" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45509538      <row Id="45509538" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45509642" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45509538" CreationDate="2017-08-04T14:42:48.653" Score="5" Body="<p>First I recommend to read the following questions / answers:</p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42345060/freeosmemory-in-production/42345554#42345554">FreeOSMemory() in production</a></p>

<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37382600/golang-cannot-free-memory-once-occupied-by-bytes-buffer/37383604#37383604">Golang - Cannot free memory once occupied by bytes.Buffer</a></p>

<p>You may trigger a gc to free unused objects with <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/runtime/#GC" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>runtime.GC()</code></a> and you may urge your Go runtime to release memory back to OS with <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/runtime/debug/#FreeOSMemory" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>debug.FreeOSMemory()</code></a>, but all these are just fire fighting. A well-written Go app should never have to call these.</p>

<p>What you should do is prevent the runtime having to allocate large amount of memory.</p>

<p>How may you achieve this? Some means (you can even combine these solutions):</p>

<ul>
<li><p>Limit serving the requests requiring large memory, more about it: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37529511/process-management-for-the-go-webserver/37531953#37531953">Process Management for the Go Webserver</a>; also <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38170852/is-this-an-idiomatic-worker-thread-pool-in-go/38172204#38172204">Is this an idiomatic worker thread pool in Go?</a></p></li>
<li><p>Use memory / buffer pools, do not allocate big arrays / slices all the time, more about it: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38505830/how-to-implement-memory-pooling-in-golang/38506367#38506367">How to implement Memory Pooling in Golang</a></p></li>
<li><p>Create / change your processing units not to operate on byte slices but on <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Reader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Reader</code></a>s, so you don't need to read all content into memory, you can just pass <code>resp.Body</code> on. Note that even if multiple units have to read / inspect the body, it is still possible to only read and process it once, and not keep it in memory. Means may be <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Pipe" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Pipe()</code></a>, <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#TeeReader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.TeeReader()</code></a> or custom solutions.</p></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-04T15:04:11.527" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T15:04:11.527" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45510787      <row Id="45510787" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45511137" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45510787" CreationDate="2017-08-04T15:59:52.813" Score="1" Body="<p>Unmask takes a pointer to a pointer, let's say pointer X to pointer Y, pointer Y points to the string value. Unmask then <strong>changes</strong> the pointer to which X is pointing to, Y is unchanged and points still to the same old string.</p>

<p>You can do this:</p>

<pre><code>func UnMask(n **string, k string) {
    **n = k
}
</code></pre>

<p>or</p>

<pre><code>func UnMask(n *string, k string) {
    *n = k
}
// ....
UnMask(n1, "Joe") // drop the '&amp;'
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="965900" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T15:59:52.813" CommentCount="2" />

question:

<row Id="45512643" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45506424" CreationDate="2017-08-04T17:40:52.093" Score="1" Body="<p>You can possibly use bytes.Equal or bytes.Contains to compare with a zero initialized byte slice, see <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/mvUXaTwKjP" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/mvUXaTwKjP</a>, I haven't checked for performance, but hopefully it's been optimized. You might want to try out other solutions and compare the performance numbers, if needed.</p>

question:
45510348      <row Id="45510348" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45513018" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45510348" CreationDate="2017-08-04T18:05:08.090" Score="1" Body="<p>If you look at how <code>(*http.Server).Serve()</code> is implemented <a href="https://golang.org/src/net/http/server.go?m=text" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>, it is clear that you can just define your own class that implements <code>net.Listener</code> and give it to the <code>Serve()</code> function, instead of using <code>ListenAndServe()</code>, which puts a default listener there. Make it <code>panic</code> on error and later <code>recover</code> from that panic in your code, or implement any other error handling logic.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6444852" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T18:05:08.090" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45515604      <row Id="45515604" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45516325" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45515604" CreationDate="2017-08-04T22:29:04.053" Score="3" Body="<p>Even though you could figure it out yourself by reading the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Switch_statements" rel="nofollow noreferrer">doc</a> here is what you should write:</p>

<pre><code>switch a.Type {
case "v1":
    // ...
    // no need to 'break' in go
case "v2":
    // ...
default:
    // usual 'else' clause statements
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5016244" LastActivityDate="2017-08-04T22:29:04.053" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45515809      <row Id="45515809" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45517192" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45515809" CreationDate="2017-08-05T00:47:44.410" Score="4" Body="<p>If all you do is reading the content of variable - then no, you do not need mutex. However, if you ever mutate its state, then you need to protect it. </p>

<p>Two concurrent writes or concurrent write and read can cause problems. If your writes are rare, you might want to use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#RWMutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer">RWMutex</a>. It will allow multiple readers to access, but not together with a writer.</p>

<p>Also, check out <a href="https://blog.golang.org/race-detector" rel="nofollow noreferrer">race detector</a>. It is best effort detector, so it does not guarantee that you do not have race condition, but it can detect some use cases. Also note that you need to cause race in order for race detector to detect it, so writing tests that use your <code>bus</code> concurrently or simulating real conditions has to be done.</p>
" OwnerUserId="61363" LastActivityDate="2017-08-05T00:47:44.410" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45517523      <row Id="45517523" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45517723" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45517523" CreationDate="2017-08-05T02:51:50.443" Score="2" Body="<p>For example, the <code>main</code> goroutine blocks forever,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "time"
)

func forever() {
    for {
        fmt.Println(time.Now().UTC())
        time.Sleep(time.Second)
    }
}

func main() {
    go forever()
    select {} // block forever
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>2017-08-05 02:50:10.138353286 +0000 UTC
2017-08-05 02:50:11.138504194 +0000 UTC
2017-08-05 02:50:12.138618149 +0000 UTC
2017-08-05 02:50:13.138753477 +0000 UTC
2017-08-05 02:50:14.13888856 +0000 UTC
2017-08-05 02:50:15.139027355 +0000 UTC
...
...
...
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastActivityDate="2017-08-05T02:51:50.443" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45519669      <row Id="45519669" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45520100" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45519669" CreationDate="2017-08-05T08:57:40.363" Score="0" Body="<p>Let me explain:</p>

<p>First of all in this function:</p>

<pre><code>func (predator Cat) eatingVictim(victim *Mouse) {
    fmt.Println(predator.name + "'s eating victim " + victim.name)
    predator.hungry = false
    victim.alive = false
}
</code></pre>

<p>You want to pass Herbivore. This is a bad solution because you will not
use methods from Herbivore interface here. Better approach is to define
another interface.</p>

<pre><code>type Animal interface {
    GetName() string
    SetAlive(bool)
}
</code></pre>

<p>And implement it for Mouse (and Cat if you wish):</p>

<pre><code>func (m *Mouse) GetName() string {
    return m.name
}

func (m *Mouse) SetAlive(alive bool) {
    m.alive = alive
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then change interface Predator to:</p>

<pre><code>type Predator interface {
    eatingVictim(victim Animal)
}
</code></pre>

<p>and implement it for Cat</p>

<pre><code>func (predator *Cat) eatingVictim(victim Animal) {
    fmt.Println(predator.name + "'s eating victim " + victim.GetName())
    predator.hungry = false
    victim.SetAlive(false)
}
</code></pre>

<p>I need to mention  that if you want your original structs to
be modified then you need to pass a pointer to struct, not a struct as
receiver argument:</p>

<p>Here Mouse struct will not be modified. Only a copy of it.</p>

<pre><code>func (herbivore Mouse) eatingGrass() {
    fmt.Println(herbivore.name + "'s eating a grass.. ^___^")
    herbivore.hungry = false
}
</code></pre>

<p>And here is the fixed version:</p>

<pre><code>func (herbivore *Mouse) eatingGrass() {
    fmt.Println(herbivore.name + "'s eating a grass.. ^___^")
    herbivore.hungry = false
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you want better explanation for this - then visit
<a href="https://www.writeingo.com/blog/method-receiver-types-in-go/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">my blog post</a></p>

<p>The last thing - as best practice - if you used Struct pointer in one of the methods of your
type then all of them should take a pointer to it.</p>

<p>Final solution:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

type Predator interface {
    eatingVictim(victim Animal)
}

type Herbivore interface {
    eatingGrass()
}

type Animal interface {
    GetName() string
    SetAlive(bool)
}

type Cat struct {
    name   string
    hungry bool
    alive  bool
}

type Mouse struct {
    name   string
    hungry bool
    alive  bool
}

func (herbivore *Mouse) eatingGrass() {
    fmt.Println(herbivore.name + "'s eating a grass.. ^___^")
    herbivore.hungry = false
}

func (m *Mouse) GetName() string {
    return m.name
}

func (m *Mouse) SetAlive(alive bool) {
    m.alive = alive
}

func (predator *Cat) eatingVictim(victim Animal) {
    fmt.Println(predator.name + "'s eating victim " + victim.GetName())
    predator.hungry = false
    victim.SetAlive(false)
}

func main() {
    cat := Cat{"cat", true, true}
    mouse := Mouse{"mouse", true, true}

    fmt.Println(cat)
    fmt.Println(mouse)

    mouse.eatingGrass()
    cat.eatingVictim(&amp;mouse)

    fmt.Println(cat)
    fmt.Println(mouse)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8307258" LastEditorUserId="8307258" LastEditDate="2017-08-05T09:11:02.427" LastActivityDate="2017-08-05T09:11:02.427" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45520813      <row Id="45520813" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45521249" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45520813" CreationDate="2017-08-05T11:12:45.693" Score="2" Body="<p>The MySQL client-server protocol returns the value of <code>LAST_INSERT_ID()</code> in response packets to queries performing an <code>INSERT</code> operation. Generally the client APIs give that back to client code using methods like <code>sql.Result.LastInsertId()</code> in the SQL API. No round-trip query is required.</p>

<p>So the answer to your question is "the first INSERT."</p>

<p>To be clear, MySQL connections aren't thread safe in the broad sense. Instead, they are serially reusable resources. Multi-threaded client environments make them appear thread-safe by managing the serial reuse. You have described how that works for <code>golang</code> in your question.</p>
" OwnerUserId="205608" LastEditorUserId="205608" LastEditDate="2017-08-05T11:22:08.507" LastActivityDate="2017-08-05T11:22:08.507" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45519075      <row Id="45519075" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45523001" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45519075" CreationDate="2017-08-05T14:27:04.480" Score="1" Body="<p>Don't use Curl if you are not using HTTP protocol. Curl is expecting certain format of the message that is compatible with HTTP protocol.
If you send text "true", that is for sure not valid HTTP Header.</p>

<p>To test TCP server use Netcat instead:</p>

<pre><code>nc localhost port
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8307258" LastActivityDate="2017-08-05T14:27:04.480" CommentCount="0" />

question:
44764400      <row Id="44764400" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45524409" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44764400" CreationDate="2017-08-05T17:02:17.717" Score="0" Body="<p>This issue could be solved by configuring the host machine mount to be private which <em>does not receive or forward any propagation events to other mounts</em>, vide  <a href="https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/6/html/Storage_Administration_Guide/sect-Using_the_mount_Command-Mounting-Bind.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">RedHat - Sharing Mounts</a>.</p>

<p>This command should be executed on your host machine before your create the container:</p>

<pre><code>$ mount --make-rprivate /
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1253306" LastActivityDate="2017-08-05T17:02:17.717" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45525332      <row Id="45525332" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45525909" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45525332" CreationDate="2017-08-05T20:01:45.480" Score="6" Body="<p>The echo context exposes the HTTP request, which has a context tied to the server request already.  Just get that context, and check it for cancellation, and/or pass it along to methods that take a context.</p>

<pre><code>ctx := c.Request().Context()
select {
case &lt;-ctx.Done():
    return ctx.Err()
default:
    // Continue handling the request
}

// and pass along to the db or whatever else:
rows, err := db.QueryContext(ctx, ...)
</code></pre>

<p>If the client aborts the connection, the Request-scoped context will automatically be cancelled.</p>

<p>If you want to add your own cancellation conditions, (timeouts, or whatever) you can do that, too:</p>

<pre><code>req := c.Request()
ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(req.Context())
req.WithContext(ctx)
defer cancel()
// do stuff, which may conditionally call cancel() to cancel the context early
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastEditorUserId="13860" LastEditDate="2017-08-07T09:11:16.357" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T09:11:16.357" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45526926      <row Id="45526926" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45527050" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45526926" CreationDate="2017-08-05T22:54:12.387" Score="12" Body="<p>Yes. From the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Assignments" rel="noreferrer">language spec</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The assignment proceeds in two phases. First, the operands of index expressions and pointer indirections (including implicit pointer indirections in selectors) on the left and the expressions on the right are all evaluated in the usual order. Second, the assignments are carried out in left-to-right order.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So in your example, <code>child</code> and <code>child.child</code> will be evaluated first, then assigned to <code>parent</code> and <code>child</code> respectively. </p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastEditorUserId="13860" LastEditDate="2017-08-06T17:07:41.697" LastActivityDate="2017-08-06T17:07:41.697" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45525539      <row Id="45525539" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45527603" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45525539" CreationDate="2017-08-06T00:41:25.047" Score="1" Body="<p>There is a bug in <a href="https://github.com/fragmenta/query" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>https://github.com/fragmenta/query</code></a>. The <code>TimeString</code> method in <code>query/adapters/database.go</code> is not valid for all DBMS adapters.</p>

<pre><code>// TimeString - given a time, return the standard string representation
func (db *Adapter) TimeString(t time.Time) string {
    return t.Format("2006-01-02 15:04:05.000 -0700")
}
</code></pre>

<p>It's not valid for a MySQL timestamp: <a href="https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/datetime.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">MySQL 5.7 Reference Manual, 11.3.1 The DATE, DATETIME, and TIMESTAMP Types</a>. The MySQL <code>TimeString</code> method in <code>query/adapters/database_mysql.go</code> should be:</p>

<pre><code>// TimeString - given a time, return the MySQL standard string representation
func (db *MysqlAdapter) TimeString(t time.Time) string {
    return t.Format("2006-01-02 15:04:05.999999")
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-08-06T04:31:18.477" LastActivityDate="2017-08-06T04:31:18.477" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45526476      <row Id="45526476" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45527888" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45526476" CreationDate="2017-08-06T01:50:06.737" Score="6" Body="<p>As stated in the comments, problem here is once your interface has this signature:</p>

<pre><code>type Greeter interface {
    Greet() Greeting
}
</code></pre>

<p>The any valid implementation must use exactly <code>Greeting</code> as the return type.</p>

<p>But, as the documentation shows, you don't need to give the interface a name:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Interface_types" rel="noreferrer">https://golang.org/ref/spec#Interface_types</a></p>

<p>In order to be able to implement what you need, you might declare the interface directly in the return value, without giving it a name.</p>

<pre><code>// Greeter greets with anything that has a String() method
type Greeter interface {
    Greet() interface{ String() string }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then your <code>Greet()</code> function for <code>Hello</code> can do this:</p>

<pre><code>// Hello greets by returning itself...
func (h *Hello) Greet() interface{ String() string } {
   return h
}
</code></pre>

<p>Find here a modified playground showing the working example:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/HteA_9jFd4" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/HteA_9jFd4</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-06T01:50:06.737" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45534941      <row Id="45534941" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45535827" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45534941" CreationDate="2017-08-06T19:31:18.633" Score="1" Body="<p>If you look at the source code for the method <a href="https://github.com/golang/text/blob/master/language/language.go#L452" rel="nofollow noreferrer">tag{}.Region()</a> you'll see that if region is not specified it tries to add tags and sets the likelihood to low. <a href="https://github.com/golang/text/blob/2bf8f2a19ec09c670e931282edfe6567f6be21c9/language/match.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">addTags()</a> If you look at the implementation for addTags() you'll see</p>

<pre><code>if t.lang == 0 {
  t.lang = _en // default language
}
</code></pre>

<p>where the default language is set to English. Cheers.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4639336" LastEditorUserId="4639336" LastEditDate="2017-08-06T19:45:36.117" LastActivityDate="2017-08-06T19:45:36.117" CommentCount="0" />
