question:
45536166      <row Id="45536166" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45541753" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45536166" CreationDate="2017-08-07T07:45:18.037" Score="4" Body="<p>It's called reverse proxy. Each application uses it's own port to listen. And then you just point to them in nginx config:</p>

<pre><code>server {
    listen 80;
    server_name turalasgar.pro;
    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8080;
        ...
    }
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name engossip.com;
    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8081;
        ...
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5040388" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T07:45:18.037" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45541656      <row Id="45541656" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45541764" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45541656" CreationDate="2017-08-07T07:45:48.393" Score="2" Body="<p><code>os.Open</code> will open a file, since the file doesn't exist you will get an error.
Use <code>os.Create</code> instead it will create a new file and open it. (ref: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/os/#Open" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/os/#Open</a>)</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><strong>func Open</strong></p>
  
  <p><code>func Open(name string) (*File, error)</code> </p>
  
  <p>Open opens the named file for
  reading. If successful, methods on the returned file can be used for
  reading; the associated file descriptor has mode O_RDONLY. If there is
  an error, it will be of type *PathError.</p>
  
  <p><strong>func Create</strong></p>
  
  <p><code>func Create(name string) (*File, error)</code></p>
  
  <p>Create creates the named file with mode 0666 (before umask),
  truncating it if it already exists. If successful, methods on the
  returned File can be used for I/O; the associated file descriptor has
  mode O_RDWR. If there is an error, it will be of type *PathError.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><strong>EDIT</strong></p>

<p>Made a new handler as an example:
And also using OpenFile as mentioned by: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45541656/golang-send-file-via-post-request/45541764?noredirect=1#comment78043634_45541764">GoLang send file via POST request</a></p>

<pre><code>func Upload(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    io.WriteString(w, "Upload files\n")

    file, handler, err := r.FormFile("file")
    if err != nil {
        panic(err) //dont do this
    }
    defer file.Close()

    // copy example
    f, err := os.OpenFile(handler.Filename, os.O_WRONLY|os.O_CREATE, 0666)
    if err != nil {
        panic(err) //please dont
    }
    defer f.Close()
    io.Copy(f, file)

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8405576" LastEditorUserId="8405576" LastEditDate="2017-08-07T08:33:20.230" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T08:33:20.230" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45537444      <row Id="45537444" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45542325" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45537444" CreationDate="2017-08-07T08:18:12.737" Score="1" Body="<p>Writing unit tests is relatively easy. <strong>Writing good unit tests is hard</strong>. This isn't helped because we are introduced to unit testing with trivial code examples that don't mimic real life usage.</p>

<p>Try to avoid mocking unless you need to verify the invocations of a dependency. Prefer using stubs, fakes or real implementations. Knowing when to use each is a matter of experience and where the difficulty comes in. Also, think about your design. If you are finding it difficult to unit test, this could be because you need to redesign.</p>

<p>Unit tests take time to write and maintain. You will always be quicker writing code without unit tests. However, we write unit tests to give us some assurance that our code works correctly and confidence to re-factor. </p>

<p>Hence it's important to try to write the test against the behaviour (black box) instead of the implementation (white-box). This isn't always possible but unit tests that are tied to the implementation are fragile, discourage refactoring and can also sometimes mask unexpected behaviour.</p>

<p>Some unit testing resources worth reading:</p>

<ol>
<li><a href="https://martinfowler.com/articles/mocksArentStubs.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Mocks Aren't Stubs</a></li>
<li><a href="https://testing.googleblog.com/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Testing on the Toilet Blog</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.infoq.com/presentations/tdd-original" rel="nofollow noreferrer">TDD - Where it all went wrong</a></li>
</ol>

<p>As way as an example, think of writing a unit test for a simple email address validator. We want to write a function that will take a string and return true/false based on whether a valid email address was supplied.</p>

<p>A trivial example implementation would be:</p>

<pre><code>var re = regexp.MustCompile("[regular expression]")
func ValidateEmail(s string) bool {
   return re.MatchString(s)
}
</code></pre>

<p>We would then write a table driven test with the various inputs, e.g. <code>""</code>, <code>good@example.com</code>, <code>bad</code> etc and verify the result was correct.</p>

<p>Now this is a bit of a trivial example but illustrates my point. One may argue that this is easy because the function has no dependencies but it does! We are relying on the regexp implementation and the regular expression we are passing it.</p>

<p>This is testing the desired behaviour, not how we implement it. We don't care how it validates an email address, simply that it does. If we were to tweak the regular expression or completely change the implementation then none of this would <em>break</em> the tests unless the result was incorrect.</p>

<p>Very few would suggest that we should isolate the dependency and test the validation function by mocking the regexp and ensuring that it is called with the regular expression we expect. This would be far more fragile but also less useful, i.e. how would we know the regular expression is actually going to work?</p>

<hr>

<p>For your specific example, you could easily avoid mocking &amp; use a trivial fake to test both normal results and the error cases. This would be something like:</p>

<pre><code>// Used to test error result, 
var errFail = errors.New("Failed")

// Fake type
type fakeD func(input int) (int, error)

// Implements Dinterface
func (f fakeD) DoSomethingWithD(input int) (int, error) {
    return f(input)
}

// Fake implementation. Returns error on input 5, otherwise input * input
var fake fakeD = func(input int) (int, error) {
    if input == 5 {
        return nil, errFail
    }
    return input * input, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Then simply use <code>fake</code> as your dependency and run your table based tests as normal. </p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T08:18:12.737" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45544133      <row Id="45544133" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45544387" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45544133" CreationDate="2017-08-07T10:08:11.387" Score="1" Body="<p>How about only starting e.g. 10 goroutines and pass the values in from one for loop in another go routine. The channels have a small buffer to decrease synchronisation time.</p>

<pre><code>chIn := make(chan label.Label, 20)
chOut := make(chan label.Label, 20)

for i:=0;i&lt;10;i++ {
    go func(gClient *gmail.Client, chIn chan label.Label, chOut chan&lt;- label.Label) {

        for gmailLabels := range chIn {
            d, err := s.gClient.Service.Users.Labels.Get(s.gClient.User, l.Id).Do()

            if err != nil {
                panic(err)
            }

            // Performs some operation with the label `d`
            preparedLabel := ....

            chOut &lt;- preparedLabel

        }

    }(s.gClient, chIn, chOut)

}

go func(chIn chan label.Label) {
    defer close(chIn)
    for _, l := range r.Labels {
        chIn &lt;- l
    }
}(chIn)

for i := 0; i &lt; len(r.Labels); i++ {
    lab := &lt;-chOut
    fmt.Printf("Processed %v\n", lab.LabelID)
}
</code></pre>

<p>EDIT:</p>

<p>Here a <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/R4b296QOrk" rel="nofollow noreferrer">playground sample</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastEditorUserId="6220193" LastEditDate="2017-08-07T10:44:40.237" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T10:44:40.237" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45547169      <row Id="45547169" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45547634" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45547169" CreationDate="2017-08-07T13:04:26.837" Score="1" Body="<p>What exactly is your target type supposed to be? It can't be a struct since you do not know the fields beforehand.</p>

<p>The only fitting type to me seems to be a <code>map</code> of type <code>map[string]interface{}</code>: with it any nested structure can be achieved:</p>

<pre><code>a := map[string]interface{}{
    "item.field1": "val1",
    "item.field2": "val2",
    "item.fieldN": "valN",
    "custom_fields": map[string]interface{}{
        "fields.field1": "cval1",
        "fields.field2": "cval2",
    },
}
b, err := json.Marshal(a)
</code></pre>

<p>See playground sample <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/kw_OZWTMGS" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>.</p>

<p>Filling this structure from a database as you hinted at should probably be a custom script (not using json).</p>

<p>Note: <code>custom_fields</code> can also be of other types depending on what type the value column is in the database. If the value column is a string use <code>map[string]string</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T13:04:26.837" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45526086      <row Id="45526086" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45547741" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45526086" CreationDate="2017-08-07T13:10:03.910" Score="0" Body="<p>With the help of several commenters, I know have it all figured out.</p>

<p>The Linux version is as follows:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    bytes
    encoding/binary
    fmt
    os
    os/exec
    syscall
)

// parses through the /proc/bus/input/devices file for keyboard devices.
// Copied from `github.com/gearmover/keylogger` with trivial modification.
func dumpDevices() ([]string, error) {
    cmd := exec.Command(/bin/sh, -c, /bin/grep -E Handlers|EV= /proc/bus/input/devices | /bin/grep -B1 EV=120013 | /bin/grep -Eo event[0-9]+)

    output, err := cmd.Output()
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }

    buf := bytes.NewBuffer(output)

    var devices []string

    for line, err := buf.ReadString(\n); err == nil; {
        devices = append(devices, /dev/input/+line[:len(line)-1])

        line, err = buf.ReadString(\n)
    }

    return devices, nil
}

// Using MS names, just because I dont feel like looking up the Linux versions.
var keys = map[uint16]string{
    0xa3: VK_MEDIA_NEXT_TRACK,
    0xa5: VK_MEDIA_PREV_TRACK,
    0xa6: VK_MEDIA_STOP,
    0xa4: VK_MEDIA_PLAY_PAUSE,
}

// Most of the code here comes from `github.com/gearmover/keylogger`.
func main() {
    // drop privileges when executing other programs
    syscall.Setgid(65534)
    syscall.Setuid(65534)

    // dump our keyboard devices from /proc/bus/input/devices
    devices, err := dumpDevices()
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
    }
    if len(devices) == 0 {
        fmt.Println(No input devices found)
        return
    }

    // bring back our root privs
    syscall.Setgid(0)
    syscall.Setuid(0)

    // Open the first keyboard device.
    input, err := os.OpenFile(devices[0], os.O_RDONLY, 0600)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }
    defer input.Close()

    // Log media keys
    var buffer = make([]byte, 24)
    for {
        // read the input events as they come in
        n, err := input.Read(buffer)
        if err != nil {
            return
        }

        if n != 24 {
            fmt.Println(Weird Input Event Size: , n)
            continue
        }

        // parse the input event according to the &lt;linux/input.h&gt; header struct
        binary.LittleEndian.Uint64(buffer[0:8]) // Time stamp stuff I could care less about
        binary.LittleEndian.Uint64(buffer[8:16])
        etype := binary.LittleEndian.Uint16(buffer[16:18])        // Event Type. Always 1 for keyboard events
        code := binary.LittleEndian.Uint16(buffer[18:20])         // Key scan code
        value := int32(binary.LittleEndian.Uint32(buffer[20:24])) // press(1), release(0), or repeat(2)

        if etype == 1 &amp;&amp; value == 1 &amp;&amp; keys[code] !=  {
            // In a real application I would send a message here.
            fmt.Println(keys[code])
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>And the Windows version:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    fmt
    syscall
    time
)

var user32 = syscall.NewLazyDLL(user32.dll)
var procGAKS = user32.NewProc(GetAsyncKeyState)

// Key codes from MSDN
var keys = [4]uint{
    0xb0, // VK_MEDIA_NEXT_TRACK
    0xb1, // VK_MEDIA_PREV_TRACK
    0xb2, // VK_MEDIA_STOP
    0xb3, // VK_MEDIA_PLAY_PAUSE
}

var names = [4]string{
    VK_MEDIA_NEXT_TRACK,
    VK_MEDIA_PREV_TRACK,
    VK_MEDIA_STOP,
    VK_MEDIA_PLAY_PAUSE,
}

func main() {
    fmt.Println(Running)

    // Since I dont want to trigger dozens of times for each key I need to track state.
    // I could check the bits of GAKS return value, but that is not reliable.
    down := [4]bool{false, false, false, false}

    for {
        time.Sleep(1 * time.Millisecond)
        for i, key := range keys {
            // val is not a simple boolean!
            // 0 means not pressed (also certain errors)
            // If LSB is set the key was just pressed (this may not be reliable)
            // If MSB is set the key is currently down.
            val, _, _ := procGAKS.Call(uintptr(key))

            // Turn a press into a transition and track key state.
            goingdown := false
            if int(val) != 0 &amp;&amp; !down[i] {
                goingdown = true
                down[i] = true
            }
            if int(val) == 0 &amp;&amp; down[i] {
                down[i] = false
            }
            if goingdown {
                // In a real application I would send a message here.
                fmt.Println(names[i])
            }
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>The only "issue" is that the Linux version must be run as root. For me this is not a problem. If running as root is a problem I think there is a way that involves X11...</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastEditorUserId="1094529" LastEditDate="2017-08-07T13:22:20.510" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T13:22:20.510" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45549682      <row Id="45549682" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45551937" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45549682" CreationDate="2017-08-07T16:47:59.453" Score="2" Body="<p>I decided to add an answer showing a type assertion instead of the <code>reflect</code> package. You can decide which is best for your application. I personally prefer the builtin functions over the complexity of the <code>reflect</code> package.</p>

<pre><code>var data = `
array:
  - name: myvar
    val: 1
  - name: mymap
    val: [1, 2]
`

type Data struct {
    Array []struct {
        Name string
        Val  interface{}
    }
}

func main() {
    d := Data{}
    err := yaml.Unmarshal([]byte(data), &amp;d)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    for i := range d.Array {
        switch val := d.Array[i].(type) {
        case int:
            fmt.Println(val) // is integer
        case []int:
            fmt.Println(val) // is []int
        case []string:
            fmt.Println(val) // is []string
            //  .... you get the idea
        default:
            log.Fatalf("Type unaccounted for: %+v\n", d.Array[i])
        }
    }

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastEditorUserId="1276480" LastEditDate="2017-08-07T20:50:12.080" LastActivityDate="2017-08-07T20:50:12.080" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45558049      <row Id="45558049" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45558262" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45558049" CreationDate="2017-08-08T02:12:29.933" Score="2" Body="<p>you can use httputil's <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/httputil/#ReverseProxy" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ReverseProxy</a></p>

<p>here's an example code</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "log"
    "net/http"
    "net/http/httputil"
)

func main() {
    director := func(req *http.Request) {
        switch req.Host {
        case "address001.com":
            req.URL.Host = "localhost:4444"
            req.URL.Scheme = "http"
        case "address002.com":
            req.URL.Host = "localhost:5555"
            req.URL.Scheme = "http"
        default:
            log.Println("error")
        }
    }
    proxy := &amp;httputil.ReverseProxy{Director: director}
    log.Fatalln(http.ListenAndServe(":8080", proxy))
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2427222" LastActivityDate="2017-08-08T02:12:29.933" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45563495      <row Id="45563495" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45563919" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45563495" CreationDate="2017-08-08T09:01:04.380" Score="0" Body="<p>Your question is very unspecific and you do not show us what you have done so far.</p>

<p>Since I don't know where your actual problem lies I will just post my <code>WriteRecord</code> function I wrote a while back when testing cassandra with the gocql package:</p>

<pre><code>func (cs *cassandra) WriteRecord(table string, fields []string, values ...interface{}) error {
    var placeholder []string

    for range fields {
        placeholder = append(placeholder, "?")
    }
    querystring := fmt.Sprintf(insertstring, table, strings.Join(fields, ", "), strings.Join(placeholder, ", "))
    return cassandraSession.Query(querystring, values...).Exec()
}
</code></pre>

<p>As you can see the values are of type <code>interface{}</code>. So they can be anything including of type <code>[]byte</code>. Note that the following condition must be met: <code>len(fields) = len(values)</code></p>

<p>I hope this helps you on your journey of becoming a <code>golang</code> expert :)</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-08T09:01:04.380" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45570947      <row Id="45570947" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45571006" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45570947" CreationDate="2017-08-08T14:25:21.430" Score="7" Body="<p>Simplest way would be to just iterate the map, since in Go the syntax would allow direct access to keys and values and dump them into the array.</p>

<pre><code>m := map[string]string { "1":"a", "2":"b" }
arr := []string{}
for k, v := range m { 
   arr = append(arr, k, v)
}
</code></pre>

<p>One caveat here: In Go, map iteration order is randomized, as you can see here, under "Iteration Order":</p>

<p><a href="https://blog.golang.org/go-maps-in-action" rel="noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/go-maps-in-action</a></p>

<p>So if you want your resulting array to have a particular ordering, you should first dump the keys and order (as shown in that same blog entry).</p>

<p>Playground (without the sorting part):</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/mCe6eEy25A" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/mCe6eEy25A</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="4907630" LastEditDate="2017-08-08T14:31:42.877" LastActivityDate="2017-08-08T14:31:42.877" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45573392      <row Id="45573392" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="45573469" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45573392" CreationDate="2017-08-08T16:24:19.497" Score="2" Body="<p>You use <code>$$</code> which is exactly what the documentation tells you. </p>

<p>The godoc section for <code>ReplaceAll</code> (<a href="https://godoc.org/regexp#Regexp.ReplaceAll" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://godoc.org/regexp#Regexp.ReplaceAll</a>) tells you:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>$ signs are interpreted as in Expand</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So reading the section for <code>Expand</code> has the answer. <a href="https://godoc.org/regexp#Regexp.Expand" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://godoc.org/regexp#Regexp.Expand</a></p>

<p>Please throughly read all relevant documentation for the package and functions you are using before posting a question.</p>

question:
45571628      <row Id="45571628" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45573993" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45571628" CreationDate="2017-08-08T16:55:48.307" Score="2" Body="<p>The reason is because you have created synchronous channel and you push here 1 message and then you could read it only once as well. That is because you get only 1 (random) read from <code>done</code> channel.</p>

<p>The way you can shut down your goroutines is to use <code>WaitGroup</code>:<br>
main.go:  </p>

<pre><code>var (
    done            chan bool
)

func main() {
    cameras := client.CameraConfig()
    client.DrawUserControls(cameras)
    operator := client.NewOperator(cameras)

    done = make(chan bool, 1)
    wg := &amp;sync.WaitGroup{}
    wg.Add(2)
    go operator.UserInputListener(done, wg)
    go operator.ParseAndExecuteUserCommand(done, wg)

    handleShutdown()
    wg.Wait()
}


func handleShutdown() {
    ch := make(chan os.Signal, 1)
    go func() {
        &lt;-ch //wait for application terminating
        log.Println("Shutdown received.")
        close(done)
    }()
    signal.Notify(ch, os.Interrupt, syscall.SIGTERM, syscall.SIGHUP)
}
</code></pre>

<p>client.go:  </p>

<pre><code>func (o *Operator) UserInputListener(done &lt;-chan bool, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
    defer wg.Done()
    for {
        select {
        case &lt;-done:
            log.Println("Keyboard listener shutting down.") 
            return
        ........
        }
    }
}

func (o *Operator) ParseAndExecuteUserCommand(done &lt;-chan bool, wg *sync.WaitGroup) {
    defer wg.Done()
    for {
        select {
        case &lt;-done:
            log.Println("Command operator shutting down.") 
            return
        ........
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Use this <a href="http://www.hydrogen18.com/blog/stopping-it-all-in-go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer" title="link">link</a> for details</p>
" OwnerUserId="2706190" LastActivityDate="2017-08-08T16:55:48.307" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45575942      <row Id="45575942" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45578319" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45575942" CreationDate="2017-08-08T21:28:03.200" Score="1" Body="<p>For testing purposes, I tend to use the mocking approach you described instead of creating new interfaces. One of the reasons being, AFAIK, there are <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31759184/golang-documentation-on-all-known-implementation-of-interfaces">no direct ways to identify which structs implement an interface</a>, which is important to me if I wanted to know whether the mocks are doing the right thing.</p>

<p>The main drawback of this approach is that the variable is essentially a package-level global variable (even though it's unexported). So all the drawbacks with declaring global variables apply.</p>

<p>In your tests, you will definitely want to use <code>defer</code> to re-assign <code>storeFunc</code> back to its original concrete implementation once the tests completed. </p>

<pre><code>var storeFunc = func *Store {
    // concrete implementation for opening store
}

// and in the testing file
func TestParse(t *testing.T) {
    storeFuncOriginal := storeFunc
    defer func() {
        storeFunc = storeFuncOriginal
    }()

    storeFunc := func() {
        // set contents of mock
    } 

    parse()

    // etc...
}
</code></pre>

<p>By the way, <code>var storeFunc = func openStore() *Store</code> won't compile.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1144203" LastActivityDate="2017-08-08T21:28:03.200" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45578172      <row Id="45578172" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45579190" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45578172" CreationDate="2017-08-08T22:52:33.443" Score="2" Body="<p>Pay attention to details and efficiency. Check for errors. You asked for files so skip directories and other things. Allow for multiple files with the same modified time stamp (for example, Windows file times have a resolution of, at best, 100-nanoseconds). You already have ModTime() so don't call os.Stat(). Use time.Time methods directly. And so on.</p>

<p>For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "io/ioutil"
    "os"
    "time"
)

func main() {
    dir := `C:\temp\` // Windows directory
    files, err := ioutil.ReadDir(dir)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Fprintln(os.Stderr, err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
    var modTime time.Time
    var names []string
    for _, fi := range files {
        if fi.Mode().IsRegular() {
            if !fi.ModTime().Before(modTime) {
                if fi.ModTime().After(modTime) {
                    modTime = fi.ModTime()
                    names = names[:0]
                }
                names = append(names, fi.Name())
            }
        }
    }
    if len(names) &gt; 0 {
        fmt.Println(modTime, names)
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastActivityDate="2017-08-08T22:52:33.443" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45580151      <row Id="45580151" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45580232" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45580151" CreationDate="2017-08-09T01:18:39.840" Score="6" Body="<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec" rel="noreferrer">The Go Programming Language Specification</a></p>
  
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Select_statements" rel="noreferrer">Select statements</a></p>
  
  <p>Execution of a "select" statement proceeds in several steps:</p>
  
  <ol>
  <li>For all the cases in the statement, the channel operands of receive operations and the channel and right-hand-side expressions of send
  statements are evaluated exactly once, in source order, upon entering
  the "select" statement. The result is a set of channels to receive
  from or send to, and the corresponding values to send. Any side
  effects in that evaluation will occur irrespective of which (if any)
  communication operation is selected to proceed. Expressions on the
  left-hand side of a RecvStmt with a short variable declaration or
  assignment are not yet evaluated.</li>
  <li>If one or more of the communications can proceed, a single one that can proceed is chosen via a uniform pseudo-random selection.
  Otherwise, if there is a default case, that case is chosen. If there
  is no default case, the "select" statement blocks until at least one
  of the communications can proceed.</li>
  <li>Unless the selected case is the default case, the respective communication operation is executed.</li>
  <li>If the selected case is a RecvStmt with a short variable declaration or an assignment, the left-hand side expressions are
  evaluated and the received value (or values) are assigned.</li>
  <li>The statement list of the selected case is executed.</li>
  </ol>
</blockquote>

<hr>

<blockquote>
  <p>"What I'm most concerned about is that the branch of a select that is
  chosen could be non-deterministic, so that default may be chosen even
  if one of the cases is ready. Is this possible?"</p>
</blockquote>

<p>No. See step 2 of the <code>select</code> specification.</p>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-08-09T01:24:05.403" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T01:24:05.403" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45582678      <row Id="45582678" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45583982" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45582678" CreationDate="2017-08-09T07:16:26.847" Score="1" Body="<p>The <code>&lt;nil&gt;</code> pinted above is the output of <code>session.Run</code>, which returns an <code>error</code> (as per <a href="https://godoc.org/golang.org/x/crypto/ssh#Session.Run" rel="nofollow noreferrer">docs</a>).</p>

<p>The output of the command is already being displayed on your console by the following goroutine:</p>

<pre><code>go io.Copy(os.Stdout, stdout)
</code></pre>

<p>You don't need to print the <code>output</code>, which is <code>nil</code> since no error occurs when <code>session.Run</code> is call complete. A better thing to do would be to check the error:</p>

<pre><code>// ...
if err := session.Run(input); err != nil {
  // handle error
}
// ...
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3129778" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T07:16:26.847" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45583641      <row Id="45583641" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...

answer:
<row Id="45584340" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45583641" CreationDate="2017-08-09T07:35:34.523" Score="2" Body="<p><code>go run</code> is getting the signal, not the program that is being run.</p>

<p>Compile the program ahead of time and run the binary directly in docker, and it will work as expected.</p>

question:
45586944      <row Id="45586944" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45587010" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45586944" CreationDate="2017-08-09T09:40:12.997" Score="6" Body="<p>You could just use</p>

<pre><code>if strings.HasSuffix(strings.ToLower(s), "suffix") {
    // do something 
}
</code></pre>

<p>You can also write your own wrapper function:</p>

<pre><code>func hasSuffix(s, suffix string, caseSensitive bool) bool {
    if caseSensitive {
        return strings.HasSuffix(s, suffix)
    }
    return strings.HasSuffix(strings.ToLower(s), suffix)
}
</code></pre>

<p>For file names or paths you can use (see answer of PeterSO):</p>

<pre><code>if strings.ToLower(filepath.Ext(s)) == ".fileending" {
    // do something
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastEditorUserId="6220193" LastEditDate="2017-08-09T11:09:24.117" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T11:09:24.117" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45592817      <row Id="45592817" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45592870" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45592817" CreationDate="2017-08-09T13:59:13.370" Score="7" Body="<p>The parameters that specify a length (e.g. <code>[SharedKeyBytes]byte</code>) are arrays, not slices; therefor, you cannot pass a slice, hence the type mismatch error. You can either:</p>

<ul>
<li>Change the parameter type to slice (<code>[]byte</code>)</li>
<li>Copy the slice to an appropriately-sized array prior to calling the function, then pass the array to the function instead of the slice (<a href="https://play.golang.org/p/KEr23NVvUo" rel="noreferrer">playground example</a>)</li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-08-09T14:09:59.413" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T14:09:59.413" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45585013      <row Id="45585013" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45593476" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45585013" CreationDate="2017-08-09T14:25:48.813" Score="1" Body="<p>User Magik6k answered my question in <a href="https://discuss.ipfs.io/t/error-command-not-found-when-im-using-go-ipfs-api/916" rel="nofollow noreferrer">another forum</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>You can't use the public IPFS gateway to add content. For this you
  need locally running daemon and pass it's API endpoint to NewShell
  (localhost:5001 by default).</p>
  
  <p>Public gateways(ipfs.io, localhost:8080) only support a limited API
  subset, see
  <a href="https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/blob/master/core/commands/root.go#L1412" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/blob/master/core/commands/root.go#L1412</a>
  for what is available</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="3440266" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T14:25:48.813" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45594286      <row Id="45594286" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45594384" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45594286" CreationDate="2017-08-09T15:06:55.517" Score="6" Body="<p>If you use the <a href="https://www.gnu.org/software/gdb/" rel="noreferrer">gdb</a> debugger to debug your program, loading that script improves its features for working with Go programs, such as being able to look at the values inside of maps and slices (instead of seeing them as opaque pointers) and being able to list and inspect goroutines (instead of native threads). gdb uses Python for extensions.</p>
" OwnerUserId="152948" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T15:06:55.517" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45567710      <row Id="45567710" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45597204" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45567710" CreationDate="2017-08-09T17:33:49.927" Score="0" Body="<p>When we look up <a href="https://github.com/golang/exp/blob/master/shiny/widget/widget.go#L56-L58" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a> we see that <code>widget.RunWindow( ... )</code> doesn't handle such external requests from the caller.</p>

<p>A workaraound could be to implement an analogous function <code>MyRunWindow( ... )</code> and assign the <code>Window</code> to an global Interface. Like this:</p>

<pre><code>func MyRunWindow(s screen.Screen, root node.Node, opts *RunWindowOptions) (err error) {
    var nwo *screen.NewWindowOptions

    // ... assign window options ...

    if MyWindow, err = s.NewWindow(nwo); err != nil {
        return err
    }

    // event loop, processing 'lifecycle.Event', 'input.Event', etc.
    // and you can process own 'Events' in a type switch
    for {
        e := MyWindow.NextEvent()

        if e = gef.Filter(e); e == nil {
            continue
        }

        switch e := e.(type) {
        case MyEvent:
        // ... call on 'root' here
        }
    }
</code></pre>

<p>On the caller side you can use your global <code>Interface</code> like this:</p>

<pre><code>MyWindow.Send(paint.Event{}) // for a needed call to root.Paint()
MyWindow.Send(MyEvent{})     // for your own event to be processed
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4831421" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T17:33:49.927" CommentCount="0" />

question:
24770235      <row Id="24770235" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45599165" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="24770235" CreationDate="2017-08-09T19:30:14.170" Score="1" Body="<p>I developed a library which can help you in this regard: <a href="https://github.com/liip/sheriff" rel="nofollow noreferrer" title="Sheriff">Sheriff</a></p>

<p>You can annotate your struct fields with special tags and call Sheriff to transform the given struct into a subset of it. After that you can call <code>json.Marshal()</code> or whatever else you want to marshal into.</p>

<p>Your example would become as simple as:</p>

<pre class="lang-golang prettyprint-override"><code>type Community struct {
    Name          string      `json:"name" groups:"trending,detail"`
    Description   string      `json:"description" groups:"trending,detail"`
    Sources       []Source    `json:"sources" groups:"detail"`
    Popularity    int         `json:"popularity" groups:"trending,detail"`
    FavoriteCount int         `json:"favorite_count" groups:"trending,detail"`
    Moderators    []string    `json:"moderators" groups:"detail"`
    Children      []Community `json:"children" groups:"detail"`
    Tracks        []Track     `json:"tracks" groups:"detail"`
}

communities := []Community{
    // communities
}

o := sheriff.Options{
    Groups: []string{"trending"},
}

d, err := sheriff.Marshal(&amp;o, communities)
if err != nil {
    panic(err)
}

out, _ := json.Marshal(d)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="315242" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T19:30:14.170" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45592701      <row Id="45592701" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45599437" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45592701" CreationDate="2017-08-09T19:47:15.213" Score="1" Body="<p>In go a framework cannot really limit you. Let's take the example of the martini framework.</p>

<p>Here the first sample from their github page:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "github.com/go-martini/martini"

func main() {
    m := martini.Classic()
    m.Get("/", func() string {
        return "Hello world!"
    })
    m.Run()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Before executing <code>m.Run()</code> you can start whatever cli job you want. All you have to do is start it in another goroutine:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "github.com/go-martini/martini"

func main() {
    // start some function doing background stuff
    go someCliFunc()        

    // initiate a struct and start a job in the background
    go func(){
        cli := MyPackage.SomeCli{}
        cli.Start()
    }()

    m := martini.Classic()
    m.Get("/", func() string {
        return "Hello world!"
    })
    m.Run()
}
</code></pre>

<p>The function actually doing the background stuff could have a structure like this:</p>

<pre><code>func someCliFunc() {
    // do some initial stuff

    defer func() {
        // do some stuff on exit
    }()

    // start the loop
    for {
        // do stuff regularly

        // make sure the loop does not use the entire cpu
        time.Sleep(5*time.Second)
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T19:47:15.213" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45599637      <row Id="45599637" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45599707" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45599637" CreationDate="2017-08-09T20:04:42.343" Score="3" Body="<p>Use escape sequences preceded by <code>\</code> to show literal special characters in a formatted string <code>\\</code> for <code>\</code> and <code>\"</code> for <code>"</code></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

func main() {
    x := "hello"
    q := fmt.Sprintf("\\\"%s\"\\", x)
    fmt.Println(q)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2790047" LastEditorUserId="2790047" LastEditDate="2017-08-09T20:06:24.433" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T20:06:24.433" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45596651      <row Id="45596651" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45600231" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45596651" CreationDate="2017-08-09T20:37:34.440" Score="0" Body="<p>This is considered the cornerstone (or more of a limitation) of Go's type system. <code>struct{}</code> is an unnamed type that is different from <code>struct{ field1 int }</code> and of course is not the same as <code>OrderRevenue{}</code>.</p>

<p>Go emphasizes abstraction through interfaces, and perhaps you should try that. Here is the first take:</p>

<pre><code>  type OrderRevenue interface {
          MarshalMyself() ([]byte, error)
  }

  type Anonymous struct {}
  func (a Anonymous) MarshalMyself() ([]byte, error) {
          // implementation's up to you
          return []byte{}, nil
  }

  // the function signature
  generateResponse(rows *sqlx.Rows, structSlice []OrderRevenue, structBody Body) ([]Body, error) {
          // ...
  }
</code></pre>

<p>In this case you can also use empty interface <code>interface{}</code>, which all types implement, but you'll have to recursively go through the structure to do manual type assertion. The best approach in Go is to know the shape of your data in advance, at least partially.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1965774" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T20:37:34.440" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45601338      <row Id="45601338" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45601525" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45601338" CreationDate="2017-08-09T22:22:08.407" Score="1" Body="<p>If you want to use a struct receiver, remove the * from before Group in the definition of your function on line 8. As a convenience they do work the other way round (defined on struct works on a pointer receiver). See effective go for an explanation. </p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#pointers_vs_values" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#pointers_vs_values</a></p>

<p>Modified version: </p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ww6IYVPtIE" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/ww6IYVPtIE</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastActivityDate="2017-08-09T22:22:08.407" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45601402      <row Id="45601402" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45601936" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45601402" CreationDate="2017-08-09T23:05:57.127" Score="2" Body="<p>To control whether timing information is output in instructions.go, yes you could add a boolean variable to the file instructions.go (perhaps something like):</p>

<pre><code>var Debug bool
</code></pre>

<p>and wrap the logging in a check on it:</p>

<pre><code>if Debug {
   // log ellapsed execution time
fmt.Println("execute opAdd consume = ",(time.Now().UnixNano() - startTime))
}
</code></pre>

<p>and then set it somewhere (for example in your api pkg) with </p>

<pre><code>import ".../core/vm"
vm.Debug = true 
</code></pre>

<p>this is not goroutine safe so would have to be set once on startup depending on conditions or protected with a mutex. It's also pretty horrible but as a quick hack to see it work you could do this (sorry not familiar with this particular code base) . </p>

<p>I'm not clear on how opAdd is triggered by your other code if it was directly called you could of course just add a parameter to the function to control the output from the calling site, this would be preferable. </p>

<p>Normally this sort of thing you'd either:</p>

<ol>
<li>Pass in whether to debug or not to the function call opAdd </li>
<li>Set a global debugging level on startup once to control whether logging takes place or at what level globally and this would affect all such tracing. </li>
</ol>

<p>They do have a log package, I don't know why it's not used here:</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/log/logger.go" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/log/logger.go</a></p>

<p>EDIT </p>

<p>I would just always allocate startTime , but if you wish to avoid that, you need to declare it at the top level, compare this to your code above:</p>

<pre><code>// wrap the logging in a check
var startTime time.Time
if OpcodeTrigger {
    // begin execution time tracking
    startTime = time.Now().UnixNano();
}
</code></pre>

<p>NB if this is concurrent at all you should be adding a mutex to the vm pkg and only mutating OpCodeTrigger with a function which wraps the access with a mu.Lock - at that point you might start to ask yourself if there are better ways to do this :)</p>

<p>Better if you get stuck again to ask on a forum like forum.golangbridge.org as stackoverflow is not designed for extensive back and forth. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastEditorUserId="1601137" LastEditDate="2017-08-10T20:20:45.663" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T20:20:45.663" CommentCount="10" />

question:
45607483      <row Id="45607483" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45607559" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45607483" CreationDate="2017-08-10T07:49:11.843" Score="3" Body="<p>It's due to the scope of your variable declarations. You are shadowing the variable declaration inside the switch statement.</p>

<p>Simply change <code>car:=</code> to <code>car=</code> and you will be fine. You might also want to change <code>car:=&amp;Car{}</code> to <code>var car *Car</code>. This will make your intent clearer and avoid an unnecessary allocation (as you are creating a new object which is never used).</p>

<p>Read about <a href="http://www.tapirgames.com/blog/golang-block-and-scope" rel="nofollow noreferrer">blocks &amp; scopes</a> and see the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Declarations_and_scope" rel="nofollow noreferrer">scoping</a> section of the Go language reference.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T07:49:11.843" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45610700      <row Id="45610700" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45610758" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45610700" CreationDate="2017-08-10T10:10:17.987" Score="1" Body="<p>Only the fields that starts with an upper case letter are public visible.<br>
To solve your problem you can create getter and setter for each field or rename your fields' struct as follow:  </p>

<pre><code>type OperatInfo struct {
    EventId string
    HallId string
    UserId string
    Operating string
    OperatingID string
    Ip string
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2606098" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T10:10:17.987" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45611344      <row Id="45611344" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45612142" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45611344" CreationDate="2017-08-10T11:13:33.107" Score="3" Body="<p>Using only template code you can't. You need some kind of support from the executing Go code to do that. By design philosophy, templates should not contain complex logic. You may argue whether this is complex, but the template syntax has no support for this.</p>

<p>Simplest solution would be to add a <code>Version()</code> method to the <code>templateData</code> struct, which would simply return the version for a given environment and service:</p>

<pre><code>func (t *templateData) Version(environment, service string) string {
    return t.Versions[versionKey{
        Environment: environment,
        Service:     service,
    }]
}
</code></pre>

<p>Using this from the template:</p>

<pre><code>{{range $service := $services -}}
  {{range $environment := $environments}}
    {{$environment}} - {{$service}} version: {{$.Version $environment $service}}
  {{end}}
{{end}}
</code></pre>

<p>Testing it:</p>

<pre><code>t := template.Must(template.New("").Parse(templ))
td := &amp;templateData{
    Environments: []string{"EnvA", "EnvB"},
    Services:     []string{"ServA", "ServB"},
    Versions: map[versionKey]string{
        {"EnvA", "ServA"}: "1.0.0",
        {"EnvA", "ServB"}: "1.0.1",
        {"EnvB", "ServA"}: "1.0.2",
    },
}
if err := t.Execute(os.Stdout, td); err != nil {
    panic(err)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/7ytztACizl" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>EnvA - ServA version: 1.0.0

EnvB - ServA version: 1.0.2


EnvA - ServB version: 1.0.1

EnvB - ServB version: 
</code></pre>

<h3>Alternatives</h3>

<p>Instead of the <code>templateData.Version()</code> method you could just as easily register a function which could create and return a value of type <code>versionKey</code> from a given environment and service. See <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/html/template/#Template.Funcs" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Template.Funcs()</code></a> for details. This would be more complicated though, but more flexible as this could be reused elsewhere. See an example of this here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35550326/golang-templates-and-passing-funcs-to-template/35550730#35550730">Golang templates (and passing funcs to template)</a>. A slight variation of this would be to pass a function value as any other template data instead of registering it as a named function, which can be called.</p>

<p>Another alternative would be to "transform" your <code>Versions</code> field into a map of maps, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>Versions map[string]map[string]string
</code></pre>

<p>Which first could be indexed by environment, then by service, which in the template you can achieve by 2 <code>{{index}}</code> actions. You would have to check if the first indexing yields any results though.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-10T19:56:26.730" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T19:56:26.730" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45614430      <row Id="45614430" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45614530" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45614430" CreationDate="2017-08-10T13:04:52.237" Score="3" Body="<p>You are declaring this as a global variable in your package:</p>

<pre><code>var product_out []ProductOut
</code></pre>

<p>That way, the slice is just created once, and you are sharing it between requests.</p>

<p>If you want to declare a new slice for each request, you should move that line inside your <code>GetProductInfo</code> function.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T13:04:52.237" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45616552      <row Id="45616552" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45616587" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45616552" CreationDate="2017-08-10T14:31:27.083" Score="5" Body="<p>The <code>go/format</code> package makes a function available to format arbitrary text:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/go/format/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/go/format/</a></p>

<p>Should be as simple as:</p>

<pre><code>content, err := format.Source(content)
// check error
file.Write(content)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastEditorUserId="121660" LastEditDate="2017-08-10T14:51:30.363" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T14:51:30.363" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45617758      <row Id="45617758" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45617791" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45617758" CreationDate="2017-08-10T15:25:14.983" Score="6" Body="<p>The whole point of <code>defer</code> is that it does not execute until the function returns, so the appropriate place to put it would be immediately after the resource you want to close is opened. However, since you're creating the resource inside the loop, you should not use defer at all - otherwise, you're not going to close any of the resources created inside the loop until the function exits, so they'll pile up until then. Instead, you should close them at the end of each loop iteration, <em>without</em> <code>defer</code>:</p>

<pre><code>for rows.Next() {

   fields, err := db.Query(.....)
   if err != nil {
      // ...
   }

   // do something with `fields`

   fields.Close()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T15:25:14.983" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45622348      <row Id="45622348" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45622721" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45622348" CreationDate="2017-08-10T20:12:13.120" Score="0" Body="<p>As you have discovered, there are no macros and are unlikely to be. There may be generics at some point which could be helpful. In the meantime, there are a few options for code generation. You can use go generate for this:</p>

<pre><code>// add a magic comment to your go file 
// which needs some extra generated code
// this calls a tool called stringer to generate, 
// but it could be yacc or some homemade tool. 
//go:generate stringer -type=Pill

// call go generate to generate the methods:
go generate
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://blog.golang.org/generate" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://blog.golang.org/generate</a></p>

<p>But it really requires you to have a tool to generate the code you want like stringer. </p>

<p>Or you could just use text/template, build your own template, and run a simple tool that substitutes values into this template (from a config file, or perhaps arguments on the command line). </p>

<pre><code>mytool generate -type=thing -field=type...
... mytool loads a tmplate file, 
runs it through text/template and outputs it. 
</code></pre>

<p>This is pretty straightforward and you could easily build a custom system with it, though you'll probably want to generate once, then use the code. Here are some examples of this approach:</p>

<p><a href="http://clipperhouse.github.io/gen/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://clipperhouse.github.io/gen/</a></p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/fragmenta/fragmenta" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/fragmenta/fragmenta</a></p>

<p>Finally, you can use tools like grpc which generate structs in multiple languages in order to ease cross-language communication, which sounds like exactly the use case you are looking for:</p>

<p><a href="https://grpc.io/docs/quickstart/go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://grpc.io/docs/quickstart/go.html</a></p>

<p>I'd look at something like grpc first. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T20:12:13.120" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45621902      <row Id="45621902" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45622734" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45621902" CreationDate="2017-08-10T20:12:49.660" Score="1" Body="<p>What you are probably experiencing is the result of this code or something similar (your code does not compile):</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "net/http"
)

var Content struct {
    Data map[interface{}]interface{}
}

func main() {
    mux := http.NewServeMux()

    mux.Handle("/favicon.ico", http.NotFoundHandler())
    mux.HandleFunc("/", Index)
    mux.HandleFunc("/test", Testhandler)
    http.ListenAndServe(":8080", mux)
}

func Index(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    if r.URL.Path != "/" {
        fmt.Println("404")
        return
    }
    fmt.Println("index content ", Content)
}

func Testhandler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    data := make(map[interface{}]interface{})
    data["data1"] = "data 1 content"
    data["data2"] = "data 2 content"
    Content.Data = data
    fmt.Println("test content ", Content)
}
</code></pre>

<h3>Solution</h3>

<p>With this you are creating a global variable <code>Content</code> that keeps its state across calls to the webserver. What you probably intended is this:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "net/http"
)

type Content struct {
    Data map[interface{}]interface{}
}

func main() {
    mux := http.NewServeMux()

    mux.Handle("/favicon.ico", http.NotFoundHandler())
    mux.HandleFunc("/", Index)
    mux.HandleFunc("/test", Testhandler)
    http.ListenAndServe(":8080", mux)
}

func Index(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    var c Content
    if r.URL.Path != "/" {
        fmt.Println("404")
        return
    }
    fmt.Println("index content ", c)
}

func Testhandler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    var c Content
    data := make(map[interface{}]interface{})
    data["data1"] = "data 1 content"
    data["data2"] = "data 2 content"
    c.Data = data
    fmt.Println("test content ", c)
}
</code></pre>

<h3>Changes made</h3>

<ul>
<li>make <code>Content</code> a type as you already did in your sample (that way it is not a global variable any more but defining a type we can reuse)</li>
<li>declare <code>Content</code> in each call where it is needed (not globally as we do not want it to keep its content across server calls)</li>
</ul>

<h3>Essence</h3>

<p>You cannot use a type without declaring a variable from it first. That is why your sample did not build. If you try go will complain that <code>Content</code> is not an expression.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-10T20:12:49.660" CommentCount="0" />

question:
38724556      <row Id="38724556" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45625408" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="38724556" CreationDate="2017-08-11T00:52:55.050" Score="0" Body="<p>I'm find the package,Generate .proto files from Go source code:
<a href="https://github.com/src-d/proteus" rel="nofollow noreferrer">proteus (https://github.com/src-d/proteus)</a></p>

<p>Proteus /protis/ is a tool to generate protocol buffers version 3 compatible .proto files from your Go structs, types and functions.</p>

<p>The motivation behind this library is to use Go as a source of truth for your models instead of the other way around and then generating Go code from a .proto file, which does not generate idiomatic code.</p>

<p><strong>Generate protobuf messages</strong></p>

<pre><code>  //proteus:generate
  type User struct {
        Model
        Username string
  }

  type Model struct {
        ID int
        CreatedAt time.Time
  }
</code></pre>

<p>This example will generate the following protobuf message.</p>

<pre><code>  message User {
          int32 id = 1;
          google.protobuf.Timestamp created_at = 2;
          string username = 3;
  }
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Install</strong></p>

<pre><code> go get -v gopkg.in/src-d/proteus.v1/...
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Requirements</strong></p>

<p>There are two requirements for the full process.</p>

<pre><code> protoc binary installed on your path
 go get -u github.com/gogo/protobuf/...
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Usage</strong></p>

<p>You can generate the proto files, the marshal/unmarshal and the rest of protobuf stuff for your Go types, the RPC client and server interface and the RPC server implementation for your packages. That is, the whole process.</p>

<pre><code> proteus -f /path/to/protos/folder \
    -p my/go/package \
    -p my/other/go/package
</code></pre>

<p>You can generate proto files only using the command line tool provided with proteus.</p>

<pre><code> proteus proto -f /path/to/output/folder \
    -p my/go/package \
    -p my/other/go/package
    --verbose
</code></pre>

<p>You can also only generate gRPC server implementations for your packages.</p>

<pre><code>  proteus rpc -p my/go/package \
    -p my/other/go/package
</code></pre>

<p>NOTE: Of course, if the defaults don't suit your needs, until proteus is extensible via plugins, you can hack together your own generator command using the provided components. Check out the godoc documentation of the package.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4152293" LastEditorUserId="4152293" LastEditDate="2017-08-11T03:41:23.087" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T03:41:23.087" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45626184      <row Id="45626184" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45626399" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45626184" CreationDate="2017-08-11T03:16:09.583" Score="1" Body="<p>For your JSON structure following might suit well.</p>

<p>Play Link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ygXsdYALCb" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/ygXsdYALCb</a></p>

<p>Create a <code>struct</code> called <code>Info</code> or name you prefer also customize your field names as you like.</p>

<pre><code>type Info struct {
    EntityID               string `json:"entity_id"`
    WebsiteID              string `json:"website_id"`
    Email                  string `json:"email"`
    GroupID                string `json:"group_id"`
    CreatedAt              string `json:"created_at"`
    DisableAutoGroupChange string `json:"disable_auto_group_change"`
    Firstname              string `json:"firstname"`
    Lastname               string `json:"lastname"`
    CreatedIn              string `json:"created_in"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>And create <code>map</code> of <code>Info</code> struct and the unmarshal it.</p>

<pre><code>var result map[string]Info
if err := json.Unmarshal(jsonBytes, &amp;result); err != nil {
    fmt.Println(err)
}
fmt.Printf("%+v", result)
</code></pre>

<hr>

<p><strong>EDIT:</strong></p>

<p>As asked in the comment, adding <code>for</code> example:</p>

<pre><code>fmt.Println("Accessing unmarshal values:")
for key, info := range result {
    fmt.Println("Key:", key)
    fmt.Printf("Complete Object: %+v\n", info)
    fmt.Println("Individual value, typical object field access:")
    fmt.Println("EntityID:", info.EntityID)
    fmt.Println("Email:", info.Email)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastEditorUserId="1343356" LastEditDate="2017-08-11T04:56:43.330" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T04:56:43.330" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45628831      <row Id="45628831" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45629091" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45628831" CreationDate="2017-08-11T07:13:21.823" Score="1" Body="<p>Create a request:</p>

<pre><code>req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", path, nil)
if err != nil {
     // handle error
}
</code></pre>

<p>Set the headers:</p>

<pre><code>req.Header.Add("Accept", "application/json")
</code></pre>

<p>Run the request using client as configured in the question:</p>

<pre><code>resp, err := httpClient.Do(req)
if err != nil {
     // handle error
}
</code></pre>

<p>Example that worked for me: </p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "io/ioutil"
    "log"
    "net/http"

    "github.com/dghubble/oauth1"
)

func main() {

    config := oauth1.NewConfig("consumer key", "consumer secret")
    token := oauth1.NewToken("token key", "token secret")

    httpClient := config.Client(oauth1.NoContext, token)

    path := "https://www.example.com/api/rest/customers?limit=2&amp;order=created_at&amp;dir=DESC"
    req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", path, nil)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    req.Header.Add("Accept", "application/json")

    resp, err := httpClient.Do(req)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    defer resp.Body.Close()
    body, _ := ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    fmt.Printf("Raw Resonse Body:\n%v\n", string(body))
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>Raw Resonse Body:
&lt;!doctype html&gt;
&lt;html&gt;
&lt;head&gt;
      &lt;title&gt;Example Domain&lt;/title&gt;
      ...
&lt;/head&gt;
&lt;body&gt;
&lt;div&gt;
    &lt;h1&gt;Example Domain&lt;/h1&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;This domain is established to be used for illustrative examples in documents. You may use this
    domain in examples without prior coordination or asking for permission.&lt;/p&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.iana.org/domains/example"&gt;More information...&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;
&lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt;
      ...
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3310285" LastEditorUserId="3310285" LastEditDate="2017-08-11T10:25:57.627" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T10:25:57.627" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45635839      <row Id="45635839" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45636408" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45635839" CreationDate="2017-08-11T13:27:48.767" Score="1" Body="<p>As mentioned in the comments, embedding is not inheritance but composition, so you'll probably have to either:</p>

<ul>
<li>Re-think your design to use the tools Go has available</li>
<li>Resort to extensive hacking to get the results you want</li>
</ul>

<p>In the particular case you are showing (trying to get <code>GetJSON()</code> to include also the fields of the outer struct, here is a possible way of getting that to work that does not require many changes (just storing a pointer to the outer struct in Base when creating the struct):</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
)

type Base struct {
    Type  string      `json:"$type"`
    selfP interface{} // this will store a pointer to the actual sub struct
}

func (b *Base) SetSelfP(p interface{}) {
    b.selfP = p
}

func (b *Base) GetJSON() ([]byte, error) {
    return json.Marshal(b.selfP)
}

func (b *Base) SetType(typeStr string) {
    b.Type = typeStr
}

type Auth struct {
    Base
    Username string
    Password string
}

func main() {
    a := &amp;Auth{
        Username: "Test",
        Password: "test",
    }
    a.SetSelfP(a) // this line does the trick
    a.SetType("testtype")
    j, _ := a.GetJSON()
    fmt.Println(string(j))
}
</code></pre>

<p>Playground link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/npuy6XMk_t" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/npuy6XMk_t</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T13:27:48.767" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45634812      <row Id="45634812" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45636982" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45634812" CreationDate="2017-08-11T13:55:03.890" Score="0" Body="<p>Assuming you already had a look at the <a href="https://github.com/kubernetes/client-go/tree/master/examples/create-update-delete-deployment" rel="nofollow noreferrer">update example</a>?</p>

<p>In any case, the <code>dp</code> variable here contains all you need:</p>

<pre><code>dp, err := clientset.ExtensionsV1beta1Client.Deployments("default").Get("nginx-deployment", metav1.GetOptions{})
</code></pre>

<p>So <code>dp</code> is of type <code>v1beta1.Deployment</code> which contains a variable of type <code>metav1.ObjectMeta</code> which has the <code>ResourceVersion</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="396567" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T13:55:03.890" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45630401      <row Id="45630401" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45639914" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45630401" CreationDate="2017-08-11T16:36:06.673" Score="2" Body="<p>The problem is has to do with the 'data.' metadata envelope that Fabric injects into the document that is persisted into CouchDB state database.  From the chaincode author's perspective, there is no 'data' envelope, and as such the 'data' envelope should be excluded from any queries that are passed in.  The Fabric will inject the 'data' envelope, both upon save and upon query.  If you utilize the Fauxton UI for trial queries directly against CouchDB (without the benefit of the Fabric injection code), you will need to include the 'data' envelope.  Just remember to exclude the 'data' envelope when writing chaincode queries.</p>

<p>See the <a href="https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/examples/chaincode/go/marbles02/marbles_chaincode.go#L37" rel="nofollow noreferrer">example queries</a> that correspond to the marbles02 example, note that there is no data envelope provided.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8205919" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T16:36:06.673" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45640144      <row Id="45640144" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45640476" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45640144" CreationDate="2017-08-11T17:11:29.163" Score="5" Body="<p>@RayfenWindspear has the easiest to use and read answer, but is correct about the performance hit. If performance is more important than maintainability, you can do the same thing using iterative division to get the most-significant base-10 digit:</p>

<pre><code>var i int
for i = n; i &gt;= 10; i = i / 10 {}
// i == most significant digit
</code></pre>

<p>Note that you have to declare <code>i</code> outside the loop to be able to use it after the loop finds the most-significant digit. I'd also benchmark both with your own data set to see what the real performance impact is in your particular situation.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ozFw_ll6Y3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Full playground example, courtesy of Rayfen</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="7426" LastEditDate="2017-08-11T17:23:16.717" LastActivityDate="2017-08-11T17:23:16.717" CommentCount="5" />

question:
45645900      <row Id="45645900" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45645923" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45645900" CreationDate="2017-08-12T02:22:42.670" Score="4" Body="<p>It looks like you are trying to use string formatters, which aren't supported by <code>fmt.Println</code>.</p>

<p>According to the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">godocs</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Printf formats according to a format specifier </p>
</blockquote>

<p>whereas</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Println formats using the default formats</p>
</blockquote>

<p>The following will give the output you are trying to get:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    kvs := map[string]string{
        "a": "apple",
        "b": "banana",
    }
    for k, v := range kvs {
        fmt.Printf("%s -&gt; %s\n", k, v)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Note that maps in Go do not have a specific ordering so you may get any arbitrary key-value pair before another.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2631732" LastEditorUserId="2631732" LastEditDate="2017-08-12T20:42:33.273" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T20:42:33.273" CommentCount="0" />
