question:
45647958      <row Id="45647958" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45647970" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45647958" CreationDate="2017-08-12T08:03:09.883" Score="4" Body="<p>When you use <code>:=</code>, you declare new variables. An <code>s</code> is created inside the loop unrelated to the <code>s</code> outside it. Assign instead:</p>

<pre><code>for len(s) != 0 {
    j := len(s) - 1
    <b>var top int
    top, s = s[j], s[:j]</b>
    fmt.Printf("top = %+v
", top)
    fmt.Printf("s = %+v
", s)
    fmt.Printf("len(s) = %+v
", len(s))
}</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="707111" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T08:03:09.883" CommentCount="5" CommunityOwnedDate="2017-08-12T08:03:09.883" />

question:
45648262      <row Id="45648262" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45648864" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45648262" CreationDate="2017-08-12T09:49:55.647" Score="2" Body="<p>Use <a href="https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/static/sql-update.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">PostgreSQL's <code>RETURNING</code> clause</a> and <code>db.Query/db.Select</code> variants instead of <code>Exec</code>, e.g. </p>

<pre><code>//get the primary key of updated rows
db := s.getDB(tx)

results := []int{}
err = db.Select(&amp;results, "UPDATE mytable SET var_name = 0 WHERE var_name = 1 RETURNING id")
</code></pre>

<p>To retrieve more than one columns, just list the column names after <code>RETURNING</code>, e.g.</p>

<pre><code>rows, err := db.Queryx("UPDATE mytable SET var_name = 0 WHERE var_name = 1 RETURNING id,var_name,other_columns")
for rows.Next() {
    //do something with the result
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T09:49:55.647" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45651387      <row Id="45651387" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45651488" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45651387" CreationDate="2017-08-12T14:43:33.310" Score="2" Body="<p>if you read the code of worker carefully, you will notice</p>

<pre><code>w.WorkerPool &lt;- w.JobChannel
</code></pre>

<p>each time a loop begin, the channel of worker itself has been put back</p>

<p>I copy the whole function below:</p>

<pre><code>func (w Worker) Start() {
    go func() {
        for {
            // register the current worker into the worker queue.
            w.WorkerPool &lt;- w.JobChannel

            select {
            case job := &lt;-w.JobChannel:
                // we have received a work request.
                if err := job.Payload.UploadToS3(); err != nil {
                    log.Errorf("Error uploading to S3: %s", err.Error())
                }

            case &lt;-w.quit:
                // we have received a signal to stop
                return
            }
        }
    }()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="2791115" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T14:43:33.310" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45653222      <row Id="45653222" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45654290" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45653222" CreationDate="2017-08-12T19:47:19.217" Score="0" Body="<p>Is this what you are looking for?</p>

<p>You can test the code <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Qx3hkUR6vu" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "log"
)

func main() {
    // test input (json.Unmarshal expects []byte)
    b := []byte("[[{\"client\": \" 321\"}], [{\"number\": \"3123\"}]]")

    // declare the target variable in the correct format
    var f [][]map[string]string

    // unmarshal the json
    err := json.Unmarshal(b, &amp;f)
    if err != nil {
        // handle error
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    // output result
    fmt.Println(f)
}
</code></pre>

<p>For details see the comments in the code. Feel free to ask.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T19:47:19.217" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45652717      <row Id="45652717" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45655153" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45652717" CreationDate="2017-08-12T21:38:36.327" Score="1" Body="<p>The input you have is definitely invalid XML. There is a bug in the creation routine of the XML.</p>

<h3>Idea</h3>

<p>Since you say you have to deal with it the way it is... here a suggestion:</p>

<ol>
<li>replace all closing tags via regex to something you will basically never have in your input (e.g. <code>@#lt#@/tagname@#gt#@</code>). While doing that save all the distinct tag names to a slice.</li>
<li>With the slice of tag names replace the start tags</li>
<li>Now escape all remaining <code>&lt;</code> and <code>&gt;</code></li>
<li>Last but not least replace the original tags back: <code>@#lt#@</code> to <code>&lt;</code> and <code>@#gt#@</code> to <code>&gt;</code></li>
</ol>

<p>Now you should have valid xml that is parseable.</p>

<h3>Proof of Concept</h3>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/Ht_Igi67kX" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Playground</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "regexp"
    "sort"
)

var (
    rlt = []byte("@#lt#@")
    rgt = []byte("@#gt#@")
    lt  = []byte("&amp;lt;")
    gt  = []byte("&amp;gt;")
)

// used for sorting strings by length
type ByLength []string

func (s ByLength) Len() int {
    return len(s)
}
func (s ByLength) Swap(i, j int) {
    s[i], s[j] = s[j], s[i]
}
func (s ByLength) Less(i, j int) bool {
    return len(s[i]) &lt; len(s[j])
}

func main() {
    s := `&lt;Shop&gt;
    &lt;ShopName&gt;Fresh Fruit &lt;Fruit Shop&gt;&lt;/ShopName&gt;
    &lt;ShopName attr="val1"&gt;Fresh Fruit &lt;Shop test&gt;&lt;/ShopName&gt;
&lt;/Shop&gt;`

    r1, err := regexp.Compile("&lt;/([^&lt;&gt;]*)&gt;")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    names := []string{}
    out := r1.ReplaceAllFunc([]byte(s), func(b []byte) []byte {
        name := b[2 : len(b)-1]

        // TODO: only append name if not already in list
        names = append(names, string(name))

        // probably optimizable
        bytes := make([]byte, 0, len(name)+12)
        bytes = append(bytes, rlt...)
        bytes = append(bytes, name...)
        bytes = append(bytes, rgt...)
        return bytes
    })

    // sort names descending by length otherwise we risk replacing parts of names like with &lt;Shop and &lt;ShopName
    sort.Sort(sort.Reverse(ByLength(names)))

    for _, name := range names {
        // replace only exact start tags
        out = bytes.Replace(out, []byte(fmt.Sprintf("&lt;%s&gt;", name)), []byte(fmt.Sprintf("@#lt#@%s@#gt#@", name)), -1)

        // replace start tags with attributes
        r3, err := regexp.Compile(fmt.Sprintf("&lt;%s( [^&lt;&gt;=]+=\"[^&lt;&gt;]+)&gt;", name))
        if err != nil {
            // handle error
        }
        out = r3.ReplaceAll(out, []byte(fmt.Sprintf("@#lt#@%s$1@#gt#@", name)))
    }

    out = bytes.Replace(out, []byte{'&lt;'}, lt, -1)
    out = bytes.Replace(out, []byte{'&gt;'}, gt, -1)

    out = bytes.Replace(out, rlt, []byte{'&lt;'}, -1)
    out = bytes.Replace(out, rgt, []byte{'&gt;'}, -1)

    fmt.Println(string(out))
}
</code></pre>

<h3>Notes</h3>

<ol>
<li>this is a proof of concept. This is not optimised for performance.</li>
<li>you might still run into content that might not be escaped properly. Then you will need to further optimise. If there is something like this in the content it will be falsely considered a tag: <code>&lt;tagname&gt;</code> or <code>&lt;tagname something ="something&gt;</code>. Therefore expect some xml to still to be invalid. Log invalid xml so you can improve the algorithm.</li>
</ol>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastEditorUserId="6220193" LastEditDate="2017-08-12T21:50:59.173" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T21:50:59.173" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45650875      <row Id="45650875" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45655266" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45650875" CreationDate="2017-08-12T21:57:03.033" Score="1" Body="<p>You can declare new types which represent slice of your models. For example,</p>

<pre><code>type ModelAList []ModelA
type ModelBList []ModelB
</code></pre>

<p>Then when you pass variables of these new types into your <code>r.GetDocumentBySlug()</code>, the functions in the <code>encoding/json</code> package will unmarshal the slices accordingly.</p>

<p>You can find working examples <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/MRz2vLJHGp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here (marshaling)</a> and <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/H5ODIZIdWJ" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here (unmarshaling)</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1144203" LastEditorUserId="1144203" LastEditDate="2017-08-12T22:07:34.520" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T22:07:34.520" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45654383      <row Id="45654383" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45655373" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45654383" CreationDate="2017-08-12T22:14:47.673" Score="2" Body="<p>Your namespace is not correctly set. See also <a href="https://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace" rel="nofollow noreferrer">xml namespace</a></p>

<p>Add the namespace here:</p>

<pre><code>elementToSign := &amp;etree.Element{
    Tag: "ExampleElement",
    Space: "xml",
}
elementToSign.CreateAttr("ID", "id1234")
</code></pre>

<p>With the added line it will pass validation. Tested with <a href="https://www.w3schools.com/xml/xml_validator.asp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">XML Validator</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-12T22:14:47.673" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45656937      <row Id="45656937" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45656975" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45656937" CreationDate="2017-08-13T04:10:06.833" Score="1" Body="<p><code>http.Dir("/tmp")</code> is actually a type conversion where you convert the string <code>/tmp</code> into the <code>http.Dir</code> type. Looking at the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#Dir" rel="nofollow noreferrer">docs</a>, you will see that <code>http.Dir</code> is actually a string type. Hence, this type conversion works. </p>

<p>In addition, the <code>http.Dir</code> type also implements the <code>func Open(name string) (File, error)</code> function. Hence, it can be used anywhere where a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#FileSystem" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>FileSystem</code></a> interface is used.</p>

<p>You can also check out the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#ServeFile" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>func ServeFile(w ResponseWriter, r *Request, name string)</code></a> function in the <code>net/http</code> package.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1144203" LastActivityDate="2017-08-13T04:10:06.833" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45660762      <row Id="45660762" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45661001" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45660762" CreationDate="2017-08-13T13:43:34.977" Score="2" Body="<p>May be like this?</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "sync"
    "time"

    "github.com/davecgh/go-spew/spew"
)

func callbackWithTimeout(cbFunc func() ([]byte, error), timeout time.Duration) {
    time.Sleep(timeout)
    d, e := cbFunc()
    spew.Dump(d)
    spew.Dump(e)
}

func main() {
    var wg sync.WaitGroup

    wg.Add(1)

    go func() {
        defer wg.Done() // move it here
        cbFunc := func() ([]byte, error) {
            //I feel like I should be able to defer here instead
            return nil, nil
        }
        callbackWithTimeout(cbFunc, time.Duration(4*time.Second))
    }()

    println("some line")

    wg.Wait()
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="8075949" LastActivityDate="2017-08-13T13:43:34.977" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45665698      <row Id="45665698" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45666636" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45665698" CreationDate="2017-08-14T02:18:37.953" Score="1" Body="<p>Take a look at <a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">How to Write Go Code</a></p>

<p>From the documentation, this is how a workspace should look in practice:</p>

<pre><code>bin/
    hello                          # command executable
    outyet                         # command executable
pkg/
    linux_amd64/
        github.com/golang/example/
            stringutil.a           # package object
src/
    github.com/golang/example/
        .git/                      # Git repository metadata
    hello/
        hello.go               # command source
    outyet/
        main.go                # command source
        main_test.go           # test source
    stringutil/
        reverse.go             # package source
        reverse_test.go        # test source
    golang.org/x/image/
        .git/                      # Git repository metadata
    bmp/
        reader.go              # package source
        writer.go              # package source
    ... (many more repositories and packages omitted) ...
</code></pre>

<p>I would probably create a CSV and an XML package, and put their corresponding importers/exporters there, or have an importer and an exporter package.</p>

<h2>Update:</h2>

<p>Suggested project structure -</p>

<pre><code>app
|- main.go
|- config
    |- config.go
|- importer
    |- importer.go
    |- csv.go
    |- xml.go
|- exporter
    |- exporter.go
    |- csv.go
    |- xml.go
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5395709" LastEditorUserId="5395709" LastEditDate="2017-08-14T15:13:13.817" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T15:13:13.817" CommentCount="11" />

question:
45675092      <row Id="45675092" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45675210" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45675092" CreationDate="2017-08-14T13:06:01.433" Score="1" Body="<p>The mutexes are protecting data structures, they are both captured in the closure given to the <code>replyFunc</code> callback.</p>

<p>The <code>wait</code> mutex blocks until the callback returns, and the <code>change</code> mutex protects the <code>replyData</code> and <code>replyErr</code> values.</p>

<p>The commit that added those only says:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Make SimpleQuery race safe, irrespective of what the server does.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So this may be extra protection against some unintended or legacy behavior, which is why it's using multiple mutexes rather than a single primitive to synchronize the operation. </p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-08-14T13:15:12.720" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T13:15:12.720" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45557831      <row Id="45557831" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45675560" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45557831" CreationDate="2017-08-14T13:24:45.610" Score="1" Body="<p>This happens due to mount events propagation between namespaces. The propagation type of your mount point is <code>MS_SHARED</code>.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><code>MS_SHARED</code>: This mount point shares mount and unmount events with other mount points that are members of its "peer group". When a mount point is added or removed under this mount point, this change will propagate to the peer group, so that the mount or unmount will also take place under each of the peer mount points. Propagation also occurs in the reverse direction, so that mount and unmount events on a peer mount will also propagate to this mount point.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Source - <a href="https://lwn.net/Articles/689856/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://lwn.net/Articles/689856/</a></p>

<p>The <code>shared:N</code> tag in <code>/proc/self/mountinfo</code> indicates that the mount is sharing propagation events with a peer group:</p>

<pre><code>$ sudo go run namespace-1.go
[root@localhost]# mount --bind /home/andrii/test /mnt
# The propagation type is MS_SHARED
[root@localhost]# grep '/mnt' /proc/self/mountinfo
264 175 254:0 /home/andrii/test /mnt rw,noatime shared:1 - ext4 
/dev/mapper/cryptroot rw,data=ordered
[root@localhost]# exit
$ ls /mnt
test_file
</code></pre>

<p>On most Linux distributions the default propagation type is <code>MS_SHARED</code> which is set by <code>systemd</code>. See <code>NOTES</code> in <code>man 7 mount_namespaces</code>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Notwithstanding the fact that the default propagation type for new 
  mount points is in many cases MS_PRIVATE, MS_SHARED is typically more 
  useful. For this reason, systemd(1) automatically remounts all mount 
  points as MS_SHARED on system startup. Thus, on most modern systems, 
  the default propagation type is in practice MS_SHARED.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>If you want a fully isolated namespace, you can make all mount points private this way:</p>

<pre><code>$ sudo go run namespace-1.go
[root@localhost]# mount --make-rprivate /
[root@localhost]# mount --bind /home/andrii/test /mnt
# The propagation type is MS_PRIVATE now
[root@localhost]# grep '/mnt' /proc/self/mountinfo
264 175 254:0 /home/andrii/test /mnt rw,noatime - ext4 
/dev/mapper/cryptroot rw,data=ordered
[root@localhost]# exit
$ ls /mnt
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="5737938" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T13:24:45.610" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45679529      <row Id="45679529" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45679626" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45679529" CreationDate="2017-08-14T17:13:39.040" Score="5" Body="<p>Rather than converting this to a string, you'll want to convert it to a <code>time.Time</code> and from there to a string. You can use the handy <code>Unix</code> method to get a <code>Time</code> object back for that time stamp.</p>

<pre><code>import "time"
import "fmt"

t := time.Unix(0, 1502712864232)
fmt.Println(t.Format("02/01/2006, 15:04:05"))
</code></pre>

<p>Edit: added format to the println - note, testing your unix stamp in go playground, that value is neither nano seconds nor seconds, in both cases the time value produced is way off of what it should be. The code above still demonstrates the basic idea of what you want to do but it seems an additional step is necessary or the sample <code>int64</code> you gave just does not correspond to the string you provided.</p>

<p>relevant docs:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Unix" rel="noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/time/#Unix</a></p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/" rel="noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="763585" LastEditorUserId="763585" LastEditDate="2017-08-14T17:19:55.037" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T17:19:55.037" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45679408      <row Id="45679408" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45680060" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45679408" CreationDate="2017-08-14T17:43:47.160" Score="1" Body="<p>The problem here is that if you omit the type assertion here:</p>

<pre><code>new := v.Elem().Interface()
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>new</code> is inferred to have a <code>interface{}</code> type.</p>

<p>Then when you take the address to unmarshal, the type of <code>&amp;new</code> is <code>*interface{}</code> (pointer to interface{}) and unmarshal does not work as you expect.</p>

<p>You can avoid the type assertion if instead of getting the <code>Elem()</code> you work directly with the pointer reference.</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
  //Original struct
  orig := new(Employee)

  t := reflect.TypeOf(orig)
  v := reflect.New(t.Elem())

  // reflected pointer
  newP := v.Interface()

  // Unmarshal to reflected struct pointer
  json.Unmarshal([]byte("{\"firstname\": \"bender\"}"), newP)

  fmt.Printf("%+v\n", newP)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Playground: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/lTBU-1PqM4" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/lTBU-1PqM4</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-08-14T19:28:13.093" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T19:28:13.093" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45682353      <row Id="45682353" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45682537" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45682353" CreationDate="2017-08-14T20:27:01.360" Score="2" Body="<p>As indicated in the documentation, <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/httptest/#NewRequest" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>httptest.NewRequest</code></a> "returns a new incoming server Request, suitable for passing to an http.Handler for testing", while <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#NewRequest" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>http.NewRequest</code></a> "returns a Request suitable for use with Client.Do or Transport.RoundTrip." So, if you're passing the request directly to the handler in a unit test, use <code>httptest.NewRequest</code>, and if you're executing a full round-trip using <code>http.Client</code>, use <code>http.NewRequest</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T20:27:01.360" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45682512      <row Id="45682512" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45683067" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45682512" CreationDate="2017-08-14T21:08:58.310" Score="1" Body="<p>Typically it is best to use XML decoder for large XML, it uses the stream and Go with selective binding (like <code>WantThisElement&gt;Bar</code>) then XML decoder follows that path.</p>

<p>Let's use XML content from your question to create an example.</p>

<p>XML Content:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;Report&gt;
    &lt;ElementOne Blah="bleh"&gt;
        &lt;IgnoreElement&gt;
            &lt;Foo&gt;
                &lt;FooValue&gt;example foo value&lt;/FooValue&gt;
            &lt;/Foo&gt;
        &lt;/IgnoreElement&gt;

        &lt;WantThisElement&gt;
            &lt;Bar Baz="test"&gt;
                 &lt;BarValue&gt;example bar value 1&lt;/BarValue&gt;
            &lt;/Bar&gt;
            &lt;Bar Baz="test2"&gt;
                &lt;BarValue&gt;example bar value 2&lt;/BarValue&gt;
            &lt;/Bar&gt;
        &lt;/WantThisElement&gt;
    &lt;/ElementOne&gt;
&lt;/Report&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>Structures:</p>

<pre><code>type Report struct {
    XMLName    xml.Name `xml:"Report"`
    ElementOne ElementOne
}

type ElementOne struct {
    XMLName xml.Name `xml:"ElementOne"`
    Blah    string   `xml:"Blah,attr"`
    Bar     []Bar    `xml:"WantThisElement&gt;Bar"`
}

type Bar struct {
    XMLName  xml.Name `xml:"Bar"`
    Baz      string   `xml:"Baz,attr"`
    BarValue string   `xml:"BarValue"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>Play Link: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/26xDkojeUp" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/26xDkojeUp</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1343356" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T21:08:58.310" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45683207      <row Id="45683207" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45683350" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45683207" CreationDate="2017-08-14T21:31:16.123" Score="2" Body="<p>Because you can shadow outer-scope variables in an inner scope, such as a closure or loop; the compiler cannot infer purely based on whether the variable existed before or not. Having to explicitly define variables also helps to reduce defects which are commonplace in languages like PHP and JavaScript that allow you to just <code>foo = bar</code> without any consideration of whether <code>foo</code> has been defined. That kind of loose compilation paves over common mistakes <em>like typos</em> such that they're no longer caught at compile time, they show up as "weird behavior" at runtime, which is much, much harder to track down and fix.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-14T21:31:16.123" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45684996      <row Id="45684996" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45685121" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45684996" CreationDate="2017-08-15T01:03:52.840" Score="1" Body="<p><code>GOPATH</code> is a variable that indicates where the dependencies of your application are installed. It is basically a path to a directory where you store the packages your application might use.</p>

<p>Any application of a reasonable size has dependencies. In golang, these come in the form of packages. At compile time, the location of the dependencies (i.e. packages you use) needs to be known such that your executable can be built.</p>

<p>They can either be stored at a fixed, predefined location or make somehow the user be able to specify the location himself. The first approach has a lot of downsides (for example, it would be impossible to support operating systems with different directory structure). Thus, the designers of the go tool decided to make it user configurable by the means of this variable. This also gives the user much more flexibility, such as the ability to group the dependencies for different projects in different directories.</p>

<p>The usage of a environment variable (as <code>GOPATH</code>) is not limited to golang. Java has its <code>CLASSPATH</code>, Python its <code>PYTHONPATH</code> and so on (each of them with their quirks, but with the same basic role).</p>
" OwnerUserId="2896626" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T01:03:52.840" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45685024      <row Id="45685024" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45685393" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45685024" CreationDate="2017-08-15T01:45:05.310" Score="0" Body="<p>To do it using channels you'll have to refactor your code quite a bit.</p>

<p>Smallest change would be to do the assignment in the goroutine:</p>

<pre><code>go func(){
    person.WillDieAt = slowExternalFunction(i)
}()
</code></pre>

<p>However, to make this work we'd need to make some other changes as well:</p>

<ul>
<li>Use an array of pointers so that you can add the person before the assignment finishes.</li>
<li>Implement a wait group so that you wait for all goroutines to finish before printing the results.</li>
</ul>

<p>Here's the complete <code>main</code> function with the changes:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    var persons []*Person
    var wg sync.WaitGroup

    for i := 0; i &lt;= 100; i++{
        person := &amp;Person{}
        person.Id = i
        person.Name = fastInternalFunction(i)
        wg.Add(1)
        go func(){
            person.WillDieAt = slowExternalFunction(i)
            wg.Done()
        }()

        persons = append(persons,person)
    }
    wg.Wait()
    for _, person := range persons {
        fmt.Printf("%v ", person )
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Playground: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/8GWYD29inC" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/8GWYD29inC</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T01:45:05.310" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45686163      <row Id="45686163" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45686455" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45686163" CreationDate="2017-08-15T04:21:55.750" Score="5" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>I was thinking of using strconv ParseInt and ParseFloat but not sure
  if that is the right way.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Well, it's certainly <em>a</em> right way.</p>

<p>You don't need to use ParseInt, though. ParseFloat will do the job.</p>

<pre><code>func isNumeric(s string) bool {
    _, err := strconv.ParseFloat(s, 64)
    return err == nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>See an example here: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/D53HRS-KIL" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/D53HRS-KIL</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1949322" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T04:21:55.750" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45686269      <row Id="45686269" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45686466" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45686269" CreationDate="2017-08-15T04:23:06.227" Score="2" Body="<p>The error you are getting is due to the way you are defining your <code>OrderAddresses</code> struct. Instead of</p>

<pre><code>type OrderAddresses []struct {
</code></pre>

<p>If you use</p>

<pre><code>type OrderAddresses struct {
</code></pre>

<p>without the braces, your compile error should go away. </p>

<p>That being said, I'm not sure if your json will parse as you expect given the blob I'm looking at. It appears that <code>addresses</code> in the json blob is an array. This means that instead of representing it as</p>

<pre><code>Addresses map[string]OrderAddresses `json:"addresses"`
</code></pre>

<p>You should simply make it a slice of <code>OrderAddresses</code></p>

<pre><code>Addresses []OrderAddresses `json:"addresses"`
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6621535" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T04:23:06.227" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45685547      <row Id="45685547" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45686610" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45685547" CreationDate="2017-08-15T04:43:00.810" Score="3" Body="<p>You should separate the <em>logic</em> (function) from <em>presentation</em> (template). 
The function registered in <code>template.FuncMap</code> should not depends on template as its input to produce an output. If you want to return HTML template as the function output, you should generate it manually (using <code>fmt.Sprintf</code>, etc.). </p>

<p>In your case, you can simply register a function to check the media type, then generate different output using template's <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/#hdr-Actions" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>{{if}}</code></a>  action. The function may looks like:</p>

<pre><code>func matchType(ext, s string) bool {
    return strings.ToLower(ext) == strings.ToLower(path.Ext(s))
}
</code></pre>

<p>and the template looks like:</p>

<pre><code>{{ range .Media }}&lt;p&gt;
    {{if . | matchType ".jpg"}}&lt;img src={{.}}&gt;
    {{else if . | matchType ".mp4"}}&lt;video controls src={{.}}&gt;&lt;/video&gt;
    {{else}}{{.}}
    {{end}}&lt;/p&gt;
{{ end }}
</code></pre>

<p>A working example based on your reduced example: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/U64_7UHZQU" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/U64_7UHZQU</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T04:43:00.810" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45694512      <row Id="45694512" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45695868" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45694512" CreationDate="2017-08-15T15:14:16.287" Score="2" Body="<p>An explicit type is required in a type assertion. The type cannot be constructed through reflection.</p>

<p>Unless the argument is a []interface{}, the slice or array must be copied to produce a []interface{}.</p>

<p>Try this:</p>

<pre><code>func AnythingToSlice(a interface{}) []interface{} {
    v := reflect.ValueOf(a)
    switch v.Kind() {
    case reflect.Slice, reflect.Array:
        result := make([]interface{}, v.Len())
        for i := 0; i &lt; v.Len(); i++ {
            result[i] = v.Index(i).Interface()
        }
        return result
    default:
        panic("not supported")
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/3bXxnHOK8_" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/3bXxnHOK8_</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T15:14:16.287" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45696665      <row Id="45696665" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45696673" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45696665" CreationDate="2017-08-15T15:56:59.223" Score="1" Body="<p>No, that is the very definition of not safe, and would be caught by the <a href="https://golang.org/doc/articles/race_detector.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">race detector</a> if you tested it. You will absolutely need to synchronize access, for example using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sync.Mutex</code> or <code>sync.RWMutex</code></a>.</p>

<p>If it is not critical to always have the latest values, you can also allow each goroutine to cache a <em>copy</em> of the struct, and then regularly update their copy from the "master" copy every so often. If there is frequent access to the struct, this can help avoid some performance issues due to lock contention.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T15:56:59.223" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45698298      <row Id="45698298" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45698461" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45698298" CreationDate="2017-08-15T17:43:04.877" Score="5" Body="<p>What you are asking about is called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-circuit_evaluation" rel="noreferrer">Short Circuiting,</a> and yes, Go does it.</p>

<p>In the <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Logical_operators" rel="noreferrer">language spec,</a> it says that</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Logical operators apply to boolean values and yield a result of the same type as the operands. The right operand is evaluated conditionally.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>This means that, in your case, if <code>function1</code> returned false, <code>function2</code> would not be called.</p>

<p>See an example for <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/RAMY4386Ct" rel="noreferrer"><code>&amp;&amp;</code> here</a> and for <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/vCU3K-J2t6" rel="noreferrer"><code>||</code> here.</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4099287" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T17:43:04.877" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45698552      <row Id="45698552" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45698612" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45698552" CreationDate="2017-08-15T17:53:09.973" Score="1" Body="<p>You're almost there - I think the confusion is you're using piping <em>to call bash</em>, which means you actually need to call bash <em>using bash</em>:</p>

<pre><code>exec.Command("bash", "-c", `bash --rcfile &lt;(echo "export PS1='&gt; ' &amp;&amp; ls")`)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T17:53:09.973" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45698651      <row Id="45698651" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45698725" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45698651" CreationDate="2017-08-15T18:00:04.043" Score="5" Body="<p>This one is easy. This is why you never use WaitGroup's Add in a goroutine. Always call it before starting a goroutine.</p>

<p>The problem is that you stack up a bunch of goroutine's and then call Wait immediately. Go does not promise to run your goroutines at any particular time, just like POSIX or Windows threads are not guaranteed.</p>

<p>So, in this case, you gave the scheduler a bunch of goroutines to run in the future, but it decided to finish your code first. So it ran <code>wg.Wait()</code> and <code>close(out)</code> before ever doing <code>wg.Add()</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13422" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T18:00:04.043" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45702591      <row Id="45702591" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45703012" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45702591" CreationDate="2017-08-15T23:33:16.727" Score="0" Body="<p>It looks like Go is using system's native DNS resolution code (via a C library) when compiling locally, but Go's own resolver written in Go when cross-compiled. As confirmation, sounds like it's slow when <code>CGO_ENABLED=0</code>. Although it isn't specifically about what you're experiencing here, <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/16345" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/issues/16345</a> came up in a quick search and refers to how CGO_ENABLED determines which resolver runs.</p>

<p>I'm not sure, though, how you either compile a binary you want to use the cgo native resolver cross-platform (probably need to at least install C cross-compilers) or get the resolver in Go to work well under your Darwin VPN setup. </p>
" OwnerUserId="2714852" LastActivityDate="2017-08-15T23:33:16.727" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45705921      <row Id="45705921" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45706182" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45705921" CreationDate="2017-08-16T06:07:36.327" Score="2" Body="<p>Those are <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">slices</a>, not <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Array_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">arrays</a>. It's important to emphasize as arrays are comparable but slices are not. See <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Comparison_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Comparision operators</a>. And since slices are not comparable, structs composed of them (structs with fields having slice types) are also not comparable.</p>

<p>You may use <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/reflect/#DeepEqual" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>reflect.DeepEqual()</code></a> for this. Example:</p>

<pre><code>type Foo struct {
    A []int
    B []string
}

f := Foo{}
fmt.Println("Zero:", reflect.DeepEqual(f, Foo{}))
f.A = []int{1}
fmt.Println("Zero:", reflect.DeepEqual(f, Foo{}))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/qQSydTe4uk" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>Zero: true
Zero: false
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T06:07:36.327" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45700232      <row Id="45700232" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45709116" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45700232" CreationDate="2017-08-16T08:53:26.813" Score="0" Body="<p>Here is your "while" loop. Go simply doesn't have a while loop because it's <code>for</code> loop already covers that.</p>

<pre><code>for !(intN &gt; 0 &amp;&amp; intN &lt;= 12) {
    fmt.Println("Enter a number (0 &lt; N &lt;= 12): ")
    fmt.Scanf("%d", &amp;intN)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Not sure if you wanted the 12 included or not (the print statement suggests it should be included, so I did include it).</p>

<p>Hope this helps.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T08:53:26.813" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45705930      <row Id="45705930" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45709646" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45705930" CreationDate="2017-08-16T09:17:56.637" Score="1" Body="<p>Here some ways to access the data:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"

    "github.com/yvasiyarov/php_session_decoder/php_serialize"
)

func main() {
    // this string is generated from php code
    str := `a:3:{s:4:"name";s:3:"tom";s:3:"age";s:2:"23";s:7:"friends";a:2:{i:0;a:1:{s:4:"name";s:5:"jerry";}i:1;a:1:{s:4:"name";s:4:"jack";}}}`

    decoder := php_serialize.NewUnSerializer(str)

    result, err := decoder.Decode()
    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Println(result)

    // simple assert
    t := result.(php_serialize.PhpArray)
    // use php_seriale build in function to get string
    strVal := php_serialize.PhpValueString(t["name"])
    fmt.Println(strVal)

    // type switch in case of different valid types
    switch t := result.(type) {
    default:
        fmt.Printf("unexpected type %T\n", t) // %T prints whatever type t has
    case php_serialize.PhpArray:
        fmt.Println(t)
        fmt.Println(t["name"])
        fmt.Println(t["age"])

        // should be done recursively...
        switch f := t["friends"].(type) {
        default:
            fmt.Printf("unexpected type %T\n", f) // %T prints whatever type t has
        case php_serialize.PhpArray:
            fmt.Println(f)
            fmt.Println(f[0])
            fmt.Println(f[1])
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>I hope this gives you some ideas.</p>

<h3>Basic concept</h3>

<ul>
<li><code>php_serialize</code> has built in functions to convert primitives.</li>
<li>Variable structures are represented with built in types which need to be used to access the structure.</li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T09:17:56.637" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45710188      <row Id="45710188" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45710447" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45710188" CreationDate="2017-08-16T09:55:56.957" Score="2" Body="<p>This is not possible. The best you can do is use a constructor method:</p>

<pre><code>type abc struct {
    prop1 int
    prop2 int  // default value: 0
}

func New(prop1 int) abc {
    return abc{
        prop1: prop1,
        prop2: someDefaultValue,
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>But also note that all values in Go <em>automatically</em> default to their zero value. The zero value for an <code>int</code> is already <code>0</code>. So if the default value you want is literally <code>0</code>, you already get that for free.  You only need a constructor if you want some default value other than the zero value for a type.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T09:55:56.957" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45637267      <row Id="45637267" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45715958" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45637267" CreationDate="2017-08-16T14:13:49.937" Score="1" Body="<p>Try <code>*[]*VM.VirtualMachineCdrom</code> (or just <code>*[]VM.VirtualMachineCdrom</code> if you don't actually need the elements to be pointers). A <code>nil</code> slice == a zero length slice, but a <code>nil</code> <em>pointer to a slice</em> does not.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T14:13:49.937" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45719297      <row Id="45719297" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45719395" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45719297" CreationDate="2017-08-16T17:10:07.663" Score="4" Body="<p>Both your JSON input, and your "manual" example are using maps of slices, not slices of maps.  Change your target type to <code>map[string][]string</code> and you should be good to go:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "encoding/json"
)

var file = []byte(`{
    "recordType1": [
        "field1", "field2", "field3", "field4", "field5"
    ],
    "recordType2": [
        "field1", "field2", "field3", "field4", "field5", "field6", "field7"
    ]
}`)

func main() {
    output := map[string][]string{}
    if err := json.Unmarshal(file, &amp;output); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    fmt.Println(output)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Produces the following output:</p>

<pre><code>map[recordType1:[field1 field2 field3 field4 field5] recordType2:[field1 field2 field3 field4 field5 field6 field7]]
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/q7noWrlzy9" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Playground link</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T17:10:07.663" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45721470      <row Id="45721470" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45721570" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45721470" CreationDate="2017-08-16T19:29:57.867" Score="4" Body="<p>If you want to control how a type is unmarshaled, you can implement <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/#Unmarshaler" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>json.Unmarshaler</code></a></p>

<p>Since a map allows you to tell the difference between an unset value, and a <code>null</code> value, unmarshaling first into a generic <code>map[string]interface{}</code> will allow you to inspect the values without tokenizing the JSON. </p>

<pre><code>type Item struct {
    Value *int
}


func (i *Item) UnmarshalJSON(b []byte) error {
    tmp := make(map[string]interface{})

    err := json.Unmarshal(b, &amp;tmp)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }

    val, ok := tmp["Value"]
    if ok &amp;&amp; val == nil {
        return errors.New("Value cannot be nil")

    }
    if !ok {
        return nil
    }

    f, ok := val.(float64)
    if !ok {
        return fmt.Errorf("unexpected type %T for Value", val)
    }

    n := int(f)
    i.Value = &amp;n
    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/MNDsQpfEJA" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/MNDsQpfEJA</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-08-16T20:03:12.277" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T20:03:12.277" CommentCount="10" />

question:
45722785      <row Id="45722785" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45722910" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45722785" CreationDate="2017-08-16T20:59:30.190" Score="3" Body="<p>The scratch image contains nothing. No files. But actually, that can work to your advantage. It turns out, Go binaries built with <code>CGO_ENABLED=0</code> require absolutely nothing, other than what they use. There are a couple things to keep in mind:</p>

<ul>
<li>With <code>CGO_ENABLED=0</code>, you can't use any C code. Actually not too hard.</li>
<li>With <code>CGO_ENABLED=0</code>, your app will not use the system DNS resolver. I don't think it does by default anyways because it's blocking and Go's native DNS resolver is non-blocking.</li>
<li>Your app may depend on some things that are not present:

<ul>
<li>Apps that make HTTPS calls (as in, to other services, i.e. Amazon S3, or the Stripe API) will need ca-certs in order to confirm HTTPS certificate authenticity. This also has to be updated over time. This is not needed for serving HTTPS content.</li>
<li>Apps that need timezone awareness will need the timezone info files.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<p>A nice alternative to <code>FROM scratch</code> is <code>FROM alpine</code>, which will include a base Alpine image - which is very tiny (5 MiB I believe) and includes musl libc, which is compatible with Go and will allow you to link to C libraries as well as compile without setting <code>CGO_ENABLED=0</code>. You can also leverage the fact that alpine is regularly updated, using its tzinfo and ca-certs.</p>

<p>(It's worth noting that the overhead of Docker layers is amortized a bit because of Docker's deduplication, though of course that is negated by how often your base image is updated. Still, it helps sell the idea of using the quite small Alpine image.)</p>

<p>You may not need tzinfo or ca-certs now, but it's better to be safe than sorry; you can accidentally add a dependency without realizing it breaks your build. So I recommend using <code>alpine</code> as your base. <code>alpine:latest</code> should be fine.</p>

<p>Bonus: If you want the advantages of reproducible builds inside Docker, but with small image sizes, you can use the new Docker multi-stage builds available in Docker 17.06+.</p>

<p>It works a bit like this:</p>

<pre><code>FROM golang:alpine
ADD . /go/src/github.com/some/gorepo  # may need some go getting if you don't vendor
RUN go build -o /app github.com/some/gorepo

FROM scratch  # or alpine
COPY --from=0 /app /app
ENTRYPOINT ["/app"]
</code></pre>

<p>(I apologize if I've made any mistakes, I'm typing that from memory.)</p>

<p>Note that when using <code>FROM scratch</code> you must use the exec form of <code>ENTRYPOINT</code>, because the shell form won't work (it depends on the Docker image having <code>/bin/sh</code>, which it won't.) This will work fine in Alpine.</p>
" OwnerUserId="610744" LastEditorUserId="610744" LastEditDate="2017-08-16T21:03:31.403" LastActivityDate="2017-08-16T21:03:31.403" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45655516      <row Id="45655516" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45725592" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45655516" CreationDate="2017-08-17T02:13:46.003" Score="1" Body="<p>It seems the problem is related to including this attribute in some of your elements:</p>

<pre><code>xml:lang="en"
</code></pre>

<p>For example in:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;OrganizationName xml:lang="en"&gt;Your Identities&lt;/OrganizationName&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>If you remove the <code>xml:lang="en"</code> for all elements, the generated signature turns to be valid and correctly verified.</p>

<p>As far as I can see, when you include that attribute, the elements written on the actual XML document seem to turn into this:</p>

<pre><code>&lt;OrganizationName xmlns:xml="http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace" xml:lang="en"&gt;Your Identities&lt;/OrganizationName&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>And that makes the signature invalid.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T02:13:46.003" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45666306      <row Id="45666306" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45725831" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45666306" CreationDate="2017-08-17T02:46:14.040" Score="0" Body="<p>Thanks for the responses but they were not satisfactory. I had to do some reading on this topic.</p>

<p><strong>The correct answer is that the login prompt/dialog is a response built into the user-agent/browser and cannot be changed by the server. This also explains why some browsers show realm while others don't.</strong></p>

<p>According to Wikipedia Basic access authentication all the server does is:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>When the server wants the user agent to authenticate itself towards the server, it must respond appropriately to unauthenticated requests.</p>
  
  <p>Unauthenticated requests should return a response whose header contains a HTTP 401 Unauthorized status[4] and a WWW-Authenticate field.[5]</p>
  
  <p>The WWW-Authenticate field for basic authentication (used most often) is constructed as following:</p>
  
  <p>WWW-Authenticate: Basic realm="User Visible Realm"</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="4984574" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T02:46:14.040" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45725795      <row Id="45725795" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45725928" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45725795" CreationDate="2017-08-17T02:59:49.917" Score="3" Body="<p>Try this.</p>

<pre><code>func splitOutput(outs []byte) {
    outputStr := string(outs[:])
    split := strings.Split(outputStr, "
")
    fmt.Printf("Splitted result: %q
", split)
    for index, line := range split {
        fmt.Printf("Line %d: %s
", index, line)
        if len(line) &gt;= 9 &amp;&amp; line[0:9] == "Users of " {
            lineSplit := strings.Split(line, " ")
            if len(lineSplit) == 16 {
                name := lineSplit[2]
                name = name[0:len(name) - 1]
                fmt.Printf("%s %s %s
", name, lineSplit[6], lineSplit[12])
            }
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Test it online: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/m6JIBytU0m" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/m6JIBytU0m</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="6482303" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T02:59:49.917" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45718580      <row Id="45718580" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45732044" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45718580" CreationDate="2017-08-17T09:58:57.097" Score="1" Body="<p>To answer the "<strong>My Real Question: How can I customize the behaviour of mgo before upsert?</strong>" - you can customise bson marshalling by defining <a href="https://godoc.org/labix.org/v2/mgo/bson#Getter" rel="nofollow noreferrer">bson Getter</a> to the model. </p>

<p>To illustrate how it works, lets simplify the model to avoid nested documents:</p>

<pre><code>type Game struct {
    ID int `bson:"_id"`
    Name string
    Stats [] float64
}
</code></pre>

<p>With newGame as following:</p>

<pre><code>newGame := Game{
    ID: 1,
    Name: "foo",
    Stats: []{5.0}
}
</code></pre>

<p>The update <code>col.UpsertId(newGame.ID, newGame)</code> by default marshals <code>newGame</code> into JSON, producing mongo query like:</p>

<pre><code>update({_id:1}, {name: "foo", stats: [5]}, {upsert: true});
</code></pre>

<p>To make use of <code>$set</code>, <code>$push</code> etc, you can define a custom bson getter. E.g.</p>

<pre><code>func (g Game) GetBSON() (interface{}, error) {
    return bson.M{
        "$set": bson.M{"name": g.Name}, 
        "$push": bson.M{"stats": bson.M{"$each": g.Stats}},
    }, nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>So the update <code>col.UpsertId(newGame.ID, newGame)</code> will produce a mongodb query </p>

<pre><code>update({_id:1}, {$set: {name: "foo"}, $push: {stats: {$each: [5]}}}, {upsert: true});
</code></pre>

<p>To make it crystal clear - the custom marshaler will be used in all mgo queries, so you probably don't want to define it directly to the model, but to its derivative to use in upsert operations only:</p>

<pre><code>type UpdatedGame struct {
    Game
}

func (g UpdatedGame) GetBSON() (interface{}, error) {
    return bson.M{....}
}

.....

newGame := Game{
    ID: 1,
    Name: "foo",
    Stats: []{5.0}
}

col.UpsertId(newGame.ID, UpdatedGame{newGame})
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1110423" LastEditorUserId="1110423" LastEditDate="2017-08-17T10:31:40.097" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T10:31:40.097" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45727904      <row Id="45727904" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45732913" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45727904" CreationDate="2017-08-17T10:39:58.113" Score="1" Body="<p>Your problem is here:</p>

<pre><code>//push single code on the block
func (s *SmartContract) pushCode(APIstub shim.ChaincodeStubInterface, args []string) sc.Response {

    hsCode := args[0]
    lenChk := checkHashLen(hsCode)
    if lenChk == false {
        fmt.Println("Length should be 32")
        continue
    }
    codeBytes, _ := json.Marshal(hsCode)
    APIstub.PutState(strconv.FormatInt(makeTimestamp(), 10), codeBytes)
    return shim.Success(nil)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The error explains what is going wrong. You're using the keyword continue when not in a for loop, this function doesn't contain a for loop. </p>

<p>initCodeLedger contains a for loop, so you are getting distracted by that, but that's not the line no given in the error which is around line 86/87/88. Ideally post code on play.golang.org if asking a question like this. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T10:39:58.113" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45734988      <row Id="45734988" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45735476" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45734988" CreationDate="2017-08-17T12:43:50.817" Score="1" Body="<p>This is because your <code>elec</code> and <code>gas</code> fields are lowercase. <code>json.Unmarshal</code> will only touch the fields starting with an uppercase. Renaming them to <code>Elec</code> and <code>Gas</code> should probably fix the issue.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6444852" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T12:43:50.817" CommentCount="1" />

<row Id="45735956" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45734686" CreationDate="2017-08-17T13:06:16.887" Score="1" Body="<p>Perhaps your server is on port 8086 and the tls challenge is on port 443?
 Try instead serving on port 443 (You may have to setcap your binary to allow it to do this).</p>
