question:
45737715      <row Id="45737715" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45737921" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45737715" CreationDate="2017-08-17T14:30:11.743" Score="1" Body="<p><code>sqlx.Open</code> return a <code>sqlx.DB</code> struct (<a href="https://github.com/jmoiron/sqlx/blob/d9bd385d68c068f1fabb5057e3dedcbcbb039d0f/sqlx.go#L238" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a> the definition) that is different from the DB struct definition inside the <code>package databqase/sql</code>.<br>
Change the <code>Conn</code> type to <code>sqlx.DB</code> and it should work.</p>
" OwnerUserId="2606098" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T14:30:11.743" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45739102      <row Id="45739102" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45740350" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45739102" CreationDate="2017-08-17T16:20:36.903" Score="1" Body="<p>The way you're reading the result, it has no idea what the JSON field names are. In order for it to use those tags, it must actually deserialize into the struct where the tags have been specified. When you do:</p>

<pre><code>    resp := []bson.M{}
    db.C(common.C_TRAINING).Pipe(pipeline).All(&amp;resp)
</code></pre>

<p>You're explicitly telling <code>mgo</code> to return BSON results. The object you pass in (a slice of <code>bson.M</code>) has no json tags on it. In order to control the serialization to JSON, you must pass a struct with the JSON tags specified to <code>All</code>:</p>

<pre><code>    resp := []Training
    db.C(common.C_TRAINING).Pipe(pipeline).All(&amp;resp)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T16:20:36.903" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45741018      <row Id="45741018" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45741122" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45741018" CreationDate="2017-08-17T17:02:03.190" Score="5" Body="<p>Two problems. First, you've created a race condition. By closing over the loop variable, you're sharing it between the thread running the loop and the thread running the goroutine, which is causing your described problem: by the time the goroutine that was started for the first URL tries to run, the value of the variable has changed. You need to either copy it to a local variable, or pass it as an argument, e.g.:</p>

<pre><code>for _, url := range urls {
    go func(url string) {
     fmt.Println(IsReachable(url)) 
     }(url)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Second, you said you wanted to display them "in order", which is not a goal generally compatible with concurrency/parallism, because you cannot control the order of parallel operations. If you want them in order, you should do them in order in a single thread. Otherwise, you'll have to collect the results, wait for all them to come back, then sort the results back into the desired order before printing them.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastEditorUserId="1080064" LastEditDate="2017-08-17T17:05:12.863" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T17:05:12.863" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45741209      <row Id="45741209" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45741268" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45741209" CreationDate="2017-08-17T17:12:04.560" Score="8" Body="<p>This:</p>

<pre><code>for range &lt;-md{
</code></pre>

<p>is not the same as:</p>

<pre><code>for range md{
</code></pre>

<p>The latter ranges over the channel (what you want), while the former ranges over <em>the value received from the channel when the loop starts</em>, which happens to be a two-element array, hence the two executions. You're also ignoring the value received from the channel in the <code>for</code> statement, and reading from it <em>again</em> in the loop body, ignoring every other message on the channel (though this makes no difference in the example, since every value is identical, it would make a significant difference in practice). What you really want is:</p>

<pre><code>for foo := range md{
    fmt.Println(foo)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Here's a working version of your playground example, slightly modified to avoid "program took too long" errors because in its current form it never stops: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/RSUJFvluU5" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/RSUJFvluU5</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T17:12:04.560" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45740042      <row Id="45740042" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45741285" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45740042" CreationDate="2017-08-17T17:12:47.370" Score="0" Body="<p>Here an example based on your code:</p>

<pre><code>func sqlQueryHandler(response http.ResponseWriter, request *http.Request) {
    var (
        userName   = getUserName(request)
        sqlCommand = request.FormValue("sqlQuery")
    )

    db, err := sql.Open("mysql", userName)
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Fprintf(response, "

An error occured during your MySQL command: %s", err)
        // if you panic you stop here anyway. no else needed
        panic(err)
    }
    rows, err := db.Query(sqlCommand)
    if err != nil {
        http.Redirect(response, request, "/error", 302)
        // return, so no else is needed
        return
    }

    if err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
    defer rows.Close()
    for rows.Next() {
        var (
            name string
            age  int
        )
        if err := rows.Scan(&amp;name, &amp;age); err != nil {
            panic(err)
        }
        fmt.Printf("%s is %d
", name, age)
    }
    if err := rows.Err(); err != nil {
        panic(err)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>There are several problems however with this approach:</p>

<ul>
<li>You are passing the sql from outside the server. Anyone accessing this can read all the data from your server.</li>
<li>One of Go's strengths is being a typed language. Here you are building a general sql query function which contradicts the <code>typed language</code> paradigm. You can write general function dealing with differently structured data (like <code>json.Unmarshal()</code>) -- but especially early in programming go you shouldn't.</li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="6220193" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T17:12:47.370" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45744165      <row Id="45744165" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45744248" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45744165" CreationDate="2017-08-17T20:16:54.283" Score="5" Body="<p>A mutex does not need initialization.</p>

<p>Also that could just be var mutex sync.Mutex, there's no need for a pointer, same for the int values, there's no need to set them to 0, so that example you found could be improved. In all these cases the zero value is fine. </p>

<p>See this bit of effective go: </p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#data" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/effective_go.html#data</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Since the memory returned by new is zeroed, it's helpful to arrange
  when designing your data structures that the zero value of each type
  can be used without further initialization. This means a user of the
  data structure can create one with new and get right to work. For
  example, the documentation for bytes.Buffer states that "the zero
  value for Buffer is an empty buffer ready to use." Similarly,
  sync.Mutex does not have an explicit constructor or Init method.
  Instead, the zero value for a sync.Mutex is defined to be an unlocked
  mutex.</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastEditorUserId="1601137" LastEditDate="2017-08-17T20:20:59.913" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T20:20:59.913" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45744683      <row Id="45744683" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45744803" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45744683" CreationDate="2017-08-17T20:55:12.980" Score="4" Body="<p>You need to derefence the pointer:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
)

func main() {
    count := 0
    for i:=0; i&lt;10; i++ {
        counting(&amp;count)
    }
}

func counting(count *int) {
    fmt.Println(*count)
    *count++
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1412534" LastEditorUserId="53212" LastEditDate="2017-08-17T23:27:49.320" LastActivityDate="2017-08-17T23:27:49.320" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45747849      <row Id="45747849" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45747875" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45747849" CreationDate="2017-08-18T03:07:07.370" Score="5" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#WaitGroup" rel="nofollow noreferrer">sync.WaitGroup</a> is what you want here. You <code>wg.Add(1)</code> before starting each goroutine (or <code>wg.Add(n)</code> if you know the count up front), <code>wg.Done()</code> in each routine when finished, and  <code>wg.Wait()</code> in <code>main</code> to wait untill all finish. The linked docs have an example, and as the docs note, copying it won't do what you want; you may want to make the variable a pointer (<code>wg := new(sync.WaitGroup)</code>).</p>
" OwnerUserId="2714852" LastEditorUserId="2714852" LastEditDate="2017-08-18T03:17:56.030" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T03:17:56.030" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45749030      <row Id="45749030" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45751266" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45749030" CreationDate="2017-08-18T07:48:05.383" Score="1" Body="<p>You need to use <code>$cond</code> to do conditional counting. For example the following counts all tests, failed ones and successful ones in one step:</p>

<pre><code>o2 := bson.M{
    "$group" :bson.M{
        "_id": "$channel",
        "Total": bson.M{
            "$sum": 1,
        },
        "Success": bson.M{"$sum": bson.M{
            "$cond": []interface{}{
                bson.M{ "$eq": []interface{}{"$teststatus", "Pass"}},
                1, 0,
            },
        }},
        "Fail": bson.M{"$sum": bson.M{
            "$cond": []interface{}{
                bson.M{"$eq": []interface{}{"$teststatus", "Fail"}},
                1, 0,
            },
        }},
    },
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-18T11:59:16.003" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T11:59:16.003" CommentCount="7" />

question:
45751608      <row Id="45751608" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45751833" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45751608" CreationDate="2017-08-18T08:16:42.340" Score="5" Body="<p>I would really take the <a href="https://tour.golang.org/welcome/1" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Tour</a> to get a feeling of the language and its basic syntax first.</p>

<p>The type declaration you quoted only contains the <em>fields</em> of the struct, but not its <em>methods</em>. Methods are defined elsewhere, like functions but with a <em>receiver</em> added which designates the type they belong to. For example the definition of <code>Client.Get()</code> method is this:</p>

<pre><code>func (c *Client) Get(url string) (resp *Response, err error) {
    req, err := NewRequest("GET", url, nil)
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    return c.Do(req)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The part before the method name is called the receiver, and that designates the type the method belogns to (<code>*Client</code> in this example). See <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_declarations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Method declarations</a> for more details.</p>

<p>The <code>&amp;</code> is an <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">address operator</a>, it takes the address of its operand. In this case the local variable <code>client</code> will be of type <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/#Client" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>*http.Client</code></a>. <code>http.Client{}</code> is a <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Composite_literals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">composite literal</a> which creates a value of the struct type <code>http.Client</code>, and <code>&amp;</code> takes the address of the anonymous variable where this struct value is stored:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Taking the address</a> of a composite literal generates a pointer to a unique <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Variables" rel="nofollow noreferrer">variable</a> initialized with the literal's value.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>It is used so that the <code>client</code> variable will be a pointer to an <code>http.Client</code> value, one that is encouraged to be shared and reused:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The Client's Transport typically has internal state (cached TCP connections), so Clients should be reused instead of created as needed. Clients are safe for concurrent use by multiple goroutines.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>And if <code>client</code> is a pointer, you are free to pass it around to other functions, only the pointer value will be copied, not the pointed <code>http.Client</code> struct, so the struct itself (the <code>http.Client</code> value) will be reused. Should you not use a pointer, if you would pass it to other functions, the struct itself would be copied and not reused.</p>

<p>Note that in this simple example it doesn't really matter, as even though all methods of <code>http.Client</code> are declared with pointer receiver, you can still call pointer methods on non-pointer variables, as <code>client.Get()</code> would be a shorthand for <code>(&amp;client).Get()</code>. This is mentioned in <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Calls" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Spec: Calls:</a></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If <code>x</code> is <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Address_operators" rel="nofollow noreferrer">addressable</a> and <code>&amp;x</code>'s method set contains <code>m</code>, <code>x.m()</code> is shorthand for <code>(&amp;x).m()</code>.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So even though the <code>&amp;</code> address operator is not needed in this simple example, it's good to keep the habit of using it, should the example grow or should you write code where this does matter (e.g. you pass around the created client).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-18T13:48:39.487" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T13:48:39.487" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45753397      <row Id="45753397" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45753506" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45753397" CreationDate="2017-08-18T09:42:18.857" Score="5" Body="<p>By calling the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/#Seed" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>rand.Seed()</code></a> function, passing it a (random) seed (typically the current unix timestamp). Quoting from <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/math/rand/" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>math/rand</code></a> package doc:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Top-level functions, such as Float64 and Int, use a default shared Source that produces a deterministic sequence of values each time a program is run. Use the Seed function to initialize the default Source if different behavior is required for each run. </p>
</blockquote>

<p>Example:</p>

<pre><code>rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
</code></pre>

<p>If <code>rand.Seed()</code> is not called, the generator behaves as if seeded by 1:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Seed uses the provided seed value to initialize the default Source to a deterministic state. If Seed is not called, the generator behaves as if seeded by Seed(1).</p>
</blockquote>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-18T09:57:26.430" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T09:57:26.430" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45751869      <row Id="45751869" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45754815" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45751869" CreationDate="2017-08-18T10:47:07.313" Score="2" Body="<p>This is a known issue, see this thread:</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20239" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20239</a></p>

<p>Hopefully they will fix it soon but for now it sounds like adding a short delay in your test is the simplest solution - it probably doesn't come up in real world use much because you won't trigger a shutdown so soon after starting. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T10:47:07.313" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45746753      <row Id="45746753" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45757940" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45746753" CreationDate="2017-08-18T13:31:44.873" Score="1" Body="<p>If you want your test to represent reality, you need to use it in the same manner that you do outside of tests. In this case you're not reading any of the responses, and the transport happens to be preventing lost connections because it's discarding them as quickly as possible since they can't be reused.</p>

<p>Reading the response will use the connection, and get it into a state where it's "leaked". You also need to properly handle errors in all cases, and you always need to <code>Close()</code> the response body. The pattern to handle an http response and make sure it's closed is very simple, and doesn't necessarily require testing (see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33238518/what-could-happen-if-i-dont-close-response-body-in-golang/33238755#33238755">What could happen if I don&#39;t close response.Body in golang?</a>)</p>

<pre><code>    resp, err := GetWithTimeout(s.URL)
    if err != nil {
        t.Fatal(err)
    }
    ioutil.ReadAll(resp.Body)
    resp.Body.Close()
</code></pre>

<p>This is arguably of limited usefulness, since the most common bugs would result from improper error and response handling, and you're not testing that because the test needs to do it correctly in the first place.</p>

<p>The remaining problem here is that your <code>GetWithTimeout</code> method returns an error value <em>and</em> a valid http response, which contradicts the http package documentation as well as most user's expectations. If you're going to insert an error, it would be better to also handle the response at the same point to ensure the body is closed and discarded.</p>

<p>Finally, most of <code>GetWithTimeout</code> is superfluous, since not only is creating Transports every time incorrect, but creating an http.Client every request is usually unnecessary as they are meant to be reused and are safe for concurrent use.</p>
" OwnerUserId="32880" LastEditorUserId="32880" LastEditDate="2017-08-18T15:20:05.723" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T15:20:05.723" CommentCount="16" />

question:
45756011      <row Id="45756011" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45758022" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45756011" CreationDate="2017-08-18T13:35:51.017" Score="5" Body="<p>You can create structs to mimic your json structure and then decode your json.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bytes"
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
    "log"
)

type Example struct {
    Type    string   `json:"type,omitempty"`
    Subsets []Subset `json:"subsets,omitempty"`
}

type Subset struct {
    Addresses []Address `json:"addresses,omitempty"`
}

type Address struct {
    IP string `json:"IP,omitempty"`
}

    func main() {

    m := []byte(`{"type":"example","data": {"name": "abc","labels": {"key": "value"}},"subsets": [{"addresses": [{"ip": "192.168.103.178"}],"ports": [{"port": 80}]}]}`)

    r := bytes.NewReader(m)
    decoder := json.NewDecoder(r)

    val := &amp;Example{}
    err := decoder.Decode(val)

    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    // If you want to read a response body
    // decoder := json.NewDecoder(res.Body)
    // err := decoder.Decode(val)

    // Subsets is a slice so you must loop over it
    for _, s := range val.Subsets {
        // within Subsets, address is also a slice
        // then you can access each IP from type Address
        for _, a := range s.Addresses {
            fmt.Println(a.IP)
        }
    }

}
</code></pre>

<p>The output would be:
    <code>192.168.103.178</code></p>

<p>By decoding this to a struct, you can loop over any slice and not limit yourself to one IP</p>

<p>Example here:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/sWA9qBWljA" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/sWA9qBWljA</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1793374" LastEditorUserId="1793374" LastEditDate="2017-08-18T19:37:03.337" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T19:37:03.337" CommentCount="8" />

question:
45755110      <row Id="45755110" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45758094" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45755110" CreationDate="2017-08-18T13:39:19.947" Score="3" Body="<p>As Tim Cooper stated in his comment, you're comparing two different representations of the same data. <code>aligncheck</code> tells you how much space is occupied in memory (heap/stack) by an instance of a struct, which is affected by struct field alignment and padding, for reasons <a href="https://dave.cheney.net/2015/10/09/padding-is-hard" rel="nofollow noreferrer">explained at length elsewhere</a>.</p>

<p><code>binary.Read</code> and <code>.Write</code>, on the other hand, are not trying to store objects in memory with boundary alignment; they're just writing a stream of contiguous bytes. Therefor these will output the same size struct regardless of the order of fields, and it will always be the minimum size of the struct (because there is no padding added).</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T13:39:19.947" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45764315      <row Id="45764315" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45764558" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45764315" CreationDate="2017-08-18T20:23:45.933" Score="2" Body="<p>What decides what the backend is? That should help guide you. I've done something similar with support for multiple databases on a project, and what I did was basically:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>config</code> package reads in config file, which determines what backend is being used</li>
<li><code>store</code> package offers the generic interface and has a function that takes a config, and returns an implementation</li>
<li><code>server</code> package references only the interface</li>
<li><code>main</code> package reads the config, passes it to the factory function in <code>store</code>, then injects the result into the server on creation</li>
</ul>

<p>So when I create my server (which actually uses the data store), I pass the config to the factory function in <code>store</code>, which returns an interface, and then inject that into the server. The only thing that has to know about the different concrete implementations is the same package that exposes the interface and factory; the <code>server</code>, <code>config</code>, and <code>main</code> packages see it as a black box.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-18T20:23:45.933" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45765046      <row Id="45765046" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45765166" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45765046" CreationDate="2017-08-18T21:16:38.113" Score="2" Body="<p>You need to either pre-size the slice with</p>

<pre><code>ma := make(movingaverage.MovingAverage, 5)
</code></pre>

<p>Which gives a slice of capacity 5 and length 5 with each entry set to the zero value </p>

<p>Better though to initialise it as you did but then to add new entries with</p>

<pre><code>ma = append(ma, movingaverage.New(15)) 
</code></pre>

<p>If you know how big your eventual slice will be you can pre-allocate the underlying array with </p>

<pre><code>ma := make(movingaverage.MovingAverage, 0, 5)
</code></pre>

<p>which will give you a slice of length 0 but capacity 5 so you don't have to do repeated memory allocations and moves</p>
" OwnerUserId="176300" LastEditorUserId="176300" LastEditDate="2017-08-19T11:20:01.793" LastActivityDate="2017-08-19T11:20:01.793" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45766572      <row Id="45766572" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45766707" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45766572" CreationDate="2017-08-19T01:02:08.337" Score="6" Body="<p>If you are timing an entire function, then you can use <code>defer</code> to eliminate some of the repetitive code.</p>

<pre><code>func elapsed(what string) func() {
    start := time.Now()
    return func() {
        fmt.Printf("%s took %v\n", what, time.Since(start))
    }
}

func main() {
    defer elapsed("page")()
    time.Sleep(time.Second * 2)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/8sKNmOdoEM" rel="noreferrer">playground example</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-08-19T01:02:08.337" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45767208      <row Id="45767208" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45767259" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45767208" CreationDate="2017-08-19T03:11:08.230" Score="4" Body="<p>You're not misunderstanding anything really, you just can't do that. The <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Passing_arguments_to_..._parameters" rel="nofollow noreferrer">spec</a> says:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If the final argument is assignable to a slice type <code>[]T</code>, it may be passed unchanged as the value for a <code>...T</code> parameter if the argument is followed by <code>...</code>. In this case no new slice is created.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>In short, <code>p...</code> can only be used as the <em>entire</em> variadic part of the arguments, because when you do that, it simply re-uses <code>p</code> as the parameter slice within the function, instead of making a new one.</p>

<p>If you want to add some arguments at the beginning, you would have to construct your own slice with all of the arguments first, something like:</p>

<pre><code>p := []string{"a", "b", "c"}
p2 := append([]string{"d"}, p...)
fmt.Println(path.Join(p2...))
</code></pre>

<p>which works alright and prints "d/a/b/c".</p>
" OwnerUserId="152948" LastEditorUserId="152948" LastEditDate="2017-08-19T03:33:50.470" LastActivityDate="2017-08-19T03:33:50.470" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45771734      <row Id="45771734" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45772091" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45771734" CreationDate="2017-08-19T13:26:23.553" Score="3" Body="<p>Your path when cloning the source must be on the golang PATH like : 
<code>/home/gujarat/golang/src/github.com/lucapette/fakedata</code></p>

<p>as you can see my Path to golang path is : <code>/home/gujarat/golang/</code>.
You can also print your golang path in your terminal by entering : <code>$GOPATH</code>.</p>

<p>And the <code>git clone</code> should be in the following the exact as above path : <code>src/github.com/lucapette/</code>.</p>

<pre><code>cd $GOPATH/src/github.com/
mkdir lucaptte
cd lucapette
git clone https://github.com/lucapette/fakedata.git
</code></pre>

<p>When you are running the <code>make</code> command which trigger <code>go build</code> this command will look the <code>$GOPATH</code> and your <code>$GOROOT</code> folder.</p>

question:
45776043      <row Id="45776043" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45776499" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45776043" CreationDate="2017-08-19T21:35:39.790" Score="2" Body="<p>Export var:</p>

<pre><code>CC_TEST_REPORTER_ID=...
</code></pre>

<p>Run:</p>

<pre><code>for pkg in $(go list ./... | grep -v vendor); do
    go test -coverprofile=$(echo $pkg | tr / -).cover $pkg
done
echo "mode: set" &gt; c.out
grep -h -v "^mode:" ./*.cover &gt;&gt; c.out
rm -f *.cover

./cc-test-reporter after-build
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="551932" LastActivityDate="2017-08-19T21:35:39.790" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45777113      <row Id="45777113" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45777356" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45777113" CreationDate="2017-08-20T00:11:50.847" Score="5" Body="<p>This is not currently possible with the go-sqlite3 library. <a href="https://github.com/mattn/go-sqlite3/blob/1828334c4a7937cf4d957e36e995b9d6ba4fc535/sqlite3.go#L689-L693" rel="noreferrer">Looking at the source</a>, you can see <code>SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE</code> is always passed to the open function:</p>

<pre><code>rv := C._sqlite3_open_v2(name, &amp;db,
    C.SQLITE_OPEN_FULLMUTEX|
        C.SQLITE_OPEN_READWRITE|
        C.SQLITE_OPEN_CREATE,
    nil)
</code></pre>

<p>I would suggest you <a href="https://github.com/mattn/go-sqlite3/issues/new" rel="noreferrer">open a ticket</a> on the package to add such functionality.</p>

<p>In the mean time, you could add the following code before your DB is created (keep in mind that a race condition exists, which is why you should still request this feature in the library itself):</p>

<pre><code>_, err := os.Stat("db.sqlite3")
if os.IsNotExist(err) {
    panic("database doesn't exist")
}
// TODO: create db
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T00:11:50.847" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45776238      <row Id="45776238" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45777570" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45776238" CreationDate="2017-08-20T00:58:31.007" Score="3" Body="<p>The other answer here advocates putting each microservice into its own repository. There may be valid reasons for splitting things up that way, but there may be equally valid reasons from wanting to keep everything in one repository as well (it really depends on your project / circumstances)</p>

<p>If you want all the code in one repository, you can- you just need to follow Go's package rules. (this is a good read: <a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html#Workspaces" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/code.html#Workspaces</a>)</p>

<p>If you have a mix of commands and libraries, the directory structure you proposed in your question comes close, but you probably don't need the <code>src</code> directories in there. Here's an example of how a directory structure within a repo with libraries and commands might look:</p>

<pre><code>lib1/
-- some.go
-- source.go
lib2/
-- more.go
-- source.go
cmd/
-- microservice1/
   -- main.go
-- microservice2/
   -- anothermain.go
</code></pre>

<p>To use this repository, you would clone it inside a Go workspace on your system (see the link I shared above). Assuming your repository lives in github.com/mybiz/project, and your <code>GOPATH</code> was <code>~/go</code>, the workspace would look as follows:</p>

<pre><code>~/go/src/github.com/mybiz/
  -- project/
     &lt;clone repo in here&gt;
</code></pre>

<p>The file <code>cmd/microservice1/main.go</code> would include the library <code>lib1</code> via a path it expects it in relative to <code>$GOPATH/src</code> as follows:</p>

<pre><code>import "github.com/mybiz/project/lib1"
</code></pre>

<p>Now, your code has access to the exported symbols in that package using the package name declared in the files under <code>lib1</code>... usually just:</p>

<pre><code>package lib1
</code></pre>

<p>In <code>cmd/microservice1/main.go</code>, with the import above, you could use <code>lib1</code> symbols as follows:</p>

<pre><code>lib1.CallMe()
</code></pre>

<p>I hope that helps clear up how Go's directory structure works.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4648046" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T00:58:31.007" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45777038      <row Id="45777038" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45777951" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45777038" CreationDate="2017-08-20T02:36:28.633" Score="2" Body="<p>The <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Declarations_and_scope" rel="nofollow noreferrer">specification says</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The scope of the package name of an imported package is the file block of the file containing the import declaration.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Because imports do not have package scope, imports are not merged together and are required in each file that uses the import.</p>

<p>The scoping for imports is unrelated to how the compiler and linker load imported packages. These tools are smart enough to load any given package once.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastEditorUserId="5728991" LastEditDate="2017-08-20T14:54:44.610" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T14:54:44.610" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45781644      <row Id="45781644" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45782606" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45781644" CreationDate="2017-08-20T13:21:33.010" Score="0" Body="<p>Here is the solution which I found <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/12206584/5799860">here</a> (thank you <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/users/362021/malcolm">Malcolm</a>)</p>

<pre><code>func Readln(r *bufio.Reader) (string, error) {
    var (
        isPrefix = true
        err      error
        line, ln []byte
    )
    for isPrefix &amp;&amp; err == nil {
        line, isPrefix, err = r.ReadLine()
        ln = append(ln, line...)
    }
    return string(ln), err
}

func handle(s string) {
    //Do something with your string
}

func main() {
    c := exec.Command("sh", "./tmuxpipe.sh")
    err := c.Run()
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    f, err := os.Open("/tmp/tmuxpipe")
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Printf("error opening file: %v\n", err)
        os.Exit(1)
    }
    r := bufio.NewReader(f)
    s, e := Readln(r)
    for e == nil {
        handle(s)
        log.Println(s)
        s, e = Readln(r)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>here is the tmuxpipe.sh:</p>

<pre><code>mkfifo /tmp/tmuxpipe
tmux pipe-pane -o -t tmuxSession 'cat &gt;&gt; /tmp/tmuxpipe'
</code></pre>

<p>The reason I did not just use <code>exec.Command()</code> there, is because for some reason beyond my comprehension this:</p>

<pre><code>c := exec.Command("tmux", "pipe-pane", "-o", "-t", "tmuxSession", 'cat &gt;&gt; /tmp/tmuxpipe'") 
err := c.Run()
handleError(err)
</code></pre>

<p>did not work (for me).
There was no error occuring, but the output of the tmux session wasn't displayd either.</p>

<p>I hope this helps anybody</p>
" OwnerUserId="5799860" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T13:21:33.010" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45785639      <row Id="45785639" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45785661" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45785639" CreationDate="2017-08-20T18:43:28.337" Score="2" Body="<p>The outer dimension is just <code>len(x)</code> where <code>x</code> is the slice of slices you pass to the function (your example <code>[][]float64{{11, 5, 14, 1}, {11, 5, 14, 1}}</code>).
However, the inner dimensions are not guaranteed to be equal so you will have to go through each element and check what <code>len</code> they have.</p>

<p>If you have the guarantee than each element of <code>x</code> has the same number of elements, just find <code>len(x[0])</code> if <code>len(x) &gt; 0</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4236078" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T18:43:28.337" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45786042      <row Id="45786042" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45786193" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45786042" CreationDate="2017-08-20T19:47:35.743" Score="2" Body="<p><strong>1. For the first point, the infinite loop:</strong></p>

<p>Citing from <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Receive_operator" rel="nofollow noreferrer">golang language spec</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>A receive operation on a closed channel can always proceed
  immediately, yielding the element type's zero value after any
  previously sent values have been received.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So in this function</p>

<pre><code>func errorChannelWatch(ch chan error, list []error) {
    for {
        select {
        case err := &lt;- ch:

            list = append(list, err)
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>after ch gets closed this turns into an infinite loop adding <code>nil</code> values to <code>list</code>.</p>

<p>Try this instead:</p>

<pre><code>func errorChannelWatch(ch chan error, list []error) {
    for err := range ch {
            list = append(list, err)
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>2. For the second point, why you don't see anything in your error list:</strong></p>

<p>The problem is this call:</p>

<pre><code>errorChannel := make(chan error)
errorList := []error{}

go errorChannelWatch(errorChannel, errorList)
</code></pre>

<p>Here you hand <code>errorChannelWatch</code> the <code>errorList</code> as a value. So the slice <code>errorList</code> will not be changed by the function. What is changed, is the underlying array, as long as the <code>append</code> calls don't need to allocate a new one.</p>

<p>To remedy the situation, either hand a slice pointer to <code>errorChannelWatch</code> or rewrite it as a call to a closure, capturing
<code>errorList</code>.</p>

<p>For the first proposed solution, change <code>errorChannelWatch</code> to</p>

<pre><code>func errorChannelWatch(ch chan error, list *[]error) {
    for err := range ch {
            *list = append(*list, err)
    }
}    
</code></pre>

<p>and the call to</p>

<pre><code>errorChannel := make(chan error)
errorList := []error{}

go errorChannelWatch(errorChannel, &amp;errorList)
</code></pre>

<p>For the second proposed solution, just change the call to</p>

<pre><code>   errorChannel := make(chan error)
   errorList := []error{}

   go func() {
      for err := range errorChannel {
          errorList = append(errorList, err)
      }
   } () 
</code></pre>

<p><strong>3. A minor remark:</strong></p>

<p>One could think, that there is a synchronisation problem here:</p>

<pre><code>fileWaitGroup.Wait()

close(errorChannel)

log.Println(errorList)
</code></pre>

<p>How can you be sure, that errorList isn't modified, after the call to close? One could reason, that you can't know, how many values the goroutine <code>errorChannelWatch</code> still has to process.</p>

<p>Your synchronisation seems correct to me, as you do the <code>wg.Done()</code>
after the send to the error channel and so all error values will
be sent, when <code>fileWaitGroup.Wait()</code> returns.</p>

<p>But that can change, if someone later adds a buffering to the error
channel or alters the code.</p>

<p>So I would advise to at least explain the synchronisation in a comment.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7824574" LastEditorUserId="7824574" LastEditDate="2017-08-20T20:06:45.700" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T20:06:45.700" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45786756      <row Id="45786756" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45786786" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45786756" CreationDate="2017-08-20T21:03:04.883" Score="4" Body="<p>You'll want to use <a href="https://godoc.org/regexp#Regexp.ReplaceAllStringFunc" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Regexp.ReplaceAllStringFunc</code></a>, which allows you to use a function result as the replacement of a substring:</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "regexp"
    "strings"
)

func main() {
    logLine := `Date=2017-06-29 03:10:01.140 -700 PDT,clientDataRate="12.0,18.0,24.0,36.0,48.0,54.0",host=superawesomehost.foo,foo=bar`
    fmt.Println("logLine:        ", logLine)

    reg, err := regexp.Compile(`"([^"]*)"`)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }

    repairedLogLine := reg.ReplaceAllStringFunc(logLine, func(entry string) string {
        return strings.Replace(entry, ",", " ", -1)
    })
    fmt.Println("repairedLogLine:", repairedLogLine)
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/BsZxcrrvaR" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/BsZxcrrvaR</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-08-20T21:03:04.883" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45791233      <row Id="45791233" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45791340" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45791233" CreationDate="2017-08-21T07:19:55.470" Score="3" Body="<p>Just get the <code>len</code> of <code>array</code> and the <code>len</code> of any element of <code>array</code>.</p>

<pre><code>len(array) // 4
len(array[0]) // 5
</code></pre>

<p>As a note, you are using a 2d slice, not array. Read more about Go slices <a href="https://blog.golang.org/slices" rel="nofollow noreferrer">here</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="816892" LastEditorUserId="816892" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T08:16:48.653" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T08:16:48.653" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45791241      <row Id="45791241" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45791377" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45791241" CreationDate="2017-08-21T07:21:56.143" Score="12" Body="<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/time/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Package time</a></p>
  
  <p>Monotonic Clocks</p>
  
  <p>Operating systems provide both a wall clock, which is subject to
  changes for clock synchronization, and a monotonic clock, which is
  not. The general rule is that the wall clock is for telling time and
  the monotonic clock is for measuring time. Rather than split the API,
  in this package the Time returned by time.Now contains both a wall
  clock reading and a monotonic clock reading; later time-telling
  operations use the wall clock reading, but later time-measuring
  operations, specifically comparisons and subtractions, use the
  monotonic clock reading.</p>
  
  <p>For example, this code always computes a positive elapsed time of
  approximately 20 milliseconds, even if the wall clock is changed
  during the operation being timed:</p>

<pre><code>start := time.Now()
... operation that takes 20 milliseconds ...
t := time.Now()
elapsed := t.Sub(start)
</code></pre>
  
  <p>Other idioms, such as time.Since(start), time.Until(deadline), and
  time.Now().Before(deadline), are similarly robust against wall clock
  resets.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Starting with Go 1.9 (released August 24, 2017), Go uses a monotonic clock for durations.</p>

<p>See <a href="https://golang.org/design/12914-monotonic" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Proposal: Monotonic Elapsed Time Measurements in Go</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-08-25T00:04:10.980" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T00:04:10.980" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45791820      <row Id="45791820" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45792195" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45791820" CreationDate="2017-08-21T08:12:24.697" Score="2" Body="<p>Start by seeding the pseudorandom number generator. For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "math/rand"
    "time"
)

func main() {
    rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
    const letterBytes = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"
    b := make([]byte, 7)
    for i := range b {
        b[i] = letterBytes[rand.Intn(len(letterBytes))]
    }
    fmt.Println(string(b))
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>jfXtySC
</code></pre>

<hr>

<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://play.golang.org" rel="nofollow noreferrer">The Go Playground</a></p>
  
  <p>About the Playground</p>
  
  <p>In the playground the time begins at 2009-11-10 23:00:00 UTC
  (determining the significance of this date is an exercise for the
  reader). This makes it easier to cache programs by giving them
  deterministic output.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Therefore, in the Go playground, <code>time.Now().UnixNano()</code> always returns the same value. For a random seed value, run the code on your computer.</p>

<hr>

<p>For any Unicode code point (Go rune),</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "math/rand"
    "time"
)

package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "math/rand"
    "time"
)

func main() {
    rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())
    chars := []rune("abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ!@=")
    r := make([]rune, 50)
    for i := range r {
        r[i] = chars[rand.Intn(len(chars))]
    }
    fmt.Println(string(r))
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>QRYSp=@giJMIKly=tXRefjtVkeE!yHhTSQHvLyUYdRNIBbILW
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T13:21:55.657" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T13:21:55.657" CommentCount="6" />

question:
45793299      <row Id="45793299" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45794023" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45793299" CreationDate="2017-08-21T09:46:23.443" Score="2" Body="<p>Yes <code>tlsHandshakeTimeoutError</code> - is not exported and the only one 
possibility to check on this error is:</p>

<pre><code>import "net/url"

// ....

if urlError,ok :=  err.(*url.Error)  ; ok {
    if urlError.Error() == "net/http: TLS handshake timeout" {
        // handle the error
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Here is open ticket with discussion about it:</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/15935" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/issues/15935</a></p>

<p>By the way <code>http</code> errors (and <code>tlsHandshakeTimeoutError</code> also) provide also:</p>

<pre><code>type WithTimeout interface {
   Timeout() bool
}
</code></pre>

<p>You can use it for you check if you don't like string comparsion. <a href="https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/blob/25b4a426b40c26c07c80af674b03db90b5bd4a60/transport/http2_client.go#L125" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Here</a> is example of isTemporary implementation from http2 package.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1209451" LastEditorUserId="1209451" LastEditDate="2017-08-22T09:52:53.227" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T09:52:53.227" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45797858      <row Id="45797858" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45798099" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45797858" CreationDate="2017-08-21T13:14:13.243" Score="4" Body="<p>Use <code>log.Print</code> instead of <code>log.Fatal</code> and return the error value that you declared in signature of function <code>checkIfReadable</code>. Or don't the error it and return it to some place that knows better how to handle it.</p>

<p>The function <code>log.Fatal</code> is strictly for reporting your program's <em>final breath</em>.</p>

<p>Calling <code>log.Fatal</code> is a bit worse than calling panic (there is also <code>log.panic</code>), because it does not execute deferred calls. Remember, that overusing <code>panic</code> in Go is considered a bad style. </p>
" OwnerUserId="450989" LastEditorUserId="450989" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T13:31:04.500" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T13:31:04.500" CommentCount="3" />

question:
44044556      <row Id="44044556" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45798318" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="44044556" CreationDate="2017-08-21T13:25:11.670" Score="0" Body="<h2>My solution.</h2>

<p>To eliminate the warnings I configured vim and git to work the way golang likes.</p>

<h3>git</h3>

<p>The following command stops git from trying to do what is normally the right thing: standard line-endings in repo, platform line-endings on each developers working directory, convert as needed.</p>

<pre><code>git config core.autocrlf false
</code></pre>

<p>Now git won't change <code>lf</code> to <code>crlf</code> on checkout or bleat about line-endings.</p>

<h3>vim</h3>

<p>In <code>_vimrc</code></p>

<pre><code>au FileType go setl ts=3 sw=3 nowrap nu syntax=go ruler fileformat=unix
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>fileformat=unix</code> seems to keep vim complaint-free regarding line-endings that are not native to the platform.</p>

<hr>

<h3>Footnote</h3>

<p>3 months after posting the above question I haven't come across any drawbacks or problems - at least not the way I use <code>go</code>, <code>vim</code> and <code>git</code>. </p>
" OwnerUserId="477035" LastEditorUserId="477035" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T13:31:52.457" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T13:31:52.457" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45801809      <row Id="45801809" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45802094" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45801809" CreationDate="2017-08-21T16:45:46.937" Score="2" Body="<p>A slice is a struct with a pointer to an underlying array, a length, and a capacity.</p>

<pre><code>type slice struct {
    array unsafe.Pointer
    len   int
    cap   int
}
</code></pre>

<p>You are changing the underlying array after you have appended the slice struct. <code>ia.Next()</code> reuses its return buffer.</p>

<p>For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"

    "golang.org/x/text/unicode/norm"
)

func Normalizer(s string) (ss [][]byte) {
    ss = make([][]byte, 0)
    var ia norm.Iter
    ia.InitString(norm.NFC, s)
    for !ia.Done() {
        next := ia.Next()
        fmt.Println(string(next), &amp;next[0])
        ss = append(ss, next)
    }
    fmt.Println()
    for i := range ss {
        fmt.Println(string(ss[i]), &amp;ss[i][0])
    }
    fmt.Println()
    return
}

func main() {
    ss := Normalizer("abc")
    fmt.Printf("%s\n", ss)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>a 0xc420092228
b 0xc420092228
c 0xc420092228

c 0xc420092228
c 0xc420092228
c 0xc420092228

[c c c]
</code></pre>

<p>Replace a copy of a slice struct</p>

<pre><code>next := ia.Next()
</code></pre>

<p>with a new slice struct with a new underlying array</p>

<pre><code>next := append([]byte(nil), ia.Next()...)
</code></pre>

<p>For example,</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"

    "golang.org/x/text/unicode/norm"
)

func Normalizer(s string) (ss [][]byte) {
    ss = make([][]byte, 0)
    var ia norm.Iter
    ia.InitString(norm.NFC, s)
    for !ia.Done() {
        next := append([]byte(nil), ia.Next()...)
        fmt.Println(string(next), &amp;next[0])
        ss = append(ss, next)
    }
    fmt.Println()
    for i := range ss {
        fmt.Println(string(ss[i]), &amp;ss[i][0])
    }
    fmt.Println()
    return
}

func main() {
    ss := Normalizer("abc")
    fmt.Printf("%s\n", ss)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Output:</p>

<pre><code>a 0xc4200120d0
b 0xc4200120e8
c 0xc420012108

a 0xc4200120d0
b 0xc4200120e8
c 0xc420012108

[a b c]
</code></pre>

<p>References:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Slice_types" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Slice types</a></p>

<p><a href="https://blog.golang.org/go-slices-usage-and-internals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Slices: usage and internals</a></p>

<p><a href="https://blog.golang.org/slices" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Arrays, slices (and strings): The mechanics of 'append'</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T22:40:44.687" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T22:40:44.687" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45802492      <row Id="45802492" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45802962" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45802492" CreationDate="2017-08-21T17:48:07.703" Score="1" Body="<p>You can't. You can find this in net/http source, it only happens if the request was malformed:</p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/net/http/server.go#L1744" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://github.com/golang/go/blob/master/src/net/http/server.go#L1744</a></p>

<p>I think your problem might be a new line in the header you're adding in curl?</p>

<p>401, 403, 404, 500 errors you'll be able to respond with json, but bad requests or bad headers (too long, malformed) are handled within server.go. </p>

<p>There is at present no way to intercept such errors though it is under <a href="https://github.com/golang/go/issues/18997" rel="nofollow noreferrer">consideration</a>, so your only solution in go would be to patch the stdlib source (I don't recommend this). However, since this error only presents if the client has made a mistake and the request is malformed, it's probably not a huge problem.  The reason for the text response is so that a browser or similar client (like curl without -v) doesn't just see an empty response. You could put a proxy like nginx in front of your app but then you'd never see the request either as it is a bad request, your proxy would handle it. </p>

<p>Possibly you'd be able to do it with a proxy like nginx in front though if you set a specific static error page for it to serve for 400 errors and serve a 400.json file that you specify? That's the only solution I can think of. A directive something like this might work for nginx:</p>

<pre><code>error_page 400 /400.json;
</code></pre>

<p>If you'd like to be able to customise these errors, perhaps add a comment to the issue linked to let them know you had this specific problem. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastEditorUserId="1601137" LastEditDate="2017-08-21T19:28:19.947" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T19:28:19.947" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45803373      <row Id="45803373" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45803440" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45803373" CreationDate="2017-08-21T18:22:22.010" Score="3" Body="<p>I don't know of any possible way for this to fail, and if it is possible, it would result in a panic (and therefor application crash). I have never seen it happen, and I'm aware of examples of applications running <em>millions</em> of goroutines. The only limiting factor is available memory to allocate the goroutine stack.</p>

<p><code>go foo()</code> is not like <code>pthread_create</code>. Goroutines are lightweight green threads handled by the Go runtime, and scheduled to run on OS threads. Starting a goroutine does not start a new OS thread.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T18:22:22.010" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45789101      <row Id="45789101" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45803548" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45789101" CreationDate="2017-08-21T18:30:10.183" Score="0" Body="<p>I got the solution for this...</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Is the global value not getting set? Or the changes to that global var is not getting updated in TestHelperProcess?</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Since in <code>TestPrintDate()</code>, <code>fakeExecCommand</code> is called instead of exec.Command, and calling <code>fakeExecCommand</code> runs <code>go test</code> to run only <code>TestHelperProcess()</code>, it's altogether a new invocation where only <code>TestHelperProcess()</code> will be executed. Since only <code>TestHelperProcess()</code> is called, the global variables aren't being set.</p>

<p>The solution would be to set the Env in the <code>fakeExecCommand</code>, and retrieve that in <code>TestHelperProcess()</code> and return those values.</p>

<p><em>PS> <code>TestHelperProcess</code> is renamed to <code>TestExecCommandHelper</code></em>, And few variables are renamed.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "os"
    "os/exec"
    "strconv"
    "testing"
)

var mockedExitStatus = 0
var mockedStdout string

func fakeExecCommand(command string, args ...string) *exec.Cmd {
    cs := []string{"-test.run=TestExecCommandHelper", "--", command}
    cs = append(cs, args...)
    cmd := exec.Command(os.Args[0], cs...)
    es := strconv.Itoa(mockedExitStatus)
    cmd.Env = []string{"GO_WANT_HELPER_PROCESS=1",
        "STDOUT=" + mockedStdout,
        "EXIT_STATUS=" + es}
    return cmd
}

func TestExecCommandHelper(t *testing.T) {
    if os.Getenv("GO_WANT_HELPER_PROCESS") != "1" {
        return
    }

    // println("Mocked stdout:", os.Getenv("STDOUT"))
    fmt.Fprintf(os.Stdout, os.Getenv("STDOUT"))
    i, _ := strconv.Atoi(os.Getenv("EXIT_STATUS"))
    os.Exit(i)
}

func TestPrintDate(t *testing.T) {
    mockedExitStatus = 1
    mockedStdout = "Sun Aug 201"
    execCommand = fakeExecCommand
    defer func() { execCommand = exec.Command }()
    expDate := "Sun Aug 20"

    out, _ := printDate()
    if string(out) != expDate {
        t.Errorf("Expected %q, got %q", expDate, string(out))
    }
}

func TestPrintDateUnableToRunError(t *testing.T) {
    mockedExitStatus = 1
    mockedStdout = "Unable to run date command"
    execCommand = fakeExecCommand
    defer func() { execCommand = exec.Command }()

    expDate := "Unable to run date command"

    out, _ := printDate()
    // println("Stdout: ", string(out))
    if string(out) != expDate {
        t.Errorf("Expected %q, got %q", expDate, string(out))
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong><code>go test</code> results as below...</strong> 
<em>(Purposely failing one test to show that the mock is working properly).</em></p>

<pre><code> go test hello
--- FAIL: TestPrintDate (0.01s)
        hello_test.go:45: Expected "Sun Aug 20", got "Sun Aug 201"
FAIL
FAIL    hello   0.018s
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="3141044" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T18:30:10.183" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45800136      <row Id="45800136" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45804366" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45800136" CreationDate="2017-08-21T19:33:59.847" Score="1" Body="<p>I use templates for this and it works well. You can generate the views and potentially the handlers and model with basic admin views for CRUD actions very quickly, which is nice. Obviously for each admin view you're going to want to customise it to some extent but as a starting point it works very well. </p>

<p><a href="https://github.com/fragmenta" rel="nofollow noreferrer">This</a> is the tool I'm using (if you've used rails it should be familiar), you should also be able to knock something together with go generate (for code), a tool like <a href="https://github.com/cheekybits/genny" rel="nofollow noreferrer">genny</a>, or just your own solution using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/text/template/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">text/template</a> to output what you need. I've used this approach on a few projects now, I recommend if you find yourself creating dashboards which then need to be customised later. Most apps have a certain amount of boilerplate for each resource (create, update, delete, index).</p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastEditorUserId="1601137" LastEditDate="2017-08-22T14:29:50.773" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T14:29:50.773" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45803618      <row Id="45803618" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45804467" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45803618" CreationDate="2017-08-21T19:41:44.683" Score="1" Body="<p>With unpredictable structures, deserializing into a struct is not going to work. Instead, you'll be better off using the streaming mode of the XML parser using <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/#Decoder.Token" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>xml.Decoder.Token</code></a> to parse elements in order and handle them as necessary.</p>

<pre><code>decoder := xml.NewDecoder(xmlFile) 
solutions := make([]string,0,0)

for { 
    t, _ := decoder.Token() 
    if t == nil { 
        break 
    }
    switch se := t.(type) { 
    case xml.StartElement: 
        if se.Name.Local == "Paragraph" {
            // Get the next token after the Paragraph start element, which will be the tag contents
            innerText,ok := decoder.Token().(xml.CharData)
            if !ok {
                continue
            }
            solutions = append(solutions, string(innerText))
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>This code is untested but should provide a decent starting point.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T19:41:44.683" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45804868      <row Id="45804868" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45804997" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45804868" CreationDate="2017-08-21T20:23:20.960" Score="3" Body="<p>Per the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/#Unmarshal" rel="nofollow noreferrer">documentation</a>:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>If the XML element contains character data, that data is
     accumulated in the first struct field that has tag ",chardata".
     The struct field may have type []byte or string.
     If there is no such field, the character data is discarded.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>So, you can decode it with a struct as such:</p>

<pre><code>type Book struct {
    Title   string   `xml:"title"`
    Price   string   `xml:"price"`
    Year    string   `xml:"year"`
    Author  string   `xml:"author"`
    Body    string   `xml:",chardata"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>(Note that fields you're unmarshaling into <strong>must be exported</strong>, i.e., must start with an uppercase letter, or they cannot be unmarshaled into.)</p>

<p>You can see an example here: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/OlwSqnHsT7" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/OlwSqnHsT7</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="7426" LastActivityDate="2017-08-21T20:23:20.960" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45808394      <row Id="45808394" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45808753" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45808394" CreationDate="2017-08-22T04:08:23.360" Score="2" Body="<p>In Go, a name is exported if it begins with a capital letter. You should make first letters of fields UPPERCASED to make sure they're exported, like:</p>

<pre><code>type UserInfo struct {
    Gender     string            `dynamo:"gender"`
    Product    string            `dynamo:"product"`
    Id         string            `dynamo:"id"`
    CreateTime int               `dynamo:"create_time"`
    Name       string            `dynamo:"name"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>more info: <a href="https://www.goinggo.net/2014/03/exportedunexported-identifiers-in-go.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://www.goinggo.net/2014/03/exportedunexported-identifiers-in-go.html</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="391464" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T04:08:23.360" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45808852      <row Id="45808852" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45809232" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45808852" CreationDate="2017-08-22T05:03:03.847" Score="4" Body="<p>Assuming that you're pulling back 2 separate values from the DB, you can use <code>fmt.Sprintf</code> to <code>0</code> pad <code>timeString</code>. Combining it with the <code>date</code> string, you can use the following:</p>

<pre><code>value := fmt.Sprintf("%s %08s", date, timeString)[:15]
</code></pre>

<p>In your code:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    date := "20170228"
    timeString := "5013756"
    value := fmt.Sprintf("%s %08s", date, timeString)[:15]
    layout := "20060102 150405"

    t, _ := time.Parse(layout, value)
    fmt.Println(t)
}
</code></pre>

<p>Results:</p>

<pre><code>2017-02-28 05:01:37 +0000 UTC
</code></pre>

<p>This approach is useful because it will also correctly pad any shorter value of time, e.g. <code>13756</code> will be converted to <code>00013756</code>.</p>

<p>The <code>fmt.Sprintf</code> function is useful to format arguments into a string using the formatting you desire as specified by a format string and a list of arguments (<code>...interface{}</code>). The format string tells the function how to render the arguments.</p>

<p>This format string uses two items of note:</p>

<ul>
<li>String verb (<code>%s</code>): The format string uses a variety of <code>verbs</code> that are used for string substitutions. <code>%s</code> is specifically to render a string or a slice. Other popular verbs include <code>%d</code> for base 10 integer and <code>%f</code> for float with a complete list in the docs. The <code>%v</code> verb is very useful can also be used here as it will render an argument's default value.</li>
<li><code>0</code> left padding: To <code>0</code> left pad an argument, use <code>0</code> followed by a length number in the verb after the <code>%</code>. This will prepended the argument with a maximum number of <code>0</code>s specified in the length number. For example, <code>%08s</code> will render a string with up to 8 prepended zeros. This means a string <code>""</code> will be <code>"00000000"</code> while a string <code>"1234567"</code> will result in <code>"01234567"</code>. If the string is longer than the length, nothing will be prepended.</li>
</ul>

<p>From the documentation:</p>

<pre><code>%s  the uninterpreted bytes of the string or slice

0   pad with leading zeros rather than spaces;
    for numbers, this moves the padding after the sign
</code></pre>

<p>More detailed is available in the documentation: <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/fmt/</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="1908967" LastEditorUserId="1908967" LastEditDate="2017-08-22T08:53:42.297" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T08:53:42.297" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45807184      <row Id="45807184" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45810521" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45807184" CreationDate="2017-08-22T06:39:25.297" Score="1" Body="<p>If the crash is being caused by your <code>log.Fatal(err)</code>, you can avoid this by checking and avoiding it:</p>

<pre><code>_, err := orm.NewOrm().Insert(product)

if err != nil {
    if err.Error() == "no LastInsertId available" {
        log.Println(err)
    } else {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1908967" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T06:39:25.297" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45811933      <row Id="45811933" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45812276" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45811933" CreationDate="2017-08-22T08:11:22.757" Score="6" Body="<p>As you can see <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Logical_operators" rel="noreferrer">here</a>, the right operand of <code>&amp;&amp;</code> is evaluated conditionally.</p>

<p>This means that <code>result =  result &amp;&amp; &lt;-in</code> will only evaluate <code>&lt;-in</code> if <code>result</code> is true. So, the coodrinator reads only one <code>false</code> from that channel, and skips reading messages from the other workers. If you switch the operands of <code>&amp;&amp;</code> places, then the <code>&lt;-in</code> will evaluate every time and the deadlock goes away.</p>
" OwnerUserId="6444852" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T08:11:22.757" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45806377      <row Id="45806377" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45812612" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45806377" CreationDate="2017-08-22T08:28:58.703" Score="0" Body="<p>According to your description and the error information <code>SSHException: No existing session</code>, it sounds like you were using <code>os/exec</code> for calling your shell script file,  but failed because command <code>az</code> needs to use something like <code>azureProfile.json</code> at the path <code>.azure</code> within a ssh session.</p>

<p>So I suggested you can try to use the code below with <code>golang.org/x/crypto/ssh</code> package to do it.</p>

<p>Here is my sample code for Linux which I think the same as on MacOS.</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "bufio"
    "bytes"
    "errors"
    "fmt"
    "log"
    "os"
    "path/filepath"
    "strings"

    "golang.org/x/crypto/ssh"
)

func getHostKey(host string) (ssh.PublicKey, error) {
    file, err := os.Open(filepath.Join(os.Getenv("HOME"), ".ssh", "known_hosts"))
    if err != nil {
        return nil, err
    }
    defer file.Close()

    scanner := bufio.NewScanner(file)
    var hostKey ssh.PublicKey
    for scanner.Scan() {
        fields := strings.Split(scanner.Text(), " ")
        if len(fields) != 3 {
            continue
        }
        if strings.Contains(fields[0], host) {
            var err error
            hostKey, _, _, _, err = ssh.ParseAuthorizedKey(scanner.Bytes())
            if err != nil {
                return nil, errors.New(fmt.Sprintf("error parsing %q: %v", fields[2], err))
            }
            break
        }
    }

    if hostKey == nil {
        return nil, errors.New(fmt.Sprintf("no hostkey for %s", host))
    }
    return hostKey, nil
}

func main() {
    hostKey, err := getHostKey("localhost")
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
    config := &amp;ssh.ClientConfig{
        User: "peter",
        Auth: []ssh.AuthMethod{
            ssh.Password("peter ssh password"),
        },
        HostKeyCallback: ssh.FixedHostKey(hostKey),
    }
    // Dial your ssh server.
    conn, err := ssh.Dial("tcp", "localhost:22", config)
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal("unable to connect: ", err)
    }
    defer conn.Close()
    session, err := conn.NewSession()
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal("Failed to create session: ", err)
    }
    defer session.Close()

    // Once a Session is created, you can execute a single command on
    // the remote side using the Run method.
    var b bytes.Buffer
    session.Stdout = &amp;b
    if err := session.Run("./test.sh"); err != nil {
        log.Fatal("Failed to run: " + err.Error())
    }
    fmt.Println(b.String())
}
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Notes</strong>: There must be a record like the content below for <code>localhost</code> in your <code>.ssh/known_hosts</code> file. If not, you can first login via ssh to generate it and change the host with <code>localhost</code>.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>|localhost|qx8q1geNHGyRFp8Ttu+m2xY4OpU=|noyfrjpDRvtIzP2gzWEV77VZULo= ecdsa-sha2-nistp256 AAAAE2VjZHNhLXNoYTItbmlzdHAyNTYAAAAIbmlzdHAyNTYAAABBBKXlyt/EFLnqwlNDimn73+wZVgCh3dhXi2YMWN6tHUj5LMirrUt0AtmQQVHex2b2ur79L5P6/L2J28NID569qAA=</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Hope it helps.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4989676" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T08:28:58.703" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45817640      <row Id="45817640" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45817853" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45817640" CreationDate="2017-08-22T12:36:45.090" Score="2" Body="<p>Yes, you can fetch the precise structure of the type, if that's what you mean with "root type":</p>

t := reflect.TypeOf(item)
