question:
45818964      <row Id="45818964" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45819780" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45818964" CreationDate="2017-08-22T14:00:30.373" Score="2" Body="<blockquote>
  <p>Is it guaranteed that the order of the pointers remains the same? (For
  example, I can imagine some GC trickery which also reorders the data.)</p>
</blockquote>

<p>In answer to this part of your question, it doesn't look like it. See pkg unsafe linked below. </p>

<p>If you want the memory address of a pointer, try the unsafe package:</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/pkg/unsafe/#Pointer" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/pkg/unsafe/#Pointer</a></p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "unsafe"
)

func main() {
    var a,b int
    var pa,pb *int
    pa = &amp;a
    pb = &amp;b

    //var c int
    //pa = &amp;c

    if uintptr(unsafe.Pointer(pa)) &lt; uintptr(unsafe.Pointer(pb)) {
      fmt.Printf("a:%p &gt; b:%p",pa,pb)   
    } else {
      fmt.Printf("b:%p &gt; a:%p",pb,pa)
    }

}
</code></pre>

<p>This will let you get an arbitrary Pointer type and then the <em>current</em> memory address of that pointer (as printf would). Note the caveats there though, you cannot rely on this address:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>Converting a Pointer to a uintptr produces the memory address of the
  value pointed at, as an integer. The usual use for such a uintptr is
  to print it. Conversion of a uintptr back to Pointer is not valid in
  general. A uintptr is an integer, not a reference. Converting a
  Pointer to a uintptr creates an integer value with no pointer
  semantics. Even if a uintptr holds the address of some object, the
  garbage collector will not update that uintptr's value if the object
  moves, nor will that uintptr keep the object from being reclaimed.</p>
</blockquote>

<p><strong>This bypasses the Go type system and memory security so it's unsafe and you probably don't want to do it</strong>, unless you're just experimenting. I can't think of a reason to do it in tests, but if you want to be sure to read that entire document and be very sure you know that what you are doing will work as you expect.  </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastEditorUserId="1601137" LastEditDate="2017-08-22T14:07:10.387" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T14:07:10.387" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45820737      <row Id="45820737" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45821375" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45820737" CreationDate="2017-08-22T15:12:28.367" Score="3" Body="<p>The short answer is no, you cannot use a query as part of a transaction unless you are querying a specific entity group. Global queries are alway eventually consistent. However, to put everything in a single entity group would likely limit write throughput too much.</p>

<p>A workaround is you can have another Kind with entities that map email addresses to users. Then you can, in a transaction, check the email Entity and if it doesn't exist or it points to a bad location, set the email Entity and the user Entity all as a single transaction.</p>
" OwnerUserId="727643" LastEditorUserId="727643" LastEditDate="2017-08-22T15:23:58.600" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T15:23:58.600" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45823531      <row Id="45823531" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45823718" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45823531" CreationDate="2017-08-22T17:30:14.200" Score="3" Body="<p>Yes, you can use them interchangeably.</p>

<p>As you already noticed, the <code>context</code> variables returned by <code>WithCancel</code>, etc, are actually pointers, so both <code>localCtx</code> and <code>ctx</code> will be pointing to the same thing.</p>

<p>About <code>emptyCtx</code> being an <code>int</code>, it should not change things as it is also being used as a pointer.</p>

<p>The <code>background</code> variable you mention is actually a pointer to an <code>emptyCtx</code>, as it is initialized by using the <code>new</code> keyword:</p>

<pre><code>background = new(emptyCtx)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4907630" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T17:30:14.200" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45823566      <row Id="45823566" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45824081" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45823566" CreationDate="2017-08-22T17:54:19.093" Score="1" Body="<p>Just collect the non-nil values in a slice and then use that slice with <code>...</code> when executing the query.</p>

<pre><code>var values []interface{}
for i := range m {
    if v := m[i]; v != "" &amp;&amp; v != 0 &amp;&amp; v != 0.0 &amp;&amp; /* you're missing a condition here */{
        j++
        query = query + strings.ToLower(i) + "=$" + strconv.Itoa(j) + ","
        values = append(values, v)
    }
}

// ....

database.DB.QueryRow(query_string, values...)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="965900" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T17:54:19.093" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45824062      <row Id="45824062" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45824109" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45824062" CreationDate="2017-08-22T17:56:09.480" Score="1" Body="<p>The issue is caused by you wrapping the map in an object, the YAML has no such nesting.</p>

<pre><code>map := map[string]string{}
err := yaml.Unmarshal([]byte(val), &amp;map)
</code></pre>

<p>You can actually just unmarshal directly into the map itself</p>

<p>EDIT: hard to tell with your formatting but if those integer keys are nested under <code>A</code> then you will need a different structure as well, it would actually be a <code>map[string]map[string]string</code> -- however that is rather ugly so I would recommend moving to a different paradigm at that point... You could either use a <code>map[string]interface{}</code> which wouldn't care what types go into the map and then you could deal with it later or you could define the object more statically, using actually keys such a <code>A</code> in a struct to denote where each item goes, if that were the case you'd have an object like the following;</p>

<pre><code>type TranslationVal struct {
    A map[string]string
    B string
    C string
    // and so on
    F string `yaml:f` // necessary because f would be unexported
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="763585" LastEditorUserId="763585" LastEditDate="2017-08-22T18:02:08.637" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T18:02:08.637" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45824738      <row Id="45824738" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45824776" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45824738" CreationDate="2017-08-22T18:41:54.230" Score="7" Body="<p>I would suggest using <a href="https://godoc.org/strings#Map" rel="noreferrer"><code>strings.Map</code></a> for this:</p>

<pre><code>s = strings.Map(func(r rune) rune {
   switch r {
     case 'a':
       return '3'
     case 'e':
       return '2'
     // etc.
     default:
       return r
   }
}, s)
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/D66J5hZsNs" rel="noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/D66J5hZsNs</a></p>

<p>With a slight modification, if you need to dynamically set the replacement values, you could store the vowels in a map. For example:</p>

<pre><code>vowels := map[rune]rune{
    'a': '3',
    'e': '2',
}

s = strings.Map(func(r rune) rune {
    if u, ok := vowels[r]; ok {
        return u
    }
    return r
}, s)
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="142162" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T18:41:54.230" CommentCount="8" />

question:
45815938      <row Id="45815938" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45826152" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45815938" CreationDate="2017-08-22T20:07:52.167" Score="1" Body="<p>Hope this can help you as a start point:</p>

<pre><code>---
- hosts: all
  connection: local 

  tasks:
  - name: check go version
    command: go version
    register: result
    changed_when: no
    ignore_errors: true

  - set_fact:
      go_path: "{{ lookup('env', 'GOPATH') | default(ansible_env.HOME+'/go', true) }}"
    when: not result|failed

  - name: go get gogs
    shell: go get -u github.com/gogits/gogs
    environment:
      GOPATH: "{{ go_path }}"
    register: gogs
    when: not result|failed

  - debug: var=gogs
</code></pre>

<p>Try to run this on your remote server by typing:</p>

<pre><code>ansible-playbook gogs.yml -i localhost,
</code></pre>

<p>If that works then just later try remotely.</p>

<p>Normally you don't want to do this since you want to execute this remotely over ssh, but since you had tried so far and are getting some errors, probably by trying locally <code>connection: local</code> could help to debug more in details this issue.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1135424" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T20:07:52.167" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45817797      <row Id="45817797" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45826181" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45817797" CreationDate="2017-08-22T20:09:55.647" Score="1" Body="<p>It seems that you do not have your chaincode in the $GOPATH, you need to run:</p>

<pre><code>go get github.com/myuserId/fabrcicV1_chaincodes/mychaincode
</code></pre>

<p>Before trying to install the chaincode on peer, in your case where you are using <strong>build your first network</strong>, you need to make sure your new chaincode inside <code>fabric-samples/chaincode</code> folder. And also note that you need to mount folder with your chaincode into docker cli container, see example of current <code>docker-compose-cli.yaml</code> file:</p>

<pre><code>volumes:
    - /var/run/:/host/var/run/
    - ./../chaincode/:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go
    - ./crypto-config:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/crypto/
    - ./scripts:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/scripts/
    - ./channel-artifacts:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/peer/channel-artifacts
</code></pre>

<p>In particular, you probably need to replace here with your chaincode or make sure to mount an additional folder within <code>$GOPATH</code> of cli container:</p>

<pre><code>- ./../chaincode/:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="104014" LastActivityDate="2017-08-22T20:09:55.647" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45828485      <row Id="45828485" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45828623" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45828485" CreationDate="2017-08-23T00:02:21.160" Score="1" Body="<p>The import path maps directly to the filesystem path, relative to <code>$GOPATH/src/</code>.</p>

<p><a href="https://golang.org/doc/code.html#ImportPaths" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/doc/code.html#ImportPaths</a></p>

<p>It seems that you can do a relative import like this:</p>

<pre><code>../other-pkg
</code></pre>

<p>But it's <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10687627/relative-import-from-parent-directory">not idiomatic or recommended</a>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="966798" LastEditorUserId="966798" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T00:08:34.167" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T00:08:34.167" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45828996      <row Id="45828996" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45829567" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45828996" CreationDate="2017-08-23T02:10:44.537" Score="1" Body="<p>You check if the current field is a struct <strong>value</strong>, but you never account for the case when it is a <code>reflect.Ptr</code> to a struct or something else, so your function never recurses for that case. Here is your function with the missing piece.</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/FdLxeee9UU" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/FdLxeee9UU</a></p>

<pre><code>// ContainsNil returns true if any fields within the supplied structure are nil.
//
// If the supplied object is not a struct, the method will panic.
// Nested structs are inspected recursively.
// Maps and slices are not inspected deeply. This may change.
func ContainsNil(obj interface{}) bool {
    if obj == nil {
        return true
    }
    s := reflect.Indirect(reflect.ValueOf(obj))
    for i := 0; i &lt; s.NumField(); i++ {
        f := s.Type().Field(i)
        field := s.Field(i)
        if fieldIsExported(f) { // Exported-check must be evaluated first to avoid panic.
            if field.Kind() == reflect.Ptr { // case when it's a pointer or struct pointer
                if field.IsNil() {
                    return true
                }
                if ContainsNil(field.Interface()) {
                    return true
                }
            }
            if field.Kind() == reflect.Struct {
                if ContainsNil(field.Addr()) {
                    return true
                }
            } else {
                if field.IsNil() {
                    return true
                }
                if field.Interface() == nil {
                    return true
                }
            }
        }
    }
    return false
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastEditorUserId="1276480" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T02:18:58.053" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T02:18:58.053" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45830855      <row Id="45830855" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45831260" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45830855" CreationDate="2017-08-23T05:26:51.800" Score="2" Body="<p>Instead of statically defining each subject, how about simply using a map from subject name => array of class details ?</p>

<p>One way you can get very close to the JSON you want by using a map like I described above, and by embedding the map into a struct as follows:</p>

<pre><code>type ClassDetails struct {
    ClassNumber int      `json:"classNumber"`
    Names       []string `json:names`
}

type Subjects map[string][]ClassDetails

type Classes struct {
    School string `json:"school"`
    Subjects
}
</code></pre>

<p>An instance of the <code>Classes</code> struct above would fill in the following part of your desired JSON:</p>

<pre><code>{
  "classes": {
    ... the Classes instance goes here...
  }
}
</code></pre>

<p>The remaining outer object can just be constructed as follows:</p>

<pre><code>c := Classes{...}
outer := map[string]Classes{"classes": c}
</code></pre>

<p>A JSON marshal of the <code>outer</code> object, with the right data initialized, arrives at almost exactly your JSON above (to match it exactly you'd have to turn the <code>ClassNumber</code> into a string type).</p>

<p>Here is a Go Playground link that initializes these structs with the exact data you want and pretty-prints your JSON: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/HFMbHtY2os" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/HFMbHtY2os</a></p>

<p>EDIT: This still doesn't exactly match the JSON in your question, as it will add a new object in there called "Subjects". The problem is that the object inside of <code>"classes"</code> in your JSON mixes types, and Go can't declare dynamic struct fields.</p>

<p>If you really have to use that JSON structure, you'll need to go with the more generic <code>map[string]interface{}</code> to allow mixed types at the same level in your object hierarchy. Here's another Go Playground link that has the correct implementation: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/rlYTYGofSI" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/rlYTYGofSI</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="4648046" LastEditorUserId="4648046" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T05:41:52.137" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T05:41:52.137" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45834542      <row Id="45834542" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45834733" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45834542" CreationDate="2017-08-23T08:39:25.360" Score="2" Body="<p>This is not an issue of the <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#Reader.ReadByte" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>Reader.ReadByte()</code></a> implementation, nor that of <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/bufio/#NewReader" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>bufio.NewReader()</code></a>.</p>

<p>See this example to prove it:</p>

<pre><code>buf := bytes.NewBufferString("Hello World!\n")
in := bufio.NewReader(buf)
for {
    c, err := in.ReadByte()
    if err == io.EOF {
        break
    }
    fmt.Print(string(c))
}
</code></pre>

<p>When running, the above prints</p>

<pre><code>Hello World!
</code></pre>

<p>And terminates properly.</p>

<p>Your issue is with <code>os.Stdin</code>. Reading from it is specific to its source. If it is your terminal, reading from it simply blocks and does not report <code>io.EOF</code>. See this example to prove it:</p>

<pre><code>in := bufio.NewReader(os.Stdin)
for {
    fmt.Println("Reading.")
    c, err := in.ReadByte()
    if err == io.EOF {
        break
    }
    fmt.Print(string(c))
}
</code></pre>

<p>Its output is:</p>

<pre><code>Reading.
</code></pre>

<p>And nothing happens. There is no new iteration, it is blocked. Now if you enter a line and press <kbd>Enter</kbd>, e.g. you enter <code>Go!</code>, output will be:</p>

<pre><code>Go!
GReading.
oReading.
!Reading.

Reading.
</code></pre>

<p>And again, waits for new input. As you can see, data is fed / available per line. This is what your terminal does: while you enter your line, it is not sent to <code>os.Stdin</code>. Once you press <kbd>Enter</kbd>, the whole line is fed and is available from <code>os.Stdin</code>. This is what we see: each letter of the input <code>Go!</code> and a newline character. And we see the <code>Reading.</code> text printed for each iteration. After the input is consumed, <code>in.ReadByte()</code> is blocked again, waiting for new input. It does not report <code>io.EOF</code>.</p>

<p>Now try the following: create a file e.g. <code>a.txt</code> and edit it to have one line: <code>Go!</code> and a newline. Now feed this file as the standard input to your program:</p>

<pre><code>go run play.go &lt; a.txt
</code></pre>

<p>Running it we'll see:</p>

<pre><code>Reading.
GReading.
oReading.
!Reading.

Reading.

Reading.
</code></pre>

<p>And it terminates so it works! It works because this time the source of <code>os.Stdin</code> is not your console / terminal, but the contents of a file, and once it's consumed, attempting to read from <code>os.Stdin</code> will properly report <code>io.EOF</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T09:01:15.283" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T09:01:15.283" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45836767      <row Id="45836767" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45837752" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45836767" CreationDate="2017-08-23T10:56:19.857" Score="3" Body="<p>Unfortunately there is no ready solution for an in-memory <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#WriteSeeker" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.WriteSeeker</code></a> implementation in the standard lib.</p>

<p>But as always, you can always implement your own. It's not that hard.</p>

<p>An <code>io.WriteSeeker</code> is an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Writer" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Writer</code></a> and an <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/io/#Seeker" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>io.Seeker</code></a>, so basically you only need to implement 2 methods:</p>

<pre><code>Write(p []byte) (n int, err error)
Seek(offset int64, whence int) (int64, error)
</code></pre>

<p>Read the general contract of these methods in their documentation how they should behave.</p>

<p>Here's a simple implementation which uses an in-memory byte slice (<code>[]byte</code>). It's not optimized for speed, this is just a "demo" implementation.</p>

<pre><code>type mywriter struct {
    buf []byte
    pos int
}

func (m *mywriter) Write(p []byte) (n int, err error) {
    minCap := m.pos + len(p)
    if minCap &gt; cap(m.buf) { // Make sure buf has enough capacity:
        buf2 := make([]byte, len(m.buf), minCap+len(p)) // add some extra
        copy(buf2, m.buf)
        m.buf = buf2
    }
    if minCap &gt; len(m.buf) {
        m.buf = m.buf[:minCap]
    }
    copy(m.buf[m.pos:], p)
    m.pos += len(p)
    return len(p), nil
}

func (m *mywriter) Seek(offset int64, whence int) (int64, error) {
    newPos, offs := 0, int(offset)
    switch whence {
    case io.SeekStart:
        newPos = offs
    case io.SeekCurrent:
        newPos = m.pos + offs
    case io.SeekEnd:
        newPos = len(m.buf) + offs
    }
    if newPos &lt; 0 {
        return 0, errors.New("negative result pos")
    }
    m.pos = newPos
    return int64(newPos), nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>Yes, and that's it.</p>

<p>Testing it:</p>

<pre><code>my := &amp;mywriter{}
var ws io.WriteSeeker = my

ws.Write([]byte("hello"))
fmt.Println(string(my.buf))

ws.Write([]byte(" world"))
fmt.Println(string(my.buf))

ws.Seek(-2, io.SeekEnd)
ws.Write([]byte("k!"))
fmt.Println(string(my.buf))

ws.Seek(6, io.SeekStart)
ws.Write([]byte("gopher"))
fmt.Println(string(my.buf))
</code></pre>

<p>Output (try it on the <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/TjXBLd3E5m" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Playground</a>):</p>

<pre><code>hello
hello world
hello work!
hello gopher
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Things that can be improved:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li><p>Create a <code>mywriter</code> value with an initial empty <code>buf</code> slice, but with a capacity that will most likely cover the size of the result PDF document. E.g. if you estimate the result PDFs are around 1 MB, create a buffer with capacity for 2 MB like this:<br>
<code>my := &amp;mywriter{buf: make([]byte, 0, 2&lt;&lt;20)}</code></p></li>
<li><p>Inside <code>mywriter.Write()</code> when capacity needs to be increased (and existing content copied over), it may be profitable to use bigger increment, e.g. double the current capacity to a certain extent, which reserves space for future appends and minimizes the reallocations.</p></li>
</ul>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-24T13:22:49.920" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T13:22:49.920" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45713666      <row Id="45713666" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45837827" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45713666" CreationDate="2017-08-23T10:59:39.310" Score="0" Body="<p>I have the GO exe deployed in Program Files, I changed the LogOnAs attribute of Windows Service to "Local Service" and gave "Local Service" complete Access to the installation folder in "Folder Security". </p>

<p>This seems to fix the issue for windows10. The service starts on windows restart, But this fix still does not work for windows 7 and windows8.</p>

<p>Edit:</p>

<p>Making the service "Automatic Delayed" works, however you have to wait for the service start after boot which takes 2-3 minutes.</p>

<p>The answer mentioned here helped: <a href="https://serverfault.com/questions/697608/automatic-windows-service-not-starting/697852#697852?newreg=788f7ab0bb084fec85d1ce2e51bf8317">https://serverfault.com/questions/697608/automatic-windows-service-not-starting/697852#697852?newreg=788f7ab0bb084fec85d1ce2e51bf8317</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="5604249" LastEditorUserId="5604249" LastEditDate="2017-08-26T14:27:55.007" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T14:27:55.007" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45836981      <row Id="45836981" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45837940" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45836981" CreationDate="2017-08-23T11:04:02.920" Score="3" Body="<blockquote>
  <p><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go Wiki</a></p>
  
  <p><a href="https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/CompilerOptimizations" rel="nofollow noreferrer">CompilerOptimizations</a></p>
  
  <p>Function Inlining</p>
  
  <p>Only short and simple functions are inlined. To be inlined a function
  must contain less than ~40 expressions and does not contain complex
  things like function calls, loops, labels, closures, panic's,
  recover's, select's, switch'es, etc.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Currently, functions with loops are not inlined.</p>
" OwnerUserId="221700" LastEditorUserId="221700" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T11:09:02.973" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T11:09:02.973" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45842551      <row Id="45842551" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45842582" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45842551" CreationDate="2017-08-23T14:29:36.073" Score="6" Body="<p>You can get the length of a slice with <code>len(employees)</code>. Generally, if you know the size up front, <code>ids := make([]int64, length)</code> is preferrable to <code>ids := []int64{}</code> because it will result in fewer allocations as the slice grows.</p>

<pre><code>ids := make([]int64, len(employees))
for i,e := range employees{
   ids[i] = e.ID
}
</code></pre>

<p>Or a slightly alternate style:</p>

<pre><code>ids := make([]int64, 0, len(employees)) // declare capacity, but not length
for _ , e := range employees{
   ids = append(ids, e.ID)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="121660" LastEditorUserId="121660" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T14:32:21.023" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T14:32:21.023" CommentCount="0" />

question:

answer:
<row Id="45843669" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45843390" CreationDate="2017-08-23T15:20:04.647" Score="1" Body="<p>You should first perform a Type assertions on weather as an array of interface{}.</p>

<p>Then do the same on the first element as a map[string]interface{} </p>

<pre><code>temps := parsedMap["weather"].([]interface{})
mainTemp := temps[0].(map[string]interface{})
</code></pre>

<p>You can see a full example here <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/JIfCGrsYl9" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/JIfCGrsYl9</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="905927" LastEditorUserId="905927" LastEditDate="2017-08-23T15:35:37.943" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T15:35:37.943" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45845181      <row Id="45845181" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45846743" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45845181" CreationDate="2017-08-23T18:12:35.647" Score="2" Body="<p>Alright, I propose a solution that will give you the maximum code reuse and minimum code copying. This, in my opinion, is by far the most generic solution. We will also take into account the answer given by <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/users/7426/adrian">https://stackoverflow.com/users/7426/adrian</a> to complete the solution. You only have to define a single function which will be a higher order function <code>CreateHandler</code> which will return a function of the following signature: 
<br /><code>func(*AppContext, http.ResponseWriter, http.Request) (int, error)</code>.</p>

<p>This signature is the actual signature of the handler that is to be used as a mux end point. The solution involves defining a <code>Handler</code> type which is a struct having three fields:</p>

<p> <code>handlerType</code>: Think of it as an enum having either a value of <code>"CREATE"</code> or <code>"GET"</code>. This will decide which among the two blocks of code that you pasted in your question should we use.</p>

<p> <code>handlerActionName</code>: This will tell the <code>"CREATE"</code> or <code>"GET"</code> which Elastible to use. Value should either be <code>"flow"</code> or <code>"process"</code>.</p>

<p> <code>elastible</code>: This will the Interface type <code>Elastible</code> that will have the <code>SetESID</code> function. We will use this to send our <code>Flow</code> or <code>Process</code> types to our <code>Handler</code>. Thus both <code>Flow</code> and <code>Process</code> should satisfy our interface.
This will make the solution even more generic and will only calling <code>handler.elastible.SetESID()</code> and we will have inserted the ESID irrespective of that fact the underlying type in 'elastible' can either be 'Flow' or a 'Process'</p>

<p>I also define a <code>sendResponse(response interface{})</code> function that we will resuse to send the response. It acquires <code>w http.ResponseWriter</code> using closure. <code>response</code> can thus be anything, a </p>

<pre><code>struct {
    Highest int `json:"id"`
}{highest} 
</code></pre>

<p>or a <code>Flow</code> or a <code>Process</code>. This will make this function generic too.</p>

<p>The complete solution would now be.</p>

<pre><code>// This is the type that will be used to build our handlers.
type Handler struct {
    handlerType       string    // Can be "CREATE" or "GET"
    handlerActionName string    // Can be "flow" or "process"
    elastible         Elastible // Can be *Flow or *Process
}

// Your ESID Type.
type ESIDType string

// Solution proposed by https://stackoverflow.com/users/7426/adrian.
type Elastible interface {
    SetESID(id ESIDType)
}

// Make the Flow and Process pointers implement the Elastible interface.
func (flow *Flow) SetESID(id ESIDType) {
    flow.ESID = id
}

func (process *Process) SetESID(id ESIDType) {
    process.ESID = id
}

// Create a Higher Order Function which will return the actual handler.
func CreateHandler(handler Handler) func(*AppContext, http.ResponseWriter, http.Request) (int, error) {

    return func(a *AppContext, w http.ResponseWriter, r http.Request) (int, error) {

        // Define a sendResponse function so that we may not need to copy paste it later.
        // It captures w using closure and takes an interface argument that we use to call .Encode() with.

        sendResponse := func(response interface{}) (int, error) {
            b := new(bytes.Buffer)
            json.NewEncoder(b).Encode(response)
            w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
            w.Write(b.Bytes())
            return 200, nil
        }

        // Define these variables beforehand since we'll be using them
        // in both the if and else block. Not necessary really.
        var code int
        var err error

        // Check the handlerType. Is it create or get?
        if handler.handlerType == "CREATE" {
            var highest int

            // Creates the thing using handler.handlerActionName which may be "flow" or "process"
            highest, code, err = a.Create(handler.handlerActionName, r)
            if code != 200 || err != nil {
                return code, err
            }

            // Send the response using the above defined function and return.
            return sendResponse(struct {
                Highest int `json:"id"`
            }{highest})

        } else {

            // This is GET handlerType.
            var hit HitType

            // Get the hit using again the handler.handlerActionName which may be "flow" or "process"
            hit, code, err = a.GetByID(handler.handlerActionName, mux.Vars(r)["id"], r)
            if code != 200 || err != nil {
                return code, err
            }

            // Do the un-marshalling.
            err = json.Unmarshal(*hit.Source, ob)
            if err != nil {
                return 500, err
            }

            // We have set the handler.elastible to be an interface type
            // which will have the SetESID function that will set the ESID in the
            // underlying type that will be passed on runtime.
            // So the ESID will be set for both the Flow and the Process types.
            // This interface idea was given inside an earlier answer by
            // https://stackoverflow.com/users/7426/adrian

            handler.elastible.SetESID(hit.id)
            return sendResponse(handler.elastible)
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>And you would setup your mux end points using the following code.</p>

<pre><code>    // This was your first function. "CreateFlow"
    api.Handle("/createFlow/{id:[0-9]+}", handlers.AppHandler{
        context, CreateHandler(Handler{
            elastible:         &amp;Flow{},
            handlerActionName: "flow",
            handlerType:       "CREATE",
        }),
    }).Methods("GET")

    // This was your second function. "CreateProcess"
    api.Handle("/createProcess/{id:[0-9]+}", handlers.AppHandler{
        context, CreateHandler(Handler{
            elastible:         &amp;Process{},
            handlerActionName: "process",
            handlerType:       "CREATE",
        }),
    }).Methods("GET")

    // This was your third function. "GetFlow"
    api.Handle("/getFlow/{id:[0-9]+}", handlers.AppHandler{
        context, CreateHandler(Handler{
            elastible:         &amp;Flow{},
            handlerActionName: "flow",
            handlerType:       "GET",
        }),
    }).Methods("GET")

    // This was your fourth function. "GetProcess"
    api.Handle("/getProcess/{id:[0-9]+}", handlers.AppHandler{
        context, CreateHandler(Handler{
            elastible:         &amp;Process{},
            handlerActionName: "process",
            handlerType:       "GET",
        }),
    }).Methods("GET")
</code></pre>

<p><br />
Hope it helps!</p>
" OwnerUserId="7641174" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T18:12:35.647" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45849468      <row Id="45849468" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45849851" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45849468" CreationDate="2017-08-23T21:53:01.000" Score="0" Body="<p>Use something like this to capture groups, you may want to limit the characters accepted with [], note the use of ` and the use of \ escaping for () within the regexp:</p>

<pre><code>func main() {
    re := regexp.MustCompile(`(.+)\((.+),\s?(.+)\)`)
    for _, t := range tests {
        fmt.Println("result", re.FindStringSubmatch(t))
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/43YLTafgQt" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/43YLTafgQt</a></p>

<p>output: </p>

<pre><code>result [contains(field, value) contains field value]
result [contains(name, Joe) contains name Joe]
result [lt(quantity, 2.5) lt quantity 2.5]
result [plus(no,44) plus no 44]
</code></pre>

<p>Depending on how strict you want to be you could use [a-z]+ or similar instead of .+ to match only certain characters but if you are not worried about bogus values this would probably be fine. </p>
" OwnerUserId="1601137" LastActivityDate="2017-08-23T21:53:01.000" CommentCount="0" />

<row Id="45852529" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45852398" CreationDate="2017-08-24T03:36:42.400" Score="2" Body="<p>Object is part of S3, so I created struct as below and I was able to read key </p>

<pre><code>type Root struct {

type Record struct {

type SS3 struct {

type Object struct {

}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1768567" LastEditorUserId="251311" LastEditDate="2017-08-24T03:45:20.020" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T03:45:20.020" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45854441      <row Id="45854441" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45855074" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45854441" CreationDate="2017-08-24T07:06:29.943" Score="1" Body="<p>You can just use query parameters like in your question and handle any known fields as criteria to narrow your search.</p>

<p>The way you actually search these fields depends on where / how your data is stored- you didn't specify this in your question, so I don't know if you're going to query MongoDB, an SQL DB, a map in memory...</p>

<p>You can iterate over your query parameters as follows:</p>

<pre><code>http.HandleFunc("/news", func(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
  params := r.URL.Query()

  for field, values := range params {
      value := values[len(values)-1] // the last given value of this type
      // gradually build your query using field / value
  }
})
</code></pre>

<p>If you provide more information about how your data is stored, I can give you a more specific answer to help you build your query and retrieve the matching records.</p>
" OwnerUserId="4648046" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T07:06:29.943" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45855530      <row Id="45855530" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45855822" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45855530" CreationDate="2017-08-24T07:46:53.453" Score="1" Body="<p>The JSON package can only process exported struct fields (e.g. start with a capital letter). That's why you use the JSON tag so you can change the tag name/case to use. </p>

<p>Otherwise, this works as you would expect. See example:</p>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/pRVKNrekWe" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/pRVKNrekWe</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="8356442" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T07:46:53.453" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45856464      <row Id="45856464" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45856760" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45856464" CreationDate="2017-08-24T08:36:10.260" Score="3" Body="<p>The <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/regexp/#Regexp.FindAllStringSubmatch" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>func (*Regexp) FindAllStringSubmatch</code></a> extracts matches and <em>captured</em> submatches. </p>

<p>A submatch is a part of the text that is matched by the regex part that is enclosed with a pair of unescaped parentheses (a so called <a href="http://www.regular-expressions.info/brackets.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><strong>capturing group</strong></a>). </p>

<p>In your case, <code>^.*(mes).*$</code> matches:</p>

<ul>
<li><code>^</code> - start of string</li>
<li><code>.*</code> - any 0+ chars as many as possible</li>
<li><code>(mes)</code> - <strong>Capturing group 1</strong>: a <code>mes</code> substring</li>
<li><code>.*$</code>  - the rest of the string.</li>
</ul>

<p>So, the match value is the whole string. It will be the first value in the output. Then, since there is a capturing group, there must be a place for it in the results, hence, <code>mes</code> is placed as the second item in the list.</p>

<p>Since there may be more matches than 1, we need a list of lists.</p>

<p>A better example may be the one with several match / submatch extraction (and maybe an optional group, too):</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "fmt"
    "regexp"
)

func main() {
    someRegex, _ := regexp.Compile(`[^aouiye]([aouiye])([^aouiye])?`)
    matches := someRegex.FindAllStringSubmatch("somestri", -1)
    fmt.Printf("%q\n", matches)
}
</code></pre>

<p>The <code>[^aouiye]([aouiye])([^aouiye])?</code> matches a non-vowel, a vowel, and a non-vowel, capturing the last 2 into separate groups  #1 and #2.</p>

<p>The results are <code>[["som" "o" "m"] ["ri" "i" ""]]</code>. There are 2 matches, and each contains a match value, Group 1 value and Group 2 value. Since the <code>ri</code> match has no text captured into Group 2 (<code>([^aouiye])?</code>), it is empty, but it is still there since the group is defined in the regex pattern.</p>
" OwnerUserId="3832970" LastEditorUserId="3832970" LastEditDate="2017-08-24T08:43:39.377" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T08:43:39.377" CommentCount="0" />

Name: question, dtype: object

<row Id="45859629" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45859471" CreationDate="2017-08-24T10:49:02.163" Score="2" Body="<p>Here's a Playground solving your problem (Quick and Dirty, there may be better solutions out there, but this one works.): <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/7vTXLtaGNh" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/7vTXLtaGNh</a></p>

question:
45867532      <row Id="45867532" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45867582" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45867532" CreationDate="2017-08-24T17:21:02.800" Score="3" Body="<p>As soon as the main goroutine returns, the program exits. So you need to make sure to <em>not</em> return from <code>main</code> early. One way to do this is to execute the write-loop to the channel in the main goroutine:</p>

<pre><code>var mq chan string

func main() {
        mq = make(chan string)
        for i := 0; i &lt; 4; i++ {
                go dequeue()
        }
        for {
            mq &lt;- "ping" 
        }
}

func dequeue() {
        for m := range mq {
                fmt.Println(m)
        }
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="1080064" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T17:21:02.800" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45870518      <row Id="45870518" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45870654" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45870518" CreationDate="2017-08-24T20:50:45.260" Score="4" Body="<p>It does work if you define your method on a struct rather than a pointer: <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/zU4sbFe2RB" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/zU4sbFe2RB</a>.</p>

<p>If you can't do that in real code, I'm afraid you can't accomplish what you want. These two pointers will be different values, even if they point to similar data.</p>

<p>You can add an <code>Equals(Object) bool</code> method to the <code>Object</code> interface and roll out your own implementation of a map. Alternatively, you can define <code>Hash() string</code> method and use a <code>map[string]whatever</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1892060" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T20:50:45.260" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45870273      <row Id="45870273" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45870668" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45870273" CreationDate="2017-08-24T20:51:48.753" Score="0" Body="<p>Your <code>UnmarshalJSON</code> function calls itself recursively, which will cause the stack to explode in size.</p>

<pre><code>func (t *Tags) UnmarshalJSON(b []byte) (err error) {
    str := string(b)
    if str == "" {
        t = &amp;Tags{}
        return nil
    }

    err = json.Unmarshal(b, t) &lt;--- here it calls itself again
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }

    return nil
}
</code></pre>

<p>If you have a reason to call <code>json.Unmarshal</code> from within a <code>UnmarshalJSON</code> function, it must be on a different type.  A common way to do this is to use a local alias:</p>

<pre><code>    type tagsAlias Tags
    var ta = &amp;tagsAlias
    err = json.Unmarshal(b, ta)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }

    *t = Tags(ta)
</code></pre>

<p>Also note that <code>t = &amp;Tags{}</code> does nothing in your function; it assigns a new value to <code>t</code>, but that value is lost as soon as the function exits.  If you really want to assign to <code>t</code>, you need <code>*t</code>; but you also don't need that at all, unless you're trying to unsset a previously set instance of <code>*Tags</code>.</p>
" OwnerUserId="13860" LastActivityDate="2017-08-24T20:51:48.753" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45871203      <row Id="45871203" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45872636" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45871203" CreationDate="2017-08-25T00:10:26.467" Score="3" Body="<p>The runtime panics with the "all go routines are a sleep - deadlock error" error when all goroutines are blocked on channel and mutex operations.</p>

<p>The sleeping goroutine does not block on one of these operations. There is no deadlock and therefore no panic.</p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T00:10:26.467" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45872614      <row Id="45872614" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45872676" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45872614" CreationDate="2017-08-25T00:17:35.687" Score="4" Body="<p>You cannot reference the anonymous type of the <code>Data</code> field using a field selector. The fix is to declare a named type for the <code>Data</code> field:</p>

<pre><code>type GetRecipesPaginatedResponse struct {
    ...
    Data        []DataItem
    ...
}

type DataItem struct {
    ID               int       `json:"id"`
    ParentRecipeID   int       `json:"parent_recipe_id"`
    UserID           int       `json:"user_id"`
    Name             string    `json:"name"`
    ...
}
</code></pre>

<p>Use it like this:</p>

<pre><code>func insertIntoRecipes(db *sql.DB, exists bool, newRecipe DataItem) {
    ...
}
</code></pre>

<p>There's probably a better name for <code>DataItem</code>.  </p>
" OwnerUserId="5728991" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T00:17:35.687" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45874311      <row Id="45874311" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45874481" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45874311" CreationDate="2017-08-25T04:32:53.550" Score="2" Body="<p>You are passing the structures by value. This works fine so long as you are not modifying the structure, but if you do modify it you are actually only modifying a copy. To make this work you need to use <em>pointers</em> to the structures you need to modify.</p>

<p>Instead of:</p>

<pre><code>func (this MockConnector) sendCommand(payload map[string]string)
</code></pre>

<p>Use:</p>

<pre><code>func (this *MockConnector) sendCommand(payload map[string]string)
</code></pre>

<p>Also, it is considered a bad idea to use <code>this</code> (or <code>self</code>) as a receiver name in Go, as a receiver is not the same thing as a <code>this</code> pointer/reference in other languages.</p>

<p>Another best practice, is if one method for a given type needs a pointer receiver, all methods for that type should have pointer receivers. This is so that the method set remains consistent no matter if the value is a pointer or not.</p>

<p>See <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Method_sets" rel="nofollow noreferrer">method sets</a>, and <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#methods_on_values_or_pointers" rel="nofollow noreferrer">these</a> <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#different_method_sets" rel="nofollow noreferrer">FAQ</a> <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#pass_by_value" rel="nofollow noreferrer">answers</a> for more information.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1094529" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T04:32:53.550" CommentCount="3" />

question:
45861848      <row Id="45861848" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45876312" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45861848" CreationDate="2017-08-25T07:25:29.387" Score="1" Body="<p>First off, I would suggest reading this <a href="https://blog.golang.org/go-slices-usage-and-internals" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go blog post</a> to clarify the difference between <em>arrays</em> and <em>slices</em>.</p>

<p>Simply put:</p>

<ul>
<li><em>Arrays</em> are a numbered sequence of elements.</li>
<li><em>Slices</em> contains a pointer to an underlying array element, a length and a capacity.</li>
</ul>

<p>What you normally do with pointer arithmetic in languages like C, you do with slices in Go. Actually, you very seldom use arrays directly in Go.</p>

<p><strong>Slicing</strong></p>

<p>In your example, you can do the following:</p>

<pre><code>data := make([]byte, 10) // Create a slice with length of 10
row := data[3:]          // Slicing a new slice starting from index 3. Length is 6
row[0] = 42
fmt.Println(data[3])
</code></pre>

<p><strong>Output:</strong></p>

<blockquote>
  <p>42</p>
</blockquote>

<p>Using slicing, you pass different sections of an underlying array/slice to different Go routines to work on, without any races.</p>

<p>But if you instead want to have them work on the same slice, you can always protect it with a <a href="https://golang.org/pkg/sync/#Mutex" rel="nofollow noreferrer"><code>sync.Mutex</code></a> instead.</p>
" OwnerUserId="694331" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T07:25:29.387" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45875444      <row Id="45875444" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45877934" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45875444" CreationDate="2017-08-25T09:03:27.283" Score="0" Body="<p>The best way to do this is to use the builder pattern.
In the first image you download all the dependencies and build the executable.
In the second you copy the executable into a new image. You can use the scratch image as a base, but alpine is maybe better because it is also small but provides a shell and a packet manager for something like certificates for https.</p>

<p>If you first copy the sources and the install the dependencies, they will be downloaded with every source change, so it ist better to use something like go dep. With it you can copy the Gopkg file, install your dependencies and then copy the sources.</p>

<p>Official article <a href="https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/eng-image/multistage-build/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/eng-image/multistage-build/</a>
and in more detail
<a href="https://blog.alexellis.io/mutli-stage-docker-builds/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://blog.alexellis.io/mutli-stage-docker-builds/</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="6540936" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T09:03:27.283" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45877980      <row Id="45877980" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45878151" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45877980" CreationDate="2017-08-25T09:15:04.010" Score="2" Body="<p>The preferred way is the same as in any other cases.</p>

<p>Either use a mutex when the shared struct is read / updated:</p>

<pre><code>var shared = &amp;SharedStruct{}
var mux = &amp;sync.RWMutex{}

func someHandler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    mux.RLock()
    defer mux.RUnlock()
    t.ExecuteTemplate(w, "page.html", shared)
}

// Code that modifies shared:
mux.Lock()
shared.Counter++
mux.Unlock()
</code></pre>

<p>Or if the template execution takes long time, it may be protitable to make a copy of the <code>shared</code> struct and pass the copy when executing the template, so that during template execution access to <code>shared</code> is not blocked. Note that while making the copy you still have to use a mutex. Also if not only the pointers but the pointed values may change, you also have to make a copy of those:</p>

<pre><code>func someHandler(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request) {
    mux.RLock()
    shared2 := &amp;SharedStruct{}
    *shared2 = *shared
    shared2.Status_ = new(Status)
    *shared2.Status_ = *shared.Status_
    mux.RUnlock()

    t.ExecuteTemplate(w, "page.html", shared2)
}
</code></pre>

<p>If the template only uses a small subset of the <code>shared</code> fields, it is enough to make only a copy of those of course.</p>
" OwnerUserId="1705598" LastEditorUserId="1705598" LastEditDate="2017-08-25T09:23:54.773" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T09:23:54.773" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45871304      <row Id="45871304" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:

</code></pre>

question:
45880883      <row Id="45880883" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45881151" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45880883" CreationDate="2017-08-25T12:11:39.827" Score="1" Body="<p>You can "reset" a slice by setting it to nil. Also, you may not be aware that nil-slices work just fine with append:</p>

<pre><code>var sc []SubContainer
c := Container{}

for k, v := range commits {
    sc = append(sc, SubContainer{Key: k, Value: v})
    if len(sc) == 2 {
        c.Collection = append(c.Collection, sc...)
        sc = nil
    }
}
if len(sc) &gt; 0 {
    c.Collection = append(c.Collection, sc...)

}
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/ecj52fkwpO" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/ecj52fkwpO</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="603316" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T12:11:39.827" CommentCount="4" />

question:
45881894      <row Id="45881894" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45886114" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45881894" CreationDate="2017-08-25T16:48:11.980" Score="1" Body="<p>The issue is that the <code>balance()</code> goroutine eventually gets blocked in <code>dispatch()</code> on <code>w.requests &lt;- req</code> at the same time that specific <code>Worker</code> is blocking in <code>work()</code> on <code>done &lt;- w</code>, producing a deadlock for the goroutine running <code>balance()</code>.</p>

<p>Here is the fix you need. <code>balance()</code> needs to utilize goroutines internally. This will fix the issue because now it doesn't matter if the routine blocks in <code>dispatch()</code> or <code>completed()</code>, the main routine for <code>balance()</code> will continue <code>select</code>ing from the <code>channel</code>s.</p>

<p>NOTE: This does not work on the playground because it goes on forever.</p>

<pre><code>func (b *Balancer) balance(work chan Request) {
    for {
        select {
        case req := &lt;-work:
            go func() {
                b.dispatch(req)
                b.printStatus()
            }()
        case w := &lt;-b.done:
            go func() {
                b.completed(w)
                b.printStatus()
            }()
        }
    }
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now that <code>printStatus</code> calls can be done concurrently, it needs to make use of the <code>mutex</code> as well, or you will get random <code>panic</code>s.</p>

<pre><code>func (b *Balancer) printStatus() {
    b.mu.Lock()
    fmt.Fprintf(os.Stderr, "Status: %v %v %v %v %v %v\n", b.pool[0].pending, b.pool[1].pending, b.pool[2].pending, b.pool[3].pending, b.pool[4].pending, b.pool[5].pending)
    b.mu.Unlock()
}
</code></pre>

<p>Now if I could just figure out why the <code>pending</code> values just keep increasing... As far as I can tell, <code>Worker.work()</code> should only ever allow <code>pending</code> to be <code>0</code> or <code>1</code> because the <code>Worker</code> has to wait on <code>done &lt;- w</code> before it can get another <code>Request</code> from <code>dispatch()</code>. I believe this is the desired result though isn't it?</p>
" OwnerUserId="1276480" LastEditorUserId="1276480" LastEditDate="2017-08-25T17:55:19.523" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T17:55:19.523" CommentCount="2" />

question:
45889437      <row Id="45889437" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45889524" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45889437" CreationDate="2017-08-25T21:16:29.437" Score="1" Body="<p>No point in marshalling the <strong>body</strong> separately from the <code>HttpResp</code>. Instead change the <code>Body</code> field's type to <code>interface{}</code> and then set the field to any value of a concrete type as opposed to a json string, e.g. <code>[]Article</code> and then marshal the resp once.</p>

<pre><code>type HttpResp struct{
    Status      int         `json:"status"`
    Description string      `json:"description"`
    Body        interface{} `json:"body"`
}
</code></pre>

<p>And the rest...</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "net/http"
    "log"
)

type Article struct{
    Id          string  `json:"id"`
    Title       string  `json:"title"`
    Body        string  `json:"body"`
    Description string  `json:"description"`
}

func AllArticles(w http.ResponseWriter, r *http.Request){
    log.Print("/articles - GET")
    db := connect()
    defer db.Close()

    var articles []Article
    results, err := db.Query("SELECT * FROM Articles")

    if err != nil{
        log.Print(err)
        return
    }

    for results.Next(){
        var article Article
        err = results.Scan(&amp;article.Title, &amp;article.Description, &amp;article.Body, &amp;article.Id)

        if err != nil{
            serr, _ := json.Marshal(err)
            json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(HttpResp{Status: 500, Description: "Failed to retrieve all articles", Body: string(serr)})
        }

        articles = append(articles, article)
    }

    w.Header().Set("Content-Type", "application/json")
    json.NewEncoder(w).Encode(HttpResp{Status: 200, Body: articles})
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="965900" LastActivityDate="2017-08-25T21:16:29.437" CommentCount="1" />

question:
45890244      <row Id="45890244" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45890888" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45890244" CreationDate="2017-08-26T00:33:45.343" Score="1" Body="<p>The data stored in <code>val</code> is not null-terminated. In your C code, when you make a copy using <code>memcpy</code>, the null terminator is not included. In the C code, change the code to:</p>

<pre><code>// Generate memory for picture data
char* val = new char[len+1];
memcpy (val, apicBase64.data(), len);
val[len] = '\0';
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="6207052" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T00:33:45.343" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45891600      <row Id="45891600" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45891610" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45891600" CreationDate="2017-08-26T03:17:34.290" Score="4" Body="<p><a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#Conversions" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Convert</a> the value to a string:</p>

question:
45891799      <row Id="45891799" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45892056" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45891799" CreationDate="2017-08-26T04:52:58.577" Score="1" Body="<p>Not sure what you're trying to do with <code>lll</code> but without using it your code should not event compile.</p>

<hr>

<p>When <code>range</code>ing over slices/arrays with a <em>single iteration variable</em> on the left of <code>:=</code> it will be assigned the index of the iteration. So in your case <code>ccc</code> is the index.</p>

<p>One thing you can do is:</p>

<pre><code>for ccc := range connections {
    websocket.Message.Send(connections[ccc], "Another connection!!!")
}
</code></pre>

<p>But what you probably really want is, drop the index and get the element right away which you can do using two iteration variables with the <code>_</code> as the first one if you don't inted to use the index at all.</p>

<pre><code>for _, ccc := range connections {
    websocket.Message.Send(ccc, "Another connection!!!")
}
</code></pre>

<p>read more here: <a href="https://golang.org/ref/spec#For_range" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://golang.org/ref/spec#For_range</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="965900" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T04:52:58.577" CommentCount="0" />

question:

answer:
<row Id="45896783" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45896605" CreationDate="2017-08-26T15:06:45.840" Score="1" Body="<p>Go templates support js and css and the evaluation of <em>actions</em> (<code>{{ ... }}</code>) is contextual so you can iterate over schools in js the same as you do in html. Although I have no idea what smarty is, so if this isn't working you need to check smarty's documentation.</p>

<pre><code>events: [
    {{range $.Schools}}
    {
        title: {{.Course}},
        start: {{.Duration}}
    },
    {{end}}
]
</code></pre>

<p><a href="https://play.golang.org/p/LBDBAMY4cL" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://play.golang.org/p/LBDBAMY4cL</a></p>
" OwnerUserId="965900" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T15:06:45.840" CommentCount="9" />

question:
45897371      <row Id="45897371" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45897635" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45897371" CreationDate="2017-08-26T16:47:41.817" Score="0" Body="<p>@simon_xia is right and it looks like you <em>might</em> be a little new to Go.</p>

<p>First off, welcome to the community!!</p>

<p>Now to expand a bit on his comment... instead of providing public/private scope for a member/method, Go has the concept of <a href="https://tour.golang.org/basics/3" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Exporting</a>. So if you want to allow a method to be accessed from another package, just capitalize the method's signature :)</p>

<p>Most of the <em>basic</em> features of OOP are satisfied in some way by Go, but it's important to understand that <a href="https://golang.org/doc/faq#Is_Go_an_object-oriented_language" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go is not an object-oriented language</a>.</p>

<p>I'd <strong>highly recommend</strong> working your way through the entire <a href="https://tour.golang.org/list" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Tour of Go</a> since it hits this concept of Exporting as well as many, many other key features of the Go language. The entire tour can be finished in an afternoon and it did <strong>a lot</strong> to get me up to speed on the language a few years back.</p>

<p>If you're still hungry for more after that, I found <a href="https://gobyexample.com" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Go By Example</a> to be an awesome point of reference for a bit of a deeper study into some major topics.</p>
" OwnerUserId="8345637" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T16:47:41.817" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45896930      <row Id="45896930" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45897737" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45896930" CreationDate="2017-08-26T17:00:19.790" Score="1" Body="<p>You can unmarshall bottom half in json.RawMessage first, something like</p>

<pre><code>package main

import (
    "encoding/json"
    "fmt"
)

type Message struct {
    Code    int
    Payload json.RawMessage // delay parsing until we know the code
}
type Range struct {
    Start int
    End   int
}
type User struct {
    ID   int
    Pass int
}

func MyUnmarshall(m []byte) {
    var message Message
    var payload interface{}
    json.Unmarshal(m, &amp;message) // delay parsing until we know the color space
    switch message.Code {
    case 3:
        payload = new(User)
    case 4:
        payload = new(Range)
    }
    json.Unmarshal(message.Payload, payload) //err check ommited for readability
    fmt.Printf("\n%v%+v", message.Code, payload) //do something with data
}

func main() {
    json := []byte(`{"Code": 4, "Payload": {"Start": 1, "End": 10}}`)
    MyUnmarshall(json)
    json = []byte(`{"Code": 3, "Payload": {"ID": 1, "Pass": 1234}}`)
    MyUnmarshall(json)
}
</code></pre>
" OwnerUserId="4374109" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T17:00:19.790" CommentCount="1" />

<row Id="45900145" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45900081" CreationDate="2017-08-26T22:24:39.833" Score="1" Body="<p>Change line number two to </p>

<p><code>t := map[string]map[string]interface{}{"internal":internal_map}</code></p>

<p>Access it like this <code>t["internal"]["key_in_internal_map"]</code>.</p>

<p>This is essentially a map of maps. You can add as many embedded levels as you want.</p>

<p>Goplayground <a href="https://play.golang.org/p/0644j5qz1i" rel="nofollow noreferrer">example</a>.
Although I would recommend making nested structs to avoid map chaining.</p>
" OwnerUserId="7641174" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T22:24:39.833" CommentCount="0" />

question:
45899964      <row Id="45899964" PostTypeId="1" AcceptedAn...
Name: question, dtype: object
answer:
<row Id="45900290" PostTypeId="2" ParentId="45899964" CreationDate="2017-08-26T22:49:44.853" Score="1" Body="<p><code>DB.Where(&amp;Pokemon{Type: t}).Find(&amp;retData.Poke)</code> esentially returns back the <code>*db</code> pointer which you can use to chain further methods.
You're already deserializing postgre rows into your struct slice when you do <code>.Find(&amp;retData.Poke)</code>. Thus, <code>pokemon</code> isn't actually what you think it is. </p>

<p>The only thing left now is to chain <code>.Find()</code> with a <code>.Error()</code> so that you can return and check any error in your query. Just like this :</p>

<pre><code>for _, t := range pokemonTypes {
    err := DB.Where(&amp;Pokemon{Type: t}).Find(&amp;retData.Poke).Error()
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }
    p, _ := json.Marshal(retData.Poke)
    err = json.Unmarshal(p, &amp;retData.Poke) 
    if err != nil {
        fmt.Println(err)
        return
    }
    m[category] = retData.Poke
}
</code></pre>

<p>Hope it helps!</p>
" OwnerUserId="7641174" LastActivityDate="2017-08-26T22:49:44.853" CommentCount="1" />
